site_title: Facebook shares slip despite jump in earnings
summary: Facebook reported earnings that beat expectations, with profit increasing 20% to $4.26 billion and revenue rising 47% to $13 billion. However, shares fell 4% to $177.92 after the company outlined changes to curb time spent on the platform, including reducing viral videos and promoting meaningful real-world connections. The company aims to focus on "community" and address misinformation, with plans to deliver local news and ask users to rank their trust in news sources.

site_title: Uber planning expansion in Japan, Singapore amid talks of retreat
summary: Uber is planning an expansion in Japan and Singapore, despite speculation of a potential retreat from the Asian market. Head of Uber's business in the region, Brooks Entwistle, said the company is offering faster booking and cheaper rides to gain share in Singapore. Uber is also in talks with payments firms and taxi companies in Japan, aiming to strike partnerships similar to its tie-up with Vietnamese mobile wallet company MoMo. This move may create tension with SoftBank, a major shareholder, which has urged Uber to pull out of certain Asian markets.

images.alt_text: If Uber Technologies is planning a retreat from Asia, no one told Brooks Entwistle, head of the ride-hailing company's business in the region.

site_title: Global investor confidence up in January, led by Europe
summary: Global investor confidence rose in January, with Europe leading the way, according to the State Street Global Exchange's Global Investor Confidence Index. The index increased to 102.1, up 6.4 points from December, as investors showed an increased appetite for risk. Europe's index jumped 16.0 points to 113.4, while Asia's index rose 6.1 points to 100.8. The increase in confidence is attributed to the strong performance of global equities, which have seen the best start of a new year in three decades.

site_title: Malaysia: Stock market closed for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's stock market is closed on Wednesday and Thursday due to public holidays, with trading resuming on Friday.

site_title: Brexit haunts May as she seeks China trade post-EU
summary: Theresa May, UK Prime Minister, visited China to forge deeper trade ties despite Brexit criticism at home. She announced $16.6 billion in business deals and lifted a ban on British beef exports to China within six months. May and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to deepen their trading relationship, with both leaders championing a "golden era" of relations. May also sought to address concerns over human rights abuses in China, but had yet to make public statements on the matter.

site_title: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway, JPMorgan Chase join forces to tackle US health care
summary: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway, and JPMorgan Chase have formed a nonprofit healthcare plan to provide simplified, high-quality, and transparent healthcare to US employees and their families at a reasonable cost. The initiative aims to reduce healthcare costs, which have doubled since the 1980s to 18% of GDP, and improve outcomes for employees. The trio plans to invest collective resources to tackle the rising healthcare costs, with details of the plan yet to be disclosed.

site_title: BlackGold's largest shareholder halves stake as directors raise holdings
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources' largest shareholder, Sujono Hadi Sudarno, has sold 104 million shares, reducing his stake to 12.26% from 23.43%. CEO Philip Rickard acquired 27 million shares, increasing his stake to 4.4%, while independent chairman Intekhab Ahmad Khan bought 20 million shares, raising his stake to 6.14%. The shares were sold at a 71% premium to the company's closing price, with the stock trading at 9.9 Singapore cents.

site_title: Gold edges lower after Fed says it sees signs of inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, but signaled a possible rate hike in March to combat rising inflation. Gold prices edged down 0.07% due to expectations of higher interest rates, making it less attractive as a safe-haven asset. The Fed's statement also hinted at a possible 2-3 rate hikes in 2018, citing synchronized economic growth.

site_title: Julius Baer pushes ahead with hires, M&A under new CEO
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer plans to hire 80 relationship managers in 2018, aiming to drive growth through organic development and targeted M&A under new CEO Bernhard Hodler. The bank reported a 14% increase in net profit to 705 million francs in 2017 and will propose a dividend of 1.40 francs per share. Baer aims to increase business with existing clients and double down on existing markets, while also exploring acquisitions.

site_title: Singapore January total market cap up 2.1%
summary: The Singapore stock market saw a 2.1% increase in January, driven by gains in finance stocks and rising interest rates. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, reached new historical highs, with DBS up 6.2% and OCBC up 4.4%. Manufacturing stocks also benefited from strong factory output data and rising oil prices. However, the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% lower on Wednesday due to overseas sell-offs and dropping oil prices.

site_title: South-east Asia's top drugmaker eyes Sri Lanka, Mideast Expansion
summary: PT Kalbe Farma, Southeast Asia's largest pharmaceutical company, is seeking a partner in Sri Lanka and expanding to the Middle East. The company will initially export its products to Sri Lanka before manufacturing generic drugs with a local partner. Kalbe aims to broaden its reach beyond South-east Asia, focusing on developed countries like the US and Europe. The company expects 4-5% revenue and profit growth in 2018, driven by new products and expanded markets, despite regulatory challenges in the export segment.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AA Reit, Genting HK, AEM Holdings, mm2 Asia, OUE C-Reit
summary: Aims AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported a distribution per unit of 2.62 Singapore cents for its third quarter 2018, down 5.4% from the previous quarter. Genting Hong Kong warned of another net loss for the year, with an expected consolidated net loss of US$240-270 million. AEM Holdings acquired Afore for 7.58 million euros, and mm2 Asia approved the spin-off of Vividthree Productions. OUE Commercial Reit's distribution per unit dipped to 1.14 Singapore cents due to an absence of performance fees and higher income support.

site_title: Japan's ANA to expand budget aviation business, Q3 profit shines
summary: ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's largest airline by revenue, plans to expand its budget aviation business in the medium-haul segment due to robust travel demand in Asia. The carrier aims for 2.45 trillion yen in revenue by 2022, up 27% from the current fiscal year, and expects 50% growth in its core international service. ANA's operating profit jumped 25% in the third quarter to 50.9 billion yen, maintaining its forecast of 160 billion yen for the year to March. This expansion is driven by the success of its lower-cost carriers business, including Vanilla Air and Peach Aviation.

images.alt_text: ANA Holdings Inc, Japan's biggest airline by revenue, said on Thursday it plans to expand its lower-cost carriers business in the medium-haul segment due to robust travel demand in Asia, after it notched a strong third quarter performance.

site_title: H&M falls 8% to lowest since December 2008
summary: H&M's stock plummeted 8% to its lowest level since December 2008, amid a sales slump. The fashion retailer's like-for-like revenue is expected to drop by a "mid-single digit" percentage, following a 1% increase in December and January sales. This marks the biggest drop in quarterly sales in at least a decade, with CEO Karl-Johan Persson stating the first quarter started weaker than expected.

site_title: Australia toughens foreign investment rules amid China concerns
summary: Australia has introduced tougher restrictions on foreign investment in agricultural land and electricity infrastructure amid concerns over Chinese influence. Foreign buyers of land worth over A$15 million must now demonstrate it has been widely marketed to locals for a month. New restrictions on electricity infrastructure include assessing the "cumulative level of ownership within a sector" to ensure national security. The move comes after Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's reforms to espionage and foreign interference legislation, citing "disturbing reports" about China's influence, and as the country's spy agency warned of a greater foreign espionage threat.

site_title: Sinostar extends long stop date of Dongming Qianhai acqusition to Apr 30
summary: Sinostar Pec Holdings Limited has extended the long stop date of its proposed acquisition of Dongming Qianhai Petrochemical to April 30, 2018, due to the company needing additional time to complete a trial run for production capacity and design requirements.

site_title: Cadbury and Oreo maker Mondelez opens global innovation hub in Jurong, its first in Asia
summary: Mondelez International, the world's No 2 confectionary company, has opened its first global innovation hub in Jurong, Singapore, as part of its US$65 million investment in research and development centers worldwide. The Singapore Technical Center (STC) will focus on innovation and product development for iconic brands like Cadbury and Oreo. The hub aims to improve speed, efficiency, and effectiveness in meeting consumer needs, with increased scale enabling quicker responses to changing market demands.

site_title: New e-waste disposal rules to come for electronic goods producers and possibly retailers in Singapore
summary: Singapore will implement Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) rules, requiring electronic goods producers and possibly retailers to collect and recycle products sold. The government will set collection targets, with non-compliance attracting fines. A transition period will be given for companies to adapt, with Minister Masagos Zulkifli announcing the move during a public consultation session.

site_title: City Harvest case: Apex Court dismisses bid for longer sentences for Kong Hee, former church leaders
summary: The Singaporean Court of Appeal dismissed a bid by prosecutors to reinstate longer sentences for Kong Hee and five former City Harvest Church leaders, ending a marathon case involving the misuse of millions in church funds. The original convictions were reduced, and the defendants will continue serving their existing jail terms of 1½ to 3½ years. The decision has wider implications for future misappropriation cases, with Judge Andrew Phang stating that any gaps in the law should be left to Parliament to shape the remedy.

images.alt_text: The Court of Appeal will be handing down its verdict on the City Harvest Church case, involving (clockwise, from top left) Kong Hee, Tan Ye Peng, Serina Wee, John Lam, Chew Eng Han and Sharon Tan.

site_title: Temasek unit mulls over UOB's stake in Marco Polo Marine
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, is considering acquiring stakes in listed groups Marco Polo Marine and Ezion Holdings. Heliconia Capital, a Temasek-funded firm, is eyeing UOB Bank's 10.29% stake in Marco Polo, while Temasek is reviewing capital injection into liftboat-focused Ezion Holdings. The discussions are reportedly on hold for now.

site_title: China factory PMI falls to 8-month low of 51.3 after debt clean-up
summary: China's factory PMI fell to an 8-month low of 51.3 in January, missing estimates, due to a financial clean-up moderating output at home and a stronger yuan trimming export demand. The non-manufacturing PMI rose to 55.3, its highest since September, while a new composite index stood at 54.6. Economists warn that policies to purge pollution and excessive borrowing may weigh on growth, while heightened trade tensions with the US could further impact the economy.

site_title: Taiwan appoints deputy Yang Chin-Long as new central bank governor
summary: Taiwan's central bank has appointed Deputy Governor Yang Chin-Long as the new governor, succeeding Perng Fai-nan, who is one of the world's longest-serving central bank governors. Yang, 64, has been a top lieutenant to Perng since joining the central bank in 1989, and his appointment signals a continuation of monetary policy stability.

site_title: SIC: Hyflux's Lum must make offer for HyfluxShop following dividend in specie
summary: Hyflux's controlling shareholder Olivia Lum must make a general offer for HyfluxShop following a dividend in specie distribution. The offer price is 17.83 Singapore cents per share, matching a previous partial offer. The distribution involves distributing 70% of HyfluxShop shares to existing shareholders for free, with Hyflux retaining 30%. This move is part of plans to list HyfluxShop.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index advancing to 3,539.6 points, driven by Wall Street's modest gain overnight. Despite concerns over US monetary policy, the market remained optimistic about economic data. The most actively traded counters included BlackGold Natural Resources, up 6.3%, and UOB, up 0.47%. The field was evenly matched, with 70 gainers to 69 losers, as 79.1 million shares worth S$127.3 million changed hands.

site_title: Bank lending closes flat in December
summary: Bank lending in Singapore closed flat in December, with loans standing at S$652 billion, unchanged from the previous month. This reflects a contraction in lending in key business segments such as finance, construction, and trade. The result is in line with expectations, following a similar trend in previous months.

site_title: Why brands matter more than ever
summary: Dollar Shave Club's success demonstrates the importance of brands in a crowded market. By focusing on convenience and value, the company created a compelling story that resonated with customers, ultimately leading to $1 billion in sales and acquisition by Unilever. In contrast, plain packaging, which removes branding, can hinder consumers' ability to distinguish between products, undermining their ability to make informed choices and potentially leading to decreased innovation and investment in product improvement. Strong brands are crucial for companies to succeed in a market with numerous competitors, and their value is evident in Dollar Shave Club's story.

site_title: Swiss Re launches Asia-Pacific HQ in Singapore
summary: Swiss Re has launched its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, signaling its commitment to the region. The company has established a regional board of directors, led by Lim Siong Guan, to tap into growth opportunities in health, natural catastrophe, and cyber risks. Asia accounts for about a quarter of Swiss Re's group revenues, and the company sees a "huge protection gap" in the region, presenting opportunities to introduce new insurance models. The board includes external directors from the Bank of Japan and GIC, as well as Swiss Re executives.

site_title: First high-rise hub for metal, machinery and timber SMEs in 2020
summary: Singapore's JTC, Singapore Cranes Association, and Singapore Timber Association announce an agreement to provide shared services and special infrastructure at TimMac@Kranji, a high-rise development for metal, machinery, and timber SMEs. The 134,620 sq m facility, set for completion in 2020, features ceilings up to 12 meters and will accommodate heavy automation machinery. The development aims to improve operational efficiency by allowing companies to consolidate multiple sites into a single location, and the government will partner with MMT companies to raise productivity and remain competitive.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Transit-Mixed Concrete CEO Chua Eng Him, 68, died after an undisclosed illness. His duties will be covered by a senior management team until a replacement is found. Singapore Life marked its 100th day of retail operations with S$250 million in life insurance coverage. Atlantic Navigation is in talks with Gulf Navigation Holding for a potential sale of a substantial equity stake.

site_title: Noble refutes Goldilocks claims, says management is essential to business
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, has refuted claims by Goldilocks Investment Company that the company's management is enriching itself at the expense of shareholders. Noble stated that its management is essential to the company's business and will retain a 10% stake in the restructured entity. The company's restructuring plan proposes to halve its debts of US$3.5 billion by asking creditors to take on equity and new debt instruments. Goldilocks has accused Noble of market manipulation and minority oppression, which the company denies, and has requested an investigation by Singapore regulators.

site_title: Federal Reserve leaves rates unchanged, sees inflation rising this year
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained interest rates unchanged, citing solid economic gains in employment, household spending, and capital investment. The Fed expects the economy to expand at a moderate pace and inflation to rise this year, potentially reaching 2% over the medium term. This decision comes ahead of Jerome Powell's appointment as the new central bank chief.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged on Wednesday but said inflation likely would rise this year, bolstering expectations borrowing costs will continue to climb under incoming central bank chief Jerome Powell.

site_title: Frasers Property to ride global platforms for growth
summary: Frasers Property, formerly Frasers Centrepoint Limited, has rebranded after a name change approved by shareholders, reflecting the company's diversified portfolio across asset classes and geographies. The group, which has more than doubled its assets, revenue, and profit over the past five years, now operates under the Frasers Property brand globally. CEO Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi notes that the name change marks a shift towards a more global presence, with a focus on building platforms for future growth. The company has made significant acquisitions in Europe, the UK, and Thailand, and is expanding its logistics and industrial assets portfolio.

site_title: India's once red-hot property market now struggling
summary: India's property market is struggling due to the collapse of major developers, including Unitech, Jaypee Infratech, and Amrapali Group. Homebuyers, who paid millions in deposits for unfinished projects, are fighting to recover their investments. The industry's troubles have significantly impacted the economy, with real estate and construction accounting for a substantial portion of GDP and major sources of employment. The government has introduced new regulations to protect homebuyers, but the outlook remains bleak, with prices dropping 3-15% across top cities and a recovery unlikely until 2019.

images.alt_text: Homes under construction at an Amrapali Group development in Noida, Uttar Pradesh. Several real estate developers have been dragged to court by irate homeowners who shelled out payments for apartments that have yet to be completed.

site_title: MAS, EDB appoint new directors
summary: MAS appoints Attorney-General Lucien Wong as a director, effective Feb 1, 2018, for a term until May 31, 2020. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Economic Development Board also made changes to their boards, with new members appointed and several stepping down. EDB's new board includes Alexander Hungate, Suranjan Magesvaran, Wouter Van Wersch, and Gan Seow Kee.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up soon after open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday morning, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.24% to 32,964.62, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.06% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.21%. This trend was in line with broader Asian gains despite US trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: HK raises sails to flag maritime heritage
summary: Hong Kong showcased its maritime heritage as it hosted the Volvo Ocean Race for the first time in its 44-year history, drawing excitement among local enthusiasts. The event highlighted the city's nautical pedigree, which has contributed to its prosperity through its busy ports. Although Hong Kong is not well-known as a sailing nation, the race is seen as an opportunity to boost its sailing credentials and diversify its tourist appeal. The event is part of the city's efforts to rebrand itself beyond its shopping appeal, with the government seeking to promote its cultural and heritage aspects.

site_title: Lenovo to miss mobile turnaround target, posts Q3 net loss
summary: Lenovo reported a quarterly loss of $289 million due to a one-off charge linked to US tax reforms. The company's mobile business, which accounts for 16% of revenue, is struggling with higher component prices and fierce competition. Lenovo's core PC and smart device business saw an 8% revenue rise, but the company missed its target to turnaround its mobile business by March. The company plans to open 1,000 new retail shops in China and launch more high-end products.

images.alt_text: Personal computer maker Lenovo Group said it would miss a target to turnaround its mobile business by March, after earlier posting a quarterly loss due to a one-off charge linked to tax reforms in the United States.

site_title: Samsung Electronics posts record Q4 and full-year profits
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 73% jump in its Q4 net profit, setting a record, driven by demand for memory chips and display panels. The company's full-year net profit was also a record at 42.19 trillion won, up 85.6% on 2016. Despite past challenges, Samsung's financial performance has strengthened, with its shares more than doubling in the past two years. The company announced a 50-for-1 stock split, sending shares up 6.4%, and plans to bolster returns to shareholders with larger dividends and buybacks.

site_title: Australia shares end higher, led by financials and materials; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% on Thursday, led by financials and materials, to reach a 6-month high. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed to 6,090.1 points, boosted by strong gains in mining stocks and a robust expansion in Australian manufacturing. Materials stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, surged 1.5% and 1.1%, respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.7%.

site_title: AA Reit's Q3 DPU drops 5.4%
summary: AA Reit's third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) dropped 5.4% to 2.62 Singapore cents, down from 2.77 cents in the same period last year. The Reit's gross revenue fell 4.9% to S$28.9 million, mainly due to lower rental income and recoveries from 20 Gul Way. Despite this, the Reit's manager remains focused on active asset management and unlocking organic value through asset enhancements and redevelopments. The Reit will continue to prudently manage capital and diversify its portfolio across 27 industrial properties.

site_title: In another reversal, SIA cancels auto-inclusion of travel insurance
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has removed an online booking feature that automatically includes travel insurance, following customer complaints. The airline had previously automatically include insurance in bookings, but now requires customers to opt-in. This change comes after complaints about customers being charged for insurance without realizing it, and after SIA made a similar reversal regarding a credit card fee earlier this month. SIA encourages customers to take up travel insurance but now gives them the option to decline it.

site_title: US pork demand strong, but trade disputes could hit exports
summary: US pork demand remains strong due to a strong US economy and upcoming spring grilling season, but trade disputes with China, Mexico, and Canada could hurt exports. The US Meat Export Federation reported a record 2.23 million tonnes of pork exports worth US$5.9 billion in 2017. However, trade tensions with China and slow progress in Nafta talks have raised concerns, with US pork producers worried about possible retribution from China and the potential loss of a significant market.

site_title: Beijing urging crackdown on M&A loans used to buy land: sources
summary: China's banking regulator has urged lenders in Shanghai to increase scrutiny of M&A loans to prevent funds from being used to buy land. The directive aims to curb risks in the $38 trillion banking industry and reduce money flowing into the real estate sector. Banks are prohibited from providing loans for land projects without permission or payment of land-acquisition fees. The move follows earlier restrictions on real estate lending and comes as Chinese developers spent a record $134.6 billion on buying competitors last year.

site_title: SGX launches public consultation on changes to MOG listing rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a public consultation on proposed changes to its listing rules for mineral, oil and gas (MOG) companies. The aim is to align the rules with industry developments and strengthen listing profiles. Proposed changes include requiring companies to establish reserves, inferred resources, and contingent resources, as well as demonstrating plans to obtain necessary approvals. The SGX also plans to introduce a simpler Qualified Person's Report, making reports more readable for investors. The public has until February 28 to submit feedback on the proposed changes.

site_title: Trump's State of Union address scores one round for the 'normalisers'
summary: Donald Trump's State of the Union address has been met with mixed reactions from those hoping for his premature exit. The "normalisers" see the speech as a step towards Trump aligning his agenda with the establishment, suggesting he will learn the ropes of governing and potentially win re-election in 2020. However, those seeking his exit are not ready to make deals with the White House, indicating a potential divide within the Republican Party. The outcome remains uncertain, leaving Trump's future in the presidency still shrouded in uncertainty.

site_title: Oil rebounds, ends up on petrol demand, Opec compliance
summary: Oil prices rebounded, ending higher on Wednesday, after the US Energy Department reported a rise in oil inventories for the first time in nearly three months. Despite this, strong demand for gasoline and distillate products, as well as Opec countries' continued supply cuts, drove the increase. Crude oil futures gained 7.7% in January, the best month since September. Opec countries maintained heavy supply cuts in January, according to a Reuters survey, supporting the price rebound.

site_title: STI falls again as cautious mood reigns
summary: The Singapore stock market fell 0.4% on January 31, 2018, closing at 3,533.99, following a sharp sell-off in US stocks ahead of a key Federal Reserve policy decision. Despite the decline, the bourse is still up nearly 4% for the month. Technical chartists expect further consolidation, but a "bullish bias" is expected above 3,470. The losses were attributed to rising Treasury yields and improving US data, which may prompt the Fed to hike interest rates.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China's 2015 GDP puffed up by fake economic data: Bloomberg Economics
summary: China's 2015 GDP was likely overstated by 2% due to fake data, according to Bloomberg Economics research. The exaggeration occurred from 2011 to 2015, where provincial GDP numbers were inflated by consistently overstating energy consumption data. However, this method of inflation was closed off in 2016. The overstated national GDP number for 2015 may also have occurred, potentially affecting China's economic growth rate and policy decisions. The findings raise concerns about the accuracy of China's economic data and the implications for policymakers.

site_title: Eleven people killed in fire at Japanese seniors welfare facility: NHK
summary: A fire at a Japanese seniors welfare facility in Sapporo killed 11 people, with five rescued. The 16 elderly residents paid a monthly rent of 36,000 yen. Three survivors are being treated in hospital with non-life-threatening conditions. The cause of the fire is not specified.

images.alt_text: Eleven people were killed and five were rescued in a fire at a facility to support senior people on welfare in northern Japan late on Wednesday, public broadcaster NHK said.

site_title: Australian dollar off after soft data, hawkish Fed; NZ$ down
summary: The Australian dollar fell 0.2% to US$0.8040, its fourth consecutive decline, after weaker-than-expected economic data and the US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hikes. The Aussie's decline follows a 3% surge in January, led by commodity prices. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar dropped 1.4% to US$0.7360, its first weekly loss in seven sessions. The contrasting policy stances between the RBA and the US Fed have widened the interest rate gap, with analysts expecting the antipodean currencies to continue to appreciate.

site_title: White House seeking to slash renewable energy research: report
summary: The Trump administration plans to ask Congress to cut funding for clean energy and energy efficiency programs by 72% in the 2018 budget, according to a report. The proposed cuts would reduce the Energy Department's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy funding from $2.04 billion to $575.5 million. This move aligns with the administration's focus on prioritizing fossil fuels and their export, particularly the coal sector. The proposal is seen as a significant setback for renewable energy research and development.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration will ask US Congress to cut funding for clean energy and energy efficiency programs by 72 per cent in this year's budget, according to a report in the Washington Post, underscoring its preference for fossil fuels.

site_title: Nintendo to produce Super Mario animation film with Illumination
summary: Nintendo plans to produce an animated film featuring its Super Mario Bros characters with Illumination Entertainment, a US film studio. The film will be distributed by Universal Pictures and marks Nintendo's efforts to diversify revenue sources. The launch date has not been decided. This move aims to reduce Nintendo's reliance on gaming console business and explore new revenue streams.

images.alt_text: Japanese videogames maker Nintendo Co said on Thursday it would team with US film studio Illumination Entertainment to produce an animation film using its Super Mario Bros characters.

site_title: Temasek Foundation Ecosperity makes call for sustainable, innovative solutions to improve liveability
summary: Temasek Foundation Ecosperity has announced its third call for proposals for sustainable, innovative solutions to improve liveability. The call focuses on 10 focal areas, including air, biodiversity, and waste management. Applicants are encouraged to collaborate with industry partners to scale up and commercialize their technologies. The goal is to develop sustainable solutions that can be operationalized and eventually commercialized.

site_title: Genting HK flags narrower loss of up to US$270m for FY17
summary: Genting Hong Kong reported a narrower net loss of up to $270 million for FY17, compared to a year-ago loss of $537 million. The company attributes the improvement to a one-off gain of $205 million from the sale of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings and the absence of an impairment on NCLH shares in 2016. Start-up losses in the Dream Cruises brand and repositioning of Genting Dream to Singapore also impacted the results. The audited consolidated results are expected to be announced in March 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps six-day losing streak
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index snapped a six-day losing streak, gaining 1.68% to close at 23,486.11. The stable yen and modest gains on Wall Street, with investor focus shifting to corporate earnings announcements, supported the rally. The broader Topix index also rose 1.84%. The US dollar strengthened against the yen, reaching 109.47 yen in Asian afternoon trade.

site_title: Seaplane crash that killed Compass CEO still a mystery
summary: A seaplane crash in Australia on New Year's Eve 2018 killed Compass CEO Richard Cousins and five others. The cause remains a mystery, with no evidence of an object or collision before the crash. The aircraft took a sudden turn before plummeting into the Hawkesbury River, with witnesses reporting a normal-sounding engine. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau is investigating, with a preliminary report released. The pilot and occupants received fatal injuries, and the wreckage was recovered on January 4. An initial examination found no signs of a bird strike or collision.

site_title: Japan messaging service Line posts surprise loss amid higher outlays for new businesses
summary: Japan's messaging service Line Corp reported a surprise loss of 4 billion yen (S$48 million) for the fourth quarter, citing upfront costs for AI speakers, game marketing, and venture investments. The shares declined 5.6% as Line invests in new businesses, including financial services like cryptocurrency trading and loans. The company aims to transform into an all-in-one communications and entertainment service over the next five years, with plans to expand into financial services to reduce reliance on advertising revenue.

site_title: Facebook bans all ads for cryptocurrencies in bid to fight fraud
summary: Facebook bans all ads for cryptocurrencies, including initial coin offerings (ICO) and binary options, to combat scams and deceptive practices. The move follows a US Securities and Exchange Commission shutdown of a Texas-based ICO. The ban aims to prevent misleading advertising and protect users from scams, with the possibility of revising the policy as detection signals improve.

site_title: Apple challenged to show iPhone star shines
summary: Apple faces challenges in sustaining growth as investors watch for the impact of its newest iPhone X on quarterly results. Despite concerns about sales, data suggests the iPhone X performed well in key regions. Analysts warn that the smartphone market may be maturing, and Apple needs to consider future innovations beyond smartphones. The company's cash hoard is also being tapped, with potential plans to invest in research, acquisitions, or services, including a possible Netflix buyout.

images.alt_text: With Apple set to report quarterly results on Thursday investors and others are cautiously watching to see whether its newest iPhone will help fuel momentum for the world's most valuable company.

site_title: Microsoft reports loss due to tax charge
summary: Microsoft reported a $6.3 billion loss in its fiscal second quarter due to a $13.8 billion tax charge, mainly related to repatriating overseas cash holdings following the US tax overhaul. Despite the loss, revenue rose 12% to $28.9 billion, driven by gains in business services and cloud computing. The company's CEO, Satya Nadella, attributed the results to Microsoft's focus on the internet cloud, artificial intelligence, and services for connected devices. Microsoft shares rose 2.45% in after-hours trade.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: City Developments (CDL) secured the top bids for two government land sales sites in Singapore, including a S$212.2 million plot in Handy Road and a S$472.4 million parcel in West Coast Vale. CDL's breakeven point is estimated near S$2,250 psf, suggesting launch prices of around S$2,500 psf with an 11% profit margin.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up, won down on foreign selling and upbeat Fed
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 2.08 points or 0.08% to 2,568.54, while the won slumped 0.37% to 1,071.9 per US dollar on the local platform. The currency was pressured by foreign selling of stocks and a stronger US dollar due to the Federal Reserve's upbeat stance.

site_title: Sector convergence, overlaps focus of next transformation phase: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for sector convergence in the next phase of industry transformation efforts. He cautioned against vertical silos and instead encouraged the convergence of sectors, citing examples such as fintech and retail-real estate overlaps. Heng defended the Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs), highlighting their benefits, including the sharing of high-tech facilities and collective internationalization efforts. He called for collaboration among businesses, government, and research institutes to achieve more.

site_title: Bitcoin's big wipeout erases US$44b of value in January
summary: Bitcoin experienced its largest one-month loss in dollar terms, erasing $44.2 billion from its market value in January, bringing its total loss for the year to $44.2 billion. The slide, attributed to negative news and regulatory scrutiny, has pushed the cryptocurrency down to the $5,000-$6,000 range, with experts predicting a bumpy recovery to $10,000-$15,000. The loss comes after a record $500 million heist at Japanese exchange Coincheck and amid growing concerns over the industry's business practices.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia in Winter Olympics feat
summary: A Singaporean speed skater and a figure skater and skier from Malaysia will participate in the Winter Olympics, marking a significant milestone for winter sports in the region. The athletes, who have faced challenges such as limited facilities and public skepticism, have persevered to pursue their dreams. Malaysian figure skater Julian Yee and Singaporean speed skater Cheyenne Goh will represent their countries in the Games, with Yee having won gold at the SEA Games and Goh having represented Singapore at the Asian Winter Games. Their participation aims to inspire more people from the region to take up winter sports.

site_title: IBF to help financial industry professionals with career advice and job placement
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) in Singapore has expanded its mandate to provide career advisory and job placement services for the financial sector. The IBF will establish a dedicated Career Centre by July, offering services including competency standards, skills development, and job matching. The centre will also provide professional conversion programs to reskill professionals affected by changes in their job roles. Additionally, professionals from other sectors can seek placement in the financial sector. This move aims to support the financial industry professionals in adapting to transformation in their job roles.

site_title: Hybrid car sales propel surge in European alternative-fuel autos
summary: European alternative-fuel auto sales surged 39% in 2017, with 953,355 units sold, driven by Toyota's hybrid models and Renault's extended electric Zoe range. Demand for hybrid cars and all-electric models rose 52% and 49%, respectively, outpacing the European car market's 3.3% gain. Despite accounting for only 6.1% of total sales, alternative systems saw a significant increase, driven by consumer interest in environmentally friendly options to meet EU carbon-dioxide emission regulations.

site_title: Ailing H&M's CEO plans store closures, markdowns, new format in revamp
summary: H&M's CEO Karl-Johan Persson is revamping the company with store closures, markdowns, and a new format called Afound to sell marked-down merchandise. The company plans to shut 170 stores this year and invest in online sales and technologies. H&M shares rose 2.7% after the announcement, despite reporting a 14% drop in operating profit to 20.6 billion kronor (S$3.4 billion) in the past year. The company will also open 390 new stores, including formats other than H&M, to adapt to the industry's digital shift.

site_title: Global funds cut stocks on fears that rise in inflation will trigger a sell-off
summary: Global investors reduced their equity holdings by 1.2 percentage points in January due to concerns about rising inflation and market complacency. A poll of 50 wealth managers found that investors cut their equity allocation to 50.1% from 51.3% in December. This comes as markets have rallied hard in 2017, with a sell-off in January's MSCI world equity index, and investors fear that inflation could trigger a sell-off in both equities and bonds.

site_title: AirAsia India's international services to take off in Q1 2019 with regional flights
summary: AirAsia India plans to launch international flights by the first quarter of 2019, starting with regional flights, as part of its expansion into the international market. The airline, backed by Tata, will have 21 aircraft by the end of 2018 and will focus on flights within a four to five-hour radius initially. A listing for AirAsia India is also possible, with its CEO indicating the decision will be made by shareholders and the board of directors at an appropriate time.

site_title: China to Japan: Work harder if you want to be my friend
summary: Japan's foreign minister, Taro Kono, met with China's Wang Yi over the weekend, marking a step towards improving relations between the two countries. The talks came after Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed interest in cooperation on infrastructure projects, including the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. However, the Chinese showed a lack of enthusiasm, indicating that progress in improving relations remains limited. This marks a tangible sign of progress since China halted normal relations with Japan in 2012 over disputed islands.

site_title: The art of ordering room service
summary: Executive chef Martyn Nail of Claridge's hotel in London shares his tips for ordering room service. He recommends requesting meals in courses for a fresher taste and more leisurely experience. Soups tend to stay hot, while club sandwiches and Caesar salads travel well. Regional dishes are a good option, and asking for a sommelier can help with wine and cocktail recommendations. Giving advance notice and speaking to a real person, such as an order taker or sommelier, can ensure a good result.

site_title: Waymo's self-driving tests in California have fewest human interventions
summary: Waymo's self-driving tests in California have shown the fewest human interventions, with an average of 9km without disengagement. The company's vehicles logged 567.3km with only 63 disengagements, outperforming rivals Cruise and Nissan, which had averages of 1,953km and 8km, respectively. This metric measures the reliability of self-driving systems, with regulators considering a decade or more before autonomous vehicles are introduced in large numbers. Waymo's performance suggests it is ahead of competitors in autonomous driving performance.

site_title: Katong Park Towers put up for en bloc sale with S$288m reserve price
summary: Katong Park Towers, a 99-year leasehold residential site in Singapore, has been put up for en bloc sale with a reserve price of S$288 million (about S$1,165 per square foot per plot ratio). The site, located near the future Katong Park MRT Station, can potentially yield 388 apartment units. The tender will close on March 15, offering a compelling opportunity for an exclusive condominium in an affluent neighbourhood.

images.alt_text: Located at 114A Arthur Road, Katong Park Towers sits on a 99-year leasehold residential site with a land area of 13,076.9 sq m.

site_title: Like Pfizer, Roche sees US tax cut boosting 2018 profit
summary: Roche, a Basel, Switzerland-based company, expects its 2018 profit to increase due to US tax cuts, despite its most significant transformation in decades. Core earnings per share are expected to grow in the high single digits, driven by new medicines in cancer and other areas, offsetting slower sales growth. The company faces competition from biosimilar copies of its top-selling medicines, including Rituxan, which is expected to hit the US market in the second half.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session flat; STI at 3,533.97
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading flat on Thursday afternoon with the Straits Times Index at 3,533.97, down 0.02 point. About 1.40 billion shares worth S$757.1 million changed hands, with losers beating gainers 177 to 173. Notable movers included Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments falling 25% and Hoe Leong Corporation surging 20%. The index was down marginally from its pre-midday break level of 3,534.

site_title: GIC joins Blackstone-led group that's buying US$11b stake in Thomson Reuters unit
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has joined a Blackstone-led consortium that is buying a majority stake in Thomson Reuters' Financial and Risk (F&R) business for $11 billion. The Blackstone-led group will own 55% of the F&R business, while Thomson Reuters retains a 45% stake. The deal, valued at $20 billion, is expected to close in the second half of 2018 and will see the new entity enter into a 30-year contract to distribute Reuters News.

site_title: China rebuffs Taiwan's objection to flight paths
summary: China has rejected Taiwan's concerns over new flight paths in the Taiwan Strait, citing the space separating the routes as exceeding international standards. China opened several new air routes, including a northbound route through the sensitive waterway, which divides China from the island. The move is part of a deepening row between the two sides, with Taiwan objecting to the increased air traffic. Beijing's decision is seen as a challenge to Taiwan's sovereignty and territorial claims.

site_title: Twitter followers vanish amid inquiries into fake accounts
summary: Dozens of prominent Twitter users have lost over a million followers amid scrutiny of fake accounts and companies selling them. Twitter faces criticism for allowing the proliferation of fake accounts, with investigations underway into firms like Devumi, which sold fake followers and engagement. The company has yet to comment on purging fake accounts, as lawmakers and law enforcement officials in multiple states, including the US, launch inquiries into Devumi's business practices. Several high-profile users, including celebrities and business figures, have lost substantial numbers of followers, sparking debate about the prevalence of fraud on social media.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up as dollar holds gains after Fed
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on February 1, driven by the dollar's gains after the Federal Reserve indicated it may speed up interest rate hikes this year. The Fed's comments also showed economic growth, investment, and unemployment are on the right track. Tokyo rose over 1%, while Hong Kong and Sydney added 0.1% and 0.7% respectively. However, Shanghai fell 0.3% as regional stocks have mostly fallen this week on profit-taking following a strong January. The dollar's rise is expected to continue as US borrowing costs may rise further.

site_title: Euro consolidates gains after inflation quickens
summary: The euro strengthened by half a percent on Wednesday, nearing its biggest monthly rise in nearly two years, following firm eurozone inflation data for January. Underlying inflation accelerated to 1.2% from 1.1% in December, keeping expectations alive for a swift withdrawal of the European Central Bank's stimulus policies. This has led to increased investor optimism, with European funds seeing over $22 billion in equity inflows in January. The euro remains broadly undervalued on a trade-weighted basis, while the US dollar faces its biggest monthly drop in nearly two years due to President Trump's lack of clarity on the economy.

site_title: Debt payment behaviour of Singapore SMEs worsened in 2017
summary: Singapore SMEs' debt payment behaviour worsened in 2017, with 14% of severely delinquent debts remaining unpaid more than 90 days after due. This is an improvement from 2014, when a quarter of firms had such late debts. The proportion of severely delinquent debts has increased from 12% in 2016.

site_title: Oreo maker Mondelez's profit beats on higher demand for key brands
summary: Mondelez International, the world's No.2 confectionary company, reported a quarterly profit that beat estimates, driven by strong demand for Cadbury Dairy Milk and Oreo cookies in Europe and growth in emerging markets. Revenue from Europe rose 5% and accounted for nearly 40% of total revenue, while North America's biscuits business was affected by a malware-related loss. Net income rose to $802 million, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company expects double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth and organic net revenue growth of 1-2% for 2018.

images.alt_text: Mondelez International, the world's No.2 confectionary company, posted a quarterly profit that beat estimates on Wednesday, benefiting from strong demand for Cadbury Dairy Milk and Oreo cookies in Europe and growth in emerging markets.

site_title: Safest house in US goes on the market for US$14.7m
summary: The safest house in the US, a 36,000-square-foot compound outside Atlanta, is on the market for $14.7 million. Built to last 1,000 years and withstand every type of attack, the eight-bedroom, 15-bathroom home features reinforced walls, braided copper wires, and a 15,000 sq ft concrete-fortified bunker. The property includes multiple concealed entrances, Kevlar-reinforced doors, and a defense system called "Man Traps." The home is equipped with off-grid capabilities, including solar panels and underground generators, and is designed to operate at a tenth of the cost of a traditionally large home.

site_title: World Bank searches for meaning of its existence
summary: The World Bank is facing an identity crisis after Paul Romer's departure as chief economist, amid heated disputes and criticism of the Ease of Doing Business rankings. Romer accused the bank of changing the rankings unfairly, citing examples of countries with conservative governments improving their rankings. However, evidence suggests that the rankings have no measurable effect on economic growth, and the bank may be squandering its policy clout. This raises concerns about the bank's usefulness and its future existence, as it struggles to find a reason to continue providing development loans to countries that no longer need them.

site_title: When silence is not golden
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies have faced scrutiny for tardy or non-disclosures, including Noble Group, JEP Holdings, and Ipco International. Noble Group restructured its US$3.5 billion debt in exchange for 70% of the company, while JEP Holdings' stock surged 111% after a major shareholder acquired a controlling interest. Ipco International cited a lack of formal arrest or charges against its executives in explaining its decision not to disclose certain information. Regulators have opted for a principles-based approach, but listed firms have been slow to disclose negative material information, raising concerns about investor protection and market efficiency.

site_title: AEM to buy Finnish semiconductor equipment maker Afore for 7.6m euros
summary: AEM Holdings is acquiring Finnish semiconductor equipment maker Afore Oy for 7.58 million euros in cash and shares. The deal, valued at S$12.3 million, provides AEM with high-performance test capabilities and solutions in micro-electro-mechanical systems. Afore's founder and managing director Vesa Henttonen will receive consideration shares, while other shareholders will receive cash. The acquisition is expected to expand AEM's product and customer portfolio in the semiconductor and industrials sectors.

site_title: Global business leaders support coordinated approach to tech-driven changes: poll
summary: A poll of 1,400 business leaders worldwide found that 84% support a coordinated approach to tackle technological advancements. The majority (46%) believe inter-governmental bodies like the UN should lead the response, followed by individual governments and businesses. Despite 76% feeling governments aren't doing enough, most leaders expect the most impactful trends to be the online world, automation, and the ageing population. Only 28% are altering their business strategy to prepare for tech-driven change, with 44% focusing on upskilling existing employees.

site_title: Open societies under siege all over the world
summary: The article discusses the rise of nationalism and illiberalism worldwide, 30 years after the fall of the Soviet Union and the supposed triumph of liberal democracy. The shift from national to global competition, driven by globalization and technological advancements, has led to economic growth in developing countries but hollowing out of the middle class in Western societies. This has created a sense of frustration and anger, which has manifested in increasingly xenophobic and nationalist movements. The article highlights the example of Poland, where the nationalist leaders are erasing the legacy of Lech Walesa, the former Solidarity movement leader who played a key role in bringing down communism. The article concludes that the current turnabout is not just a reaction to globalization but a symptom of deeper societal issues, including economic inequality and cultural despair.

site_title: 285,000 Singaporeans have used SkillsFuture Credit, with more doing so in 2017
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Credit has seen a significant increase in users, with 285,000 individuals using the scheme since its launch in 2016. In 2017, 160,000 Singaporeans started using their credits, up from 126,000 in the first year. The funding scheme provides 25-year-olds and above with $500 to use on training courses. The growth in users suggests increased awareness and adoption of the initiative, which aims to support lifelong learning and skill development among Singaporeans.

site_title: Revolutions in time, in the Weekend magazine
summary: Luxury watchmakers showcased their latest timepieces at the SIHH fair in Geneva, featuring intricate mechanical designs. The Weekend magazine also explored the challenges and joys of men over 40 becoming fathers for the first time, and featured articles on Chinese New Year designs, snack creations, and wellness topics. Additionally, lifestyle articles covered topics such as mod-Indian cuisine, corporate purpose, and zero-waste living.

site_title: Venezuela sets initial digital currency value at US$60
summary: Venezuela has set the initial value of its digital currency, Petro, at US$60 per unit, backed by the country's vast oil reserves. The pre-sale for 38.4 million units will take place between February 20 and March 19. The currency's value will fluctuate based on oil market changes, with President Nicolas Maduro stating it will aid the country's economic and social development. Venezuela is struggling with a deep economic crisis, restructuring its external debt of around US$150 billion, and facing US and EU sanctions.

site_title: Crumbling bridges? Fret not America, it's not that bad
summary: US President Donald Trump called for increased spending on bridges and roads in his State of the Union address, citing a need for $1.5 trillion over 10 years. However, a Reuters analysis of nationwide bridge data reveals that the nation's bridge infrastructure is not as dire as claimed, with the share of structurally deficient bridges decreasing over the past few decades. Most failed bridges are not due to structural decline, but rather natural disasters, fires, and collisions. Experts agree that boosting public and private investment in infrastructure could meet the growing economy's needs, but the focus on bridges may distract from more pressing infrastructure issues, such as mass transit and water infrastructure.

site_title: Business expectations still positive for H1, but lower than in previous survey
summary: Singapore businesses remain cautiously optimistic about the economy for the next six months, with the services sector showing marginally more optimism than the manufacturing sector. The services sector has a net weighted balance of 3% of firms expecting more favorable business conditions, while the manufacturing sector has a net weighted balance of 1%. However, sentiment has dipped since the previous quarter due to concerns about the economic upswing lasting. Economists note that the services sector remains a "mosaic" picture, with some parts brighter than others, and caution against reading too much into the sentiment-based survey.

site_title: EU seeks to soften rules for tackling failing banks
summary: The European Union is proposing to shorten the moratorium period for withdrawing deposits from a failing bank from five working days to two business days. This change aims to prevent bank deposit runs and "unintended consequences" on financial markets. The proposed compromise has been welcomed by EU member states and stakeholders, with Bulgaria's presidency believing it achieves the desired policy objectives while addressing concerns. The change is part of a broader effort to soften EU rules for tackling failing banks.

site_title: Defections weaken Dutch banks' fintech defence
summary: Dutch banks' fintech defense has been weakened by the departure of ABN Amro from a new mobile payments system, Payconiq. The system, which aims to create a single standard for mobile payments, has been launched six months behind schedule. ING, which founded Payconiq, has acquired a controlling stake in a fintech payments company, further fragmenting the Dutch payment landscape. The move is seen as a challenge to the banks' ability to fend off fintech rivals, with experts predicting that consumers will ultimately determine the winner in the market.

site_title: Number of unrelated tenants in flats, commercial properties cut to 6 from May: HDB
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has reduced the number of unrelated tenants allowed in four-room or larger flats to six, down from nine, starting May 1. The cap for three-room commercial properties has also been lowered from eight to six. The changes aim to minimize overcrowding problems and maintain a conducive living environment in public housing estates.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit's Q4 distribution income up 14.6%
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 14.6% increase in Q4 distribution income to S$17.7 million, despite a 3.4% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.14 Singapore cents. This was attributed to an enlarged unit base and lower management fees. Gross revenue and net property income declined 2.3% and 0.3% respectively, but operating costs fell 8.9%. The company's portfolio occupancy remained at 96.8% in 2017, and it is currently in negotiations for refinancing ahead of debt maturity in 2H 2018.

site_title: A strategic move to enhance independence of directors
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) Corporate Governance Council (CGC) proposes two options to address the issue of independent directors serving beyond nine years, a principle intended to strengthen board quality. The options are the hard-limit option, which would ban directors from continuing as independent directors after nine years, and the two-tier approval option, which would require shareholder approval at two levels. The CGC aims to generate discussion in boardrooms and beyond, with a proposed three-year transition period for companies to adjust.

site_title: Europe: Shares claw back declines
summary: European shares recovered slightly, rising 0.2% as investors surveyed mixed results from major industrial names. The UK's FTSE 100 underperformed, while euro zone stocks followed suit. Struggling UK outsourcer Capita's shares plummeted 35% after profit warnings and a dividend suspension. Other European benchmarks are set to end the month on a positive note.

site_title: BOJ dismisses market talk of early stimulus exit
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has reaffirmed its commitment to maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy, dismissing market speculation of an early exit from its massive stimulus program. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda and Deputy Governor Kikuo Iwata stated that the BOJ will continue to boost its bond buying plan and keep short-term interest rates at minus 0.1% to achieve its 2% inflation target. The BOJ's efforts aim to counteract market expectations of a rate hike and strengthen the economy, despite subdued inflation and signs of economic growth.

images.alt_text: "Government steps, as well as appropriate monetary policy, are necessary to achieve price stability with sustained economic growth," says Mr Iwata, whose five-year term ends in March.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by modest gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.70%, or 162.57 points, to 23,260.86, while the Topix index gained 0.59%, or 10.88 points, to 1,847.59. The gains were supported by investor focus on upcoming corporate earnings announcements.

site_title: SGX seeks to tweak listing rules for mineral, oil and gas companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a public consultation for changes to listing rules for mineral, oil, and gas (MOG) companies. The proposed changes aim to strengthen listing profiles, requiring companies to establish reserves and resources, and demonstrate plans to obtain necessary approvals. The SGX expects to implement the changes this year, which will enable companies at different stages of development to raise funds via the board that is more appropriate to them, benefiting investors with improved readability of reports. The public has until February 28 to submit feedback on the proposed changes.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust to acquire nine properties in Australia for A$177.6m
summary: Cache Logistics Trust has agreed to acquire nine logistics properties in Australia for A$177.6 million, with a total acquisition cost of A$191 million. The portfolio spans 142,103 sq m and has an initial net property yield of 6.4%. The acquisition will almost double Cache's assets under management in Australia, raising its portfolio valuation by 15.6% to S$1.4 billion. The deal is expected to complete by end of February.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments issues letter of offer to acquire shares in IPC
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments Ltd has issued a conditional letter of offer to acquire 46.91% of IPC Corporation Ltd's shares from existing shareholders. The offer price is 28.2% premium to the last traded price, and new shares will be issued in a ratio of 133 for every IPC share. The acquisition aims to integrate IPC's business into the group and its subsidiaries, with shareholder approval and in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange required. The deal is expected to trigger a mandatory unconditional offer for IPC under Singapore's takeover code.

site_title: Next phase of industry transformation to consider industries in clusters, not isolation: Heng
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the next phase of Singapore's industry transformation efforts will focus on clusters of industries, considering overlaps between sectors. This shift aims to address the blurring of industry boundaries due to global and technological changes. Heng defended the sector-specific roadmaps, citing examples of synergies in food manufacturing and retail. He emphasized the need for partnership between businesses, government, and research institutes to achieve more. The government will explore synergies in clusters, such as finance and technology, and retail and real estate.

site_title: STC-invested fund buys into properties in Japan for 880.58m yen
summary: STC-invested fund buys properties in Japan for 880.58 million yen (S$10.62 million). The properties, located in Tokyo, consist of 88 apartment units with a total net lettable area of 2,487.4 sq m. The fund, managed by Savills IM Japan Residential Fund GP Pte Ltd, aims to acquire residential properties in the Greater Tokyo area and other key markets. This investment is part of a larger commitment by Straits Trading to invest in the fund.

site_title: Julius Baer's new CEO said to eye deals in Latin America, China
summary: Bernhard Hodler, the new CEO of Julius Baer, plans to focus on advisory mandates and boost revenues from advisory services compared to transaction-based income. He aims to pursue deals in regions like South America and China, with a potential entry into China to cater to onshore clients. Hodler also seeks to increase lending and push clients into advisory and discretionary mandates. The bank has put on hold plans for an initial public offering of Italian wealth manager Kairos Investment Management.

site_title: US chicken producers accused of market manipulation
summary: US food distributors Sysco and US Foods have filed lawsuits against major chicken producers, alleging market manipulation and artificially inflated prices. The producers, including Pilgrim's Pride and Tyson Foods, allegedly limited hen supplies in 2008 to lower production levels and control prices. The lawsuit claims that the producers manipulated the Georgia Dock indicator, which determined chicken prices, and that their actions were a significant departure from industry practice. Sysco is seeking financial compensation, with one of the producers dismissing the case as "completely without merit."

site_title: Singapore Medical Group takes stake in Australian IVF specialist
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) has acquired a 65% stake in Australian IVF specialist CFC Global, the country's fourth-largest IVF provider. The joint venture company, CHA SMG (Australia), will acquire CFC Global through a 20% equity interest held by SMG. The deal aims to capitalize on the rising global IVF market and cross-border synergies through technological knowledge sharing and referrals to other countries. SMG's executive director Beng Teck Liang expects the partnership to drive growth in Vietnam and other markets.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 3,533.99, led by a decline in Wall Street overnight and ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee rate decision. Trading volume decreased to 2.3 billion shares worth S$1.9 billion. Losers outpaced gainers with 256 counters down and 195 up.

site_title: IBF to help financial industry professionals with career advice and job placement
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) announced that IBF will expand its mandate to provide career advisory and job placement services for the financial sector. IBF will establish a dedicated Career Centre by July to offer services including competency standard-setting, skills development, career advisory, job matching, and placements. This move aims to support financial industry professionals in their career development and job placement.

site_title: Swiss Re launches regional HQ in Singapore
summary: Swiss Re launched its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, marking the company's commitment to the region. The new headquarters will be led by a regional board of directors, including Lim Siong Guan, former GIC group president. The company aims to tap into growth areas such as health, natural catastrophe, and cyber risks in Asia, which accounts for a quarter of Swiss Re's group revenues. The regional board will provide new perspectives and help craft the company's vision for the region.

site_title: US private payrolls growth maintains brisk pace; labor costs rise in Q4
summary: US private payrolls grew 234,000 jobs in January, beating economists' expectations, with labor costs rising 0.6% in the fourth quarter, the largest increase since 2015. This growth is expected to accelerate due to a tightening labor market forcing employers to raise wages. The unemployment rate remains at 4.1%, with forecasts predicting a drop to 3.5% by the end of 2018. The strong labor market is also expected to boost wage growth, with some companies planning to use tax cut savings to raise wages for workers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks have best month since April 2015
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed at a 32-year high, with the Hang Seng index rising 279.98 points or 0.86% to 32,887.27. This marks the best month since April 2015, driven by gains for financial and services firms. In contrast, China's Shanghai Composite index fell 0.19%, while its CSI300 index rose 0.48%. The strong performance is attributed to the resilience of Hong Kong's economy amidst global market uncertainty.

site_title: US pending home sales rise 0.5 per cent in Dec
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.5% in December, marking the third consecutive month of growth, according to the National Association of Realtors. This increase is attributed to a robust job market. Compared to the same month in 2016, pending home sales rose 0.5%, with significant gains in the South (4.0%) and Midwest (0.3%), but declines in the Northeast (2.7%) and West (3.1%).

site_title: 'Appalling' Malaysian tourism logo to stay: tourism chief
summary: Malaysia's tourism logo, "Visit Malaysia 2020," featuring cartoon animals wearing sunglasses, will remain despite widespread criticism. The logo, designed to showcase the country's sunny beaches and conservation efforts, has been deemed "dated" and an "eye-sore" by netizens. An online petition has garnered 9,873 signatures, calling for the logo's removal. Tourism Minister Nazri Abdul Aziz has refused to change the design, stating it represents the country's sunny and environmentally conscious image.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Business expectations for the services and manufacturing sectors remain positive but have decreased from the previous quarter. Companies expect business prospects to improve in the next six months. The Singapore bourse closed 0.4% lower, with the Straits Times Index falling 14.8 points. A redevelopment site in Geylang is up for tender at S$36 million, while Chinatown Plaza has been put up for collective sale with an asking price of S$270 million. Insurance group Swiss Re launched its Asia HQ in Singapore, and the MAS and EDB appointed new directors.

site_title: Order boom helps truck maker Volvo to raise market outlook
summary: Swedish truck maker AB Volvo raised its market outlook for commercial vehicles, citing strong demand and a 30% rise in fourth-quarter core earnings. The company reported a 29% growth in order bookings for its trucks, beating analyst expectations. Volvo also lifted its 2018 guidance for heavy-duty truck sales in Europe and North America, citing a good freight environment, low fuel prices, and low interest rates. The company's shares have climbed 43% in the past year, but the ownership structure is changing with China's Geely Holding set to become a second-largest shareholder.

site_title: Finnair board member quits after government lambasts CEO pension
summary: Finnair board member, responsible for management compensation, will quit at the next shareholder meeting following a dispute with the government over CEO Pekka Vauramo's pension arrangement. The airline's board approved the arrangement, despite state recommendations. Economy minister Mika Lintila had previously threatened to propose changes to the board, prompting the resignation. The move comes after the government expressed dissatisfaction with the airline's pension plan for its CEO.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat as Samsung Elec rally fizzles; won firms
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index ended flat on Wednesday, despite a rise in the Korean won and a drop in bond yields. Samsung Electronics' stock split announcement sparked earlier gains but fizzled out, contributing to the flat market. The won rose 0.53% against its previous close, while bond yields fell. The KOSPI is up 4.1% so far this year, and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.2%.

site_title: Apple supplier Wistron nears land deal in India: sources
summary: Apple's Taiwanese contract manufacturer Wistron Corp is nears finalizing a land deal in India's Bengaluru to invest around $157 million, sources say. The deal would allow Wistron to set up new assembly lines for Apple, potentially including the iPhone 6s models, to cut costs and diversify production. Local assembly could help Apple save on import taxes, price phones cheaper, and expand its customer base in India, one of the world's fastest-growing smartphone markets.

site_title: Datapulse completes Tai Seng sale, but says it might restart disk drive manufacturing
summary: Datapulse Technology has completed the sale of its Tai Seng property, which housed its manufacturing activities, after being scheduled for late-2017. The company will cease operations, but retains some necessary hardware and may consider restarting digital media storage manufacturing if suitable premises can be found. Datapulse's board of directors previously stated that the company's existing business, manufacturing media storage products, was not viable or sustainable. The company has shifted its registered office and closed down, with shares falling 1.39% to S$0.355.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit distribution income rises, DPU falls for Q4 2017
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 14.6% increase in income available for distribution to S$17.7 million in Q4 2017, despite a 2.3% decline in gross revenue to S$44.0 million. Distribution per unit fell to 1.14 Singapore cents from 1.18 cents in the previous year. Net property income decreased 0.3% to S$34.7 million. The decline in gross revenue was attributed to lower rental income. OUE C-Reit units remained unchanged at S$0.75.

site_title: AMD's earnings top estimates as graphics chip demand surges
summary: AMD's fourth-quarter earnings exceeded Wall Street forecasts, with revenue rising 33.3% to $1.48 billion and net income increasing to $61 million. The company attributed growth to demand from cryptocurrency miners and sales of graphics processing units. AMD forecast revenue of $1.55 billion for the next quarter, driven by demand for Ryzen processors and GPUs. The company reported 8 cents per share earnings, beating analyst estimates of 5 cents. Despite initial concerns, AMD's shares remained relatively flat after-hours trading.

site_title: Search resumes for Quiksilver CEO missing off French coast
summary: Search efforts resumed for Quiksilver CEO Pierre Agnes, 24 hours after his empty boat washed up on a French coast. A helicopter and two boats were deployed to scour the coast near Biarritz, where Agnes had been fishing. The 54-year-old had contacted the harbour master earlier, citing fog and a late return. Three helicopters and two boats scoured the coast Tuesday but found no signs of Agnes, a father of three and former French national surfing team member. His fate remains unknown.

site_title: US: Boeing leads Wall St higher after two-day slump
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, rebounding from two days of losses, driven by a surge in Boeing shares. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 226.17 points, or 0.87%, to 26,303.06, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the latter adding 43.36 points, or 0.59%. The rally followed a controversy-free State of the Union address by President Donald Trump.

site_title: Popular Line messaging app starts crypto trading spinoff
summary: Japan's messaging app Line is launching a financial services spinoff to allow users to exchange and trade virtual currencies, including bitcoin. The transactions will be made within the app, which already has a mobile payment system. Line has registered its new business with Japan's Financial Services Agency and shares rose 2.57% after the announcement. This comes after a massive cryptocurrency heist from Japanese virtual currency exchange Coincheck, which has led to tightened regulations on virtual currency trade in the region.

site_title: mm2 board's approval of Vividthree spin-off paves way for Catalist listing
summary: Mainboard-listed mm2 Asia's board has approved the spin-off of Vividthree Productions, a 51% stake in which mm2 Asia holds, paving the way for its eventual listing on the Catalist board. The company did not provide a timeline for the listing.

site_title: TimMac@Kranji: First high-rise hub for metal, machinery and timber SMEs to be ready in 2020
summary: The Singapore Cranes Association, JTC, and the Singapore Timber Association have agreed to develop TimMac@Kranji, a high-rise hub for metal, machinery, and timber SMEs. The facility, set to be completed in 2020, will offer shared services and special infrastructure to support the industries. The development features ceilings up to 12 meters and heavy floor loading, allowing for the use of overhead cranes and heavy automation machinery. The government plans to partner with the companies to enhance productivity and optimise space usage, aiming to improve operational efficiency and competitiveness.

site_title: Noble says allegations of management enriching themselves at shareholders' expense 'unfounded'
summary: Noble Group has denied allegations that its management enriched itself at shareholders' expense, calling the claims "unfounded." The company's management will retain a 10% equity stake in the restructured entity, with further grants subject to performance hurdles. Shareholders, including Goldilocks Investment Company, have questioned the management's fiduciary duty and the fairness of asset disposals. Noble said it maximized value from asset disposals and that announcements were made to address leaks and rumors. The company's shares rebounded on Wednesday after an 11.5% fall on Tuesday.

site_title: Steelmaker ArcelorMittal upbeat about 2018, slowly resumes dividend
summary: ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steelmaker, reported an upbeat assessment of the steel market for 2018, with expected global apparent steel consumption increasing 1.5-2.5% due to strong recoveries in Brazil, Europe, and North America. The company resumed dividend payments, paying out $0.10 from its 2017 results, and plans to reduce net debt to $6 billion. ArcelorMittal's core profit rose by over a third in 2017, driven by higher sales and steel prices, particularly in China.

site_title: Lonza FY2017 profit more than doubled on sales growth, higher margins
summary: Lonza Group reported a 141.9% surge in net profit to 728 million Swiss francs (S$1 billion) for fiscal 2017, driven by strong organic sales growth and higher margins. Revenue jumped 23.5% to 5.1 billion francs, with core earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) reaching a record-breaking 24.8% and core Ebit margin at 18.8%. The company's acquisition of Capsugel in July 2017 contributed to the growth, with CEO Richard Ridinger praising the results as a demonstration of the company's strength.

site_title: South Korea says uncovered about S$777m in cryptocurrency crimes
summary: South Korea's customs service has uncovered cryptocurrency crimes worth 637.5 billion won (S$777.27 million), including illegal foreign exchange trading and money laundering. Domestic investors bought cryptocurrencies and sent them to overseas partner companies, converting them back into fiat currencies for unrecorded capital outflows. The customs office will continue to monitor the use of cryptocurrencies to prevent such crimes.

site_title: Australian shares recover to end higher; NZ gains
