summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, ending a 0.5% decline in January, which was the first losing month in four. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 14.9 points to 6,037.7, driven by a recovery in real estate stocks. Global cues, including lower oil prices and rising bond yields, were largely ignored, with investors focusing on domestic market conditions.

site_title: Fed expected to keep interest rates steady as Yellen era ends
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, signaling a gradual tightening of monetary policy later this year. The decision comes as the economy continues to expand, with solid job gains and low unemployment. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's last meeting is expected to focus on inflation and the impact of the Trump administration's tax overhaul. Incoming Fed chief Jerome Powell is expected to maintain a slow upward path for interest rates, and analysts do not anticipate a dramatic shift from the Fed's current message.

site_title: South Korea doesn't intend to shut down virtual coin trading: finance minister
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Kim Dong-yeon, stated that the government has no plans to shut down cryptocurrency trading, contradicting market speculation. The minister emphasized regulating exchanges as the government's immediate task, rather than banning or suppressing the market. This decision aligns with South Korea's approach, which differs from China's ban on virtual coin platforms.

site_title: Melania braves public eye after Trump cheating claim
summary: First Lady Melania Trump made a visible return to the public stage at her husband's State of the Union address, her first official appearance since accusations of infidelity surfaced about President Donald Trump. Melania attended the event smiling and waving, dressed in a cream white pantsuit, amidst speculation about her marriage. The couple arrived separately to the Capitol, and it was unclear if they returned together to the White House after the address.

site_title: US probing Apple on updates that slow older iPhones: sources
summary: The US Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating Apple over its disclosures about a software update that slowed older iPhone models. The probe concerns whether Apple misled investors about the performance of older phones. Apple has confirmed receiving questions from government officials and reiterated that it would never intentionally shorten the life of any Apple product. The slowdown affects iPhone 7 models and older, and Apple has apologized and offered a battery replacement service.

site_title: Transit-Mixed Concrete CEO Chua Eng Him, 68, dies of illness
summary: Transit-Mixed Concrete CEO Chua Eng Him, 68, died on January 30 following an undisclosed illness. He was on medical leave since November 26 and had led the company since 1979. His duties will be covered by a senior management team until a replacement is found. Chua held a 28.96% stake in the company, with 20.1 million shares.

site_title: Business expectations of services, manufacturing sectors for first-half 2018 still sanguine: EDB, DOS
summary: Business expectations for the services sector are still optimistic, with a net weighted balance of 3% of firms forecasting more favourable business conditions. This is down from 9% in the previous quarter but still an improvement from -14% last year. In manufacturing, only 1% of firms expect an improved business situation, with the precision engineering cluster being the most optimistic. The majority of firms in both sectors expect the business situation to maintain status quo.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower again after Wall Street selloff
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index fell 0.83% for the sixth straight day, closing at 23,098.29, amid a US Wall Street selloff. Investors remained unfazed by US President Donald Trump's State of Union address. The broader Topix index also declined 1.15% to 1,836.71.

site_title: Iceland puts onus on companies to pay gender equal wages
summary: Iceland has introduced a law requiring employers to prove they pay men and women equally for the same work, with fines of up to 400 euros per day for non-compliance. The law, which takes effect in January 2018, shifts the onus from employees to employers to demonstrate equal pay. The country aims to close the 16.1% wage gap between men and women, despite already being one of the world's best performers in terms of gender equality.

site_title: Thai Dec factory output rises 2.35% y-o-y, below forecast
summary: Thai industrial output rose 2.35% in December, missing expectations of a 3.50% increase, following a revised 4.14% increase in November. The manufacturing production index (MPI) was up 1.58% in 2017, with capacity utilisation at 59.53% in December. The finance ministry forecasts 4.2% economic growth for 2018, after a 4% growth in 2017.

site_title: Singapore bank lending weakens in December: MAS
summary: Singapore bank lending declined 0.3% in December from November, reversing a 0.6% month-on-month gain in the previous month. Loans stood at S$652 billion, down from S$654 billion in November. This marks a weakening trend in bank lending after a brief increase.

site_title: State of the Union: Trump policy agenda starts to stick to the script
summary: US President Donald Trump's first State of the Union address highlighted his policy agenda, with a focus on immigration and infrastructure. The speech called for a $1.5 trillion infrastructure bill and simplified project approvals, as well as changes to the immigration system, including border security measures and a path to citizenship for 1.8 million undocumented immigrants. The speech also included proposals on defence spending, the opioid epidemic, and job training. The administration's agenda has become more predictable, with few surprises, and investors can feel more confident in its direction.

site_title: MAS, EDB appoint new directors
summary: Singapore's central bank, MAS, and economic development board, EDB, have appointed new directors, effective February 1, 2018. MAS appointed Attorney-General Lucien Wong to its board, while EDB added four new members, including Alexander Charles Hungate and Suranjan Magesvaran. Existing board members, including Tan Gee Keow and Patrick Tay, were also re-appointed. Several outgoing board members, including Jean-Luc Butel and Dr Stefan Doboczky, will step down from EDB's board. The changes aim to enhance the boards' capabilities and expertise.

site_title: China says plenty of space separates Taiwan flights amid route row
summary: China has rebuffed Taiwan's objections over the opening of new flight paths in the Taiwan Strait, saying the space separating routes is over 23km, exceeding international standards. The move came after Taiwan withheld approval of flights by China Eastern and Xiamen Airlines, citing a 2015 deal to discuss such routes. The dispute highlights tensions between China and Taiwan, with China considering Taiwan a wayward province.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session lower; STI at 3,534.87, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% to 3,534.87 in the afternoon session, with the Straits Times Index down 13.87 points. About 1.10 billion shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 226 to 139. Key movers included Keppel Corporation, up 2.67%, and DBS, up 0.04%. The market followed a global trend of lower opening, with US stocks also down amid tariff threats.

site_title: State of the Union: Trump connects presidency with prosperity in 'American moment'
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered his first State of the Union address, emphasizing the country's prosperity and seeking bipartisanship. He portrayed his administration as working to build a "safe, strong and proud America" and promised to unify the country. Despite his divisive image, Trump aimed to connect his presidency to the nation's wealth and opportunity, referring to it as a "new American moment." The speech marked a departure from his typical antagonistic tone, with Trump calling for unity among Americans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open after US losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Wednesday, tracking US losses. The Hang Seng Index lost 0.32% to 32,502.77, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.50% and 0.58% respectively. The decline follows sharp losses on Wall Street amid tariff threats, with US stocks edging down from records.

site_title: State of the Union address: After year of bitter feuds, Trump urges bipartisan cooperation
summary: President Donald Trump delivered his first State of the Union address, urging bipartisan cooperation on immigration and infrastructure despite a year of partisan battles. Trump called for a compromise on rebuilding aging roads, bridges, and infrastructure, aiming for a $1.5 trillion investment. He also sought to overcome doubts about his presidency, battling a Russia probe and low job approval ratings. The speech was marked by deep divisions between Republicans and Democrats, with Trump's message falling on deaf ears at times.

site_title: Asia: Warnings on stocks correction grow louder
summary: Asian stocks are expected to correct, with Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs predicting a "meaningful" dip in the Hang Seng Index within weeks. Despite warning signs, investors have been reluctant to cash out due to resilient economic growth and relatively low multiples. Strategists say a correction is possible but fundamentals remain well-supported. The Hang Seng Index fell for a third day, its longest losing streak in almost two months, and Asian stocks trimmed their best January gain in six years. A correction is seen as a near-term caution for traders.

site_title: US dollar inches lower, barely reacts to Trump speech
summary: The US dollar inched lower against a basket of major currencies, down 0.1% to 89.062, following US President Donald Trump's State of the Union address. Trump called for $1.5 trillion in new infrastructure spending and pushed for bipartisan compromises on immigration. The dollar index remained above a three-year low, while the euro edged up 0.2% and the yen slipped after the Bank of Japan increased its buying of Japanese government bonds. Market participants expect the US Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged this week, with little reaction to the Fed's policy statement.

images.alt_text: The dollar inched lower against a basket of major rivals on Wednesday, showing scant reaction to US President Donald Trump's State of the Union address.

site_title: China factory gauge weakened amid pollution, leverage campaigns
summary: China's official factory gauge slipped to 51.3 in January, missing estimates, amid efforts to rein in debt and reduce pollution. The non-manufacturing PMI rose to 55.3, while a new composite index stood at 54.6. The slowdown in growth momentum is supportive of further reforms, according to chief economist Raymond Yeung, amid a broad global recovery and industrial reflation. The economy's first full-year acceleration since 2010 is expected to slow in coming months due to pollution and borrowing policies.

site_title: Katong Park Towers put up for en bloc sale with S$288m reserve price
summary: Katong Park Towers, a 99-year leasehold residential site, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$288 million (S$1,165 per square foot per plot ratio). The site, zoned for residential use, can potentially yield 388 apartment units. The tender will close on March 15, 2018. The site's location near the future Katong Park MRT Station and in close proximity to several high-end schools make it an attractive opportunity for exclusive condominium development in the affluent Katong area.

site_title: China drawing up new 2018-2020 crackdown on smog: official
summary: China is developing a new three-year plan to combat smog, following a successful five-year crackdown that helped meet its air quality targets in 2017. The plan, aimed at 2018-2020, will focus on tightening regulations in major industrial regions like Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei and the Yangtze and Pearl River deltas. China's previous plan, implemented from 2013-2017, forced the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region to reduce PM2.5 concentrations by over 25%. The new plan aims to continue reducing pollution from coal-burning sources and promoting clean energy heating.

site_title: May arrives in China eyeing post-Brexit trade links
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May arrived in China on January 31, 2018, to bolster post-Brexit trade links. Her visit includes talks with Premier Li Keqiang and President Xi Jinping, as well as discussions on climate change and North Korea. China expects London to endorse its Belt and Road initiative, while the British government has expressed concerns about meeting international standards. May's trip comes amid scrutiny of Brexit legislation and amid expectations for a historic agreement.

site_title: Blackstone bets big on Wall Street information business with Thomson Reuters deal
summary: US private equity firm Blackstone Group acquired a majority stake in Thomson Reuters' Financial and Risk business for $20 billion, its largest bet since the financial crisis. This deal positions Blackstone as a major player in Wall Street's financial information industry, competing with Bloomberg's market-leading terminals. The acquisition is a significant move by Blackstone, co-founded by Stephen Schwarzman, against fellow billionaire and former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

site_title: Owner offers 1,696 sq m redevelopment site in Geylang for at least S$36m
summary: The owner of a 1,696.3 sq m redevelopment site in Geylang, Singapore, is offering the property for tender at a minimum price of S$36 million. The site, on a 99-year leasehold tenure, can be redeveloped into an eight-storey building with a maximum allowable gross floor area of 4,749.6 sq m. The tender closes on March 22, with the property suitable for commercial or institution use, including restaurants, shops, and offices.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall after sharp Wall Street losses
summary: Asian stocks fell on Wednesday, tracking US President Donald Trump's call for infrastructure investment, following sharp Wall Street losses. The Dow posted its largest decline since May, while China's manufacturing data fell below expectations. Shanghai and Hong Kong declined 0.7% each. Markets await the Federal Reserve's policy announcement tonight, which may signal an acceleration in interest rate increases. Despite some positive news in Japan, such as Samsung's record fourth-quarter net profit, overall global sentiment remains bearish.

site_title: Dealmakers jump ship as China tycoon Xie Zhikun's US$5b M&A push ends
summary: China tycoon Xie Zhikun's US$5 billion M&A push has ended due to the Chinese state's clampdown on capital outflows and reverse mergers. Despite hiring top dealmakers, Xie's firm, ZZ Capital International, has completed zero deals, and senior executives are negotiating severance packages. The firm is scaling back operations, with a core team of less than 10 people remaining, and is exploring alternative capital sources. This setback is part of a string of recent difficulties for Xie, who has been mired in a dispute and facing financial stress in the shadow banking industry.

site_title: South Korea factory output slips in December as chips soar, cars slump
summary: South Korea's industrial production unexpectedly fell 6% in December, led by a sharp contraction in car output, despite solid growth in the memory chip sector. The economy remains on track, with the finance ministry stating growth remains "solid." The semiconductor industry saw record exports, but major manufacturing sectors like shipbuilding and autos continue to struggle. The Bank of Korea is unlikely to raise interest rates in the first quarter due to uneven growth, but may consider a move in the second quarter if exports and the global economy hold up.

site_title: Samsung Electronics reports record Q4 and full year profits
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 73% jump in its Q4 net profit to 12.26 trillion won, setting a record for any three-month period, driven by demand for memory chips and display panels. The company's full-year net profit reached 42.19 trillion won, up 85.6% from 2016, with operating profit up 64.3% to 15.15 trillion won. The firm announced a 50-for-1 stock split, sending shares up 6.4%, and expects strong demand for memory products in the first quarter. Analysts predict Samsung's full-year operating profit will rise beyond 60 trillion won this year.

site_title: Chinatown Plaza put up for collective sale with S$270m asking price
summary: Chinatown Plaza has been put up for collective sale with an asking price of S$270 million, equivalent to S$1,989 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, zoned for commercial and residential use, spans 3,154.3 square meters and is located near the Central Business District and popular Keong Saik Street. The tender exercise will close on March 15, and the site can be redeveloped up to its existing gross floor area of 12,610.89 sq m. The property is ideal for mixed-use redevelopment, serviced apartments, or hotel development, subject to planning approval.

site_title: Australia: Shares on track to extend losses; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,010.70, extending a decline for a second day, due to weakening global markets and falling oil prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 12.10 points. The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, but investors will look for hints on future rates. Australian exporters were hit by a survey showing China's manufacturing sector growth slowed to an eight-month low, with BHP and Rio Tinto falling. Real estate stocks rose after soft inflation data reduced expectations for interest rate hikes.

site_title: NTUC forms 22-member network to offer accessible training for hospitality professionals
summary: NTUC has formed the Hospitality ABC (HABC) Network, a 22-member collaboration to offer accessible training for hospitality professionals in Singapore. The network aims to equip employees with "accessible, bite-sized competencies" to take on higher-value-added roles and keep pace with industry transformation. The network will offer training programs in leadership, digital, and operations disciplines, and can be accessed through online lessons, face-to-face classes, or hands-on sessions. The initiative is supported by the Singapore Tourism Board and aims to enhance the skills of the hospitality workforce.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall Street selloff
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, January 31, 2018, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.44% to 23,189.45, and the broader Topix index dropped 0.51% to 1,848.70. This marked the fifth consecutive day of decline for the Nikkei 225.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday, STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.5% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 17.64 points to 3,531.1, following a decline in global bond yields and a drop in Wall Street. The Dow Jones fell 1.4% and the S&P 500 declined 1.1%. Asian markets also fell, with Japan's Topix index sinking 0.4% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index sliding 0.3%.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust's Q4 DPU flat at 2.37 cents
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported flat fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) at 2.37 Singapore cents, despite a 6.8% increase in income available for distribution to S$22 million. Gross revenue declined 4.6% to S$54.1 million, and net property income dropped 5.2% to S$33.0 million. The decline was mainly due to the divestment of CapitaMall Anzhen and disruptions to trading activities. CRCT's portfolio remains well-positioned to tap China's sustainable growth, with Soh Kim Soon, chairman, stating the Reit is positive about its prospects.

site_title: LY Corp debuts at 28.5 S cents on Catalist, 9.6% higher than IPO price
summary: LY Corp, a Malaysian bedroom furniture maker, made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at 28.5 Singapore cents, a 9.6% gain from its 26 cents IPO price. The company raised S$19.7 million in gross proceeds from its IPO, with Heah Theare Haw and Pheim Asset Management among the investors. LY Corp's market cap is approximately S$127 million, and the company plans to use the funds for its next phase of growth.

site_title: Gold off highs as market braces for Trump speech, Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-week low on Tuesday amid market anticipation for US President Donald Trump's State of the Union address and potential hawkish language from the US Federal Reserve. Spot gold was down 0.22% at $1,336.99 an ounce, while US gold futures for February delivery settled down 0.4% at $1,335.40 per ounce. The market is also bracing for the US economic growth and potential rate hikes.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CRCT, OUE H-Trust, Datapulse, TMC Education, MTQ
summary:
Key developments in Singapore stocks include:

- CapitaLand Retail China Trust's (CRCT) fourth-quarter distribution per unit remained flat at 2.37 Singapore cents, despite a 6.8% increase in income available for distribution.
- OUE Hospitality Trust's (OUE H-Trust) distribution per stapled security slipped to 1.27 Singapore cents from 1.36 Singapore cents in the previous year.
- Datapulse Technology's CEO, Kee Swee Ann, has quit the company, effective Friday.
- TMC Education's mandatory takeover offer has closed, with the offeror now owning 53.05% of the company's shares.
- MTQ Corporation has proposed a renounceable underwritten rights cum warrants issue, with estimated net proceeds of up to S$15.5 million.

site_title: Japan factory output up in December, beating expectations
summary: Japan's factory output rose 2.7% in December, beating market expectations of a 1.5% rise, marking the third consecutive monthly increase. This growth, coupled with seven straight quarters of economic expansion, is seen as a positive sign for the economy ahead of the 2020 Olympic Games. However, deflation fears persist, with household spending slipping 0.1% in December and the jobless rate edging up to 2.8%. The government and central bank hope to achieve a "virtuous cycle" of export-led growth boosting jobs and household income, ultimately driving domestic demand.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation in talks to sell stake to UAE firm
summary: Atlantic Navigation, an offshore supply operations firm, is in talks with UAE-based Gulf Navigation Holding to sell a substantial stake in the company. The proposed sale is subject to due diligence, regulatory approval, and senior lender consent. No further details have been announced by the company, and it will provide updates on material developments.

site_title: Chile's Axxion now largest shareholder of Sarine after S$30m of open-market buying
summary: Chilean investment firm Axxion SA has become the largest shareholder of diamond specialist Sarine Technologies after purchasing S$30 million of shares on the open market over two months. Axxion's stake now stands at 9.18%, surpassing its previous 8.7% share. This follows Mondrian Investment Partners' sale of its 29.3 million shares on November 30.

site_title: GIC joins Blackstone consortium buying stake in Thomson Reuters' financial, risk business
summary: GIC joins a Blackstone-led consortium to buy a 55% stake in Thomson Reuters' financial and risk business, F&R, for $11 billion. The deal values F&R at $20 billion. Thomson Reuters retains a 45% stake valued at $9 billion. The partnership is expected to close in the second half of 2018. The new F&R entity will distribute Reuters News through its products for 30 years. Reuters News will maintain editorial independence.

site_title: Federal Reserve opens Yellen's final meeting; no rate hike seen
summary: The US Federal Reserve opened its first meeting of 2018, the last under Chair Janet Yellen's tenure, with no interest rate hike expected. Markets anticipate policymakers will leave rates unchanged, despite expectations of three more rate increases this year to combat inflation. Inflation remains below the Fed's 2% target, but some economists predict price pressures will rise in the first half of 2018. Yellen's successor, Jerome Powell, is seen as more amenable to President Trump's deregulation agenda, potentially altering the Fed's environment.

site_title: Malaysia: Stock market closed for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's stock market was closed on January 31 and February 1, 2018, for public holidays. Trading resumed on February 2.

site_title: Global cancer survival rates improve, but wide gaps remain: study
summary: Global cancer survival rates have improved, with some of the deadliest types showing significant progress, but disparities remain. The CONCORD-3 study found wide variations in cancer survival rates between countries, particularly for children, with some countries having five-year survival rates as high as 80% and others as low as 40%. The study attributed the disparities to differences in cancer diagnosis and treatment services. Despite improvements in awareness and services, cancer still claims over 100,000 children worldwide each year.

site_title: Swiss Re opens Asia HQ in Singapore; GIC adviser Lim Siong Guan chairs new regional board
summary: Swiss Re has opened its Asia headquarters in Singapore, led by a new regional board of directors chaired by Lim Siong Guan, a former GIC group president. The move aims to address regional risks, including geopolitical uncertainty and environmental concerns, as the world becomes more interconnected. The new entity Swiss Re Asia has eight offices and 1,900 staff across the Asian region, coinciding with the 50th anniversary of Swiss Re's Singapore office opening in 1968.

site_title: Europe: Cyclical reversal dents shares as results roll in
summary: European shares fell 0.9% on Tuesday, marking their largest one-day loss since early November, due to a risk-averse turn in global markets. Cyclical sectors such as mining and financials were hit hard, while defensive sectors outperformed. Investors took profits after a strong run, with basic resources stocks sinking 1.6% and banking stocks falling 1.3%. However, some companies, like Swatch and Alfa Laval, saw gains, while others, like Leonardo and Loomis, disappointed with their results.

site_title: Quiksilver CEO missing off French coast
summary: Quiksilver CEO Pierre Agnes, 54, is missing after his empty boat washed up on a beach in southwest France. Agnes had gone on a routine fishing trip but contacted the harbour master to delay his return due to fog. A search is underway with three helicopters and two boats, but searches on land have been suspended due to rough seas. Agnes, who joined Quiksilver nearly 30 years ago, was part of the company's European headquarters before it changed its name to Boardriders.

site_title: Noble's debt revamp plan kicks up storm
summary: NOBLE Group's restructuring plan has sparked outrage among shareholders and creditors, with major shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company calling for a probe into the firm. The plan, which would see the company's management own 70% of the restructured entity, has triggered credit rating cuts and led to a decline in Noble's shares. Minority investors are also seeking a more equitable deal, with Securities Investors Association Singapore urging the firm to offer existing shareholders a similar deal to the management. The plan is set to be reviewed by regulators, with Noble planning to file schemes of arrangement in several jurisdictions.

site_title: Oil falls a second day on stock market sell-off, US output
summary: Oil prices fell for a second day, with Brent crude futures dropping 44 cents to $69.02 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures falling $1.06 to $64.50 a barrel. The decline was driven by rising US crude output and a sell-off in stocks, bonds, and commodities. Investors sold off assets amid concerns that a pull-back in the stock market may be killing the bullish argument that the economy is strong. US crude inventories are expected to rise, further putting pressure on oil prices.

site_title: Volkswagen suspends company lobbyist over "repulsive" diesel fume tests
summary: Volkswagen suspended its chief lobbyist, Thomas Steg, after reports revealed the company funded a study that exposed monkeys and humans to toxic diesel fumes, methods described as "repulsive" by CEO Matthias Mueller. The study was commissioned by European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector (EUGT) and was funded by VW and German peers BMW and Daimler. The incident has raised concerns about VW's commitment to ethics and trust, with the company's supervisory board set to meet next week to discuss internal investigations.

site_title: Rare lunar eclipse offers glimpse of 'super blue blood moon'
summary: A rare lunar eclipse, dubbed a "super blue blood moon," occurred on January 31, 2018, offering a glimpse of a giant crimson moon. The event combined a blue moon, a super moon, and a total eclipse, visible in the western United States and parts of Australia and Asia. The moon appeared 14% bigger and 30% brighter due to its proximity to Earth, while the reddish tint occurred due to the scattering of sunlight. The eclipse was visible in the US West Coast and could be viewed via a live stream broadcast on NASA.gov, with moon-watching parties held across the region.

site_title: 'Glee' actor Mark Salling, who pleaded guilty to child porn, commits suicide
summary: US actor Mark Salling, 35, who pleaded guilty to child pornography, died by hanging Tuesday, weeks before his sentencing on March 7. Salling, known for his role in "Glee," had been facing up to 42 years in prison after possessing over 50,000 child pornography images. He had previously attempted suicide in August. The "Glee" star's lawyer described him as a "gentle and loving person" trying to atone for his mistakes. Authorities confirmed Salling's death, respecting the family's request for privacy.

site_title: Hawaii fires warning officer who sent missile alert believing it was real
summary: Hawaii's Emergency Management Agency administrator Vern Miyagi resigned after a false ballistic missile alert triggered mass panic across the Pacific islands. The alert, sent out by a warning officer with a history of "poor performance," was not corrected for nearly 40 minutes. The officer, who was fired, claimed he believed the threat was real, while a state report stated he had confused real-life events with drills. The incident highlighted human error, insufficient management controls, and poor computer software as contributing factors. The FCC and state investigators have implemented changes to prevent similar mistakes in the future.

site_title: EDB forecasts S$8-10b in fixed-asset investments for 2018
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) forecasts fixed-asset investments of S$8-10 billion for 2018, steady with 2016 levels. The US remains the largest source of investment, while China's share rose to 9.6%. Despite forecasts of 19,000-21,000 new jobs, only 16,000-18,000 jobs are expected to be created due to slower local workforce growth and higher-skilled industries. The EDB prioritizes workforce development, industry transformation, and innovation in 2018, with a focus on advanced manufacturing and digital capabilities.

site_title: Trump to tout strong economy in State of the Union address
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to deliver his State of the Union address, aiming to sell his economic record to a divided America. The speech is seen as an opportunity for Trump to unite the nation and improve his sagging approval ratings. An estimated 40 million Americans are expected to tune in, just after 9pm ET.

site_title: Imposing sulphur cap easier said than done
summary: Leading environmental groups and the shipping industry have called for a ban on non-compliant marine fuels by 2020, when the global 0.5% sulphur cap kicks in. The International Maritime Organisation (IMO) has agreed to lower the sulphur content in marine fuels from 3.5% to 0.5%. The proposed ban aims to ensure efficient and robust enforcement globally, preventing market distortion and unfair competition. However, concerns have been raised about the practicality of implementing the ban, including the availability of compliant fuel and the potential for technical issues with scrubbers and fuel testing.

site_title: Indian gold demand wanes as jewellers expect import tax cut
summary: Indian gold demand is waning due to high import tax rates, with jewellers expecting a potential tax cut in the annual budget. The industry has urged a 2-4% reduction in import duty to combat smuggling and unauthorised sales. Smugglers offer discounts of up to $7 an ounce, while tax evaders avoid paying GST, leading to market offers of discounts of about $2 an ounce. The government is considering a tax cut to boost India's gold demand and support global prices.

site_title: Building a new business model
summary: The article argues that the success of tech-driven companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Google has distracted investors from the need to drive growth across the global economy. It suggests that corporations and shareholders should prioritize long-term investment and real research and development to create a more sustainable business model. The article identifies common failings, including zero and negative interest rates, stock buybacks, and short-term focus, which can lead to underinvestment in essential business areas. It concludes that a shift towards long-term thinking and R&D-focused approach is necessary to address the world's economic problems and create transformative innovation.

site_title: Tencent leads acquisition of 14% stake in Wanda's property unit
summary: Chinese conglomerate Wanda Group received a 34 billion yuan (S$7 billion) investment from a group of investors, including Tencent Holdings, to acquire a 14% stake in its property arm, Wanda Commercial Properties. The investment eases pressure on Wanda to meet a listing deadline and marks a 23% gain from its 2016 price. The company will rename its unit to Wanda Commercial Management Group, focusing on management rather than property development.

site_title: Manila plans to move govt staff to new city
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's administration plans to move thousands of government workers from Manila to New Clark City, a new administrative center being built on a former US military base. The project aims to ease traffic congestion in the capital, with an estimated 50 billion pesos (S$1.3 billion) investment. The city will feature mid-rise government towers, 8,000 housing units, and a train connecting to Manila, and is expected to be completed within five years.

site_title: Amazon, Warren Buffett join forces to tackle health care
summary: Amazon, Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, and JP Morgan Chase are joining forces to create a nonprofit health care plan offering simplified, high-quality, and transparent care at a reasonable cost to US employees and their families. The trio aims to tackle rising health care costs, which have doubled as a share of the economy since the 1980s, and improve outcomes for employees and their families. The initiative will be spearheaded by a team of executives and will use combined data, technology, and buying power to cut costs and improve delivery.

site_title: Amazon opens its own rainforest in Seattle
summary: Amazon has opened a rainforest-like office space, The Spheres, in Seattle, featuring three glass domes housing 40,000 plants of 400 species. The complex aims to spark new ideas among employees, with a focus on walkways, unconventional meeting spaces, and lush environs. The investment of $3.7 billion is part of Amazon's decade-long development in the South Lake Union district, where the company has expanded its main campus. The Spheres will become part of guided campus tours and is expected to inspire creativity among Amazon employees.

images.alt_text: The Spheres' three glass domes house some 40,000 plants of 400 species.

site_title: Consumer sector to lead mergers and acquisitions growth in 2018
summary: The consumer sector is expected to lead mergers and acquisitions growth in 2018, with global transactions predicted to rise to US$632.6 billion. Asia-Pacific growth is predicted to be 21% over last year's total of US$104 billion, driven by rising GDP and younger, internet-savvy consumers. The sector is expected to be the top sector for initial public offerings this year, with a predicted 60% increase over last year. However, deal activity is forecast to drop by 13% in 2019, with M&A values expected to reach US$551.3 billion and IPOs expected to decline to US$55.1 billion.

site_title: Renault-Nissan pips VW to become 2017's top-selling carmaker
summary: Renault-Nissan surpassed Volkswagen as the world's top-selling carmaker in 2017, with total light vehicle sales of around 10.61 million, driven by Mitsubishi's inclusion. Nissan sold 5.82 million vehicles, while Renault sold 3.76 million. The alliance aims to double savings to 10 billion euros by 2022 and achieve economies of scale through shared parts and production platforms. Toyota remains second with 10.2 million units sold, while General Motors focuses on profitability through strategic sales and partnerships.

site_title: London attack accused hoped to kill Corbyn
summary: A London man, Darren Osborne, has denied charges of murdering 51-year-old Makram Ali and trying to kill others in a van attack on June 19, 2017. During his trial, Osborne stated he aimed to kill Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, calling it "one less terrorist off our streets," and also expressed a desire to kill London Mayor Sadiq Khan. Osborne, 48, from Cardiff, claims he plotted with two men to attack a pro-Palestinian march, but Corbyn was not present. Osborne denies the charges and claims another man, Dave, carried out the attack.

site_title: US: Dow posts biggest drop since May 2017 as stocks tumble
summary: US stocks fell for a second straight session, with the Dow posting its largest decline since May 2017, as health care shares tumbled due to Amazon's push into the sector. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.4% to 26,076.89, while the S&P 500 fell 1.1% to 2,822.43. Treasury bond yields spiked ahead of a Federal Reserve policy announcement and President Trump's State of the Union address. Health-related shares, including UnitedHealth Group and Cigna, plummeted 4.4% and 7.2%, respectively.

site_title: Proposed takeover of OldTown by JDE 'not anti- competitive', says CCS
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has cleared the proposed acquisition of OldTown Berhad by JDE Asia, stating it will not lead to substantial lessening of competition in the supply of instant coffee mixes and instant milk tea mixes in Singapore. The CCS conducted a public consultation and found that JDE and OldTown face competition from multiple suppliers, with low barriers to entry and negotiation power with larger customers. The proposed deal, valued at RM1.47 billion, will result in JDE Asia's parent firm JDE having sole control over OldTown.

site_title: Multiple tender closings, but bids still bullish
summary: Top bidders for three 99-year private housing sites in Singapore's batched tender exercise exceeded or reached the high end of expectations, defying tempered bullish bids from property consultants. Property giant City Developments Ltd emerged as the top bidder for two of the sites, despite the simultaneous tender closings. This indicates continued strong demand for private housing projects in Singapore.

site_title: Mulberry keeps prices down even as Brexit pushes costs up
summary: Mulberry, a UK-based handbag maker, is committed to manufacturing in Britain despite higher leather import costs due to Brexit. The company, which produces 55% of its leather goods in England, may consider opening another factory. CEO Thierry Andretta attributed the cost increase to the weakened pound and the need to maintain two-thirds of its collection at £995. Mulberry is expanding sales overseas, including Japan, and rolling out a China-based distribution centre to boost online shopping. The company aims to capture a younger clientele with updated designs and strategies.

site_title: Keppel O&M faces challenging prospects
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) faces a challenging road to recovery from its corruption scandal in Brazil, with stricter compliance controls and rising competition hindering its growth. The company booked its first quarterly loss of S$495.8 million, largely due to a S$619 million charge related to the scandal. Despite the Keppel group's financial resources, the offshore and marine business may take a back seat in the group's strategy, with demand still recovering in the offshore drilling market and prevalent risks in the industry.

site_title: Global jobs abound but wage gains stay soft
summary: The global labor market is experiencing a strong employment cycle, with jobless rates falling across the G7 industrialized economies. However, wage growth remains sluggish, with many countries reporting high rates of labor underutilization and discouraged workers. The disconnect stems from economists and policymakers underestimating slack in the labor market, which has augmented full employment. As global growth firms up and business investment picks up, wage growth is expected to rise, but modest wage growth has kept enthusiasm in check, influencing central bank monetary policy decisions.

site_title: Asia's 2018 refined oil product demand to rise 2%: Woodmac
summary: Asia's fuel demand is expected to rise 2% in 2018, driven by expanding economies, with China and India accounting for 40% of global demand growth. Asia's oil product demand will average 34.5 million barrels per day, up 630,000 bpd from 2017. Refiners are expected to increase crude oil distillation capacity to meet the increase, but delays could lead to supply and demand imbalances, potentially tightening the market and increasing profits for existing facilities.

site_title: Market highs: Investors should beware widespread complacency
summary: The US stock market is nearing its ninth year of recovery, with corporate earnings forecast to remain robust. However, some investors should be cautious due to economic expansions averaging eight years, and a reliance on central bank intervention for growth. Labour productivity growth has stagnated since 2010, and the US stands out as one of the most expensive stock markets, according to Schroders. As equity markets continue their upward march, prudent investors should be aware of potential hurdles ahead and consider valuations when making investment decisions.

site_title: Katzenberg guns for mobile TV mash-up of HBO and YouTube
summary: Jeffrey Katzenberg, former studio chief, is launching a new startup called NewTV, aiming to create short-form, high-end content for mobile devices. The venture, which will produce award-worthy, binge-ready original series, seeks to merge the quality of HBO with the ubiquity of YouTube. With the help of Hewlett-Packard Enterprise CEO Meg Whitman, NewTV aims to attract 18-34-year-olds who currently prefer non-professional short-form videos on mobile devices. The startup has reportedly sought $2 billion in funding and plans to operate as a premium, subscription-based model.

site_title: MAS mopping up excess liquidity amid decline in interest rates
summary: MAS is increasing the size of its bill auctions amid a decline in interest rates, with weekly bill auction sizes rising from S$1.4 billion to S$1.6 billion for one-month bills and S$5.8 billion for three-month bills. This move aims to mop up excess liquidity in the banking system. The decline in interest rates, largely due to the weakened US dollar, has slowed, with the three-month SOR and Sibor rates steadying at levels last seen in October and November. Analysts warn of a potential snapback in interest rates, but some expect a gradual increase in SOR rates this year.

site_title: UOB brings cheer to SPD beneficiaries
summary: About 200 UOB employees and clients assisted 130 individuals with special needs from SPD in Singapore's Chinese New Year preparations, including grocery shopping and distributing gifts. The event, led by UOB's deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong, is part of the bank's annual tradition of giving back to the community. The activities included a sing-along session and the distribution of festive goodie bags, with proceeds going to support SPD and other charities.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Micro-Mechanics Holdings' Q2 FY18 revenue and profit missed expectations, with revenue and earnings growth below forecasts. The company's semiconductor sales surged in October and November, but the weaker-than-expected results are attributed to currency movement and inventory loading. RHB Research downgrades Micro-Mechanics to accumulate due to limited upside. Meanwhile, Starhill Global Reit's Q2 FY18 results also fell short of estimates, with the retail and office markets in Singapore remaining challenging. The company's asset enhancement initiatives are expected to contribute positively to DPU from FY19 onwards.

site_title: New programme for SMU undergrads to shadow SME owners
summary: The Singapore Management University (SMU) has launched the Entrepreneur Shadow Programme, a new initiative to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) secure young talent. Undergraduates in their final two years will shadow SME owners, document their observations, and provide targeted recommendations. The programme aims to provide students with business experience and knowledge, while SMEs benefit from fresh perspectives and skilled talent. This is part of a tie-up between United Overseas Bank (UOB) and SMU's Asian Enterprise Institute (AEI).

site_title: SGX-backed independent research firms a solution to better stocks coverage
summary: Independent research firms backed by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) aim to provide better coverage of smaller-cap stocks, addressing the issue of brokerage houses ceasing coverage due to cost pressures. This move could boost investor education and increase market volume. SGX-backed research houses would be given financial support, independence, and leeway to make calls on companies, similar to the SGX-MAS Research Incentive Scheme established in 2003. This could lead to more research on mid and small-cap stocks, benefiting retail investors and the market as a whole.

site_title: US authorities charge 3 banks, 8 individuals in futures 'spoofing' probe
summary: US authorities have charged three European banks, UBS, Deutsche Bank, and HSBC, and eight individuals for alleged "spoofing" in the US futures and commodities market. The banks agreed to pay $46.6 million to settle the cases, with Deutsche Bank and UBS paying $30 million and $15 million, respectively. The charges are related to placing bids to buy or sell futures contracts with the intent to cancel them before execution, a criminal offence under the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law. The case marks the first time the Justice Department and the CFTC have worked together to bring both criminal and civil charges against multiple companies and individuals.

site_title: OUE H-Trust posts lower DPS
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust posted a 6.6% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.27 cents for the fourth quarter ended 2017, due to higher interest expenses and absence of income support. Despite this, its hospitality segment saw higher master lease income from Mandarin Orchard Singapore and Crowne Plaza Changi Airport, while retail revenues slipped. The company expects the market environment to remain competitive, with the return of large events and cautious tenants.

site_title: Najib waiting for 'inspiration' to call polls
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is waiting for inspiration to decide when to call a general election, with less than six months remaining until the end of his five-year term. He faces a challenge from former mentor and ex-premier Mahathir Mohamad, who has led efforts to unseat Najib due to a multi-billion dollar scandal. Najib has denied wrongdoing, but polls suggest he is still widely expected to win, despite a divided opposition and criticism of electoral boundaries.

site_title: Italy's Snam seeking to shift gas hub away from UK to S Europe
summary: Italy's Snam is seeking to shift its gas hub from the UK to southern Europe, aiming to make Italy an exporter of natural gas for the first time. The company, with new supplies from the Caspian Sea and tankers, is building a pipeline network to capitalize on the region's growing demand. This move could accelerate the shift away from the UK, which has seen declining gas production, and towards the Netherlands and southern Europe.

site_title: Scientists achieve breakthrough in human genome sequencing with pocket-sized device
summary: Scientists have achieved a breakthrough in human genome sequencing using a portable device, no bigger than a cellphone, that can read long, unbroken strands of DNA with 99.88% accuracy. This technology, called nanopore sequencing, has the potential to revolutionize personalized medicine, allowing doctors to sequence genomes during regular check-ups. The device can also identify cancer DNA in the blood and detect viruses and bacteria in patients with suspected infections. The cost of sequencing a human genome has decreased significantly, from $3 billion in 2003 to a few thousand dollars, making it more accessible and paving the way for widespread adoption in the near future.

site_title: Cyberattackers take aim at top 3 Dutch banks, govt services
summary: Cyberattackers targeted the top 3 Dutch banks (ABN Amro, ING, Rabobank) and government services, including the Dutch Revenue Service and digital signature system, in a series of DDoS attacks over the past week. The attacks blocked access to websites and internet banking services, but were quickly resolved. The Dutch central bank chief stated that these attacks are serious, but the country's website is also under constant attack. Experts emphasized the need for continued investment in digital safety to counter the evolving threat of DDoS attacks.

images.alt_text: ING, the top Dutch bank by assets, experienced a "distributed denial of service" attack on Sunday evening, which was restored while ABN Amro and Rabobank bounced back from fleeting attacks.

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise gives Singapore firms a leg-up in innovation
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has launched its InnovateNext programme in Singapore, a five-year initiative worth $140 million to support local startups in developing innovative solutions in hybrid IT, IoT, and data analytics. The programme, in collaboration with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB), aims to co-innovate and commercialize new technologies with 12 startups, with the goal of developing market-viable solutions worldwide. The move is seen as a strategic partnership to tap into Singapore's vibrant startup ecosystem and accelerate technological advancements in the region.

site_title: Maze Runner outruns Jumanji to lead US box office
summary: Maze Runner: The Death Cure led the US box office, earning $24.2 million over the weekend. Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle took in $16.1 million, while Hostiles and The Greatest Showman followed in third and fourth place, respectively. The Post, starring Tom Hanks and Meryl Streep, rounded out the top 10 with $9.1 million. These films outperformed other releases, including 12 Strong, Den of Thieves, and The Shape of Water.

site_title: Singapore stocks pull back on bond rout
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 28.33 points or 0.8% to 3,548.74 on Tuesday, its lowest finish in nearly two weeks, following a global bond rout. The decline was led by technology and energy stocks, but experts believe it may be a temporary blip. They point to factors such as global synchronized growth, tax cuts, and strong earnings growth as supporting the rally, and note that the rise in bond yields may create headwinds for equities in the short term.

site_title: Philips shares fall after Q4 profit misses estimates
summary: Philips shares fell after the company's Q4 profit missed estimates, primarily due to the weaker US dollar affecting earnings. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, and amortization rose 9% to €884 million, missing the average analyst estimate of €898.2 million. Despite this, comparable sales rose 5% and orders climbed 7%, with the company aiming to boost revenue through partnerships with hospitals and possible acquisitions. CEO Frans van Houten expressed satisfaction with growth in orders and plans to continue exploring acquisitions.

site_title: Procurri eyes turnaround in 2018 with changed profile
summary: Procurri, a Singapore-based enterprise hardware vendor, is expected to make a net loss for 2017 but is turning a corner in 2018. The company has secured a seven-digit maintenance contract from a European pharmaceutical firm and has a strong order book. Procurri's higher margin lifecycle services business accounts for 30% of gross profit, with "hardware-as-a-service" being a key growth area. The company aims to reduce costs and explore small acquisitions to further grow its business.

site_title: ElderShield review panel calls for compulsory severe disability insurance
summary: A Singaporean ElderShield review panel recommends making the severe disability insurance scheme compulsory for all citizens, starting at age 30. The government will administer the scheme, and claims will be simplified. The panel aims to provide a social safety net for those with disabilities, as half of Singaporeans are at risk of long-term disability by age 65. The committee also plans to help low-income individuals afford premiums and adjust payouts and duration.

site_title: Should you pay more taxes if you live near the subway?
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo's plan to implement "value capture" – taxing property owners for their proximity to the subway – aims to generate revenue for the subway system. The proposal, which has sparked opposition from Mayor Bill de Blasio, would allow the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) to designate "transit improvement subdistricts" and impose taxes on property owners. The plan's proponents argue that it's a necessary measure to address the subway's financial crisis, while opponents claim it would unfairly burden property owners and undermine the city's property tax system.

site_title: Saudis reap US$107b in graft pacts; 56 still held
summary: Saudi authorities have recovered over $107 billion from 380 people held under a corruption investigation, but 56 suspects remain in custody due to pending cases. The payments include assets like real estate, securities, and cash. Some individuals were released for lack of evidence, while others, like billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, were released after settling with the government. The anti-corruption drive, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has raised concerns about transparency and its impact on foreign investors.

site_title: Michelin allows top French chef to pull out of guide
summary: Top French chef Sebastien Bras has withdrawn his restaurant, Le Suquet, from the Michelin guide due to the "huge pressure" of being judged by inspectors. This marks the first time a restaurant has been allowed to withdraw from the guide. Bras, who held the maximum three-star rating for 18 years, cited the risk of losing his reputation due to a single below-par dish. The decision comes after Bras announced he would relinquish his three-star status, citing the pressure and stress of the Michelin system.

site_title: India's budget needs to bring focus back on growth
summary: India's upcoming budget, set to be presented by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, aims to revive economic growth, which is expected to expand at a 6.5% pace in 2018, the slowest in four years. The government seeks to address structural issues, including agriculture, rural distress, and high non-performing assets. Infrastructure development, particularly in roads, ports, and airports, is also expected to receive major attention. The budget may also include initiatives on income tax and corporate tax, with a focus on sustained long-term growth rather than short-term gains.

site_title: Verizon follows AT&T in ditching plans to sell Huawei phones amid spying concerns
summary: Verizon has dropped plans to sell Huawei phones in the US amid US government concerns about Chinese spying, following AT&T's decision to not introduce the Mate 10 Pro. The move is part of a broader conflict between the US and China, with the US seeking to limit Chinese companies' access to the US market. Huawei is pushing to be among the first to offer 5G-capable phones, but US carriers are wary due to security risks. The US government is considering plans to nationalize 5G network construction, despite industry leaders' opposition.

site_title: McDonald's investors hungry for more growth after comeback
summary: McDonald's has left investors wanting more growth despite matching Wall Street estimates for US comparable sales growth last quarter. The company's shares slipped 1.9% due to a high valuation and the expectation of continued beating estimates. McDonald's US strategy has become a "race to the bottom" with discounts and promotions, but it remains to be seen how long the company can fuel growth by appealing to Americans' penny-pinching instincts. Despite this, McDonald's globally exceeded estimates with a 5.5% sales increase and profit beating estimates.

site_title: US businesses optimistic on China growth but bemoan unfair treatment
summary: US businesses are optimistic about China's growth, with 46% of respondents expressing confidence that the government will further open its market to foreign investment within three years. However, three-quarters of members feel unwelcome by the Chinese government. The American Chamber of Commerce in China calls for "even-handed enforcement of laws and regulations" to reduce trade frictions. US President Donald Trump's visit to China may have contributed to improved perceptions, but his administration's hard line on China's intellectual property has raised concerns about further tariffs. The chamber advocates for investment reciprocity and multilateral trade agreements.

site_title: New Datapulse CEO quits; board says directors were in touch with controversial vendor two weeks before their appointment
summary: Datapulse Technology's CEO, Kee Swee Ann, has quit the company just a month into the job. The board defended its decision to acquire a Malaysian personal care product business, Wayco Manufacturing, citing a need to avoid trading suspension and delisting if Datapulse ceased operating. The board had been in touch with Wayco's owner, Ang Kong Meng, two weeks before the acquisition. The company's new interim CEO, Lee Kam Seng, will oversee finances and corporate governance. The board denies any wrongdoing and says it acted in the company's best interests.

site_title: The guerilla wins if he does not lose
summary: The Tet Offensive, launched 50 years ago by Vietnamese revolutionaries, remains a significant lesson for the US in its ongoing conflicts in Afghanistan and the Middle East. The coordinated attacks shattered the US's confidence in winning a war against guerrilla forces, leading to a withdrawal of US troops and the eventual defeat of the US-backed South Vietnamese government. The US's inability to combat guerrilla forces, as highlighted by Henry Kissinger, has been a recurring theme in its conflicts, with parallels drawn to the US's experiences in Vietnam and ongoing struggles in Afghanistan and Iraq.

site_title: US consumer confidence rebounds in Jan
summary: US consumer confidence rebounded in January, rising to 125.4 from 123.1 in December, as expectations for the next six months improved. The present situation index dipped slightly, but remains at historically strong levels. Consumers remain confident about the solid pace of growth in 2017 continuing into 2018, with optimism about business conditions improving slightly. However, income prospects remain uncertain, with a slight decline in those expecting income to increase.

site_title: Dollar reverses gains as bond yields soften
summary: The US dollar is set for its biggest monthly decline since July 2017 against the euro, amid strong global growth and slow inflation. However, a spike in global bond yields led to a brief increase in the dollar's value. The dollar declined 0.2% against a basket of six major currencies, reaching a low of 88.43, its weakest level since December 2014. Analysts expect the dollar's weakness to continue, with investors waiting for US President Donald Trump's State of the Union speech for further guidance.

site_title: When euphoria may turn to despair
summary: The 10-year US Treasury yield has reached 2.7%, its steepest monthly increase since November 2016, catching investors off-guard and raising concerns about a potential sell-off in equities and corporate bonds. Experts predict that a 3% yield could be the breaking point for stocks, leading to higher corporate financing costs, loss of market momentum, and a decline in growth. Investors are bracing for potential pain in the municipal bond market, with yields on Treasuries and munis rising faster than expected. The market is waiting for inflation to pick up and send interest rates higher, but elevated asset prices and risk of a global increase in inflation are also concerns.

site_title: Board: Wayco buy aimed at avoiding delisting
summary: Datapulse Technology, a Singaporean digital media storage manufacturer, has acquired Wayco Manufacturing, a Malaysian business that makes personal care and household products, in a deal aimed at avoiding delisting from the Singapore Exchange. The board of Datapulse claims its decision to buy Wayco was partly driven by the risk of being deemed a cash company and facing a trading suspension. The company's new CEO, Kee Swee Ann, has resigned, and the board has denied allegations of "undue haste" in the deal. The board also stated that it had sufficient opportunity to review and consider the acquisition before deciding to undertake it.

site_title: Microsoft issues update to disable Intel's buggy Spectre patch
summary: Microsoft has released an emergency update to disable Intel's buggy Spectre patch, which was causing computers to reboot more frequently. The update, released nearly four weeks after Intel confirmed the issue, aims to prevent system instability and data loss or corruption. The Spectre and Meltdown vulnerabilities, affecting nearly every modern computing device, were identified by Intel and Microsoft. The patches have been deemed faulty, and Intel advises customers to stop installing them. The update can be manually downloaded from the Microsoft Update Catalog website.

site_title: Oil falls for a second day as investor risk appetite wanes
summary: Oil prices fell for a second day, with Brent crude futures down 46 US cents to US$69.00 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures down US$1.00 to US$64.56 a barrel. The decline was driven by rising US crude output, weak investor risk appetite, and a stronger US dollar. The US dollar's negative correlation to oil prices has strengthened, with expectations of rising US inventories also contributing to the decline.

site_title: HPE partner gridComm lights up smart cities
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) partner gridComm has successfully implemented smart city lighting systems in Singapore, reducing energy consumption by 50% in cities worldwide. The company's technology uses wireless networks over power lines to control street lighting levels in real-time, enabling predictive maintenance and cost savings. With HPE data analytics, gridComm has enabled a holistic solution for smart city applications, including traffic, pollution, and weather monitoring. The partnership aims to expand gridComm's network to other cities, promoting a more efficient and cost-effective approach to urban infrastructure management.

site_title: Datapulse Technology saga presents a challenge to SGX rules
summary: The Datapulse Technology saga raises concerns about the effectiveness of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) rules in protecting minority shareholders' interests. A controlling shareholder, Ng Siew Hong, acquired a 29% stake in the company at a significant premium through several married deals. The company's board, including its chairman, failed to disclose key information and made questionable decisions, including the rapid acquisition of a Malaysian company, Wayco Manufacturing, without due diligence. The acquisition may not be in the best interest of minority shareholders, and the SGX's rules on interested person transactions (IPTs) are unclear. The board's lack of transparency and strategic thinking has led to concerns about the company's governance and compliance with listing rules.

site_title: Luxe tour agency Scott Dunn buys Singapore's Country Holidays
summary: Luxury tour agency Scott Dunn has acquired Singapore's Country Holidays, becoming Asia's largest bespoke tour agency. The acquisition, valued at 100% of Country Holidays' business, is expected to boost Scott Dunn's revenue to S$290 million. Country Holidays, specializing in bespoke travel, will be rebranded as Scott Dunn and will expand its European destinations portfolio. The acquisition brings in Country Holidays' 10,000 customers and is expected to increase Scott Dunn's staff strength to over 300 employees.

site_title: Mandatory offer for TMC Education closes with valid acceptances of 2.05%
summary: A mandatory takeover offer by Singapore tycoon Koh Wee Meng's investment holding firm JK Global Asset for TMC Education Corporation has closed with valid acceptances of 2.05%. The offer, made at 6.75 cents per share, was deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent financial adviser ZICO Capital. The offeror now controls 53.05% of TMC Education's shares, following the acquisition of a 51% stake from controlling shareholders.

site_title: Robot delivery vans may hit your street before self-driving cars
summary: Nuro, a Silicon Valley startup, has unveiled an autonomous delivery vehicle designed to carry packages, not people. The vehicle, which weighs 1,500 pounds and is roughly the size of an SUV, can navigate through streets without a driver and is powered by an electric motor. Nuro plans to partner with companies like Amazon and UPS to deliver packages, aiming to revolutionize the last-mile of delivery. With its minimalist design and modular interior, Nuro believes its cargo vehicle has a clearer path to profit than passenger self-driving cars.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SMRT Corporation appointed Abu Bakar Mohd Nor as a board director, effective January 23. Meanwhile, CATALIST-listed QT Vascular completed the sale of its Chocolate PTA balloon catheter to Medtronic for US$28 million. In other news, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Additionally, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Saudis reap 400b riyals in graft pacts as 56 remain held
summary: Saudi authorities have agreed to settle corruption cases with 381 suspects, recovering over 400 billion riyals (S$140 billion). However, 56 suspects remain held due to ongoing investigations. The anti-corruption drive, launched by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has raised concerns about transparency among foreign investors, with some seeing it as a means to level the playing field among investors and drive economic diversification.

site_title: Saudi Sipchem mulls first US petrochemicals investment
summary: Saudi Arabia's Sipchem is considering its first US petrochemicals investment based on shale gas, aiming to tap into the booming industry. The company, facing higher costs and feedstock shortages at home, may seek a US partner. Sipchem's CEO, Ahmad Al Ohali, stated that the company is targeting a US project this year, despite the challenges of the US business landscape. This move is seen as an effort to diversify and capitalize on the US shale industry, which has reduced America's reliance on imported energy and threatened OPEC's market share.

site_title: Ammonia leak at QAF's warehouse prompts stop work order
summary: An ammonia leak occurred at QAF Limited's warehouse in Singapore, prompting a stop work order. Four employees were hospitalized but discharged, and the incident is under investigation by the Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority. The Ministry of Manpower has issued a stop work order until measures are taken, and QAF is in discussion with authorities to resume operations. The incident is ongoing, with investigations and potential impacts to be determined later.

site_title: Indonesia's fintech lending boom exploits shortfall in bank loans
summary: Indonesia's fintech lending boom is helping alleviate a US$73 billion financing shortfall, with over 250,000 people taking out loans through peer-to-peer (P2P) platforms. Fintech firms offer cheap loans, with some platforms accepting less than a fifth of loan applicants to curb risk. The trend has been welcomed by Indonesia's financial regulators, who see it as a much-needed service to cash-strapped businesses and consumers. However, analysts warn that a more accurate credit assessment process must be developed to ensure the stability of the fintech industry.

site_title: US: Dow off 250 points after opening bell
summary: US stocks fell for a second straight day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 249.83 points, or 0.94%, to 26,189.65, due to a rise in bond yields and a drop in healthcare shares. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 losing 24.32 points, or 0.85%, to 2,829.21, and the Nasdaq dropping 78.76 points, or 1.05%, to 7,387.75.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close down on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 1.94 points to 1,868.58 on Tuesday, with 794 losers outweighing 252 gainers. The index saw 3.25 billion shares traded worth RM2.89 billion.

site_title: Signs of upswing in Sentosa property market
summary: The Sentosa property market in Singapore is showing signs of an upswing, with 65 units transacted in 2017, more than double the 31 in 2016. The market, which includes Sentosa Cove, a luxury residential enclave, is expected to see further deals in 2018, with prices forecast to rise 8-10% in 2018. The niche market is appealing to buyers looking for a resort lifestyle, despite its limited accessibility and higher costs. Experts attribute the revival to falling prices and the perception of value in Sentosa properties.

images.alt_text: After the hiatus of the past few years, there are signs that interest in buying on Sentosa is reviving, though more slowly than for the rest of Singapore.

site_title: Banker bonuses jumping while traders brace for smaller payouts
summary: Wall Street bankers saw their bonuses for 2017 increase by about 5% due to record debt-underwriting fees, while traders in sales and fixed-income trading divisions braced for smaller payouts. The gap may widen in 2018 as the US tax overhaul sparks a surge in mergers. Investment-banking fees at the five biggest US firms jumped 17% to $31 billion, while fixed-income trading personnel saw a 12% decline. Banker bonuses didn't rise as sharply as revenue, with some firms cushioning the impact to avoid abrupt changes.

site_title: CMA CGM unveils new global start-up incubator Ze Box to drive digital strategy
summary: French container shipping giant CMA CGM has launched Ze Box, a global startup incubator to drive its digital strategy. Located in Marseilles, France, the incubator will house 12 startups starting in June, with a call for applications to be launched soon. Ze Box aims to accelerate CMA CGM's digital transformation and develop global innovations, combining expertise with startups to create value for customers and the company. This move follows recent initiatives, including the setup of CMA CGM Ventures and new partnerships with major e-business firms.

site_title: May's China trip revisits 'golden age' in ties
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to embark on her first official visit to China from Wednesday to Friday, seeking to deepen the bilateral strategic partnership and build on the momentum of President Xi Jinping's 2015 London visit, dubbed the "golden age" in ties. The visit will focus on economics, with discussions on trade, investment, and infrastructure, as well as security issues. China is the UK's second-largest non-EU trade partner, and the two countries are expected to announce several trade and financial deals during the visit. The trip aims to enhance ties despite concerns from Washington about the UK's close relationship with Beijing.

site_title: Has new owner bitten off more than she can chew?
summary: Singaporean accountant Ng Siew Hong, a new owner of 29% stake in Datapulse Technology, faces a shareholder mutiny amid concerns over the independence of the revamped board and a perceived rushed buyout of a Malaysian-incorporated firm from a party she has ties with. Ng had bought the shares at a premium, and her turnaround plan involves the acquisition of Wayco Manufacturing, which has sparked a storm due to the lack of due diligence. A group led by Ng Bie Tjin and Uniseraya Holdings is contesting the new board appointments and diversification plan, and two EGMs will be held by Feb 26.

site_title: Vaping may raise cancer risk: study
summary: A US study found that vaping may raise cancer risk due to DNA damage, despite containing fewer carcinogens than tobacco smoke. Lab mice exposed to e-cigarette smoke showed higher DNA damage in key organs, and human lung and bladder cells exposed to nicotine and nicotine-derived compounds were more likely to mutate and become cancerous. While vaping is considered a safer alternative to traditional cigarettes, the study suggests a potential increased risk of lung and bladder cancers and heart diseases.

site_title: MTQ announces rights cum warrants issue to raise up to S$15.5m in net proceeds
summary: MTQ Corporation has proposed a renounceable underwritten rights cum warrants issue to raise up to S$15.5 million in net proceeds. The issue involves the sale of up to 61.81 million new ordinary shares at 20 cents each and 15.45 million free detachable warrants, with each warrant carrying the right to subscribe for one share at 22 cents. The proposed issue price represents a 50% discount to the closing price of MTQ shares on January 30. The company aims to strengthen its financial position and provide greater flexibility for its business plans.

site_title: US releases 'Putin list' of Russians eligible for sanctions
summary: The US Treasury released a list of 114 Russian officials and 96 business leaders eligible for sanctions, including top officials in President Vladimir Putin's administration and oligarchs worth at least $1 billion. The list, which does not trigger sanctions immediately, features prominent figures such as Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev. The release of the list, under a law passed by Congress, aims to punish Russia for alleged meddling in the 2016 US election and destabilizing Ukraine.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde urges urgent action as Arab discontent bubbles
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde urged Arab governments to take urgent action to create jobs and increase social spending to address simmering public discontent. The Arab world's growth is forecast at 3.5% in 2018 and 2019, below the 5.6% average from 2000-2008. Protests have broken out in Tunisia, Egypt, and Morocco, with demands for jobs and investment. Lagarde emphasized the need for broader and more equitable tax bases and private-sector job creation to ease the burden on state budgets.

site_title: Leaked Brexit economic forecasts rekindles old UK debate
summary: A leaked UK government report on the economic impact of Brexit has reignited the debate on the country's decision to leave the European Union. The report, which was initially meant to be secret, predicts that the hardest Brexit would leave the economy 8% smaller than expected in 15 years, while the softest would slow growth by 2%. The leak comes as the UK government is divided on the best approach to Brexit, with some arguing that Britain's trade opportunities lie beyond Europe and others suggesting that a closer relationship with the EU is necessary to mitigate the economic impact.

site_title: CDL places top bids for Handy Road, West Coast Vale plots at URA tender
summary: CDL places top bids for two 99-year leasehold private housing sites at a URA tender, with total bids of S$212.2 million for a Handy Road plot and S$472.4 million for a West Coast Vale plot. CDL's top bid for Handy Road is S$1,722 psf ppr, while for West Coast Vale it's S$800 psf ppr. The group plans to develop three residential towers on the Handy Road site and two 36-storey towers on the West Coast Vale site, with a total of about 200 apartments.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Erupting volcano sparks Philippine tourism boom
summary: The Philippines is experiencing a tourism boom due to the eruption of Mayon volcano, with many tourists flocking to view the volcano from viewing decks and hotels offering "volcano-view" rooms. The eruption has sparked a business boom in the region, with restaurants and hotels near the volcano offering unique attractions such as "lava ice cream" and live TV streaming of the eruption. However, the disaster has also brought misery to many farmers who have lost crops due to volcanic ash, and nearly 90,000 people have fled to overcrowded relief camps.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks skid over 1%; won ends at more than 1-month low
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 1.17% to 2,567.79, marking its lowest close in over a month. The won dropped to a 1-month low, closing at 1,073.6 per dollar. Bond yields rose, and foreign investors were net sellers of 175.78 billion won worth of shares. The US dollar has risen 0.63% against the won this year, and the KOSPI index is up 5.3% so far this year.

site_title: Mulberry banks on UK heritage even as Brexit vote nudges up costs
summary: Mulberry, a UK handbag maker, remains committed to manufacturing in Britain despite higher leather import costs since the Brexit vote. The company produces about 55% of its leather goods in England and sees Britain as its biggest market. CEO Thierry Andretta said Mulberry will continue to balance costs and consider opening another factory in England. The brand is expanding overseas, with a China-based distribution centre planned for later in 2018, and is trying to capture a younger clientele with updated designs.

site_title: UK watchdog presses banks on "ticking time bomb" of interest-only home loans
