summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has urged banks to step up checks on 1.7 million customers with interest-only home loans, as regulators warn that many have no clear plan for repaying capital. The FCA has previously labeled the interest-only mortgage market a "ticking time bomb," citing concerns that customers may lose their homes due to shortfalls in repayment plans. Despite progress in reducing the number of interest-only mortgages, the FCA remains concerned about the risk of borrowers defaulting on their loans.

site_title: Singapore's Competition Commission clears proposed acquisition of OldTown by JBE Asia
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore has cleared the proposed acquisition of OldTown Berhad by JBE Asia, a subsidiary of Jacobs Douwe Egberts Holdings Asia NL BV. The acquisition will result in JDE Asia's parent firm, JDE, having sole control over OldTown. The CCS concluded that the deal will not lead to a substantial lessening of competition in the supply of instant coffee mixes and instant milk tea mixes for in-home sales in Singapore. The deal was examined after a public consultation and feedback from intermediate customers, which found barriers to entry and negotiation power with the merged entity.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slid at the start of trading on Tuesday, following sharp losses in Asia and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 retreated 0.8%, and Paris's CAC 40 lost 0.5%. The declines came as traders banked profits from recent strong gains.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.8% down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 0.8% lower at 3,548.74 on Tuesday, following an overnight sell-off in Wall Street. The index saw 3.2 billion shares traded worth S$1.6 billion, with losers outpacing gainers 324-150.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank sued for alleged rate rigging by regulator
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia is being sued by the Australian Securities & Investments Commission for allegedly rigging the benchmark bank-bill swap rate from January to October 2012. The regulator alleges "unconscionable conduct and market manipulation" to maximize profits and minimize losses. This is the last of the nation's big-four lenders to face similar claims, following agreements from Westpac and National Australia Bank to pay A$50 million each to settle. Commonwealth Bank disputes the allegations, amid other legal problems including allegations of anti-money laundering breaches and a class-action lawsuit.

images.alt_text: Commonwealth Bank of Australia is being sued by the nation's securities regulator for allegedly rigging the benchmark bank-bill swap rate, adding to legal problems for the nation's largest lender.

site_title: Doing business in South Korea getting harder: EU firms
summary: More than three in five European Union executives say doing business in South Korea has become harder due to rising labour costs, ambiguous rules, market access barriers, and inconsistent regulations. A survey by the EU Chamber of Commerce in Korea found 61% of respondents feel it has become more challenging than two years ago. Despite President Moon Jae-In's promise of reforms, the EU Chamber of Commerce stated that substantial changes have not been made, citing a need for more transparent policymaking and improved rule of law.

site_title: China Eastern cancels holiday flights amid dispute with Taiwan
summary: China Eastern Airlines and Xiamen Airlines cancelled 176 flights to Taiwan due to a dispute between the two governments. The cancellations were sparked by China's approval of four new flight routes over the Taiwan Strait, which Beijing considers a province to be reunited with the mainland. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing Wen's administration refused to approve the flights, citing concerns over aviation safety and national security. The dispute is the latest escalation in tensions between China and Taiwan, with China cutting off communications with the island in 2016.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down for fifth straight day
summary: Tokyo stocks declined for the fifth consecutive day, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.43% to 23,291.97 and the Topix index dropping 1.19% to 1,858.13. The decline was attributed to a strong yen and a retreat from records on Wall Street.

site_title: Scott Dunn buys Singapore's Country Holidays to form Asia's largest bespoke tour agency
summary: Scott Dunn, a London-based luxury tour agency, acquired Singapore's Country Holidays to form Asia's largest bespoke tour agency. The deal, valued but undisclosed, will increase Scott Dunn's staff strength to over 300 employees. Existing Country Holidays customers will benefit from expanded support and a new hotline. Revenue is expected to rise to S$290 million in 2018, with no staff cuts planned. Country Holidays founder Chang Theng Hwee will become Scott Dunn's Asia chief executive, and the combined company aims for a 31,000 customer base in 2018.

site_title: Swatch "very positive" about 2018 after 2017 profit up 28 per cent
summary: Swatch Group reported a 28% increase in net profit in 2017, driven by improved demand for Swiss watches, particularly among Chinese shoppers. The company expects "very positive" growth in 2018, driven by its own distribution channels and third-party channels, with production areas also expected to utilize their capacities.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower with Asia retreat
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index losing 1.09% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 0.99%. The decline followed cautious investor sentiment ahead of economic data and earnings reports. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.53%. The losses were part of a broader Asia-wide retreat, with traders brushing off new US trade threats to extend stocks rallies.

site_title: OUE H-Trust Q4 DPS slips to 1.27 S cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 4.2% decline in Q4 income available for distribution to S$23.0 million, and a 1.8% increase in gross revenue to S$33.8 million. The trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) slipped to 1.27 Singapore cents from 1.36 Singapore cents in the previous year. The hospitality segment posted higher revenue, while the retail segment saw lower revenue. The trust highlighted its highest recorded annual distributable income of S$92.9 million in 2017.

site_title: Philips quarterly profit rises amid strong orders in China
summary: Royal Philips NV reported a 9% increase in fourth-quarter adjusted profit to 884 million euros, exceeding the average analyst estimate of 898.2 million euros. Orders were strong in China and North America for its diagnosis-equipment business. Comparable sales rose 5% and orders increased 7% for the quarter. The company aims to meet its 4-6% growth target and has pledged to improve profit margins by refocusing on healthcare equipment and services.

site_title: China's Shanxi province asks coal miners to cut or shorten holidays: document
summary: China's Shanxi province has asked coal miners to shorten or eliminate staff holidays during the upcoming Spring Festival to manage a wild price rally and ensure fuel supplies. This comes after Reuters reported that four top utilities warned of heating and electricity shortages due to tight coal supplies. The province aims to cut coal capacity by 23 million tonnes this year and streamline the sector. Thermal coal futures have gained 10% this year, highlighting the need for increased supplies. The request follows Shanxi's efforts to cut capacity and close small mines.

site_title: Renault-Nissan group pips VW to become top-selling carmaker in 2017
summary: The Renault-Nissan group surpassed Volkswagen as the world's top-selling carmaker in 2017, with a total of 10.61 million light vehicle sales. Nissan Motor Co. reported a record 5.82 million sales, while Renault SA sold 3.76 million, and Mitsubishi Motors added 1.03 million. The alliance's combined sales beat Volkswagen's 2016 record of 10.53 million.

images.alt_text: The Renault-Nissan automaking alliance emerged as the world's biggest seller of light vehicles in 2017, bumping Volkswagen AG off the top spot, after the inclusion of Mitsubishi Motors' numbers boosted its final tally.

site_title: SAP talks up cloud business, buys Callidus software for US$2.4b
summary: SAP posted 2017 results below market expectations, despite a "dynamite" final quarter in its cloud business. The company reported a 6% increase in fourth-quarter non-IFRS operating profit to €2.37 billion, beating analyst expectations. SAP also announced a $2.4 billion acquisition of Callidus Software Inc, its first major acquisition in 3.5 years. The company expects sustained margin improvements in 2018, with total non-IFRS revenue projected to grow 5-7% and operating profit to increase by 8-11%.

images.alt_text: SAP posted 2017 results on the lower side of market expectations after Chief Executive Bill McDermott had promised a "dynamite" final quarter in its cloud business, as Europe's top technology company announced a US$2.4 billion US acquisition.

site_title: Noble's restructuring plan leaves major shareholder Goldilocks upset; Sias calls for more equitable terms
summary: Noble Group's restructuring plan has upset major shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company, which holds 8.1% of the firm. Goldilocks and minority investor advocacy group Securities Investors Association (Singapore) (Sias) are calling for an investigation into Noble's management, citing concerns over the steep cut in shareholder and creditor shareholdings and favorable terms for management. A group of senior creditors will own 70% of the restructured company, with existing shareholders holding 10%. Noble's shares plummeted 11.5% on the news, with the stock falling to 20 Singapore cents.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO says diesel fume tests on monkeys were "repulsive"
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller has apologized for the company's involvement in a 2014 study using monkeys to test the effects of diesel fumes, calling the methods "unethical and repulsive." The study, commissioned by the European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector (EUGT), was intended to defend diesel after revelations of its carcinogenic properties. Volkswagen is investigating EUGT's work and will take necessary action based on its findings. The study was funded by Volkswagen and fellow German carmakers Daimler and BMW.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is expected to attract S$8-10 billion in fixed asset investments in 2018, comparable to the previous two years. The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) also announced the launch of the first half 2018 Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) Programme, with two industrial sites available for sale. Meanwhile, Noble Group's restructuring plan has upset a major shareholder, who is calling for an investigation by Singapore regulators.

site_title: Indian gold demand wanes as jewellers expect import tax cut in budget
summary: Indian gold demand is waning due to high import taxes, with jewellers expecting a potential import tax cut in the upcoming budget. The current 10% import duty has led to smuggling, with smugglers offering discounts of up to $7 an ounce. The government is expected to reduce the duty by 2-4%, which could boost demand and support global prices near their 17-month high. Smuggling has increased since the duty was raised in 2013, with 120 tonnes of gold smuggled into India in 2016.

site_title: Durian-themed cafe in Chinatown smells winning combination
summary: A durian-themed cafe in Singapore's Chinatown district has gained popularity for its unique offerings, including durian-infused coffee and savory dishes like chicken nuggets with durian dip. The cafe, Mao Shan Wang, offers a range of durian-based products, catering to both fans and detractors of the divisive fruit. Despite its strong smell, customers are flocking to the cafe, with many tourists eager to try the exotic delicacy, and some even purchasing durian-flavored confectionery to take home.

images.alt_text: A Singapore eatery centred around the pungent tropical fruit durian has caught a whiff of success as patrons flock to the cafe in droves for a bite of its exotic offerings.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session lower; STI at 3,557.62, down 0.5% on day
summary: Singapore stocks opened the afternoon session down 0.5% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,557.62, following a 5-day rally. About 1.81 billion shares worth S$760 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 228 to 123. Key movers included Keppel Corporation and DBS, both trading higher.

site_title: Blackstone in talks to buy Thomson Reuters' financial unit
summary: Blackstone Group is in talks to buy a 55% stake in Thomson Reuters' financial unit, valued at around $20 billion, in a potential partnership that would increase Blackstone's exposure in the market for financial data. The unit generates $6.1 billion in revenue and includes Eikon, a flagship terminal providing data and analytics to financial industry professionals. The deal would put Blackstone in direct competition with Bloomberg and News Corp's Dow Jones division, and Thomson Reuters would retain a significant interest in the business.

site_title: Microsoft issues update to disable Intel's buggy Spectre patch
summary: Microsoft has released an emergency update to disable Intel's buggy Spectre patch, which caused system instability and data loss or corruption in some cases. The update, available on the Microsoft Update Catalog website, specifically targets Intel's Spectre variant 2 patch. The move comes after Intel admitted its patches for the Spectre and Meltdown vulnerabilities were faulty. The update aims to prevent computers from rebooting unexpectedly and urges customers to manually download it.

images.alt_text: Microsoft said it was rolling out an out-of-band update that specifically disables Intel's Spectre variant 2 patch.

site_title: China trying to broker sale of stake in insurer Anbang: sources
summary: China's government is seeking to broker the sale of a stake in insurer Anbang Insurance Group, amid allegations of financial wrongdoing. The sale would be handled by Central Huijin Investment, a unit of China's sovereign wealth fund. Anbang chairman Wu Xiaohui was detained in June, and a working team was dispatched to oversee the company's operations. The sale is part of China's efforts to control financial risks, following President Xi Jinping's vow to prioritize risk management.

site_title: Australia warns Commonwealth athletes not to overstay visas
summary: Australia has warned Commonwealth athletes not to overstay their visas for the 2018 Games in April, citing past issues with athletes breaching visa conditions or applying for asylum. Home Affairs Minister Peter Dutton stated that Australia will enforce its immigration laws and impose penalties on those who do not abide by visa conditions. This warning comes after previous major sporting events in Australia experienced issues with athletes overstaying or seeking asylum.

site_title: Revlon CEO steps down as losses mount at cosmetics company
summary: Revlon CEO Fabian Garcia has stepped down as the company struggles with mounting losses and heavy debt, amid plans to reach $5 billion in annual sales within five years. Garcia, 58, will be replaced by board member Paul Meister, who will oversee day-to-day operations on an interim basis. Revlon reported a widened fourth-quarter net loss of up to $80 million and slipped in sales to $785 million. The company faces challenges from shifting consumer behavior and intense competition in the beauty industry.

site_title: Rare Picasso painting in Hong Kong ahead of historic auction
summary: A rare Picasso painting, "Femme au beret et a la robe quadrillee (Marie-Therese Walter)", debuted in Hong Kong ahead of a global tour, with Sotheby's predicting a US$50 million sale price. The painting, from the 1930s, is a colourful and angular depiction of Picasso's lover, showcasing his legacy as a portraitist of women. The artwork is set to embark on a global tour before being auctioned off, with experts praising its significance in the artist's oeuvre.

site_title: US washer tariffs put Samsung, LG supply chains through the wringer
summary: The US government has imposed tariffs of up to 50% on imports of washing machines and key components, affecting Samsung and LG's supply chains. The move, part of the "Section 201" safeguard case, was intended to protect domestic manufacturers but has caught the companies off guard. The tariffs are expected to set alarm bells for other companies doing business in the US, with supply chains and investment threatened. Samsung plans to import parts until its US factory is ready, while LG is accelerating production to mitigate the impact.

site_title: Signs of upswing in Sentosa property market, Singapore's playground for the rich
summary: Singapore's Sentosa property market is showing signs of an upswing, with a nascent recovery in the island's housing market. Sentosa, a 5-square-kilometer resort lifestyle destination, is seeing interest in buying, with 65 units transacted in 2017, more than double the 31 in 2016. Experts predict prices will rise 4-7% this year, driven by falling prices during the market downturn. Sentosa's unique lifestyle, with sea views, greenery, and golf courses, is a draw for buyers, despite its limited connectivity to the mainland.

images.alt_text: A nascent recovery in Singapore's housing market is showing signs of reaching Sentosa, a tiny isle off the southern tip of South-east Asia's wealthy island state that is both a playground for partying Singaporeans and home for rich ex-pats.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track Wall Street lower amid investor caution
summary: Asia stocks fell on Tuesday, tracking a slump on global markets amid investor caution. Higher US bond yields and anticipation of significant macro data releases weighed on sentiment, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Hong Kong experiencing declines. Investors await company and economic announcements, including earnings reports from technology heavyweights, and a Federal Reserve meeting. The sell-off extends a global trend, with bourses in Shanghai, Taipei, Singapore, and Jakarta also declining. Investors are concerned that stocks "may be priced for perfection" heading into the busiest stretch of earnings season.

site_title: Residential projects boost construction in British cities: survey
summary: British cities are reporting record levels of construction activity, with nearly 17,000 residential units being built in major cities such as Belfast, Birmingham, Leeds, and Manchester. According to the Deloitte Real Estate Crane Survey UK, residential development is booming, with some cities doubling activity from the previous year. The National House-Building Council also reported a 6% increase in new homes started in 2017, with the goal of reaching 300,000 new homes per year to tackle the housing shortage.

site_title: Wanda stock skyrockets after US$5.4b Tencent tie-up
summary: Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate, has sold a 14% stake in its largest shopping mall operator, Wanda Commercial Properties, to a group of investors including Tencent, JD.com, and Suning, in a $5.4 billion deal. The move marks a strategic shift for Wanda, focusing on commercial management and retail, rather than property development. The company plans to rebrand Wanda Commercial as Wanda Commercial Management and take it public soon. The deal is seen as a significant investment by Tencent and signals a change in Wanda's strategy.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares track global peers lower on ECB official's hawkish remarks
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Tuesday, with the benchmark S&P/ASX 200 Index dropping 0.9% to its lowest in over a week. The decline followed hawkish remarks by a European Central Bank official, who suggested stimulus cuts due to a strengthening global economy. Global bond yields surged, making Australian financials less attractive. The benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand also fell 0.4%, with dairy firm a2 Milk Company Ltd leading the decliners.

site_title: MAS mopping up excess liquidity as Singapore interest rates fall
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is increasing the size of its bill auctions in response to the recent decline in short-term interest rates. The weekly auction sizes have risen, with one-month bills increasing from $1.4 billion to $1.6 billion and three-month bills rising from $5.1 billion to $5.8 billion. The 3-month Sibor rate has slowed its decline, steadying at 1.126% after a pressured drop due to the weakened US dollar. Analysts expect the SGD to strengthen towards 1.25 by end of the year, but warn of a snapback in interest rates if risk asset volatility increases.

site_title: Americans are staying home more. That's saving energy.
summary: A new study suggests that Americans spending more time at home due to remote work and online shopping has reduced energy use by 1.8% nationwide, equivalent to 1,700 trillion BTUs in 2012. The lifestyle shift, particularly among 18- to 24-year-olds, resulted in fewer travel days and lower energy intensity per minute. However, the study's findings have limitations, as it only accounts for primary activities recorded in the American Time Use Survey, potentially missing changes in commuting and work habits.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks take a breather after 5-day rally, won edges down
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.27% to 2,590.59, with Samsung Electronics dropping 2% due to a US tech stocks slump. The Korean won weakened 0.43% against the dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is up 5.3% this year, with foreign investors selling 92,252 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares track global equities lower as investors eye stimulus exit
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Tuesday, led by financials, after a European Central Bank official's hawkish remarks fueled expectations of reduced stimulus as the global economy improves. Global equity markets eased, and US Treasury yields surged to three-year highs, making Australian financials less attractive. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 31.4 points, or 0.5%, to 6,044, with banks and materials leading the decline.

site_title: Singapore expected to attract S$8-10b in inbound investments in 2018: EDB
summary: Singapore is expected to attract S$8-10 billion in fixed asset investments in 2018, comparable to the previous two years, according to the Singapore Economic Development Board. This is expected to generate 16,000-18,000 new jobs, lower than in the past two years. The jobs will be in higher-skilled, higher-value industries such as advanced manufacturing and the digital sector. The board's managing director attributed the lower job forecast to the slowing growth of the local workforce and the type of jobs being created.

site_title: Amazon opens plant-filled "The Spheres" buildings
summary: Amazon has opened "The Spheres," a plant-filled building in Seattle, as part of its urban campus. The structure, which resembles a giant glass and steel ball, houses over 40,000 plants and features such as treehouse meeting rooms, a river, and waterfalls. The Spheres aim to create a unique gathering place for employees and the Seattle community, providing a space for collaboration and innovation amidst biodiversity. Amazon's vice president of global real estate and facilities, John Schoettler, described The Spheres as a workplace "more like a tropical rainforest in the clouds than an office."

site_title: US dollar index holds steady as markets await Trump's speech and Fed
summary: The US dollar index held steady at 89.430 against a basket of six major currencies, as markets await US President Donald Trump's State of the Union speech and a Federal Reserve policy meeting. Analysts attribute the recent rise in US bond yields to the dollar's support. The euro eased 0.1% to $1.2373, while the yen rose 0.2% to 108.78 yen, driven by risk aversion and speculation about US currency policy. The dollar's recent pullback from a three-year low has paused, with traders awaiting Trump's speech for further guidance on the US dollar.

site_title: Wanda selling US$5.4b property unit stake, to seek listing 'soon'
summary: Dalian Wanda Group Co is selling a $5.4 billion stake in its property arm, Wanda Commercial Properties Co, to a group of investors, including Tencent Holdings Ltd. The deal aims to ease pressure on the conglomerate to meet a listing deadline and marks a transition from property development to management. Wanda plans to take the company public as soon as possible and will offload projects being developed for sale to a third party within one to two years.

site_title: Japan's Aso tells cryptocurrency exchanges to strengthen controls after 58b yen theft
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso urged cryptocurrency exchanges to strengthen controls after hackers stole 58 billion yen ($698 million) from Tokyo-based Coincheck. Authorities will investigate all exchanges for security gaps and ordered Coincheck to raise its standards. Aso emphasized the need to balance innovation with user protection, while policymakers struggle to regulate cryptocurrencies. The theft highlights the risks of cryptocurrency trade and its potential for illicit use, with world leaders warning of potential dangers. Aso's comments come ahead of a G-20 finance ministers meeting in Argentina, where cryptocurrency regulation is expected to be discussed.

site_title: 'Mediterranean' diet may boost IVF chances: study
summary: A study of 244 women undergoing IVF in Athens, Greece, found that those following a Mediterranean diet for six months before treatment had a 65-68% greater chance of achieving a successful pregnancy and birth. The diet, rich in fresh fruit and vegetables, fish, and olive oil, was associated with better IVF outcomes, particularly among women under 35. The study's findings highlight the importance of healthy eating in fertility, but caution that the results may not be generalizable to all women or those with obesity.

site_title: SMRT appoints Keppel executive Abu Bakar Mohd Nor as board director
summary: SMRT Corporation has appointed Abu Bakar Mohd Nor, a Keppel executive and former soldier, as a board director, effective January 23, 2018. Mohd Nor, who is also managing director of Keppel Offshore & Marine and various Keppel Group companies, brings extensive experience in the marine industry and public sector. His appointment reflects SMRT's commitment to attracting talent from diverse backgrounds.

site_title: FBI's No 2 official McCabe, blasted by Trump, steps down
summary: FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe, who was criticized by President Donald Trump for alleged bias against him and in favor of his 2016 Democratic opponent Hillary Clinton, has stepped down, effective immediately. McCabe had been expected to leave his post in March but decided to leave earlier amid concerns about an upcoming Justice Department inspector general report. David Bowdich will take over as acting deputy director. The decision was made without President Trump's involvement, according to White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders, who expressed "full confidence" in FBI Director Christopher Wray.

site_title: US says no need for new Russia sanctions
summary: The US government has determined that no new sanctions are needed to deter Russia from interfering in US elections and destabilizing Ukraine, citing the threat of US action as a sufficient deterrent. Billions of dollars in potential deals with Russian arms companies have been canceled, but the list of Russian oligarchs eligible for sanctions remains unpublished. The State Department and Treasury missed the deadline to comply with the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act, which was signed by President Trump last year.

images.alt_text: World governments have canceled billions of dollars in potential deals with Russian arms companies, the US government said Monday, arguing there is no need for new sanctions to deter them.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS has 'buy' call on ESR-Reit on proposed merger
summary: DBS Group Research has issued a "buy" call on ESR-Reit due to a proposed merger with Viva Industrial Trust. The combined entity would become the fourth largest industrial Reit in Singapore, offering a significant pipeline of acquisition prospects and deal flow. This merger is expected to close the gap in asset under management with larger cap industrial Reits, and DBS has set a target price of S$0.63 for ESR-Reit. The analysts believe the merger will empower the combined entity with additional firepower to pursue inorganic growth opportunities.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks down at open after US retreat
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.36% on Tuesday, following a broader retreat in global markets, as investors took profits after recent rallies. The Hang Seng Index closed at 32,847.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.33% and 0.27% respectively. The decline comes amid US market volatility, with US stocks edging down from records due to tariff threats.

site_title: Michelin lets top French chef pull out of guide
summary: Sebastien Bras, a 46-year-old French chef, has withdrawn his restaurant Le Suquet from the Michelin guide, citing "huge pressure" from inspectors. This is the first time a restaurant has been allowed to leave the guide. Bras, who held three Michelin stars for 18 years, said he no longer wanted to risk his reputation with the possibility of a subpar dish. He plans to start a new chapter in the restaurant's history without the pressure of Michelin's inspectors.

images.alt_text: Sebastien Bras, whose Le Suquet restaurant in the rural Aveyron region has held the maximum three-star rating from the gastronomic bible for 18 years, told AFP in September that he could no longer put himself through the ordeal of knowing that one below-par dish could cost him his reputation.

site_title: Exxon plans major US investments due to tax reform: CEO
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to invest $50 billion in US projects over the next five years, largely due to recently approved corporate tax rate cuts. The company's CEO, Darren Woods, stated that the lower tax rate and smarter regulation create an environment for future capital investments. Exxon is increasing investments in US refining, petrochemical, and shale operations, and has already committed $20 billion for US Gulf Coast chemical and oil refining efforts through 2022.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil Corp plans to invest billions of dollars in the United States due in part to recently approved corporate tax rate cuts, the company's chief executive said on Monday.

site_title: Britain worse off under any Brexit scenario: report
summary: Britain would be worse off under any Brexit scenario, according to a leaked internal report. The report, titled "EU Exit Analysis," found that if the UK remained in the European single market, growth would be 2% lower over 15 years. Under a comprehensive free trade agreement, growth would be 5% lower, and with a "no deal" scenario, growth would be reduced by 8%. The UK government is undertaking ongoing analysis, but has not yet published the full report.

site_title: Verizon dropping plans to sell phones from China's Huawei: sources
summary: Verizon is dropping plans to sell phones from Chinese manufacturer Huawei, citing US government pressure due to concerns about Chinese spying and security risks. The move follows AT&T's decision not to introduce the Mate 10 Pro to the US market, which is expected to have 5G capabilities. The US government's concerns about 5G phones made by companies with close ties to the Chinese government could pose a security risk, prompting the Trump administration to consider nationalizing the construction of a 5G system. Huawei has denied spying allegations and maintains its commitment to security and privacy.

site_title: US businesses optimistic on China growth, bemoan unfair treatment
summary: US businesses are optimistic about China's growth potential, with 46% of respondents expressing confidence that the Chinese government will further open its market to foreign investment within the next three years. However, 75% of members feel unwelcome by the Chinese government, citing unfair treatment and policies that hinder foreign-invested companies. The American Chamber of Commerce in China emphasized the need for "even-handed enforcement of laws and regulations" to reduce trade frictions between the US and China. US President Donald Trump's visit to China may have contributed to the increased optimism, but his administration's hard line on China's alleged intellectual property theft remains a concern.

site_title: JTC launches sale of two industrial sites in Tuas
summary: JTC has launched the sale of two industrial sites in Tuas, Singapore. The 0.43 ha site at Tuas South Link 3 is zoned for Business-2 development with a 20-year tenure, while the 2.72 ha site at Tuas Bay Close has a 30-year tenure. The sites are part of the government's efforts to offer more choices for industrial development, with tenders closing on March 27 and 13, 2018, respectively.

site_title: Canada 'serial killer' linked to five deaths, targeted gay men
summary: A 66-year-old Canadian landscaper, Bruce McArthur, is suspected of being a serial killer linked to five deaths, all of which targeted gay men in Toronto. McArthur was charged with three additional premeditated murders and is being investigated for the disappearances of two men in April and June 2018. Police are searching 30 properties in Toronto and examining planters for human remains, with DNA tests underway to identify the victims. Authorities believe there may be more remains and victims, but the exact number is unknown.

site_title: Human genome decoded with pocket-sized device
summary: Scientists have successfully sequenced the human genome using a portable device, called MinIONs, no bigger than a cellphone. The breakthrough, published in Nature Biotechnology, achieved 99.88% accuracy and can be used for routine clinical exams, detecting cancer DNA, and identifying viruses or bacteria. The new technology sheds light on poorly understood regions of the genome, paving the way for personalized medicine and simultaneous analysis of the microbiome. The cost of sequencing, previously a $3 billion endeavor, is now estimated to be a few thousand dollars.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian upgrades SIA Engineering to 'buy'
summary: UOB Kay Hian has upgraded its call on SIA Engineering to 'buy', citing an expected surge in engine shop visits in 2018, which could boost engine maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) earnings. Despite a 7.1% year-on-year decline in 2017, analysts expect a turnaround in 2018 and 2019, with lifted target prices to S$4 and higher joint venture and associate income. Industry authority Aviation Week forecasts strong engine shop visits in Asia-Pacific, supporting the upgrade.

site_title: UOB to help SMEs secure talent through understudy programme for SMU undergrads
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has launched a new initiative to help Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) secure promising young talent through its Entrepreneur Shadow Programme. The programme, in partnership with the Singapore Management University, allows final-year undergraduates to understudy SME owners and gain experience in running a business. This aims to address the challenge faced by SMEs in hiring young talent, with more than half of SME leaders reporting difficulty in finding suitable candidates. The programme has already benefited a fire protection services firm, Fitterlab Engineering, with fresh perspectives and new ideas on business improvement.

site_title: Red card for Vietjet after football PR stunt with lingerie models
summary: Vietjet, Vietnam's budget airline, apologized for sending lingerie models to join the country's under-23 football squad on a flight home from China, sparking outrage on social media. The airline claimed it was an "improvised move" and not a marketing strategy, but many users found it "rude, cheap, and offensive." Despite the backlash, the stunt captivated football-mad Vietnam and elevated the athletes to national heroes, with the team receiving a rock star welcome upon their return. Vietjet disciplined "relevant staff" for the stunt.

site_title: Australia business conditions strong in Dec, confidence grows: survey
summary: Australian business conditions remained strong in December, with a seasonally adjusted index of +13, above the long-run average of +5. Profits and sales were healthy, while business confidence improved to +11, the highest reading since July. The construction sector reported booming conditions, while retail remained in the doldrums due to intense competition. Employment growth remains strong, with a reading of +6, indicating around 300,000 jobs per year. The survey suggests a positive signal for investment and helps narrow the gap between business conditions and confidence.

site_title: Noble Group shares tumble on debt restructuring plan
summary: Noble Group shares plummeted 23% in early trading after the company agreed to restructure US$3.5 billion of debt in exchange for 70% equity, diluting existing holders' stakes to 10%. The debt-for-equity swap is backed by 30% of senior debt holders. The move comes after Noble Group made significant job cuts, sold assets, and raised funds in a crisis-wracked three years.

site_title: QT Vascular completes US$28m sale of catheter product to Medtronic, requests to lift trading halt
summary: QT Vascular has completed the sale of its Chocolate PTA balloon catheter product to Medtronic for US$28 million. The sale, announced in May, follows the achievement of certain milestones. QT Vascular will continue to develop and market its other products, including a drug-coated version of the catheter. The company has requested the lifting of a trading halt on the Singapore bourse, citing the completion of the sale. The acquisition is seen as a validation of the intrinsic value of QT Vascular's internally developed products.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.85 points to 1,864.67. Losers outnumbered gainers 112 to 83, and volume reached 64.26 million lots worth RM23.34 million.

site_title: ECB must halt bond-buying, says Dutch bank governor
summary: Dutch bank governor Klaas Knot says the European Central Bank (ECB) must halt its bond-buying programme due to its limited effectiveness in stimulating economic growth. The ECB has already committed to buying 30 billion euros in government and corporate bonds until September, but Knot believes it's time to phase it out. The move could signal the end of the cheap money era and make it more complicated to chart a way out of quantitative easing, given the recent strength of the euro.

site_title: A bone-deep heart threat emerges
summary: Scientists have discovered a previously unknown risk factor for heart attacks and strokes, known as clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), which increases the risk of death by 40-50% within a decade. This condition is caused by a mutation in bone marrow stem cells, which can be acquired through bad luck or exposure to toxins like cigarette smoke. CHIP is not uncommon, with up to 20% of people in their 60s and 50% of those in their 80s affected. The condition acts independently of traditional risk factors like high cholesterol and blood pressure, and its discovery has been hailed as one of the most significant in cardiology since statins.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall Street falls
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, falling 0.31% or 74.07 points to 23,555.27, weighed down by a strong yen and a retreat from Wall Street records. The US stock market had also fallen, despite reaching fresh records, amid tariff threats. Investors seemed unfazed by new Trump threats, however, and the rally continued in Asia.

site_title: Japan stock bible sells like hot cakes, sets stage for Nomura to prosper
summary: Japan's largest brokerages, Nomura and Daiwa Securities, are expected to benefit from a surge in individual investor interest in the stock market. Sales of the well-known stock handbook "Kaisha Shikiho" have increased by 50% from last year, with the latest edition selling out quickly. This trend is driven by individuals seeking to capitalize on Japan's rising stocks, with stock transactions by individuals rising 15% last year, the most in four years. Analysts predict a continued recovery in individual investor sentiment, with Goldman Sachs upgrading its ratings on Nomura and Daiwa shares.

site_title: London home prices rise at slowest pace since 2011 in buyer's market
summary: London's housing market is experiencing a buyer's market, with home prices rising at the slowest pace in six years. In December, prices rose less than 2% year-on-year to £488,400, driven by affordability issues and discounts of up to 10% in some areas. Vendors cut prices by an average of 4% to secure deals, contrasting with the boom years of gazumping. Regional cities like Manchester and Birmingham are skewed towards sellers, while prices fell in Oxford, Cambridge, and Aberdeen due to weaker demand and economic factors.

site_title: CWX Global Q2 profit almost triples to US$1.1m on one-off gains, lower borrowings
summary: CWX Global reported a net profit of US$1.1 million in its second fiscal quarter, almost tripling from the previous year, driven by one-off gains and lower borrowings. Revenue fell 51% to US$1.3 million due to declining oil production, but other income doubled to US$1.6 million. Finance costs declined by US$0.3 million, and the net asset value per share fell to 1.65 US cents.

site_title: Facebook to deliver more local news to US users
summary: Facebook plans to deliver more local news to US users, aiming to combat the spread of misinformation and promote community engagement. The move comes after the company's efforts to combat false news, particularly ahead of the 2016 US presidential election. Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg stated that local news helps build community and can foster progress. The company will show users more stories from local news sources and plans to expand this feature to more countries later this year.

site_title: Progress in Nafta talks, but 'very slow': US trade official
summary: US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said talks on revamping the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) have advanced slowly, but expressed hope for breakthroughs in the next round of talks. Negotiators from Canada, the US, and Mexico discussed key issues in Montreal, with Canada presenting new proposals. While progress was made, friction remains between Ottawa and Washington, particularly on calculating trade imbalances and rules of origin in the auto sector. A next round of Nafta negotiations is scheduled for February in Mexico.

site_title: Top Dutch banks, government services hit by cyber attacks
summary: Top three Dutch banks, ING, ABN Amro, and Rabobank, were targeted in multiple cyber attacks over the past week, blocking access to websites and internet banking services. The Dutch Revenue Service and digital signature system DigiD were also hit, but services were quickly restored. The attacks, including distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, were described as "serious" by central bank chief Klaas Knot, who noted that Dutch banks experience thousands of website attacks daily. Experts say the best defense against cyber attacks is to ensure proper systems are in place, as the attacks remain a "cat-and-mouse game" between security measures and attackers.

images.alt_text: The top Dutch bank by assets, ING, experienced a so-called distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack on Sunday evening while the eurozone nation's third largest lender, ABN Amro, suffered three attacks over the weekend in a total of seven over the last week, Dutch media reported.

site_title: Japan spending slips in December
summary: Japan's household spending slipped 0.1% in December from a year earlier, contradicting market expectations of a 1.5% rise. The jobless rate edged up to 2.8% in December, while the ratio of available jobs to those looking for work improved to 1.59, the highest level since 1974. Despite seven consecutive quarters of economic growth, Japan has yet to achieve the 2% inflation rate target, and fears of deflation persist. The government and central bank aim for a "virtuous cycle" of export-led growth boosting jobs and household income.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending slipped 0.1 per cent in December from a year earlier, according to government data released Tuesday, suggesting demand remains sluggish in the world's third-largest economy.

site_title: China workplace deaths fall to 38,000 in 2017: report
summary: China's workplace deaths decreased by 12.1% to 38,000 in 2017, according to a report by the State Administration of Work Safety. Fines for work safety violations rose 58% to 3.3 billion yuan. The coal sector saw a 28.7% decrease in fatalities, with 375 deaths in 2017. Despite progress, around 28% of China's coal mines have annual production capacity below 90,000 tonnes, making them more prone to accidents. The number of onsite inspections increased to 4.6 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Starhill Global Reit, ESR-Reit, Viva Industrial Trust, SIA , Procurri
summary: Noble Group reached an agreement with senior creditors to slash debt by half, leaving existing shareholders with 10% of the new group. Starhill Global Reit reported a 7.1% drop in distribution per unit for Q2 2017. ESR-Reit proposed a merger with Viva Industrial Trust. Singapore Airlines launched its Digital Innovation Blueprint, while Procurri Corp expects to report a net loss for Q4 2017 and FY2017 due to foreign exchange differences and write-offs.

site_title: Procurri warns of Q4, full-year 2017 loss
summary: Procurri Corp, a Singapore-listed provider of data centre equipment and maintenance services, is expecting to report a net loss for Q4 2017 and FY2017 due to foreign exchange differences and write-offs. The group's administrative expenses rose due to acquiring EAF Supply Chain Holdings and forming a joint venture. Despite a 41.9% revenue growth in the first nine months of 2017, Procurri's bottom line was negatively affected. The company aims to improve gross profit margin and increase its Lifecycle Services segment's contribution to half of the group's total gross profit in five years.

site_title: Alibaba to take on Kuala Lumpur's traffic in first foreign project
summary: Alibaba Group is launching a traffic control system in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, harnessing artificial intelligence to predict and optimize traffic flow. The system, called "City Brain," will utilize data from 500 inner city cameras and integrate with public transportation systems and mapping apps. Partnering with Malaysia Digital Economy Corporation and the Kuala Lumpur city council, Alibaba Cloud aims to increase traffic efficiency and reduce congestion. The project marks Alibaba's first foreign traffic control system, with potential for further expansion in Malaysia and other countries.

site_title: Gold slips as US dollar claws back, Treasury yields gain
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% on Monday as the US dollar recovered and Treasury yields rose, making gold a less attractive investment due to its lack of interest payments. Spot gold dropped to $1,342.56 an ounce, while US gold futures settled down 0.9% at $1,340.30. This marks the sixth weekly price rise in seven weeks, with gold rising over 3% this month. The decline is attributed to rising bond yields and a stronger US dollar, which has pulled gold back after a strong end to December.

site_title: Europe: Chipmakers, Sanofi deal dominate trading
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% as chipmakers AMS and Dialog Semiconductor surged on strong earnings, with AMS doubling revenue and raising growth forecasts. Sanofi also made headlines with a 3.9 billion euro deal to buy Ablynx. However, the euro eased back from its highs, and bond yields rose, weighing on income stocks. Getinge's poor quarterly results and Bankia's fourth-quarter loss also affected the Stoxx 600 index.

site_title: UK surplus? US surplus? Who knows, trade statisticians say
summary: UK and US trade statisticians are puzzled by a 33 billion-pound mismatch in services trade figures between the two countries for 2016. Britain reported a trade surplus of 23 billion pounds with the US, while the US reported a surplus of 10 billion pounds. The discrepancy, attributed to differences in methodologies and data sources, raises questions about the emphasis on services trade in future trade deals. Statisticians are urging a deeper understanding of the UK's trading relationship with other countries, particularly as the country prepares to leave the EU.

site_title: Dell considering sale to VMware in reverse-merger; would be biggest tech deal ever
summary: Michael Dell's technology empire, Dell Technologies Inc, is considering a sale to VMware Inc in a reverse-merger, aiming to create a publicly traded entity and reduce debt. Dell owns 80% of VMware, acquired in 2015, and seeks to combine the businesses to manage debt. The combined company would have VMware's management in place, with Dell as a parent company. The transaction would be paid for with VMware stock, and Dell would eliminate a tracking stock related to VMware's stake. The deal would be the biggest tech deal ever, and Dell's board will meet later this month to discuss options.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.4% at 3,563.94 points. The decline follows Wall Street's retreat from records seen at the end of last week amid tariff threats. Losers outnumbered gainers 78 to 49, with QT Vascular up 0.3 cents and Noble Group down 3.5 cents. Volume was 111.6 million shares worth S$105.7 million.

site_title: Asset managers rush to launch MSCI index funds ahead of China A-share inclusion
summary: Chinese asset managers are launching MSCI index funds ahead of the expected inclusion of mainland stocks in MSCI's emerging market benchmark this year. Truvalue Asset Management Co's MSCI China stock index fund was the first to launch after receiving regulatory approval. Other fund managers are also in the pipeline, despite concerns about elevated valuations and the 2015 stock market crash. A "fear of missing out" is expected to drive demand for mainland stocks, supporting a surge in the market.

site_title: US budget deficit to top US$1t in 2019: budget experts
summary: The US federal budget deficit is projected to exceed $1 trillion in 2019, according to the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget. This would be the first time since 2012 that the US economy will have to support a deficit of this magnitude. The deficit is expected to rise further, potentially reaching $2 trillion by 2027, due to current policies and a delayed update to the Congressional Budget Office's projections. This trend is attributed to the 2017 tax overhaul, which added $1.5 trillion to the national debt over a decade.

site_title: Meryl Streep wants to trademark her own name
summary: Meryl Streep, the 68-year-old actress, has filed an application to trademark her name for "entertainment services," including movie appearances, speaking engagements, and autographs. This move aims to protect her intellectual property and prevent others from using her name without permission. Streep has won numerous awards, including three Oscars, and has been nominated for 21 Academy Awards, extending her record. The trademark application is not the first for a celebrity, with Taylor Swift filing over 60 trademark applications in the last decade.

site_title: Oil settles lower after dollar strengthens, rising US output
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Monday, pressured by a strengthening US dollar and rising US crude output. Brent crude futures fell 1.5% to $69.46 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 0.9% to $65.56 a barrel. A strengthening dollar, which is expected to fall 3% this month, weighed on crude prices. Analysts expect US crude supplies to post a weekly rise for the first time in 10 weeks, despite OPEC's efforts to limit output.

site_title: Singapore-based metals trader Kyen to set up London office
summary: Singapore-based metals trader Kyen Resources is setting up a London office with 12 initial employees, led by Matthew Hadfield, to expand its recycled metals and concentrates trading business. This move follows other China-backed firms entering the international metals trading market, driven by a global manufacturing revival and companies seeking to fill gaps left by large banks and brokers due to regulations and higher costs.

site_title: Religare brothers slapped with another suit
summary: India's billionaire Singh brothers, Malvinder and Shivinder, are accused of "diversion, siphoning and digression of assets" by a New York-based investor in a lawsuit filed in the High Court of Delhi. The lawsuit alleges that Religare Enterprises' lending arm diverted at least $300 million in loans to aid the brothers' personal debt load of about $1.6 billion. The suit seeks to halt lending and asset sales, aiming to ensure Religare has funds to pay potential liabilities.

site_title: US authorities charge three banks, eight individuals in futures' spoofing' probe
summary: The US Justice Department and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) have filed civil and criminal charges against three European banks (UBS, Deutsche Bank, and HSBC) and eight individuals for alleged "spoofing" in US futures and commodities markets. The banks paid $46.6 million to settle, with UBS and Deutsche Bank paying $30 million and $15 million respectively. The charges involve manipulating prices by creating an illusion of demand, and the CFTC aims to hold individuals accountable for corporate wrongdoing.

site_title: Why prospect of economic recovery won't deflate populist fervour
summary: The global economic recovery may not lead to a decline in populist fervor, as factors such as accelerated cultural and social change, and perceived corruption of established elites, contribute to the rise of populism. While economic growth can improve middle-class incomes, it may not address underlying issues of inequality and disillusionment with politics. Populist parties have gained support in countries with strong economies, and the phenomenon is not new, with examples in 19th and 20th century Europe and Latin America. Effective political leadership and reforms are needed to address the root causes of populism and build trust in institutions.

images.alt_text: Markets are hopeful now that the world economy is well on its way towards a somewhat sustained recovery. But there are fears growth could be of the kind that again disproportionately increases the income and wealth of the top 1 per cent.

site_title: US democracy at risk, with or without Trump
summary: US democracy is at risk due to deepening partisan animosities, despite President Trump's actions. The country's democratic institutions are strong, but the problems it faces run deeper than the Trump presidency. The Constitution requires two basic norms, mutual toleration and forbearance, to function well. However, these norms are vulnerable to polarisation, which can lead to constitutional hardball and undermine democratic norms. Extreme polarisation, driven by racial and cultural differences, has already begun to eviscerate democratic norms, making democracy at risk, regardless of Trump's presidency.

images.alt_text: Extreme partisan polarisation had already begun to eviscerate US democratic norms long before Mr Trump's election.

site_title: Global green bond issuance expected to spike by 30% in 2018: S&P Global Ratings
summary: Global green bond issuance is expected to increase by 30% in 2018, reaching around $200 billion, according to S&P Global Ratings. This growth is driven by strengthening market fundamentals and a global push to address climate change. New issuers and financing types, such as green loans and Islamic bonds, are expected to emerge, with emerging markets like China, India, and Mexico playing a significant role. Despite potential headwinds from the revised US tax code and monetary policy tightening, the US is expected to remain a leading country for green bond issuance in 2018.

site_title: US lifts ban on refugees from 11 countries
summary: The US has lifted its ban on refugees from 11 "high-risk" countries, including North Korea, but with enhanced security assessments. Applicants from these countries, including Egypt, Iran, Iraq, and others, will face tougher "risk-based" vetting measures. The move aims to protect the homeland from terror and crime threats, but critics say it will result in a bias against African, Asian, and Muslim countries. The policy change is part of President Trump's efforts to overhaul US immigration policy, including a proposed wall on the southern border and a path to citizenship for "Dreamers."

site_title: Singapore's outbound property investments hit record in 2017
summary: Singapore's outbound property investments reached a record $28.4 billion in 2017, up 40% from $20.4 billion in 2016. The majority of these investments were made by the sovereign wealth fund GIC, which also acquired several notable assets, including Monogram Residential Trust and a portfolio of student accommodation assets. Singapore-based investors focused on industrial, suburban, and niche asset classes, and entered secondary and tertiary US markets, surpassing Chinese and Hong Kong firms in US real estate investments.

images.alt_text: Singapore monies that went into overseas real-estate investments last year rose by about 40 per cent to a record US$28.4 billion, up from US$20.4 billion in 2016 and upending the last high of US$27.6 billion in 2015.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to divest Beijing Novotel Sanyuan and Ibis Beijing Sanyuan for 1,156.4 million yuan (S$235.9 million). The trust posted a 15% growth in distribution per unit and 23% growth in net property income for the third fiscal quarter ended Dec 31, 2017. This follows Raffles United Holdings' expected return to profitability in 2017, driven by increased revenue and lower operating expenses.

site_title: US coal mining industry faces gloomy future
summary: The US coal mining industry is facing a gloomy future due to declining demand and increasing competition from natural gas. Despite President Trump's efforts to revive the industry, coal production has dropped by 38% in a decade, with only the most efficient mines able to survive. The closure of the 4 West coal mine in Pennsylvania has left 370 workers without jobs, with many forced to relocate. The decline in coal consumption has led to a shift towards natural gas, with energy experts predicting a continued decline in coal's share of electricity generation.

site_title: London looks to raise game for Brexit transition talks amid uncertainty
summary: The UK and EU are set to begin Brexit transition negotiations, amid uncertainty and a lack of clarity from the UK government. The UK's Prime Minister Theresa May faces significant challenges in the talks, including a potential £40 billion divorce bill and the need to agree on a post-Brexit trade deal. The EU, led by chief negotiator Michel Barnier, is seeking to establish a clear negotiating position and is pushing for swift talks to be completed by October. The negotiations will cover issues such as the Irish border, transitional arrangements, and a new trade deal, with the UK facing a high risk of failure due to its weakened bargaining hand and the complexities of the talks.

site_title: Hong Kong seeks to cash in on frenzy for Chinese biotech stocks
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is considering a proposal that would allow biotech firms to list before they turn a profit, paving the way for Chinese healthcare companies to raise funds and access the US market. The move aims to boost innovation and competitiveness in the Asian country's healthcare industry, which has seen significant growth in recent years. The proposal, expected to be finalized by June, could provide a boost to companies like Chipscreen Biosciences and Hutchison China MediTech, which have surged in value in the US market.

site_title: Wynn Macau shares drop after US rout on harassment allegations
summary: Shares of Wynn Macau Ltd, the Chinese casino operation of US-based Wynn Resorts Ltd, dropped 6.5% after allegations of chairman Steve Wynn's sexual harassment against women. The allegations, reported by the Wall Street Journal, led Morgan Stanley and Union Gaming Group LLC to downgrade their ratings on Wynn Macau stock. Wynn's assets are considered "best in class," but the scandal may deter investors, pushing them towards rivals Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd and Sands China Ltd.

site_title: Bungalow at Leedon/Belmont road junction fetches S$57.5m
summary: A Singaporean freehold bungalow on a 43,926 sq ft site at the Leedon/Belmont road junction was sold for S$57.5 million, or S$1,309 per square foot. The property, dubbed the "Queen of Leedon Park," is being sold by a company majority-owned by Chong Swee Hah, a prominent investor in Good Class Bungalows. The buyer, a foreigner turned Singapore citizen, paid a premium price, and the site's subdivisibility into two plots is uncertain.

site_title: Condo price increase eases to 0.6% in Dec: NUS index
summary: Singapore's condo prices rose 0.6% in December, easing from the 1.6% increase in November, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) latest flash estimates. Prices in the central region rose 0.5%, while those in the non-central region increased 0.7%. Small units saw no change. Year-on-year, prices rose 5.5% in 2017, reversing the 2.3% decline in 2016.

site_title: Patient-centric focus no more an extra in value-based care
summary: Singapore's healthcare system is shifting towards value-based care, focusing on improving care outcomes and patient engagement. However, patient engagement remains a crucial component, with variability in care, knowledge, and operational processes hindering high-value care. The rising costs of healthcare, chronic diseases, and changing illness patterns further exacerbate the issue. To address these challenges, hospitals must implement patient-centric strategies, leveraging technologies such as electronic medical records and clinical decision support tools to reduce variation in care and increase clinical quality.

site_title: The founder's identity crisis: When your startup becomes an SME
summary: A Singaporean entrepreneur shares his experience as a serial entrepreneur, highlighting the challenges of transitioning from a startup to a Small Medium Enterprise (SME). The founder must shift their leadership style, develop humility, and make difficult decisions to ensure the company's survival. This transition requires establishing formal processes, trusting a leadership team, and leveraging technology to analyze data and gain insights. By doing so, the SME can thrive and overcome its limitations.

site_title: Dollar nurses losses but set for big monthly fall
summary: The US dollar consolidated losses against a basket of currencies on Monday, rising a quarter of a percent to 89.30 after six consecutive weeks of losses. However, it is set to fall 3% on a monthly basis, marking the 10th time in the last decade it has fallen by that extent. Despite recent strong economic data, traders remain cautious about the path of US interest rates, with the Federal Reserve expected to raise rates in March, and yields rose to fresh multi-year highs.

site_title: Air finance titans ponder whether boom will end
summary: The aircraft financing industry is celebrating an unprecedented boom, with the US$140 billion market growing to 140% of its pre-crisis size. Industry titans gather in Dublin to debate whether the current boom will end, with concerns about the risks of spectacular collapses and the emergence of inexperienced players. New investors, particularly from China, have flooded the market, but some worry that the industry may be due for a downturn, with rising interest rates and increasing leverage posing risks. The industry's dominance in Ireland is attributed to the rise and collapse of Guinness Peat Aviation in 1992.

site_title: Tech giants gear up for Europe's privacy rules
summary: Tech giants such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon are preparing for the May 25 implementation of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in Europe, a set of stringent data privacy rules. The rules restrict personal data collection, storage, and use, and require companies to give users control over their digital data. In response, companies have overhauled their privacy settings, redesigned products, and removed products from the European market to comply with the regulations. The GDPR is seen as a regulatory standard for the tech industry, with European officials stating that US tech giants are "very eager" to understand how to comply.

site_title: AI: The next frontier of marketing
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing marketing by helping marketers reach the right audience, attract the right crowds, convert interested consumers, and engage customers through personalized touchpoints. AI tools such as machine learning, chatbots, and automated emails simplify the process, leveling the playing field for small to medium enterprises (SMEs) to compete with larger companies. With the right tools and knowledge, SMEs can analyze data, predict consumer behavior, and create targeted marketing strategies, ultimately driving business growth and customer loyalty.

site_title: Long-term involvement a key theme
summary: PwC Singapore has long prioritized corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives, focusing on long-term engagement with underprivileged communities. Since 2008, the company has partnered with local charities and NGOs, including the Banda Street Project, a flagship community outreach program. PwC staff have rallied to support the community through various drives, initiatives, and projects, including painting murals, hosting community parties, and replacing old mattresses and light bulbs for elderly residents. The company also works with the YMCA on Overseas Community Projects and collaborates with other organizations to share CSR experiences and skills-based volunteering.

site_title: German carmaker group sponsored emissions experiments on people: paper
summary: German carmakers Volkswagen, Daimler, and BMW funded a research organization that sponsored experiments on humans, exposing them to nitrogen dioxide gas, a byproduct of exhaust fumes. The European Research Group on Environment and Health in the Transport Sector (EUGT) conducted the study, which was published in 2016. The purpose and outcome of the study remain unclear, but the experiments raise concerns about the industry's handling of emissions. Daimler has condemned the experiments, and the other carmakers have also expressed outrage, amid ongoing bans on toxic diesel vehicles.

site_title: US mulls building 5G network amid China concerns: sources
summary: The US government is in talks with private companies to build a secure 5G network amid concerns about China and cyber security. The plan, which aims to be decided by the end of September, would involve either a single secure network or multiple systems, with funding and control to be determined. The Trump administration is in contact with US, European, and Asian companies, but not Chinese firms. A secure 5G network is seen as crucial for technologies like self-driving cars and virtual reality.

site_title: Singapore R&D tax perks could be among world's weakest when PIC expires: KPMG
summary: Singapore's Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme, set to expire this year, may leave the country with one of the weakest R&D tax incentives globally. SMEs are calling for targeted measures to drive innovation, citing the need for more effective tax incentives and streamlined processes. The expiry of the PIC scheme could impact Singapore's standing as a research and development hub and its ability to attract high-potential startups. Experts recommend a shift towards more targeted, industry-specific measures to bolster innovation and address the growing global competition for R&D talent.

site_title: How SMEs can draw and retain young tech talent
summary: Singaporean SMEs face a challenge in attracting and retaining top tech talent due to a shortage of skilled workers. To overcome this, SMEs must understand the needs and expectations of millennials and Gen Z, who value progressive career opportunities, diversity, and a sense of purpose. Strategies include considering unconventional talent pools, building a unique culture, offering continuous training and development, and showcasing the company's brand and social impact. By adopting these approaches, SMEs can differentiate themselves from larger companies and attract the best tech talent in Singapore.

site_title: Restructuring: SMEs urged to seize the day while the going is good
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) are urged to seize the day and push ahead with restructuring efforts to stay future-ready amidst a rising tide of digitalization and globalization. The upcoming Budget 2018 is unlikely to be a game-changer for SMEs, and instead, businesses must transform themselves to capitalize on these changes. Digitalization, tooling up workers, and attracting the right talent are key areas of focus for SMEs to remain competitive. Despite the challenges of hiring skilled staff, SMEs must prioritize talent acquisition and development to drive business growth and transformation.

site_title: Carillion tried to shirk pension obligations: MPs
summary: Carillion, Britain's largest corporate failure in a decade, attempted to "wriggle out of its pension obligations" for the last decade, according to Parliament's Work and Pensions Select Committee. The company cited cash flow problems despite paying over £70 million in dividends to investors. A £990 million pension deficit may have existed, but trustees were "kept in the dark" about the company's finances. The collapse threatens suppliers, merchants, and big banks, and the government has stepped in to guarantee public services provided by the company.

site_title: Facebook makes privacy push ahead of strict EU law
summary: Facebook publishes its first set of privacy principles ahead of the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) on May 25, aiming to give users more control over their information. The company will roll out educational videos to help users manage their data, delete old posts, and understand data usage. Facebook's principles emphasize user control, data security, and accountability, as the GDPR increases fines for companies found to be in breach of data protection law, potentially up to 4% of global annual turnover.

site_title: China's tourism industry is only just getting going
summary: Chinese outbound tourism has experienced explosive growth over the past decade, with 135 million travelers in 2016, generating US$261 billion in expenditure. The industry's boom is attributed to Deng Xiaoping's economic opening in the 1980s and the 1995 Approved Destination Status (ADS) program, which allowed organized tours to approved countries. The industry has three distinct phases, with rising income, increased travel experience, and easier visa regulations contributing to its growth. Investors should target destinations, industries, and companies that can attract Chinese tourists, such as Marriott, Ctrip, and foreign luxury brand retailers.

site_title: Fung Group opens Singapore hub in Asia push
summary: Fung Group, a retail and logistics conglomerate, has opened its 21,550 sq ft regional headquarters in Singapore, aiming to expand its presence in South Asia and Southeast Asia. The move is part of the company's strategy to shift its focus from Greater China to other markets, driven by the growth of the middle class and domestic consumption in the region. Singapore's educated workforce and status as a regional commercial centre will be essential to Fung Group's ambitions.

site_title: Singapore's first business radio station Money FM 89.3 debuts
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) launched Money FM 89.3, the country's first and only business and personal finance radio station, on January 29, 2018. Targeting professionals above 35 years old, the station features a lineup of presenters and analysts covering topics such as personal finance, market updates, and lifestyle reports. The station aims to exceed 300,000 weekly listeners within two years and break even in three to four years, with competitive advertising rates.

images.alt_text: A lion dance at the launch of Money FM 89.3. The station will reach out to anyone aged 35 and up with news and information on business and personal finance issues such as saving and investing.

site_title: Oil appears unstoppable as hedge funds take bets to new high
summary: Hedge funds have placed record bets on continued price increases for US and global oil benchmarks, fueling the enthusiasm in oil markets. OPEC-Russia solidarity, low US stockpiles, and a weak dollar are key factors driving the upward momentum. Futures are trading at three-year highs, with the futures curve showing backwardation, a typical sign of rising demand and tightening supplies. Experts predict prices will trade between $60 and $75 a barrel throughout 2018, with Brent crude potentially reaching $80.

site_title: Brexit - a difficult balancing act all round
summary: The UK and EU continue to negotiate Brexit, with talks progressing behind closed doors. EU leader Emmanuel Macron recently visited the UK, where he lent the Bayeux Tapestry, a symbol of France's past victory over Britain. This move has raised concerns among EU leaders, who worry about the UK's potential departure from the EU. The UK government remains indecisive, with Prime Minister Theresa May struggling to establish a clear negotiating position. Influential commentators urge the UK to become a business-friendly nation like Singapore, but this vision is hindered by the government's lack of direction and leadership.

site_title: CDL appoints new group CIO
summary: CDL appoints Frank Khoo, 49, as group chief investment officer from February 1, succeeding Sherman Kwek. Khoo has over 20 years of international experience in fund management, private equity, and real estate investments. He will assist the group CEO in sourcing new investment opportunities and set up a dedicated fund management platform. Khoo's expertise will help CDL build a fund management business providing strong recurring income and enhancing capital deployment efficiency.

site_title: Cairo keeps building homes, but who's buying?
summary: Egypt's government plans to introduce tens of thousands of new housing units into the market, but analysts say most will remain unsold due to prices being beyond the means of most Egyptians. The new residences are part of a five-year plan to provide a million subsidized homes for the poor, with 150,000 units already delivered and 260,000 under construction. The demand for new housing is driven by Egyptians working overseas and searching for investments to preserve their assets, with housing prices expected to continue to rise.

site_title: Bullish investors look past failed bid by CDL to privatise M&C Hotels
summary: City Developments (CDL) shares rose 1.97% after an aborted attempt to privatize Millenium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) due to insufficient minority shareholder support. CDL's offer of 620 pence per share was rejected, and the company will remain listed on the London Stock Exchange. Despite the failed bid, CDL's high-end condominium project New Futura saw 35 of 40 units sold for an average price of S$3,200 psf.

site_title: Ascott wins deals to manage 4 properties totalling 1,200 units
summary: Ascott has secured contracts to manage four properties with 1,200 units in Malaysia, the Philippines, China, and the Philippines. The properties include Somerset Melaka Island, Citadines Riverside Davao, lyf Cebu City, and Citadines Panyu Guangzhou. Ascott aims to double its global portfolio to 160,000 units by 2023, driven by the global economic upswing and international travel arrivals. The company will focus on key gateway cities and markets, leveraging digital innovation to enhance customer experience.

site_title: Ford China chief's abrupt departure a blow to recovery hopes
summary: Ford China's chief, Jason Luo, has stepped down after five months for personal reasons, raising concerns over the company's sales slump in China. Luo's departure is a blow to Ford's recovery hopes, as the carmaker has been falling behind rivals in the market. Luo was meant to improve ties with local joint venture partners and respond to local consumer demands. His replacement will be announced in the future, amid fierce competition from local rivals and government support for electric vehicles.

site_title: No end to hairy fights at Datapulse
summary: A feud between two families, the Ngs, has erupted at Datapulse Technology, a Singapore-based disk drive maker. Co-founder Ng Cheow Chye sold his stake to Ng Siew Hong in November, prompting a power struggle. The new board, appointed by Ng Siew Hong, has been at odds with the other co-founder, Ng Khim Guan's family, who claim they were misled about the company's intentions. Datapulse has announced an extraordinary general meeting to consider the proposed diversification into personal care products, amid allegations of inadequate due diligence and a possible takeover bid by private fund manager Ascapia Capital.

site_title: Rajah and Tann set 'to shift to Marina One by 2020'
summary: Major law firm Rajah and Tann plans to move to Marina One by 2020, occupying 80,000-90,000 square feet over two to three floors. The move is part of a trend of companies relocating to newer developments in the Central Business District. Rajah and Tann will marginally reduce its space, likely due to a shift towards a hot-desking model, rather than a cut in operations or staff size. Several other financial institutions and corporations have also moved to Marina One.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts drop in Q2 DPU
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 7.1% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2 2017, to 1.17 Singapore cents, due to lower net property income and higher withholding taxes. Gross revenue fell 3% to S$52.46 million, with NPI slipping 2.2% to S$40.5 million. Despite challenging market conditions, the portfolio has remained relatively resilient, with Singapore retail revenue stable and office space take-up encouraging.

site_title: December consumer spending up 0.4% but savings drop to 10-year low
