Wealth managers expect some family offices and rich clients to watch closely for updates on the budget, but overall, Singapore's safe haven reputation and measured approach are expected to outweigh any negative effects. The government aims to fund rising expenditure on infrastructure and healthcare through new taxes or increased tax rates.

images.alt_text: While the average worker is wringing his hands in anticipation of a GST hike, the possibility of new wealth taxes is also not lost on the rich.

site_title: Kushner Cos secures US$57m loan for troubled New Jersey towers
summary: Kushner Cos secured a $57 million loan from Fortress Investment Group for its troubled 1 Journal Square project in New Jersey. The loan is a small part of the estimated $124 million in debt needed to complete the project, which includes two 56-story towers with over 1,500 residential units. The project has faced issues, including the loss of a major tenant and strained relationships with local officials. This loan comes as Kushner Cos navigates potential conflicts of interest with Jared Kushner's role in the White House.

site_title: Twitter's twice-yearly executives' meeting hijacked by COO's resignation
summary: Twitter's twice-yearly meeting was disrupted by the sudden resignation of COO Anthony Noto, who is leaving to become CEO of Social Finance Inc. Noto's departure has led to a decline in Twitter shares, but analysts believe it won't impact the company's turnaround efforts, citing improved user engagement and upgrades in analyst estimates. CEO Jack Dorsey expressed his support and gratitude for Noto's accomplishments, calling his departure "bittersweet". Despite the loss, Dorsey's leadership is seen as a reassuring presence, and analysts expect Twitter's financial performance to continue strengthening over the next year.

site_title: Rates at some Trump hotels have dropped a year into his presidency
summary: Rates at some Trump hotels have dropped a year into his presidency, with his downtown Washington, DC hotel appearing to be doing well, while his Toronto and New York locations saw his brand become polarizing, leading to its removal.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us to shut about 180 US stores in bid to exit bankruptcy
summary: Toys 'R' Us plans to close about 180 US stores, approximately 20% of its US store base, as part of a reorganization plan to exit bankruptcy. The closures, starting next month, will include Babies "R" Us locations accounting for at least half. The move aims to simplify operations and supply chain, while also revamping loyalty programs and pricing models to be more competitive. The company has made operational mistakes that need to be fixed, despite a challenging Christmas shopping season.

site_title: Stamp duty cut no boon as UK home sales fall to 13-month low
summary: UK home sales have fallen to a 13-month low, with 99,100 properties changing hands in December, the lowest since November 2016. Chancellor Philip Hammond's stamp duty cut for first-time buyers, which applies to homes up to £300,000, has shown no impact. Analysts attribute the slowdown to inflation, Brexit uncertainty, and tax changes affecting landlords and owners of second homes, rather than the stamp duty cut. Prices remain out of reach for many young buyers, with the average cost of a first home in London at a record £409,975.

site_title: Higher rents boost Mapletree Commercial's Q3
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1.3% increase in income available for distribution to S$66.5 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2017. Distribution per unit (DPU) rose to 2.3 Singapore cents, up from 2.28 Singapore cents a year ago. The trust's Q3 results were boosted by higher rents, with the increase attributed to the rising demand for retail space. The distribution will be paid on Feb 28, with a books closure date of Feb 1.

site_title: Eurozone businesses start 2018 on decade high as work floods in
summary: Eurozone businesses started 2018 on a decade-high growth trajectory, driven by a strong performance in the service industry. The IHS Markit composite PMI for the eurozone rose to 58.6, its highest since June 2006, surpassing economists' forecasts. Consumer confidence jumped to a 17-year high, and price pressures increased, supporting the European Central Bank's case for tighter monetary policy. This data could lead to faster GDP growth, with estimates suggesting a 1% first-quarter growth rate.

site_title: Chanel goes all girly with pretty-in-pink walk in the park
summary: Karl Lagerfeld transformed Coco Chanel's classic silhouettes into sugar plum fairy creations for the brand's Paris haute couture show, giving them an intensely girly twist. The collection featured pretty-in-pink dresses, beaded tweed suits, and crystal-encrusted boots. Lagerfeld, 84, wore an unkempt white beard, his first radical change of image in nearly two decades. The show also featured a young model, 19-year-old Dutch model Luna Bijl, who walked the catwalk in a white tuxedo and rose-petal trail.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust prices upsized S$100m placement of units at top end of S$1.48
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) priced an upsized S$100 million placement of units at S$1.48 apiece, exceeding its indicated price range. The placement saw strong participation from new and existing institutional investors, with 67.6 million new units to be issued. The funds will be used to partially finance the proposed acquisition of a 50% stake in Farnborough Business Park in west London, with the remaining proceeds for placement-related expenses. Trading of the new units is expected to commence on February 1.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers have made positive updates on three companies: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Frencken Group. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's target price was raised to S$2.48 due to increased rental growth assumptions and optimism over 7% distribution growth in 2018. Mapletree Logistics Trust was upgraded to "add" with a raised target price of S$1.43, citing a constructive bottom-up story and potential upside from redevelopment initiatives. Frencken Group was initiated with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.79, driven by its diversified customer base and robust cash pile.

site_title: US home sales fall as record low inventory boosts prices
summary: US home sales declined 3.6% in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.57 million units, driven by a record low inventory of 1.48 million homes on the market. This led to a 5.8% increase in median house prices to $246,800, the 70th straight month of year-on-year gains. Despite the drop, housing is expected to contribute to economic growth in the fourth quarter, with first-time buyers accounting for 32% of transactions. A shortage of lower-end homes and low housing inventory continue to impact the market.

site_title: Ending shutdown with hopes for bi-partisan deal
summary: A US government shutdown has ended after a three-day closure, with Democrats agreeing to reopen the government in exchange for a Senate debate on an immigration policy, including the fate of the "Dreamers" - young undocumented immigrants brought to the US as children. The deal comes after President Trump's administration threatened to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which allows Dreamers to live and work in the US. The shutdown was sparked by a disagreement over funding for the government and the proposed border wall.

site_title: Suntec Reit's DPU up 0.31% for Q4
summary: Suntec Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 0.31% to 2.604 Singapore cents for Q4, driven by a 0.31% increase in its DPU. However, the quarter's earnings were dented by lower revenue from Suntec Singapore and a fall in office rentals. Despite this, the trust maintained its distribution per unit for the full year. The trust's quarterly earnings fell short of market expectations, with analysts anticipating a higher DPU.

site_title: Datapulse proposes special payout to get minorities' backing
summary: Datapulse Technology, a digital storage maker, proposes a special cash dividend of one Singapore cent per share after selling its headquarters for S$53.5 million. The move aims to win over minority shareholders, but experts say it's unlikely to address concerns about shareholder value. The board's diversification plan has sparked controversy, and two shareholder meetings are set to decide the company's future.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust grows DPU despite tough market conditions
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust, Singapore's largest retail Reit, reported a 0.7% increase in quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.9 Singapore cents, despite tough market conditions. The Reit's distributable income rose 0.4% to S$395.8 million, while net property income dipped 0.3% to S$478.2 million. The manager plans to continue sustaining payout despite intense competition in the retail sector.

site_title: Take changes to corporate governance rules in the right spirit
summary: Singapore's Corporate Governance Council has proposed changes to the Code of Corporate Governance, including a "nine-year rule" for independent directors, requiring them to serve a maximum of nine years to avoid a two-tier vote. The council also proposes tightening the definition of independent directors, requiring them to own less than 5% of company shares. These changes aim to reduce the risk of cosy relationships between directors and major shareholders, aligning with international best practices and ensuring Singapore remains competitive among listing destinations.

site_title: US Senate confirms Jerome Powell as Fed chair
summary: The US Senate confirmed Jerome Powell as the new Federal Reserve Chair, succeeding Janet Yellen, with a 84-13 vote. Powell, 64, will serve a four-year term starting early next month. The confirmation is seen as a sign of bipartisan support and continuity in US monetary policy, which is expected to gradually increase interest rates and reduce the balance sheet. However, a debate is brewing about the Fed's approach to inflation and potential financial deregulation, with some lawmakers expressing concerns about Powell's lack of economic expertise.

site_title: DBS cuts transaction fees for SME corporate payments
summary: DBS has reduced transaction fees for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, offering 50 cents per transaction for corporate payments using the FAST payment system. This is significantly lower than typical charges from competing banks, which range from $1 to $8 per transaction. The move aims to ease cashflow problems and eliminate human error for SMEs, with a 2.5 times increase in online payments to vendors and suppliers in 2017. The bank also plans to introduce a new payments solution to SMEs in Hong Kong by the end of the year.

site_title: Expert behind new MH370 search hopeful of find within a month
summary: A fresh search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370) has begun in the remote Indian Ocean, led by private exploration firm Ocean Infinity. The search, which began on Monday, aims to utilize oceanographic analyses and a high-tech search vessel to locate the Boeing 777, which vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board. The search area was pinpointed by top Australian scientist, and experts are hopeful of finding the jet within a month.

site_title: Riots in Indian cities on eve of Hindu queen film release
summary: Hindu hardliners in India have rampaged through several cities, protesting the upcoming release of the film "Padmaavat," which tells the story of a legendary Hindu queen. Rioting and violence broke out in Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, and other states, with police firing shots in the air to disperse protesters. The film's producers deny the allegations of a romance between the queen and a Muslim ruler, and police have increased security measures ahead of the film's release. A group of women from a caste-based group threatened to burn themselves alive if the film is released, but the Indian court rejected efforts to ban the film, citing creative freedom.

site_title: Lure of private chalets in Swiss ski town
summary: Visitors to Wengen, a Swiss ski town, are increasingly opting for private chalet rentals over hotels, driven by the village's unique charm and scenic views. The area's famous peaks and rail station make it a popular destination, with tourists drawn to its traffic-free environment. As a result, local businesses are adapting to meet the demand for private accommodations, offering a more personalized experience for visitors.

site_title: Allied Tech to buy 51% stake in e-commerce ticketing solutions platform Asia Box Office
summary: Allied Technologies, a Catalist-listed company, has signed a binding memorandum of understanding to buy a 51% stake in Asia Box Office, a Singapore-based e-commerce ticketing solutions platform. The deal's valuation is estimated at approximately S$60 million. The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. This move aims to expand Allied Technologies' presence in the digital ticketing market.

site_title: US warns Hong Kong on illicit North Korea trade
summary: A US official warned Hong Kong authorities to stop being a "safe harbour" for illicit North Korea trade, violating UN sanctions. This comes after a Hong Kong-flagged ship was seized in South Korea for transferring oil products to a North Korean vessel. The US urges Hong Kong to tighten up its regulations and press China to expel North Korean financial facilitators. Hong Kong's government has stated it strictly implements UN sanctions and will investigate suspected violations, with two new laws strengthening existing requirements set to come into force in March.

site_title: ADM opens food innovation centre in Biopolis
summary: Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) has opened a new food innovation centre in Biopolis, Singapore, marking its first research centre in South-east Asia. The 8,900 sq ft facility will develop flavours and ingredients for food manufacturers, with a focus on local tastes. The centre, staffed by 50 employees, includes labs and pilot plants for various food applications. ADM aims to collaborate with customers to refine flavours and create final products, and is part of the company's efforts to transform the food manufacturing sector in Singapore.

site_title: Forget Davos for a moment, Emmanuel Macron is making dinner
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is wooing CEOs and investors with a grand dinner at Versailles, a move seen as a confidence booster for the country's economy. Mergers and acquisitions are already picking up, with completed deals involving French targets growing 80% last year to $71 billion. Privatisations are likely to accelerate, with the government planning to sell assets worth 60 billion euros to build a 10 billion-euro innovation fund. Macron's efforts are seen as a step towards making France a more attractive destination for foreign investment, but challenges remain, including high government spending and rigid labor laws.

images.alt_text: Mr Macron has a grand plan to woo CEOs and investors. He has invited 140 bosses for dinner at the palace of Versailles this week.

site_title: Malaysia probes leak of organ donor details
summary: Malaysia has launched an investigation into the leak of 220,000 organ donor details, including names, identity card numbers, and next of kin information, which were reportedly dumped online. The breach occurred between 2009 and 2016, and is the second major data breach in the country in recent months. The Personal Data Protection Commission views the leak "seriously" and is working to determine the source of the leak.

site_title: Cambodia-Laos-Vietnam triangle striving to succeed
summary: The Cambodia-Laos-Vietnam Development Triangle (CLV-DT) aims to reduce its economic gap with Asean countries by harnessing free trade, investments, and tourism. However, it faces obstacles including poor cooperation, infrastructure, and coordination. The region has significant potential, with Vietnam's Viettel telecom group leading efforts to modernize telecommunication networks. Despite progress, the CLV lags behind major Asean countries, with wide income disparities among its member provinces. The region's underdeveloped transport infrastructure and lack of coordination hinder development efforts, but the CLV prime ministers plan to hold their 10th summit meeting to push forward development.

site_title: EU fines chipmaker Qualcomm 997m euros over exclusivity deal with Apple
summary: The European Union has fined chipmaker Qualcomm 997 million euros for paying Apple to exclusively use its chips, blocking out rivals like Intel. The fine, 4.9% of Qualcomm's 2017 turnover, was approved by EU antitrust regulators after an investigation from 2015. Qualcomm plans to appeal the decision, while Apple will not face repercussions. The fine comes as Qualcomm faces other regulatory challenges, including a hostile bid from Broadcom and investigations by US regulators.

site_title: Hong Fok Corporation redeems S$100 million 4.75 per cent notes
summary: Hong Fok Corporation has fully redeemed its S$100 million 4.75 per cent notes due this year, along with accrued interest. The redemption was made under the company's S$600 million Multicurrency Debt Issuance Programme. Following the redemption, there are no notes outstanding.

site_title: Qatar economy weathers Saudi-led blockade: report
summary: Qatar's economy has weathered the impact of a months-long blockade by Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt, with positive growth in the seven months since the blockade began. The economy grew by 1.9% in the third quarter, despite a 20% decline in tourism visitor arrivals and a 9.9% drop in real estate prices. Capital Economics report also noted that foreign liabilities of Qatari banks rose for the first time in six months, indicating domestic banks secured additional financing from foreign banks. The blockade, which began in June, was due to Qatar's alleged support of extremist groups.

site_title: Pacific Radiance asks for more time to report FY2017, Q1 2018 results
summary: Pacific Radiance has applied to the Singapore Exchange for more time to announce its FY2017 and Q1 2018 results, citing ongoing debt restructuring discussions with potential investors, lenders, and noteholders. The company expects to finalize the main terms of the restructuring before releasing its financial results, which may provide incomplete information. The request for an extension also includes a delay in convening the AGM for FY2017 and lodging the annual return due to the need for additional time to complete the audit of its results and publication of the annual report.

site_title: White House seen declaring open season on US dollar at Davos
summary: The US dollar has declined to its lowest in three years after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin endorsed its weakness as a benefit to the American economy at Davos. Mnuchin's comments, made days after President Trump's protectionist push, have been seen as a "green light" for the currency's decline. The dollar has lost value against every Group-of-10 peer since Trump's inauguration, with Bloomberg's US dollar index slumping 0.8% as of 9:23am in New York. Analysts believe the White House may be using the currency as part of its trade agenda, validating further weakness.

site_title: China to surprise world with reform in 2018
summary: China plans to introduce more economic reforms in 2018, aiming to open up its economy and make it more accessible to international investors. Top financial and economic adviser Liu He stated that some measures will exceed expectations, echoing President Xi Jinping's remarks on the importance of economic globalization. China aims to integrate with international trade rules, ease market access, and control financial risks, with a focus on ensuring financial stability. The moves come as the country battles pollution, poverty, and financial risk, and amid rising tensions with the US.

site_title: Oriental Group granted extension of judicial management order until July 26
summary: The Singapore High Court has approved an extension of the judicial management order for Oriental Group until July 26, with the order initially set to expire on January 26. The six-month extension allows the company to hold its annual general meeting as instructed by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA).

site_title: Mary Chia Holdings granted extension until March 9 to raise public float to at least 10%
summary: Mary Chia Holdings, a slimming services chain, has been granted an extension until March 9 to raise its public float to at least 10% and maintain its listing status. The company's shares have been suspended since October 9, 2017, following a mandatory unconditional cash offer by Suki Sushi, which now holds a 93.18% stake in the firm. The extension allows more time to facilitate the placement of shares to meet Catalist listing rules.

site_title: UBS chairman Weber sees 'massive' potential drop in Bitcoin
summary: UBS chairman Axel Weber warned of a "massive" potential drop in Bitcoin's value due to increased regulation, citing concerns over money laundering and tax evasion. He stated that banks are reluctant to invest client money into cryptocurrencies, and the European Commission may ramp up regulation of virtual currencies. Despite this, Credit Suisse's CEO Tidjane Thiam believes digital currencies have a future and blockchain technology has potential. Bitcoin's value has dropped to $11,076, down from a high of $18,675, with some experts calling it a "bubble".

site_title: US: Wall St opens at record levels
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened at record levels on January 24, 2018, following positive earnings reports from companies such as General Electric, Abbott Labs, and United Technologies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 85.89 points to 26,296.7, the S&P 500 gained 7.1 points to 2,846.23, and the Nasdaq Composite added 14.48 points to 7,474.77.

site_title: Saudi still holding 95 people as it aims to wind down corruption probe
summary: Saudi authorities continue to hold 95 people as part of their anti-corruption campaign, launched by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in November. 90 detainees have been released with their charges dropped or traded assets for freedom. The government aims to recover $100 billion in illicit funds and expects a small number to be prosecuted. The crackdown has raised concerns about the economy, particularly among foreign investors. Those released are free to move without restrictions, and the Ritz Carlton hotel, where detainees are being held, is expected to reopen next month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1 point to 1,837.04. The trading volume was 3.4 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 606 to 402.

site_title: Mexico's drug cartels, now hooked on fuel, cripple nation's refineries
summary: Mexico's drug cartels, now hooked on fuel, have crippled the nation's refineries. In 2015, a Michoacan Family cartel member called a pump technician at an oil refinery in Salamanca, seeking information. The cartel's demand for fuel has led to a series of attacks on refineries, crippling the nation's oil production. This has resulted in fuel shortages and economic losses for the country. Authorities are struggling to combat the cartel's influence, and the situation remains volatile, with the cartels' grip on the fuel supply showing no signs of weakening.

site_title: SoftBank leads US$865m investment in construction technology startup Katerra
summary: SoftBank led a US$865 million investment in construction technology startup Katerra, valuing the company at over US$3 billion. The investment, made by SoftBank's Vision Fund and other investors, brings Katerra's bookings to US$1.3 billion. The company aims to shake up the building industry with its technology. Jeffrey Housenbold, a SoftBank executive, will join Katerra's board.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rebound to end at fresh record
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose to a fresh record on Wednesday, driven by optimism about the corporate earnings season. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.08% to 32,958.69, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.37% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.51%. The gains follow a strong start to the year, with investors seeking to capitalize on the expected earnings season.

site_title: China's HNA considers IPO for cargo handler Swissport: sources
summary: China's HNA Group is considering an initial public offering (IPO) or sale of cargo handler Swissport to fix its finances, with a potential valuation of 2.7 billion Swiss francs. The process may start in the second quarter, following HNA's plan to float Swiss caterer Gategroup in Zurich. Swissport provides ground services for 835 aviation clients and has annual sales of 2.7 billion euros. HNA has been struggling with financing problems, with Chinese banks voicing concerns over its debt.

site_title: Europe's Brexit serenade failing to lure many London bankers
summary: London bankers are unlikely to leave the UK immediately due to the prospect of a softer Brexit, with Frankfurt and Paris expecting a trickle rather than a wave of new arrivals in 2018. Despite conciliatory signals from British Prime Minister Theresa May and progress in EU talks, banks such as Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs are delaying large staff moves, with only hundreds of jobs expected to be transferred. A hard Brexit remains a possibility, but positive signals from regulators and politicians have encouraged banks to reassess their strategies.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's Q3 DPU up on higher rental contributions
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1.3% increase in income available for distribution to S$66.5 million for its Q3 2017, with a 2.3 Singapore cent DPU. Revenue rose 0.8% to S$109.7 million, driven by higher contributions from VivoCity and Mapletree Business City I. The nine-month FY2018 DPU grew 6.4% to 6.77 Singapore cents, with trust units adding one Singapore cent to close at S$1.66.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust reports 1.1% dip in DPS for Q1 FY2018
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 1.1% year-on-year dip in distribution per stapled security to 1.3107 Singapore cents for Q1 FY2018. Gross revenue rose 4.8% to S$41.5 million and net property income increased 3.1% to S$31.4 million. The company attributed the decline to a higher stapled security base and renovation at the Novotel Rockford Darling Harbour. Despite this, the trust remains well-positioned for growth and asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q4 earnings rocket 456.4% on fair value gains
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a 456.4% increase in net profit to S$17.1 million in Q4 2017, driven by fair value gains from the reclassification of an associated firm. Revenue declined 12.1% to S$43.7 million. The company also reported a 50.7% drop in full-year net profit to S$51.8 million. Earnings per share rose 416.7% to 3.1 Singapore cents. A final dividend of 3.5 Singapore cents per share was proposed, 22.2% lower than last year.

site_title: ComfortDelGro starts petrol retail business
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean transport giant, has started its petrol retail business, offering discounted fuel to its growing fleet of hybrid taxis and potentially private-hire cars. The company's petrol pumps, supplied by Caltex, are priced lower than commercial pumps, with a current retail price of S$1.56 per liter. This move is seen as a strategic expansion, following ComfortDelGro's addition of hybrid vehicles to its fleet in 2011. The company's petrol retail business is expected to be joined by two other locations later this year.

site_title: Qatar Airways to comply with TSA's tougher cargo screening
summary: Qatar Airways has agreed to comply with the US Transportation Security Administration's (TSA) enhanced cargo screening requirements for its flights originating from six Middle East airports. The TSA had announced the new Air Cargo Advance Screening protocols, which will apply to cargo from Doha, Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Jeddah, Cairo, and Amman airports. Qatar Airways is liaising with the TSA and regulators to ensure regulatory compliance. The new requirements are part of an effort to strengthen cargo security, which most airlines have already been applying voluntarily.

site_title: Creditors grant nod for Nam Cheong's Singapore scheme
summary: Creditors of Nam Cheong, a Singapore-listed holding company, have approved a debt restructuring plan by a majority vote of 94.139% of total creditors present. The plan allows for a debt-to-equity conversion and two options for the sustainable portion of debts, with creditors able to convert into a seven-year term loan or cash out at a recovery rate of between 5-20 cents per dollar. The decision paves the way for Nam Cheong to restructure under three schemes in Malaysia and Singapore, seeking extra time to recover from a prolonged offshore and marine downturn.

site_title: Geopolitical risk is fund managers' top concern for 2018, says IMAS survey
summary: Fund managers in Singapore cite geopolitical risks as their top concern for 2018, surpassing interest rate hikes and US politics uncertainty. A survey by the Investment Management Association of Singapore found that 55 firms prioritize geopolitical risks, with multi-asset strategies expected to grow in popularity. The top three strategies are multi-asset (53%), ESG-focused (39%), and absolute return (35%) strategies, driven by client demand for diversification and risk management. The survey also highlights fintech's rise as a growth driver, with 57% of respondents expecting it to impact fund distribution channels over the next three years.

site_title: Europe: Shares weighed down by Suez warning, tumbling tech stocks
summary: European shares declined on Wednesday due to a profit warning from France's Suez and tumbling tech stocks, particularly Apple supplier AMS, which fell 7% after a JP Morgan rating cut. The STOXX 600 index dropped 0.1%, while Germany's DAX index remained flat. However, Novartis' strong update lifted healthcare stocks, and the Swiss-based group forecast faster operating profit growth in 2018. The decline was attributed to additional costs in Spain and contract closures in Morocco and India, affecting peer Veolia and the utilities index.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.48% as STI crosses 3,600 at the finish
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.48% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index advancing to 3,609.24 points, driven by gains in aluminium part maker Midas Holdings and all three local banks. Midas Holdings surged 5% after a S$7.7 million deal, while Singtel and Accrelist also increased. However, City Developments Ltd shed 0.15% after reporting a takeover offer for London-listed Millenium & Copthorne Hotels fell short of the conditional acceptance threshold.

site_title: Google outspends tech rivals on Washington lobbying in 2017
summary: Google outspent its tech rivals in lobbying in 2017, with over $18 million spent, according to federal disclosures. Facebook and Amazon also set records, spending $11.5 million and $10.5 million, respectively. The increased lobbying came as the tech sector faced scrutiny over issues such as Russia's use of their platforms during the 2016 election and regulatory rollback under President Trump. The lobbying efforts were part of a broader push to capitalize on tax overhaul and regulatory changes.

site_title: Gold inches up on weaker US dollar, trade war concerns
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,342.30 per ounce on Wednesday, nearing a four-month high, as the US dollar hit a fresh three-year low against the yen due to concerns over a potential trade war. A weaker US dollar makes gold more attractive for holders of other currencies. Investors are also concerned about the impact of US President Trump's import tariffs on global trade. Gold prices are expected to trend higher, with a near-term target of $1,400 per ounce.

site_title: Novartis sees return to growth this year with new chief
summary: Novartis AG has projected a return to growth in 2018, driven by new medicines such as Entresto, Cosentyx, and Kisqali, which are expected to boost sales and counter the impact of cheaper copycats on its aging blockbuster Gleevec. The company's new CEO, Vas Narasimhan, will initially receive 8.9 million francs in annual compensation, and earnings excluding some items rose 7% to US$3.2 billion in the fourth quarter. Sales rose 5% to US$12.9 billion, with a possible decline at Sandoz, the generics unit, due to price pressure.

site_title: Plug wars: the battle for electric car supremacy
summary: German carmakers are launching a network of high-power charging stations with Ford to establish a standard for plugs and protocols, aiming to gain an edge over electric car rivals. The Combined Charging System (CCS) favored by Europe is seen as key to resolving the issue of different plug technologies. The charging infrastructure will require an estimated $360 billion investment over the next eight years, with Swiss bank UBS estimating that the number of plug formats will need to be limited to keep costs down. Industry analysts believe that carmakers backing the winning technology will benefit from having an established supply chain and extensive network.

site_title: New banknotes for CNY available from Jan 29 at POSB pop-up ATMs in community clubs
summary: Singaporeans can obtain new Chinese New Year banknotes starting January 29 at 36 POSB pop-up ATMs in community clubs. The machines, except one, will be available 24/7 until February 14. DBS and POSB branches also offer online reservations and in-branch collection. The move aims to reduce waiting time for customers, who can also deposit money using DBS PayLah during the auspicious day of Li Chun (February 4) to win $88.

site_title: HNA Group seeks investors for Hong Kong property
summary: HNA Group, a heavily indebted Chinese conglomerate, is seeking outside investors to buy into two Hong Kong plots it purchased for $1.8 billion. The plots, located near the former Kai Tak airport, will be sold through a fund with two investment classes, offering 9% annual returns for a two-year term and 40% of profits for a four-year term. The move aims to ease HNA's financial pressure, which has been exacerbated by a debt-fuelled acquisition spree and mounting loan repayments.

site_title: Professional services sector roadmap aims to create 5,500 new jobs annually till 2020
summary: Singapore has launched a roadmap to boost its professional services sector, aiming to create 5,500 new jobs annually until 2020. The Industry Transformation Map (ITM) targets 4.6% annual growth and a value-add of S$31 billion by 2020. The sector, which includes accounting, consulting, and advertising, will focus on high-growth areas such as data science and artificial intelligence. The government will play a catalytic role by supporting innovation platforms and training programs for professionals, including four new Professional Conversion Programs.

site_title: MAS slaps 8-year ban on former AIA agent for cheating widowed factory worker
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued an 8-year ban on former AIA representative Tan Peng Khoon for cheating a widowed factory worker. Tan is prohibited from carrying on business, providing financial advisory services, and managing insurance intermediaries. The ban is under the Insurance Act and Financial Advisers Act. This action is taken to protect consumers from unscrupulous practices in the insurance industry.

site_title: Asia-Pacific companies account for a quarter of world's top 250 retailers: Deloitte
summary: A quarter of the world's top 250 retailers by revenue now come from the Asia-Pacific region, with 63 companies hailing from this area, up from 10.4% in 2006 to 15.4% in 2016. However, despite growing global presence, Asia-Pacific retailers have been slow to invest in international operations, with most operating in only 3.6 countries on average. European retailers remain the most globally active, with 85% operating internationally, and top-line focus came at the expense of profit for some Asian retailers, such as China's JD.com.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A new professional services sector roadmap aims to generate 5,500 new jobs annually from 2015 to 2020. Meanwhile, CDL's takeover offer for M&C is nearing its conditional acceptance threshold. Other news includes the sale of a freehold serviced apartment project by TA Realty, Frasers Commercial Trust's placement at S$1.48, and Singapore Airlines' restructuring of flights between Canberra and Wellington. Additionally, EZ-Link payments will be accepted on NETS terminals at hawker centres, and Singtel has appointed a new head of its global cybersecurity unit.

site_title: American drivers begin warming up to riding in self-driving cars
summary: US drivers are gradually warming up to the idea of self-driving cars, with 63% of drivers expressing some level of comfort, down from 78% last year. Younger drivers are more open to the technology, with fewer than half of millennials concerned. Despite this, total trust remains a work in progress, with 13% of drivers feeling safer sharing the road with a driverless vehicle. US Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao has called on companies to educate the public on the safety of autonomous vehicles, citing education, exposure, and experience as key to easing consumer fears.

site_title: EZ-Link payments to be accepted on NETS terminals at hawker centres
summary: NETS and EZ-Link announced that EZ-Link payments will be accepted on NETS terminals at hawker centres starting April 2018. This expansion will cater to senior citizens and students without bank accounts, allowing them to use their concession cards for payments. The move aims to promote cashless payments in Singapore, with both companies planning to partner up for further forms of cashless payments in the future.

site_title: Barry Callebaut expects chocolate recovery to continue after solid Q1
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Barry Callebaut reported a 8% increase in sales volumes in Q1, driven by a global confectionery sales volume growth of 3.1% and outsourcing deals with big food groups. The company expects the market recovery to continue, with average volume growth of 4-6% on track. Sales revenue declined 0.7% due to lower raw material prices, but the company remains optimistic, citing strong demand for its products.

site_title: Google, Tencent, Sequoia China join US$15m funding for pharma startup XtalPi
summary: Google, Tencent, and Sequoia China have invested $15 million in XtalPi, a pharmaceutical startup using AI, cloud computing, and quantum physics to improve drug design processes. This brings XtalPi's total funding to $20 million. The deal is the first co-investment by Google and Tencent, following their patent sharing agreement. Google has increased its investment in the Chinese market, with a dedicated AI lab launched last month. XtalPi's funding round follows its use of AI and cloud computing to enhance drug development processes.

site_title: Tennis: Chung blazes trail into Australian Open semi-finals
summary: Chung Hyeon, a 21-year-old South Korean tennis player, has become his nation's first grand slam semi-finalist at the Australian Open. He defeated American Tennys Sandgren 6-4 7-6(5) 6-3, advancing to the semi-finals. Chung, ranked 58th in the world, is the lowest-ranked player to reach the last four since Marat Safin in 2004. He will face either champion Roger Federer or Tomas Berdych for a spot in the final, looking to build on his confidence.

site_title: Tesla still welcome in India after Musk picks China for factory
summary: Tesla remains welcome in India despite choosing China for its first overseas factory. Transport Minister Nitin Gadkari stated that the country is open to Tesla's operations and is willing to offer help, including land, if the company decides to set up shop. The decision to opt for China was reportedly a result of discussions with Indian officials, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who has been promoting the country as a hub for global investors. India aims to become a major hub for electric vehicle manufacturing, with a goal of all new car sales being electric models by 2030.

images.alt_text: India is still open to Tesla Inc setting up operations in the country, even though the electric-car maker has chosen China for its first plant overseas.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us says to shut a fifth of its US stores
summary: Toys 'R' Us plans to close about 180 US stores, roughly one-fifth of its US locations, as it emerges from bankruptcy. The closure will begin in early February and continue until mid-April. The company aims to restructure $5 billion of debt and invest in its remaining stores, including $400 million for sprucing up about 900 stores over three years. The US bankruptcy filing cast doubt on the future of its 64,000 employees.

site_title: China's man in Davos is 'the brain' behind economy's overhaul
summary: Chinese technocrat Liu He, a key adviser to President Xi Jinping, is set to become the country's top economic policymaker, overseeing the overhaul of China's economy and financial system. A Harvard-educated expert, Liu has guided policy behind the scenes and is seen as the heir-apparent to Vice Premier Ma Kai. He will play a crucial role in shaping economic policy for the next five years, focusing on supply-side reforms to cut overcapacity and boost market forces. Liu's appointment comes amid China's struggle to ease its addiction to credit and avoid a collapse in asset values.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close lower on stronger yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday due to a stronger yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.76% to 23,940.78 and the Topix index dropped 0.51% to 1,901.23. This follows a 26-year high closed the previous day. The yen's appreciation weighed down Japanese exporters.

site_title: Hot stock: Midas up on S$7.7m married deal, say sources
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based maker of aluminium parts for trains, saw its shares surge 7% to S$0.171 following a S$7.7 million married deal involving 44 million shares. The deal, involving unknown buyers and sellers, led to over 200 million shares changing hands, the most active trading on the Singapore Exchange. The news comes after Midas' associate company secured new contracts worth S$552 million to supply metro train cars in China.

site_title: China's Premier Li calls for more targeted economic policy
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang has called for more targeted economic policies to address structural changes in the country's economy, which reported a 6.9% growth rate in 2017, exceeding the government's target of 6.5%. Li emphasized the need for reform, opening up, and innovation to propel transformation and foster new economic drivers. Policymakers are balancing the need to contain financial risks and slow corporate debt with the risk of destabilizing economic growth. Li's comments come after China's economy showed signs of improvement, but policymakers face challenges in shuttering polluting factories without causing unemployment.

images.alt_text: China's Premier Li Keqiang has called for more targeted economic policies and measures to cope with structural changes in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: TA Realty puts up freehold serviced apartment project for sale
summary: TA Realty is selling its freehold serviced apartment project, 12onShan, in Novena for S$107 million. The 16-storey development, comprising 78 serviced apartments, is expected to obtain a temporary occupation permit in the second quarter. Located near the medical hub and 550 meters from Novena MRT station, the project benefits from the upcoming integrated healthcare master plan development, Health City Novena. The tender will close on March 8, with Knight Frank Singapore and Savills Singapore marketing the asset as an ideal investment opportunity due to its locational attributes and investment size.

site_title: Thai Dec car sales jump 20.1% y-o-y: federation
summary: Thai domestic car sales surged 20.1% in December, reaching 104,302 units, the highest level in four years, driven by motor shows, improving consumer confidence, and the country's economic recovery. This marks the first annual increase in five years. The Federation of Thai Industries forecasts 900,000 domestic car sales for 2018, up from 870,000 in 2017. Annual domestic car sales had declined from 2013-2016 following a government car subsidy scheme end in 2012.

site_title: China's HNA Group says wins compliance clearances from JPMorgan, UBS, among others
summary: China's HNA Group has received compliance clearances from major banks, including JPMorgan, UBS, and Credit Suisse, after passing know-your-customer checks. The aviation-to-financial services conglomerate has been under scrutiny following its July announcement of a changed shareholding structure and the revelation that two previously named shareholders were proxies for company founders. This rare positive news provides a boost to the cash-strapped conglomerate amid governance and ownership concerns.

site_title: Green logo for Budweiser as brewer taps into US wind power
summary: Budweiser, a US brewer, has switched all its US brewing to renewable electricity, adding a "100 per cent renewable electricity" symbol to its labels. This move, part of its parent Anheuser-Busch InBev's global shift to green power, aims to lift sales after a dip. As one of over 100 multinational firms committing to renewable power under the Paris accord, Budweiser joins the world's biggest brewer in combating pollution and climate change.

site_title: New Zealand dollar breaks to 4-month peak, Aussie lags a little
summary: The New Zealand dollar reached a four-month peak at US$0.7362, driven by heightened global risk appetite and recent dairy price rises. The Australian dollar lagged behind, struggling to break above US$0.8030 and facing potential retracement. The kiwi's performance was aided by US President Donald Trump's imposition of tariffs, which sparked fears of further protectionist measures. The New Zealand dollar is expected to face domestic hurdles, including consumer price figures for the fourth quarter, which may impact interest rate decisions.

site_title: Australian shares finish higher, QBE Insurance leads; NZ up
summary: Australian shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.3% to 6,054.7, driven by gains in financial and healthcare stocks. QBE Insurance led the gains with a 5.4% jump, rebounding from a 6% drop on Tuesday after it announced a record annual loss. Other top performers included Macquarie Group, CSL, and Cochlear. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also rose 0.2%.

site_title: Asia: Most markets suffer losses as rally peters out
summary: Asian markets suffered losses on Wednesday, marking a rare breather from a rally that sent Hong Kong to record highs and Tokyo to levels not seen in over a quarter century. The rally was fueled by optimism over the global economy, strong earnings reports, and Donald Trump's tax cuts. Central banks' stimulus withdrawal expectations and the US dollar's decline weighed on the markets, despite Trump's recent tariff threats.

site_title: Vaping under threat in tobacco-loving Indonesia
summary: Indonesia is cracking down on the e-cigarette industry, citing concerns over public health, amid a high smoking rate of 65% among adult men. The government has been criticized for siding with tobacco firms at the expense of public health. The move comes as Indonesia has one of the world's highest smoking rates, with cigarette packs costing just $2. The government's decision is seen as a significant blow to the country's booming e-cigarette sector.

site_title: Sujoy Ghosh joins Citi from Allianz as new regional head of insurance for Asia Pacific and EMEA
summary: US banking giant Citi has appointed industry veteran Sujoy Ghosh as its regional head of insurance for the Asia Pacific and EMEA, effective next month. Ghosh, previously regional head of bancassurance for Allianz in the Asia Pacific, will oversee Citi's insurance business and develop strategic partnerships. His appointment aims to capture a greater share of the growing insurance market, supporting the bank's recent growth. Ghosh will report to Gonzalo Luchetti, head of Asia Pacific and EMEA retail banking, and will work closely with Citi's cards and loans team.

site_title: Singtel appoints new head of global cybersecurity unit
summary: Singtel has appointed Arthur Wong as the new head of its global cybersecurity unit, following the acquisition of US-based security services firm Trustwave in 2015. The business unit is expected to generate around S$550 million in revenue this financial year. Wong joins from DXC Technology, where he was the general manager of its cyber security business. With over 2,000 cybersecurity professionals in Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the Americas, the unit is a significant part of Singtel's expansion into the business.

site_title: Singapore-Sri Lanka FTA helps both countries access regional markets, says Iswaran
summary: Singapore and Sri Lanka have signed a free trade agreement (FTA), marking a significant milestone in their relations. The deal guarantees zero tariffs for 80% of Singapore's exports to Sri Lanka, estimated to save S$10 million yearly. It also ensures greater access to Sri Lanka's services market and government procurement projects, as well as better protection for Singapore investments. The agreement has raised some concerns among Sri Lankan businesses, but Minister of Trade and Industry S Iswaran believes the trade-offs are manageable.

site_title: China planning to set up personal credit reporting agency: PBOC
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), is planning to set up a personal credit reporting agency, focusing on information protection. The agency will replace the existing centralized credit scoring system, which only covers around 300 million people, leaving half a billion borrowers without credit scores. The new agency aims to provide a more comprehensive system, rewarding honesty and compliance while punishing misconduct. The PBOC is working to supervise information collection and limit its use, following concerns over data security and conflicts of interest.

site_title: Fresh tremors halt search ops after Japan volcano eruption
summary: Tremors halted search operations at Mt. Kusatsu Shirane in Japan, a day after an eruption killed a soldier and injured others. A group of 50 police and rescue workers were searching the area on Wednesday but stopped due to volcanic tremors detected. The eruption occurred near a popular ski resort. No further details on casualties or injuries were provided. The cause of the eruption is unclear, but the volcanic activity prompted the suspension of search operations.

images.alt_text: New volcanic activity Wednesday forced Japanese police to suspend search operations a day after an eruption near a popular ski resort that killed a soldier and injured several other people.

site_title: Warning signs go overlooked in Hong Kong's hot stock market
summary: Hong Kong's equity market is experiencing a record-breaking boom, with the Hang Seng Index jumping almost 10% this year, outpacing peers globally. Despite warning signs such as high momentum, market turnover, and valuation, many analysts remain optimistic, citing fundamentals and lower valuations compared to other developed markets. However, some indicators, including relative strength indices and market turnover, suggest a potential temporary pullback is possible, with some predicting a further 4.8% climb by June.

site_title: US dollar extends losses vs yen, hits lowest since mid-Sept
summary: The US dollar slid to a four-month low of 110.06 yen, its lowest level since September 15, due to concerns that the dollar's yield advantage will erode as central banks unwind their stimulus. The decline was attributed to simmering fears that the US currency's yield advantage will start to fade as major central banks head toward unwinding their massive stimulus.

site_title: New York man pleads guilty to attempting to join Islamic State
summary: A New York man, Arafat Nagi, 47, has pleaded guilty to trying to join the Islamic State by traveling to Turkey to fight in Syria. Nagi, born to Yemeni parents, was arrested in 2015 and charged with attempting to materially aid the group. He faces a maximum 15-year prison sentence. Prosecutors said Nagi pledged allegiance to the group and was found with military equipment, including body armor and night vision goggles, at his apartment. Nagi's sentencing is scheduled for May 7.

site_title: Malaysian makeover: At 92, Mahathir seeks to be PM again
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 92, is seeking to become the world's oldest prime minister if he wins the upcoming general election. Mahathir is rebranding himself as a "droll but sage father-figure" to appeal to younger voters, after burying the hatchet with his former deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim. Mahathir has promised to seek a royal pardon for Anwar if he wins and steps aside, allowing Anwar to lead the opposition campaign against current Prime Minister Najib Razak. With the election due by August, Mahathir's Twitter following has risen to over 300,000, targeting millennials and young voters.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1% to 3,587.18
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 4.9 points, or 0.1%, to 3,587.18. Despite US stocks closing on record highs, Singapore's market was influenced by local trading activity, with 113.6 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 120 to 54, with Sembcorp Marine and Ley Choon Group Holdings being the top performers.

site_title: Datapulse to pay special 1 cent dividend, book S$44.6m gain from disposal of Tai Seng factory
summary: Datapulse Technology is proposing a special 1 Singapore cent dividend from the disposal of its Tai Seng factory, resulting in a gain of approximately S$44.6 million. The sale of the property is expected to complete on January 31, with net sale proceeds of about S$52.9 million. The company aims to diversify its business through multi-industry investments.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session higher; STI at 3,594.81, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher in the afternoon session, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,594.81, up 0.1% on the day. About 1.10 billion shares changed hands, with Lion Gold rising S$0.001 to S$0.002. Active index stocks included DBS and Keppel Corporation, both trading up 0.61% and 2.3% respectively. Losers outnumbered gainers 203 to 162, with total turnover at S$837 million.

site_title: Chinese gadget-maker Huami's IPO tracks Xiaomi hype
summary: Huami, a Chinese wearable device manufacturer, plans to go public with an initial public offering (IPO) ahead of Xiaomi's highly anticipated listing. Huami's top line increased 37% year-over-year, driven by the higher-priced Mi Band 2, and it swung to a net profit of 95 million yuan. As Xiaomi's largest customer, Huami is heavily reliant on the company, but its growth and increasing revenue suggest it may be able to separate itself from competitors. The IPO could value Huami at over $350 million, potentially outpacing Xiaomi's estimated $100 billion valuation.

images.alt_text: China's answer to Fitbit is tracking another company's big steps. Huami, a maker of wearable devices, just unveiled plans for an initial public offering(IPO) ahead of a more highly anticipated one by Xiaomi.

site_title: 'White oil': Saudi Arabia seeks place on tourism map
summary: Saudi Arabia is set to launch tourist visas, aiming to diversify its economy and reduce dependence on crude oil. The country is promoting its natural wonders, including the Al Wahbah crater, to attract global tourists. Despite conservative rules and an absolute ban on alcohol, tourism officials hope to change perceptions and encourage local and regional visitors first, with plans to relax rules and develop tourist infrastructure. The sector is expected to become a top revenue earner, with the goal of nearly doubling annual tourists to 30 million by 2030.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge up, won weakens
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.17% to 2,540.94, while the won weakened 0.14% to 1,071.7 per dollar. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.04%, and US stocks ended with mild gains. Foreigners bought 48,057 million won worth of shares, and the US dollar rose 0.44% against the won this year. The Kospi is up 2.8% so far this year, with a current price-to-earnings ratio of 12.10 and a dividend yield of 1.28%.

site_title: Sessions questioned in Russia probe as FBI accused of bias
summary: US Attorney General Jeff Sessions was questioned by special counsel Robert Mueller's probe for his ties to Russia, amid allegations of anti-Trump bias in the FBI investigation. The Justice Department lost five months of text messages between investigators Peter Strzok and Lisa Page, fueling accusations of a Watergate-like coverup. Republicans are calling for a second independent investigation into the FBI's 2016 decision not to charge Hillary Clinton, citing the lost text messages and alleged bias.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.70 points to 1,837.34. The market saw 121.24 million lots traded worth RM49.17 million, with 198 gainers and 93 losers. This comes as global markets experienced volatility amid US tariff threats, with US stocks edging down from records and European shares rising on mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Vietnam's biggest bourse shuts stock trading for second day
summary: Vietnam's main stock exchange, the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange, has shut trading for a second day due to a technical issue. The malfunction occurred on Monday and prevented orders from being matched, resulting in a halt to trading. The exchange plans to run tests with securities firms to ensure the trading system's safety and accuracy before resuming trading. The closure affects stocks including Vietnam Dairy Products JSC and VietJet Aviation JSC, with the market averaging $319 million in daily trading over the past month. Trading is expected to resume without a specific timeline.

site_title: Agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland opens food innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) has opened a food innovation centre in Singapore's Biopolis research hub, its first in South-east Asia. The 8,900 sq ft facility will develop novel flavours and speciality ingredients for food and beverage manufacturers in the region. The centre, staffed by food scientists and sales personnel, aims to recruit 50 local employees. Singapore's government supports the centre, citing the city-state's value as a hub for agri-commodity companies to co-innovate with customers. The centre will serve as an extension of ADM's customers' research facilities, facilitating collaboration and innovation.

site_title: Twitter's Dorsey lets Wall Street wunderkind Noto walk away
summary: Twitter's Chief Operating Officer Anthony Noto has left the company to become CEO of online-lending startup Social Finance Inc. Noto's departure, which occurred during a crucial time for Twitter, comes after the company showed stability and growth after years of struggling to expand its audience. Despite the loss, Twitter's leadership believes the company's turnaround efforts will continue, citing improved user engagement and upgrades by analysts. CEO Jack Dorsey expressed his support for Noto, while acknowledging the departure as "bittersweet". The company will assess its business structure and consider filling the COO position or promoting an existing employee.

site_title: SIA to restructure flights connecting Canberra, Wellington
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is restructuring flights connecting Canberra and Wellington, replacing Canberra-Wellington services with Melbourne-Wellington flights and introducing a daily Sydney-Canberra connection. The new Singapore-Melbourne-Wellington service will operate four times a week starting May 3, while the Canberra-Sydney flights will be launched on May 1 with a daily service. The changes aim to better serve Canberra and Wellington, with improved frequency and route options. Regulatory approval is still pending.

site_title: Modi courts investors with plans for US$5 trillion economy
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced plans to reach a US$5 trillion economy by 2025, courting global investors and removing obstacles to foreign direct investment. The country has abolished over 1,400 archaic laws and eased restrictions on foreign investment in various sectors. Modi warned that globalisation is shrinking due to protectionist moves, following US President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs. The Indian government aims to bring down its budget deficit to 3.2% of GDP in the current fiscal year, with growth forecast to expand at the slowest pace since 2014.

images.alt_text: India is working towards a US$5 trillion economy by 2025, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said at the opening session of the World Economic Forum in Davos, as he courted global investors to Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks edged down 0.10% in early trade on Wednesday, following a string of record highs since last week. Investors cashed out profits, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 32,897.21. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.20% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.10%. The decline in Hong Kong stocks came despite a strong performance in Shanghai.

site_title: UK-listed ICG buys PSB Academy from Baring
summary: ICG buys PSB Academy from Baring Private Equity Asia for an undisclosed sum, marking the asset management firm's second education investment. The sale follows the opening of PSB Academy's new S$15 million campus in Marina Square last year. This marks seven years since Baring acquired the institution in 2011. The terms of the sale have not been disclosed, but the acquisition is seen as a strategic move by ICG to expand its presence in the Singapore education sector.

site_title: US Senate confirms Jerome Powell as next Federal Reserve chairman
summary: The US Senate confirmed Jerome Powell as the next Federal Reserve chairman, replacing Janet Yellen. Powell, a former investment banker, was confirmed by a vote of 85-12 and will take over as head of the Federal Reserve when Yellen steps down next month. Analysts say Powell's appointment signals a continuation of slow and deliberate rate increases, while also signaling to markets that Trump favors a more business-friendly approach to regulation. This move marks a significant shift in the Fed's leadership, with Trump being the first president in nearly 40 years to not reappoint the incumbent chair.

site_title: Oil jumps as Brent tops US$70, with inventory data on tap
summary: Oil prices surged over 1% on Tuesday, with Brent crude reaching $70 a barrel for the first time in a week, driven by healthy economic growth prospects and expected production cuts by Opec, Russia, and their allies. US crude futures rose 1.4% to $64.47 a barrel, with some analysts predicting a modest build in US inventories, which could blunt the rally. The International Monetary Fund revised upward its forecast for world economic growth, which could boost demand for petroleum products.

site_title: Gold rises as dollar dips, stocks jump
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,337.36 an ounce as the US dollar fell to a three-year low, making dollar-denominated assets cheaper for holders of other currencies. The US government shutdown had little impact on gold, and markets are anticipating an expected interest rate increase in March, which could weigh on gold. The US economy is expected to grow at its fastest pace in three years, increasing the likelihood of interest rate rises and making gold less attractive.

site_title: As deadline looms, CDL's M&C offer yet to hit conditional acceptance threshold
summary: CDL's takeover offer for Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) has yet to reach the 50% conditional acceptance threshold, three days before the deadline of January 26, 2018. As of Wednesday, the offer has received accepted offers representing 44.2% of shares not already owned or controlled by CDL, valuing M&C at approximately £2.01 billion. The offer price has been raised to 620 pence per share, up from 552.5 pence earlier, and is considered final and non-negotiable.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen firms
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on January 24, 2018, as Japanese exporters were affected by a stronger yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.40% to 24,026.83, while the Topix index declined 0.30% to 1,905.38. This decline followed Wall Street's rally, with stocks opening lower despite the US market's gains.

site_title: Private firm pushes ahead with UK-France power cable despite Brexit
summary: A private investment firm, Aquind, is pushing ahead with plans to build a 1.4 billion euro power cable between the UK and France despite Brexit uncertainties. The 2,000 megawatt project aims to increase competition and improve power security. Aquind is seeking an exemption from EU regulations to use profits to repay investors, as a private operator. The project is on track to complete in 2022, with planning permits and authorizations from both countries being obtained.

site_title: Acromec plans S$3.84m share placement, to pay S$96,000 'introducer fee'
summary: Acromec Limited plans to issue S$3.84 million worth of new shares at S$0.24 apiece, representing 13.05% of its current share capital. The share placement, not underwritten, includes investors linked to Catalist listing and a stake in Thailand's onshore oil concessions. The company will pay S$96,000 in "introducer fee" to TSS Capital for introducing the investors. The issue price is a 3.9% discount to the volume weighted average price trades done on Tuesday.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust prices placement at top end of S$1.48, upsizes to S$100m
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) priced its S$100 million private placement at S$1.48 per unit, the top end of its indicated price range. The placement was over five times subscribed, with strong participation from institutional investors. The funds will be used to partially fund the proposed acquisition of a 50% stake in Farnborough Business Park in London, with the remaining proceeds to pay placement-related expenses. Trading of the new units is expected to commence on February 1.

site_title: Suntec Reit's DPU up 0.31% for Q4
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 0.31% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, reaching 2.604 Singapore cents. However, gross revenue declined 1.8% to S$87.3 million due to lower revenue from Suntec Singapore and office rentals. Net property income also shrank 2.2% to S$59.4 million. The overall occupancy for office and retail portfolios remained high at 99.2% and 98.8%, respectively.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise, financials, energy firms lead; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,058.20, driven by gains in financial and energy firms. This followed a 0.8% increase on Tuesday. The US stock market also advanced, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite reaching fresh records. The rally was fueled by strong results from Netflix.

site_title: Japan's record exports to Asia raise hopes for Q4 growth
summary: Japan's exports rose 9.3% in December, driven by record demand from China and Asia, for the 13th consecutive month. Exports to China reached a record 1.5 trillion yen, while shipments to Asia grew 9.9% to a record 4.1 trillion yen. This boost in exports could contribute to vigorous economic growth in the fourth quarter, fueled by business investment and consumer spending. However, US President Donald Trump's potential intensification of protectionism and trade imbalances remains a concern.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust's Q4 DPU up 0.7%
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 0.7% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.9 Singapore cents, driven by higher occupancy at Bugis Junction and The Atrium@Orchard. The trust's income available for distribution rose 0.8% to S$102.9 million, while gross revenue grew 1.8% to S$172.4 million. Despite a 1.1% decline in full-year gross revenue, CMT's comparable mall basis showed a 0.6% increase in gross revenue and a 1.2% increase in net property income.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, CMT, FCT, M1, Acromec
summary: Suntec Reit reported lower revenue for its fourth quarter, with a 1.8% drop in gross revenue and a 0.31% increase in distribution per unit to 2.604 Singapore cents. CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) saw a 2.6% increase in net property income, while Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 3.8% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit. M1 Limited's net profit dipped 2.5% due to a drop in handset sales. Acromec Limited plans to place S$3.84 million worth of new shares, offering a 3.9% discount to the volume weighted average price.

site_title: Qualcomm set to be fined by EU antitrust regulators: FT
summary: The European Union is set to fine US chipmaker Qualcomm Inc for taking advantage of its dominance by paying Apple Inc exclusively for its chips from 2011 to 2016. The antitrust watchdog claims Qualcomm hurt competition and innovation. This move comes amid a wide-ranging legal battle between Apple and Qualcomm over patent royalty rebates. The European Commission declined to comment, while Qualcomm did not respond to a request for comment.

site_title: S i2i secures additional 12-month extension to exit SGX watch list
summary: IT services firm S i2i has secured a 12-month extension to exit SGX's watch list, with the deadline now set for March 3, 2019. The company, which was placed on the list in 2015 due to consecutive losses and low market capitalization, is committed to fulfilling financial exit criteria. S i2i reported a consolidated pre-tax profit of S$1.64 million for fiscal 2016 and S$1.2 million for the nine-month period ended Sept 30, 2017. The company must record a pre-tax profit and maintain a market capitalization of at least S$40 million to avoid delisting.

site_title: Carbon tax 'works better with industry benchmarks'
summary: Industry players in Singapore urge the government to consider a differentiated approach to the carbon tax, proposing the use of industry benchmarks to set tax rates. Companies that exceed benchmarks would pay less or no tax, while those that fall short would face higher taxes. This approach aims to encourage investment in energy efficiency and achieve the government's goal of a 36% reduction in emissions intensity by 2030. The proposal also seeks to ease the transition for companies and avoid eroding competitiveness.

site_title: Investors in advanced talks to buy Weinstein company
summary: A group of investors, led by former Obama administration official Maria Contreras-Sweet, is in advanced talks to buy The Weinstein Company, on the verge of bankruptcy due to sexual misconduct allegations against co-founder Harvey Weinstein. The investors have submitted a second offer of around $500 million, including a fund to compensate victims, and are expected to close the deal within 7-10 days. The new company will be led by a board of women and will purchase the assets of the old Weinstein Company, beating out other bids including Qatari group beIN and Hollywood studio Lionsgate.

site_title: Manhattan office leasing seen boosted by US economy, tax cuts
summary: The US economy, fueled by President Trump's tax cuts, is expected to boost Manhattan office leasing in the near term. Office-using jobs growth in New York has been robust, with a record 1.66 million people employed last year, contributing to the best year of leasing activity since 2014. The International Monetary Fund has lifted its world economic growth forecast, predicting a 2.7% US economy expansion this year and 2.5% next year. Despite a tight labor market, further jobs growth and strong leasing activity are expected for New York this year.

site_title: UK's globetrotting trade chief defends globalism
summary: UK International Trade Secretary Liam Fox defended globalism and free trade as Britain charts its post-Brexit path, despite economic challenges. Fox stated Britain will continue to push for global free trade, with the country acting as a champion of free trade as it leaves the EU. He aims to press Britain's case in talks with US and other counterparts at the World Economic Forum.

site_title: British pound hits post-Brexit high of US$1.40
summary: The British pound reached a post-Brexit high of US$1.4005 on January 23, 2018, driven by investor optimism about the UK's near-term currency outlook. This marks a 3.5% rally since December, surpassing the euro's 2% gain. Speculators increased their net long sterling positions to the highest level in 2.5 years, citing relatively well-progressed Brexit talks and a stronger-than-expected UK economy.

site_title: Emerging markets see booming bond sales as investors hunt for yields
summary: Emerging markets are experiencing a record-breaking bond sales pace, with issuers raising $64.7 billion in dollar- and euro-denominated bonds this year, up from $50.5 billion last year. Investors are seeking yields ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate increase, driving down yield premiums for emerging issuers. Many issuers have tightened their pricing, with some cutting borrowing costs by significant margins, as investors continue to hunt for yield in riskier assets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally on US shutdown deal, DAX hits record
summary: European stocks surged to new highs on Tuesday, with Germany's DAX reaching a record of 13,596 points, driven by a US government shutdown deal and earnings updates. Retailer Carrefour rose 3.2% after announcing cost-cutting plans, while Logitech jumped 8% on better-than-expected sales. EasyJet also rose 5.1% after reporting strong first-quarter results. Other gainers included Sky, Wizz Air, and Ocado. Analysts see a potential target of 14,000 points on the DAX, but concerns over broadcasting standards and US-EU trade talks remain.

site_title: FCT posts 3.8% growth in Q1 DPU; it's still eyeing acquisitions
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 3.8% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to three Singapore cents for the fiscal first quarter ended Dec 31, 2017. Gross revenue rose 8.7% to S$47.9 million, driven by higher rental revenue and higher occupancy following an asset enhancement initiative. Net property income grew 9.1% to S$34.5 million. FCT continues to eye acquisitions, despite the growth.

site_title: 11 countries, including Singapore, agree to new Trans-Pacific Partnership deal
summary: Eleven countries, including Singapore, have agreed on a revised version of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), dubbed TPP-11. The deal will give Singapore companies access to a market of 500 million people with a combined output of $10 trillion, with tariffs and non-tariff barriers for goods, improved access for service suppliers, and greater facilitation of investments. The treaty will take effect once ratified by at least six countries, with Japan aiming to ratify it by June. The agreement marks a significant victory for trade liberalization.

site_title: M1's Q4 profit down 2.5% amid fall in handset sales
summary: M1's Q4 profit fell 2.5% to S$31 million due to a 2.1% decline in operating revenue. Mobile service revenue rose 4.1%, while fixed-service contributions increased. The company expects increased competition this year due to new mobile providers. M1's full-year net profit dropped 11.5% to S$132.5 million, despite a 1% increase in operating revenue. The company plans to scale up its infocomm technology capabilities and digital services portfolio to capture opportunities from the Internet of Things and Singapore's Smart Nation drive.

site_title: Local fintech DC Frontiers wins at India-Asean Youth Awards
summary: DC Frontiers, a Singapore-based fintech startup, won the Most Innovative Business Idea award at the India-Asean Youth Awards for its Handshakes app. The app uses artificial intelligence to map out relationships and events between companies and people. Founded in 2011, the app currently covers Singapore, Hong Kong, and Malaysia, with plans to include China this year. The award was presented by the Indian government, recognizing the app's innovative approach to helping businesses connect safely.

site_title: Corruption is now fastest-rising type of fraud: report
summary: Corruption and bribery is the fastest-rising type of fraud, affecting 21% of companies, up from 11% in 2015. The Kroll Global Fraud & Risk Report found information theft, loss or attack to be the most prevalent type of fraud, reported by 29% of respondents. Overall, reported fraud has risen to 84% since 2012, with significant losses in the retail, wholesale, and distribution, and construction, engineering, and infrastructure sectors. Experts attribute the increase to companies operating in frontier markets and lack of implementation of anti-fraud policies at the operational level.

site_title: Prudential to sell Vietnam finance unit for US$151m
summary: Prudential plc has agreed to sell its consumer finance business in Vietnam, Prudential Vietnam Finance Co Ltd, to South Korea's Shinhan Financial Group for US$151 million. The sale, which marks the UK's largest insurer's first major asset divestment, comes as Prudential seeks to focus on its core insurance arm in Vietnam. The deal also includes a new long-term bancassurance partnership between Prudential and Shinhan in Vietnam and Indonesia.

site_title: DBS and CDL make the cut to Bloomberg's 2018 Gender-Equality Index
summary: DBS Group Holdings and City Developments Ltd (CDL) have made it to Bloomberg's 2018 Gender-Equality Index, recognizing their efforts to promote gender equality in the workplace and community. The two Singapore-listed companies are among six Asian companies tracked by investors, following Singapore's ranking fifth out of 188 countries for gender equality in a 2016 Human Development Report. DBS has implemented family-friendly policies and a board diversity policy, while CDL has established an internal task force and a formal board diversity policy, with women making up 60% and 70% of their workforces respectively.

site_title: Richemont makes 2.8b euro offer for Yoox Net-a-Porter
summary: Richemont, the conglomerate behind luxury brands like Cartier and IWC, has made a 2.8 billion euro ($4.53 billion) offer to buy Yoox Net-a-Porter, targeting wealthy clients who prefer online luxury shopping.
