As part of the plan, BJEV will be acquired by a publicly traded affiliate of BAIC Group, with investors able to directly bet on the world's largest new-energy vehicle market. The move follows a surge in electric vehicle sales, with BJEV's sales almost doubling to 103,199 last year and its market share increasing to 23%. The listing is part of China's push to lead in automotive technology and curb pollution.

site_title: Tokyo digs out from heavy snow, transport disruptions remain
summary: Tokyo residents continued to dig out from a record 23cm of snow that caused widespread disruptions on Tuesday, January 23. Transport services remained delayed, with 6,000 people stuck at Narita airport overnight due to canceled flights. Over 740 traffic accidents were reported, and 67 people were injured from falls. The Japanese capital rarely sees snow accumulate, with most commuter lines operating normally, but highways remained closed and train services canceled.

site_title: Ninja Van raises additional funds through Series C round
summary: Ninja Van, a logistics firm, has raised additional funds through a Series C fundraising round. The exact amount was not disclosed, but it will be used to further consolidate its presence in six high-growth markets in Southeast Asia. The funds will also be invested in technology and operational capabilities to improve delivery solutions for businesses. Ninja Van has over 1,000 staff and has partnered with bluechip investors such as The Abraaj Group and Monk's Hill Ventures. DPDgroup, a European parcel delivery network, is one of the latest investors in the company.

site_title: Manhattan office leasing seen boosted by US economy, tax cuts
summary: A stronger US economy fueled by President Trump's tax cuts is expected to boost Manhattan office leasing in the near term, according to CBRE. The US economy is forecast to expand by 2.7% this year and 2.5% next year, with the International Monetary Fund citing tax cuts as a key factor. This growth is expected to translate to robust office-using jobs growth in New York, making it a positive indicator for the office market.

site_title: Banks need human upgrade to stay competitive: Oliver Wyman poll
summary: A survey by Oliver Wyman found that the financial services industry needs to upgrade its human capital to stay competitive, as it lags behind global tech firms in meeting customer demand. The industry's growth significantly trailed global tech firms, and its long-standing models have deteriorated. To bridge the gap, financial firms must adopt a new human capital model, led by business-building, entrepreneurial leaders with skills in science, technology, engineering, art, and maths. This will help firms fend off "tech usurpers" and achieve long-term success.

site_title: 'The rich look' lives on in Paris
summary: Paris fashion shows have adopted a "rich look" aesthetic, characterized by refined luxury and understated elegance. Designers such as Haider Ackermann, Berluti, and Hermès showcased sophisticated coats, suits, and accessories that evoke a sense of wealth and sophistication. The trend is a departure from the athleisure wear that has dominated recent seasons, with many designers opting for classic, high-end pieces. The "rich look" is seen as a way for men to communicate their economic status, with prices often reflecting the exclusivity and craftsmanship of the designs.

site_title: MetLife seeking sale of Hong Kong insurance unit: sources
summary: MetLife is seeking to sell its Hong Kong insurance unit, following international rivals Axa and MassMutual in divesting their stakes in the territory. The sale could raise over $600 million, based on an estimated embedded value of $400 million. This move comes as Chinese companies pursue acquisitions of life insurers and wealth managers in Hong Kong to cater to mainland customers. MetLife remains committed to its Asian operations, including those in South Korea and Japan, and has boosted its business from mainland clients, ranking as Hong Kong's 14th largest insurer by total new business.

site_title: Europe: Dealmaking drives stocks as equity melt-up continues
summary: European stocks surged, hitting fresh 10-year highs, as merger activity and dealmaking drove the market. The Euro zone stocks gained 0.3% and the Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3%. Key deals included a reported merger between Orange and Deutsche Telekom, a $11.6 billion takeover of Bioverativ by Sanofi, and Richemont's offer for Yoox Net-a-Porter. Strong banking and oil stocks also contributed to the gains, while retailers like Ocado and Steinhoff benefited from agreements and sales.

site_title: DBS, CDL make it to Bloomberg's Gender-Equality Index
summary: DBS Group Holdings and City Developments Limited (CDL) have been included in Bloomberg's 2018 Gender-Equality Index, recognizing their commitment to gender equality. DBS, a Singapore-listed bank, has 60% women in its workforce and 40% in senior management, while CDL, a real estate firm, has 70% women in its workforce and 40% in department heads. Both companies have established policies to promote diversity and inclusion, and DBS has also supported social enterprises empowering disadvantaged women. The recognition marks a milestone for both companies, highlighting the importance of gender equality in the workplace.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday, STI up 11.44 points to 3,580.87
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.3% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 11.44 points to 3,580.87. About 64 million shares changed hands, with Lion Gold being the most actively traded stock, rising 0.001 to 0.002. US stocks also reached record levels after a deal was struck to end the federal government shutdown, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 65.67 points. Regional markets, including Japan, Australia, and South Korea, also saw gains.

site_title: Optimism booms among Davos CEOs despite geopolitical storm clouds
summary: A survey of nearly 1,300 CEOs by PwC found that 57% expect global growth to improve in 2018, with US CEOs being the most optimistic, citing robust growth, deregulation, and tax cuts under President Trump. However, 40% of CEOs expressed concern about geopolitical uncertainty, cyber threats, and terrorism, while 31% worried about climate change. The survey also showed that CEOs are confident in delivering revenue growth, with 52% in the US expecting revenue growth in 2018.

site_title: Richemont, doubling down on online luxury, makes 2.8b-euro offer for Yoox Net-a-Porter
summary: Richemont, the Swiss luxury conglomerate, is making a 2.8 billion-euro (S$4.53 billion) offer to acquire Yoox Net-a-Porter, a leading online fashion retailer. This move is a significant shift in strategy as Richemont acknowledges that wealthy consumers prefer online shopping due to its convenience and speed. Online sales of personal luxury goods have risen 24% last year, with estimates suggesting they will account for 25% of the market by 2025. The acquisition aims to capitalize on this growth and strengthen Richemont's presence in the digital luxury market.

site_title: Record number of CEOs in PwC survey optimistic about global economy
summary: A record 57% of CEOs worldwide are optimistic about the global economy in the short term, according to a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey of 1,300 CEOs. This represents a significant increase from 29% last year, with the US seeing a doubling of optimism to 59%. CEOs are also confident about their own company's growth prospects, with 42% saying they are "very confident" of their company's growth outlook. However, anxiety about societal and economic threats such as geopolitical uncertainty, cyber threats, and terrorism is also rising, with 40% of CEOs expressing "extreme concern" about these issues.

site_title: Five missing in Oklahoma drilling rig explosion
summary: A drilling rig explosion in eastern Oklahoma on January 23, 2018, injured one worker with burns and left five missing. Emergency responders contained the fire, which burned for hours, and 17 workers escaped the flames. The cause of the explosion is unknown, and officials are relying on private sector experts to determine how to extinguish the fire. The incident occurred on a rig owned by Patterson-UTI, a provider of drilling services to North American oil and gas companies.

site_title: Trump's solar tariffs mark biggest blow to renewables yet
summary: US President Donald Trump approved 30% tariffs on imported solar equipment, the biggest blow to the renewable energy industry yet. The move threatens to increase costs for US solar installers, with estimated rises of 3-10% for residential and commercial projects. Despite this, some industry players, such as First Solar and Tesla, are expected to benefit from the tariffs. The Solar Energy Industries Association warns that the tariffs will delay or kill billions of dollars in solar investments, projecting 23,000 job losses this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as Wall Street rises
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following Wall Street's gains as a deal to end a three-day US government shutdown was reached. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.45% to 23,924.25, while the Topix index gained 0.37% to 1,898.98. This follows Wall Street's record-breaking performance, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: US Senate votes to end government shutdown, bill heads to House
summary: The US Senate passed a temporary spending bill to end a three-day government shutdown, with 81 senators voting in favor and 18 against. The measure, which funds federal operations until February 8, was made possible after Democrats won assurances from Republicans on addressing the deportation of hundreds of thousands of young immigrants. The bill now heads to the House of Representatives for consideration, with Republican leaders indicating it has enough support to pass.

site_title: SGX rejects Foreland's request for extension to submit trading resumption proposal
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Foreland Fabrictech Holdings' request for an extension to submit a proposal to resume trading, citing an inadequate plan to deal with former executive chairman Tsoi Kin Chit and the firm's unit Fulian Knitting Co. Foreland had sought to extend the deadline from December 2017 to December 2018 to complete fundraising and address the issues. The SGX stated that Foreland's decision not to conduct a special audit on Fulian and lack of progress on fundraising efforts led to the rejection.

site_title: Oil ends higher after volatile trade on dollar, Libya output
summary: Oil prices rose after a volatile session, with Brent crude futures settling up 42 cents, or 0.6%, at $69.03 a barrel. The dollar's decline, which had initially weighed on prices, was later offset by a US government shutdown's end. Libya's As-Sarah oil fields resumed production, adding 55,000 barrels per day. Saudi Arabia's comments on oil output cuts also supported the market. Global economic growth drove demand, pushing prices near three-year highs.

site_title: Trump approves steep tariffs on solar panels, washing machines
summary: US President Donald Trump has approved steep tariffs of up to 50% on imports of large residential washing machines and up to 30% on solar panels to protect domestic producers. The move, which was criticized by the solar industry, was determined by an exhaustive review that found US producers were "seriously injured by imports." The tariffs are expected to cost thousands of US jobs and billions in investment, despite not meeting rising demand.

site_title: Man United retain top spot in Deloitte 'Money League'
summary: Manchester United narrowly retained the top spot in Deloitte's "Money League" report, with a revenue of 676 million euros (S$1.09 billion) in 2016/17, edging out Real Madrid by 1.7 million euros. This marks the 10th time United has topped the list, with a record 10 English clubs featured in the top 20. Combined revenue for the top 20 clubs grew six percent to 7.9 billion euros, with broadcast revenue making up 45% of total revenue. United's Europa League victory contributed to their financial performance.

images.alt_text: Manchester United narrowly pipped Real Madrid to remain the top revenue-generating club in the world as Premier League sides underlined their growing financial clout, Deloitte's "Money League" report said Tuesday.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover on broad-based gains; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to 6,037.5, snapping a five-day losing streak, driven by a broad-based rally across sectors after US lawmakers agreed to end a federal government shutdown. Energy stocks gained 1.7% and healthcare stocks rose 0.8% as ResMed Inc reported record quarterly revenue. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2% as telecom stocks and consumer cyclicals declined.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AEM, FCOT, MLT, Lum Chang, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Keppel DC Reit, ST Electronics
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore companies reported updates on Tuesday, including AEM Holdings, which raised its operating profit before tax guidance, and Frasers Commercial Trust, which posted a lower distribution per unit. Mapletree Logistics Trust reported stable performance and new acquisitions, while Lum Chang won a tender for a major construction project. Keppel Infrastructure Trust and Keppel DC Reit also reported unchanged or increased distributions per unit. ST Electronics secured a contract worth US$72 million for a smart sensor network. These updates may affect trading of the companies' shares.

site_title: Global unemployment down but working poverty rampant: UN
summary: The global unemployment rate is expected to decrease to 5.5% in 2018, a marginal improvement from 5.6% in 2017, according to the International Labour Organization. However, the report warns of widespread "decent work deficits" and the persistence of vulnerable employment, where workers lack social and contractual protections. The problem is most acute in the developing world, where 40% of employed people live in extreme poverty, and the wealth gap between the rich and poor continues to widen, with the top 1% controlling 82% of 2017's global wealth.

site_title: Rupert Murdoch says Facebook should pay for 'trusted' news
summary: Media tycoon Rupert Murdoch suggested that Facebook should pay "trusted" news organizations a carriage fee to improve credibility and stem misinformation. Murdoch, who owns News Corp, proposed a model similar to the one used in the cable TV industry, citing the need to boost trust in online news and support journalism. He criticized Facebook's algorithms for promoting unreliable news sources and called for greater transparency from the platform. Murdoch's comments come amid concerns over the spread of false news and the impact of digital ad revenues on traditional news organizations.

site_title: Japan Inc sees strong run of economic growth, but more wary than market estimates: poll
summary: Japan's companies expect the economy to continue expanding, but with a more cautious outlook than market estimates. Nearly three-quarters of firms predict the economy will continue to grow, but roughly half expect it to stop expanding by mid-2019. A planned sales tax hike and labor shortage are cited as impediments to future growth. Most firms believe the recovery is not self-sustaining and will not end deflation soon. In contrast, economists are more upbeat, with 20 of 33 projecting continued expansion until 2020 or beyond.

site_title: Netflix crosses US$100b market cap as subscribers surge
summary: Netflix reported 117.58 million streaming subscribers worldwide, exceeding expectations, and crossed the $100 billion market capitalization mark. The company added 6.36 million international subscribers and 1.98 million US subscribers, driven by new content releases like "Stranger Things" and "The Crown." Despite spending billions on programming, Netflix expects negative cash flow in 2018 due to increased marketing expenses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains after US budget deal
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.66% on Tuesday, reaching new highs, following a rally on Wall Street as the US government reopened after a budget deal was agreed. The Hang Seng Index increased to 32,606.14, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.09%. The move followed a strong performance on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices reached fresh records despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Gold flat after US government shutdown ends
summary: The US government shutdown has ended with the Senate passing a temporary spending plan, leading to a surge in US stocks. Gold prices remained relatively stable, edging up 0.05% to $1,332.13 per ounce, after falling 0.5% the previous week. Platinum and palladium also experienced fluctuations, with platinum reaching a four-month peak and palladium narrowing its price gap to below $100 per ounce. The dollar hovered near three-year lows, and US Treasury yields rose as investors focused on the global economy and inflation pressures.

site_title: Greece gets fresh cash on road to leaving bailout
summary: Eurozone finance ministers approved a 6.7-billion-euro (S$8.2 billion) cash injection for Greece to support its exit from a bailout program later this year. This is Greece's third financial rescue package since 2010, and the current program will run until August. The move aims to help Greece return to market financing and emerge stronger and more resilient. However, protests against reforms imposed by creditors continue, with thousands demonstrating in Athens against measures including a curb on industrial action and foreclosure of properties owned by bankrupted borrowers.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS maintains 'buy' on Keppel DC Reit; OCBC downgrades
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" call on Keppel DC Reit, raising its target price to S$1.60 due to a rebound in operational performance and new acquisitions. In contrast, OCBC Investment Research has downgraded Keppel DC Reit to "hold" citing limited upside potential due to slower occupancy ramp-up, lower finance costs, and a higher effective tax rate. DBS analysts also highlighted competition from larger data centre players as a key risk. Keppel DC Reit's units were trading at S$1.48, up 0.68% as of 10:20am.

site_title: PSB Academy acquired by UK-listed Intermediate Capital Group
summary: PSB Academy, a private education institute, has been acquired by UK-listed Intermediate Capital Group (ICG). Baring Private Equity Asia previously held a shareholding in PSB, but ICG's investment value was undisclosed. ICG plans to leverage PSB as a platform for additional education-related acquisitions, building on the institute's strong track record of business growth. PSB has seen double-digit percentage growth in its student population since 2016 and is set to launch a new STEM-focused campus in Singapore this year.

site_title: Billionaire Gupta sets sights on making electric cars in Australia
summary: Billionaire Sanjeev Gupta plans to bid on industrial assets at General Motors' former Holden site in South Australia, aiming to produce electric vehicles. If successful, it would revive Australia's defunct car manufacturing industry. Gupta's GFG Alliance aims to use technology developed by Gordon Murray Design to build electric cars, utilizing solar energy to power steel-making operations. This move would be part of Gupta's ambitious investments, including plans to use solar energy to power steel production.

site_title: Will populist Trump re-emerge in 2018?
summary: US President Donald Trump's first year in office has been marked by a shift towards pragmatism, contradicting his populist rhetoric. Instead of pursuing protectionist policies, Trump has focused on boosting the economy, cutting taxes, and deregulating industries. Key accomplishments include a historic tax cut, a growing economy, and a low unemployment rate. However, Trump's administration is still exploring trade wars with China and renegotiating trade agreements, including Nafta and the trade deal with South Korea. While there are concerns about Trump's "America First" agenda, experts believe that pragmatism will continue to guide his policies, and major trade wars may be exaggerated.

site_title: Abe avoids timeline for revising pacifist constitution
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has avoided setting a timeline for revising the country's post-war, pacifist constitution, which bans a standing military. Abe aims to build a lasting legacy and wants to add a clause making clear the armed forces are constitutional. The proposed amendment would retain Article 9's first clause renouncing war and add a reference to Japan's military, but opponents argue it would make it easier for Japan's military to take part in overseas conflicts. A public vote on the constitution could end up as a referendum on Abe's leadership.

site_title: Saudi graft settlements may top US$100b
summary: Saudi Arabia's anti-corruption drive, which began in November 2017, is nearing its end with 90 charges dropped against suspects. Authorities expect to recover over $100 billion in settlements from those who reach deals, with a handful of remaining detainees likely to agree. The probe, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, aimed to eradicate corruption and pave the way for the post-oil economy. While the crackdown may reduce foreign investment, it's seen as a step towards a more open and transparent Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Intel halts chip flaw fix due to problem with patches
summary: Intel has halted the deployment of patches for a Meltdown and Spectre vulnerability in its computer chips due to potential "unpredictable" problems in affected devices. The patch, meant to prevent hackers from stealing data, could cause higher-than-expected reboots and system behavior issues. Intel recommends that computer makers and users test early versions of the updated solution, with updated patches expected to be released later this week. The company advised users to be vigilant with security practices until then.

site_title: How a China bank branch foxed regulators and may force a market rethink
summary: China's banking regulator fined Shanghai Pudong Development Bank Co a record 462 million yuan for a "well-organised fraud" involving hiding non-performing assets through shell companies. The branch had reportedly funnelled 77.5 billion yuan of illegal loans, leading to a re-evaluation of China's bad-loan data and a potential market rethink. The fine, one of the steepest penalties in the industry, may lead to further investigations and disclosures, particularly for smaller banks with rapid asset growth.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P, Nasdaq finish at records as government shutdown ends
summary: US stocks reached new all-time highs as the government shutdown ended, with the Dow gaining 0.6%, the S&P 500 jumping 0.8%, and the Nasdaq rising nearly a full percentage point. The shutdown lasted three days, with lawmakers reaching a deal to reopen the government. Investor enthusiasm rose ahead of major corporate earnings reports, with 68% of companies beating Wall Street's estimates. The market showed resilience despite extended circumstances, and major companies such as Procter & Gamble and Ford are set to report earnings this week.

site_title: Bacardi buys Patron, valuing tequila maker at US$5.1b
summary: Bacardi has acquired Patron Spirits International AG in a deal valued at $5.1 billion, combining the two companies' portfolios of premium spirits brands including Grey Goose vodka, Dewar's scotch, and Patron's tequilas. The acquisition will give Bacardi a strong presence in the fast-growing tequila market, with plans to boost sales by targeting overseas consumers. The deal is expected to create a top spirits maker in the US super-premium segment, with Patron's founder John Paul DeJoria set to remain chairman.

site_title: Foreign workforce: take into account economic cycles
summary: Singapore must allow a certain rate of net immigration to augment its shrinking resident population, according to Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore. While the foreign workforce cannot be increased indefinitely, flexibility in allowing fluctuations according to economic cycles is needed. The country's growth demographic constraints, driven by declining fertility and tighter immigration flows, will weigh on the economy if not addressed. Economists suggest balancing choices to address the issue, focusing on specific skills of foreign workers rather than quantity, to maximize job and wage opportunities for Singaporeans.

site_title: Toshiba considering IPO for memory chip unit: FT
summary: Toshiba is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its memory chip business, Toshiba Memory, if a proposed $18 billion sale to a Bain Capital-led consortium fails to gain antitrust approval by March 31. The Japanese conglomerate has sufficient funds to cover its liabilities after raising $7.14 billion through a new share issue. Activist investor Argyle Street Management Ltd has opposed the sale, suggesting an IPO instead. If the deal falls through, Toshiba is free to walk away, and the company's shares have risen 4.7% in morning trade.

site_title: Ex-China central banker joins rating firm for offshore push
summary: Pengyuan Credit Rating, a Hong Kong-based unit of Shenzhen's Pengyuan Credit Rating, has hired 11 people since October to analyze the credit worthiness of companies issuing offshore bonds. The team, led by former People's Bank of China official Liang Zhong, aims to expand the firm's research offerings in the booming Asian dollar bond market. Pengyuan joins other Chinese rating firms in expanding overseas, targeting mainland Chinese companies and seeking to gain investors' confidence. The firm plans to rate yuan-denominated dim sum and Panda bond issuers and may eventually expand globally.

site_title: 2018 should be another good year for US
summary: US President Donald Trump marks one year in office without impeachment, despite controversy. He has passed tax cuts, despite criticism, and the economy remains strong with low inflation. Trump's unorthodox tactics with North Korea have led to talks with South Korea, and Iran remains stable. However, his budgetary plans are uncertain, and his efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act will depend on the midterm elections in November. Despite criticism, Trump may be a successful president, and his presidency is seen as a new chapter in US foreign policy.

site_title: Singapore and France to deepen tie-ups in fintech and smart cities
summary: Singapore and France are deepening their collaboration in fintech and smart cities, with a focus on innovation and economic development. The two countries will launch the France-Singapore Year of Innovation, which aims to promote new technologies, digitalization, and creative solutions. The initiative includes joint research projects, partnerships, and networking events, such as the VivaTechnology festival and the Smart Nation Innovations Week. The collaboration is seen as a key platform for economic growth, with both countries emphasizing the importance of innovation in driving development.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran and France's Minister for Higher Education, Research and Innovation Frederique Vidal reaffirmed their countries' commitment to advance cooperation on innovation at the France-Singapore Year of Innovation 2018.

site_title: Leadership of Singapore mustn't become aged, renewal is key: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the need for leadership renewal in Singapore, stating that a certain vitality and energy are required to lead a country. He acknowledged the importance of continuity and expressed hope that the younger generation of ministers would benefit from having "more senior" members in the Cabinet. Teo's comments come amid a discussion on Singapore's leadership succession, following a recent Facebook post by Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, who urged the fourth-generation team to pick a leader within six to nine months.

site_title: US should raise its tech base in global race for knowledge
summary: The US should strengthen its technology base to counter China's rapid advancements in science and technology. According to the National Science Foundation's "Science & Engineering Indicators" report, China has made significant strides in high-tech production, including supercomputers and smaller jet liners, and is now venturing into demanding areas. China's technological prowess poses a threat to the US, particularly in the military and economic spheres, and could lead to a shift in the strategic balance and economic warfare. To respond, the US should overhaul its immigration system, increase defense spending on new technologies, and increase federal spending on basic research.

site_title: As Facebook changes its feed, advertisers see video ambitions
summary: Facebook is shifting its News Feed focus to "meaningful social interactions" with close friends and family, reducing visibility of publishers' content and prioritizing sponsored posts. Advertisers see this as an opportunity for the company's video ambitions, including Facebook Watch and live videos, to grow. The change aims to encourage users to spend less time passively viewing content and more time engaging with live streams and videos. This shift may also clear the field for Facebook-owned content, which is seen as a potential solution to the company's reputation issues.

site_title: STI shrugs off US worries to end 0.54% up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.54% to close at 3,569.43, shrugging off a looming US government shutdown. Analysts predict minimal impact on the US economy, but warn of potential confidence dampening effects if the shutdown prolongs. Sembcorp Marine surged 4% after speculation on potential privatization or divestment. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) was also upgraded to a buy, with analysts expecting 4-11% earnings growth.

site_title: Domain says CEO resigns just two months after listing
summary: Domain Holdings Australia Ltd CEO Antony Catalano resigned two months after listing, citing the demands of his role and his family as the reason. The move is seen as a surprise and puts pressure on the company as it tries to convince investors it can grow in a cooling residential real estate market. Domain's shares tumbled to a record low following the resignation. This setback comes as Australia's home prices stall after years of double-digit increases.

site_title: US soya cargo to China traded using blockchain
summary: A US soybean cargo to China became the first fully digitalized agricultural trade using blockchain, conducted by Louis Dreyfus Co, Shandong Bohi Industry Co, and banks ING, Societe Generale, and ABN Amro. The transaction reduced document processing time by five-fold and is expected to bring significant cost savings and speed. This marks a potential shift in the agricultural commodity trading market, with experts predicting widespread adoption of blockchain technology in the near future, citing benefits such as reduced margins and increased efficiency.

site_title: Oil spill from sunken Iranian tanker now three times larger
summary: A sunken Iranian tanker, the Sanchi, has caused an oil spill three times larger, with three oil slicks covering 332 square kilometers, compared to 101 square kilometers previously reported. The ship, carrying 136,000 tonnes of crude oil, collided with a Hong Kong-registered freighter in early January. Only three crew members have been found dead, and the spill poses a threat to marine life, including endangered species like the swordtip squid and yellow croaker fish. The area is also a critical habitat for marine mammals like humpback and grey whales.

site_title: It's a battle against ice and time for ships in the northern Great Lakes
summary: The US Coast Guard Cutter Mackinaw, the largest American icebreaker on the Great Lakes, has been working tirelessly to free commercial ships stuck in ice on the northern Great Lakes. Since December, the 57-member crew has freed four to five ships daily, often for hours. The ship's unique bow design allows it to slice through heavy ice, exposing bright blue water beneath. The Soo Locks, which connect Lake Superior to the rest of the Great Lakes, will close for 10 weeks, prompting concerns about the shipping season's impact on steel mills.

site_title: Man gets 4 months' jail for manipulating Wilton Resources share price
summary: A Singapore court sentenced Mok Piak Liang to 4 months' jail for manipulating Wilton Resources Corp's share price in 2014. Mok pleaded guilty to 4 of 13 market misconduct charges, agreeing to have the remaining 9 charges considered for sentencing. He artificially inflated Wilton's share price by 5.9-22.8% through 13 purchases, creating a "false appearance" of the share price. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department jointly investigated the case, taking a serious view on false trading and manipulation.

site_title: US global cooperation may help to improve world affairs
summary: US President Donald Trump is attending the World Economic Forum in Davos, where the theme focuses on creating a shared future in a fractured world. However, Trump's "America First" agenda has undermined international cooperation, particularly in areas such as the Paris climate change treaty and the Iran nuclear deal. Despite this, opportunities for cooperation remain, including on climate change and nuclear security. The forum will discuss how to renew international cooperation and address geostrategic challenges, with a key focus on the US-China relationship and its potential for either growing tension or fruitful partnership.

site_title: Record UK deal hints at strains in Malaysia's property sector
summary: Malaysia's state-owned investment funds, Permodalan Nasional Bhd and the Employees' Provident Fund, are proposing a record £1.6 billion deal to acquire a development at London's Battersea power station. The move has raised questions about the health of Malaysia's property sector, which has been plagued by cost overruns and a sluggish London market. The deal has sparked debate about a potential financial bailout, with concerns that the sector is struggling due to lending limits and an oversupply of units.

site_title: Euro nears recent three-year high on dollar weakness
summary: The euro rose 0.3% to a three-year high of $1.2323 on Monday, driven by dollar weakness and expectations that the European Central Bank will maintain its current monetary policy. UBS Wealth Management upgraded its forecast for the euro to $1.25 over the next three months. Investors are also watching policy decisions in Japan and Europe, with caution advised on betting on a quick withdrawal of ECB policy stimulus. The dollar's index against a basket of currencies dipped to a three-year low of 90.113, while sterling steadied around $1.39.

site_title: Philadelphia Energy Solutions to file for bankruptcy: memo
summary: Philadelphia Energy Solutions, the largest US East Coast oil refining complex, plans to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy due to financial struggles. The company has secured US$260 million in new financing and expects no immediate impact on employees. Philadelphia Energy Solutions' financial troubles stem from the Renewable Fuels Standard, a costly biofuels law, and its lack of access to cheaper crude oil supplies. The bankruptcy filing is a potential flashpoint in the debate over the Renewable Fuels Standard.

site_title: Trump's 'America First' policy may not go down so well at Davos meet
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to attend the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, marking his first sitting US president to do so in nearly two decades. Trump's "America First" policy appears to be at odds with the conference's theme of creating a shared future in a fractured world. Despite criticism from experts, Trump may use the platform to promote his economic growth and tax cut policies, as well as call for fairer and more reciprocal trade. His attendance is seen as a strategic move to showcase US influence and address concerns over US-China relations.

site_title: Data centre acquisitions lift Keppel DC Reit's DPU
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 1.75 Singapore cent increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.75 cents for the three months to Dec 31, 2017, driven by fresh data centre acquisitions. The increase was a result of the acquisitions made in 2017, which lifted the company's distributable income. This marks a positive development for the real estate investment trust (REIT).

site_title: Embrace change - and thrive
summary: Managing change in today's complex world requires embracing it and being open about plans to change. Comfort with change is key, as it allows individuals and organizations to adapt to new needs, technologies, and discoveries. In uncertain times, authentic leadership is crucial for thriving. Companies should also consider removing executive chairmen to promote more effective decision-making. Furthermore, Singapore's affluent individuals require a significant amount of savings to retire comfortably, at $1.39 million.

images.alt_text: Robots of every stripe at a recent China International Robot Show in Shanghai. Bosses who keep their employees' future career paths close to their hearts will win their trust and help them support the decisions that the company makes.

site_title: FCOT Q1 DPU down 4.4% on lower occupancies
summary: FRASERS Commercial Trust (FCOT) posted a Q1 DPU of 2.40 Singapore cents, down 4.4% from the same period last year, due to lower occupancies at several properties. Gross revenue and net property income also fell 11% and 14.9%, respectively. However, FCOT's CEO, Jack Lam, expressed optimism about the attractiveness of China Square Central and rising demand for co-working facilities, citing a commitment from WeWork to lease 28,700 sqft of space.

site_title: NTU, BlueSG launch fast-charging, all-electric shuttle
summary: NTU and BlueSG have launched a fully-electric, 22-seat shuttle that can recharge in 20 seconds. The NTU-Blue Solutions Flash Shuttle will test run between NTU and CleanTech Park in Singapore from the second-half of this year. The shuttle can travel 2km on a single charge and has a lower operating cost compared to traditional tram systems. The partnership is part of a two-year research program to enhance sustainable transportation options in Singapore.

site_title: Japanese retail investors pull out of bear fund as Nikkei hits 26-year peak
summary: Japanese retail investors are pulling out of a popular bear market fund as the Nikkei index reaches 26-year highs, prompting a shift from contrarian strategies. The Nomura ETF's net asset value dropped 24% to 150.1 billion yen, reversing the trend of increased buying in the inverse ETF when the Nikkei rises. This change is attributed to the losses incurred by retail investors in November, leading to caution in taking short positions, with margin selling also decreasing.

site_title: Singapore firms still slow to adopt sustainability practices: survey
summary: A HSBC survey found that Singapore mid-market enterprises (MMEs) lag their global peers in adopting sustainable business practices. 47% of respondents recognize customer demand for environmentally sustainable products, but only 26% consider sustainability a top three long-term objective. Only 26% prioritize investments into becoming more sustainable, compared to 27% globally. Employment diversity is the most popular tactical approach, with 61% planning to set targets and make progress within the next three years.

site_title: OCBC Cycle 2018 to offer 2,000 Mobikes in first-of-its-kind tie-up
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered Mobike for the first time to offer 2,000 bicycles rent-free at this year's OCBC Cycle in Singapore. Participants can redeem a free bicycle ride for use during the event weekend and receive a complimentary 2018 pass for unlimited free Mobike rides till the end of the year. The event also features new categories, including The Corporate Chase, where companies can compete against each other for a cash prize, and The Business Times Cycle Of Hope Corporate Bike Ride for a charitable cause.

images.alt_text: (From left) Managing editor of SPH's EMTM Group Alvin Tay, group CEO of OCBC Samuel Tsien, CEO of Sport Singapore Lim Teck Yin and digital editor of The Business Times Christopher Lim at the launch of OCBC Cycle 2018.

site_title: Krung Thai Bank posts over 30% drop in 2017 profit
summary: Krung Thai Bank, Thailand's fourth-largest lender, reported a 30.5% drop in 2017 profit to 22.45 billion baht due to higher provisions for impairment. The bank missed analyst expectations and attributed the decline to a suppressed private consumption and lower purchasing power from low-income households. Despite this, net interest income dropped only 1.37% and net fee and service income rose 9%. The bank's annual results follow a series of missed earnings reports from other major Thai banks, with Siam Commercial Bank Pcl citing stiff competition and declining fee-based earnings as challenges.

site_title: Singapore think-tank helps Sri Lanka form action plan to clean up lake
summary: A Singapore think-tank, Centre for Liveable Cities, collaborated with Sri Lanka officials to form an action plan to clean up the polluted Beira Lake district in Colombo. The workshops, attended by 200 officials, aimed to eliminate pollution and redevelop surrounding areas. The Sri Lanka government has cleared illegal settlements around the lake, and the action plan is now a priority project. The collaboration has strengthened ties between the two countries and demonstrates the importance of political will in successful urban rejuvenation, similar to Singapore's successful clean-up of the Singapore River.

images.alt_text: One area of strong collaboration between Singapore and Sri Lanka is in the rejuvenation of the Beira Lake district in Colombo.

site_title: Singapore firms bullish after news of Sri Lanka FTA
summary: Singapore businesses are optimistic about the newly signed free trade agreement (FTA) with Sri Lanka, expecting to benefit from reduced tariffs on imported goods. Tariff cuts of up to 60-80% are a key goal, with sectors like IT, real estate, and tourism showing promise. However, domestic groups have expressed concerns and resistance to the deal, citing protectionist reflexes. Despite challenges, Singapore firms see the FTA as an opportunity for growth and investment in Sri Lanka, with some already expanding their operations in the country.

site_title: Lum Chang wins S$136.9m construction contract from PSA
summary: Lum Chang Building Contractors has won a S$136.9 million construction contract from PSA Singapore for a 20-storey office tower and adjacent recreational amenities. The 26-month contract will involve building a new structure and altering the existing terminal building. This contract brings Lum Chang's total outstanding construction value to S$679.5 million.

site_title: SGX gains on hopes of market momentum
summary: SGX shares rose 4.64% to close at S$8.35 on Monday after the bourse operator announced it would allow companies with dual-class share structures to list on the exchange. Analysts expect earnings growth of 4-11% and a target price increase to S$8.90, citing market momentum and new product initiatives. The company reported flat year-on-year net profit and revenue growth of 2.7%.

site_title: Creditors give nod to Nam Cheong's schemes filed in Malaysia
summary: Nam Cheong's two operating companies, Nam Cheong International and Nam Cheong Dockyard, received creditor approval to proceed with debt restructuring plans in Malaysia and Singapore. Creditors representing 80.9% and 95.4% of loan values voted in favor of the plans, which will convert non-sustainable debt into equity and sustainable debt into a seven-year term loan. The restructuring aims to address the company's non-sustainable debt and facilitate the delivery of build-to-stock offshore vessels from Chinese shipyards.

site_title: Noble stock up on news of potential buyer
summary: Noble Group's stock surged 37% to a mid-day high of 28 Singapore cents after a Bloomberg report revealed Chinese conglomerate Cedar Holdings' interest in buying control of the embattled commodities trader as part of a rescue plan. This news may revive Noble's hopes for a sale, despite initial doubts.

site_title: Market concentration helping upend conventional wisdom
summary: The US stock market has become increasingly concentrated, with fewer, larger companies dominating the playing field. Despite this, these giants are competing on price rather than profit, with Amazon and Facebook driving competition and innovation. The number of publicly-traded companies has decreased by half since 1996, and smaller firms are struggling to survive, resulting in less innovation and vitality. Market concentration is also helping to restrain market volatility, with more price-insensitive investors and lower credit spreads. This shift challenges conventional wisdom on the performance of small-cap stocks and value versus growth stocks in a "winner takes all" world.

site_title: Stable portfolio, new buys boost MLT's Q3
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a stable Q3 performance, driven by new acquisitions and existing properties. Distribution per unit increased to 1.907 Singapore cents, and income available for distribution climbed 24.5% to S$58.3 million. Gross revenue grew 2.8% to S$98.2 million, and net property income expanded 3.9% to S$83 million. The trust's portfolio occupancy improved to 96.2%, and average rental increases were seen in Hong Kong and Vietnam.

site_title: 'Billionaire bonanza' driving huge global inequality, says Oxfam
summary: A report by Oxfam found that 82% of wealth generated in 2017 went to the richest 1% of the global population, while the poorest half of humanity saw no increase in their wealth. The charity blames "tax dodging" for global inequality and urges leaders to take action. The report highlights the concentration of wealth among the super-rich, with women workers being worst hit by global inequality. Oxfam calls for a minimum living wage, elimination of the gender pay gap, and tougher rules to crack down on tax avoidance.

site_title: Live it up in Paris for US$1,000 a night at hotels fit for royalty
summary: Two iconic Parisian hotels, the Ritz Paris and Hotel de Crillon, have reopened after major renovations. The Ritz, known for its opulent Marie Antoinette-inspired design, offers a pampering experience with plush beds and antique furnishings. In contrast, Hotel de Crillon has adopted a more contemporary aesthetic with sleek silhouettes and edgy metal accents. Both hotels boast exceptional service, fine dining options, and luxurious amenities, with prices starting at $1,000 per night.

images.alt_text: Owned by Rosewood Hotels & Resorts, Hotel Crillon is the first property that can sweep you to the era of Louis XVI. The underground pool and spa make for spectacular hideaways to get away from it all.

site_title: Singapore competition panel to refine checks on airline alliance pacts
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is refining checks on airline alliance pacts by seeking feedback on a new airline guidance note. The note aims to provide clarity on the notification process, including market definition, product assessment, and potential new entry. The commission aims to streamline the assessment process, adding certainty for airlines planning alliances. Singapore's open-skies policy, based on open competition, has contributed to its growth as a key air hub, but airline alliances may impact competition in affected markets. The consultation closes on February 12.

site_title: Remuneration: Get basics right and avoid pitfalls
summary: A Singapore Exchange (SGX) report identified 13 companies with good remuneration practices, despite only 2.5% of 609 listed companies meeting the criteria. Companies with a strong ethical culture and transparent disclosure of performance measures were highlighted as key factors. However, many companies allow non-executive directors to participate in share options, which can lead to conflicts of interest. The report recommends that remuneration paid to controlling shareholders and their associates should be subject to a binding vote by independent shareholders. Effective "pay for performance" requires a strong ethical culture and transparent disclosure of performance measures.

images.alt_text: Companies should assess whether the performance measures used and the mix of fixed salaries, short-term incentives and long-term incentives are fostering the right behaviour and are consistent with their roles.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to grow its earnings by 4-11% due to improved market sentiment and higher volumes. Analysts are bullish on the Singapore market activity for securities and derivatives, citing new product initiatives and potential structural changes to boost liquidity. ComfortDelGro is recommended to buy with a target price of S$2.40, driven by the inclusion of its taxi drivers in Uber's ride-booking platform. Sembcorp Marine's share price surged 9.4% after a potential privatisation or divestment by Sembcorp Industries was rumored, with a possible 20% premium translating to S$2.76/share.

site_title: KIT's Q4 DPU flat at 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: KEPPEL Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, unchanged from the previous year. Profit attributable to unitholders rose 25.4% to S$9.6 million, driven by higher contributions from City Gas and Basslink. Revenue for the quarter increased by 4% to S$158.1 million. The company's total DPU for FY2017 was 3.72 Singapore cents, with revenue rising 8.8% to S$632.5 million.

site_title: Palladium flows from west to east to meet industry demand
summary: Palladium flows from the UK to Hong Kong, driven by growing demand from the Asian automotive sector. Shipments to Hong Kong rose 10% from 2016 levels, while physically-backed investment funds in London saw large outflows, potentially feeding the metal's users. This tight market is expected to keep record-high prices, with premiums in Hong Kong reaching $12-$15 an ounce. The shortage of palladium is being addressed through hoarding and investment, but further depletion could lead to significant price implications.

site_title: Two more collective sale tenders launched
summary: Two collective sale tenders were launched in Singapore, with Eunos Mansion and ICB Shopping Centre going up for sale at reserve prices of S$218 million and S$60 million, respectively. The tenders reflect continued interest in collective sales, following last year's S$8.73 billion sales of 31 sites. Developers are attracted to the sites' potential for mid-sized condominium projects, with Eunos Mansion offering a 165-unit development possibility. The tenders close on March 7 and February 28, respectively, with owners allowed to enter into private treaty contracts within 10 weeks.

images.alt_text: The 11-storey Eunos Mansion, which was built in the mid-1980s, now houses 107 residential units.

site_title: JEP trade surge raises burning questions
summary: A surge in trading activity in Singapore-based precision engineering firm JEP Holdings raised suspicions of insider trading. Between Jan 9-12, the company's shares rose 17-63% with unusually high trading volumes, but no queries were raised by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) until Jan 15. An exploratory deal between JEP and UMS Holdings was later disclosed, with the deal ultimately being finalized on Jan 16. The incident highlights concerns over the effectiveness of the SGX's system for detecting unusual trading activity and the need for greater transparency and disclosure.

site_title: Hedi Slimane taking over the reins at Céline
summary: Hedi Slimane, 49, has been appointed as the new artistic, creative, and image director of luxury brand Céline, effective immediately. Slimane, who previously worked at Yves Saint Laurent and created Dior Homme, will oversee collections, store design, and advertising campaigns. His return to the LVMH group marks a potential shift in direction for Céline, which has been led by Phoebe Philo since 2011. Slimane's style, known for its sharp tailoring and "cool" aesthetic, may appeal to younger customers, and LVMH is backing his efforts to expand the brand.

images.alt_text: Mr Slimane's return to LVMH is part of an ambitious plan to expand Céline into a Dior-size brand.

site_title: Start-up nation: Macron's France lures US, UK tech
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's optimistic government has attracted US and UK tech firms, with companies like Mark Heath's start-up choosing France over their home countries due to favorable business conditions and reduced uncertainty. Macron's long-term vision and supportive policies are seen as key factors in the country's appeal. This shift is part of a broader trend, with other countries also investing in AI innovation hubs and edtech research, highlighting the growing importance of technology in global business and economic development.

images.alt_text: President Macron with Ms Varza during the inauguration of Station F. Located inside a vast glass and concrete structure, the startup hub is emblematic of Mr Macron's vision for a dynamic new France.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Do taxes really need to go up?
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat is expected to announce tax hikes in the upcoming Budget 2018, amid growing spending needs and an ageing population. Experts suggest alternative options, such as tapping into the country's significant reserves, which are estimated to be over S$1 trillion. Managing costs, including healthcare and subsidies, is also crucial to addressing fiscal sustainability. Economists emphasize the importance of long-term growth to generate higher tax revenue, but acknowledge the challenges posed by demographic shifts.

site_title: SoftBank nears deal to invest in Ping An's health app
summary: SoftBank is nearing a $400 million investment in Ping An's health app, Good Doctor, ahead of its potential initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The investment, potentially made through the Vision Fund, would value the unit at around $1.2 billion. Good Doctor aims to file an IPO application by the end of January, as China's benchmark Hang Seng Index rallies, with first-time share sales in Hong Kong raising $16.5 billion last year.

site_title: Airbus's superjumbo finds new life on Malaysia Airlines pilgrim trips
summary: Malaysia Airlines is launching trial services on its Airbus A380 superjumbo jets to transport Muslim pilgrims to Saudi Arabia for the Umrah and Hajj pilgrimages. The carrier will use two of its six A380s for the year-round trips, with plans to establish the operation as a new division by the end of 2018. The service will initially operate under Malaysian's own licence but may be converted to a standalone charter brand in 2019, with potential for up to 700 seats.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lum Chang Building Contractors won a S$136.9 million tender to build PSA Singapore's corporate headquarters, a 20-story office tower and adjacent recreational block. Meanwhile, Singtel sold its 14.14% stake in CS Loxinfo to Advanced Wireless Network for S$27 million. The sale follows Singtel's other divestments as the company continues to restructure and focus on its core business.

site_title: Son Ye-jin, represented by Spackman talent agency, to star in new K-drama
summary: Son Ye-jin, a top Korean actress, is set to star in the upcoming K-drama "Pretty Sister Who Buys Me Food," her return to television after a five-year hiatus. The 16-episode drama will air on JTBC in March and marks her highest paid role ever in K-drama history. Directed by Ahn Pan-seok, the drama tells a love story between two characters. Son Ye-jin's return to television follows the release of her blockbuster movies "Now I Will Meet You" and "Negotiation" in 2018.

images.alt_text: The 16-episode Pretty Sister Who Buys Me Food marks the return of Son Ye-jin to TV after a five-year hiatus.

site_title: STE unit bags US$72m smart sensor network deal
summary: ST Electronics' unit, Telematics Wireless, has secured a US$72m contract with Israeli manufacturer Arad Technologies to supply smart sensor networks for six years. The deal includes AMR radio transceivers that will monitor utility vital signs and alert providers to faults. The transceivers are designed to operate for up to 10 years on internal batteries and reduce installation costs. The contract contributes to ST Electronics' efforts to drive "worldwide implementation of smart city initiatives" and join the over 15 million wireless sensors installed globally.

site_title: No end to eyesores at Taj Mahal as repair work drags on
summary: The Taj Mahal, a 17th-century Indian mausoleum, continues to face issues with ongoing repair work that has been ongoing for four years, despite criticism that the scaffolding is causing damage to the monument. Pollution and old age are taking a toll on the structure, with experts warning that iron scaffolding may leave irreversible scars on the fine marble. Authorities are exploring alternatives, but a solution remains unclear, with Fodor's Travel advising tourists to avoid the site until at least 2019.

site_title: Growth obsession is fuelling inequality around world: WEF
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has criticized the focus on gross domestic product (GDP) as a measure of national performance, citing its contribution to rising inequality. The WEF developed an alternative metric, the Inclusive Development Index, which ranks 103 countries based on growth, equity, and sustainability. The top 10 countries are mostly European nations, with Australia and Austria in the top 10. The report found that decades of prioritizing GDP have led to high levels of wealth and income inequality, with only 8 countries reducing poverty and income inequality over the past 5 years.

site_title: Saudi graft settlements may top US$100 billion as probe nears end
summary: Saudi authorities are expected to recover over $100 billion in settlement agreements with corruption suspects in a probe that has implicated dozens of princes and billionaires. The probe, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has already dropped charges against about 90 suspects who were released, with around 95 still at the Ritz Carlton in Riyadh reviewing settlement proposals. Only a handful of those still detained are likely to reach an agreement with the authorities, with the majority facing prosecution.

site_title: Tesco UK to cut net 800 jobs in cost-cutting drive
summary: Tesco UK plans to cut 1,700 jobs, a net reduction of 800, in its UK business as part of a cost-cutting drive. The roles of people manager, compliance manager, and customer experience manager will be removed from 226 stores and large fulfillment centers. However, 900 new roles will be created to support the changes. The cuts are part of Tesco's plan to achieve a 3.5-4.0% group operating margin by 2019-20 and simplify operations.

site_title: Inside Amazon's store of the future: No lines, no cashiers
summary: Amazon's store of the future, Amazon Go, has been launched in Seattle. The store allows customers to enter without lines or cashiers, using only the store's smartphone app. The 1,800 square foot mini-market features a variety of food items, including those typically found at convenience stores and Whole Foods. Customers simply grab items and leave, with their purchases automatically charged to their app. The store uses AI-powered technology to track and pay for items, eliminating the need for human intervention. This marks a significant shift in the retail industry, with Amazon leading the way in innovative shopping experiences.

site_title: Singapore businesses must engage with Gen Z consumers
summary: Singapore businesses must adapt to Gen Z consumers, who are digitally savvy and value-driven. With high expectations and short attention spans, Gen Zers spend 6.7 hours daily online, using multiple social media platforms and constantly switching between instant messaging, gaming, and online video. To connect with this group, businesses should focus on creating engaging, interactive experiences and leveraging digital channels to reach them. As Gen Zers grow in spending power, businesses must prioritize their needs and values to stay relevant in the market.

site_title: BP Said to weigh bid for 1.5b euros Italian solar company
summary: BP is considering a bid for Rete Rinnovabile Srl, a 1.5 billion euro Italian solar company, according to people familiar with the matter. Terra Firma Capital Partners will sell the company next month, with interest from Chinese, Abu Dhabi, and European companies. This sale follows BP's $200 million investment in Lightsource Renewable Energy Ltd in January, as oil companies expand into renewables. A spokesman for BP declined to comment on a potential bid, with Terra Firma having grown RTR through seven acquisitions, doubling its power output since 2011.

site_title: US: S&P opens lower as US shutdown extends
summary: The US benchmark S&P 500 index opened lower on Monday, weighed down by losses in major companies such as Boeing, Apple, and General Electric. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.34% to 25,983.46, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.01%. The US government shutdown entered its third day, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Singapore startup 99.co buys Indonesia's property portal
summary: Singapore's 99.co acquires Indonesia's UrbanIndo, a property portal with over 1.2 million listings, to expand its presence in the Southeast Asian market. The acquisition aims to build a "great real estate technology company" in the region over the next 10 years. With the deal, consumers in both Singapore and Indonesia can access 99.co for all property-related transactions, and the company plans to expand into other key regional markets, including Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: "Indonesia is the region's largest market, and naturally the most important over the next 10 to 20 years," says Mr Cheung.

site_title: Nike supplier risks own goal with US$1.4b buyout
summary: Nike supplier Pou Chen offers to buy full control of Pou Sheng for HK$10.9 billion (US$1.4 billion), valuing the Hong Kong-listed retailer at a 32% premium to its last close. The deal is seen as a risky bet due to the growing threat of online shopping, which has led to a string of de-listings of Chinese retailers trading in Hong Kong. Pou Sheng investors are advised to cash in, as the offer price is 29 times its depressed earnings in 2017.

site_title: Uber CEO eyes "responsible growth", seeks fresh start in Germany
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi vows to prioritize "responsible growth" as he seeks to revamp the company's culture and approach after joining in August. The company aims to make a fresh start in Germany, where it previously faced regulatory battles, and is working with regulators to offer licensed rides with taxi drivers. Khosrowshahi seeks to distance himself from past business practices that led to scandals and regulatory issues, and is committed to a "total reset" in the German market.

site_title: Oxley, China developer lead Singapore land bank race - for now
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore-listed developer, has taken the lead in the country's land bank race with its large residential land bank, boasting nearly 4,000 potential housing units. The company's inventory may have a gross development value of S$4 billion. This comes as other developers, such as Frasers, Sekisui, and CSC Land, also vie for prime land sites in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Singapore-Listed developer Oxley Holdings is enjoying a sweet homecoming after a flurry of overseas ventures - it now holds the largest residential land bank in the Republic by the number of dwelling units.

site_title: Nordea imposes Bitcoin ban across all of bank's departments
summary: Nordea Bank AB, the largest Nordic bank, has imposed a ban on trading in Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies across all departments, effective February 28. The decision was made due to the "unregulated nature" of the market, citing risks such as volatility, liquidity, and financial crime. Existing employees with Bitcoin holdings are allowed to keep their assets, while new investments are prohibited. The bank's CEO, Casper von Koskull, has previously expressed skepticism about Bitcoin, calling it an "absurd" construction.

site_title: AEM raises FY2017 profit guidance; expects FY2018 to outperform FY2017
summary: AEM Holdings raised its FY2017 profit guidance, expecting operating profit before tax to reach between S$35 million and S$37 million. The company also expects FY2018 to outperform FY2017, with revenue and operating profit reaching at least S$255 million and S$42 million respectively. This follows the receipt of S$100 million in sales orders for the first half of 2018, driven by demand for its High Density Modular Test handler from key customer Intel.

site_title: Thai Bank posts over 30% drop in 2017 profit on higher provisions
summary: Krung Thai Bank Pcl, Thailand's fourth largest lender, posted a 30.5% drop in 2017 profit to 22.45 billion baht due to higher provisions for impairment. The bank set aside 44.8 billion baht, a 34.1% increase, to prepare for future standards. Net interest income dropped 1.37% and net fee and service income rose 9%. The Thai economy grew on exports and tourism, but private investment remained low, suppressing private consumption. This marks the second consecutive year of missed earnings reports from major Thai banks.

site_title: IMF sees global growth picking up as US tax cuts gain traction
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its global growth forecast to 3.9% for 2018 and 2019, the fastest pace in seven years, driven by US tax cuts that are expected to spur business investment. The US growth forecast is also upgraded to 2.7% for 2018, while the euro zone is expected to grow 2.2% and Japan 1.2%. However, the IMF warns that a financial-market correction and widening US trade deficit could offset the gains, and urges policymakers to boost productivity and resilience to financial shocks.

site_title: BofA sees oil demand peaking by 2030 as electric vehicles boom
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch analysts predict that oil demand will peak by 2030 due to the rise of electric vehicles, which are expected to account for 40% of car sales by 2030. This prediction is consistent with other forecasts, including Royal Dutch Shell Plc's estimate of a peak in the early 2030s. However, some analysts, such as Wood Mackenzie, expect oil demand growth to continue until 2035. The shift towards electric vehicles is seen as a significant threat to oil demand, with major energy companies expected to diversify into natural gas and chemicals.

site_title: More than 10% of US$3.7b raised in ICOs has been stolen: Ernst & Young
summary: Ernst & Young found that over 10% of the $3.7 billion raised in initial coin offerings (ICOs) has been stolen, with $400 million lost or stolen. Phishing was the most common hacking technique, with hackers stealing up to $1.5 million per month. The volume of ICOs has slowed since 2017, with less than 25% reaching their target in November. The study attributed this to lower quality projects and issues with earlier projects.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.32 points to 1,833.15. The trading session saw 4.6 billion shares worth RM2.9 billion, with gainers slightly outnumbering losers 520 to 502.

site_title: Growth obsession is fueling inequality around world, WEF says
summary: The World Economic Forum warns that relying too heavily on GDP growth metrics is fueling global inequality. The forum has introduced the Inclusive Development Index, which rates 103 countries on growth, equity, and sustainability. Smaller European nations dominate the top, with Norway ranking as the most inclusive advanced economy. The report highlights the need for a more balanced approach to measuring national performance, one that prioritizes people's living standards over short-term growth. This shift could lead to more equitable economic policies and a more sustainable future.

site_title: US tax reforms send UBS profits plunging
summary: Swiss banking giant UBS reported a 63% decline in annual profits to 1.16 billion Swiss francs (S$1.59 billion) due to US tax reforms. The bank suffered a net loss of 2.2 billion Swiss francs in the fourth quarter, taking a charge of 2.87 billion Swiss francs due to changes in US tax laws. The decline was attributed to the bank's exposure to US clients affected by the tax reforms.

site_title: Tennis: Dream comes true as Chung dumps Djokovic from Open
summary: South Korean tennis star Chung Hyeon achieved a historic upset, defeating six-time Australian Open champion Novak Djokovic 7-6 (7/4), 7-5, 7-6 (7/3) in a 3hr 21 min match on January 22, 2018. Chung, 21, became the first South Korean man to reach the Australian Open quarter-finals. He will face American Tennys Sandgren in the next round on Wednesday. This victory marked a dream come true for Chung, who had idolized Djokovic.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets diverge at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets diverged at open on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 falling 0.2% to 7,719.15 points and Paris's CAC 40 losing 0.1% to 5,520.21 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.1% to 13,435.14 points due to hopes for a new German government. The divergence was attributed to US government shutdown concerns, with investors anxious about its impact on the global economy.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's DPU up by 33.6% to 1.75 cents for Q4 2017, fuelled by acquisitions
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 33.6% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.75 Singapore cents, driven by acquisitions and a one-off capital distribution. Distributable income rose 37.1% to S$20.25 million, with net property income and gross revenue also increasing. The real estate investment trust's full-year distributable income grew 34.8% to S$82.32 million, with net property income and gross revenue rising 37.6% and 40.3%, respectively.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust Q1 DPU down 4.4% on lower occupancies
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 4.4% decline in first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.40 Singapore cents due to lower occupancies at several properties. Gross revenue fell 11% to S$35.3 million, while net property income decreased 14.9% to S$24.9 million. The company expects to complete its UK acquisition by the end of January and sees rising demand for co-working facilities. FCOT's average occupancy rate was 80.3% as of December 31.

site_title: From hunting to hiking: biggest threats to protected areas identified
summary: A new study identifies hunting wild animals for food and recreational sports as the two biggest threats to the world's protected areas. The study found that hunting poses the biggest threat in developing countries, while recreational activities are most damaging in affluent nations. 61% of protected areas reported hunting of "wild meat," often sold to meet urban demands for food or medicine. The study recommends regulating hunting and promoting sustainable food sources to protect these areas.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to thrive due to its willingness to pay taxes, said Monetary Authority of Singapore chief Ravi Menon. China's Cedar Holdings Group is interested in buying control of commodities trader Noble Group. A prime freehold residential site, Eunos Mansion, is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$218m. Singapore office rents are set to rise twice as fast as Hong Kong, while mid-size firms trail global peers in adopting sustainable practices. The Straits Times Index rose 0.54% on Monday, finishing at 3,569.43.

site_title: China's biggest electric-car maker to list in 28.8b-yuan deal
summary: China's largest electric-car maker, Beijing Electric Vehicle Co (BJEV), is set to list on the stock market after being acquired by BAIC Group's affiliate, Chengdu Qian Feng Electronics Co, in an asset-swap deal valued at 28.8 billion yuan (S$5.94 billion). Qian Feng will acquire BJEV in exchange for selling 761.1 million shares to its shareholders. This deal gives investors a chance to participate in China's largest new-energy vehicle market. The transaction is expected to provide BAIC Group with a larger stake in the electric vehicle industry.

site_title: OCBC Cycle 2018 to offer 2,000 Mobike bicycles in a first-of-its-kind partnership
summary: OCBC has partnered Mobike for the first time to offer over 2,000 bicycles rent-free at this year's OCBC Cycle in Singapore. Participants with a Mobike account can redeem a free bicycle ride for the event weekend, and all participants will receive a complimentary 2018 Mobike pass for unlimited free rides until the end of the year. This marks the first time a bicycle-sharing company is involved in a cycling competition in Singapore.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q4 DPU flat at 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a flat DPU of 0.93 Singapore cents for Q4, unchanged from the year-ago period. Profit attributable to unitholders rose 25.4% to S$9.6 million, driven by higher contributions from City Gas. Revenue increased 4% to S$158.1 million, boosted by City Gas and Basslink revenues. Net asset value fell to 29.9 Singapore cents per unit, primarily due to distributions and derivative financial instrument movements.

site_title: Son Ye-jin, represented by Spackman talent agency, to star in new K-drama
summary: Son Ye-jin, a top Korean actress, will star in the new K-drama "Pretty Sister Who Buys Me Food," marking her return to television after a five-year hiatus. The 16-episode drama, directed by Ahn Pan-seok, follows a love story between a woman and her best friend's younger brother. Son will be one of the highest-paid actresses in K-drama history, and her recent movies "Now I Will Meet You" and "Negotiation" are expected to be released this year, solidifying her status as a leading actress in the industry.

site_title: How a China bank foxed regulators and may force a market rethink
summary: A Chinese bank branch, Shanghai Pudong Development Bank, has been fined 462 million yuan by regulators for hiding non-performing assets through a complex web of fresh lending. The bank's branch in Chengdu was accused of cooking the books, funneling 77.5 billion yuan of illegal loans through shell companies to conceal sour debts. The case may lead to a systemic review of bad loan ratios across China's financial industry, with smaller banks potentially at risk. The fine is one of the stiffest penalties imposed in the industry, highlighting the need for regulators to increase transparency and scrutiny.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on positive ground; STI at 3,554.19
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading on Monday afternoon in positive territory, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.11% to 3,554.19. Gainers outnumbered losers 201 to 161, driven by gains in SGX and Sembcorp Marine. The total value of shares traded was S$715.6 million.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won falter on investor worries after US government shutdown
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.72% to 2,502.11 points, while the won declined 0.39% to 1,070.1 per dollar, amid investor worries following the US government shutdown. The decline in riskier assets led to a decrease in the benchmark index. The US government shutdown has raised concerns about global economic stability, affecting investor sentiment and leading to a decrease in riskier assets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick week off with fresh record
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index reached a new record high on January 22, 2018, rising 0.43% to 32,393.41, despite US government shutdowns. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, with increases of 0.39% and 1.16%, respectively. Investors appeared to brush off concerns over US tariff threats, continuing their rally.

site_title: Singapore e-commerce logistics startup Parcel Perform raises US$1.1 seed funding
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce logistics startup Parcel Perform has raised US$1.1 million in seed funding, led by Wavemaker Partners and 500 Durians. The funding will be used for "worldwide growth" and expanding its product offering. Parcel Perform's self-service software provides merchants with real-time tracking and analytics to improve the after-checkout experience for online shoppers. The startup aims to drive merchants' growth and customer loyalty, broadening its reach and product portfolio.

site_title: ST Electronics unit bags US$72m contract to supply smart sensor network
summary: ST Electronics unit Telematics Wireless has secured a US$72 million contract to supply smart sensor networks to Israeli company Arad Technologies. The six-year deal involves the supply of automatic meter reading radio transceivers for Arad's AMR solutions in various global markets. The transceivers will provide precise monitoring of utility vital signs and alert utility providers to faults such as leakages, with a lifespan of up to 10 years on an internal battery. The deal is expected to join more than 15 million wireless sensors currently installed globally, enhancing city planning and operational efficiencies.

site_title: Leadership of Singapore must not become aged, and renewal is key: DPM Teo Chee Hean
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean emphasized the importance of leadership renewal in Singapore, stating that a nation's vitality and energy are needed to lead effectively. He acknowledged the value of having more senior members in Cabinet, citing the example of former prime ministers who remain as senior ministers and mentors. This arrangement has been beneficial for younger leaders, and Teo hopes it will continue to be a useful aspect of Singapore's political system.

site_title: UK not keeping up with Russia threat, head of army to warn
summary: The UK's military chief, Nick Carter, is set to warn that Britain is not keeping up with Russia's military capabilities, posing a significant threat to the country's national security. Carter will highlight Russia's aggressive and expeditionary forces, as well as its use of superior long-range missiles in Syria. He will urge the government to increase funding to address these threats, stating that the UK's ability to pre-empt or respond to threats will be eroded if it doesn't keep up with its adversaries.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.54% on Monday
