summary: China has drawn up new "special" emission curbs on industries in major northern cities, aiming to maintain environmental compliance beyond a recent anti-smog campaign. The curbs will apply to new industrial projects and existing facilities in sectors like thermal power and cement, with stricter emission limits for pollutants like sulfur dioxide and particulate matter. Failing to comply will result in fines, output restrictions, or shutdowns. This move is part of China's efforts to establish a nationwide, real-time monitoring system to ensure permanent compliance with environmental rules.

images.alt_text: China will impose "special emissions restrictions" on enterprises in major industrial sectors in northern China later this year, as it bids to ensure its war on pollution continues once a tough winter anti-smog campaign ends in March.

site_title: Keppel confirms talks with Borr Drilling for sale of jack-ups
summary: Keppel Corporation confirmed discussions are ongoing for the possible sale of jack-up rigs to Borr Drilling, with no agreement on a sale and leaseback financing arrangement with Grupo R. This comes after a Business Times report. The conglomerate emphasized that no agreement has been reached, and the sale process is still in progress.

site_title: Norwegian Airlines sets record for fastest transatlantic flight
summary: Norwegian Airlines set a record for the fastest transatlantic flight, arriving 53 minutes ahead of schedule with a final flight time of 5 hours and 13 minutes. The flight was aided by better-than-expected weather conditions and a tailwind. This beats the previous record held by British Airways in 2015. The achievement comes as NASA plans to build a supersonic aircraft with a low-level sonic boom, aiming for a sound level of 60-65 decibels.

site_title: Swimming: Phelps opens up about battling anxiety, depression
summary: Michael Phelps, a 23-time Olympic gold medal winner, revealed at a mental health conference in Chicago that he has battled severe anxiety and depression for 17 years. He experienced a major depression episode after the 2012 Olympics, considering suicide and feeling he didn't want to be alive. Phelps encourages others to seek help, stating that mental illness is real and has a stigma that can be eliminated through open discussion.

images.alt_text: Swimming great Michael Phelps revealed that he has battled severe anxiety and depression for much of his life which drove him to consider suicide after his success at the 2012 Olympics.

site_title: Singapore considering regulation of e-waste disposal
summary: Singapore is considering introducing laws to regulate e-waste disposal due to low awareness of recycling methods among residents. The National Environment Agency found that 60% of residents are ignorant or unsure of how to recycle e-waste, with only 6% actually being recycled. The government plans to expand voluntary initiatives into a comprehensive system, with the goal of increasing public awareness and encouraging electronics producers and retailers to take responsibility for e-waste disposal.

site_title: Europe brings on charm and blue skies to lure Chinese tourists
summary: China is expected to increase its tourism in Europe by nearly 70% over the next five years, with 20.8 million Chinese visitors predicted by 2022. Chinese tourists are drawn to Europe's culture, countryside, and blue skies, and are willing to spend more than twice the amount that US tourists do. To attract them, European countries are rolling out the red carpet, offering gestures such as hot water and Chinese language television stations. China is also seeking to simplify visa procedures for European visitors, in exchange for more flexible visa policies for Chinese tourists.

site_title: Taiwan is said to favour Yang Chin-long as central bank chief
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen is reportedly favoring Yang Chin-long as the next central bank chief, succeeding Perng Fai-nan in February. Yang, the current deputy governor, is expected to maintain stability in currency and monetary policies, following Perng's stance. The appointment aligns with economist expectations and is seen as a safe choice to avoid controversies ahead of local elections. Yang's strong knowledge of the economy and experience in currency markets are cited as reasons for the president's choice.

site_title: Tom Petty died of accidental overdose: family
summary: Tom Petty died of an accidental overdose in October 2017 due to a combination of medications, including fentanyl, oxycodone, and temazepam, according to his family and the Los Angeles county medical examiner. Petty, 66, had been touring despite suffering from various ailments, including emphysema and a fractured hip. His family attributed his overuse of medication to the unbearable pain from his hip injury. The cause bears similarities to the 2016 death of pop icon Prince, highlighting the dangers of opioid misuse.

site_title: UOB tests out new branch concept aimed at millennials in Tampines
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is testing a new branch concept in Tampines, Singapore, aimed at millennials. The branch features a QR code wall for digital information, self-service machines, and a collaboration with local café Sugarhaus. The design is part of UOB's "design thinking" approach to create a customized banking experience for young professionals and families. The bank drew on customer insights, showing that millennials prefer digital channels and financial advisory services. The Tampines 1 branch is open seven days a week, excluding public holidays, and aims to meet the growing demand for banking services in the area.

site_title: ST Electronics secures contracts worth S$742m in Q4
summary: ST Electronics secured contracts worth S$742m in Q4 2017, bringing its total new orders for the year to S$2.24 billion. The bulk of the contracts were for advanced electronics and ICT solutions, including a US$72m contract for a smart sensor network system and a comprehensive electronics system for a hospital in Hong Kong. The projects will be completed progressively until 2022 and 2024, respectively, with minimal impact on ST Engineering's financials.

site_title: Google executives pledge to scour more content as elections loom
summary: Google and YouTube executives pledge to more closely scrutinize content for misleading news and inappropriate messages ahead of US midterm elections later this year. Google CEO Sundar Pichai and YouTube chief Susan Wojcicki stated that they feel a "huge sense of responsibility" and are working harder to address the issue. YouTube plans to hire more employees to review videos using artificial-intelligence software, aiming to remove 98% of extreme content. The companies acknowledge the challenges of determining truth and false information, but emphasize the importance of maintaining trust in technology.

site_title: Yorkshine boss removed after independent review of 2017 transactions
summary: Yorkshine Holdings' executive chairman and CEO Chow Kin Wa has been removed following an independent review of the company's 2017 transactions. The review, conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers Consulting, found Chow to be involved in issues related to the trading and distribution of iron ore, coal, and steel products. Chow had also failed to cooperate with the company's requests for access to records. The Yorkshine board removed Chow from his duties after the review was completed, with trading of shares remaining suspended.

site_title: Audemars Piguet embraces second-hand business
summary: Audemars Piguet, a Swiss luxury watchmaker, is launching a second-hand business, becoming the first major brand to enter the market. The company plans to launch the business in several Swiss outlets and, if successful, in the US and Japan. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for pre-owned premium watches, driven by online platforms and changing consumer habits. Experts estimate the second-hand luxury watches market to be around $5 billion annually, with sales of pre-owned watches outperforming new pieces in recent years.

site_title: Conductor acquitted in worst Canadian rail disaster in century
summary: A Canadian court has acquitted Thomas Harding, the train conductor, of criminal negligence in the 2013 Lac-Megantic rail disaster that killed 47 people. Harding and two former colleagues were found not guilty, but still face federal charges and a civil suit. The derailment occurred when an unattended oil train derailed and exploded in a Quebec town, destroying much of downtown. Harding's lawyer said he is "happy to turn the page" after carrying the burden of the tragedy for four years.

site_title: US approves possible sale of F-35 jets to Belgium for US$6.5b
summary: The US State Department has approved a possible $6.53 billion sale of 34 Lockheed Martin F-35 jets to Belgium, with 38 Pratt & Whitney F-135 engines and other equipment. This sale would make Belgium the fourth foreign customer for the F-35, following South Korea in 2014. The announcement clears the potential purchase by the Belgian government, which is currently competing for a new jet fighter. The F-35 is a vital product for Lockheed, accounting for about a quarter of its total revenue.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries, Sembcorp Marine power ahead in Friday's session
summary: Sembcorp Industries (SCI) shares rose 14 cents to close at S$3.39, while Sembcorp Marine jumped 20 cents to S$2.30, amid speculation about a potential spin-off in India and an upgrade to a "buy" rating by Nomura. SCI clarified there are no developments warranting an IPO announcement, while Nomura analysts cited improving gearing, orders, and free cash flow for SembMarine, which they upgraded to a "buy" with a target price of S$2.70.

site_title: TSMC shares hit record high as investors bet on crypto-mining
summary: TSMC shares reached a record high after reporting quarterly results ahead of expectations, driven by strong demand for semiconductors used in cryptocurrency mining. The stock rose 2.8% to NT$255.50, fueled by the boom in bitcoin's value and the company's ability to supply chips for mining. Founder Morris Chang predicted 10-15% revenue growth in 2018, with crypto-mining potentially accounting for up to 10% of TSMC's revenue.

site_title: On new Indian condos, the name is Trump, and the lure is meeting one
summary: A new Trump Towers project in India promises to attract buyers with the chance to meet Donald Trump Jr, with around 100 initial buyers set to fly to the US for an event. The luxury condos, priced from $800,000 to $1.5 million, will feature high-end amenities. Ethics experts have raised concerns about the conflict-of-interest issues, with some labeling the offer as "outrageous" and "inappropriate." The project, a joint venture between Indian developers and the Trump Organization, is the fourth Trump Tower in India and aims to capitalize on the country's growing economy.

site_title: Bitcoin use under scrutiny in Bali amid warnings by central bank over risks
summary: Indonesian authorities are investigating the use of bitcoin in Bali, following a December 7 ban on cryptocurrencies in payment systems by the central bank. An undercover probe found 44 businesses, including cafes and hotels, offering bitcoin payment services, but 42 had stopped. The central bank considers ownership of virtual currencies high risk and prone to speculation. Authorities are enforcing a rule that all transactions in Indonesia must use the local currency, rupiah, and will ban businesses that continue to use bitcoin. The probe started after social media postings about bitcoin transactions in Bali.

images.alt_text: Some locals in Bali said bitcoin was being used mainly by foreigners on the island, which has a large expatriate community.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records despite US shutdown risk
summary: US stocks closed at records on Friday, despite concerns over a potential government shutdown, as investors focused on corporate earnings reports. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes rose 0.4% and 0.6%, respectively, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%. Investors shrugged off worries about a shutdown, citing it as a short-term issue, and instead focused on strong corporate earnings. However, some companies, such as IBM and American Express, reported disappointing earnings.

site_title: Europe: Shares on a high as optimism on earnings, economy, grow
summary: European shares reached a 10-year high, with the Stoxx benchmark index closing up 0.73% at 402.95 points, driven by growing confidence in corporate earnings and the global economy. The rally came despite US government shutdown fears, with the US stock market also reaching fresh records. The euro zone's Stoxx 600 benchmark rose 0.5% to 400.71 points, its highest level in 2.5 years.

site_title: With no deal in sight, US Congress faces looming government shutdown
summary: US Congress faces a midnight deadline to avoid a federal government shutdown, as a meeting between President Donald Trump and Democratic Senate leader Chuck Schumer failed to produce a deal on a stopgap spending bill. The bill, which would fund the government through February 16, is headed to defeat in the Senate, where Democratic votes are needed to pass it. Democrats are demanding protections for hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants, while Republicans have refused. The shutdown would put hundreds of thousands of 'non-essential' federal workers on temporary unpaid leave, with essential employees continuing to work.

images.alt_text: The US Congress raced against the clock to avoid a federal government shutdown before a midnight deadline on Friday after a meeting between President Donald Trump and Democratic Senate leader Chuck Schumer failed to produce a deal.

site_title: Meet your art twin: a 400-year-old with an oily complexion
summary: A 400-year-old painting in a Pasadena, California, museum sparked a man's resemblance to a bearded warrior in armor. Ross Duffin and his wife, Beverly Simmons, were astonished by the similarity. Duffin's wife initially discovered the painting and convinced him to revisit it. The incident highlights the phenomenon of people searching for their "art twin" – a duplicate of themselves in art pieces created centuries ago.

site_title: India mired in over 20 trade arbitration cases
summary: India is struggling to convince foreign governments to accept new trade arbitration terms, amid over 20 ongoing international arbitration cases. The new model agreement aims to reduce exposure to claims by requiring investors to fight cases in Indian courts for at least five years before seeking arbitration. However, some foreign partners, including Australia, Iran, and the European Union, are rejecting the more restrictive approach, citing inadequate protection for investors. This could lead to billions of dollars in damages if India loses the cases, involving companies like Vodafone Group and Cairn Energy.

site_title: Pacific Radiance offers noteholders S$100m debt-to-equity swap
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, is restructuring its debt by offering noteholders a debt-to-equity swap, where S$100 million notes will be converted to equity at a 3:1 ratio. The company aims to issue 300 million new shares worth S$36 million and plans to launch a consent solicitation exercise on Feb 26 to convert notes into shares. Pacific Radiance also seeks to release S$4.3 million from an escrow account, representing two coupon payments, to meet its financial obligations.

site_title: Coke to expand recycling as pressure mounts to cut plastic
summary: Coca-Cola is expanding its recycling efforts, aiming to recycle one bottle or can for every one sold by 2030. The company plans to increase recycled content in its bottles to 50% by 2030 and guide consumers through the recycling process through educational outreach. This move follows similar announcements from McDonald's and the European Union, which are also pledging to reduce plastic waste. The effort is part of a global push to address the issue of plastic waste, with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation predicting that there will be more plastic than fish in the oceans by 2050 if current recycling rates do not improve.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola Co chief executive officer James Quincey is kicking off a recycling spree, part of efforts to burnish the beverage giant's image.

site_title: The exuberant world of Ronaldinho
summary: Ronaldinho, the Brazilian football legend, has officially retired from the sport. A World Cup winner in 2002 and Ballon d'Or winner in 2005, Ronaldinho's career was marked by his signature tricks, skills, and party lifestyle. Despite winning numerous trophies, his career declined in the latter stages, with his brother announcing his retirement after a two-year hiatus. Ronaldinho's impact on the "beautiful game" will be remembered for his flair, control, and acceleration, leaving fans to wonder what might have been if his personal life hadn't distracted him.

site_title: Wanda expected to declare sale of Australian projects: sources
summary: Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate, is expected to announce the sale of two Australian property projects worth A$1 billion (S$1.06 billion) in the coming days, aiming to alleviate financial strains caused by recent acquisitions. The sale follows an agreement to sell interests in a London property development and will help the group meet upcoming debt deadlines. Wanda's cash reserves are expected to reduce debt repayment pressure, with a US$510 million payment due by March. This sale is part of Wanda's efforts to comply with China's regulators' crackdown on irrational spending by domestic conglomerates.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian bullish on S'pore residential, office segments
summary: UOB Kay Hian has expressed bullishness on Singapore's residential and office segments, citing strong sales momentum and pricing in the luxury segment, which began recovering in early 2016. The recovery was driven by "pent-up" demand following the implementation of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio in 2013. The report also noted that a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

site_title: Bill to avert government shutdown passes House
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a stop-gap funding measure to avert a government shutdown, sending it to the Senate where Democrats are expected to block it. The bill, which would fund the government until March 2, passed with a 230-197 vote. The federal government is set to run out of money on Friday, marking the one-year anniversary of Donald Trump's inauguration. The Senate's opposition to the bill raises concerns about a potential government shutdown, which would have significant economic and operational implications.

site_title: Hang on to your older tranche of Singapore Savings Bonds
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) have been re-announced, offering higher interest rates in earlier years but lower interest in later years due to a flattening yield curve. The new February 2018 tranche pays a 1.55% coupon in the first year, the highest since SSBs were introduced in 2015. However, holders of older tranches may consider switching to the new SSB if they have a short one-year investment horizon, as the coupon pickup is only 14 basis points and they will forgo higher coupons in later years.

site_title: CDL sells 18 units of high-end Leonie Hill project on first day of sale
summary: CDL sold 18 units of its high-end New Futura project at an average price of S$3,200 psf on the first day of sale, exceeding market expectations. The majority of units sold were three- and four-bedroom units. This decent showing is attributed to the project's prime location on Leonie Hill Road, despite the limited number of units released for sale.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) has been downgraded to "buy" by DBS Group Research, citing the removal of lease uncertainty and a change in tenant mix at Alexandra Technopark. The acquisition of Farnborough Business Park is seen as a growth catalyst, despite concerns over the company's growth path. ComfortDelGro has a "hold" rating, with a target price of S$2.15, driven by the launch of UBERFLASH and the pending acquisition of Lion City Rentals.

site_title: Niam Chiang Meng to succeed Ernest Wong as Mediacorp chairman
summary: Mediacorp appoints Niam Chiang Meng, 59, as its new chairman, succeeding Ernest Wong, 72, on April 21. The move comes after a leadership change at the Singaporean broadcaster. No further details on the reasons for the change are provided.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific partners Tong Eng group MD to buy Kismis View for S$102.75m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings and Tong Eng Group's MD Teo Tong Lim have acquired a 90,863 sq ft site in Upper Bukit Timah for S$102.75 million. The site, Kismis View, may be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment development of up to five storeys with a total gross floor area of about 139,929 sq ft. The acquisition brings Roxy-Pacific's share of total residential landbank and unsold inventory to around 570 units.

site_title: Purchase a flat in India and get to meet Donald Trump Jr
summary: Prospective buyers of luxury apartments in India's Trump Towers project are being offered a unique sales pitch: a meeting with Donald Trump Jr. in exchange for purchasing a flat. The developers claim $23 million in sales in the first day, with over 20 units sold. The unusual offer raises questions about influence peddling and whether the Trump family is cashing in on the president's name.

site_title: Machines are encroaching on bond markets' last line of resistance
summary: Digital platforms are disrupting the corporate bond market, potentially reducing the influence of traditional syndicate desks. Investors like Najib Nakad are bypassing large investment banks to place orders directly with issuers, citing difficulty in securing allocations. The shift is driven by electronic trading and regulatory pressure, which has led to increased transparency and competition. Digital platforms, such as Ipreo and Neptune Networks, are facilitating direct communication between investors and issuers, threatening the traditional sales model of syndicate bankers. This change could lead to job cuts and reduced revenue for investment banks.

site_title: Hong Kong targets tighter scrutiny of listed firms' auditors
summary: Hong Kong is introducing a new framework to oversee auditors of listed entities, aiming to enhance investor protection and strengthen its status as an international financial centre. The proposed legislation will give the Financial Reporting Council (FRC) independence to investigate and discipline auditors, and empower it to oversee ethics and standards in the industry. This move comes after Hong Kong slipped below Singapore in corporate governance rankings in 2016 and follows a broader shift away from self-regulated bodies. The changes are expected to address concerns about questionable accounting and bring Hong Kong's auditor regulatory regime in line with international standards.

site_title: Ex-banker has Wall Street-sized ambitions as a wine critic
summary: Antonio Galloni, a former banker, aims to lead the wine industry with his online publication Vinous, which has partnered with top critics and acquired Delectable, a crowd-sourced ratings app. Unlike previous influential critics like Robert Parker, Galloni plans to review the same wines alongside top critics, making Vinous a more interactive platform. With a 250,000-strong database of professionally written reviews and a partnership with Whole Foods, Vinous seeks to dominate the industry with its innovative approach and commitment to showcasing diverse wines. Galloni aims to make Vinous the definitive platform for connoisseurs and novices alike.

site_title: Cryptocurrency frenzy points to it being one of history's biggest bubbles
summary: A cryptocurrency frenzy is being described as one of history's biggest bubbles, with investors caught up in speculative mania. The article compares the current bubble to the 2000 global technology bubble, where companies were valued based on their potential for Internet growth rather than sales or profits. The article warns that avoiding the bursting of a bubble is critical to long-term financial well-being, citing losses of up to 100% for investors who failed to sell during the 2000 bubble. The article concludes that while some cryptocurrencies may survive the inevitable bursting, the current frenzy is driven by fear of missing out and the expectation of future price increases.

site_title: As Bitcoin tumbles, new fund offers crypto holders an easy exit
summary: A new investment fund, InvestX Financial, offers a unique approach to exiting the crypto market by investing in traditional assets, specifically private companies about to go public. The fund's CEO, Marcus New, advises investors to diversify and avoid the losses of early dotcom believers. The fund aims to raise US$100 million and targets investors globally. This strategy contrasts with the trend of funds buying and holding cryptocurrencies, which saw a 1,167% return in 2017. InvestX's approach seeks to provide a safer and more stable exit for investors.

images.alt_text: "They need to diversify - take a portion of the profits and do what Mark Cuban did. . . Diversify it - whether you put it in a fund or into real estate or into an ETF. But please, please take some of your profits and put it somewhere else." Marcus New, CEO and chief entrepreneur of InvestX Financial (Canada)

site_title: EOL restructuring terms not sitting well with DBS, UOB
summary: DBS Bank and UOB Bank have expressed dissatisfaction with the restructuring proposals for Emas Offshore Limited (EOL) and its subsidiary, Emas Offshore Pte Ltd. The banks have filed affidavits stating they are not prepared to agree to the terms, despite ongoing talks with EOL and investors. The hearing date for the scheme applications has been set for March 19. EOL is seeking a revised proposal or new terms from investors, with a potential equity injection of US$50 million. The banks' refusal may delay the restructuring process for EOL, which is the OSV arm of Ezra Holdings.

site_title: Retro gadgets get a tech reboot
summary: Retro gadgets are gaining popularity, with companies like Kodak, Polaroid, and BlackBerry reviving classic products. Kodak's Super 8 camera reboot costs $2,500-$3,000 and features a 3.5-inch LCD screen. Polaroid's OneStep 2 is a $99 instant camera, while BlackBerry's KeyOne phone has been re-released with a $550 price tag. Other retro gadgets include the Ultra Game Boy, NES and SNES Classic Editions, Luciano Speaker, and Lofree Four Seasons Retro Mechanical Keyboard. These products are part of a growing trend of consumers embracing nostalgia and seeking unique, analog experiences.

site_title: Trump marking one-year anniversary with gala; tickets priced from US$100,000
summary: US President Donald Trump will mark the first anniversary of his inauguration with a gala at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida on Saturday. Tickets start at $100,000 per pair, with a roundtable event costing $250,000. The event, hosted by Ronna Romney McDaniel and Steve Wynn, will benefit Trump's presidential campaign and the Republican National Committee. The gala comes as the government faces a potential shutdown due to an impasse in the Senate over a short-term funding extension.

site_title: China may call Trump's bluff on trade action
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened "big damages" against China due to intellectual property concerns, prompting a mixed reaction from Chinese officials. Despite the threat, Beijing appears unimpressed, with officials believing Trump is bluffing. However, US insiders warn that the White House is "deadly serious" about taking action, which could lead to a trade war. China is preparing for potential tariffs, but its Ministry of Commerce says it will take all necessary measures to defend itself. The US business community is concerned about the growing gulf in expectations between Washington and Beijing, fueling the risk of a collision course.

site_title: Did you just throw a sheep at me?
summary: Facebook is prioritizing posts that engage interactions among friends over content from businesses, including traditional media companies. The move comes amid criticism that Facebook has not effectively distributed information and has a significant impact on users' mental health. However, critics argue that this change may lead to louder echo chambers and deeper social anxiety, rather than improving human relations. Facebook's decision may also prioritize profit over promoting dialogue across ideological divides, potentially entrenching existing views among like-minded friends.

images.alt_text: Facebook has said it expects users to spend less time on the platform - is it really just distancing itself from its responsibility (which is still fuzzy anyway)?

site_title: Cordlife Group on the hunt for second chief executive in two years
summary: Cordlife Group, a Singapore-based cord-blood banking company, is searching for its second CEO in two years. Dr. Wong Chiang Yin, 49, is stepping down as group CEO on April 4 after 1.5 years, citing a desire to pursue personal interests. The board praised Dr. Wong for his stabilizing influence and safe leadership. Interim CEO Michael Weiss, also 49, will oversee the company until a new CEO is appointed. The company's stock price dropped 0.63% after the announcement.

site_title: Traders cast aside their doubts on blue-chip buzz
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) advanced 29.05 points, or 0.82%, to 3,550.36 on Friday, snapping a two-day losing streak. Key drivers of the index's gain included ComfortDelGro's tie-up with Uber, Sembcorp Industries' plans for an initial public offer in India, and Keppel Corporation's offshore and marine unit's Nomura rating upgrade to "buy". The STI narrowly bested its 10-year high of 3,550.21, which it hit on Tuesday.

site_title: The state of tech in 2018
summary: In 2018, technology advancements will focus on artificial intelligence, autonomous driving, and smart home devices. Driverless cars, voice assistants like Amazon's Alexa and Google Assistant, and augmented reality headsets are expected to take center stage. Major companies like Mercedes, Toyota, and automakers will showcase their self-driving capabilities, while television manufacturers will integrate smart assistants into their products. Wireless charging and audio will also become more widespread, with wireless audio adoption expected to gain traction.

site_title: New investor shakes up Ipco board, but shareholders still fret over direction of firm
summary: Ipco International's executive director Carlson Smith was ousted during an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on January 19, 2018, after a new investor, James Blythman, requisitioned the meeting. Blythman, an Australian with 14.24% stake in Ipco, appointed two new independent directors, replacing two who left last year. A Malaysian shareholder, Tow Kong Liang, accused Smith of resisting the appointment of certain directors and questioned his absence from duties due to passport issues. Ipco's interim CEO Goh Hin Calm now holds sole executive power, but shareholders expressed concerns over the company's future direction.

site_title: Speculation grows that Opec will end cuts early as prices rise
summary: Oil prices near a three-year high, with crude stockpiles falling rapidly, sparking speculation that Opec's production cuts may end early. Analysts predict the deal may be phased out informally or formally unwound by mid-2018, with some expecting a summer agreement to ramp up production. Despite the Opec-led group's commitment to the plan, some members, including Russia and the UAE, have expressed willingness to discuss mechanisms for exiting the cuts. The probability of an early exit is seen as "growing" by some analysts, with prices above $60 a barrel and inventories near the five-year average.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as investors shrug off shutdown fears
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, defying fears of a potential government shutdown, as investors focused on a strong earnings season. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.05%, the S&P 500 gained 0.24%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.32%. This marks the third straight week of gains, with hopes of a positive earnings season overshadowing concerns over a potential shutdown.

site_title: Saudi's refined oil exports offset crude curbs
summary: Saudi Arabia's refined oil exports rose 155,000 barrels per day in October, offsetting a drop in crude oil sales, according to the International Energy Agency. The country exported 6.9 million barrels of crude oil in October, down 760,000 bpd from last year, while refined product exports reached 8.5 million barrels per day. This accounted for 19% of total exports in October, up from 13% last year. Saudi Arabia's refineries have contributed to this growth, meeting domestic demand and selling products overseas.

site_title: SGX introduces dual-class shares and unveils debt issue plans
summary: SGX introduces dual-class shares and unveils debt issue plans, aiming to support the growth of high-tech companies. The exchange will allow companies with dual-class share structures to list first, with the first listing expected soon after June. SGX will also borrow between $1 billion and $2 billion to acquire businesses, complementing its existing $200 million of unrestricted cash. The move follows Singapore's efforts to transition into the 'new economy' and comes after a regional rival, Hong Kong Stock Exchange, proposed similar reforms.

site_title: FLASH: SGX to implement dual class shares with rules out by end-June
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to implement dual class shares by the end of June. This decision aims to promote organic and inorganic growth. The exchange also plans to establish a S$1-2 billion euro medium term note programme to finance its expansion.

site_title: 'Heroes' who expose irregularities in companies and generate massive profits
summary: Fraser Perring, a 44-year-old former social worker, rose to fame as a short seller after publishing a damning report on Steinhoff International Holdings NV, detailing accounting irregularities. His research, conducted by Viceroy Research, led to a 90% plunge in the company's shares. Perring's career as a social worker was marked by controversy, including a report accusing him of forging records. He shifted to equity research and short selling after losing his job and eventually found success, earning millions in his first three months. Perring's work has earned him the title of "hero" among short sellers.

site_title: Keppel Corp confirms talks with Borr Drilling for possible sale of jack-ups
summary: Keppel Corp confirmed talks with Borr Drilling for the possible sale of six jack-up rigs, with discussions ongoing. The conglomerate denied having entered into an agreement with Grupo R for a potential sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Keppel said the sale and leaseback terms have not been finalized, and no definitive agreement has been signed. The company expressed openness to pursuing win-win solutions for customers, but did not disclose the number of rigs being considered for sale.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end record-breaking week on a high
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng Index ended a record-breaking week with further gains, closing at 32,254.89, a 0.41% increase. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.38%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.14%. The Hang Seng Index has now posted a 1.72% gain over the week.

site_title: Philippines halts sending workers to Kuwait over deaths, abuses
summary: The Philippines has suspended sending workers to Kuwait due to alleged abuses and deaths of Filipino domestic helpers. Labour Secretary Silvestre Belo announced the halt pending investigation into the deaths of about six or seven Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs). The move comes after President Rodrigo Duterte complained of abuse and suicides among Filipino workers in Kuwait, with some women reporting sexual abuse and claiming they endured it. The suspension affects over 250,000 Filipinos working in Kuwait, a significant contributor to the country's economy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Food Empire expects to record a loss before tax in its fourth quarter due to exposure to its associated company, Caffe Bene, totaling around US$10 million. However, the group expects to report a full-year profit. Imperium Crown's executive chairman and CEO, WAN Jinn Woei, is resigning to focus on personal endeavors, with Tan Keng Keat taking over as acting CEO. CDW Holding's Chinese subsidiary sold its stake in Tomoike Electronics for 12.754 million yuan, accounting for its assets' net book values.

site_title: Credit Suisse's top China dealmaker said to be leaving bank
summary: Credit Suisse is set to replace top China dealmaker Mervyn Chow, who is leaving after nearly two decades with the firm, according to sources. Chow, who was also CEO for Greater China, will be succeeded by Zeth Hung, head of investment banking and capital markets for Greater China. The move comes as Credit Suisse seeks to strengthen its presence in the Chinese market. Chow's departure and Hung's appointment are seen as part of the bank's efforts to drive business in the region. No immediate comment was available from Credit Suisse.

site_title: China to enshrine Xi's name in state constitution
summary: China's Communist Party proposed enshrining President Xi Jinping's guiding philosophy in the country's constitution, further solidifying his power. The proposed amendment would add "Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era" to the state constitution, following the already enshrined principle in the party constitution. The move must be approved by the National People's Congress, expected to hold its annual plenary session in March. This would cement Xi's status as the most powerful leader in decades, building on his already significant influence following the 19th Party Congress.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.23 points to 1,828.83 on Friday, driven by a 518-446 gain-to-loss ratio. The stock market closed with 3.83 billion shares traded worth RM2.19 billion.

site_title: Cordlife CEO resigns after 11/2 years on the job
summary: Cordlife Group's CEO, Wong Chiang Yin, has resigned after 1.5 years, citing personal interests. He will remain as an honorary adviser until a replacement is found. Interim CEO Michael Weiss, who took over in 2017, will lead the company until then. The board praised Wong's knowledge and stabilizing influence, but Cordlife's stock dipped 0.5% following the announcement. The company recently reported a net profit of S$649,000 for the third quarter of 2017, a turnaround from a loss in the same period last year.

site_title: Wall Street traders brace for meager paychecks as bonus season approaches
summary: Wall Street traders are bracing for possible paychecks of $0 as bonus season approaches due to declining trading revenue. The five largest Wall Street banks reported an average 32% decline in fourth-quarter revenue, and 12% for the full year, largely due to inactive clients and market volatility. As a result, bonuses could be 10-20% lower than the previous year, with some traders potentially receiving nothing. This marks a significant shift from previous years, with traders expecting to take home a percentage of their generated revenue or assets.

images.alt_text: Some traders at the largest Wall Street banks are about to get big, fat zeroes for bonuses while they watch markets thrive.

site_title: ST Electronics clinches S$742m in contracts for Q4 2017; total new orders for 2017 stand at S$2.24b
summary: ST Electronics clinched S$742 million in contracts for Q4 2017, bringing total new orders for the year to S$2.24 billion. The majority of deals, S$498 million, were for advanced electronics and ICT solutions. This marks a significant increase in the company's contract wins for 2017, highlighting its growth in the electronics and technology sector.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets flatten at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained flat at the opening on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index unchanged at 7,704.19 points. In the eurozone, the Paris CAC 40 index remained flat at 5,493.99 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 edged up 0.1% to 13,297.74. The flat opening followed a strong rally in Asia, where stocks extended their gains despite US trade threats.

site_title: UK retail sales slide after Black Friday boost
summary: UK retail sales declined 1.5% in December from November, the largest monthly drop since June 2016, as consumers brought forward Christmas shopping due to Black Friday deals. Sales climbed 1.4% year-over-year. Analysts had forecast a 1.1% drop. The decline is attributed to consumers moving their spending earlier, with higher sales in November and lower spending in December. The UK's annual inflation rate hit 3.0% in December, down from a multi-year high, and the Bank of England raised interest rates in November.

site_title: New award to celebrate corporate social responsibility
summary: A new award, Brands for Good, has been launched in Singapore to celebrate corporate social responsibility initiatives, particularly among small and medium enterprises. The award recognizes companies that champion sustainable and inclusive economic goals, social development, and environmental protection. The awards will be divided into three categories and up to 50 awards will be given, with no monetary incentives attached initially. The initiative aims to encourage businesses to make a positive impact on society, with B Lab co-founder Caroline Seow stating that creating positive impact is good for business.

images.alt_text: Speaking at the launch of Brands for Good yesterday, founder Glenn Lim explained that it recognises companies that have championed sustainable and inclusive economic goals, social development and environmental protection.

site_title: Airbus says supplier bottlenecks easing as deliveries rise
summary: Airbus reports easing supplier bottlenecks, allowing increased production of its newest models. Key supplier Zodiac Aerospace, which delayed A350 deliveries, has improved operational performance. The company addressed quantity and quality issues, resolving a major blockage. A backlog of 30 undelivered A320neo-family jets is expected to be cleared by mid-year. This development enables Airbus to resume production increases for its newest models.

site_title: Bitcoin use under scrutiny in Indonesian island of Bali
summary: Indonesian authorities are investigating the use of bitcoin in Bali, following a ban by the central bank in December 2017. Head of Bank Indonesia's representative office in Bali, Causa Iman Karana, stated that authorities found bitcoin transactions on social media, indicating the island had become a hub for such activities. The probe aims to understand the risks and potential implications of bitcoin use in the region.

site_title: Croupier and guard arrested over HK$48m Macau casino heist
summary: Police in Macau have arrested a croupier and a security guard over a HK$48 million (S$8.1 million) casino heist at the Wynn Macau casino. The heist occurred early Tuesday morning when the croupier, Lee, took out HK$47,895,000 worth of chips from a VIP room. Lee admitted guilt but refused to reveal the chips' whereabouts, while the security guard, Ho, denied committing any crime. The incident has raised concerns over casino security in Macau, a money-laundering hub, with major industry players reviewing their procedures.

site_title: Let's build a bridge to Europe after we Brexit, Boris Johnson suggests
summary: Boris Johnson, Britain's Foreign Secretary, has suggested building a 22-mile bridge across the English Channel to France after Brexit, citing the need for improved infrastructure and connections. The idea, initially discussed in private, was met with approval from French President Emmanuel Macron. Johnson believes the bridge would facilitate increased tourism and trade, and could be privately funded. The proposal has raised questions about its feasibility and potential impact on the UK-France relationship.

site_title: DBS, UOB not agreeable to EOL restructuring terms
summary: DBS Bank and UOB Bank have submitted joint affidavits to Singapore's High Court stating they are not agreeable to the restructuring terms proposed for Emas Offshore Limited (EOL) and its subsidiary. Despite this, EOL is open to continuing discussions on a revised proposal or any other proposal from investors. EOL had filed scheme applications with the court in response to the proposed restructuring.

site_title: Rajiv Shah leaves BNP Paribas for Goldman Sachs
summary: Rajiv Shah, head of debt capital markets for BNP Paribas in the Middle East, Turkey, and Africa, has left the bank to join Goldman Sachs as a senior originator for the Middle East and North Africa financing business. Shah will be based in Dubai and report to Martin Weber, who will assume responsibility for the MENA financing group and relocate to Dubai. This move comes after Weber, who will retain his existing responsibility for sovereigns and supranationals business in Europe, Middle East, and Africa, relocates from London.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.82% on Friday
summary: Singapore shares closed up 0.82% on Friday, snapping a two-day losing streak, with the Straits Times Index rising 29.05 points to 3,550.36. Sembcorp Industries and ComfortDelGro led the gains, driven by speculation over plans for an initial public offer in India. The market saw 1.47 billion shares traded for S$1.4 billion, with 271 gainers outpacing 165 losers.

site_title: SGX sees pick-up in market activity, posts flat Q2 profit
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a flat Q2 profit of S$88.4 million, driven by a 2.7% increase in revenue. The company expects increased market activity and more listings, with a stronger derivatives trading performance. SGX has been considering introducing dual-class shares listings, but has yet to make a decision. Despite this, revenue rose 11.2% to S$205 million, supported by derivatives revenue growth.

site_title: UBS strategy update seen due by investors after four-year hiatus
summary: UBS Group is considering a strategy update after a four-year hiatus, amid shifting economic conditions and growing investor expectations. The bank, led by CEO Sergio Ermotti, has created a stable lender with a focus on wealth management, asset management, and corporate businesses. Investors are calling for a refresh of objectives, particularly on boosting shareholder returns and improving cost-to-income ratios. The update would provide insight into the bank's growth prospects and outlook for various operating units, potentially addressing concerns about structural headwinds in its investment bank.

site_title: Cryan says Deutsche Bank in 'third phase' of turnaround plan
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan announced that the bank has entered its third phase of turnaround plan, with a focus on restoring growth. Cryan defended his strategy, stating that the bank is on the right track despite facing challenges. The lender reported a third consecutive annual loss, and its market share has been stabilizing since mid-last year. Three of the largest shareholders have expressed concerns about Cryan's performance and may withdraw support unless improvements are made by May. Cryan's team aims to regain market share in the current year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:
