Experts warn that default risks could be higher in the next one-to-two years, putting pressure on the government to write off loans before the 2024 elections. This could exacerbate the country's already massive bad loan pile of $207 billion.

site_title: A lifestyle of less, in the Weekend magazine
summary: A growing number of well-off minimalists in Singapore are embracing a lifestyle that values simplicity, meaning, and sustainability over material possessions. They're not just reducing waste and spending less, but also seeking to live more mindfully. This shift is exemplified by individuals who can afford luxury items, yet choose to prioritize experiences and values over material goods. The trend is seen as a departure from the traditional pursuit of wealth and status, and may signal a shift towards a more mindful and environmentally conscious lifestyle in Singapore.

site_title: US: Dow posts first close above 26,000 amid Wall Street records
summary: US stocks closed at record highs, with the Dow reaching 26,115.65, a 1.3% gain. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also closed at all-time highs, with the Dow surpassing the 26,000 mark for the first time. Strong performances from Boeing, IBM, and Intel contributed to the rally, driven by good news including strong company earnings and lower corporate tax rates. The market's confidence was boosted by a Federal Reserve survey showing a moderate pace of national economic growth.

site_title: US exporter Cheniere signs 15-year LNG supply pact with Trafigura
summary: US liquefied natural gas (LNG) exporter Cheniere Energy has signed a 15-year, one million tonne per annum (mtpa) sales deal with Swiss commodity trader Trafigura, marking the sector's middlemen expanding their market share. Deliveries will begin in 2019, with Trafigura handling around 8.5% of global LNG supply. The deal is expected to help Cheniere fund its expansion plans, as the company seeks to grow its presence in Asia and benefit from rising LNG demand.

site_title: Trump takes hard line on immigration, rejects 'horrible' bipartisan plan
summary: President Donald Trump rejected a bipartisan plan to address immigration, calling it "horrible" and "very, very weak" on border security and reforms. The proposal, which included protections for young undocumented immigrants, fell short of what most Republicans believe is needed. Trump criticized the plan, saying it didn't address his concerns about funding for a border wall and didn't curb visas for extended family members. Despite this, Trump remains open to finding a solution for the undocumented immigrants, known as "Dreamers," but has expressed frustration with the proposed deal.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump on Wednesday aligned himself solidly with conservative Republicans on immigration, criticizing a proposed bipartisan deal as"horrible" on US border security and "very, very weak" on reforms for the legal immigration system.

site_title: NTUC Income launches digital portal for Integrated Shield Plans
summary: NTUC Income has launched a digital portal for purchasing, claiming, and managing Integrated Shield Plans in Singapore, believed to be the first such portal in the country. The portal offers heightened accessibility, convenience, and speed, aiming to simplify the process. This move is expected to enhance customer experience and streamline the claims process.

site_title: Apple giving employees US$2,500 bonuses after new tax law
summary: Apple is issuing a US$2,500 bonus to most employees worldwide, following the introduction of the new US tax law. The bonus, in the form of restricted stock units, will be granted to most employees in the coming months. The move, announced by CEO Tim Cook, demonstrates his confidence in Apple's future and is part of a larger plan to bring back US$30 billion in cash from overseas and fund new US projects. This is not the first time a major US company has responded to the new tax law with a one-time bonus for staff, with other companies such as AT&T, Comcast, and Wal-Mart also offering similar incentives.

images.alt_text: Apple told employees on Wednesday that it's issuing a bonus of US$2,500 worth of restricted stock units, following the introduction of the new US tax law, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Trump has 'no idea' if Kazakh money was invested in SoHo hotel
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he has "no idea" whether money from Kazakhstan was invested in the Trump SoHo hotel in Manhattan. The hotel was developed by Bayrock Group, a real estate company founded by Tevfik Arif, a Kazakh of Turkish extraction. Arif allegedly fed millions of dollars from a Kazakh chromium chemicals plant to Bayrock, sparking a civil lawsuit. Trump met with Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev, calling him "highly respected" despite human rights concerns.

site_title: Global sales help VW weather fallout from diesel scandal
summary: Volkswagen AG reported a 4.3% increase in global deliveries to 10.7 million vehicles in 2017, despite a 17 billion euro cash outflow due to the diesel scandal. Strong demand in China and new SUV models helped mitigate the financial impact. The company's sales momentum is expected to continue in 2018 with new models and investments in electric and self-driving technologies. CEO Matthias Mueller expressed gratitude to customers for their trust, stating the company will meet and exceed expectations. This growth is seen as vital to VW's recovery and staying ahead of rival Toyota.

site_title: First Reit Q4 DPU rises 0.9% on hospital acquisitions
summary: Singapore's First Reit reported a 0.9% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.15 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from newly acquired hospital properties. Gross revenue rose 5.8% to S$28.6 million, while net property income grew 4.9% to S$28 million. The Reit's asset size expanded by 6.3% to S$1.35 billion, and its financial position remains strong with a stable gearing ratio.

site_title: Japan's solid machinery orders show firms ready to spend, support BOJ optimism
summary: Japan's machinery orders surged 5.7% in November, the highest level in a decade, indicating businesses may finally be spending to spur economic growth. The development supports the government's efforts to accelerate inflation and comes as the central bank prepares to paint an optimistic picture of the economy. Analysts expect capital spending to remain in a gradual uptrend, driven by strong global demand and record-high corporate profits. The move is seen as a positive sign for Premier Shinzo Abe's economic policies, which have nudged risk-shy firms to boost spending and help stimulate growth.

site_title: India cuts planned extra borrowing to 200b rupees
summary: India has cut its planned extra borrowing for the current fiscal year to 200 billion rupees, down from 500 billion rupees, to alleviate concerns about rising inflation and worsening public finances. The decision was made after a review of revenue receipts and expenditure patterns, with the government planning to sell 200 billion rupees of debt.

site_title: Economists should not make forecasts
summary: Economists should not make precise forecasts due to the limitations of economic models, which rely on assumptions that may not hold true. These models provide a range of possibilities rather than a single number, making it difficult to predict with certainty. The world of economics is inherently messy, with changing policy and economic behaviors. As a result, economic data is often revised, and forecasts can be misleading. Instead of focusing on precise numbers, economists should convey a general sense of the economy's health, highlighting trends and potential risks, such as rising inflation and central bank policy tightening.

site_title: New StanChart unit to invest in fintech and promote innovation
summary: Standard Chartered (StanChart) has established a new unit, SC Ventures, to promote innovation and invest in fintech companies. The unit will oversee new technology ventures, manage minority investments, and work with business units to explore emerging technologies. Alex Manson, former global head of transaction banking, will lead the unit, which will be based in Singapore and report to Michael Gorriz, group chief information officer. The move aims to promote innovation and deliver digital solutions that work for clients and the bank.

site_title: Man U revenue top among European clubs
summary: Manchester United generated the highest revenue among European clubs in 2016, with a 32% increase to 689 million euros, surpassing Real Madrid and Barcelona. The English Premier League had the highest revenues in Europe, averaging 244.4 million euros per club. However, the financial gap between elite clubs and the rest is increasing, with nearly half of the total revenue generated by just 30 clubs. The report also highlighted the high operating profit and net debt of top clubs, with Manchester United holding the highest net debt of 561 million euros.

site_title: YouTube toughens rules regarding which videos get ads
summary: YouTube has tightened its ad rules, requiring channels with at least 1,000 subscribers and 4,000 hours of watch time within the past year to be eligible for ads. The changes aim to ensure ads do not appear with troublesome content, following a year of issues affecting the platform and its advertising partners. Manual reviews of videos will be added to a Google Preferred system to vet content, and advertisers will have simpler controls over ad placement and transparency. The move is part of YouTube's efforts to protect users, advertisers, and creators from bad actors.

site_title: Hollandia in District 10 up for en bloc sale
summary: A freehold development in Holland residential neighbourhood, Hollandia, is up for en bloc sale with an indicative price of S$163.15 million. The site, built in the mid-1980s, has an allowable gross floor area of 10,004.56 square meters and can be developed up to 12 storeys. The sale is seen as an attractive opportunity for mid-sized developers, with Savills Singapore handling the sale. The tender will close on February 28, with the site's prestigious location near Holland Village and MRT station expected to draw interest.

site_title: Update Nafta, don't scrap it: GM chief
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra urged the Trump administration not to scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), citing potential job losses for US carmakers and workers. Barra emphasized the need to modify the agreement rather than scrap it, and expressed alignment with the administration on job preservation. Fiat Chrysler has already announced plans to move production from Mexico to Michigan, while Ford is also investing in electrified vehicles and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: New NY Transit chief rides subway to work on his first day, vows to fix ageing system
summary: New York City's newly appointed subway chief, Andy Byford, has vowed to fix the aging system, which has grown increasingly unreliable due to years of neglect. Byford, a British native who previously led Toronto's transit system, plans to maximize the existing signalling system, overhaul management, and consider aggressive repairs, including shutting down lines for extended periods. He also mentioned congestion pricing as a potential solution to raise funds for transit. Byford's first day was marked by meetings with senior officials, where he emphasized the need for honesty, transparency, and teamwork to turn the system around.

site_title: Flow of unwanted fuel from China set to turn into deluge
summary: China's fuel exports are expected to surge by over four times in 2018, with overseas shipments of diesel rising 47% to 23.8 million tonnes. This could dilute refining margins in Asia, where profits from turning crude into gasoil are near the highest level since 2015. China's net oil-product exports may climb 31% to 46.8 million tonnes, driven by a focus on quality over quantity for economic growth and stricter environmental-protection policies.

site_title: Cyber attacks, war at top of WEF elites' fears
summary: The World Economic Forum's Global Risks Perception Survey found that 90% of 999 surveyed people expect political or trade clashes between major powers to worsen, with 80% predicting an increased chance of war. Cyber attacks have replaced social polarization as the top concern, with the cost of cybercrime expected to reach $8 trillion over the next five years. The survey also highlighted the growing threat of unilateral protectionist policies and nationalism, which clash with the WEF's core philosophy of multilateral cooperation.

site_title: Burberry holiday sales miss estimates as CEO pushes brand's facelift
summary: Burberry's holiday sales fell 2% on a comparable basis, missing estimates of 4% growth, as CEO Marco Gobbetti implements a high-fashion facelift plan. The company's retail revenue rose 2% in the quarter, with US revenue flat. The planned departure of former CEO Christopher Bailey creates uncertainty over the brand's creative direction, with no updates on a new creative director. Despite this, Burberry left its guidance for operating profit unchanged, citing progress towards new CEO goals.

site_title: ANZ drops quarterly earnings update, reignites debate over QR
summary: ANZ Banking Group has announced it will stop reporting quarterly earnings figures, following Westpac Banking Corp's decision in 2012. The move is seen as a response to the changing economic landscape and the increasing debate over the value of quarterly updates. Analysts believe it may prompt other major Australian banks to follow suit, with some citing cost savings and reduced pressure on management as potential benefits. ANZ cited "strong feedback" from the investment community and the updates' decreased usefulness in the settled global economy as reasons for the decision.

site_title: COE premiums for cars, commercial vehicles slide
summary: COE premiums for cars and commercial vehicles in Singapore dropped, with car COEs sliding 10.9% to S$36,890, the lowest in four months. Motorcycle COE premiums, however, increased 3.9% to S$8,001. The decline in car COE premiums is attributed to reduced buying interest despite the Singapore Motorshow and a smaller quota ahead.

site_title: Tips from Obama's photographer
summary: Former White House photographer Pete Souza traveled to all 50 US states and over 60 countries during his eight-year tenure as chief official White House photographer for former President Barack Obama. Souza's new book, "Obama: An Intimate Portrait," features 315 memorable images from his time in office, including shots from the president's travels to Egypt, Prague, Hawaii, and iconic sites like the Great Wall of China and Christ the Redeemer statue. Souza advises travelers to capture images during the early morning or late afternoon for optimal light and to experiment with different settings, including night shots and bad weather.

site_title: Unlocking growth in Asean's digital economy - the time is now
summary: Singapore, as Asean's 2018 chair, aims to boost the region's digital economy by streamlining e-commerce trade rules and facilitating the movement of goods. The goal is to tap into the growing digital market, projected to reach US$200 billion by 2025, with e-commerce expected to reach US$88 billion. To achieve this, businesses and governments must collaborate to develop an integrated digital backbone, foster inclusive growth through partnerships, and prioritize digital security and workforce transformation. By working together, Asean can unlock new business markets and drive inclusive growth.

site_title: Microsoft heads top 100 list of global tech leaders
summary: Microsoft has taken the top spot in Thomson Reuters' debut Top 100 Global Technology Leaders list, followed by Intel and Cisco Systems. The list, which features 100 tech companies, is based on a 28-factor algorithm measuring performance across eight benchmarks. US tech giants such as Apple, Alphabet, and IBM are among the top 10, while companies like Amazon and Facebook are also included. The list highlights the growth of Asian companies, with Japan, Taiwan, and India tied for second place, and North America leading with 47 tech leaders.

site_title: India's Hike unveils cellphones that work without active data
summary: Hike, an Indian WhatsApp rival, has introduced a modified Android version called Total that allows users to access basic services like messaging, payments, and information without an active data connection. The new software will be available on four devices starting in March. This move aims to provide services to people who cannot access the internet.

site_title: A year on, Trump still has time to turn things around
summary: US President Donald Trump's first year in office ends with his presidency still facing significant challenges. Despite a modest bump in approval ratings to 37%, he has largely struggled with controversy and crisis, including a recent "shithole countries" remark. Trump's ability to govern effectively will depend on his ability to exploit two sources of power: the presidential office and leadership reputation among Congress and bureaucrats. To turn his presidency around, he needs to demonstrate a more powerful and appealing governing agenda, reduce polarizing rhetoric, and build coalitions of support.

site_title: US tensions with North Korea and Iran on the wane?
summary: US President Donald Trump has defied expectations by taking steps to ease tensions with North Korea and Iran, contrary to the aggressive rhetoric that dominated his early days in office. Trump allowed communication lines between North and South Korea to open, postponed joint military exercises with South Korea, and waived key sanctions against Iran in exchange for avoiding an immediate crisis. These diplomatic moves indicate a willingness to employ peaceful means to resolve crises, confounding pundits who predicted a more aggressive approach.

site_title: Italy's Ferrero buys Nestle's US candy business
summary: Nestle has agreed to sell its US candy business to Italy's Ferrero for 2.7 billion Swiss francs (S$3.7 billion) in cash. Ferrero, known for brands like Tic Tac, Nutella, and Ferrero Rocher, will acquire Crunch, Butterfinger, and Baby Ruth. This sale marks a significant shift in Nestle's product portfolio, as the company seeks to focus on its core businesses. The deal is expected to be completed in the coming months, with Ferrero expanding its presence in the US candy market.

site_title: CDL will not extend offer for M&C beyond Jan 26; investors must vote by Jan 23
summary: City Developments (CDL) has announced it will not extend its offer to buy Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) beyond January 26 if it doesn't receive enough acceptances to meet the required 50% threshold for the bid to become unconditional. M&C's remaining shareholders must vote by January 23, with CDL owning 65.2% of the company. Investors, including MSD Partners and Aberdeen Standard Life, have expressed concerns over the offer price, which they claim represents a 25% discount to M&C's stated book value.

site_title: BT celebrates Journalist of the Year win
summary: The Business Times (BT) won three awards, including the top prize, at the Singapore Press Holdings' English/Malay/Tamil Media (EMTM) Group Media Awards. Journalist Jamie Lee was named Journalist of the Year for her work on fintech and banking, while BT correspondents Vivien Shiao and Kalpana Rashiwala won Excellence in Journalism awards for their feature and video stories. BT editor Wong Wei Kong praised the winners for their strong instinct for news, sharp minds, and ability to connect. The awards recognize the industry's professionalism and commitment to good journalism.

site_title: South Korea's 'kimchi deficit' hits record high
summary: South Korea's kimchi trade deficit reached a record high in 2017, with imports exceeding exports by 11,500 tonnes and a value of $47.3 million. The majority of kimchi imports came from China, with 99% of the 275,000 tonnes imported, while exports were just 24,000 tonnes. The low price of Chinese kimchi, averaging $0.50 per kg, has led to a surplus, with 89.9% of kimchi purchased by South Korean restaurants coming from China.

site_title: CapitaLand's game plan to achieve 8% ROE
summary: CapitaLand aims to achieve an 8% return on equity (ROE) through asset recycling and expansion. The property group has sold 20 malls in China to China Vanke for S$1.7 billion, with an exit portfolio yield of around 3%. CapitaLand's asset-light expansion through management contracts has also contributed to its earnings. The company has sold most of its residential development projects in Singapore and has not been acquiring land to develop new properties, focusing instead on its core competencies and recycling its portfolio assets.

site_title: China's solar boom lifts clean energy funding to near record
summary: China's solar industry drove a 3% increase in global clean-energy investment to nearly $333.5 billion in 2017, with 40% of that total going to solar projects. This surge came despite US President Donald Trump's efforts to undermine pollution rules and coal curbs. China's investment accounted for half of the total, with solar power projects receiving almost half of the total clean-energy funding. This boost in solar investment was a record close to the $355 billion set in 2015.

site_title: Orange Valley opens sixth home, plans expansion
summary: Orange Valley Nursing Homes, Singapore's largest private nursing home operator, has opened its sixth location in Balestier. The company plans to expand abroad and locally, considering business areas beyond inpatient treatment. Deputy CEO Lyn Edel Yip stated the goal of positioning Orange Valley as an eldercare provider, offering services beyond nursing homes, including medical supplies and outpatient care. The company also aims to provide residential care for psychiatric patients, allowing them to reintegrate into society.

site_title: China luxury sales rebound as millennials snap up handbags, shoes
summary: China's luxury goods market experienced a significant rebound in 2017, with sales reaching 142 billion yuan (S$29.15 billion), a 20% increase from the previous year. The growth is attributed to China's tech-savvy millennial generation, who prefer ready-to-wear and fast fashion, driving demand for luxury casual wear and sports wear. This shift poses a challenge for traditional brands, with winners emerging depending on their ability to adapt to China's youth-driven market. The market is expected to continue growing, with Bain predicting low-mid teen growth rates this year.

images.alt_text: China's shoppers are the biggest spenders worldwide on luxury products, making up 32% of the 262b euro global market last year and propelling France's LVMH and Gucci owner Kering.

site_title: Juncker welcomes Britain to rejoin EU after Brexit
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker expressed openness to Britain rejoining the EU after Brexit, saying "our hands remain outstretched" if the UK changes its mind. This comes after European Council president Donald Tusk stated the EU's "hearts are still open" to Britain reversing its decision. Juncker described Brexit as a "catastrophe" and a "lose-lose situation" for both Britain and the EU, but emphasized the EU's willingness to talk about re-accession via Article 49. British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman ruled out a second vote, but Juncker's comments sparked debate among EU officials and eurosceptic leaders.

site_title: Rent declines hit ESR Reit's Q4, full-year DPU
summary: ESR Reit reported a 6.7% decline in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.929 Singapore cents due to renewed leases at lower rates. Gross revenue fell 2.2% to S$27.2 million, while net property income rose 1.2% to S$19.9 million. The decline was attributed to the lower lease rates.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Broker CIMB expects StarHub's earnings to decline 11.6% and 35.6% from 2016 to 2020 due to declining revenues in mobile, pay-TV, and broadband businesses. Fixed network services revenue is expected to grow to a quarter of total service revenue by 2020, but this growth will not offset declining revenues. CIMB also forecasts little room for dividend per share growth beyond S$0.16 from 2018 to 2020.

site_title: Euro drops after hitting a 3-year high on ECB talk
summary: The euro fell nearly half a percent after reaching a 3-year high above $1.23 due to concerns voiced by European Central Bank policymakers. Remarks by ECB policymakers, including Ewald Nowotny and Vitor Constancio, highlighted growing concerns about the euro's strength and its potential impact on monetary policy. Despite this, dollar weakness and optimism about the European economy in 2018 continue to support the euro's rally.

site_title: ITMs not static but adaptable: Iswaran
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran stated that Singapore's industry transformation maps (ITMs) are not static plans but need to adjust to changing conditions. The government has launched over 15 ITMs, with 23 expected by March, aiming to cover 80% of the economy. Iswaran emphasized the importance of trade associations, industry associations, and chambers of commerce in raising awareness of the ITMs, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). He noted that the initiatives should be owned by all parties, including the private sector, to ensure their effectiveness.

site_title: Apple needs to admit it still has a labour problem
summary: Apple's efforts to improve its supply chain and address labor issues are being called into question after a series of incidents uncovered poor working conditions and excessive overtime. Despite Apple's claims of doing more than other companies in the industry, unscrupulous suppliers are finding ways to game the auditing process, leading to worker safety issues and breaches of labor laws. Apple needs to adopt a new approach that holds suppliers personally and financially responsible for meeting its standards, and consider using financial incentives to enforce compliance.

images.alt_text: Every year at around this time, Apple makes a song and dance about how much it cares for workers and the environment.

site_title: UMS raises stake in JEP to 29.5%
summary: UMS Holdings has increased its stake in JEP Holdings to 29.5% through a cash acquisition of S$28.2 million. The investment is part of UMS's plan to diversify its revenue and income base into high-growth sectors, particularly the aerospace industry. JEP, a precision machining firm, generates 80% of its business from the aerospace industry. UMS aims to capitalize on the aerospace industry's growth opportunities and expand its customer base beyond the semiconductor industry.

site_title: ST Aerospace bags S$510m worth of contracts in Q4
summary: ST Aerospace secured S$510 million worth of contracts in Q4 2017, bringing the total for 2017 to S$2.8 billion. Contracts included airframe maintenance, landing gear repair, and pilot training for Boeing aircraft, as well as 15-year Boeing 787 component support for Gulf Air. The deals are not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore needs to remain competitive
summary: Singapore must remain competitive to attract foreign direct investments from multinational corporations. The city-state's tax competitiveness is its trump card, but other countries are reducing their corporate income tax rates. Singapore's CIT rate of 17% is lower than its Asia-Pacific neighbors, except Hong Kong, which recently introduced a two-tier tax rate. To maintain competitiveness, Singapore should monitor global trends, enhance its intellectual property regimes, and tailor incentives for Asian multinational corporations. The government should also consider introducing enhanced writing-down allowances for IP acquisition costs and revising the Productivity and Innovation Credit scheme.

site_title: Further upside for developers that can turn hope to reality
summary: Singapore's property developers are expected to continue their strong performance in 2018, with analysts predicting a 10-15% rise in share prices. Those with robust landbanks and new launches are seen as the best proxies to ride the market recovery. CDL and UOL Group are favored large-cap stocks, while mid-cap developers like APAC Realty and GuocoLand are also expected to benefit. However, the market may face uncertainties in the second half of the year, and some analysts expect a 3-7% rise in property prices, lower than initial estimates.

site_title: Bank of Canada: trade uncertainty, US tax changes to weigh on business investment
summary: The Bank of Canada projects a 2.5% reduction in business investment in Canada over the next two years due to trade uncertainty and US tax reforms. The uncertainty surrounding the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and US President Donald Trump's repeated threats to pull out of the pact are expected to impact investment growth. The bank also notes that recent US tax reforms will take another 0.5% off Canadian investment by the end of next year, with exports expected to be impacted by both factors.

site_title: KOP subsidiaries receive notice from Batam court
summary: KOP subsidiaries in Indonesia have received a notice from the Batam court regarding a statement of claim filed by Dominic Andrla to cancel a lease and unit management agreement for two properties. A court hearing is scheduled for March 13. KOP believes the claims have no merits and is seeking legal advice to defend the claims.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's Q4 DPU down 11.9%
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported an 11.9% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 2017 to 1.383 Singapore cents, due to lower gross revenue and net property income. The Reit's full-year DPU slipped 6.2% to 5.712 Singapore cents. Occupancy rate remained at 92.7% and the Reit manager secured 90,000 sq ft of new leases despite a soft leasing environment. A proposed divestment of S$55 million will free up capital for future growth drivers.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.60 points to 1,828.63 on Wednesday, with 4.97 billion shares traded for RM2.97 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 678-321. The move followed a day of global stock market stability despite US tariff threats.

site_title: Utilities, mining give industrial production a boost
summary: US industrial production surged 0.9% in December, driven by unseasonably cold weather boosting demand for heating, and robust gains in mining production. This marked the largest gain since the second quarter of 2010 and the first annual increase since 2014. The strengthening global economy and weakening dollar also contributed to the growth, making US exports more competitive. However, manufacturing output slowed, rising only 0.1% in December after a 0.3% increase in the prior month, and mining production jumped 1.6% amid a rebound in oil and gas well drilling.

site_title: How Britain could change its mind about Brexit
summary: A reversal of Britain's decision to leave the European Union is possible, despite conventional wisdom suggesting it's impossible. To change public opinion, politicians must speak out against Brexit, and the sense of inevitability must be dispelled. Recent shifts in the internal politics of both the Conservative and Labour parties could contribute to this shift, with Labour's opposition to Brexit potentially swaying public opinion. A cross-party campaign to stop Brexit is underway, and European leaders must state that Britain is legally entitled to change its mind. Ultimately, a modest shift in behavior, such as a slight shift in public opinion or credible political leadership, could be enough to change Britain's mind about Brexit.

site_title: Aerospace industry transformation map could create 1,000 new jobs by 2020
summary: A new aerospace industry transformation map (ITM) has been launched in Singapore, aiming to create 1,000 new jobs by 2020 and add S$4 billion to manufacturing in the sector. Developed by a multi-agency team and industry partners, the ITM outlines strategies to build a future-ready aerospace industry.

images.alt_text: A new aerospace industry transformation map (ITM) that could create 1,000 new jobs by 2020 and value-add S$4 billion to manufacturing in the sector has been launched.

site_title: Soo Kee Group terminates JV with Global Crown; will venture into China alone
summary: Soo Kee Group has terminated a joint venture with Global Crown Group to sell bridal jewelry in China. Instead, Soo Kee will acquire the 100% stake in Diamond Avenue Investments for HK$104,858. The acquisition will allow Soo Kee to capitalize on China's growing bridal jewelry market, one of the world's largest consumer markets.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment seeks dual listing on HK GEM board
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment, a CATALIST-listed company, is seeking a dual primary listing of its shares on the Growth Enterprise Market (GEM) board of the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (SEHK). The company aims to increase visibility, attract investors, and expand into new markets. Proceeds from the listing will be used to improve factory capabilities, enter the hospitality sector, and strengthen its presence in Hong Kong and China. The company has appointed KGI Capital Asia Limited as its sponsor and has not yet submitted an application to SEHK.

site_title: Infinio Group proposes share placement to raise S$2.24m
summary: Infinio Group proposes a share placement to raise S$2.24 million by issuing 1.26 billion shares at 0.18 Singapore cent apiece, a 10% discount to the volume weighted average price. This represents about 50% of existing shares and 33.3% of the enlarged share capital.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as tech stocks gain
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Wednesday, led by gains in technology stocks including Microsoft and IBM. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 156.43 points, the S&P 500 gained 9.75 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 33.63 points, driven by tech sector gains.

site_title: Google pitches AI image-detection tool to lure Cloud customers
summary: Google introduces Cloud AutoML, an AI image-detection tool for data-center customers, aiming to help companies with limited AI expertise. The product uses machine learning to automatically generate models for image classification, text, speech, and video analysis. Companies such as Urban Outfitters and Walt Disney are already using it to spot trends and structure e-commerce sites. This move is part of Google's effort to stand out in the competitive cloud-computing market, with estimated annual sales of $3.9 billion for the division.

site_title: Utilities, mining boost US industrial production
summary: US industrial production surged 0.9% in December, driven by unseasonably cold weather and robust gains in mining production, which rose 1.6%. Manufacturing output, however, slowed further, gaining only 0.1% after a 0.3% increase in the prior month. The fourth quarter saw an 8.2% annual rate of industrial production growth, the largest since 2010, and a 1.8% increase for 2017, the first and largest since 2014. The strengthening global economy and weakening dollar have supported the industrial sector.

site_title: Ford cuts loose from cars after years of missing margin goal
summary: Ford Motor Co is ending its pursuit of mass-market sedans, pivoting to focus on low-volume, high-margin models such as sport utility vehicles and pickups. This shift comes after years of missing its profit-margin target, leading to the departure of former CEO Mark Fields. New CEO Jim Hackett plans to reorient the company around electric, autonomous, connected, and shared vehicles, playing catch-up with industry trends. Ford's passenger-car lineup will shrink, marking a significant change for the century-old company.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's exports rose by 7% in 2017, a 7-year peak, despite a weaker-than-expected December shipment. The country's aerospace industry is set to create 1,000 new jobs by 2020 through a transformation map. Residential development Hollandia in District 10 is up for sale with an indicative price of over S$163 million. Orange Valley Nursing Homes opened its sixth centre in Balestier, increasing its total beds to over 1,000. The Straits Times Index closed down 0.23% on Wednesday.

site_title: Digital economy among Singapore's five economic priorities as Asean chair
summary: Singapore will focus on five key economic areas during its Asean chairmanship, including the digital economy and trade facilitation. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang emphasized the need for deeper economic integration despite rising anti-trade sentiments. Key priorities include developing e-commerce trade rules, implementing regional trade facilitation schemes, and promoting South-east Asia as a cruising destination. Singapore will also work to strengthen ties with external partners, cultivate energy security, and deepen services integration and investment. The country aims to deliver tangible benefits to businesses and people during its chairmanship.

site_title: Slower December export growth, currency effect mask strong finish to 2017
summary: Singapore's December export data showed a slower growth rate than expected, but economists attribute this to a high base in December 2016. Despite this, the full-year Non-Oil Domestic Terms (NODX) growth rose 9.2%, the strongest since 2010. This suggests a strong finish to 2017, driven by trade growth. The country's economy remains resilient, with a deep and strong relationship with China, and opportunities for growth in emerging sectors like advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Melrose makes £7.4b hostile offer to acquire GKN
summary: Melrose Industries Plc made a £7.4-billion hostile bid for GKN Plc, offering 430.1 pence a share in cash and stock. The bid values GKN after the company rejected an initial approach. Melrose, an investment firm, met with GKN shareholders and bid to add pressure on the target to negotiate a deal. GKN reiterated that the offer undervalues the company, despite the firm's efforts to turn it around.

site_title: First Reit's Q4 DPU rises 0.9% after hospital acquisitions
summary: First Reit reported a 0.9% increase in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.15 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from newly acquired hospitals. Distributable income rose 1.6% and gross revenue climbed 5.8%. Net property income grew 4.9% to S$28 million. The company's asset size expanded by 6.3% to S$1.35 billion, with a stable gearing ratio of 33.6%.

site_title: Nomad Foods to buy UK's Goodfella's frozen pizza
summary: Nomad Foods has agreed to buy UK's Goodfella's frozen pizza from Boparan Holdings for 225 million euros, adding frozen pizza to its Birds Eye and Iglo brands. The deal is Nomad's first since 2015 and is expected to contribute 150 million euros to revenue and 8-9 euro cents to earnings per share within two years. The acquisition will be funded through cash on hand, and Nomad raised its earnings forecast for 2017, citing improved performance and growth.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit posts 11.9% drop in Q4 DPU
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported an 11.9% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 2017, reaching 1.383 Singapore cents, due to lower gross revenue and net property income. The company's full-year DPU slipped 6.2% to 5.712 cents. Despite this, the Reit manager secured about 90,000 sq ft of new leases in Q4 and completed over 920,000 sq ft of new leases, renewals, and forward renewals for the full year. Occupancy rate remained at 92.7%.

site_title: British designer Jones quits Louis Vuitton
summary: British designer Kim Jones is quitting Louis Vuitton after his final men's collection, following his 7-year tenure at the luxury brand. Jones, 38, is likely to be replaced by a new designer, with speculation suggesting he may join Versace. He has been credited with driving successful projects and collaborations, including Supreme and artist Jake and Dinos Chapman. Jones' departure sets off a fresh round of speculation in the fashion industry, with potential contenders including Burberry.

site_title: ST Aerospace wins S$510m worth of contracts in Q4 2017
summary: ST Aerospace secured S$510 million worth of contracts in Q4 2017, totaling S$2.8 billion for the year. These contracts include airframe maintenance, landing gear repair, and pilot training services for Boeing aircraft and other platforms. The deals, announced in November, are expected to have minimal impact on ST Engineering's earnings per share.

site_title: Singapore shares close down 0.23% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.23% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 8.3 points to 3,541.91, as Thai Beverage and Singtel led the losses. However, the Singapore Exchange bucked the trend, rising 2.77%. JEP Holdings saw a significant gain after UMS Holdings acquired a 7.48% stake in the company. About 2.12 billion shares changed hands, with losers beating gainers 256 to 198.

site_title: Juncker would like Britain to rejoin EU after Brexit
summary: EU chief executive Jean-Claude Juncker has renewed an offer to Britain to stay in the European Union, even after Brexit. He acknowledged a share of responsibility for the 2016 referendum vote, but believes the reasons for Britain's exit lie deeper. Juncker and European Council President Donald Tusk have reached out to the British government, expressing a willingness to discuss another way forward, and Juncker has noted that Article 49 allows for a return to membership. France has also expressed a willingness to welcome a change of heart, with President Emmanuel Macron's adviser stating that France would look at any potential change with kindness.

site_title: Work across borders to boost digital economy: Asean business leaders
summary: Asean business leaders emphasized the need for cross-border cooperation to boost the region's digital economy. Regional developers are encouraged to look to neighbors for solutions, rather than relying on foreign countries. An Asean e-wallet framework and improved trade facilitation are proposed to encourage e-commerce across borders. The Asean Single Window has seen progress, with four member countries using the electronic version of the Certification of Origin Form D. The Singapore Business Federation will host various Asean-related events to encourage firms to venture into the region, with a focus on digitalization and young entrepreneurs.

site_title: UMS Holdings ups stake in JEP Holdings to 29.5 per cent
summary: UMS Holdings has acquired a 29.5% stake in JEP Holdings for around SS$22.5 million, increasing its overall shareholdings to 429.9 million ordinary shares. The investment, made in cash, aims to diversify UMS' revenue into the aerospace industry, with JEP's main business being in aerospace. The acquisition is expected to provide UMS with "direct and immediate capacity" into the aerospace industry and tap into growth opportunities.

site_title: Ride-hailing firm Grab buys India-based payments startup iKaaz
summary: Grab, a South-east Asian ride-hailing firm, has acquired India-based payments startup iKaaz to expand its GrabPay platform. The acquisition, without disclosed deal value, aims to cater to the region's diverse payments landscape and large unbanked population. The iKaaz team will join Grab's research and development centre in Bangalore, India, following Grab's previous purchase of Indonesian online payment startup Kudo last year.

site_title: OCBC adds 18.51% stake in Maxwealth Fund Management for S$12.6 million
summary: OCBC has acquired an 18.51% stake in China-based Maxwealth Fund Management Company for S$12.6 million. This increases OCBC's stake in Maxwealth from 10% to 28.51%, making it an associated company. The remaining 71.49% interest is held by Bank of Ningbo Co, also an associated company of OCBC. The transaction is expected to have no material impact on OCBC's financial year-end earnings. The purchase was funded by internal resources and based on Maxwealth's audited net book value as of 2016.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets cede ground at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined in opening deals on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.1% to 7,748.89 points, and the Paris CAC 40 index and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also losing 0.3% each. The decline follows earlier losses in Asia.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: US stocks edge down from records amid tariff threats, with the Dow and S&P 500 experiencing a decline. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half of the year, while OCBC announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong and the appointment of Tan Teck Long as her successor. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Indonesia exchange walkway collapse due to "building failure" -initial report
summary: A walkway at the Indonesian Stock Exchange in Jakarta collapsed, injuring over 70 people, including university students on a study tour. The incident occurred when a mezzanine floor gave way under the weight of nearly 100 students, with loose or corroded joints being cited as a possible cause. The public works ministry has released a preliminary report, stating that the structure's failure was due to a "concentration of weight" and "loose or corroded bolts" or "shearing joints".

site_title: Indian sugar processors undermine their own margins to meet payments to cane farmers
summary: Indian sugar processors have reduced their margins to meet government-mandated payments to cane farmers, who received an 11% increase in cane prices for the 2017/18 marketing year. This has led to a 13.1% drop in refined sugar prices, causing liquidity crunch and forcing some mills to make distress sales. The decline in sugar prices is expected to slash profits for major sugar companies by at least 15% from last year, with sugar output in the next season potentially rising above record levels.

site_title: Flow of unwanted oil from China set to turn into deluge
summary: China's oil exports are expected to surge by over four times in 2018, with diesel shipments rising 47% to 23.8 million tonnes. This may lead to higher crude prices and lower refining margins for processors in Asia. The expected increase in exports is attributed to China's focus on quality over quantity for economic growth and stricter environmental policies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng Index hits all-time high
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index reached an all-time high of 31,983.41, surpassing its previous record of 31,995.18 on October 30, 2007. The index rose 0.25% in late trade on Wednesday, driven by traders' optimism ahead of the weekend. The Shanghai composite index also gained 0.24%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.30%. This milestone marks a significant milestone for the Hong Kong stock market, which has seen a resurgence in recent times.

site_title: Uber's next ride-share could be in South-east Asia
summary: Uber is considering its next ride-share venture in South-east Asia, following its struggles in China and Russia. The region, spanning Indonesia to Myanmar, offers a huge market with few barriers to entry. However, rivals like Grab and Go Jek have already grown quickly, making it challenging for Uber to compete. Despite this, Uber believes its expansion is more sustainable, citing its broader strategy and plans for an initial public offering in 2019. The company is building out in the region under former Goldman Sachs executive Brooks Entwistle, aiming to eventually exit the market if it fails to meet its goals.

site_title: ANZ drops quarterly earnings updates amid debate over their worth
summary: ANZ Banking Group has decided to stop reporting quarterly earnings figures, following Westpac Banking Corp's 2012 decision. The move aims to reduce costs and pressure on management amid scandals and a government enquiry. It also aligns with some countries' efforts to reevaluate quarterly reporting requirements, such as Singapore's consultation. This decision is part of a broader trend, with lenders seeking to cut costs and focus on long-term performance. The move may also reflect a shift in the value placed on quarterly updates.

site_title: Singapore aerospace industry transformation map eyes 1,000 new jobs by 2020
summary: Singapore has launched an aerospace industry transformation map (ITM) to create 1,000 new jobs by 2020. The ITM aims to improve productivity through operational excellence, innovation, and skills development. The government expects a total of S$4 billion in value-add to manufacturing in the industry. The ITM will focus on three key areas: operational excellence, driving innovation in emerging technologies, and equipping Singaporeans with relevant skills. This is part of the government's efforts to transform the economy and drive long-term growth.

site_title: Burberry holiday sales miss estimates as Gobbetti pushes change
summary: Burberry's holiday sales fell short of estimates, with retail revenue rising 2% on a comparable basis, missing analyst predictions of 4% growth. CEO Marco Gobbetti is implementing a plan to boost the brand's image with flashier stores and a focus on handbags. The company's shares fell the most in five years after Gobbetti revealed the plan. The search for a new creative director, who will design the brand's "it" bags, remains unclear. Burberry left its guidance for operating profit unchanged, saying it is on track to meet the new CEO's strategic goals.

site_title: China to step up cryptocurrency crackdown: report
summary: China plans to crack down on cryptocurrency trading, citing online finance risks. The country will target over-the-counter trading platforms, peer-to-peer networks, and firms allowing Chinese to trade overseas. This move aims to stamp out remaining trading in the country, following a previous ban in 2017. The Securities Journal reported an anonymous source close to regulators confirming the plan, which is expected to gradually clean up these platforms.

site_title: PSA Singapore steps up green initiatives with 21-year solar power deal with Sunseap
summary: PSA Singapore has signed a 21-year solar power deal with Sunseap to roll out solar power solutions across its terminal facilities in Singapore. The deal includes installing a 4-megawatt peak solar system across five sites, generating 4.3 gigawatt hours of energy per year and offsetting 1,689 tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions annually. The project aims to enhance PSA's eco-friendliness and support the government's efforts to encourage businesses to reduce greenhouse emissions and consider clean energy options.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down, won slips on broad US dollar strength
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.25% to 2,515.43, with the won losing 0.62% to 1,069.3 per US dollar. This comes as the US dollar strengthened broadly, affecting Asian markets. The Kospi is up 2.2% this year, but has been pulled back by US stocks. Foreigners bought 70,897 million won worth of shares, while the 3-month CD benchmark rate remained unchanged at 1.66%.

site_title: Hollandia in District 10 up for en bloc sale with over S$163m indicative price
summary: Hollandia, a 53,505 sq ft residential development in District 10, Singapore, is up for en bloc sale with an indicative price of over S$163 million. The site, built in the mid-1980s, can be developed up to 12 storeys with a gross plot ratio of 2.013, translating to a land rate of S$1,515 psf ppr. The sale, handled by Savills Singapore, is seen as an attractive opportunity for mid-sized developers, with the Holland address and proximity to Holland Village MRT station drawing interest. The tender closes on Feb 28.

site_title: Food Empire's subsidiary embarks on expansion of manufacturing unit in India
summary: Food Empire Holdings' subsidiary, Indus Coffee, is expanding its manufacturing unit in India. The expansion will be funded through internal and external resources, including US$11.25 million in additional capital and US$30 million in banking facilities. The expansion is expected to be completed by December 31, 2020, with no directors or controlling shareholders having an interest in the transaction. The move comes as Food Empire Holdings remains unchanged at 69 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: India's hike unveils mobile phones that work without active data
summary: India's WhatsApp rival Hike is launching a modified Android version called Total, allowing users to access services without an active data connection. The technology uses USSD protocol, enabling users to message, make payments, and access information through a single login. Four devices will be available starting March, priced between 3,500 to 5,000 rupees. Hike aims to connect India's 1 billion citizens to mobile services, with nearly 736 million Indians lacking mobile network connections.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on investor caution over US dip
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, January 17, 2018, due to investor caution following a drop on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.35% to 23,868.34, while the Topix index dropped 0.18% to 1,890.82. This decline came amid concerns about US economic indicators, with the US stock market experiencing a drop from record levels amid tariff threats.

site_title: New StanChart unit to invest in fintech and promote innovation
summary: Standard Chartered has established a new unit, SC Ventures, to promote innovation and invest in fintech companies. The unit will work with business units to adopt innovation best practices and design client-centric solutions. Led by Alex Manson, SC Ventures will sponsor and oversee new technology ventures and manage minority investments in fintech companies. The move aims to develop and deliver digital solutions that work for clients and the bank, facilitating a culture of innovation in the banking industry.

site_title: COE prices tumble despite prospect of smaller quota
summary: COE prices in Singapore fell at the latest tender, despite increased buying interest, with prices down from previous highs. COE prices for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp dropped to $36,890, while those for larger vehicles fell to $42,661. The open COE, which can be used for any vehicle type, closed at $44,000. The smaller quota is expected to have a cooling effect on prices, but the recent surge in interest from the Singapore Motorshow may continue to impact prices in the coming months.

site_title: Two Koreas in talks on Winter Olympics athletes
summary: North Korea has offered to send over 200 cheerleaders to the Winter Olympics in South Korea and attend the Paralympics, marking a significant improvement in inter-Korean relations. The offer, made during talks in Panmunjom, also includes a 140-member North Korean orchestra performing in South Korea. The International Olympic Committee must approve extra Olympic slots for North Korean athletes, who failed to qualify or meet deadlines to register. The developments come after North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un announced his willingness to participate in the Pyeongchang Games, aimed at easing tensions on the peninsula.

site_title: Who's afraid of QE's end? Not these emerging European economies
summary: Emerging European economies are not worried about the European Central Bank's (ECB) end of quantitative easing (QE), citing improved fiscal policies, better credit ratings, and diversified debt profiles. Countries like Slovakia, Croatia, Slovenia, and Serbia have sold bonds at record-low yields, indicating investor confidence in their economies. They believe they can handle potential fallout from higher borrowing costs and lower demand. Experts predict spreads will remain contained, despite global market fluctuations, and some countries are shifting borrowing into their domestic currencies.

site_title: South Korea's 'kimchi deficit' hits record high
summary: South Korea's kimchi trade deficit reached a record high in 2017, with the country importing over 275,000 tonnes of kimchi, 99% of it from China, and exporting just over 24,000 tonnes. The deficit stood at $47.3 million, up 11% year-over-year. The low price of Chinese imports ($0.50 per kilogramme) compared to South Korea's exports ($3.36 per kilogramme) contributed to the deficit. This marks the largest kimchi deficit since the Korea Customs Service began tracking the data in 2000.

site_title: Japan Tobacco CEO favours regional deals over complex purchase
summary: Japan Tobacco's new CEO, Masamichi Terabatake, favors regional deals over complex acquisitions as the company seeks to expand overseas. The company aims to command a 40% share of Japan's heated tobacco market by 2020, driven by its next-generation device, Ploom Tech, and other new products. Terabatake prioritizes economics, population growth, and gross margin expansion in target markets, focusing on underdeveloped countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines, and Ethiopia, where Japan Tobacco has spent over $2 billion acquiring assets.

site_title: VW to defend global sales crown despite 17b euro diesel hit
summary: Volkswagen (VW) reported a 4.3% increase in global deliveries to 10.7 million vehicles in 2017, surpassing Toyota's forecast of 10.4 million. The company's sales were largely unaffected by the 17 billion euro diesel emissions scandal, with robust demand in China and new SUV models contributing to the growth. VW aims to sustain sales momentum in 2018 with investments in electric and self-driving cars, and will roll out new models including the E-tron and Q8 SUVs. The company's CEO, Matthias Mueller, expressed gratitude to customers and commitment to meeting expectations.

site_title: China luxury sales rebound as millennials snap up cosmetics, handbags: report
summary: China's luxury goods market has rebounded, with sales reaching 142 billion yuan (S$29.15 billion) in 2017, a 20% increase from the previous year. The growth is driven by millennials, who prefer ready-to-wear and fast fashion, and is expected to continue this year. China's domestic market accounts for 8% of global luxury sales, and the country's tech-savvy youth are key drivers of the market. Luxury brands such as Gucci, Chanel, and LVMH are seeing a resurgence in popularity, while traditional brands like Prada are struggling to keep up with the changing consumer preferences.

site_title: NTUC Income unveils first-in-Singapore digital portal for Integrated Shield Plans
summary: NTUC Income has launched the first digital portal for purchasing Integrated Shield Plans in Singapore, offering enhanced accessibility and convenience. The portal (healthinsurance.income.com.sg) allows customers to obtain instant quotes, purchase plans, and submit claims in seconds. New customers with no pre-existing health conditions can receive approval and coverage within 5-10 minutes. This marks a significant shift from the previous offline process, where customers required an insurance adviser to complete the purchase. The digital portal aims to streamline the Integrated Shield Plan purchasing and claiming process.

site_title: Microsoft tops Thomson Reuters top 100 global tech leaders list
summary: Microsoft tops Thomson Reuters' "Top 100 Global Technology Leaders" list, followed by Intel and Cisco Systems. The list, based on a 28-factor algorithm, features US tech giants such as Apple and IBM, and includes companies like Amazon and Facebook. The top 10 companies are financially successful and organizationally sound, with 45% headquartered in the US. Asia is represented by 38 companies, led by Tencent Holdings, which became the first Asian firm to enter the $500 billion club.

site_title: Oil prices slip as analysts warn of correction after 13% gain in the past month
summary: Oil prices declined as analysts warned of a correction after a 13% gain in the past month. Despite this, oil markets remained well-supported due to tightening supply and strong global demand. Brent crude futures fell to $69.07 a barrel, down 18 cents from their last close, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures fell to $63.68 a barrel. Analysts expect a price correction due to excessive hedge fund expectations and a lack of significant supply disruptions.

site_title: Mercedes plots more SUVs after compact models expand luxury lead
summary: Mercedes-Benz plans to expand its SUV lineup, particularly in the compact segment, to capitalize on strong demand. The company has already become the world's largest luxury carmaker for a second consecutive year, driven by the popularity of compact models like the GLA and GLC. Mercedes aims to add new products to its portfolio, but may not focus on the upper end of the SUV range. The company is confident of a strong year in 2018, driven by the revamped A-Class sedan and stable sales in the US.

site_title: Tennis: Fighting Tsonga digs deep to reel in Shapovalov
summary: Tennis: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga defeated Denis Shapovalov in a five-set thriller at the Australian Open. Tsonga overcame a 2-5 deficit in the final set to win 3-6, 6-3, 1-6, 7-6 (7/4), 7-5. The 15th seeded Frenchman ends his three-match losing run in five-setters and will face either Nick Kyrgios or Viktor Troicki in the next round. Tsonga praised his courage and determination, while Shapovalov vowed to learn from his loss.

site_title: China says it doesn't need Taiwan's permission to open new air route
summary: China denies needing Taiwan's permission to open a new air route over the Taiwan Strait, citing a 2015 agreement that only requires discussion of flight paths. The move has raised concerns about regional security and aviation safety, with Taiwan saying it was not informed and could pose a risk to its air force exercises. China claims the route is necessary to alleviate pressure on busy routes and was approved by the International Civil Aviation Organisation. Beijing has taken an increasingly hostile stance towards Taiwan since President Tsai Ing-wen's election in 2016.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session lower; STI at 3,542.28, down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% in the afternoon session, with the Straits Times Index at 3,542.28. About 1.04 billion shares worth S$645 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 214 to 160. JEP Holdings rose, while DBS and SGX shares traded down.

site_title: GM, DHL use a Chinese plant to lead manufacturing change
summary: General Motors (GM) is partnering with logistics company DHL to use a Chinese plant to lead manufacturing changes, reducing costs and errors. The strategy involves DHL assembling thousands of parts kits daily, which are then delivered to the assembly line by robots or DHL workers. This shift allows GM's workforce to focus on improving quality and efficiency, with the goal of reducing vehicle assembly errors. GM's Chinese operations are at the forefront of factory floor innovation, using advanced technologies like zero-downtime welding and collaborative robots.

site_title: Real estate stays hot in East Europe with pre-crisis growth
summary: Eastern European real estate markets remain attractive to developers, with pre-crisis growth levels reached in 2018, according to industry executives. Despite volatile politics, the region's economies are among EU's growth leaders, with GDP expected to rise 5.5% this year. Liquidity is abundant, and market players remain optimistic, with property investments more attractive than financial assets due to low interest rates. Executives believe decisions in real estate are taken with a long view, helping to blunt the effect of political risk, making the market outlook "very bright" for the region.

site_title: US Navy commanders face negligent homicide charges over collisions
summary: US Navy commanders face negligent homicide charges over two fatal collisions. The USS John S. McCain collided with an oil tanker in August 2017, killing 10 sailors, and the USS Fitzgerald smashed into a cargo ship in June, leaving seven dead. Charges include dereliction of duty, hazarding a vessel, and negligent homicide. Investigations found multiple failures by watch standers that contributed to the incidents, which were deemed preventable.

site_title: Singapore Kitchen Equipment seeks dual listing on HK GEM board
summary: Singapore Kitchen Equipment is seeking a dual primary listing of its shares on the Hong Kong Growth Enterprise Market (GEM) board through a share offer. The dual listing aims to increase visibility, attract investors, and improve share liquidity. Proceeds will be used to enhance factory capabilities, expand into the hospitality sector, and strengthen presence in the Hong Kong and Chinese markets. This move is expected to provide opportunities for growth and expansion for the company.

site_title: Australia shares extend losses hurt by materials, NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to a four-week low, extending losses for the second straight session, as material stocks plummeted due to weak base metal prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 32.8 points to 6,015.8. Australia's metals and mining index fell 2.4%, its biggest decline in over four months.

site_title: Budget 2018: SMEC suggests developing startups into unicorns as a growth strategy
summary: The Singapore Business Federation's SME Committee (SMEC) recommends developing startups into unicorns as a growth strategy in Budget 2018. The committee suggests incentives such as grants and tax breaks to attract and support promising startups. To qualify, startups must meet criteria like a minimum 30% equity stake and have their headquarters and key functions in Singapore. The goal is to position Singapore as an attractive hub for unicorns and investors, enabling the private sector to play a more active role in the economy's growth and development.

site_title: Big US lenders reap benefits of higher rates, but savers not so much
summary: The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes have benefited banks by allowing them to charge higher loan rates, but have not led to increased interest rates for savers. With $11.95 trillion in deposits at US commercial banks, savers are earning only pennies on every $100, with rates on one-year certificates remaining unchanged. Analysts expect rates to rise further, potentially sparking higher rates for deposits, but consumers have yet to demand more. Bank executives attribute the lack of pressure to pay more to the lack of competitive pressure and the absence of a "magic number" for depositors.

site_title: China official says crackdown on murky conglomerates isn't over
summary: China's banking regulator vows to continue cracking down on large financial conglomerates with complex ownership structures and fraudulent capital injections. Chairman Guo Shuqing, the China Banking Regulatory Commission, aims to root out malpractice and strengthen controls over the banking industry. The crackdown follows last year's detentions of conglomerate heads and other measures to break up entities like Tomorrow Holding Co and Anbang Insurance Group Co. Guo's stern tone suggests China will take direct action to address problems despite hurting conglomerates' interests.

site_title: British MPs to vote on landmark Brexit bill
summary: British MPs will vote on a key Brexit bill, incorporating thousands of EU pieces into British law and repealing EU membership. The bill, which faces opposition in the upper house, has already seen compromises on a "meaningful vote" and Brexit date. The House of Lords may make further changes, with veteran MP Kenneth Clarke stating the bill could be altered significantly. The bill's passage is seen as a crucial step towards the UK's exit from the EU, with negotiations on Britain's future relationship with the EU yet to be established.

site_title: Orange Valley opens sixth nursing home in Balestier in January
summary: Orange Valley Nursing Homes, Singapore's largest private nursing home operator, opened its sixth centre in Balestier on January 2, 2018, with 116 beds and rehabilitation services. The five-storey centre features various room types, including open wards and deluxe suites, and is the first to offer outpatient rehabilitation services. This brings the chain's total beds to over 1,000.

site_title: China's solar boom boosts clean energy funding near record
summary: China's solar boom drove a 3% increase in global clean-energy investment last year, reaching $333.5 billion, despite US President Donald Trump's efforts to undermine pollution rules. China accounted for 40% of the total investment, with solar projects receiving nearly half of the funding. The country's investment in solar energy rose 67% from the previous year, while wind power projects saw a 12% decline. The boom was driven by decreasing costs and increasing adoption in emerging markets, with Mexico and Australia also seeing significant increases in investment.

site_title: Forest City developer Country Garden plans HK$23.5b bond, share sale to cut debt
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese property developer, plans to raise HK$23.5 billion through a share sale and bond issue to reduce debt and provide working capital. The company will issue 460 million new shares to major shareholder Concrete Win Ltd and HK$15.6 billion worth of convertible bonds to third-party buyers. This move is expected to reduce Concrete Win's stake in Country Garden to 54.79% from 57.93%. The share sale and bond issue come as the company seeks to cut debt, which has raised concerns about high levels of borrowing among developers.

site_title: Asia dollar bond boom intensifies with sky high investor demand
summary: Asia's dollar bond market is experiencing a boom, with companies receiving over five times the demand for debt issued in the first month of the year. Despite concerns over global interest rates and emerging markets, investors are flocking to the market, driven by an improving global economic environment and strong performance of riskier assets. Asian firms are expected to issue $300-350 billion in dollar bonds in 2018, with some investors playing catch-up after a quiet December. Demand for dollar bonds has been particularly strong for Chinese property companies, with orders receiving 15 times the issued size for some deals.

site_title: Trump warns of immigration threat to national security
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that the country's current immigration system weakens national security, citing a report from the Justice and Homeland Security Departments that nearly three-fourths of international terror-related convictions involved foreign-born individuals. The administration is seeking Supreme Court backing to lift protections shielding 700,000 "Dreamer" immigrants from deportation. Trump's comments come after he sparked international uproar with comments about immigration from "shithole" countries, and amid stalled negotiations on a bipartisan immigration deal.

site_title: In Vancouver, a door to a parallel culinary world
summary: Kissa Tanto, a Vancouver restaurant, offers a unique dining experience with its parallel culinary world, blending Italian and Japanese sensibilities. The restaurant's interior, designed by executive chef Joël Watanabe, evokes a 1960s atmosphere, complete with a tribute to Tokyo's Hotel Okura wing. Watanabe's dishes, such as fried croquettes and eggplant salad, showcase a harmonious fusion of flavors, with no forced combinations. Reservations are often difficult to come by, but the restaurant's commitment to atmosphere and quality justifies the wait. Kissa Tanto is a standout in Vancouver's culinary scene, offering a captivating and respectful tribute to Chinatown's history.

site_title: Pope meets victims of child sexual abuse in Chile, 'cries with them'
summary: Pope Francis met privately with victims of child sexual abuse in Chile, expressing "pain and shame" over the abuse by priests. The meeting was the second time he has met victims on an overseas trip, following a 2015 meeting in Philadelphia. The pope criticized the Church for its handling of the crisis, including the appointment of Bishop Juan Barros, who has been accused of protecting his former mentor, Father Fernando Karadima, who was found guilty of abusing teenage boys. The pope's visit to Chile has been marked by protests and anti-Pope graffiti, but he has also received a warm welcome from many Chileans.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, retreating 8.22 points or 0.2% to 3,541.99. The decline followed global stock markets, with the Dow and Nasdaq also falling. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 71, and US stocks closed lower on Tuesday after hitting an intraday record high, with oil prices weighing on investor enthusiasm.

site_title: Qantas named as least fuel efficient airline to fly the Pacific
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd is the least fuel-efficient airline to fly across the Pacific Ocean, burning an average of one litre of aviation fuel to fly 22 kilometres, 64% more than the most efficient carriers, Hainan Airlines Holding Co and All Nippon Airways Co. The International Council on Clean Transportation's 2016 study found Qantas uses larger aircraft, flies long distances, and has premium cabins with fewer passengers. The airline's head of fuel and environment, Alan Milne, attributed the low ranking to these factors.

site_title: China's way or the highway: big business bows to Xi's world view
summary: China is exerting pressure on multinational businesses to conform to its stance on territorial disputes, particularly regarding Taiwan, Tibet, and Hong Kong. Companies such as Marriott, Qantas, and Delta Air Lines have been forced to correct online references that may be deemed offensive, with some offering apologies and acknowledging China's sovereignty. The Chinese government has warned that companies that fail to comply risk facing punishment, with President Xi Jinping's tightening grip on power contributing to the growing intolerance for perceived slights.

site_title: Asia: Shares dip as commodities ease, bitcoin licks wounds
summary: Asian stocks declined on Wednesday, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index falling 0.15% after oil and commodity prices dropped. Digital currencies, including bitcoin, also fell as investors worried about tighter regulations. The US dollar remained weak, near a three-year low, while the euro scaled a three-year high. Investors expect the Bank of Canada to raise interest rates and the European Central Bank to exit stimulus in 2018. Oil prices pulled back from three-year highs, but remained near $70 per barrel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat after record close
summary: Hong Kong stocks retreated 0.34% on Wednesday, snapping a record high close from the previous day. The Hang Seng index closed at 31,795.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index inched up 0.06% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.16%. The decline follows a surge in the previous session.

site_title: YouTube again revises rules to protect advertisers from offensive content
summary: Google is revising YouTube's rules to protect advertisers from offensive content. The new standards will remove ads from 99% of channels generating less than $100 from ads in the last year. YouTube will review every second of popular videos for advertising by the end of March, and will modify prerequisites for commercial channels. The move comes after over 250 advertisers cut back on YouTube ad-buying due to concerns over extremist propaganda and child endangerment. The changes aim to ensure ads run alongside content reflecting advertisers' values.

site_title: Bitcoin more important than iPhone to growth at some Asian firms
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), the world's largest maker of bespoke microchips, may see significant growth from supplying components for cryptocurrency mining, particularly Bitcoin. With Bitcoin's price surge last year, TSMC's revenue from crypto-mining could reach 10% of its total revenue in 2018, potentially becoming its fastest-growing segment. Analysts predict this growth could offset soft smartphone demand, but the sustainability of crypto-mining demand remains uncertain due to regulatory crackdowns and potential price volatility.

site_title: Bike sharing rejigs model for Japan to avoid sidewalk clutter
summary: Japan's bike-sharing industry faces challenges due to strict laws against sidewalk clutter, cultural sensitivities, and parking restrictions. To avoid these issues, companies like Mobike and Docomo Bikeshare are partnering with local governments and retailers to establish designated parking areas. Mobike's cautious approach has allowed it to maintain a presence in Japan, while competitors like Mercari aim to expand through a point-based system. The bike-sharing industry's success in China, with 16 million cycles, serves as a contrast to Japan's struggles with bike clutter, with some companies abandoning plans due to concerns about optics.

site_title: GE reignites break-up talk after US$11b insurance, tax hit
summary: General Electric (GE) is exploring options to break itself up, with CEO John Flannery stating the company is "looking aggressively" at a spin-off or other ways to maximize the value of its power, aviation, and healthcare units. The conglomerate announced a US$11 billion charge from its long-term care insurance portfolio and new US tax laws, which will impact its 2017 profit. A potential breakup could result in a spin-off of GE's Baker Hughes unit and a potential IPO of part of GECAS, GE's aircraft finance unit.

site_title: Rio Tinto says US SEC fraud case should be dismissed
summary: Rio Tinto has filed letters with the US District Court in Manhattan, arguing that a Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) lawsuit accusing the company of fraud over Mozambique coal assets should be dismissed. The SEC alleges Rio Tinto, former CEO Thomas Albanese, and former CFO Guy Elliott concealed asset deterioration while raising $5.5 billion from US investors. Rio Tinto's lawyers argue the SEC failed to prove intent to commit fraud or make false statements. Similar letters have been filed by Albanese and Elliott's lawyers, stating they conducted themselves reasonably and relied on a rigorous process for financial reporting.

site_title: Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong jailed for protest
summary: Hong Kong democracy activist Joshua Wong was jailed for three months for obstructing clearance of a major encampment during mass pro-democracy protests in 2014. Wong, 21, had pleaded guilty to the contempt charge, which is the second time he has been imprisoned over the rallies. He is already on bail pending an appeal over a six-month sentence for another offence related to the Umbrella Movement.

site_title: What's in a name? Chinese automaker nixes 'Trumpchi'
summary: Chinese automaker GAC is changing the name of its US market models, dubbed "Trumpchi," due to concerns over its association with President Donald Trump.
