The name "Trumpchi" translates to "legend" in Chinese, but US media had raised concerns about potential cultural dissonance. GAC plans to introduce new models in the US market by the end of 2019, as part of its expansion into the European market. This move comes after a similar incident with Tata Motors' "Zica" model, which was renamed to "Tiago" following a public relations backlash.

site_title: Iranian oil tanker wreck produced two slicks in East China Sea: China
summary: An Iranian oil tanker, Sanchi, sank in the East China Sea, producing two oil slicks covering a combined 109 sq km. Satellite imaging showed a 69 sq km and a 40 sq km slick. Maritime police are searching the area for damage to the marine ecosystem, following the worst oil ship disaster in decades.

site_title: IMDA seeks to strengthen consumer protection with dispute resolution scheme for telco, media services
summary: The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is seeking public feedback on a proposed dispute resolution scheme for telecommunications and media services. The scheme aims to strengthen consumer protection, providing an alternative platform for consumers and small businesses to resolve disputes with service providers. The scheme, which will be self-sustainable through a co-payment model, proposes a two-stage process of mediation and adjudication, with fees starting from S$10. The public consultation closes on February 28, and the scheme is expected to cover widely-used telecommunications and media services, including mobile, broadband, and subscription TV services.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FSL Trust, JEP Holdings, Top Global, LCT Holdings
summary: FSL Trust sold a chemical tanker for US$13.8 million to pare debt, recording a related impairment charge of US$9 million. JEP Holdings' shares rose after UMS Holdings acquired a 7.48% stake for S$5.7 million. Top Global cancelled its proposed purchase of shophouses due to unfulfilled change-of-use conditions. LCT Holdings expects to report a loss for the second quarter due to increased maintenance costs.

site_title: As tech ascends, has CES made Detroit Auto Show an afterthought?
summary: The Detroit Auto Show has been overshadowed by the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, with many major electric and autonomous vehicle announcements made at CES instead. The 2018 show featured revamps of tried-and-true models, with no significant new electric or autonomous vehicle launches. Critics question the relevance of the Detroit show, with some saying it has lost its luster due to the lack of innovation and the growing importance of emerging markets. Despite this, Detroit defenders argue that the show remains essential for industry networking and access to top executives and suppliers.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks down, won edges lower against dollar
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.33% to 2,513.38 points at 01:09 GMT, while the won edged down 0.08% against the dollar. Bond yields also dropped. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index was down 0.15%, and Japanese stocks weakened 0.58%. Foreigners sold 35,877 million won worth of shares. The won's high for the year was 1,056.67 per dollar on January 14, and its low was 1,073.2 on January 11.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.48 points to 1,824.55 at 9am on Wednesday, with volume reaching 172.93 million lots worth RM32.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 85.

site_title: Dow starts day with a bang and ends in a whimper
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average surged to 26,000 in the morning, only to lose 10 points by the end of the day, closing at 25,990. The 283-point gain was attributed to initial momentum, but was erased by a decline in oil prices and concerns over a government shutdown. Despite the down day, the Dow is still up 4.34% for the year, with other major indices also experiencing gains, including the Nasdaq and S&P 500.

site_title: Oil prices drop off 3-year highs but strong demand supports
summary: Oil prices dropped 3-year highs to US$69.15 a barrel, down US$1.11 from Monday's peak of US$70.37. Despite this, prices remain near US$70 per barrel due to strong demand amid healthy economic growth. Oil production curbs in Opec nations and Russia continue to support prices. Analysts expect oil prices to correct lower due to overheating, but most still forecast prices to rise. US shale production is expected to rise to 6.55 million bpd in February.

site_title: Wanda billionaire extends selloff with London luxury project
summary: Billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group has sold a London luxury project, One Nine Elms, for £59 million ($107.5 million) to Guangzhou R&F Properties. This sale adds to the company's disposals of over $9 billion in the past year as it sheds assets to reduce debt and focus on strategic investments. The sale comes amid pressure to raise cash and cut debt after the downgrade of Wanda's credit rating to junk by major credit rating agencies. Construction on the project began in 2013 and was initially valued at £700 million.

images.alt_text: Mr Wang's Wanda Hotel Development said in November that it was doing a strategic review of its projects stretching from Sydney to Chicago and would consider opportunities that create value for shareholders.

site_title: The ex-Goldman banker who quit to take over a Myanmar empire
summary: Melvyn Pun, a former Goldman Sachs banker, left his high-profile job to join his father's Myanmar conglomerate, Yoma Strategic Holdings, in 2015. The company has grown despite challenges, with the IMF projecting 6.7% growth this fiscal year. Pun aims to triple Yoma's market value within five years, expanding its consumer, automotive, and real estate units. The company has invested in the KFC franchise and High Class Whisky, and plans to open more eateries to serve Myanmar's growing middle class. Despite concerns about the Rohingya humanitarian crisis, Pun remains optimistic about the country's prospects.

site_title: Australia: Materials drag shares to 4-week low; NZ climbs
summary: Australian shares fell to a 4-week low, down 0.4% to 6022.3, as weak base metal prices hit materials stocks, dragging down the S&P/ASX 200 index. Copper and nickel touched multi-week lows, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto losing as much as 3.7% and 2.8% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%, led by consumer staples and telecoms.

site_title: Citigroup reports US$18b loss on one-time tax items
summary: Citigroup reported a US$18 billion quarterly loss due to one-time tax charges related to the new US tax law, but its adjusted earnings beat Wall Street expectations. The bank's tax rate is expected to fall to 25% this year from 30% in 2017, saving it billions of dollars. Citigroup's management is re-examining financial performance targets, which could be lifted, and expects to generate higher returns and capital. The bank's adjusted net income rose 4% to US$3.7 billion, driven by growth in consumer banking, particularly in Asia and Mexico.

site_title: Japan machinery orders rise, capex recovery seen intact
summary: Japan's core machinery orders unexpectedly grew 5.7% in November, the fastest gain in four months, indicating a steady pickup in capital expenditure. The data, which excludes ships and utilities, beat analyst expectations and suggests capital spending will remain in a gradual uptrend. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to offer tax breaks for companies investing in cutting-edge technologies to boost productivity, aiming to drive a virtuous growth cycle in the economy.

site_title: Second US winter storm forces hundreds of flight cancellations
summary: A second US winter storm is causing hundreds of flight cancellations across the United States, with American Airlines canceling 270 flights between Tuesday and Wednesday. The storm, affecting southeast Texas and the East Coast, has dumped snow, sleet, and freezing rain. Airlines have also canceled flights into Wednesday, potentially impacting carriers' first quarter outlooks.

site_title: Singapore exports log weaker-than-expected rise in December; full-year growth hits 7-year peak
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 3.1% in December, lower than expected, despite a strong full-year growth of 9.2%, the strongest pace in seven years. Electronics exports declined 5.3% in December, while non-electronics shipments rose 6.8%. The largest contributors to NODX growth were the European Union, South Korea, and Malaysia, with China being the exception, experiencing a 6% decline. This marks a muted end to a year of surging growth, which was driven by robust global demand for tech products.

site_title: ESR-Reit's DPU drops 6.7% for Q4
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 6.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.929 Singapore cents for Q4 2017, and an overall 7.7% drop in DPU for fiscal 2017. Net property income (NPI) rose 1.2% in Q4 but fell 4.7% for the year. The Reit attributed the decline to property transition and increased operating expenses. To rebalance its capital structure, ESR-Reit plans to issue up to 263 million new units via private placement, raising S$125 million.

site_title: Wall Street on cloud nine since Trump's election
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency has brought significant gains to Wall Street, with the S&P 500, Dow Jones Industrial Average, and Nasdaq reaching record highs. Since Trump's election, the principal US stock indices have gained 19.4%, 25%, and 28.3%, respectively, with only two other presidents achieving higher gains in their first years in office. Analysts attribute the surge to the tax overhaul and rising prosperity, while Trump's pro-business attitude and team of Wall Street insiders have comforted investors.

site_title: Airbus gets early 2018 jump on rival Boeing with Mexico order
summary: Airbus secured an early 2018 order from low-cost Mexican airline Volaris for 80 A320 planes worth $9.3 billion, surpassing rival Boeing. The deal, valued at $9.3 billion, is Volaris' largest plane order in history. Airbus' 2017 commercial deliveries reached a company record, and its backlog stood at 7,265 aircraft valued at $1.059 trillion. This order marks a significant jump for Airbus in 2018, following its 2017 record-breaking performance.

site_title: Ending the charade of independent directors
summary: Singapore's Corporate Governance Council is strengthening director independence by proposing a 5% threshold for substantial shareholdings and a nine-year cap on ID tenure. This move aims to address the lack of genuine independence among directors in the face of controlling shareholders. The Council also suggests annual votes for reappointments of long-serving IDs, subjecting them to shareholder approval. This change aims to protect investors and enhance corporate governance, moving towards a more stringent definition of independence, similar to Hong Kong's 1% threshold.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.79% to 23,762.55. The yen edged higher after Wall Street fell due to profit taking and a dip in oil prices. The broader Topix index was down 0.60%.

site_title: CDL will not extend offer for M&C beyond Jan 26
summary: CDL, a Singaporean real estate company, will not extend its offer to privatize London-listed Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) beyond January 26 if there are insufficient acceptances. The acceptance condition requires over 50% of unowned shares to be accepted. CDL currently holds 65.2% of M&C shares and has raised its offer price to 620 pence per share. The company believes a third-party offeror is unlikely to emerge, making the final offer the only liquidity event for M&C shareholders in the near term.

site_title: Trump 'healthy,' no cognitive issues: doctor
summary: US President Donald Trump's first medical examination, released on January 16, 2018, revealed he is physically fit and has "no cognitive issues whatsoever." According to Dr. Ronny Jackson, Trump scored 30/30 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment and performed "exceedingly well" on a cognitive test. Trump's vital statistics showed normal heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac output, with a life of abstinence from tobacco and alcohol contributing to his cardiac fitness. Dr. Jackson also plans to work on a diet plan to reduce calories, fats, and carbohydrates for the president.

site_title: Global dairy prices surge as New Zealand production wanes
summary: Global dairy prices surged 4.9% in the latest auction, the largest gain in over a year, due to anticipated sluggish supply from New Zealand, the world's largest milk exporter. Fonterra's decision to slash milk collection in the country, affected by dry weather, contributed to the price increase. Analysts note that while the gains may support prices for whole milk powder, global milk production is expected to grow, potentially easing prices in coming months.

site_title: Nestle sells US candy to Ferrero for 2.7b Swiss francs
summary: Nestle has agreed to sell its US candy business to Ferrero for 2.7 billion Swiss francs (S$3.7 billion) in cash, marking a significant shift in the Swiss food giant's product portfolio. The sale will include popular brands such as Crunch, Butterfinger, and Baby Ruth, making Ferrero the third-largest confectionary company in the US market. This deal represents Ferrero's first major acquisition in the US, as the company traditionally focuses on organic growth.

site_title: Bitcoin plunge extends to 25% as fear of crypto crackdown linger
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 25% to US$10,338, its lowest level since late December, amid fears of a regulatory crackdown. The decline also affected rival cryptocurrencies, with Ripple sinking 40% and Ethereum dropping 26%. Speculators are uncertain about when or how market watchdogs will intervene in the decentralized industry. This selloff follows previous double-digit declines, only to be followed by rebounds. The cryptocurrency market's volatility continues, with investors struggling to predict the industry's future.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge JV starts construction on office tower in Ho Chi Minh City business park
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge, a Singaporean urban solutions provider, has started construction on an office tower in Ho Chi Minh City's OneHub Saigon business park. The 12,000 sq m Office Tower 1 is expected to begin operations in the first quarter of next year and offers a premium quality business space solution. The 12-hectare development will feature seven office towers, a mixed-use commercial block, and recreational amenities. Leasing for Tower 1 is now open, targeting firms in the information technology, business process outsourcing, and finance sectors.

site_title: Hugo Boss sales pick up at stores, online and in the US
summary: Hugo Boss reported a 5% currency-adjusted sales rise in the fourth quarter, driven by store and online sales growth. The company's US sales rebounded 11% and its Asia-Pacific sales rose 10%. After a string of profit warnings, Hugo Boss revamped its core brands and closed loss-making stores to appeal to younger buyers. The company expects 2017 Ebitda to match its 2016 forecast. Its shares rose 2% after the report, narrowing the discount to luxury peers.

site_title: Reactions to the council's proposals
summary: The Corporate Governance Council proposed changes to the Corporate Governance Code, including lowering the shareholding threshold for director independence to 5% and limiting independent director tenure to nine years. Reactions from industry experts were mixed, with some supporting the hard rule for board renewal and diversity, while others believed the changes would not significantly impact compliance. The changes aim to strengthen director independence and encourage a more diverse and dynamic board composition.

site_title: Gold eases from four-month peak as dollar claws back
summary: Gold prices eased from a four-month peak as the US dollar regained some lost ground, closing 0.2% lower at $1,337.04 per ounce. The dollar's rise, coupled with strong stock markets, weighed on gold prices, while a weakening US dollar made dollar-priced gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. Analysts expect a trading range of $1,225-$1,430 for gold this year, with a potential top before a bottom.

site_title: Heathrow begins public consultation on airport expansion, motorway move
summary: Heathrow Airport has launched a 10-week public consultation on its proposed £22 billion expansion, which includes a third runway and rerouting of the M25 motorway. The proposal aims to meet strict environmental tests and deliver benefits for passengers and local communities. The government plans to give the go-ahead to the new runway in the first half of this year, with Transport Secretary Chris Grayling stating that costs will be kept down to £2.5 billion. Airlines have expressed support for the expansion, but with conditions, including keeping costs under control and passenger charges in real terms.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end steady as commodity stocks weigh
summary: European stocks ended flat on Tuesday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index closing unchanged, as commodity stocks weighed on gains. However, fashion house Hugo Boss rose 3.7% after reporting growth at its stores and online sales. PSA Group and Engie also gained, while UK midcap JD Sports Fashion jumped 6.7% ahead of profit forecasts. Despite the gains, Provident Financial fell 12.6% after reporting a loss, and miners and oil stocks fell 1.4% and 1% respectively.

site_title: Malaysia and Singapore look forward to stable ties
summary: Malaysia and Singapore leaders expressed confidence in maintaining stable ties despite the upcoming Malaysia general election and Singapore's Cabinet reshuffle. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Najib Razak said domestic developments won't affect bilateral relations, with Najib noting Malaysian voters will decide on a productive agenda. The two countries also reaffirmed their memorandum of understanding on educational cooperation and agreed to a joint study on conserving the Linggiu Reservoir's water supply. Leaders emphasized the need for a stable and productive agenda to avoid a return to confrontational diplomacy.

site_title: Man United overhaul Spanish pair as Europe's biggest earners
summary: Manchester United became Europe's biggest earner in the 2016 financial year, surpassing Real Madrid and Barcelona with a 32% revenue increase to 689 million euros. The English Premier League generated the most revenue, with Manchester United earning 146 million euros from domestic broadcasts. However, nearly half of the top clubs' revenue came from just 30 clubs, and the financial gap between the elite and the rest is increasing. The report also highlighted record transfer spending and the highest operating profit of 232 million euros for United.

site_title: Telegram - crypto junkies' favourite messaging app - planning biggest ICO ever
summary: Telegram, the encrypted messaging service, is planning the largest initial coin offering (ICO) in history, aiming to raise $1.2 billion in a private sale of tokens and $600 million in a public sale, before February 2018 and March, respectively. The project aims to create a blockchain network that can compete with Visa and Mastercard for payments. Investors will receive tokens with a 50% discount and must hold on to them for at least 18 months. The project's valuation is estimated to be around $2 billion, with some experts predicting success despite concerns over government regulation and market volatility.

site_title: Fired-up investors chase STI to 10-year high
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reached a 10-year high, closing at 3,550.21 on Tuesday, driven by a 29.6-point gain over two days. The rally was fueled by a 228-point surge on Wall Street, improved fundamentals, and rising oil prices benefiting offshore and marine companies and banks. Analysts expect the index to potentially reach its all-time high of 3,831.19, with some predicting a 20% increase this year.

site_title: STI hits peaks last seen 10 years ago
summary: Singapore shares rose for a third day, closing at 3,550.21, the highest level since Dec 11, 2007, with a 0.39% gain. The rally is attributed to the property, banking, and oil and gas sectors. Almost 2.12 billion shares worth S$1.12 billion were traded, with gainers beating out losers 272 to 182.

site_title: A vending machine that doles out rewards
summary: A vending machine in Singapore, developed by F&N and Incon Green, rewards users with discount coupons for recycling used cans and bottles. The machine, part of a recycling program, identifies and sorts items, with each five items redeemed earning a 50-cent coupon for F&N products. Since the program's launch, over 5,000 bottles and cans have been deposited at three locations. The program aims to encourage eco-conscious behavior and simple green habits among Singaporeans.

site_title: Video site backed by Tencent said to be seeking US$17b price
summary: A Chinese startup backed by Tencent, Kuaishou, is seeking a US$17 billion valuation through a private funding deal, aiming to raise around US$1 billion. This represents a nearly six-fold increase from its last fundraising in March, valuing the company at US$3 billion. The company plans to expand its video-streaming service to South-east Asia.

site_title: Citi ramps up China desk for clients seeking Asean growth
summary: Citi is expanding its operations in Singapore to support Chinese clients looking to expand into the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region. The US bank has added a second China desk in Singapore, allowing clients to use the city-state as an entry point into the region. This move aims to capitalize on growing trade between China and Asean countries.

site_title: Singapore-based ZACD Group in modest debut on HKEX
summary: ZACD Group, a Singapore-based asset management company, made its modest debut on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) with its shares closing 1.6% higher than the IPO price of HK$0.32. The company raised about HK$125.2 million (S$21.2 million) in net proceeds to set up a bridging reserve fund and expand its business. ZACD's shares opened at HK$0.33 and hit an intraday high of HK$0.355 before closing at HK$0.325.

site_title: Are shipping companies all at sea on cyber security?
summary: Major shipping companies AP Moeller-Maersk and Clarksons have been hit by damaging cyber attacks, with Maersk Line reporting a financial impact of $250-300 million. A cyber security specialist, Naval Dome, conducted penetration tests on systems used on tankers, container ships, and cruise ships, revealing the ease with which hackers can access and override critical systems. The tests showed hackers could manipulate radar displays, disable machinery, and even shift a ship's reported position. The maritime industry's vulnerability to cyber attacks is highlighted, with Naval Dome offering solutions to prevent similar breaches.

site_title: US: Early Wall Street rally fizzles as stocks end lower
summary: US stocks closed lower on Tuesday, ending an intraday record high, as a dip in oil prices weighed on investor enthusiasm. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished essentially flat at 25,792.86, while the S&P 500 fell 0.4% to 2,776.42. The Nasdaq suffered the heaviest losses, falling 0.5% to 7,223.69. Oil stocks contributed to the decline, with Chevron and Exxon Mobil falling 1.2% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: Cranberries singer Dolores O'Riordan dies suddenly, aged 46
summary: Irish singer-songwriter Dolores O'Riordan, lead vocalist of The Cranberries, has died suddenly at 46 in London, according to her publicist. Police are investigating the death as non-suspicious, and a report will be compiled for a coroner. O'Riordan, who battled bipolar disorder, was in London to record a cover of the band's hit "Zombie" with Bad Wolves. Tributes poured in from Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar, Irish President Michael D Higgins, and the band's current members, who praised her as an extraordinary talent and a voice of a generation.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, BofA lead in Asia equity trading: report
summary: Morgan Stanley and Bank of America Merrill Lynch tied for the top spot in Asian equity trading share in 2017, according to a report by Greenwich Associates. Soaring stock markets and increased volume boosted trading revenue, but EU regulations MiFID II may affect 2018 performance. Citigroup and Credit Suisse also ranked highly, with Citic Securities unit CLSA and UBS Group in fifth place. The report suggests MiFID II could lead to increased electronic trading and affect firm revenues.

site_title: There is danger in today's good economic news
summary: The global economy is expected to grow in 2018, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) adjusting its growth projections upward. The eurozone manufacturing index reached an all-time high, and Greece's economy is finally growing. However, the positive indicators are tempered by concerns about rising income inequality and stagnant wage growth. Meanwhile, US growth is predicted to exceed the IMF's October prediction of 2.3% for 2018, despite a mixed economic landscape.

site_title: Local firms fared better in paying bills promptly in 2017
summary: Singapore local firms saw improvements in paying bills promptly in 2017, with the annual average proportion of prompt payments rising to 48.4% from 43.77% in 2016. Slow payments fell by 5 percentage points to 39.71%, while partial payments reached a seven-year high of 11.87%. The construction sector bucked the trend, with slow payments increasing by nearly nine percentage points. Despite cashflow woes, firms are exercising better credit vigilance, indicating a healthy sign for creditworthiness.

site_title: Palladium prices continue to soar on strong demand from carmakers
summary: Palladium prices have soared to a record high of $1,139.68 an ounce, driven by strong demand from carmakers to reduce vehicle pollution. The metal's price has risen 3.6% in a week, with last year's shortage reaching 1.6 million ounces. Despite potential risks of a correction, analysts expect prices to remain supported by demand, with some predicting a further $150-$200 increase. However, longer-term demand may subside as electric vehicles gain market share, potentially leading to a drop in prices.

site_title: Pickups and SUVs muscle out sedans, e-cars in US market
summary: The US auto market is shifting towards larger SUVs and trucks, with the industry favoring these vehicles due to high profit margins and consumer preference. At the 2018 Detroit Auto Show, car makers unveiled dozens of new models, including luxurious and family-friendly options, while also offering lower-cost, pared-down versions. Analysts predict 2018 will be the year of trucks and SUVs, driven by Americans' preference for higher-priced, amenity-laden vehicles amid a booming economy and affordable fuel.

site_title: Facebook's new mission may be impossible
summary: Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg has expressed a desire to shift the focus of the platform from media to social interactions, potentially reducing public content from businesses and media. However, this move may be challenging due to the platform's reliance on ad revenue and the difficulties in implementing such a change without alienating users and investors. Regulators could potentially play a role in forcing Facebook to pay for news content shared on the platform, and Zuckerberg's efforts to address the issue may ultimately lead to a re-evaluation of the company's role in the media landscape.

site_title: OCBC downgrades SATS to 'hold' on rally, potential price pressure
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded SATS to "hold" from "buy" due to the stock's recent 25% climb, citing uncertainty about potential pricing pressure. However, analysts raised their fair-value to S$5.50, citing a positive longer-term outlook for the ground-handling and in-flight catering services company. SATS has entered overseas partnerships, including with AirAsia and Wilmar, to diversify and expand its business. Despite this, the analysts remain cautious about the impact of potential pricing pressure on SATS' business.

site_title: Carillion's demise puts spotlight on UK pensions shortfall
summary: The UK construction and services company Carillion Plc has collapsed with a £587 million pension shortfall, putting pressure on other companies to address their own funding gaps. The government-backed Pension Protection Fund (PPF) will likely step in to help, but future pensioners face a 10% drop in payouts and a £35,000 cap. This high-profile case may increase scrutiny on politicians and regulators to address the issue of pension shortfalls, which have reached £85 billion among FTSE 350 companies.

site_title: UMS Holdings buys 7.5% stake in JEP Holdings
summary: Singaporean precision engineering company UMS Holdings has acquired a 7.48% stake in JEP Holdings for S$5.7 million. The purchase was funded by internal resources and was made in the open market. This comes as JEP was previously in talks with an unrelated third party over a possible deal to acquire a controlling interest in the company. The transaction does not involve any directors or substantial shareholders of UMS. The acquisition of JEP shares was made on the same day that JEP revealed the talks with the third party, which could result in the third party acquiring at least 15% of the company.

site_title: Private equity firms target cloud, digitisation
summary: Private equity firms are leveraging cloud and digitisation to add value to traditional businesses, rather than transforming them into pure-play technology companies. They're hiring tech specialists and using AI to streamline operations and improve customer relations. Companies like Apax and EQT are digitising their portfolio companies, increasing productivity and sales. The trend also includes investing in the internet of things (IoT) and adopting cloud-based platforms to improve transparency and accessibility. As the industry matures, private equity firms are prioritising digital transformation and adopting technology to stay competitive.

site_title: US lawmakers call on AT&T to cut commercial ties with Huawei
summary: US lawmakers are urging AT&T to cut ties with Huawei and oppose China Mobile's US market entry due to national security concerns. The warning comes after the Trump administration took a harder stance on policies related to China's acquisition of US strategic industries. AT&T was forced to scrap a Huawei handset plan earlier this month, and the US government has blocked Chinese acquisitions over national security concerns. Lawmakers also advise US companies that ties with Huawei or China Mobile could hinder their ability to do business with the US government.

images.alt_text: Huawei and Chinese telecom firms have long struggled to gain a foothold in the American market, partly because of US government pressure on potential US partners.

site_title: Changes to SGX's regulatory rules need to be carried out consistently
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced changes to its regulatory rules, including enhancements to disclosure rules in three key areas: secondary fundraising, interested person transactions, and transactions not in the ordinary course of business. The changes aim to reduce information disparity between controlling and minority shareholders and promote stakeholder engagement. The new Corporate Governance (CG) Code includes a principle on stakeholder engagement, providing more flexibility for companies to meet the principles. SGX plans to review the CG Code again and introduce a green lane for deserving companies, offering faster turnaround times and increased transparency.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge JV starts construction on office tower in Ho Chi Minh City business park
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge, a Singaporean urban solutions provider, has begun construction on Office Tower 1 at OneHub Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City's Saigon Hi-Tech Park. The six-floor tower, with a 12,000 sq m gross floor area, is expected to start operations in the first quarter of 2023. The 12-hectare development will feature seven office towers, a mixed-use commercial block, and recreational amenities, offering a "work-live-play-learn environment" for tenants. Leasing for Tower 1 is now open, targeting firms in the IT, finance, and business process outsourcing sectors.

site_title: US govt shutdown looms as Republicans seek short-term spending deal
summary: US government shutdown looms as Republicans seek short-term spending deal. Republican leaders are unlikely to pass a long-term spending bill by Friday's deadline and are turning to a short-term funding measure. Democratic leaders, however, are adamant they will not support any deal that doesn't protect young illegal immigrants. This development increases the chances of a government shutdown, which could have significant consequences for federal agencies and the US economy.

images.alt_text: Mr Paul: The immigration debate should be resolved separately from the spending talks.

site_title: Society is demanding that companies serve a social purpose
summary: BlackRock's CEO Larry Fink emphasizes the growing demand for companies to serve a social purpose, as investors increasingly expect firms to demonstrate a positive contribution to society. To prosper, companies must show how they create long-term value for all stakeholders, including shareholders, employees, customers, and communities. BlackRock aims to engage with companies more effectively, doubling its investment stewardship team over the next three years. Companies must articulate their long-term strategy, including their path to financial performance and societal impact, and demonstrate a commitment to sustainability and good governance.

images.alt_text: We also see many governments failing to prepare for the future, on issues ranging from retirement and infrastructure to automation and worker retraining. - Laurence D Fink (above), chairman and CEO of BlackRock

site_title: Even with AI, humans still crucial in investing
summary: Artificial intelligence is increasingly used in investment management, but its role remains debated. While AI can process vast amounts of data and analyze patterns, human judgment is still crucial in making long-term portfolio decisions. Some firms, such as BlackRock, use AI to identify non-intuitive relationships and gain insights from social media and search engines, but ultimately, human managers make the final decisions. A new ETF, AI Powered Equity, uses AI algorithms to select stock holdings, but its performance is still uncertain, and experts question whether AI can truly replace human decision-making in managing portfolios.

site_title: Euro down from three-year high, bitcoin plunges
summary: The euro fell half a percent on Tuesday, its worst performance in nearly two years, after investors sold the currency amid uncertainty over German Chancellor Angela Merkel's efforts to form a "grand coalition" in parliament. The euro had reached a three-year high earlier in the week but fell to a four-week low near US$1.2208. Meanwhile, bitcoin plummeted 18% to US$11,000 due to reports of a possible South Korean ban on cryptocurrency trading, sparking fears of a wider regulatory crackdown.

site_title: Singapore slips to 8th costliest place in Asia for mid-market home rentals
summary: Singapore has slipped to 8th place in the list of most expensive places in Asia for mid-market home rentals, according to a survey by ECA International. The country's average rent for an unfurnished three-bedroom apartment is now $10,461, down from its previous ranking. Hong Kong remains the most costly destination, with average rents averaging $10,461 for an unfurnished three-bedroom apartment. This marks a decline from its previous year's ranking.

site_title: Citigroup taking steps to close gender, racial pay gaps
summary: Citigroup has announced plans to measure, publish, and close the pay gaps between men and women, as well as US minorities, in three countries, including the US, UK, and Germany. The bank found that women earn 99% of men's pay and US minorities earn 99% of non-minorities' pay. Citigroup will increase pay for those in need to close the gap and publish policies and goals to reduce the pay gap, following a shareholder proposal by Boston-based Arjuna Capital.

site_title: Shell ventures back into the solar sector
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has agreed to acquire a 43.86% stake in US solar company Silicon Ranch Corporation for up to $217 million. This move marks Shell's return to the solar sector, a decade after exiting it. The deal follows other investments by Shell in the renewable energy sector, including doubling its planned investment to $1-2 billion by 2020. Shell aims to leverage its expertise in wholesale power sales and expand its global New Energies footprint, as oil companies face pressure to adapt to the transition to lower carbon energy.

site_title: Benchmarking as a tool for determining pay
summary: Benchmarking, a common approach to determining pay, relies on matching an organization's practices to market standards. However, this method assumes an efficient market and reliable data, which may not always be the case. Over-reliance on benchmarking can lead to incorrect pay estimations due to unreliable data. This approach may not account for unique company circumstances or external factors affecting the market.

site_title: FSL Trust sells chemical tanker for US$13.8m to ease debt
summary: FSL Trust, a Singapore-based shipping company, sold a chemical tanker for US$13.8 million to ease debt. The sale will be used to repay an outstanding loan facility of US$165.6 million, reducing the debt by US$42.8 million. The company had previously applied for a scheme of arrangement to extend the loan facility, but the sale of the vessel will provide a more immediate solution. FSL Trust's net loss for the third quarter was US$21.7 million, driven by impairment charges on three tankers. The company's shares closed flat at 9.3 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: Tech first, innovation later for legal sector
summary: Singapore's Accelerate! program, a legaltech accelerator, aims to groom startups and incubate new business ideas by law firms. The program, part of the Future Law Innovation Programme, seeks to prepare the legal industry for tech disruption. Despite initial skepticism, experts believe that the program will lead to productivity gains, higher-value services, and lower legal fees. The program's success will depend on its ability to encourage tech adoption and focus on client-centric solutions, rather than just introducing new ideas.

site_title: Will Korea talks lead to US negotiations with Pyongyang?
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in's efforts to engage North Korea in talks have led to a possible US-Pyongyang dialogue. The inter-Korean Winter Olympics brought together the two nations, with US President Donald Trump postponing joint military exercises. However, Japan remains skeptical about the talks, and China's President Xi Jinping is also involved. North Korea's leader Kim Jong-un controls the agenda, and denuclearization is a key issue, but North Korea has rebuffed previous proposals. The US wants denuclearization, while North Korea seeks to confirm its status as a nuclear power. Experts believe that unconditional talks are the only realistic option, despite the risk of walking out.

site_title: S-E Asia plastics recyclers gearing up to benefit from China's ban
summary: South-east Asian countries, particularly Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand, are poised to benefit from China's ban on imports of plastic waste. The ban, which started in 2018, has led to a surge in plastic waste shipments to these countries, with imports rising by 117% in Thailand and 62% in Vietnam. Industry officials warn that unregulated plastic waste could lead to similar problems, emphasizing the need for tighter health and safety regulations. With limited recycling capacity globally, the shift to South-east Asia may exacerbate environmental issues, highlighting the need for increased recycling efforts worldwide.

site_title: Societe Generale to offer six high-risk derivatives on Jan 24
summary: Societe Generale will launch six daily leverage certificates (DLCs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on January 24, offering seven times long or short exposure to the MSCI Singapore, Hang Seng Index, and Hang Seng China Enterprises Index. This comes after Singapore's initial introduction of DLCs in July last year. The new DLCs are designed for high-risk investors, providing a leveraged return based on daily index performance, and will be available for qualified investors.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore property experts predict a year-on-year increase of 11,000-12,000 primary home sales and a 5% rise in private home prices in 2018. En-bloc sales and organic household formation will drive demand, while developers replenish their land inventory. Property stocks are undervalued, trading at a 33% discount to their revalued net asset values. Analysts maintain a "positive" outlook, citing robust land restocking and healthy affordability indicators, with UOL Group and City Developments as top picks.

site_title: Binding deal inked for new JB-Woodlands train service
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have signed a binding agreement for the RTS Link, a 4km-long MRT line between Woodlands and Johor Baru, set to begin operations by the end of 2024. The line will reduce travel time between the two countries to 30 minutes, compared to an hour via the existing shuttle service. The agreement also paves the way for the joint appointment of an operating company to manage the line, with fares to be set commercially and not regulated by the two governments.

site_title: Russian gold miner Polyus says deal with China's Fosun scrapped
summary: Russian gold miner Polyus has scrapped a deal to sell a 10% stake to a consortium led by China's Fosun International due to the arrest of Russian tycoon Suleiman Kerimov, whose family controls the company. The deal, valued at $887 million, was intended to increase Polyus's presence in the Asian market. The decision comes amid uncertainty over Polyus's prospects following Kerimov's arrest, and shares in the company fell 3.6% to a five-month low.

site_title: As economy builds steam, French deficit falls to nine-year low
summary: France's budget deficit fell to a nine-year low in 2017, reaching 67.8 billion euros, thanks to strong economic growth and increased tax revenues. The deficit reduction is seen as a positive step towards meeting the EU's three percent limit, with the country on track to meet the rule for the first time in a decade. Stronger-than-expected growth has boosted tax revenues, allowing the government to keep spending in check.

site_title: iFAST boosts stake in Indian associate company
summary: iFAST Corporation has increased its stake in associate company Pecuniam to 24.98% through a rights issue, subscribing for 3.58 million new shares at S$0.22 each, totaling S$788,000. The issue price represents a 10% premium to Pecuniam's share price. Pecuniam plans to use the net proceeds for working capital and business growth, aiming to tap into India's potential business opportunities. The transaction is expected to have no material impact on iFAST's earnings per share and net tangible assets.

site_title: Pandora braces for showdown with owners after market meltdown
summary: Pandora, a Danish jewelry maker, is preparing to face shareholders after a disappointing set of results led to a 10th of its market value being wiped off. The company's CEO and departing head of finance will host a capital markets day, where they will explain the decline in share price and profit growth being more modest through 2022. Hedge funds have bet against Pandora, and some have cashed in on profits, but others have joined the speculation, with about 12% of the company's stock being shorted. Pandora must convince investors that growth and profitability will develop as forecast.

site_title: Top Global terminates proposed purchase of South Bridge Road shophouses
summary: Top Global has terminated its proposed purchase of two shophouses along South Bridge Road in Singapore due to an unfulfilled change of use condition. The property was initially valued at S$26.5 million, but the termination will not impact the company's financial year-end results. Top Global received a refund of S$265,000 for the option deposit and shares closed 2.1% lower at 23 Singapore cents.

site_title: GM sees flat 2018 earnings, with pickups picking up in 2019
summary: General Motors (GM) expects earnings in 2018 to be flat compared to 2017, with profits expected to pick up in 2019 as its new high-margin pickup trucks hit the US market. The company's revamped line of trucks, including the Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra, is expected to boost sales. GM's shares rose over 3% in premarket trading after the announcement. The company also expects capital expenditure of around $8.5 billion in 2018, with $1 billion going towards self-driving car technology.

site_title: Hybrid IT: avoiding 'cloud cliff' by finding the right mix
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise is banking on hybrid IT adoption as companies face challenges in finding the right mix of private and public cloud solutions. The "cloud cliff" refers to the risks of over-reliance on public cloud, leading to performance, cost, or control issues. Analysts predict high demand for public cloud services, but also see opportunities for hybrid IT to meet business needs. 70% of enterprises will implement a multi-cloud strategy by 2019, with HPE's Cloud 28+ ecosystem and multi-cloud management tools like HPE OneSphere aiming to simplify the process. The right mix of hybrid infrastructure optimizes performance, security, compliance, and cost.

site_title: Big challenge for younger leaders to sustain strong Singapore-Malaysia relations
summary: Singapore and Malaysia leaders gave a positive report on bilateral relations, describing it as strong and in good order after their annual retreat. This was the eighth high-level meeting between Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Najib Razak, with chemistry and banter evident at the post-meeting press conference. Relations between the two neighbors appear to be stable, with no major issues mentioned. The meeting marked a positive note for the countries' partnership, with no negative comments or concerns raised about their cooperation.

site_title: Sysma Holdings unit awarded S$5m deal to build two landed homes for deputy chief executive
summary: Sysma Holdings unit, Sysma Construction, has been awarded a S$5 million contract to build two landed homes for deputy chief executive Sin Ee Wuen. The project will utilize the company's excess capacity and contribute positively to its financial results. Sysma's directors will convene an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval for the deal, citing that the project should not be turned down due to Mr. Sin's interest. The company believes the project will benefit the group despite Mr. Sin's involvement.

site_title: US: Stocks surge amid strong earnings reports
summary: US stocks surged on the first trading day of the holiday-shortened week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 0.8% to 26,018.07, the S&P 500 gaining 0.5% to 2,801.31, and the Nasdaq Composite Index increasing 0.7% to 7,315.13. Strong earnings reports from major companies, including Citigroup, General Motors, and United Health Group, contributed to the gains. However, General Electric's shares plummeted 4% due to a significant charge related to its legacy insurance business, with some analysts warning of potential inflation and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Relax manpower rules to help firms with digital transformation: KPMG
summary: KPMG has recommended that Singapore relax its manpower policies to help companies with digital transformation, particularly in tech segments like cybersecurity and data analytics. The firm suggests allowing foreign talent to be hired more easily and providing tax incentives for training local employees in these skills. This comes as companies face a shortage of tech talent despite efforts to ramp up digital transformation. The recommendations aim to boost the number of government incentives and tax changes to accelerate digitalization and innovation.

site_title: Home buyers should not be swayed by the fear of missing out
summary: Singapore's residential market has seen a recovery since 2017, with prices rising and demand increasing. The government's cooling measures, implemented in 2017, were deemed necessary to maintain a healthy market. Recent record prices paid by developers have lifted demand and prices, but the market remains stable. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has cautioned that investor sentiment can quickly turn into a runaway train, and buyers should not be swayed by the fear of missing out. With a surplus of 30,000 unoccupied homes, buyers should look at numbers rather than emotions when making decisions.

site_title: US report releases details on Trump properties
summary: US President Donald Trump's properties were used by 64 groups, including foreign governments and Republican candidates, during his first year in office, sparking "unprecedented conflicts of interest" concerns. Trump's global business empire was supposed to be transferred to a trust before taking office, but many ethics watchdogs say he should have divested assets. The Trump International Hotel in Washington was the most popular property, hosting events including fundraisers for Republican candidates and representatives from foreign governments like Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The issue remains unaddressed by the White House.

site_title: Nine-year threshold for independent directors back in focus
summary: The Singapore Corporate Governance Council proposes a nine-year threshold for independent directors to maintain their independence, with a hard cap or a two-tier shareholder vote to be considered. Currently, nearly 30% of independent directors have more than nine years of service. The Council also recommends simplifying the Code of Corporate Governance, enhancing board diversity, and making remuneration practices more transparent. The public consultation on the revised Code closes on March 15, with a revised version expected to be launched in the second half of 2018.

site_title: Indonesia exchange walkway collapse due to "building failure": initial report
summary: A walkway collapse at the Indonesian Stock Exchange building on Monday injured over 70 people, with some trapped beneath debris. A preliminary report by the public works ministry found that loose or corroded joints may have caused the collapse, triggered by a concentration of weight on the walkway. The structure, built in the late 1990s, was not designed to support the weight of nearly 100 university students visiting the exchange. The incident has raised concerns about safety standards in Indonesia, a country prone to natural and manmade disasters.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Acesian Partners' subsidiary, Active Building Technologies, has been ordered to pay Unitex Engineering S$1.56 million, plus interest, after a creditor was granted a final garnishee order. LCT Holdings expects to report a loss for the second quarter of 2018 due to increased maintenance costs. Hyflux has been ordered to pay US$2.7 million in interest to its unit, Hydrochem, following an arbitration dispute. First Reit has secured up to S$400 million in secured financing facilities from OCBC Bank to refinance loans, fund investments, and meet working capital requirements.

site_title: UK inflation eases for first time since June as Brexit woes wane
summary: UK inflation eased to 3.0% in December, the first drop since June, as Brexit woes subside. This decrease is a welcome relief for households struggling with the financial squeeze. The decline in inflation rate suggests that the financial strain on many households may be easing, although the UK economy shrunk for the second month in a row, adding to the economic challenges facing the country.

site_title: Maersk, IBM to launch blockchain-based platform for global trade
summary: Maersk and IBM are launching a blockchain-based platform for global trade, aiming to speed up trade and save billions of dollars. The platform will digitize the supply chain process for tens of millions of shipping containers globally. Maersk's chief commercial officer Vincent Clerc says the platform will bring standards across the ecosystem, reducing paperwork and bureaucracy. The joint venture has shown interest from customs and port authorities in the US, Singapore, and China, and is set to be available to the ocean shipping industry by mid-2018.

site_title: Balmoral Gardens to be launched for collective sale; owners expect more than S$92m
summary: Balmoral Gardens, a freehold residential land in prime district 10, will be launched for collective sale on Jan 17, 2018. Owners expect offers above S$92 million, with a land rate of S$1,872 per sq ft per plot ratio. The site has a 3,414.3 sqm area and a height limit of up to 12 storeys. Owners have given their approval for the sale, and the tender will close on Feb 7, 2018. The sale is expected to attract strong demand due to its strategic location near major MRT stations and recreational facilities.

site_title: China 2017 non-financial overseas investment falls 29.4% y-o-y
summary: China's non-financial overseas direct investment fell 29.4% in 2017 to $120.08 billion, as firms backed off speculative investments amid a government crackdown. Outbound direct investment rose 49% in December, driven by manufacturing and information sector investments. Investment in the Belt and Road initiative totaled $14.36 billion in 2017, accounting for 12% of total investments. Analysts expect an increase in overseas investment deals this year, citing the yuan's appreciation and potential for more foreign direct investment into China.

site_title: Google to expand cloud infrastructure with new regions, submarine cables
summary: Google plans to expand its cloud infrastructure with five new regions and three new submarine cables. The Netherlands and Montreal regions will open in the first quarter of 2018, followed by Los Angeles, Finland, and Hong Kong. The subsea cables, including Curie, Havfrue, and Hong Kong-Guam Cable, will be commissioned in 2019 and will carry over 90% of the world's data traffic. Google has invested $30 billion in infrastructure over the past three years and has direct investment in 11 cables, including those planned or under construction.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore implemented a revised Corporate Governance Code limiting director independence to 9 years. The country also signed a bilateral agreement with Malaysia for the JB-Woodlands RTS link. Payment performance of local firms improved in 2017, with 48.40% of prompt payments. KPMG recommended a focus on digital transformation in Budget 2018. Singapore households' inflation expectations rose to 2.97% in December. The country slipped to 8th most expensive place in Asia for mid-market home rentals.

images.alt_text: Stocks exposed to the climate-change theme in the Asia-Pacific had rallied about 60 per cent year to date.

site_title: SMJ International Holdings completes disposal of carpet business
summary: SMJ International Holdings has completed the disposal of its carpet business, SMJ Furnishings, as part of its plan to rebrand itself as a property company. The disposal was approved by shareholders in December and completed on January 16. The company has made board changes, including the resignation of its executive director and chief operating officer, and redesignation of executives. SMJ Furnishings ceased to be a unit of the company, allowing SMJ International Holdings to focus on its new direction.

site_title: LCT Holdings issues profit warning for Q2 2018
summary: LCT Holdings, formerly known as Longcheer Holdings, has issued a profit warning for Q2 2018, expecting a loss due to increased maintenance costs for an investment property in Xi'an, China. The company will disclose full details of its financial performance on or before February 14.

site_title: BOE flags it may unilaterally ease EU insurance rule
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) may unilaterally ease a European Union rule blamed for increasing insurance capital requirements, known as Solvency II. Deputy Governor Sam Woods stated that the calculation in Solvency II is incorrect, and the risk margin means £50 billion worth of insurance liabilities are tied up. The BOE has asked the EU to amend the risk margin, but progress has been slow. As the UK prepares to leave the EU in March 2019, the BOE may take action to address the issue.

site_title: Airbus condemns Brexit, Trump as double protectionist threat
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders criticized Brexit and US President Donald Trump's trade policies as a "double whammy" of protectionist threats to the aerospace industry. He stated that Brexit would weaken British industry and manufacturing, particularly in aerospace, increasing costs and reducing competitiveness. Airbus will try to mitigate the impact, but Enders believes the net result will be negative.

site_title: Japan sees little chance of oil slick from sunk tanker reaching its coast
summary: Japan believes there is little chance of an oil slick from the sunk Iranian tanker Sanchi reaching its shores, despite concerns over damage to the marine ecosystem. The tanker, carrying 136,000 tonnes of ultra-light oil, sank after several explosions weakened its hull, producing a large oil slick that spread over an area 13km x 11km. The slick is heading north, limiting its chances of reaching Japanese coasts, and experts worry about contamination of surrounding waters with the tanker's bunker fuel. The Japanese Coast Guard is monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: US opens London embassy after Trump snubs inauguration
summary: The US embassy in London officially opened on January 16, 2018, despite US President Donald Trump's decision not to attend due to the inauguration's cost and location. The embassy, which took 10 years and a $1 billion price tag to build, opened with a low-key ceremony, with embassy staff and police present. The move marked a significant development in US-UK relations and came after Trump's decision to skip the inauguration.

site_title: Bitcoin tumbles 20% as fears of cryptocurrency crackdown linger
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 20% to $11,940, its lowest level since late December, amid fears of a cryptocurrency crackdown. Speculators worry about regulatory measures, with South Korea's finance minister suggesting shutting down exchanges is an option. China's clampdown on cryptocurrency trading has also contributed to the selloff. Experts warn investors to be prepared to lose money in bitcoin, citing its volatile value and lack of acceptance as a currency.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust expands investment mandate to include Japan
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) has expanded its investment mandate to include Japan, allowing for portfolio diversification and long-term returns for unitholders. The trust manager cited Japan's large and well-established commercial property market as an attractive investment opportunity. This move builds on MGCCT's track record of operating high-quality income-generating commercial assets in Hong Kong, Beijing, and Shanghai. The expansion aims to enhance the manager's ability to provide balanced returns for unitholders.

site_title: Total disputed sum mediated at SMC crosses record S$2.7b mark in 2017
summary: The Singapore Mediation Centre (SMC) reported a record high of over S$2.7 billion in disputed sums mediated in 2017, with 538 matters filed and 465 resolved. This represents an 8% increase from 2016 and a 15% increase from the previous year. The centre attributes its growth to increased acceptance of mediation as a more affordable, flexible, and accessible option. Most cases mediated are commercial in nature, with construction and company disputes being the most common. SMC aims to build on its experience to become a trusted partner for businesses resolving high-value, complex matters.

site_title: UK inflation falls back for first time since June as Brexit hit wanes
summary: UK inflation fell to 3% in December, its first decline since June, as the Brexit-related financial squeeze on households may ease. The drop was attributed to slower growth in food prices and airline fares. However, factory gate prices rose, contradicting predictions of a fall. The Bank of England expects inflation to fall to 2% by the end of 2019, but private economists think it could subside faster.

site_title: Siemens' Healthineers in cost-cutting drive before IPO
summary: Siemens Healthineers, the medical imaging and diagnostics division of Siemens, is implementing a cost-cutting drive to address modest earnings growth before its planned IPO in March, valued at around 40 billion euros. The company aims to achieve 240 million euros in annual cost savings and 17-18% adjusted operating profit margin for 2018. Siemens expects 3-4% comparable revenue growth and organic revenue growth to speed up to 4-6% in the medium term. The unit will operate independently but remain part of the parent group in the long term.

site_title: Malaysian farmers protest Europe's push to curb palm oil imports
summary: Malaysian palm oil farmers protest the European Union's plan to curb palm oil imports, citing potential job losses and decreased income. The EU's move aims to reduce deforestation and promote sustainable biofuels. Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak and Indonesian President Joko Widodo have called the move discriminatory, while farmers like Aliasak Ambia fear their livelihoods will be threatened if palm oil prices drop. The EU Parliament is reviewing amendments to biofuel targets, which will be voted on soon.

site_title: EU's 'hearts are still open' to Brexit reversal: Tusk
summary: European Union President Donald Tusk said the EU's "hearts are still open" to a potential Brexit reversal if the UK changes its mind about leaving. This comes as talk of a second EU referendum on membership gains momentum. Tusk warned that Brexit will become a reality with negative consequences in March 2020 if the UK sticks to its decision to leave.

site_title: FSL Trust sells chemical tanker for US$13.8 million to repay debt
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) has sold a chemical tanker, the FSL Tokyo, for US$13.8 million to repay an outstanding loan facility of US$165.6 million. The sale will reduce debt by US$138 million, from US$425 million in June 2013. The trustee-manager believes this will be a significant reduction and will continue to pursue refinancing solutions. The trust remains in a substantial net equity position, and operations will continue normally.

site_title: SFMA, IE Singapore help local SMEs enter Indonesia's top supermarkets
summary: Over 100 Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) will feature their products in top Indonesian supermarkets from December 2017 to 2018 through the Tasty Singapore Food Aisle project, a joint initiative by IE Singapore and the Singapore Food Manufacturers' Association (SFMA). The project, now in its third run, allows participating SMEs to collectively sell their products under a common Singapore branding. Since its first run in 2015, 19 Singapore companies have secured permanent listings in Indonesian supermarket chains, taking advantage of the country's large domestic market and rising middle class.

site_title: McDonald's sets recycling goals for packaging, restaurants
summary: McDonald's sets ambitious recycling goals, aiming to achieve 100% of packaging from renewable, recycled, or certified sources by 2025. The company will also make recycling available in all its restaurants by 2025, up from around 10% today. This move follows the company's efforts to eliminate foam packaging from its global supply chain by the end of this year. McDonald's will work with industry experts and environmental groups to improve packaging designs and create new recycling programs, with the potential to have a transformative impact on the environment and the bottom line.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.12 points to 1,826.03 on Tuesday, driven by higher shares. Volume reached 6.2 billion shares worth RM3.31 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 765-324.

site_title: UMS Holdings buys 7.5% stake in JEP Holdings for S$5.7m
summary: UMS Holdings has acquired a 7.48% stake in JEP Holdings for S$5.7 million, purchasing 109 million shares on the open market. The investment comes after JEP said an unrelated party was in talks to acquire a controlling interest in the company, which could result in the third party holding at least 15% of the company. The transaction was funded by internal resources and did not involve any directors or substantial shareholders. UMS' investment in JEP, a precision machining company, marks a significant move into the sector.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, BofA lead in Asia equity trading: Greenwich
summary: Morgan Stanley and Bank of America Merrill Lynch led in Asia equity trading share in 2017, according to a report by Greenwich Associates. Citigroup and Credit Suisse tied in third place, while Citic Securities unit CLSA and UBS Group were in fifth spot. The surge in market valuations and rebound in activity boosted brokerages in the region, but EU regulations MiFID II may make 2018 a challenging year. The report was based on interviews with 256 Asian equity fund managers and analysts, and 111 trading desks.

site_title: Tencent-backed video site is said to seek US$17b valuation
summary: A Tencent-backed video site is reportedly seeking a $17 billion valuation. This comes as the video site continues to expand its user base and develop its content offerings. Meanwhile, other tech companies such as NIE, Amazon Web Services, and BHP have established AI-focused innovation hubs to foster research and development in the field.

site_title: What traders are watching during this earnings season in Europe
summary: European corporate profits are expected to continue their momentum in the fourth-quarter earnings season, with analysts predicting 10% profit growth at Stoxx Europe 600 Index members. However, investors are cautious due to a rising euro, which could cap sales surprises for exporters. Key themes to watch include US tax reform, with expected positive readacross for the car sector, and valuation multiples, which are seen as relatively modest. Strategists are also eyeing cyclical stocks and value sectors, which are expected to outperform in the coming months.

site_title: Macron set to pressure Britain over Calais migrant crisis
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to pressure Britain to contribute more to addressing the migrant crisis in Calais, where hundreds of migrants are massed, awaiting passage to Britain. Macron will also defend his government's proposals to stem the flow of people into France, which include speeding up asylum application processing and increasing expulsions of those turned down. The 2003 agreement between Britain and France, known as the Le Touquet accord, is under renegotiation, with Macron seeking increased British funding and refugee intake.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to pressure Britain to contribute more to dealing with migrants trying to cross the Channel from Calais on Tuesday as he visits the northern port which has long been a magnet for asylum seekers.

site_title: Russian gold miner Polyus says Fosun stake deal scrapped
summary: Russia's largest gold miner Polyus has scrapped plans to sell a 10% stake to a consortium led by China's Fosun International due to a condition not being met. The deal, valued at $887 million, was set to be the Chinese group's first Russian deal. The collapse marks a setback for Fosun, which has scaled back its foreign ambitions amid increased scrutiny from Beijing. Polyus shares fell 3.6% to a five-month low following the news, with the company citing Mr. Kerimov's arrest as a factor in the decision.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees likelihood crude prices will exceed forecasts
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts crude oil prices will exceed forecasts due to rising demand and strong OPEC compliance. The bank forecasts Brent and West Texas Intermediate average prices at US$62 and US$57.5 per barrel for 2018. Crude oil prices have risen 15% since early December, driven by OPEC's production cuts and healthy demand. Goldman expects deferred prices to decline in 2019, but spot prices may remain stable due to lower inventories.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets stable at open
summary: Europe's leading stock markets remained stable at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 2 points to 7,766.83, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.2% and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: Whisky and waders as fishermen welcome salmon season in Scotland
summary: In Scotland, the salmon fishing season officially began on January 15, 2018, with a traditional ceremony on the River Tay in Kenmore. A whisky-based blessing and a parade of pipers marked the start of the season, which runs until October 15. Despite the ceremony, only one salmon was caught by the end of the day, but participants emphasized the atmosphere and experience were the highlights of the event. The salmon season varies by river, with the Tay's running until October 15 and others running until November 30.

site_title: US pickups craze all about toughness, luxury
summary: General Motors revamped the Chevrolet Silverado pickup truck to give it a "brutal look" with a bulging hood, increased height, and more curves. The truck is part of an army of pickups unveiled at the Detroit Auto Show, driven by strong US demand for the vehicles. Pickups have been a cornerstone for Detroit since cheaper gas prices, and some see a political dimension to the trend, particularly in rural areas that voted for Donald Trump. Luxury pickups are also gaining popularity, with models like the Ram Limited and Chevrolet Silverado High Country offering high-end amenities.

site_title: Singapore slips to 8th most expensive place in Asia for mid-market home rentals
summary: Singapore has dropped to 8th most expensive place in Asia for mid-market home rentals, according to a survey by ECA International. The country's economic growth slowdown and reduced expatriate assignments have led to an oversupply of higher-end properties, driving down average rent levels. This marks a decline from its 4th ranking in 2016. Hong Kong remains the most expensive location, with an average rent of US$10,461 per month for a three-bedroom apartment.

site_title: Citi expands China desk in Singapore
summary: Citi has expanded its China desk in Singapore, adding a second desk to support clients using Singapore as an access point into the ASEAN region. The move follows a significant increase in China's foreign direct investments into ASEAN, reaching over $9 billion in 2016. The new desk will offer banking solutions, advisory services, and understanding of local operating and regulatory environments. This expansion is part of Citi's overall growth in its China business, with eight other China desks operating outside of Singapore.

site_title: When picking crypto winners, don't think long term
summary: Crypto investors should focus on short-term outcomes rather than long-term potential, as governments are unlikely to either crush or dominate cryptocurrencies. Instead, they may regulate and tax existing ones, create their own, or exploit certain types of cryptocurrencies. Dark Web coins may thrive in weak government scenarios, while mainstream coins like Bitcoin and Ethereum could find value in any likely government scenario. The author believes that cryptocurrencies will survive on the margins of the regulated financial system and will continue to have demand for cross-border independent cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Hyflux unit to be paid US$2.7 million in interest following arbitration dispute
summary: Hyflux announced that SEPCOIII Electric Power Construction Corporation has been ordered to pay US$2.7 million in interest to its unit Hydrochem following an arbitration dispute. This payment, along with additional costs of S$4.2 million for arbitration, brings the total amount SEPCOIII must pay to US$16.1 million, as previously ordered in an interim award in September last year.

site_title: Yamada Green Resources names new chief financial officer
summary: Yamada Green Resources has appointed Zhou Chen as its new chief financial officer, effective January 12. Zhou's previous roles include chief treasury officer at China Graphene Group and chief financial officer at Asia Fashion Holdings. This comes after Chew Kim Kuan resigned to pursue personal interests, leaving a vacancy in the position.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post record close
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a record close on Tuesday, driven by mainland Chinese investors and global economic optimism. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.81% to 31,904.75, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also gained. This surge follows a worldwide rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff threats. The positive trend is attributed to a surge in global economic optimism.

site_title: Indonesia Stock Exchange walkway collapse: Affected tower remains closed as probe continues
summary: A walkway in the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) twin-tower building in Jakarta collapsed on Monday, injuring over 70 people. Tower 2, where the incident occurred, remains closed as a probe continues. The police are investigating the collapse, and experts say it's too early to determine the cause. The remaining walkway on the mezzanine floor may also be affected, requiring reinforcements to prevent another collapse.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.39% on Tuesday at a high of 3,550.21
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.39% on Tuesday, reaching a high of 3,550.21, narrowly beating the "magic number" of 3,549.85 set in 2015. The Straits Times Index climbed 13.8 points, driven by gains from local banks OCBC Bank and Keppel Corporation, as well as manufacturer JEP Holdings. Almost 2.12 billion shares were traded, with gainers outpacing losers 272 to 182.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise; won stays at 3-year high on dollar weakness
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.72% on Tuesday, reaching 2,521.74, while the Korean won stayed at a 3-year high of 1,062.7 per dollar due to dollar weakness. The won was up 0.05% in offshore trading, and foreign investors were net buyers of 276,843 million won worth of shares. The KOSPI is up 1.5% this year, and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.53%.

site_title: EU toughens demands on UK for Brexit transition in draft
summary: The European Union has revised draft guidelines for the UK's post-Brexit transition period, increasing demands on the UK. The revised guidelines, seen by Bloomberg, call for more rights for EU citizens, including the ability to remain in the UK indefinitely if they arrived before the end of 2020. The UK will not be able to apply new immigration rules to these individuals during the transition period. The revised guidelines will likely be discussed in the EU-UK withdrawal agreement negotiations.

site_title: Tencent cracks down on cheats in world's top-selling video game
summary: Tencent Holdings has cracked down on cheats in PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds (PUBG), teaming up with Chinese police to root out underground cheat software rings. At least 30 cases have been uncovered and 120 people arrested, with those convicted facing jail time. Tencent aims to clean up the game ahead of its debut in China, which accounts for over half of the game's 27 million users, to prevent cheating from driving away new users and undermining growth. The crackdown is part of a broader effort to create a fair playing field and prevent cheating software from spreading.

site_title: Thailand just got the most tourists ever as boom continues
summary: Thailand has set a record for the most tourists ever, with 3.5 million foreign visitors in December, a 16% increase from the previous year. The Tourism Ministry predicts another record high in January, targeting 37 million visitors and 3 trillion baht in revenue in 2018. This boom is attributed to economic growth and a strengthened currency, but also raises concerns about strain on infrastructure and competitiveness in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Southeast Asian plastic recyclers hope to clean up after China ban
summary: Southeast Asian plastic recyclers are poised to benefit from China's ban on imports of plastic waste, which has left the US and Britain scrambling to find alternative places to send their rubbish. Industry officials say the shift will increase recycling capacities in the US and Britain, but may still not be enough to address growing stockpiles of plastic waste. Southeast Asian countries, such as Malaysia, Vietnam, and Indonesia, are expected to take on the role of processing plastic waste, with some already seeing a rise in imports. However, industry officials warn that unregulated plastic waste could lead to similar problems as those experienced in China, highlighting the need for stronger environmental controls.

site_title: Lindt & Spruengli 2017 sales rise 4.8 per cent
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Lindt & Spruengli reported a 4.8% increase in 2017 annual sales in Swiss francs, outperforming the market in the premium price segment. Organic sales rose 3.7%, below expectations, but the company maintained its outlook of 6-8% organic sales growth and increasing margins. The company's North American market remained tough, with sales falling 1.6%, while Europe and the rest of the world saw growth of 6.2% and 12.4%, respectively. Lindt expanded its retail outlets, opening 50 new stores last year.

site_title: This year looks different for US inflation as Wall St braces
summary: US inflation may stage a comeback in 2018, driven by a strong economy, low unemployment, and rising wages. The Federal Reserve's preferred index, excluding volatile fuel and food, stood at 1.5% in November, near the 2% target. Investors are taking notice, with yields on the two-year US Treasury note hitting 2% for the first time since 2008. Economists, including Harvard University's Kenneth Rogoff, predict inflation will approach or breach the 2% target, potentially leading to faster interest rate hikes.

site_title: Two Singapore Airbnb hosts to plead guilty to illegal letting charges, says lawyer
summary: Two Singapore Airbnb hosts are expected to plead guilty to charges related to unauthorized short-term letting of four apartments. The hosts face fines of up to S$200,000 per offense under Singapore's Planning Act.
