summary: Adidas aims to increase its US market share to 15-20% from around 10%, with a goal to double its current market presence. The company plans to expand its logistics capacity to address supply bottlenecks and build a new warehouse facility in Germany to scale up its e-commerce business. Adidas expects its Reebok brand to return to growth in the US this year, despite not yet making a profit. The company is taking market share from Nike in North America and China, and hopes the launch of new team kits before the soccer World Cup will boost sales in Europe.

site_title: Stricken tanker leaves large oil slick in East China Sea
summary: A burning Iranian oil tanker, Sanchi, sank in the East China Sea on Sunday, producing a large oil slick 13km x 11km in area, with concerns over damage to the marine ecosystem. The tanker, carrying 136,000 tonnes of ultra-light oil, had collided with another vessel on January 6 and sank after several explosions weakened its hull. Crew members are presumed dead, with rescue efforts reduced to "normal" operations. Experts warn the sinking may be more damaging to the ecosystem than letting the oil burn off, as it will expel toxic condensate and bunker fuel into the surrounding waters.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager waiting for approval for appointment of new CEO candidate
summary: The manager of Sabana Reit has identified a new CEO candidate and submitted an application to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for approval. The application is pending, following discussions with ESR Funds Management that have since stopped. The current CEO, Kevin Xayaraj, tendered his resignation last year after unitholders revolted over the Reit's proposed acquisition of a Changi South property. A new third independent director has also been identified, awaiting MAS approval. The strategic review will cease once the new CEO and director are appointed.

site_title: ASL Marine injects 54 million rupees into India unit
summary: ASL Marine Holdings has injected 54 million Indian rupees (S$1.1 million) into its wholly owned unit, Vosta LMG India, through the subscription of 4,386 additional equity shares. The capital injection will be used for chartering operations in India and is not expected to impact the group's financials. ASL Marine's shares rose 12.2% following the announcement.

site_title: Colour returns to Hollywood's red carpets but Time's Up still strong
summary: Actresses at the Critics Choice Awards and Golden Globes returned to red carpet glamour with a burst of colour after wearing black dresses to protest sexual harassment, as part of the Time's Up campaign. The message of unity and solidarity will continue throughout Hollywood's awards season, with some actresses opting for bold tones like pale pink and others sticking to black. The trend may influence upcoming ceremonies and designers' autumn/winter 2018 collections.

site_title: China Fibretech narrows loss to 1.1m yuan in Q3
summary: China Fibretech, a dye maker, narrowed its loss to 1.1 million yuan (S$225,900) in Q3 2017, a 99.8% improvement from the same period a year earlier. Revenue dropped 25.9% to 21.8 million yuan, but net loss for the nine months to Sept 30 was 2.2 million yuan. The company cited a production shutdown and rising costs as factors. Despite a challenging outlook, China Fibretech reported a net asset value per share of 1.95 yuan.

site_title: Third party in exploratory talks to acquire controlling interest, JEP Holdings responds to SGX query
summary: A third party is in exploratory talks with JEP Holdings' executive directors to acquire a controlling interest in the precision machining company. The heavy trading in its shares on Monday, with a volume of 193.8 million shares, may be linked to these talks. The stock closed 7% higher at 6.1 Singapore cents. JEP Holdings attributed the trading activity to the talks, but no further details were provided.

site_title: UK's Johnson fears "waste of time" watered-down Brexit: report
summary: UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson has expressed concerns that a potential Brexit deal could leave Britain subordinate to Brussels, making the 2016 EU referendum a "total waste of time". Johnson, a prominent pro-Brexit supporter, reportedly told friends he'd rather the UK stay in the EU than leave under a deal that would limit its sovereignty. This criticism comes as Prime Minister Theresa May seeks a two-year transition period, which some Brexit advocates argue could result in Britain remaining subject to EU rules.

site_title: Temasek, Kuehne + Nagel to invest in early-stage logistics tech firms
summary: Temasek Holdings and Kuehne + Nagel have signed a memorandum of understanding to invest in early-stage logistics and supply chain technology firms, including those focused on blockchain, Big Data, and artificial intelligence. The joint venture will be 50-50, with Temasek and Kuehne + Nagel combining their expertise to fund companies that can transform traditional logistics business models and improve efficiency. The move aims to capitalize on the growth of technology in the logistics sector and create a win-win situation for all parties involved.

site_title: China is said to escalate crackdown on cryptocurrency trading
summary: China escalates its crackdown on cryptocurrency trading, targeting online platforms and mobile apps that offer exchange-like services. Authorities plan to block domestic access to domestic and offshore platforms, and target individuals and companies providing market-making, settlement, and clearing services. This move is part of a global effort to curb excessive speculation, money laundering, and tax evasion. China was previously the most active market for bitcoin trading but is now looking to curb the industry, with some miners seeking alternative locations.

site_title: Silverlake sells two million shares in Global InfoTech Co for 23.6 million yuan
summary: Silverlake Axis has sold 2 million shares of Global InfoTech Co (GIT) for 23.6 million yuan (S$4.8 million) at 11.75 yuan apiece. This sale follows an earlier announcement of plans to sell up to 19 million shares, with the company now holding 39.59 million remaining shares. Silverlake intends to use the proceeds for general working capital purposes, special dividends, or other business opportunities. The sale was carried out on January 11, and the weighted average price of GIT's shares used for the calculation was 10.43 yuan per share on January 10.

site_title: Xi's economic adviser Liu He to represent China at Davos forum
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's top economic adviser, Liu He, will represent China at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, from January 22-25. Liu He's elevation to the Communist Party's 25-member Politburo shows his rise to top economic policy-making ranks. The meeting, where US President Donald Trump will attend, is expected to focus on globalism and trade. Liu He's presence highlights China's commitment to globalisation and its willingness to engage in economic discussions, despite Trump's "America First" agenda.

site_title: Mining gear maker Metso warns on profit, shares drop
summary: Metso, a Finnish mining equipment maker, reported weaker-than-expected quarterly sales and earnings, causing its shares to drop over 10% due to a higher-than-expected share of equipment sales compared to services sales. The company's core profit remained flat at around 64 million euros, below market consensus. Metso's CEO, Nico Delvaux, is leaving the company, adding to investors' concerns over the company's performance. Analysts attribute the decline to project execution problems and a lack of momentum in the business.

site_title: China Fibretech narrows loss to 1.1 million yuan for Q3 2017
summary: China Fibretech, a dye maker, reported a narrower loss of 1.1 million yuan (S$225,846) for Q3 2017, down 99.8% from the same period last year. Revenue fell 25.9% to 5.6 million yuan, and gross profit shrank to 2.5 million yuan. The company cited a production shutdown and rising costs as factors contributing to the decline. Despite the loss, China Fibretech expects a challenging 2017 for its dyeing business.

site_title: China's WeChat plans to resurrect tipping button after agreement with Apple
summary: China's WeChat is set to reintroduce its tipping feature after reaching an agreement with Apple. The feature, which allows users to send cash to content creators, was removed from iOS devices last year due to a dispute over app-store rules. The new tipping button will be tweaked to direct payments to individual authors instead of public account holders. The feature's reintroduction comes as WeChat continues to grow, with nearly 1 billion users and 580,000 mini-programmes.

site_title: No Brexit deal would cause 8.5% drop in Scotland GDP: study
summary: Scotland's economy would contract by 8.5% by 2030 if Britain leaves the EU without a deal, according to a study by Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon. This compares to 6.1% if a free trade accord is signed and 2.7% if the UK joins the European Economic Area. Sturgeon urged the UK government to reconsider its stance on single market membership, which Prime Minister Theresa May has ruled out due to its condition of free movement of people. The study's findings serve as "compelling" evidence for Scotland to remain in the single market.

site_title: China's JD.com targets US$2b fundraising at logistics unit: sources
summary: China's e-commerce firm JD.com is raising US$2 billion for its logistics unit, JD Logistics, valued at around US$10 billion. The fundraising, led by Hillhouse Capital Group and Sequoia Capital China, aims to support JD Logistics' global expansion and offer services to third-party clients. The move is part of JD.com's efforts to bulk up its logistics business and compete with Alibaba's Cainiao network. The logistics unit, set up in April, will have some independence and allow JD.com to offer services to clients.

site_title: Container volumes up 9.8% at PSA ports globally in 2017
summary: PSA International reported a 9.8% year-over-year increase in global container volumes to 74.2 million TEUs in 2017. Its Singapore terminals handled 33.35 million TEUs, a 9% rise, while terminals outside Singapore saw a 10.4% increase to 40.89 million TEUs. The company attributed the growth to a recovering global economy, despite the shipping industry facing challenges. PSA Group CEO Tan Chong Meng noted the industry's transformation due to new technologies and trade dynamics, and the company's preparedness for this change.

site_title: HG Metal Manufacturing unit renews lease at 28 Jalan Buroh
summary: HG Metal Manufacturing has renewed its lease at 28 Jalan Buroh for a further 20 years, starting from August 1, 2019. The lease renewal, accepted by Oriental Metals, will allow for a three-year development period to invest in building and plant construction. The investment will be financed internally and through external borrowings, with no material impact on the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share. HG Metal Manufacturing's shares closed 1.2% higher at 43 Singapore cents after the announcement.

site_title: Toymaker Lego teams up with Chinese internet giant Tencent
summary: Lego, a Danish toymaker, has partnered with Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings Ltd to develop online games and a social network for Chinese children. The partnership aims to create a safe online environment with content tailored for young Chinese learners. Lego plans to develop a Lego video zone on Tencent's platform, licensed games, and a joint social network. This move follows Lego's growth in the Chinese market, where sales have increased 25-30% in 2016. The partnership is part of Lego's efforts to compete with Barbie maker Mattel and Hasbro in the $31 billion toys and games market in China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.24 points to 1,825.91 on Monday, with a trading volume of 5.4 billion lots worth RM3.3 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 685 to 378.

site_title: Montblanc expands sports watches in Rolex, Breitling price range
summary: Montblanc is expanding its sports watch line to the 4,000- to 6,000-euro price range, targeting a segment previously dominated by Rolex and Breitling. The brand aims to offer better value and compete in a market where watchmakers are cutting prices by up to 30%. Montblanc's entry into sports watches may also give it an advantage in the US market, where 80% of watches are in this segment. The brand is introducing new Timewalker sports watches with a mountain-climbing theme this year.

site_title: US: Markets closed, trading resumes 16 Jan
summary: US markets are closed today due to Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Trading will resume on January 16. Despite US tariff threats, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, with stocks rallying ahead of the US-EU trade talks. Other market news includes a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, a mandatory offer for PSC shares, and a $220 million funding round for eSIM platform Airalo.

site_title: Sanofi to reimburse Philippines for unused dengue vaccine
summary: Sanofi to reimburse the Philippine government for unused doses of the anti-dengue vaccine Dengvaxia, valued at around $10 million, following a health concerns suspension. The refund is unrelated to safety issues and aims to improve ties with the Philippine health department, which is investigating deaths linked to the vaccine. The vaccine's use was halted after regulators warned it could worsen symptoms in people who contracted the disease for the first time.

site_title: H&M condemns racism after 'monkey' ad sparks protests in Africa
summary: H&M has apologized and condemned racism after a controversial ad featuring a black child modeling a hoodie with a racist text sparked protests in South Africa. The company temporarily closed its stores in the country after outlets were vandalized. H&M agreed with those who were upset by the image and pulled the garment from its stores. The company stated that racism and bias are unacceptable and will re-open its stores "as soon as the situation is safe again." The incident led to a social media storm and the cancellation of a collaboration with Canadian artist The Weeknd.

site_title: Hedge funds fatten returns with exotic bets on cheese, maize
summary: Hedge funds are capitalizing on "exotic" assets such as cheese, maize, and sunflower seeds, achieving higher returns than traditional investments. Trend-following strategies, which involve betting on future price movements, yielded average gains of 1.9% in mainstream markets, but funds that focused on these alternative assets recorded average gains of 10.6%. The success of these strategies is attracting new entrants, but risks include liquidity crunches and the need for extensive research, prompting fund managers to cap fund sizes and restrict client investments.

site_title: Russia's Lavrov lashes out at US at annual press conference
summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov criticized the US at his annual press conference, accusing Washington of issuing ultimatums and failing to recognize the emerging multipolar world. Lavrov said US President Donald Trump's stance on the Iran nuclear deal was "questionable and unscrupulous," and that the US resorts to questionable methods to contain its competitors. He also stated that US actions in 2017 "seriously aggravated" tensions worldwide, including in North Korea, and that the current administration is more assertive than under Barack Obama.

site_title: Airbus overtakes Boeing, says could halt A380 programme
summary: Airbus surpassed Boeing in aircraft orders for 2017, booking 1,109 orders and 718 deliveries, compared to Boeing's 912 orders and 763 deliveries. Airbus warned it may halt the A380 program if Emirates, its main customer, doesn't place another order. The company delivered 12 A380s in 2018, with plans to reduce production. Despite this, Airbus delivered a record 718 aircraft in 2017, and its backlog stands at 7,265 aircraft valued at $1.059 trillion.

site_title: Pope Francis sets off on trip to Chile and Peru
summary: Pope Francis departed for a 7-day Latin American trip to Chile and Peru, marking his 22nd foreign visit. The 81-year-old Argentine pontiff faces challenges, including protests over sex abuse scandals in Chile and indigenous groups' demands for land restitution in both countries. The trip coincides with a country in Peru experiencing high seismic activity, and the pontiff must tread carefully amidst the country's recent protests over the early release of former president Alberto Fujimori.

site_title: One of the biggest diamonds in history has just been found
summary: A 910-carat diamond, one of the largest in history, has been discovered in Lesotho, Africa, by mining company Gem Diamonds. The D-colour Type IIa diamond is valued for its rarity and quality, with a price tag to match. It's the fifth-largest diamond ever found, following notable discoveries like the 603-carat Lesotho Promise.

site_title: JLL says it could now have world's largest 3D-enabled property portfolio
summary: Real estate consultancy JLL has partnered with Indian startup Foyr to create the world's largest 3D-enabled property portfolio. Foyr's technology allows for the creation of 3D experiences and virtual fit-out of commercial interiors. JLL led a US$3.8 million funding round for Foyr, which has already integrated its technology with JLL's tools across Asia-Pacific markets. This partnership enables clients to efficiently plan office spaces through advanced visualisation technologies, potentially revolutionizing the industry.

site_title: Mercator resumes coal operations at Indonesian mining site
summary: MUMBAI-BASED Mercator, a coal mining company, has resumed operations at its Indonesian site after being disrupted due to changes in the management team. The new management team aims to reach optimal levels by March this year. Mercator was placed under judicial management in 2016 following an application by its creditor HSH Nordbank. The company's coal operations had been halted for a significant part of the third quarter last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon warns of a "Goldilocks economy" with three "bears" of risk, advising investors to watch. Developers sold 23% more private homes and ECs in 2017, with Singapore shares closing up 0.45% on Monday. Singapore Airlines' new A380 aircraft will be introduced in London and Hong Kong, while Temasek invests in early-stage logistics tech firms. A suspect in the 2016 Standard Chartered Bank robbery case has been detained by British authorities, with Singapore working on extradition.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets, including the FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40, remained steady at the open on Monday, with no significant changes reported. This follows a similar trend on Friday, where the markets were flat. The steady performance is attributed to the lack of major economic news and the focus on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks in year's first loss after record run
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced their first loss in 2018 after a record 14-gain streak, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.23% to 31,338.87. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 0.54% and 1.8%, respectively. The losses came amid a global stock market downturn, with US stocks also experiencing losses. The decline in Hong Kong stocks marked the end of a strong run, which had seen the Hang Seng Index approach its record high.

site_title: London, Hong Kong next in line to receive SIA's new A380 cabin products
summary: Singapore Airlines' new Airbus A380 aircraft featuring refreshed Suites and Business Class products will begin serving London and Hong Kong from February. The new A380s will operate as SQ322 (London-Singapore) and SQ860 (Singapore-Hong Kong) on select days. The upgraded cabin products were debuted in Sydney in December and will be rolled out on five new A380s, with 14 other aircraft to be retrofitted. The upgrade is part of a US$850 million investment to improve the airline's competitiveness amid stiff competition.

site_title: Euro-area economic boom to roll on after strong start to 2018
summary: Europe's economic boom continues, with economists raising their 2018 growth forecast to 2.2%, close to a decade-high 2.4%. The eurozone's core economies, including Germany and France, are driving the growth, and the European Central Bank is considering ending crisis-era stimulus. The ECB sees an "increasingly self-sustaining" expansion and predicts consumer-price growth averaging 1.5% this year, with no interest-rate increases until 2019. The euro is up 1.6% this year, but risks could weigh on growth and suppress headline inflation.

site_title: AA Reit to divest factory building in Soon Lee Road for S$8.17 million
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) is divesting a factory building in Jurong Industrial Estate for S$8.17 million, representing a 28% premium over the property's valuation of S$6.4 million. The sale was agreed upon on January 12 through its trustee HSBC Institutional Trust Services (Singapore).

site_title: Singapore shares close up by 0.45% on Monday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.45% on Monday, advancing to 3,536.41, driven by gains from Keppel Corporation and City Developments Ltd. JEP Holdings surged 7.02% after reaching the top of the actives list, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also increased following interest rate hikes. However, Singtel closed flat despite high trading volume. The Straits Times Index finished with 2.25 billion shares worth S$1.06 billion changing hands, with losers beating out gainers 238 to 206.

site_title: Indonesia to swear in new parliament speaker after huge graft case
summary: Indonesia's parliament will swear in Bambang Soesatyo as its new speaker on Monday, replacing Setya Novanto who was indicted in a $170 million graft scandal. Soesatyo, a long-time Golkar member, has criticized President Joko Widodo's government, highlighting bureaucratic inefficiency and foreign influences. His appointment could lead to tougher negotiations for the president's government as it pushes through reforms before 2019 elections. Analysts say Soesatyo's support is not automatic, and the president must ensure Golkar remains loyal.

site_title: French telcos to spend 3b euros to plug network gaps
summary: France's major mobile telephone operators, Orange, SFR, Bouygues Telecom, and Free Mobile, will invest 3 billion euros by 2020 to upgrade their 4G networks, covering 30,000 km of rail tracks and 10,000 towns and villages. The investment, led by the government, aims to address coverage gaps and improve the network. The state will not contribute financially, but will instead extend the operators' spectrum licenses. This move aims to boost coverage, particularly in rural areas, and address complaints about the inferior network compared to some African countries.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin afternoon trading on higher ground; STI at 3,533.11
summary: Singapore stocks opened Monday's afternoon trading on a positive note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,533.11, up 0.36% or 12.55 points. The index was marginally down from its pre-break level, with 198 gainers beating 173 losers. DBS Group Holdings and Keppel Corp led the gains, while JEP Holdings fell 12.3%. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: London home-sellers cut prices by most since 2009: Rightmove
summary: London home-sellers cut prices by 3.5% since 2009, the largest drop since the financial crisis, amid a double hit from higher purchase taxes and Brexit. Despite this, most of Britain saw year-on-year price increases of 4% or more. Home ownership remains out of reach for many London buyers, with initial mortgage repayments representing over 60% of average take-home pay. Finance minister Philip Hammond's decision to scrap purchase taxes for first-time buyers helped offset the slowdown.

site_title: Indonesia's December trade swings to a deficit on weak exports
summary: Indonesia posted a trade deficit of $270 million in December, contrary to market expectations of a surplus. Exports rose 6.93% in December, below the 12.70% growth expected, due to a slowdown in automotive parts and vegetable oil shipments. Imports grew 17.83% in December, higher than expected. The country's overall exports grew 16.22% last year, while imports grew 16.66%. This marks the first trade deficit in 11 months, following a surplus in November.

site_title: Metro Christmas sales solid in Germany, down in Russia
summary: Metro, a German retailer, reported flat sales in the Christmas quarter, with a 0.2% increase in overall sales to €10.1 billion. Like-for-like sales rose 0.8%, driven by a 2% increase in Germany's wholesale business, but declined 9% in Russia. The company's Real hypermarkets reported flat sales after a brand revamp, and its delivery business and ecommerce sales continued to grow. Despite a challenging market, Metro forecasts stronger profitability due to its separation from Ceconomy last July and expects sales growth of at least 1.1%.

site_title: Mizuho Securities head Sakai to replace Sato as Group CEO
summary: Mizuho Financial Group Inc. named Tatsufumi Sakai, 58, as its new Group CEO, replacing Yasuhiro Sato, 65, on April 1. Sakai, current head of securities, will lead the bank as it faces financial performance challenges due to the central bank's negative interest rate policy. The bank plans to cut costs and diversify operations, with Sakai inheriting a group whose financial performance trailed behind Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group this year.

site_title: Twenty now dead in California mudslides, major highway closed
summary: A mudslide in Montecito, California, has resulted in 20 confirmed fatalities, with four people still missing. The disaster, triggered by heavy rains after a massive wildfire, has destroyed 65 single-family homes and damaged over 450 others. A 16km stretch of Highway 101 has been closed indefinitely, causing significant traffic disruption. Emergency personnel from local, state, and federal agencies are conducting a "search-and-recovery" effort, as the likelihood of finding survivors has diminished.

site_title: Floor at Indonesia's stock exchange collapses, 75 injured
summary: At least 75 people were injured when a mezzanine floor at Indonesia's stock exchange building collapsed into the lobby, police said, with the collapse described as an accident. The incident occurred when part of the mezzanine level gave way, causing a cascade of glass, metal, and other materials to crash onto the ground floor. The Jakarta police spokesman stated that the collapse was not the result of an explosion.

site_title: Trump says 'I'm not a racist'
summary: President Donald Trump denied being a racist, saying he's "the least racist person you have ever interviewed," after sparking global criticism over his reported "shithole" comments about immigration from certain countries. Trump also reiterated his opposition to a visa lottery and expressed frustration with Democrats over the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program. The comments come as Trump tries to clinch an immigration deal, but faces opposition from lawmakers and businesses, which warn of potential economic losses if the DACA recipients leave the labor pool.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump insisted Sunday that he was "not a racist," after his reported denunciation of immigration from "shithole" countries triggered a global firestorm of criticism.

site_title: Indonesia welcomes foreign banks following MUFG's Danamon deal
summary: Indonesia has welcomed foreign banks to invest in its financial institutions, following Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's (MUFG) $1.2 billion stake purchase in PT Bank Danamon Indonesia. The country's Financial Services Authority, led by Wimboh Santoso, aims to boost lending and fund infrastructure projects. Foreign banks from China, India, and South Korea are interested in investing in Indonesia, with the goal of encouraging consolidation among the country's lenders and promoting economic development. The regulator will assess each deal on a case-by-case basis, focusing on the foreign bank's plans for local development and contribution to the economy.

site_title: Australia shares rise as materials shine, NZ down for fourth day
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 6077.1, driven by gains in material stocks such as BHP and South32, which hit record highs. Gold stocks also rose, with Regis Resources and Northern Star Resources up 3% and 4.5% respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.4% for the fourth consecutive session, led by losses in industrials and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Yuan jumps to 2-year high, Bundesbank adds renminbi to its reserves
summary: China's yuan jumped to a 2-year high against the dollar, reaching its strongest level since December 2015, after the Bundesbank added renminbi to its reserves and corporates offloaded their dollar holdings. The yuan surged 0.55% to 6.4574 per dollar, with the dollar index falling to its lowest since January 2015. The People's Bank of China set the yuan's reference rate at its highest in over 1.5 years, and the onshore yuan strengthened to 6.4280 per dollar, its highest since December 9, 2015.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher; SoftBank jumps on listing hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by record closes on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.26% to 23,714.88. SoftBank jumped 3% after considering listing its mobile unit. Analysts expect the Nikkei to rise further this week.

site_title: Saudi Electricity signs deal with Japanese firms for first EV pilot
summary: Saudi Electricity Co has signed a deal with Japanese firms Tokyo Electric Power Co, Nissan Motor Co, and Takaoka Toko for the world's first electric vehicle pilot project in Saudi Arabia. The project aims to develop fast-charger stations to charge EVs in 30 minutes. The state-controlled utility will borrow three EVs from Nissan and receive three fast chargers from the Japanese companies. The move is part of Saudi Electricity's strategy to reduce reliance on oil and cut emissions, as the country seeks to diversify its economy beyond oil.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won edges up on foreign buying
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.29% to 2,503.73 on Monday, driven by foreign buying. The won edged up 0.2% against the US dollar, while bond yields rose. The KOSPI is up 1.2% this year and 0.71% in the past 30 days. Foreigners bought 24,284 million won worth of shares, while US dollar fell 0.46% against the won this year.

site_title: Australia solar shines as power bills trigger clean energy shift
summary: Australia set a record for rooftop solar panel installations in 2017, with a preliminary estimate of 1.05 gigawatts, according to the Clean Energy Regulator. The growth was driven by users seeking to ease escalating power bills and vendors pushing into the commercial sector. The shift to solar accelerated with power prices spiking due to tight supplies of coal and gas. The cost of solar systems for residential customers has declined 44% since 2012, making it more accessible for homeowners and businesses to adopt solar panel systems.

site_title: Dunearn Gardens launched for collective sale with asking price of at least S$488.8m
summary: Dunearn Gardens, a 114-unit freehold high-rise site in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale with a reserve price of S$488.8 million. The site's land rate is estimated to be S$1,962 per square foot per plot ratio, and owners expect offers above the reserve price. The sale will also involve a development charge of S$35.7 million to intensify the site's use.

site_title: Gold miner CNMC to seek dual listing in Hong Kong
summary: CATALIST-listed CNMC Goldmine Holdings plans to seek a dual primary listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange's main board, with Alliance Capital Partners as its sponsor. The move aims to increase market visibility and attract a wider range of investors. No application has been made yet, and the company's shares were trading at 27 Singapore cents, up 1.9% on the day. A dual listing is expected to provide CNMC with access to two equity markets, potentially widening its investor base and exposure to private and institutional investors.

site_title: Capital World launches Malaysia's largest indoor theme park at Johor project
summary: Capital World Limited has launched Malaysia's largest indoor theme park concept at its Capital City Project in Johor. The theme park, which will be a hub for entertainment and shopping, has signed lease agreements with international brands such as Starbucks and KFC. The project also features a 315-room Hilton Garden Inn and various serviced apartments. The goal is to draw greater footfall to the mall and transform it into a one-stop entertainment destination in Johor Bahru.

site_title: US car industry jobs down under Trump
summary: US car industry jobs declined under President Donald Trump's administration, despite a recent announcement by Fiat Chrysler to add 2,500 jobs in Michigan. Net employment in the car sector fell to 783,200 at the end of November, down from 788,900 in 2016. Despite Trump's vow to turn the tide, General Motors' US hourly workforce dropped to 52,000, and Ford shifted production of the Ford Focus to China. Tax reform may provide incentives for companies to produce in the US, but unresolved talks on a revamped NAFTA also pose uncertainty for the industry.

images.alt_text: A year after dressing down carmakers for cutting US jobs due to trade agreements and automation, has President Donald Trump delivered on his vow to turn the tide?

site_title: China's Lufax seeks US$60 b valuation with April Hong Kong IPO: SCMP
summary: China's Lufax, a leading online wealth management platform, is seeking a US$60 billion valuation with its April initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. The company, backed by Ping An Insurance Group, aims to sell US$6 billion-US$9 billion worth of shares, representing 10-15% of its valuation. This would make Lufax the second mega fintech share offering in Hong Kong, after ZhongAn Online Property & Casualty Insurance Co Ltd. The IPO comes as Hong Kong battles for blockbuster Chinese IPOs, with the city's stock exchange proposing rule changes to allow dual-class shares.

site_title: 12,000 flee as Philippines warns of volcano eruption
summary: A Philippine volcano, Mayon, has been experiencing increased activity, prompting over 12,000 people to flee a 7km evacuation zone due to the risk of a potential eruption. Steam-driven eruptions and rockfalls have been reported, with the crater glowing bright red, and scientists warn of destructive mudflows and toxic clouds. The volcano's growth of a new lava dome and increased fluidity of lava pose a significant threat, with a history of deadly eruptions in the past, including 1,200 deaths in 1814 and 1,000 lives lost in 2006.

site_title: Mandatory offer for TMC Education 'fair and reasonable', says IFA
summary: Singapore tycoon Koh Wee Meng's mandatory takeover offer for TMC Education, valued at S$0.0675 per share, has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by the company's IFA, ZICO Capital. The offer, made through JK Global Asset, represents a 29.8% premium to the volume-weighted average price of shares prior to the announcement. Shareholders are advised to accept the offer or sell shares in the open market if a better price is available after deducting related expenses. The offer closes on January 30, with no plans to alter the company's main business or retain its Catalist listing status.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars reach 4-month peaks as greenback stumbles
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached four-month peaks as the US dollar weakened due to optimism over global growth and rising commodity prices. The Aussie dollar surged 0.25% to US$0.7937, while the New Zealand dollar reached a high of US$0.7282. Improved domestic economic news, including employment and retail sales data, contributed to the rally. Futures markets now imply a 50-50 chance of a US interest rate hike by August, with a potential rate hike to 1.75% fully priced in by December.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars racked up fresh four-month peaks on Monday as their US counterpart suffered broad-based selling while optimism over global growth underpinned commodity prices and risk trades.

site_title: StanChart robbery suspect detained by British authorities, Singapore working on extradition
summary: David James Roach, a 28-year-old Canadian national, has been detained by British authorities on suspicion of robbing a Standard Chartered Bank in Singapore in 2016. Roach was accused of stealing $30,000 and was previously sentenced to 14 months in jail in Thailand for money laundering and customs laws. Singapore is working to extradite Roach, who is now in the UK, following a request from the Singapore authorities and a mutual extradition treaty between the two countries.

site_title: PUB launches 3 requests for proposals for solutions to boost water treatment
summary: Singapore's PUB has launched three requests for proposals to improve the effectiveness of water treatment processes and operations, aiming to boost water sustainability. The agency has allocated S$30 million for the projects, which include enhancing energy efficiency in water and used water treatment, promoting water recycling in industries, and leveraging smart technologies for operational efficiency. PUB expects water demand to double by 2060, with the non-domestic sector expected to account for 70% of demand then.

site_title: Volkswagen reports record global car sales in 2017
summary: Volkswagen reported a record 6.2 million global car sales in 2017, a 4.2% increase from the previous year. China drove the growth, with sales jumping 5.9% to 3.2 million, accounting for more than half of global sales. The company's recovery from the 2015 emissions-cheating scandal was highlighted, with Herbert Diess stating it was the best performance ever for Volkswagen. The brand's sales were boosted by strong gains in the US, Russia, and Brazil, despite a 0.1% decline in Germany.

site_title: EU more dependent on Russian gas despite bid to diversify
summary: The European Union remains highly dependent on Russian gas, despite efforts to diversify its energy sources. Gazprom's record deliveries of 193.9 billion cubic meters in 2017 exceeded its previous record, with a significant increase in exports to Germany, Austria, and France. The EU's goal of reducing its energy dependency on Russia has not been met, with Russian gas now accounting for a third of the EU's total gas consumption. Economic recovery, low gas prices, and increased demand due to cold winters have contributed to the trend, and the EU's resistance to new pipeline projects has hindered efforts to diversify energy sources.

site_title: Mercedes takes soft touch to first G-Class redo since 1979
summary: Mercedes-Benz has unveiled the first major redesign of the G-Class since 1979, taking a "soft touch" approach that maintains its utilitarian design and rugged capabilities. The $124,000 model features a "G" mode for off-road driving and a large flat screen, but lacks significant changes to its emissions profile, which is double that of other Mercedes cars. The redesign is seen as a way to maintain the G-Class's profitability to fund investments in electric vehicles, with no plans for a pure-electric or hybrid variant in the near future.

images.alt_text: Daimler AG CEO Dieter Zetsche reiterated that all Mercedes will eventually be electrified, but for specifics: "Stay tuned."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.57 points to 1,825.24 at 9am. The market saw 158.12 million lots traded worth RM41.32 million, with 197 gainers outnumbering 46 losers.

site_title: Aspen to invest RM58.8m in Selangor residential project
summary: Aspen Group will invest RM58.8 million in a joint venture with Selangor Agricultural Development Corp to redevelop a 12,185 sqm site in Seri Kembangan, Selangor, into a residential project with a gross development value of RM300 million. Sales are expected to begin in 2019. Aspen will use some of its IPO proceeds and internal resources to fund the project, with PKPS receiving RM47.59 million in cash and the remaining RM11.25 million in apartment units at a 10% discount. The project is located in a prime area with ready infrastructure and amenities.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won rise on foreign buying
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.18% to 2,500.92, driven by foreign buying. The won gained 0.29% against the dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is up 1.2% this year and 0.71% in the past 30 days. Foreigners were net buyers of 12 billion won worth of shares, contributing to the market's positive momentum.

site_title: RHT Health Trust and Fortis extend exclusivity period for talks on proposed sale of assets
summary: RHT Health Trust and Fortis Healthcare have extended their exclusivity period for talks on the proposed sale of RHT's healthcare assets to 31 days, starting from January 12, 2018. The deal is valued at close to S$1 billion. Fortis has also agreed to pay 978.7 million rupees to RHT entities by January 31, related to outstanding service fees and interest income on compulsorily convertible debentures.

site_title: Xiaomi is said to choose Morgan Stanley among banks for IPO
summary: Xiaomi Corp has selected Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs Group Inc as international banks for its planned initial public offering, with a potential valuation of up to $100 billion. The company, which raised $45 billion in 2014, is looking to expand into developed markets and has a strong online community and software business. Xiaomi's rivals, including Lenovo and ZTE, have seen their shares fall following the announcement. The company plans to enter developed markets, including Spain, and is in talks with US carriers to sell devices on Apple's turf.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend rally as Hong Kong eyes record
summary: Asian markets continued their rally, with Hong Kong near its record high and the Hang Seng Index rising over 7% due to optimism about corporate earnings and the global economic outlook. The euro extended its gains against the dollar, reaching a three-year high, while the US dollar struggled against the yen and pound. Market analysts attribute the surge to US tax cuts and a stronger global growth narrative, with some predicting a possible breach of their 2018 year-end global stock market forecast.

site_title: Developers sold 23% more private homes and ECs in 2017: URA estimates
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) estimates that 14,707 private homes and executive condominiums were sold in 2017, 23% higher than the 11,971 units sold in 2016. This includes 10,682 private residential units, 34% more than 2016, and 531 units sold in December, 43% lower than November. The top-selling projects in December were Symphony Suites and Parc Riveria, with median prices of S$1,027 and S$1,223 per square foot, respectively.

site_title: Netanyahu disappointed by ally Modi's Jerusalem rejection
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed disappointment over India's refusal to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital, but vowed not to let it spoil his six-day visit to the country. Despite India cancelling a $500 million deal for Israeli Spike anti-tank missiles, Netanyahu remains optimistic about resolving the issue. The visit aims to strengthen the "special relationship" between the two nations, with agreements planned in energy, aviation, and cinema production. Netanyahu also plans to visit a Jewish centre targeted in the 2008 Mumbai attacks and make emotional gestures to India's tiny Jewish community.

site_title: SPH, StarHub renew strategic partnership with potential healthcare, retail, education tie-ups
summary: SPH and StarHub have renewed their strategic partnership for two years, expanding into healthcare, retail, and education sectors. The companies will collaborate on Internet of Things, connected buildings, and smart retail, while continuing to develop advertising and branding opportunities across multiple media platforms. StarHub will also carry SPH content on its online streaming service and promote it on existing radio stations. The partnership aims to create new business opportunities and leverage each other's strengths to benefit consumers in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open, head for record high
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose almost one percent at the open on Monday, nearing its all-time high. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.92 percent to 31,702.56, just 200 points shy of its peak. This follows fresh records on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.19 percent. The rally comes despite US tariff threats, with traders brushing off the news to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: South Korea says planned ban on cryptocurrency market not yet finalised
summary: South Korea's planned ban on cryptocurrency exchanges has not been finalized, as government agencies continue to discuss regulation measures. Justice Minister Park Sang-ki previously mentioned a bill to ban trading on domestic exchanges, but the plan is still in talks. The goal is to curb speculative investments and the government will finalize the decision after sufficient discussion.

site_title: C&A fashion chain eyes sale to Chinese investors: report
summary: The Brenninkmeijer family, owners of Dutch clothing retailer C&A, are reportedly on the brink of selling the chain to Chinese investors, according to a German media report. C&A, founded in 1841, has over 1,500 stores across Europe and employs 35,000 people. The deal is close to being finalized, but the company declined to confirm or deny the sale. The Brenninkmeijer family, worth around 20 billion euros, is exploring growth opportunities and considering partnerships in regions like China and the digital area.

site_title: Ford ups electric vehicle plans to US$11b by 2022: executive
summary: Ford Motor Co has increased its planned investments in electric vehicles to $11 billion by 2022, up from a previous target of $4.5 billion. The company will focus on full electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, with 40 models planned, including 16 battery electric models. Ford aims to electrify its mainstream vehicles, including the F-150 truck, and bring a high-performance electric utility vehicle to market by 2020. This move reflects the growing competition in the electric vehicle market and the costs of building a dedicated electric vehicle platform.

site_title: Booming Iceland has airport spending US$1 billion on capacity
summary: Iceland's Keflavik airport is investing $1 billion over 7-8 years to accommodate a predicted 10 million passengers this year, a five-fold increase in traffic over the past nine years. The airport, which has already spent $372 million since 2011, plans to expand its capacity with new airlines and routes, including flights to the US and Canada. The expansion will require foreign investment, possibly through bond issuances, and will be guided by the government's cautious approach to economic growth.

site_title: Halcyon Agri to acquire 2 firms for S$105.3m, add 4 rubber factories
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation Limited has signed a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire PT Sumber Djantin and PT Sumber Alam for S$105.3 million, adding four Standard Indonesian Rubber factories with a combined licensed annual capacity of 132,000 tonnes. The acquisition will increase Halcyon Agri's total annual processing capacity in Indonesia to 877,000 tonnes, making it the single largest producer of SIR globally. The deal is conditional upon fulfilling certain conditions and is expected to be completed by March 31, 2018.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.32% to 3,531.80
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.32% at the Monday open, reaching 3,531.80, driven by a 91-39 gain/loss ratio. Capital World surged 3.3% and Singtel, OCBC Bank, and other active index stocks also gained. The rally comes ahead of the Martin Luther King Jr Day market holiday in the US and amid a broader Asia stocks rally.

site_title: UK govt keeps 'close eye' on struggling firm Carillion
summary: The UK government has taken steps to guarantee public services after construction and services firm Carillion collapsed on January 15, 2018, due to costly contract delays and debt issues. The 200-year-old company had worked on 450 projects, including hospitals, prisons, and the country's new superfast rail line. Carillion's collapse poses a major headache for the government, which had employed the company to work on vital projects. The company's demise has thrown hundreds of major projects into doubt, highlighting the risks of the UK's public-private sector partnerships.

images.alt_text: The British government is keeping a "very close eye" on construction and outsourcing group Carillion, a senior minister said Sunday, amid reports it could go into administration within days and critics questioning the government's own role in the crisis.

site_title: Dutch millers get fresh wind in their sails
summary: Dutch miller Maarten Dolman has renewed pride in his work at his windmill, "Windotter", after it was officially included on UNESCO's list of "the intangible cultural heritage of humanity" last month. The craft of traditional flour milling is now protected, and Dolman, who has been grinding grain for 30 years, is helping to pass on the skills to his son and other apprentices. The recognition is seen as a valuable step in conserving the traditional craft, which has declined in recent years, and UNESCO has committed to financing activities to safeguard the millers' craft, including training and internships.

site_title: End of a chip boom? Memory chip price drop spooks investors
summary: South Korea's memory chip industry is experiencing a sudden price drop, sparking concerns among investors who had anticipated continued growth. The price of high-end flash memory chips fell nearly 5% in the fourth quarter, and Samsung Electronics' disappointing profit estimate led to a 7.5% decline in its shares. Despite this, analysts expect the industry's growth rate to remain stable at 30% in 2018, driven by strong demand for smartphones and cloud services.

site_title: MAS chief sounds caution over Goldilocks economy and its three bears
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon warns investors to watch three "bears" of risk in the current "Goldilocks" economy, characterized by healthy growth, low inflation, and easy financial conditions. The three bears are: the "papa bear" of inflation, the "mama bear" of protectionism, and the "baby bear" of financial instability. Menon notes that while structural factors may have created a "one-off" effect on prices, the risk of inflation, protectionism, and financial instability remains, particularly due to the high leverage in major economies and the potential for technological change to persist.

site_title: Basketball hall of famer Rodman arrested for alleged drink driving
summary: Dennis Rodman, a five-time NBA champion, was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence in Newport Beach, California. He failed a field sobriety test and an alcohol breathalyzer test, and was released from jail after being cooperative with police. This is not Rodman's first DUI conviction, as he pleaded guilty to the same offense in 1999. Rodman's lawyer stated that he is taking the incident seriously and will address his personal issues.

site_title: Google venture arm backs UK universal flu vaccine company
summary: Vaccitech, a UK-based company, has secured 20 million pounds in funding from investors including Google's venture capital arm GV. The company aims to develop a universal flu vaccine that can provide immunity against all types of flu, a long-sought goal in medicine. The vaccine works by using stable proteins found in the virus core, rather than those on its surface, and has shown promise in a mid-stage clinical trial. If successful, the vaccine could be ready for launch in 2023 or 2025, with potential implications for the treatment of other diseases, including prostate cancer and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda's optimism on economy, price outlook sends yen to 4-month high
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed optimism about the economy and inflation, citing a moderate economic expansion and rising core consumer prices, which sent the yen to a four-month high against the dollar. Kuroda stated that the economy is expected to continue expanding moderately, with inflation likely to accelerate towards the BOJ's two percent target. The BOJ also raised its assessment for three regional economies and maintained its view for the remaining six regions, with policymakers signaling a desire to maintain the status quo on monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda on Monday reiterated the central bank's resolve to maintain its massive stimulus programme until the economy reaches sustained 2 per cent inflation.

site_title: Oil dips away from 2014 highs on rising US rig count, but analysts say market supported
summary: Oil prices dipped on Monday, with Brent crude futures at $69.72 per barrel, down 0.2% from their last close. Rising US drilling activity, pointing to higher future output, countered output cuts led by Opec and Russia, while healthy demand kept crude near 2014 highs. US WTI crude futures fell to $64.27 per barrel, down 0.05%. Despite this, analysts say the market is supported, citing ongoing demand and supply cuts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, Softbank soars on listing report
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on January 15, 2018, driven by record US closes and a 5% surge in Softbank following reports of a potential listing of its mobile unit. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.65% to 23,808.11, while the Topix index gained 0.66%. Softbank's mobile unit was considered for a listing, supporting the Japanese market's positive start.

site_title: Two Koreas in fresh talks on Winter Olympics
summary: North and South Korea began fresh talks on Monday on appearances by Pyongyang's state-run artistic performers at next month's Winter Olympics in the South. The North agreed to send athletes, officials, and an art troupe, including the Moranbong music band, easing months of high tensions. The two sides will discuss details, including whether lyrics praising leader Kim Jong Un could be allowed under the South's National Security Act. The talks come after the North agreed to attend the Games, with the aim of promoting a "peace Olympics."

site_title: Singapore wary of issuing digital currencies to public: MAS chief
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is cautious about issuing digital currencies to the public, citing risks of disintermediating banks and potential bank runs. Managing Director Ravi Menon expressed concerns over the speculative nature of cryptocurrencies, which he likened to the Dutch tulip mania. The MAS is exploring the use of digital currencies to improve settlement processes within the banking system, but not for public issuance. The central bank aims to harness the benefits of digital currencies and blockchains without being swayed by their speculative aspects.

site_title: Mud ravages seaside haven for celebrities and billionaires
summary: A devastating mudslide in Montecito, California, has destroyed 65 single-family homes and damaged 462 others, killing 17 people and leaving 5 missing. The wealthy enclave, popular with celebrities and billionaires, has seen hundreds of millions of dollars in damage, with many homes valued at over $4 million. The disaster struck after the region escaped a major wildfire last month, and the area's natural appeal to the wealthy is expected to withstand short-term economic impacts.

site_title: Japan's Abe seeks to drum up EU pressure on North Korea
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe met with Bulgarian Premier Boyko Borisov in Sofia, seeking EU pressure on North Korea over its ballistic missile and nuclear programs. Abe pledged to boost economic cooperation with Bulgaria and the Balkans, including a business forum and free trade deal. The Japanese PM also pressed for a solution to the abduction of Japanese nationals by North Korea. Abe's visit aims to counter China's growing ties with Europe and to rekindle EU support for a peaceful resolution to the North Korea issue.

site_title: Detroit auto show begins amid talk of Nafta, tax cuts
summary: The Detroit Auto Show began on January 14, 2018, amidst discussions about NAFTA and tax cuts. US Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao highlighted the newly enacted 21% corporate tax rate, which she believes will attract US investment. Carmakers, including GM and Ford, showcased new pickup trucks and SUVs, which have been driving US sales. Negotiations for a revised NAFTA deal are ongoing, with industry insiders taking a cautious approach, and analysts warning of potential price increases for consumers if the agreement is altered.

site_title: Change in Facebook news feed to woo back users will increase ad revenue: analysts
summary: Facebook is shifting its news feed to prioritize posts from friends and family, away from businesses and media outlets, in an effort to boost user satisfaction and engagement. Analysts believe this change will lead to increased ad revenue, as users will spend more time on the platform engaging with meaningful social interactions. Despite concerns about the impact on advertising revenue, analysts expect top brands to continue relying on digital channels and for the company to benefit from a more social and less media-focused experience.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank Group soars on listing reports
summary: SoftBank Group shares surged nearly 6% on reports it could list its mobile unit, potentially raising $18 billion in the largest initial public offering for a Japanese company. The company, led by Masayoshi Son, has been aggressively investing in technology ventures. If successful, the listing could rival the 2.2 trillion yen raised by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone in 1987, and could include an overseas debut in London. SoftBank has acknowledged the listing as an "option" but has not made a decision to proceed.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Lian Beng, 800 Super, Noble, CWG
summary: Lian Beng Group reported a 43.2% decline in net profit to S$3.2 million for its second quarter, due to higher costs and finance expenses. 800 Super Holdings won a S$194 million contract for refuse collection in Singapore. Noble Group completed the sale of Noble Americas Corp for an estimated US$400 million. CWG International secured land use rights for a 47.683 million yuan site in China for S$234.06 million.

site_title: Noble Group completes sale of Noble Americas Corp
summary: Noble Group has completed the sale of Noble Americas Corp to Vitol US Holding Co, marking the conclusion of its monetization of Global Oil Liquids and North American Gas & Power businesses. This sale also retires Noble's senior secured borrowing base revolving credit facilities. The sale of all NAC's issued and outstanding capital stock was completed, effectively ending the company's operations.

images.alt_text: Commodity trader Noble Group on Monday said it has completed the sale of Noble Americas Corp (NAC).

site_title: GM driverless cars could be around the corner
summary: General Motors has submitted a petition to the US Department of Transportation seeking permission to operate fully autonomous cars in a commercial ride-hailing service starting next year. The company's Cruise AV, a four-passenger vehicle, has been tested in San Francisco and is expected to be mass-produced at a factory in Michigan if approved. This move could mark the beginning of widespread self-driving cars, with GM aiming to launch a commercial ride-share service in 2019 and potentially generate billions of dollars in revenue.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb on commodity prices; NZ inches up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to a 6,088.4-point index on Monday, driven by gains in commodity prices and record Wall Street highs. Zinc prices reached a decade peak, supporting gains in materials and mining stocks. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rose to multi-year highs, while gold stocks also gained. New Zealand's benchmark index inched up 0.098% to 8,250.41 points, with utilities and materials sectors leading the gains.

site_title: Can social media become less hateful by law?
summary: Germany's new law forcing major social networks to withhold certain comments deemed illegal and offensive has been criticized as well-intentioned but failing. The law, aimed at combating online hate crimes, has led to censorship of posts, with critics arguing that social networks are removing more posts than necessary to avoid fines. Facebook and Twitter deny deliberately removing content, but acknowledge the 24-hour deadline puts a burden on their teams. Users have limited options to appeal removals, and the law has sparked disagreement between social networks and the German government over the role of social networks in the public sphere.

site_title: Male models say top fashion photographers harassed them
summary: Male models and assistants have come forward alleging that high-powered fashion photographers Bruce Weber and Mario Testino subjected them to molestation, sexual advances, and unnecessary nudity. The allegations, made by 28 individuals, include models and assistants who worked with the photographers over several decades. Both Weber and Testino have denied the claims, with their lawyers describing them as "outrageous" and "completely false." As a result, Conde Nast has suspended work with the photographers, and the #MeToo movement has gained momentum in the fashion industry.

site_title: Virtual becomes reality as British shop visits fall in December
summary: British shop visits fell by 3.5% in December, the largest decline in five years, as online shopping transforms the retail industry. The drop was seen across all regions, with Scotland experiencing the sharpest decline. Retailers are adapting to changing shopping habits by closing stores and re-shaping their portfolios. The decline is attributed to a squeeze on discretionary spending, slow wage growth, and higher inflation, with many purchases moving online.

site_title: Turkish passenger plane skids off runway onto seaside cliff
summary: A Turkish passenger plane with 168 people on board skidded off a runway onto a seaside cliff in Trabzon, northern Turkey, on Saturday. No one was injured, but passengers described a "miracle" after the plane's wheels became stuck in mud. An investigation is underway, and the cause of the incident remains unknown. The airport was temporarily shut before reopening, and a crisis centre was set up. Experts suggest that the accident could have been prevented with the construction of a second runway.

site_title: US transport chief to unveil revised self-driving car guidelines
summary: US Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao plans to unveil revised self-driving car guidelines this summer, aiming to remove barriers to the technology's safe integration into various transportation modes. The revised guidelines, which will be tech-neutral and flexible, will address regulatory hurdles posed by existing safety standards written for human-driven vehicles. The move is in response to growing pressure from automakers and tech companies, who seek to remove obstacles to the development and deployment of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: China stepping up banking oversight to reduce financial risks
summary: China's banking regulator, the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC), has announced plans to step up oversight in the banking sector to reduce financial risks. The CBRC will increase supervision over shadow banking and interbank activities, and will punish violations in corporate governance, property loans, and disposal of non-performing assets more strictly. Long-term efforts will be needed to control banking sector chaos, and the regulator has vowed to strengthen risk control in interbank activities, financial products, and off-balance sheet business. This move comes as China seeks to address concerns over its massive shadow banking industry and prevent economic instability.

site_title: Cutting through the rabbit hole of cross-border payments
summary: Blockchain technology is promising to revolutionize cross-border payments by settling transactions in seconds, a trillion-dollar space that had long lagged in innovation. Banks are turning to blockchain firms like Ripple, which has signed up more users from Asia in recent months, and global banks like Standard Chartered and Axis Bank. Meanwhile, Visa and UBS are launching services that use blockchain technology to help businesses send money across borders. Swift, the dominant payment network service, is also catching up with its own blockchain-based service, which allows banks to track cross-border payments and send payments within a day.

site_title: Olam, Republic of Gabon joint venture gets another sustainable palm oil certification
summary: Olam International's joint venture with the Republic of Gabon has achieved Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) certification for its Bilala palm oil mill and concessions in Gabon. The certification covers 15,900 hectares of planted oil palm and 19,500 hectares of protected high conservation value areas, marking the second of two plantations to be certified. The certification aims to promote sustainable oil palm plantations and increase the use of certified palm oil globally.

site_title: Qatari sheikh says 'detained' in UAE
summary: Qatari Sheikh Abdullah bin Ali Al-Thani claims to be being detained in the UAE, despite a UAE denial. He had been a guest of UAE Crown Prince Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed al-Nahyan, but now says he is being held against his will. Al-Thani accuses Sheikh Mohammed of responsibility for his detention, stating he wants to make it clear the people of Qatar are innocent. The UAE claims Al-Thani is free to leave the country, citing a trusted source, amid a diplomatic dispute between Qatar and the UAE over alleged ties to extremist groups and Iran.

site_title: Bull run turning into stampede from bonds to equities and risky investments
summary: US stocks reached new record highs last week due to corporate tax cuts and speculation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed within 200 points of 26,000, with a strong market opening since 2003. Optimistic earnings reports from banks and industrial companies could lead to further gains.

site_title: Softbank plans US$18b IPO of mobile phone unit as soon as spring: Nikkei
summary: SoftBank Group Corp plans to list its mobile phone unit, SoftBank Corp, in Tokyo and overseas as early as spring, raising approximately $23.9 billion in its largest initial public offering in Japan. The move aims to give the mobile phone unit more autonomy and allow SoftBank to invest in growth opportunities, such as foreign information-technology companies. The IPO would rival a 1987 listing by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp, and would enable SoftBank to pursue its strategy of investing in companies with high growth prospects.

images.alt_text: SoftBank Group Corp plans to list its core mobile-phone unit in Tokyo and overseas as early as this spring, raising some 2 trillion yen (S$23.9 billion) in one of Japan's biggest initial public offerings, the Nikkei newspaper said on Monday.

site_title: CWG wins land use rights to 47,683 sq m site in Zhejiang with 1.1b yuan bid
summary: CWG International won a bid for a 47,683 sq m residential and commercial site in Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China, for 1.14 billion yuan. The company will enter into a joint venture with a third party to develop and manage the site, with a planned completion date of 2019. The land parcel has a plot ratio of two, yielding a maximum gross floor area of about 95,366 sq m.

site_title: Melding tech and art in pursuit of hifi
summary: French audio company Devialet is expanding its global presence, aiming to become a leader in the high-end audio market. Founded in 2007 by Quentin Sannie and co-founders Pierre-Emmanuel Calmel and Emmanuel Nardin, Devialet has disrupted the audiophile industry with its innovative products and technology. The company's focus is on delivering high-quality audio signals, rather than the music itself, allowing artists to create music that evokes emotions. Devialet has experienced 97% annual growth and is now distributed in 39 countries, with plans to integrate its technology into devices such as TVs, smartphones, and cars, aiming to make "ubiquitous audiophile quality" a reality.

site_title: Big fight brewing over what pregnant women should not eat
summary: A heated debate surrounds what foods pregnant women should avoid, with conflicting studies on common items like soda, rice, and macaroni and cheese. The American Pregnancy Association advises pregnant women to exclude these foods, but experts argue that the risks are often exaggerated. Research has linked maternal consumption of diet and regular soda with pre-term delivery and pre-eclampsia, while studies on arsenic in rice and phthalates in mac-and-cheese mixes are inconclusive. Economists and dietitians caution against unnecessary dietary changes and stress the importance of moderation, recommending water, milk, or tea instead of soda.

site_title: Fleeing migrants learn even Canada has limits
summary: Thousands of Haitian migrants crossed the US-Canada border last summer, taking advantage of a loophole in a US-Canada treaty. They hoped to benefit from a work permit, free healthcare, and education in Canada. However, Canadian officials warn that even liberal Canada has its limits, citing a backlog of 40,700 asylum cases and concerns about the strain on the immigration system. The Trump administration's decision to end temporary protected status for nearly 200,000 Salvadorans has also led to fears of a potential backlash.

site_title: Datapulse should diversify: board
summary: The board of Datapulse Technology advises diversifying the company to consider alternatives to its existing business with limited prospects for profitability or growth. Uniseraya Holdings and Ng Bie Tjin, holding a combined 16% stake, requested a feasibility study and proposed replacing four directors before a proposed business diversification. Datapulse acquired Wayco Manufacturing to enter a new business, but its CEO's familiarity with the target company led to a lack of due diligence. The company plans to elaborate on its diversification proposals in a shareholders circular.

site_title: Fed's quantitative tightening likely to hit consumer spending
summary: The US Federal Reserve is implementing quantitative tightening (QT), a policy opposite to quantitative easing, which aims to reduce its inflated security portfolio and combat inflation. QT will likely slow economic growth and downward pressure on money growth, affecting consumer spending, particularly in the US. Economists expect the Fed to continue increasing interest rates and reducing liquidity in the banking system, leading to slower bank lending standards and a reduced demand for credit. The Fed's actions may also impact European and Asian economies, as well as high government and private debt levels in the UK and other nations.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund may turn to bank loans to finance its investments
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is considering borrowing from banks to finance its investments, aiming to reach a $2 trillion fund. The PIF has held talks with local and international banks, potentially raising $5 billion this year. However, no final decisions have been made, and the PIF may instead rely on government financing. This move would be a first for the sovereign fund, which has traditionally relied on its own capital.

site_title: Home loans get pricier as banks hike interest rates again
summary: Banks in Singapore have increased mortgage rates for fixed and floating home loans by 10 to 30 basis points, with rates reaching as high as 2.05% per annum. This is the second increase in as many months, following a 10-basis-point hike in December. The rise in interest rates may dent the buoyant property market, particularly for investment properties, as borrowers may struggle to cover higher servicing costs. The S$100,000 loan over 25 years would see an extra $4.80 per month for every 10-basis-point increase, with floating rate loans being more popular among home buyers.

site_title: Hassan Basma blazes a trail with Swissco buy-out offer
summary: Hassan Basma, chairman of Asian Strategic Turnaround Ventures, has successfully acquired Swissco Holdings, the first deal in the offshore and marine sector to bring new equity since investors fled the cash-strapped sector. Basma, former CEO of Bumi Armada, transformed the company into a diversified O&M group and publicly floated it on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange. This deal marks a significant milestone for the sector, which has been struggling due to investor flight.

site_title: Ezra gets extension until Feb 19 to file reorganisation plan
summary: US Court grants Ezra Holdings extension until Feb 19 to file reorganisation plan under Chapter 11, allowing the company and its subsidiaries to seek creditor acceptance until April 12, 2018. Ezra filed for bankruptcy protection in March 2017 due to financial woes amid an industry downturn, including a US$170 million writedown and massive net loss of US$339.6 million. The company's largest bank lenders include DBS, OCBC, and UOB, with significant unsecured and contingent claims.

site_title: Republicans in Congress are wasting chance to do right thing on immigration
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked outrage with his remarks about Haiti and African countries, revealing a racist and bigoted worldview. The comments, made during a meeting with congressional Republicans and Democrats, were later denied by Trump, but confirmed by Senator Richard Durbin. The remarks are part of a pattern of Trump's rhetoric, including his 2016 campaign's demonization of Mexicans and Muslims. The Trump administration's immigration policies, including the end of Temporary Protected Status for Haitians and Salvadorans, have also sparked controversy. Republicans in Congress are struggling to address the issue, with some avoiding discussion of Trump's comments.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending January 14, 2018, highlights market trends in the tanker and dry bulk sectors. Rates for VLCCs and Suezmax vessels remained under pressure, with West Africa to China rates at WS 43.5 basis 260,000 tonnes. The North Sea saw rates stabilize at WS 20 cape/cape basis 280,000 size. Meanwhile, the US$6.10 fixed rate on the West Australia/China run was short-lived, with owners preferring to wait. The market also saw a decline in panamax and supramax rates, with the handysize market experiencing a lackluster week.

site_title: Cryptocurrency rivals - at least 1,400 of them - snap at Bitcoin's heels
summary: Bitcoin, the most famous cryptocurrency, has a market capitalization of 200 billion euros, but it's not the most lucrative one. In fact, it's not even in the top 10 best performers. Cryptocurrencies like Ripple, which rose 36,000% in 2017 and reached 100 billion euros, and Ether, based on the Ethereum protocol, are outperforming Bitcoin. The number of cryptocurrencies has increased to 1,400, with some focusing on security, anonymity, and transaction speed. Financial experts warn that cryptocurrencies are unpredictable and may "come to a bad ending."

site_title: 'Clean business or no business'
summary: Singaporean companies expanding abroad must adopt a "clean business or no business" approach in graft-prone markets. Experts emphasize the importance of honesty and integrity, as well as complying with local laws and regulations. Companies must resist the temptation to secure graft-tainted business and instead invest in management oversight, internal controls, and training to maintain a culture of zero tolerance to non-compliance. Adopting anti-corruption policies and using technology to monitor and track transactions can also help prevent corruption. Ultimately, maintaining a strong reputation and adhering to high standards of governance, integrity, and transparency is crucial for long-term success.

site_title: Detroit auto show goes heavy on pickups and light on electric cars
summary: The 30th Detroit auto show kicked off, focusing on pickup trucks and SUVs, with General Motors unveiling its revamped 2019 Chevrolet Silverado pickups. The show is expected to be light on electric cars, with US car sales falling modestly last year to 17.2 million, and industry experts discussing potential negotiations on the North America Free Trade Agreement and the impact of the recently enacted US tax-cut bill.

site_title: Fixed deposit deals for scaredy-cats
summary: Conservative investors are finding new opportunities to earn returns on their savings due to rising interest rates. In Singapore, one-year T-bill yields have increased to 1.6% and 10-year bonds are trading at 2.1%, offering higher returns than bank fixed deposits. Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) and government securities provide a stable option with embedded put options, protecting against potential capital losses. Investors can allocate a portion of their portfolio to risk-free assets, potentially sleeping better and eating well during market downturns.

site_title: Bitcoin fever hits US real estate market
summary: Bitcoin fever has hit the US real estate market, particularly in Florida, offering foreign investors a way to bypass currency controls and US economic sanctions. As of January 2018, 75 properties were listed as "Bitcoin accepted," with one seller accepting 33 bitcoins for a $500,000 condo. The use of bitcoin in real estate transactions is novel, but economists say it's driven by international investors seeking to circumvent restrictions and sanctions. However, agents are wary of the high volatility of the currency, with one agent calling it a "gimmick" and a "volatile" market.

site_title: Renewable energy goals of Japan lagging world's: foreign minister
summary: Japan's renewable energy goals are lagging behind the global average, with the nation aiming for 22-24% of energy from renewables by 2030, compared to the current 24% global average. Foreign Minister Taro Kono attributed the delay to prioritizing maintaining the status quo, citing underwhelming demand for solar power and decreasing government incentives since 2012.
