The company aims to list in the first half of 2018, following in the footsteps of other high-profile tech companies like Snap and Spotify. With annualized sales of over $1 billion and a history of profitability, Dropbox is expected to fare better than Snap, which saw its shares decline 15% after its IPO.

site_title: SPH Q1 profit up 32% to S$60m on investment income boost
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 32% increase in Q1 net profit to S$60.4 million, driven by investment income of S$12.4 million. Operating revenue fell 7% to S$258.8 million, while operating profit decreased 4.1% to S$67.9 million. CEO Ng Yat Chung announced plans to roll out new products and diversify revenue streams to address disruption in the core media business.

site_title: MSCI expects to include Aramco in Saudi Arabia index from time of IPO
summary: MSCI expects to include Saudi Aramco in its Saudi Arabia Index from the time of its IPO, potentially triggering a large influx of funds into the shares. The inclusion is contingent on Aramco meeting eligibility criteria, including listing its shares on the Tadawul stock exchange. This could lead to increased demand for Aramco shares, potentially causing instability in the stock price. MSCI is also considering upgrading Saudi Arabia to emerging market status, which could lead to further foreign investment in the Saudi market.

site_title: Mubadala is said to mull options for 3.66b ringgit RHB stake
summary: Abu Dhabi sovereign fund Mubadala Investment is exploring options for its 17.8% stake in Malaysian lender RHB Bank, valued at 3.66 billion ringgit (S$1.22 billion). Mubadala views the stake as non-core and is considering a possible sale as part of a broader portfolio review. Informal discussions with potential advisers have taken place, but no certainty exists for a transaction at this stage. The fund trails only Employees Provident Fund, Malaysia's largest pension fund, which owns 40.7% of RHB Bank. Deliberations are in the early stages.

site_title: Trump cancels UK visit, says will not unveil new US embassy
summary: US President Donald Trump cancelled a planned visit to London, citing dissatisfaction with the Obama administration's decision to sell the US embassy in Grosvenor Square for $1.2 billion to build a new one in an off-location on the South Bank, costing taxpayers $1 billion. Trump claimed he was not a fan of the deal, despite the decision being made before his presidency. The cancellation of the visit was first reported by The Daily Mail, which had initially reported Trump's inauguration of the new embassy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up, won strengthens
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.34% to 2,496.42, with the Korean won strengthening 0.68% against the US dollar. The currency gain followed the euro's rise after the European Central Bank signaled an end to its stimulus. The Kospi is up 0.8% this year, while the MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.63%. Foreigners were net sellers of 107.21 million won worth of shares, but the US dollar has fallen 0.23% against the won this year.

site_title: Blue skies in China's capital spark joy, scepticism
summary: Beijing's air quality has significantly improved over the past five years, with the city experiencing its best air quality on record in 2017, according to the capital's environmental protection bureau. The average PM2.5 level decreased by 53.8% in the last quarter of 2017, and experts attribute the improvement to favourable weather conditions and stricter enforcement of environmental rules. However, analysts warn that the measures may not be sustainable, and pollution is expected to rebound in the future. The government's efforts have been bolstered by growing public awareness and pressure, with many residents expressing hope for continued improvement.

images.alt_text: Every day for the last five years, Zou Yi has photographed Beijing's smog-cloaked skyline from his 13th-floor apartment, but there is something different in the air this year.

site_title: Top Glove inks deal to buy surgical glove maker Aspion for RM1.37b
summary: Top Glove Corporation has agreed to purchase surgical glove maker Aspion for RM1.37 billion, funded by a combination of cash and new shares. The deal is expected to expand Top Glove's product range and provide access to Aspion's expertise and resources in the surgical glove market. The acquisition is expected to increase Top Glove's revenue from surgical gloves by 8 percentage points, contributing positively to the company's profitability. The deal must be approved by Top Glove shareholders.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on positive ground; STI at 3,521.63
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading on Friday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,521.63, up 0.3% or 8.95 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 244 to 119, with China Med and IPCO being the most traded stocks. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release, with investors maintaining a positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 5.3% y-o-y in November, reversing slump in October
summary: Singapore's retail sales surged 5.3% in November, reversing the 0.2% drop in October. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail takings rose 4.7% year-over-year, driven by a 16.6% increase in computers and telecommunications equipment. Supermarkets and petrol service stations also saw significant gains. In contrast, optical goods and books declined 4.2%. This month's growth reversed the previous month's decline, with sales of food and beverage services growing 2.1% year-over-year.

site_title: Credit Suisse cautions on outlook for Singapore's surging Reits
summary: Credit Suisse has cautioned that Singapore's real estate investment trusts (Reits) may not perform well this year due to stretched valuations. Analysts point to declines in extra yield from Reits versus risk-free rates, suggesting a potential return of 3.4 percentage points over a 10-year bond, lower than the historical average. Despite a strong 2017, with the Straits Times Real Estate Investment Trust Index delivering a 28% total return, investors may want to wait for more attractive entry levels, according to Kum Soek Ching, head of South-east Asia research.

site_title: China's imports from North Korea plummet in December to lowest in 4 years
summary: China's imports from North Korea plummeted 81.6% year-on-year in December to $54.34 million, the lowest level in dollar terms since 2014. The decline is attributed to UN sanctions aimed at persuading North Korea to abandon its ballistic missile and nuclear programs. This marks the smallest monthly value in at least four years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks climb a 14th day for new record
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a 14th consecutive day of gains, closing at a record high of 31,412.54, driven by a broad Asia market advance and healthy Chinese trade data. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.9%, nearing its all-time high of 31,958.41. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also rose, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined. The rally comes despite US tariff threats, which have led to a decline in US stocks.

site_title: Bank Indonesia to open Beijing office to boost links with China
summary: Bank Indonesia is opening a representative office in Beijing, aiming to boost economic ties with China. The move reflects China's growing role in global and regional economics, particularly for Indonesia. The office will facilitate cooperation between the two countries' central banks, trade, and finance. China is already Indonesia's largest trading partner, with two-way trade exceeding $52 billion in 2016. The office is the ninth foreign central bank to establish a presence in China, strengthening bilateral finance and economic relations.

site_title: Uniqlo owner has too much cash insulation
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, reported strong first-quarter results, with operating margins at 18.1% and earnings up 12.7% year-over-year. The company now holds over $7 billion in cash, exceeding US$5.9 billion held by Inditex and $1.2 billion held by H&M. Despite this, analysts question the company's decision not to distribute more of its cash through dividends or buybacks, potentially leading to shareholder activism.

site_title: M&L Hospitality launches new hotel in Sydney
summary: M&L Hospitality has opened its new 182-room hotel, West Hotel, in Sydney's central business district, marking the company's third property in the city. The hotel, situated on Sussex Street, is close to Barangaroo and Darling Harbour waterfront, offering a unique boutique hotel experience. Established by the Kum family, M&L Hospitality operates 15 hotel properties globally, including prime locations in international gateway cities. The new hotel aims to cater to corporate and leisure travellers seeking a personalized and well-located experience.

site_title: China chides tech firms over privacy safeguards
summary: China has reprimanded three top tech firms - Alibaba Group Holding's Ant Financial, Baidu, and Beijing Bytedance Technology Co - for inadequate personal information protection policies. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology stated that any violations will be investigated and "severely punished." The move comes amid growing consumer backlash and regulatory scrutiny over excessive data collection practices. The regulator did not specify any punishments for the firms.

site_title: Aussie shares inch up for the day, but have worst week in 8; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.04% on Friday, driven by gains in miners, but the S&P/ASX 200 index had its worst week in 8, closing 0.9% lower. Iron ore supply concerns boosted material stocks, with BHP and Rio Tinto rising 2.6% and 1.7% respectively. However, financials like Commonwealth Bank and ANZ fell 0.5% and 0.8% respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% for its worst week in over a year.

site_title: China Dec imports growth slows to 4.5% y-o-y, exports beat forecast at 10.9% y-o-y
summary: China's December imports grew 4.5% year-over-year, missing market expectations, while exports rose 10.9% y-o-y, beating forecasts. The country reported a trade surplus of $54.69 billion for the month. This rebound in trade performance is attributed to strong demand at home and abroad, boosting the global economy. China's exports are contributing to its growth, but its strong appetite for industrial commodities is also driving up resource prices worldwide.

site_title: Mary J Blige gets star on Hollywood Walk of Fame
summary: Mary J. Blige celebrated her 47th birthday with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, honoring her contributions to music and acting. The Grammy-winning singer and self-proclaimed "queen of hip-hop soul" has sold tens of millions of records worldwide and recently earned a Golden Globe nomination for her role in the film "Mudbound." Blige expressed gratitude and appreciation for her career and thanked those who have supported her, including her mentor Sean "Diddy" Combs. The star unveiling ceremony marked a milestone in her illustrious career.

site_title: Thailand expects 12% rise in investment pledges this year
summary: Thailand expects a 12% increase in investment pledges this year, reaching 720 billion baht (S$30 billion), surpassing the 2017 target of 600 billion baht. The country's economic growth is forecast at 3.6-4.6% this year. Japan remains the largest foreign investor, followed by Singapore, China, and the US. Despite lagging regional peers since the 2014 military takeover, the state planning agency projects economic growth, with actual data to be announced on February 19.

site_title: China 2017 trade surplus with US tops US$275b to record high
summary: China's 2017 trade surplus with the US reached a record high of $275.81 billion, surpassing the previous record of $260.8 billion in 2015. The surplus increased due to a decline in overall trade surplus to $422.5 billion. China's December trade surplus with the US was $25.55 billion, down from $27.87 billion in November. The US-China trade imbalance remains a significant concern for policymakers.

site_title: Wing panel falls off Japanese prime minister's jumbo
summary: A panel measuring 38cm x 20cm fell off a Boeing 747 used by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's jumbo jets during a flight from Tokyo to Hokkaido on Thursday. The missing part, near an engine pylon, has not been found. The incident raises concerns about the safety of US military aircraft in Japan. Officials are investigating the cause of the panel's detachment.

images.alt_text: A panel the size of a laptop computer fell off one of the Japanese prime minister's jumbo jets, the defence force said on Friday, a potentially embarrassing mishap amid concern over the dangers posed by parts falling off US military aircraft based in Japan.

site_title: Brazil pledges to forge on with reforms after S&P downgrade
summary: Brazil's government vows to push on with economic reforms despite a downgrade by Standard and Poor's to BB- junk status, citing "slower-than-expected" changes by President Michel Temer's government. The downgrade reflects concerns over fiscal weakness, slow growth, and lack of support for stronger fiscal measures. Despite this, Brazil's economy is projected to grow 2% in 2018, and the government reiterates its commitment to pension reforms and sustainable growth. S&P sees little likelihood of a change in its long-term rating over the coming year.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as supply concerns support iron ore firms; utilities lift NZ
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Friday, driven by iron ore miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto reaching multi-year peaks. Spot iron ore prices surged 1% due to supply concerns triggered by a tropical cyclone in Australia. Despite the gain, the S&P/ASX 200 index is headed for a weekly loss.

site_title: ANZ drops plans to sell unit to HNA after New Zealand blocks deal
summary: ANZ has dropped plans to sell its UDC Finance unit to HNA Group after New Zealand blocked the deal due to concerns over HNA's ownership structure. The deal, valued at US$460 million, was rejected in December by New Zealand's Overseas Investment Office. ANZ had stated it would back out unless the decision was overturned. The bank will now continue to assess its strategic options regarding UDC, citing uncertainty over HNA's governance.

images.alt_text: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group said on Friday it had dropped plans to sell its UDC Finance unit to HNA Group after New Zealand blocked the deal over concerns about the Chinese conglomerate's ownership structure.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as strong yen weighs on sentiment
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Friday due to a strong yen, which weighed on the market, and investors' cautious sentiment ahead of US inflation figures. The Nikkei 225 index declined 0.24% and the Topix index fell 0.63% as major exporters faced selling pressure. The US dollar weakened to 111.22 yen, down from 111.29 yen in New York. Notable gains included Nintendo and Fast Retailing, while Toyota and Sony were among the losers.

site_title: Surging China stocks downplay blockchain links amid crackdown
summary: At least a dozen Chinese listed companies have issued statements downplaying links to blockchain technology amid a crackdown by regulators, who aim to limit speculative surges. Companies such as Hangzhou Sunyard System Engineering Co and Shenzhen Forms Syntron Information Co said blockchain projects have "very little contribution" to their earnings and pose great uncertainty. The move comes as China's regulators seek to curb the enthusiasm for crypto-related stocks, which have surged in recent months. The crackdown aims to prevent "stir-frying" of stocks and speculation on concept stocks.

site_title: GM drops steering wheel, gives robot driver control
summary: General Motors will test its self-driving Chevrolet Bolt in San Francisco's ride-sharing fleets starting in 2019, with the car having no steering wheel or pedals, giving total control to the machine. The test will be the first production-ready car without human intervention. GM has built in redundant systems to back up the driving systems, and the vehicles will travel on a fixed route controlled by their mapping system. The company has filed a petition with the National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration to test the cars, and will need permission from states to run the steering wheel-free cars.

images.alt_text: Next year, General Motors will no longer need an engineer in the front seat babysitting the robot brain that controls its self-driving Chevrolet Bolt. The steering wheel and pedals will be gone, giving total control to the machine.

site_title: Beyond the car: how tech firms are exploring the future of transport
summary: Tech firms are exploring alternative transportation options beyond cars, with electric bicycles, scooters, skateboards, and self-driving vehicles gaining attention at the Consumer Electronics Show. As cities become increasingly congested, companies are developing car-free concepts that prioritize sustainability and convenience. Industry leaders, including Lyft and Ford, believe that car ownership will become less relevant in the future, with autonomous vehicles and ride-sharing services becoming the norm.

images.alt_text: Carless commuting is cruising in the fast lane at the Consumer Electronics Show, with companies showing off electric bicycles, scooters, skateboards and more aimed at making the internal combustion engine a thing of the past.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks tentative, won benefits from euro strength
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index edged lower on Friday, closing at 2,486.64. The Korean won advanced 0.63% against the dollar, driven by the euro's rise after the European Central Bank hinted at stimulus tapering. The US dollar fell 0.09% against the won this year. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.39%. The Kospi is up 0.8% so far this year, with a current price-to-earnings ratio of 12.10 and a dividend yield of 1.28%.

site_title: Brent crude settles below US$70/barrel as global inventories tighten
summary: Oil prices retreated from gains, but settled at three-year highs, with Brent crude futures reaching $70.05 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures reaching $63.80 a barrel. Global inventories tightened, with US crude inventories falling to 419.5 million barrels, and production cuts led by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and Russia underpinning prices. Analysts say the market may not sustain a $70 level unless additional bullish news from the Middle East.

site_title: Chinese bitcoin miners eye sites in energy-rich Canada
summary: Chinese bitcoin mining company Bitmain Technologies is eyeing sites in Quebec, Canada, as the energy-rich province offers an attractive alternative due to China's potential crackdown on cryptocurrency mining. Bitmain is in talks with regional power authorities and plans to expand in Switzerland. Quebec's Hydro Quebec offers low electricity rates, making it an ideal location for large-scale cryptocurrency mining operations. Several companies, including ZQMiner and Resolute Forest Products, are also exploring opportunities in the province, with some expecting operations to begin this year and in early 2019.

site_title: Facebook CEO unveils news feed changes, says engagement may fall
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced changes to the social network's news feed, shifting it back toward personal moments and away from businesses and media outlets. The goal is to help users have more meaningful social interactions. Zuckerberg expects a decrease in time spent on Facebook and some measures of engagement, but believes this will lead to a more valuable user experience in the long term. The changes aim to prioritize posts from friends and family, potentially reducing time spent on the site.

site_title: Taiwan stocks' bull run seen coming to a halt as rates increase
summary: Taiwan's stock market is expected to slow down this year due to rising interest rates and net outflows. Analysts predict the benchmark Taiex may rise to 11,500 before ending the year at 11,000, with half citing rising interest rates and net outflows as the main risks. The performance of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Hon Hai Precision Industry, major suppliers of Apple, will be crucial to the market's performance, with some predicting a potential de-rating of these companies due to disappointing iPhone sales.

site_title: Fidelity values Compass at US$2b in real-estate tech deal
summary: Fidelity Investments has invested $2 billion in Compass, a real-estate tech startup, valuing the company at $2 billion. Compass aims to revolutionize the home-buying process with technology, including a neighborhood data dashboard and a Pinterest-like app for organizing home listings. However, some agents question the effectiveness of the technology, citing similarities to existing tools. Despite this, Compass plans to expand its agent base to 4,000 and offices to 40, and is expected to generate $400 million in revenue this year. The investment is a rare bet on a private company by Fidelity, which has reduced its investments in late-stage startups.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IEV Holdings, SingHaiyi Group, TIH
summary: IEV Holdings, a Catalist-listed offshore engineering company, is exiting its rice-husk biomass business in Vietnam due to a two-year lease-and-sale agreement. SingHaiyi Group will acquire a leasehold estate for S$841 million. TIH Limited faces a potential increase in its net asset value due to a takeover bid valued at over S$60 million, amid an ongoing legal dispute.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian downgrades telco sector to 'market weight' amid impending TPG debut
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded its telecommunications sector outlook from "overweight" to "market weight" due to the impending debut of TPG Telecom, the fourth mobile network operator in Singapore. Analyst Jonathan Koh cited TPG's smooth network deployment and ability to tap into NetLink's backhaul transmission network as reasons for the downgrade. However, Koh still recommended Singtel and NetLink as "buy" calls, citing their defensive positions and potential for growth.

site_title: Merkel's new govt push goes down to wire as parties dig heels in
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's efforts to form a new government in Germany are nearing a deadline, with no agreement in sight between her conservatives and the centre-left Social Democrats. After 18 hours of talks, negotiators said a result is unlikely before dawn, with issues such as the 2015 refugee influx and finances remaining sticking points. Merkel's future and that of her coalition partners, including Social Democrat leader Martin Schulz and Bavarian ally Horst Seehofer, hang in the balance, with a survey showing only 30% of Germans favouring a return of the grand coalition.

site_title: Bitcoin set for worst weekly slide since 2015 as scrutiny rises
summary: Bitcoin slumped to $13,019, on track for its worst weekly performance in three years, as regulators worldwide stepped up scrutiny over investor losses and potential strains on power systems. The token is down 33% from its mid-December peak, amid concerns over fraudulent uses and increased costs for bitcoin mining due to China's crackdown. The US Securities and Exchange Commission will hold a hearing in February to discuss risks tied to bitcoin, following similar moves by South Korea and other countries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up to extend record run
summary: Hong Kong shares opened higher on Friday, extending a record run of 13 straight gains for the benchmark Hang Seng Index. The index rose 0.57% to 31,298.05. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.46% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.09%. The record rally comes despite US tariff threats and concerns about global economic growth.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to invest US$1b, pay bonuses on US tax cut
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles is investing US$1 billion in a Michigan truck factory and paying US$2,000 bonuses to 60,000 US workers following the US tax cut. The move aims to boost the company's cause amid potential disruptions to the North American Free Trade Agreement and increased pressure from US President Donald Trump. The investment will also add 2,500 jobs at the factory near Detroit to produce heavy-duty Ram pickups. The company's CEO, Sergio Marchionne, sees the investment as a way to "pump money right into the economy" and signal the administration's efforts to hire more US workers.

site_title: Japan PM heads to Europe amid North Korea tensions
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is visiting the Baltic states and other European nations to promote his hawkish stance on North Korea. Despite recent tensions easing ahead of the Winter Olympics in South Korea, Abe aims to maximize pressure on Pyongyang. He will meet with six European leaders, including representatives from over 30 companies, to develop business ties and counter China's growing influence in the region. The visit aims to raise Japan's profile and counter China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative. Abe's tour concludes on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Japan's prime minister on Friday headed to the Baltic states and other European nations as he seeks to drum up support for his hawkish stance on North Korea.

site_title: Lufthansa beats BA to become Europe's 2nd biggest airline
summary: Lufthansa surpassed British Airways owner IAG to become Europe's second-largest airline, driven by a 15% surge in passenger traffic last year following significant takeovers, including full control of Brussels Airlines and leasing of Air Berlin planes. Lufthansa now carries more passengers than Ryanair Holdings, and its passenger traffic surpasses IAG. Air France-KLM remains the region's largest carrier with a 5% growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.26 points to 1,825.14. The market saw 177 gainers and 43 losers, with a trading volume of 79.09 million lots worth RM31.93 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat despite US record close
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on January 12, 2018, despite a record close in US stocks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.04% to 23,719.78, while the Topix index opened down 0.13% to 1,885.55. A higher yen weighed on the market, but US stocks had reached record highs earlier in the day amid concerns over US tariff threats.

site_title: Facebook, Alphabet shifted in sector classification system
summary: Facebook and Alphabet will be added to the newly broadened "Communication Services" sector, alongside Comcast and Netflix, following a change in the Global Industry Classification Standard. The sector overhaul aims to reflect changes in industries resulting from technology and acquisitions. Other companies, including Twitter, Snap, Walt Disney, and DISH Network, will also join the Communications Sector. The changes will impact sector-specific indexes and funds tracking the new categories, with the updates implemented on September 28, 2018.

site_title: Tencent sells US$5b bond, drawing comparison to Alibaba
summary: Tencent Holdings sold $5 billion in US dollar bonds, marking its largest US dollar offering since 2015 and drawing comparisons to Alibaba's $7 billion debt sale in November. The bonds priced at 65-105 basis points above US Treasuries, with spreads narrowing to 6bp. Tencent has a lower net cash position and higher gross leverage compared to Alibaba, but analysts expect the difference in credit metrics to narrow due to Alibaba's aggressive acquisition strategy. The bonds received orders of over $41 billion, with investors expecting close trading between Tencent and Alibaba bonds.

images.alt_text: Tencent Holdings sold US$5 billion bonds, the company's biggest US dollar offering and the first time its issued debt since 2015, drawing comparisons to the debt of internet giant Alibaba Group Holding.

site_title: Euro soars after ECB says it could revisit policy message soon
summary: The euro surged 0.77% against the dollar after the European Central Bank hinted it may soon adjust its policy stance, potentially reducing its vast monetary stimulus program. The ECB's decision is seen as a hawkish tilt, boosting expectations of interest rate hikes and a broader revision of policy guidance. This move has lifted euro bulls' confidence, while the dollar index fell 0.5% amid weak US producer prices and declining costs for services.

site_title: Joe Tan
summary: Philanthropist Joe Tan, a former army regular, co-founded Love Action Project (LAP), a social enterprise in Singapore that creates sustainable social-giving programs and events. Tan's experiences in the military inspired him to become a social entrepreneur, with the goal of empowering people to do good and raise awareness of social causes. LAP has organized over 20 social events, raising over $550,000 for 30 non-profit organizations. Tan's efforts aim to inspire Singaporeans to turn volunteering into a way of life, bridging the gap between the public and social causes.

site_title: Two men on the run, all jewels recovered after Ritz heist
summary: Two men on the run are the last of the robbers involved in a multimillion-euro heist at the Ritz hotel in Paris, where all of the stolen jewels and watches have been recovered. Three men, all around 30 years old, were arrested during the getaway attempt and are known to police for armed robbery and violent crime. The robbers, armed with hatchets and handguns, burst into the hotel and smashed display windows before fleeing. A police hunt for the remaining two robbers continues, with one suspect dropping a bag of jewels during a getaway on a motorbike.

site_title: Style Deal
summary: JOSEPH, a British fashion brand, has strengthened its cult-like following under creative director Louise Trotter. The label focuses on luxurious uniforms with elegant, classic cuts and high quality. To celebrate, subscribers can receive an exclusive 10% off their Spring Summer 2018 pre-collection at JOSEPH Capitol Piazza.

site_title: Intel says patches can cause reboot problems in old chips
summary: Intel says patches for security flaws in its chips could cause reboot problems in older Broadwell and Haswell processors, affecting customers with these chips. The company is working to diagnose and address the issue and may need to issue revised firmware updates. Intel had previously asked some cloud computing customers to hold off installing patches due to bugs in the updates, but now acknowledges the issue and is taking steps to resolve it.

site_title: Trump could use Nafta withdrawal letter as negotiating leverage
summary: US President Donald Trump could use a NAFTA withdrawal letter as negotiating leverage in talks to update the 24-year-old trade pact. The letter would start a six-month exit clock, but the US would not be legally bound to quit the agreement once it expires. This move could give Washington more negotiating power over Canada and Mexico, potentially leading to a more favorable agreement.

site_title: SingHaiyi wins S$841m en bloc tender for Park West near Clementi MRT
summary: SingHaiyi Group has won a S$841 million en bloc tender for a property in the west of Singapore, known as Park West, near Clementi MRT station. The 99-year leasehold estate has a land area of 58,867 square meters and a plot ratio of 2.1. The joint-venture firm plans to redevelop the site, which can yield about 1.33 million square feet of gross floor area. The acquisition is the third attempt at a sale by the property owners, and the firm intends to apply for a fresh 99-year lease and lift certain title restrictions.

site_title: Europe: Results drive sharp moves in stocks as euro weighs
summary: European shares declined 0.3% on Thursday, following a sell-off in bond markets and a stronger euro, amid disappointing results from retailers Tesco and Marks & Spencer. The European Central Bank's minutes showed the ECB may end asset purchases in September, and the euro's rise put pressure on Eurozone indexes. Britain's FTSE 100 touched a record high, while Pandora fell 11% after reporting lower-than-expected revenue. Investors expect earnings growth this year, with the retail sector falling 1.3% and bank stocks rising 0.4%.

site_title: Shopper360 H1 earnings up 31% to RM4.6m
summary: Shopper360's first-half net profit rose 31% to RM4.61 million, driven by a 6% increase in revenue to RM68.8 million. Earnings per share grew to 4.03 sen, and net asset value per share rose to RM40.95. Revenue growth was attributed to increased contributions from existing and new customers in in-store advertising and field force management segments. The company expressed cautious optimism about its performance for the year ending May 2018 and announced new joint ventures and expanded digital marketing services.

site_title: BM Mobility makes S$284,000 offer for stake in Malaysian electric car-sharing company
summary: BM Mobility Ltd, a Singapore-listed company, has made an S$284,000 offer to acquire a majority stake in Malaysian electric car-sharing company UNiRide Ecotour Sdn Bhd. The proposed acquisition, valued at RM850,000, is part of BM Mobility's expansion into Malaysia's electric car-sharing business. The deal is expected to be finalized by January 31, with BM Mobility planning to expand UNiRide's fleet and find more university partners in Malaysia.

site_title: InterContinental exits Nigeria after fallout with partners
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group is withdrawing from Nigeria due to a disagreement with local partners over the terms of bringing a Lagos hotel out of receivership. The 358-room hotel will cease operations on January 18. The exit follows other companies struggling in Nigeria, including Etisalat, which gave up a stake in its Lagos unit in June. IHG remains committed to Africa, operating hotels in South Africa, Mauritius, and Zambia.

site_title: Far East H-Reit to buy Oasia Hotel Downtown in Tanjong Pagar for S$210m
summary: Far East Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is buying the 314-room Oasia Hotel Downtown in Tanjong Pagar for S$210 million in cash. The 65-year leasehold property will be funded by debt facilities and reinvestment of distributions. The acquisition aims to benefit from potential growth in leisure demand and tourism in Singapore, according to the Reit's manager. A further S$15 million worth of stapled securities may be issued if the building's net property income reaches S$9.9 million for two consecutive fiscal years by end-2023.

site_title: Japan starts chicken cull after confirming bird flu outbreak
summary: Japan has begun a cull of 91,000 chickens in Kagawa prefecture after confirming a highly contagious form of bird flu on a farm. This marks the country's first cases of bird flu in poultry this winter. The outbreak, which was first reported earlier in the week, follows previous culls of 1.67 million chickens due to the H5N6 strain of bird flu between 2016 and 2017. The local government and Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries are taking measures to control the spread of the disease.

images.alt_text: Japan's western Kagawa prefecture has begun a cull of 91,000 chickens after the discovery of a highly contagious form of bird flu on a farm, the local government said.

site_title: S&P cuts Brazil credit rating as pension reform doubts grow
summary: Standard & Poor's cut Brazil's credit rating to BB- from BB, citing less timely and effective policymaking and policy uncertainty after this year's elections. The downgrade, with a stable outlook, brings Brazil's long-term sovereign rating three notches below investment grade. The decision follows delayed pension reform, which was initially expected last year, and is seen as a warning of economic and social consequences if reform is not approved. The downgrade reflects concerns about Brazil's fiscal deficit and policymaking effectiveness.

site_title: Larger Than Life
summary: Downsizing, a dramedy directed by Alexander Payne, is now in cinemas, exploring a near-future where Earth's overpopulation is solved by shrinking people to five inches tall. The film stars Matt Damon and features a Golden Globe nomination for Hong Chau's role as a Vietnamese activist. The movie delves into themes of social commentary and satire, offering a unique take on the human condition amidst a futuristic world. Downsizing is a timely release, coinciding with the start of awards season.

site_title: Gold nears 4-month highs after hawkish ECB boosts euro
summary: Gold prices approached a four-month high after the European Central Bank's December meeting minutes showed a hawkish tone, boosting the euro and weakening the dollar. The minutes suggested the ECB may adjust its policy message and wind down its bond-buying program, potentially increasing demand for gold. The weaker dollar, coupled with a dip in global equities and rising industrial metals, also supported gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices on Thursday approached a four-month high set on the previous day after minutes of a European Central Bank meeting showed a more aggressive tone and boosted the euro against the US dollar.

site_title: Cyclical stocks seen doing great again this year
summary: Cyclical stocks, including tech, property, and consumer discretionary sectors, led broader gains in 2017, with a 35% total return. Analysts predict a similar trend in 2018, provided there are no surprise cooling measures for property stocks. Experts point to potential catalysts such as a reversal in private home rents and en bloc sales windfalls, which could boost the construction sector and liquidity.

site_title: UK won't pay to access single market post-Brexit: Government
summary: The UK government has ruled out paying the European Union to access the single market after Brexit, as Prime Minister Theresa May reassured finance sector players. The decision comes after a Bloomberg report suggested the EU might require Britain to pay for financial companies to access European markets. Finance ministers and executives from global banking institutions met with May to discuss the impact of Brexit on the financial sector, with a focus on minimizing disruption and promoting the benefits of the UK's financial centre.

site_title: Indie Indulgence
summary: Fleet Foxes, a Seattle baroque folk-pop group, is set to perform in Singapore this weekend, marking their first time in the country. The band is supporting their highly acclaimed third album "Crack Up," released in June. The 2018 Laneway Music Festival will also take place on January 27, featuring artists such as Slowdive and Obedient Wives Club.

site_title: Five women accuse James Franco of sexual misconduct: report
summary: Five women have accused Hollywood star James Franco of sexually inappropriate behavior, including exploitative behavior during nude scenes and pressuring a woman into performing oral sex. The allegations include four former students at his film school who claim he removed protective guards during a nude scene, and a fifth woman who says he pressured her into oral sex. Franco and his lawyers have denied the accusations, with one attorney stating the allegations are "not accurate."

images.alt_text: Five women have publicly accused Hollywood star James Franco of sexually inappropriate behaviour, The Los Angeles Times reported Thursday, just days after the actor triumphed at the Golden Globes.

site_title: Tat Hong boss, StanChart PE intend to take crane supplier private with S$0.50/share offer
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a mainboard-listed crane supplier, is set to be privatized by StanChart PE with a S$0.50/share offer, an 11.1% premium over the stock's closing price. The offeror, THSC Investments, has secured undertakings from 59.74% shareholders and aims to acquire 90% of shares to make the offer unconditional. The deal will be led by Tat Hong CEO Roland Ng's family, holding 68.8%, with SCPE holding 31.2%. The offer aims to provide flexibility to manage the business and optimize resources.

site_title: Intel says chip-security fixes leave PCs no more than 10% slower
summary: Intel released test results showing that personal computers will not be significantly affected by chip security patches, with a 10% slowdown on typical tasks. The updates, covering three generations of processors from 2015, were made to address widespread vulnerabilities discovered by Google researchers. Intel's assessment contrasts with Microsoft's more pessimistic views on servers, which form the backbone of corporate networks. The company plans to share more data on server platforms in the coming days. The patches aim to prevent hackers from accessing sensitive data through these vulnerabilities.

site_title: Armed robbers seize jewels worth 4m euros from Ritz hotel in Paris
summary: Armed robbers targeted the Ritz hotel in Paris, making off with an estimated 4 million euros worth of jewels. The gang of five men arrived at the hotel, smashed windows, and stole the jewels. Three were detained, while two remain at large. The incident is the latest in a string of high-profile heists in Paris, with similar incidents occurring in 2016. The French authorities have launched a probe into the armed robbery, praising the professionalism of the officers involved.

site_title: Manhattan office rents expected to rise in 2018: Cushman
summary: Manhattan office rents are expected to rise in 2018 due to the largest amount of new construction since the 1980s, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Demand is likely to outpace the US average, driven by the city's desirability for young professionals and the overall growth of the US economy. The vacancy rate is expected to rise slightly, but new construction will push overall asking rents higher, with new Class A construction rents reaching over $100 per square foot. This marks the second-highest level of office leasing activity in 17 years.

site_title: Stock markets could go higher still in 2018: DBS
summary: DBS Private Bank's chief investment officer Hou Wey Fook expressed optimism about the stock market, stating it may continue to rise in 2018. This reassurance comes from a speech to clients on the bank's investment outlook for the first half of the year. No specific market data or indicators were mentioned, but Hou's comments suggest a positive outlook for the market.

site_title: Brexit caused 37% fall in new London financial jobs in December: report
summary: A report by Morgan McKinley found that Brexit caused a 37% decline in new London financial jobs in December, with 3,150 jobs available compared to 5,010 in December 2016. This decline was attributed to uncertainty around the terms of Britain's exit from the EU. If Britain is denied access to Europe's single market, around 10,000 finance jobs may be shifted out of the country or created overseas. The UK's economy is also at risk of a "lost decade" of low growth and investment, with London's mayor warning of nearly 500,000 job losses if a trade deal is not agreed.

site_title: Power-hungry bitcoin overtakes electric cars
summary: Miners of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies could require up to 140 terawatt-hours of electricity in 2018, about 0.6% of the global total, surpassing expected power demand from electric vehicles in 2025. This could drive growth for renewable energy producers and companies investing in wind and solar power, with potential beneficiaries including big oil companies and green-power developers. Hydro-Quebec, Canada's largest electric utility, is in talks with over 30 cryptocurrency miners to secure power from its hydroelectric dams.

site_title: China Premier sees GDP growth of 6.9 per cent for 2017
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang announced that China's GDP growth is expected to have reached 6.9% in 2017, accelerating from a 26-year low in 2016. The growth is attributed to a construction boom, robust global demand for Chinese exports, and the country's cautious approach to stimulus, which helped reduce debt risks. China's total debt in the second quarter of last year was 255.9% of GDP, but the country's corporate leverage ratio declined steadily. The official 2017 GDP data is set to be published on January 18, with policymakers aiming to maintain a 6.5% growth target in 2018.

site_title: Can Olympics turn around Korean tensions in 2018?
summary: North Korea has confirmed it will send athletes and cheerleaders to the 2018 Winter Olympics in South Korea, a move seen as a potential geopolitical dividend after a recent mini-rapprochement between the two nations. The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's New Year message sparked a thaw in relations, with the two nations reopening a diplomatic hotline and temporarily lifting sanctions. However, tensions between Pyongyang and Washington remain high, and the US is considering intensifying international pressure on North Korea through military options or further sanctions.

site_title: EU launches 1b euro supercomputing plan without the UK
summary: The European Union has launched a 1 billion euro plan to boost its supercomputing capabilities, aiming to catch up with China, the US, and Japan. The initiative, which will be implemented over several years, is seen as a response to the UK's potential exit from the EU following Brexit. British computer scientists are anxious that the UK may miss out on opportunities from the plan. The EU's move is also seen as a way to maintain its technological competitiveness in the face of growing global competition.

site_title: Java Jive
summary: Asia's largest specialty coffee e-tailer, Cafebond.com, has opened a retail store, "The Bean Shop", allowing customers to pick up freshly roasted coffee beans from over 20 top cafes and roasters worldwide. The store, located at Millenia Walk, offers a Click and Collect service to save on shipping costs. This expansion aims to make high-quality coffee more accessible to customers.

site_title: Digital transformation starts from the top
summary: Singapore's digital transformation is crucial for its Smart Nation initiative, but boards of directors often struggle to lead the charge. The key to success lies in appointing board members with strong digital experience and aligning them with management on the execution of digital transformation strategy. Boards must lead courageous conversations, ask tough questions, and re-evaluate the external environment to create greater value for customers and generate new revenue streams. By enabling the management team in five key stages of the journey, boards can drive digital transformation and achieve long-term value creation.

site_title: US: Stocks finish at all-time highs
summary: US stocks closed at all-time highs on Thursday, driven by gains in industrial and petroleum-linked equities. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8% to 25,574.73, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.7% and 0.8%, respectively. The upward climb resumed after a one-day pullback, with the rally attributed to traders brushing off new US trade threats.

site_title: France decries 'dysfunction' in baby milk recall
summary: France has criticized the recall of baby milk due to salmonella contamination, calling it a "major dysfunction" as stores continued to sell potentially contaminated products despite the order to remove them. French President Emmanuel Macron has demanded those responsible be punished. Lactalis, a major dairy producer, initiated the recall in December after discovering salmonella at its factory in Craon, northwest France.

site_title: SGX must be vigilant in a modified quarterly reporting regime
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has released a consultation paper on modifying its mandatory quarterly reporting (QR) regime, which has been in place for almost a year. The proposed changes aim to fine-tune the current system, rather than eliminating it, and include raising the threshold for companies required to issue quarterly financial statements from S$75 million to S$150 million. The regime also considers allowing minority shareholders to vote every three years on whether a company can opt out of quarterly reporting, but some experts warn that this could set a precedent for other exemptions. The SGX will need to remain vigilant in ensuring smaller companies fulfill their continuous disclosure requirements.

site_title: Dining Dreams
summary: Japanese food TV shows, including Kantaro: The Sweet Tooth Salaryman, Samurai Gourmet, and Solitary Gourmet, have gained popularity for their explicit portrayal of food and traditional Japanese desserts. Despite cheesy storylines and fantasy scenes, viewers enjoy the real-life sweet shops and history of the desserts featured. These shows are available on Netflix and online, offering a unique culinary experience for food enthusiasts. While storylines may be boring, the climax of each episode makes the experience worthwhile for fans of Japanese cuisine.

site_title: The grim reality of Hollywood's gender pay gap
summary: Michelle Williams was paid significantly less than her co-star Kevin Spacey for the film All the Money in the World, highlighting the persistent Hollywood gender pay gap. Williams was initially set to star alongside Spacey but had her scenes reshoot after allegations of misconduct against him surfaced. The incident sparked renewed calls for an end to sexual harassment and assault in all industries. The Golden Globes appearance with activist Tarana Burke further emphasized the need for change, with Williams' statement shifting the focus back to the Me Too movement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TIH Limited flagged uncertainty over its net asset value due to an ongoing legal dispute over its Mitsui Life Insurance stake. The dispute could impact the value of its shares, which were offered at a premium of 9.6% to the referred NAV. Meanwhile, BreadTalk Group priced S$100 million of five-year notes at 4% coupon, to be used for general corporate purposes. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Dancing Queen
summary: Rose Eberwein, a talented dancer, single-handedly put Singapore on the global dancing map. She started teaching dance in Singapore after learning traditional and local forms while teaching at a local school and later at the Royal Academy of Dance in London. Eberwein set up her own school, the Rose Eberwein School of Dancing, in 1959, and became the artistic director for Singapore's National Theatre Dance Company in 1969. Her contributions to Singapore's dance scene earned her recognition, solidifying her legacy as the country's most famous dancer.

site_title: New Year, New You
summary: New exercise and eating habits are being promoted in Singapore to kick-start the new year. Absolute Cycle, a cycling studio from Thailand, has opened in Singapore with rhythm cycling classes that burn 500-800 calories per session. Quorn, a meat-free product, is also gaining popularity for its health benefits and environmental advantages. Meanwhile, Pure Fitness Ngee Ann City has launched a new gym with immersive features such as virtual reality cycling and a 270° Immersive Fitness studio. A new meal-replacement powder called Lembas has also been introduced, offering a quick and nutritious solution for busy individuals.

site_title: Men's Spring/Summer 2018 Trend Report
summary: The article discusses the Men's Spring/Summer 2018 Trend Report, highlighting key fashion looks from top designers. The 80s Dad look is reimagined with updated pairings of white shirts, striped shirts, and oversized blazers. Fendi incorporates similar elements with its own line of caps, utility outerwear, and high-waist trousers. The article showcases how to incorporate these styles into everyday fashion, offering a fresh take on classic 80s trends.

site_title: Audi launches premium car rental service in Singapore
summary: Audi Singapore has launched its premium car rental service, Audi On Demand, with an initial fleet of 10 vehicles. The service, available in Singapore, allows customers to rent the latest Audi models, with a dedicated concierge delivering and retrieving the vehicle within two hours. Audi plans to expand the fleet and introduce a full chauffeur service in a few months. The service is available for a minimum of four hours and up to 28 days, with prices starting at S$76. The launch comes as Singapore considers a carbon tax, which could influence the pricing of vehicles available on the service.

site_title: NTU partners Volvo to develop driverless electric buses
summary: NTU and Volvo have partnered to develop driverless, electric buses set to begin testing in Singapore in early 2019. Volvo will provide two 12-metre, 40-seater buses with autonomous driving technologies. The partnership aims to improve public transportation and reduce emissions in Singapore. The buses are expected to be fitted with battery-powered electric motors and will operate without human drivers.

site_title: Trump Place asks if it can be called by any other name
summary: A New York City condominium, Trump Place, is seeking a state Supreme Court ruling to remove its large, brass-like letters bearing the name "T-R-U-M-P" from its building, citing a desire for a more dignified name. The letters were included in a licensing agreement signed in 2000 with DJT Holdings, a corporate entity owned by US President Donald Trump. The condominium's board argues that the agreement only requires them to use the name, not display it, and seeks a declaratory judgment to remove the letters without violating the agreement.

site_title: Investing in virtue, with BT Weekend
summary: Investing in companies with fair labor practices, corporate governance, and environmental sustainability is becoming increasingly mainstream. The article explores the growth of ethical investing, highlighting its expansion into the mainstream. It also features business mentor John Bittleston's conversation on the importance of corporate purpose and social responsibility. The article aims to encourage readers to consider the impact of their investments on the environment and society, promoting a more sustainable and responsible approach to investing.

site_title: Little Mermaid For Our Times
summary: Theatre writer-director Edith Podesta presents "The Immortal Sole", a reinterpretation of Hans Christian Andersen's "The Little Mermaid". The work questions what women have gained and lost throughout history, comparing it to the Mermaid's sacrifice of her voice for legs. The play will be performed at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from Jan 19-20, with tickets available at S$27 from Sistic. This marks Podesta's latest creative endeavor after winning the M1-The Straits Times Life Theatre Awards in 2017.

site_title: French energy giant Total leases over 100,000 sq ft at Frasers Tower
summary: French energy giant Total has leased over 100,000 sq ft at Frasers Tower in Singapore, with pre-commitments reaching over 70% of the building. Other recent signings include Japanese cosmetics group Shiseido and Sumitomo Corporation. The 38-storey development will have 664,000 sq ft of net lettable office space, with market watchers expecting high single-digit and double-digit per square foot monthly rents for the remaining space. Frasers Centrepoint aims to capitalize on the current uptick in the office market, with CBRE and JLL serving as joint marketing agents.

site_title: Short Takes
summary: Yeng Pway Ngon, a renowned Singaporean writer, has published a collection of short stories titled "The Non-Existent Lover And Other Stories." Translated from Mandarin by his wife Goh Beng Choo, the collection showcases Yeng's journey as a fiction writer from social critiques to experimental micro-fiction. The 26-volume author, now 70, remains a compelling and important writer, with some stories proving to be gems. The collection is available in bookstores, offering a faster introduction to Yeng's writing.

site_title: New 'emotional' robots to read human feelings
summary: Robots are being developed to acquire "emotional intelligence" and empathy, enabling them to read human feelings and respond accordingly. Devices such as Forpheus, a ping pong robot, and Honda's 3E-A18 robot, showcase this technology. Other robots, like Pepper and Sanbot, are being "humanized" by teaching them to interpret emotional states. Developing emotional intelligence in robots is a challenging task, but holds promise in areas such as healthcare and sports, particularly in regions with aging populations like Japan.

site_title: US airlines set to gain as fares trend higher on higher fuel costs
summary: US airlines are expected to gain in 2018 due to stepped-up pricing power, steady economic growth, and a boost from the US tax overhaul. Delta Air Lines and Alaska Air Group are projected to rise 20% or more, while American Airlines, Southwest Airlines, and United Continental Holdings are set for smaller gains. Higher fuel costs will benefit airlines by prompting them to focus on raising fares and reducing capacity expansion, which could be bad news for passengers but good for investors.

site_title: Public works, en bloc projects to fuel 2018 building demand
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore projects S$26 billion to S$31 billion in construction contracts for 2018, up from S$24.5 billion in 2017. Public sector projects, expected to grow from S$15.5 billion to S$19 billion, will contribute to the higher demand, while private sector projects are also anticipated to increase, driven by a stronger economic outlook and improved property market sentiment. Key projects expected to be awarded this year include the North-South Corridor, new MRT works, and public housing construction.

site_title: Champagne - not just for special occasions
summary: The article discusses the author's fondness for Pol Roger Winston Churchill champagne, a deluxe champagne typically reserved for special occasions. The author recalls purchasing a bottle in 1975 and has been saving it for a future celebration. Although the author was unable to find the champagne at a London restaurant, they were content with the house champagne instead. The article does not provide a specific conclusion or key takeaway, instead focusing on the author's personal experience with the champagne.

site_title: 'Grungy' label unfair for eatery, especially when our food has earned 'good reviews'
summary: A Singaporean eatery, Uni Gallery, has responded to a negative review by a food critic, claiming the label "grungy" was unfair and overly snobbish. The restaurant, which serves modern-casual Japanese cuisine, disputes the notion that its location beneath an office building is inferior to fine-dining establishments. It points out that its air-flown sashimi and uni have earned good reviews and that customers appreciate the value for money. The restaurant's general manager, Jason Ong, accuses the critic, Jaime Ee, of being unfair and insulting to customers who know value when they see it.

site_title: Architectural Stunner
summary: Bulgari introduces the B.zero1 Labyrinth collection, featuring a unique design that appears differently depending on the viewer's perspective, with rose gold at the top and white gold at the bottom. The design is inspired by the late Zaha Hadid's Design Legend Edition. Four designs are available, set to be released in stores from February.

site_title: Cracking the customer loyalty code in a mobile-first world
summary: A small business owner in Singapore can crack the customer loyalty code by leveraging the rise of vicinity-driven rewards, which offer targeted and timely promotions to customers based on their location. This approach can be achieved through partnerships with platforms like Facebook and Grab, which provide location data and vast user bases. By using this data to deliver personalized experiences and surprise customers with delightful rewards, businesses can build brand love and drive loyalty. Effective mobile-first strategies can also be implemented to cut through the clutter and make a real difference in the market.

site_title: Nvidia updates software, says graphic chips not hit by flaws
summary: Nvidia updates its software drivers for graphics processors in response to the Spectre security threat, but CEO Jensen Huang claims its chips are not affected. The company's GPUs interact with potentially vulnerable CPUs, prompting the update. Nvidia's shares initially fell but rebounded after Huang's comments, while Intel shares dropped 2.5% and AMD gained 1.2%. Security patches are being released for devices, but the full extent of affected devices is not yet known.

site_title: Australian retail sales surge in November on iPhone, Black Friday spree
summary: Australian retail sales surged 1.2% in November from October, the largest monthly rise in four years, driven by sales of Apple iPhones and Black Friday promotions. The surprise boost helped counter concerns about sluggish spending and strengthened the Australian dollar. Household goods and other retailing saw significant gains, with online sales estimated to have surged 22% in November. The improved retail performance is expected to boost the outlook for gross domestic product growth in the fourth quarter, with household spending accounting for 57% of annual economic output.

site_title: NZ house prices up as buyers rush to beat curbs
summary: New Zealand house prices rose 6.6% year-on-year in December 2017, marking the second consecutive month of growth, as buyers rushed to beat planned government regulations targeting property speculators. The robust growth contrasts with a slowdown in the middle of the year due to election uncertainty. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has vowed to ease macro-prudential mortgage lending curbs, expected to improve housing activity and demand in the coming months.

site_title: Toyota, Mazda to build US$1.6b plant in Huntsville, Alabama
summary: Toyota and Mazda announced plans to build a $1.6 billion joint assembly plant in Huntsville, Alabama, employing up to 4,000 workers and producing 300,000 vehicles annually. The plant, set to open in 2021, will produce Corolla cars and Mazda crossover SUVs. Alabama will provide $370 million in state tax incentives, while Toyota plans to build Corollas and Mazda will build crossovers. The move is seen as a boost for President Donald Trump, who wants carmakers to expand US production, despite US car sales declining 2% in 2017.

site_title: Bubbles in a frothy world economy
summary: A global economy bubble, fueled by unorthodox monetary policy, is pervasive, with bubbles in housing, credit, and government bond markets in major economies. Long-term interest rates are at historic lows, while global equity valuations are at levels experienced only three times in the last century. The world is more indebted than before the 2008 crisis, and policymakers lack experience to respond to a potential bubble burst. The US banking system's regulatory improvements are overstated, as shadow banks play a significant role in intermediating credit. A global bubble bursting could have severe consequences, with policymakers facing a daunting task in responding to the crisis.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thai Beverage Plc has acquired a 53.6% stake in Vietnamese beer company Sabeco for S$6.4 billion, increasing its net gearing and potentially leading to a downgrade in credit ratings. Fitch and Moody's have placed ThaiBev under review. Meanwhile, Banyan Tree Holdings' resort in Hue, Vietnam, has obtained approval to build a casino, which is expected to boost the project's value and contribute US$245 million annually to the local budget.

site_title: Bezos' net worth tops US$105b as Amazon climbs in new year
summary: Jeff Bezos' net worth surpassed $105 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, as Amazon's shares surged 6.6% in 2018, lifting the online shopping giant's market value by nearly 57%. Bezos passed Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates' net worth of $93.8 billion in October and crossed the $100 billion mark in November, as Amazon dominated online spending during the holiday season, capturing 89% of online spending among major retailers.

site_title: Producer prices fall for first time in 1 1/2 years
summary: US producer prices fell 0.1% in December for the first time in nearly 1½ years, according to the Labor Department. This decline followed two consecutive monthly increases of 0.4%. The drop is attributed to declining costs for services, marking the first decrease in the producer price index since August 2016.

site_title: One in three companies significantly invested for the future: SBF survey
summary: A survey by the Singapore Business Federation found that one in three companies have invested significant resources to prepare for the future, while one in four remain slow to transform their businesses. This may lead to lacklustre growth and low profitability for the latter group. The survey, which polled 1,019 companies, revealed that 84% of respondents were small and medium-sized enterprises, with the remaining 16% being large firms. The survey's findings highlight the need for businesses to prioritize future-proofing to remain competitive in a rapidly changing market.

images.alt_text: A third of companies here have invested significant resources in preparing for the future, although a notable number are still dragging their feet when it comes to transforming their businesses, according to a new survey.

site_title: LionGold says it may extend talks over debt restructuring
summary: LionGold Corp, one of the trio involved in the 2013 penny stock crash, has been queried by the Singapore Exchange over heavy trading activity. The company plans to discuss extending a debt restructuring proposal tied to S$15.8 million in outstanding debt. The long stop date was Dec 28, 2017, but the company has not obtained shareholder approvals for repayment shares. LionGold intends to extend the deadline for discussions with creditors, despite the long stop date having passed.

site_title: Jumbo's appetite for Asia sets stage for future growth
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singapore-based restaurant chain, is set to aggressively expand its regional presence in the next four to five years. The company has established a presence in key Chinese cities, including Beijing and Shanghai, and plans to open new outlets in Shenzhen and Xi'an. It also aims to grow in other Chinese cities through joint ventures and franchises, with China expected to contribute over 30% of its revenue by FY2020. The company plans to expand into markets such as Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam through franchising, with a focus on establishing new franchises in Taiwan and Indonesia.

site_title: Seoul plans to ban cryptocurrency trading, rattles market
summary: South Korea's government plans to ban cryptocurrency trading, citing concerns over tax evasion and potential addiction. The move, which requires a majority vote in the National Assembly, has sent bitcoin prices plummeting and disrupted the global market. The ban is part of a broader crackdown on cryptocurrency exchanges, which have been raided by police and tax agencies. The decision is seen as a response to the rapid growth of the virtual currency market in South Korea, which has raised concerns among regulators globally.

site_title: Fuss-free eatery in Amoy Street
summary: Kimme, a new eatery in Amoy Street, offers a fuss-free dining experience with a no-nonsense approach. The restaurant, run by the chef of Michelin-starred Meta, serves a range of small and big plates with a focus on Korean and Asian inflections. Menu highlights include the shima aji tartare, two poached prawns, and spanner crab seaweed linguine. While prices are high, the dishes are satisfying and original, making Kimme a reliable option between casual and fine-dining. A rating of 7 is given due to the high price point.

site_title: Going Green
summary: Anantara and AVANI Hotels & Resorts in Asia have switched to using bamboo straws instead of plastic ones, aligning with eco-conscious travelers' preferences. The move, made in partnership with local artist Khamchan Yano, not only reduces plastic waste but also provides local employment. The hotels hope to extend the plastic straw ban to their properties in Australasia, Europe, and the Middle East by the end of the year. This sustainable initiative aims to contribute to a zero-waste future.

site_title: More use of pre-fab, digital tech to boost building productivity
summary: Singapore's government expects another 59 design for manufacture and assembly (DFMA) projects to be tendered out in 2018, aiming to boost productivity in the construction industry. The government aims to achieve 40% adoption of DFMA, up from the current 10%. To support this, the government will create demand by requiring public agencies to consider DFMA adoption and build prefabrication hubs. Additionally, more than 70 projects have already used building information modelling (BIM), and the government targets 40-60 projects adopting integrated digital delivery by 2020.

site_title: Apple iPhone recycler 'attracting Bain, Blackstone, other bidders'
summary: Olympus Capital Asia is pursuing a sale of its stake in iPhone recycling company Li Tong Group, potentially valuing the company at up to $1 billion. Private equity firms Bain Capital and Blackstone Group are among bidders, with tech-focused investment firm Silver Lake also showing interest. Li Tong, which recycles equipment from other manufacturers, has over 20 facilities worldwide and employs over 1,200 people. The sale comes as electronic waste from mobile phones and devices is expected to rise to 52.2 million tonnes by 2021, with only 20% currently recycled.

site_title: HSBC 'hiring from Goldman, JPMorgan' to boost Asia ops
summary: HSBC Holdings is revamping its Asia-Pacific equities business and expanding a majority-owned securities venture in China. The bank has made recent hires from Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, and China International Capital Corp, including Michael Parry, Liu Kang, and Jimmy He. The China joint venture, HSBC Qianhai Securities Ltd, aims to generate $1 billion in pre-tax profit over five years and could have 300 staff within three to four years. The hires and venture are part of outgoing CEO Stuart Gulliver's priority to boost HSBC's China business, which will be crucial for the bank's growth in the region.

site_title: Chefs On A Roll
summary: Two new restaurants are set to open in Singapore in 2018. Woo Wai Leong, a MasterChef Asia winner, is launching his own eatery in North Canal Road, focusing on modern interpretations of Chinese flavors. The restaurant, which is still under construction, will offer separate dining concepts for lunch and dinner and will be funded by Woo and two investors. Anthony Yeoh, a former chef of Cocotte, is also opening a private meal service called Summer Hill, which will cater to small parties at home, providing a hassle-free experience for social gatherings.

site_title: IEV's oilfield exit spurs fears of blow to earnings
summary: CATALIST-listed IEV Holdings is selling its corporate headquarters in Malaysia at a loss, with a transaction price of RM9.2 million (S$3.06 million). The sale is part of a cost-cutting drive following the group's exit from a West Java oilfield in Indonesia, where production was deemed commercially unviable. The move is expected to result in a loss of RM660,000 for IEV, with proceeds going towards settling a related loan and working capital.

site_title: Singapore listed firms still 'weak' in remuneration disclosure: study
summary: A study on remuneration practices by listed companies in Singapore found that disclosure remains weak, with insufficient clarity for stakeholders to make informed decisions. The study, supported by the Singapore Exchange, analyzed 609 companies and found significant gaps in compliance with the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance. Companies with higher remuneration often disclosed less, and those that withheld pay information for fear of poaching were found to have higher remuneration. Recommendations include encouraging transparency and disclosure of remuneration amounts and structures, and setting a good example by disclosing own remuneration.

site_title: Luxury condo sales in Canada hit new high
summary: Luxury condo sales in Canada reached new highs in 2017, with foreign buyers and affluent baby boomers driving growth in major cities like Toronto, Vancouver, and Montreal. Sales of condos above C$1 million surged 59% in Toronto, 27% in Vancouver, and 49% in Montreal, with 2,703 units sold in these cities. This contrasts with a decline in detached sales, which pulled down the overall market. Experts attribute the trend to the growing local economy and job market, as well as the appeal of luxury condos for downsizers and investors.

site_title: US coal's best hope is proposal to cut need for uplift payments
summary: The US coal industry's best hope for a bailout may lie in a proposal by the largest power grid, PJM Interconnection LLC, to overhaul the way generators are paid during peak demand. The plan would allow coal and nuclear plants to set the price of energy when in use, reducing the need for uplift payments, which have boosted revenue for struggling coal plants. While analysts have raised concerns about market prices increasing by $4 per MWh, some coal miners see the proposal as a potential lifeline, with CEO Robert Murray calling it "in the same direction" as Energy Secretary Rick Perry's rejected plan.

images.alt_text: Dozens of US coal plants have closed in recent years as they have struggled to compete with low natural gas prices and a flood of wind and solar farms.

site_title: Fast Retailing posts record Q1 profit on overseas Uniqlo sales
summary: Fast Retailing, parent company of Uniqlo, reported a record Q1 profit of 113.9 billion yen (S$1.36 billion) due to strong overseas sales. The company's Uniqlo business saw a 54.7% increase in operating profit abroad, while domestic sales rose 18.6%. Uniqlo stores outside Japan outstripped domestic sales for the first time. Fast Retailing's operating profit forecast remains unchanged at 200 billion yen for the year. The company's expansion into Asia, particularly China, is expected to continue.

site_title: Securing buy-in from SMEs about industry transformation
summary: Singapore Business Federation CEO Ho Meng Kit expressed concerns that industry transformation maps (ITMs) are "disconnected from the reality of industry", particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). This sentiment echoes the views of many companies, who feel that the ITMs do not accurately reflect the needs and challenges of the business community. Policymakers are advised to take heed of this feedback as the ITMs are central to the government's Future Economy push.

site_title: ITMs enjoy broad support from firms, but work needed to raise awareness: SBF chief
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chief executive Ho Meng Kit stated that there is broad support for the government's Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs), but awareness needs to be raised among companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). A recent SBF survey found that 52% of companies are unaware of ITMs, while a quarter have yet to take significant steps towards business transformation. Ho emphasized the need for strong collaboration between the public and private sectors to reach companies at all stages of transformation.

site_title: Fears of a global selling spree spook investors in bond markets
summary: Global investors are concerned about a potential "selling spree" in bond markets, which could negatively impact record-high equity markets. Central banks' buying binge has driven down interest rates, but a scaling back of this buying could lead to a sharp fall-off in bond prices. China's central bank may be poised to slow or halt its buying of US Treasury bonds, which could worsen the US debt situation and lead to higher interest rates, posing a risk to bond investors.

images.alt_text: Many economists believe that the tax cuts recently signed into law by President Donald Trump could worsen the United States' financial position and make its debt less attractive as an investment.

site_title: SGX set to review mandatory quarterly reporting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is set to review its mandatory quarterly reporting (QR) requirement, which affects 240 companies. The regulator is considering options to reduce compliance costs, including raising the market value threshold from S$75 million to S$150 million, which would exempt 62 companies from QR. Alternatively, companies with a market value above S$150 million and a shareholder with at least 15% stake could be required to report quarterly. SGX expects to implement changes in the second half of this year.

site_title: Euro surges on possible ECB policy revision
summary: The euro surged 0.6% against the dollar after the European Central Bank (ECB) hinted at revising its communication stance in early 2018, potentially signaling a reduction in monetary stimulus. This move boosted expectations of the ECB winding down its bond-buying program, which could lead to a tightening of monetary policy. The euro reached a one-week high of 89.11 pence against the pound, while the dollar struggled to gain traction after losing around 10% against a basket of currencies in 2017.

site_title: Airline Niki submits insolvency filing in Austria
summary: Austrian airline Niki filed for insolvency in Austria on January 11, 2018, in an effort to secure an agreed sale of its Austrian arm to British Airways owner IAG. The filing was made after Germany's Lufthansa scrapped plans to buy Niki, and a Berlin court ruled that Niki was not under German jurisdiction, casting doubt on the IAG deal.

site_title: Europe, Iran to back nuclear deal as Trump decision looms
summary: Europe and Iran are set to unite in support of the 2015 nuclear deal as US President Donald Trump prepares to decide whether to reimpose sanctions on Iran. The European Union and foreign ministers from Britain, Germany, and France will defend the accord, which has been criticized by Trump. Iran has warned of a "heavy response" if the US abandons the deal, while the EU and its partners have urged Trump to keep the agreement. The International Atomic Energy Agency has verified Iran's compliance with the deal, but Trump's decision is expected to have significant implications for global security and relations between the US and Iran.

site_title: Trump's Nafta ideas are 'lose-lose-lose' for carmakers: giant supplier
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed Nafta changes, including increased US car content, could harm carmakers and the entire North American region, according to Magna International CEO Don Walker. The proposal could lead to a "lose-lose-lose" situation, leaving US, Mexican, and Canadian manufacturers vulnerable. The sixth round of Nafta talks in Montreal may result in a strengthened rule of origin for regional automotive content, but Canada believes Trump may withdraw from the pact, prompting contingency plans.
