site_title: IEV enters lease and sale agreement of biomass plant in Vietnam for 34b dong
summary: IEV Holdings Limited's indirect subsidiary in Vietnam entered a 5.995 billion dong two-year lease agreement with BSB Investment and Development for the MK-1 Biomass Plant. The plant's related assets will be sold for 28 billion dong upon lease expiry in January 2023. The move is attributed to low briquette production due to high rice husk prices in 2017. IEV will exit the rice-husk biomass business and refocus on its core engineering business, using the proceeds for working capital.

site_title: LionGold prompts query from SGX, looks to extend debt restructuring deadline
summary: LionGold Corp, involved in the 2013 penny stock crash, was queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) over unusual trading activity. The company plans to discuss extending its debt restructuring deadline, originally set for Dec 28, 2017, tied to an outstanding debt of S$15.8 million. The stock closed flat at S$0.002 after 724 million shares changed hands.

site_title: Claws are out in logo row between Puma and fashion designer Plein
summary: Puma has won a temporary injunction in Germany to stop fashion designer Philipp Plein from selling clothes bearing a tiger logo similar to Puma's leaping cat logo. Plein's company, based in Switzerland, has been accused of copying Puma's design, which features a tiger's head and leaping cat. Plein has responded by offering customers a discount on his branded products in exchange for used Puma shoes, but Puma remains committed to resolving the matter through negotiation rather than escalating the dispute.

site_title: HRnetGroup plans China expansion via JV
summary: HRnetGroup, a Singapore-based recruitment firm, plans to expand into China through a joint venture with REForce (Shanghai) Human Resources Management Consulting Co Ltd. The firm will acquire 51% of REForce for a price determined by the company's net profit for 2017-2019. If REForce meets the profit target, HRnetGroup will extend a S$614,412 loan for operational purposes. The acquisition is conditional on REForce's profitability, with a 5% variance allowed. The deal marks HRnetGroup's expansion into China, following its listing in 2017 and strong third-quarter earnings.

site_title: F&N appoints three new independent directors
summary: Frasers Industrial Holdings (F&N) appointed three new independent directors: Charles Mak, Chan Heng Wing, and Sujittra Sombuntham, effective immediately. Mak is a senior adviser to Morgan Stanley Asia, while Chan was managing director at Temasek Holdings. Sujittra, a medical professional, is based in Thailand.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare expands arbitration proceedings over individual investor
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare is expanding its arbitration proceedings against individual investor David Lin in Singapore. The company will seek additional claims against Mr. Lin for alleged breaches of the share purchase agreement and warranties related to financial statements and hospital ownership. This comes after the Shanghai courts ruled in favor of Weixin Hospital Investment Management, a company controlled by Mr. Lin, in a previous case. OUE Lippo Healthcare has appealed the decision, and the expanded arbitration proceedings will address further claims against Mr. Lin.

site_title: As Nestle cuts down on sugar, world's top producer is beefing up
summary: Germany's Suedzucker AG, the world's top sugar producer, expects to boost output by 30% this season due to the end of European restrictions. The company plans to increase sales to the Middle East and Africa, and has recently shipped sugar to Haiti. This comes as Nestle cuts back on sugar production, shifting focus to other products like coffee and pet food. Global sugar consumption has edged up 0.2% in the past year, with demand growing in Africa and Asia, but declining in the US and Europe due to obesity and diabetes concerns.

site_title: Bursting Heathrow crams more passengers onto bigger jets
summary: Heathrow Airport in London managed to accommodate 2.3 million additional passengers last year by deploying bigger planes and optimizing flight patterns, despite operating its two runways at capacity. Airlines upgauged to larger jets such as the A380 and A350, and airlines squeezed more seats onto existing models. The airport's passenger tally increased 3.1% to 78 million, with load factor rising 2.6 percentage points to over 78%. The airport is preparing for the construction of a £16 billion third runway, which is expected to open in 2025 and lift annual capacity to 135 million flyers.

site_title: Dividend stripping deprives Germany of 5.3b euros in tax
summary: Germany's finance ministry confirmed an investigation into 417 suspected cases of dividend stripping, resulting in 5.3 billion euros of unpaid taxes. The complex scheme, where buyers and sellers claim tax credits, has been ongoing for several years. Authorities have reclaimed 2.4 billion euros of the unpaid taxes, with investigations ongoing.

site_title: STI takes a breather after recent rally
summary: The Singapore bourse took a breather after reaching fresh 2½-year highs, closing 0.2% lower at 3,512.68 due to uncertainty in the US bond market and overnight US market declines. This follows a stellar performance in 2017.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher, shakes off bond market worries
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday, shaking off bond market worries as investors focused on quarterly earnings reports and rising US crude prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.22%, the S&P 500 gained 0.23506%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.21%. These gains come despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: TIH flags uncertainty over Mitsui Life lawsuit
summary: TIH Limited, valued at over S$60 million, flags uncertainty over a lawsuit related to its Mitsui Life Insurance stake. A takeover bid from Argyle Street Management and Lippo China Resources values TIH at S$66.6 million, with the potential for a contingent benefit of S$165 million if TIH wins the lawsuit. TIH has joined the bid, which includes a cash offer and three-year senior unsecured notes, and plans to maintain its listing status in Singapore. The outcome of the lawsuit remains uncertain, affecting TIH's net asset value.

site_title: Bank of England to ease burden of EU insurance rules
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) has proposed easing the burden of European Union capital rules for insurers, including reducing reporting requirements under Solvency II rules. The proposal aims to alleviate the reporting burden for smaller firms and was influenced by recommendations from the Association of British Insurers and the Treasury Select Committee. The PRA will respond to the TSC report at the ABI's annual conference in February, but lawmakers have called for more radical changes, including easing the "risk margin" add-on capital requirement.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip, won sedate against US dollar
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.47% to 2,487.91, while the Korean won remained stable against the US dollar. Bond yields decreased, and foreigners purchased 61 billion won worth of shares. The US dollar rose 0.43% against the won this year, with the won's high at 1,059 per US dollar on January 8.

site_title: Bitcoin ETF fast track derailed by SEC liquidity, safety worries
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has delayed the launch of a dozen bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and two cryptocurrency mutual funds due to concerns over liquidity and safety. The regulator worries that frequently traded ETFs could be tied to potentially illiquid assets, and that funds can be accurately valued when digital coin prices fluctuate. The delay follows the launch of bitcoin futures on major exchanges, which had sparked speculation about the availability of crypto ETFs and mutual funds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed 6.04 points lower at 1,816.88 on Thursday, with 781 losers outweighing 265 gainers. The market saw a low trading volume of four billion lots worth RM3 billion.

site_title: Miyoshi Q1 net profit leaps 129.5 per cent to S$746,000
summary: Miyoshi Limited reported a 129.5% increase in net profit to S$746,000 in its Q1 results, driven by an increase in orders from automotive customers. Revenue rose 4.4% to S$13.8 million, while earnings per share jumped to 0.15 Singapore cents. The company's net asset value per share dipped to 11.24 Singapore cents. Despite the positive earnings, Miyoshi shares closed flat at S$0.076 on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% lower
summary: Singapore's stock market closed 0.2% lower, extending its losses for the second day in a row, with 185 losers outpacing 248 gainers. On Thursday, 3.3 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion exchanged hands, compared to 1.9 billion shares on Wednesday. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Europe: Results drive sharp moves in European stocks
summary: European stocks opened with a hesitant start, driven by concerns over protectionism and a bond market sell-off. The STOXX 600 held steady, while euro zone stocks dipped 0.1% following a previous day's sharp losses. Britain's FTSE 100 touched a fresh record, while Tesco and Marks & Spencer fell after disappointing Christmas sales. Pandora dropped 11% after reporting lower-than-expected revenue, while Hexagon rose 6% after its CEO was cleared of insider trading charges.

site_title: SingHaiyi unit to buy Jalan Lempeng property for S$841m
summary: SingHaiyi Group will purchase the Park West property in Jalan Lempeng for S$841 million after its joint-venture firm's tender was accepted by property owners. The 99-year leasehold estate, spanning 58,867 sq m, features a plot ratio of 2.1. The acquisition is made by Sing-Haiyi Gold, a 50-50 joint venture between SingHaiyi Land and Haiyi Wealth, controlled by Gordon and Celine Tang.

site_title: k1 slides into the red in Q2 with S$3.1m loss
summary: K1 Ventures Limited reported a net loss of S$3.1 million in its second quarter, down from a net profit of S$6.6 million in the same period last year. The decline was primarily due to an increase in other operating expenses and a foreign exchange gain in the prior year. Revenue plummeted 56.9% to S$1.5 million.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB to trim stakes in asset management JV with Principal Financial
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest bank, will sell 20% of its asset management joint venture and 10% of its Islamic asset management unit to US-based Principal Financial Group for 470.3 million ringgit. The transaction, expected to be completed in the second quarter, will leave CIMB with 40% stakes in each entity. CIMB expects a gain of around 950 million ringgit and an improved common equity tier one ratio. The disposal will not affect the bank's consolidated gearing and net assets for the financial year ending December 2018.

site_title: SGX may tweak requirements for quarterly reporting in H2 2018
summary: SGX proposes possible changes to quarterly reporting (QR) to address compliance costs, particularly for smaller companies. The regulator is seeking public feedback on options, including raising the market value threshold for quarterly reporting to S$150 million and allowing minority shareholders to opt out every three years. Simplified report formats and strengthened continuous disclosure regime are also proposed to ease the reporting burden. The public has until February 9 to submit feedback on the proposals.

site_title: Singapore listed companies poor in disclosing pay practices: study
summary: A new report by Mak Yuen Teen found that listed companies in Singapore are poor in disclosing pay practices, with only a few companies, including CapitaLand, Frasers Centrepoint, and Singtel, showing good transparency. The report analyzed 609 companies, revealing weak disclosure of remuneration amounts and unclear components of remuneration. Contrary to the argument that companies withhold pay information to avoid poaching, the study found that companies with higher remuneration tended to be less transparent. The combined remuneration paid by the 609 companies was S$2.5 billion.

site_title: Son of Swee Kee founder fails in suit to claim a quarter of S$16m family home
summary: A Singapore High Court judge has dismissed a lawsuit by the third son of Swee Kee's founder, Moh Tai Siang, to claim a quarter of a S$16 million family home. Tai Siang had alleged that his brothers, Freddy and Royston, were holding his share in trust, but the judge ruled that a 1985 document transferring the share to Freddy and Royston was the only objective evidence available. The dispute is ongoing, with Tai Siang set to sue Freddy again over an office building on Middle Road.

site_title: Bitcoin's upstaging electric cars as bigger source of power use
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts predict that global power consumption for bitcoin mining could reach 140 terawatt-hours in 2018, rivaling Argentina's electricity consumption. This could lead to increased investment in renewable energy and drive growth for companies like NextEra Energy and Hydro-Quebec, which are in talks with cryptocurrency miners. The growth story represents an important opportunity for companies investing in wind, solar power, and energy storage.

site_title: US producer prices post first decline in nearly 1-1/2 years
summary: US producer prices fell 0.1% in December, marking the first decline in nearly 1-1/2 years, according to the Labor Department. The decrease was attributed to declining costs for services. In the 12 months through December, producer prices rose 2.6%, down from a 3.1% increase in November. The drop in producer prices is a positive sign for the US economy, indicating a decrease in inflationary pressures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Hang Seng strikes 13th-day winning streak
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index rose for the 13th consecutive session, closing at 31,120.39, driven by gains in financial shares. Tencent Holdings, the index's heavyweight, fell 2.5% due to losses. The Shanghai Composite index rose 0.11% and the CSI300 index fell 0.05%. This marks the 13th day of consecutive gains for the Hang Seng index, offsetting losses in other Asian markets.

site_title: ECB sees chance of gradual shift in guidance early this year
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering a gradual shift in its policy guidance, potentially aligning with a strengthening economy. This move could lead to a rise in the euro and increased bond yields. The ECB's decision to extend quantitative easing until at least September, despite a faster economic expansion, has sparked speculation about the bank's readiness to scale back its monetary stimulus. A gradual shift in guidance is seen as a way to evolve the ECB's communication without changing the sequencing of its policy stance.

site_title: HRnetGroup invests in joint venture to expand further in China
summary: HRnetGroup invests in a joint venture with REForce (Shanghai) Human Resources Management Consulting Co Ltd to expand its presence in China. The acquisition will be made in cash, with the final price determined by REForce's net profit and a "tiered price-earnings multiple". The group will also provide a 3 million yuan loan to REForce for operations. If REForce fails to meet net profit targets for two consecutive years, HRnetGroup can terminate the acquisition.

site_title: Qatar National Bank sells US$720m Formosa bond
summary: Qatar National Bank issued a $720 million, 30-year Formosa bond, marking the latest fundraising effort by Qatari banks to diversify funding resources amid regional diplomatic tensions. This move follows a six-month-old diplomatic rift in the Gulf.

images.alt_text: Qatar National Bank, the Gulf's largest bank, issued a $720 million, 30-year Formosa bond earlier this week, two sources familiar with the matter said.

site_title: China is winning its war on air pollution, at least in Beijing
summary: China's fight against air pollution is showing signs of success, particularly in Beijing, with PM2.5 levels plummeting 33% in the fourth quarter compared to last year. The drop is attributed to government policies forcing millions to switch from coal to natural gas, despite shortages and frigid temperatures. Experts say the switch has dramatically reduced pollution, and anti-coal measures will likely continue, with natural gas demand expected to rise 15% this year.

images.alt_text: China is seeing signs of success in its fight against smog as pollution levels slump dramatically in the capital region Beijing.

site_title: Trump Nafta ideas are 'lose-lose-lose' for carmakers: Magna
summary: US auto supplier Magna International CEO Don Walker warns that overly complex North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) changes could lead to a "lose-lose-lose" situation for US, Mexican, and Canadian manufacturers. The Trump administration's demand for more regional auto content, including 85% Nafta-sourced parts, may hinder negotiations. Canadian officials believe Trump may give six-months' notice to withdraw from the two-decade-old pact, prompting contingency plans. A strengthened rule of origin in regional automotive content is seen as a potential solution, but agreement among all parties remains uncertain.

site_title: Lufthansa climbs past British Airways owner following M&A spree
summary: Lufthansa surpassed British Airways owner IAG to become Europe's second-largest airline, driven by a significant M&A spree. The German carrier's passenger traffic surged 15% last year, surpassing IAG's 3.8% growth. Lufthansa's expansion includes the purchase of Brussels Airlines and the leasing of Air Berlin planes, boosting its customer base. Despite IAG's larger passenger numbers, Lufthansa now ranks ahead by market value, with Air France-KLM remaining the region's largest carrier.

site_title: Bezos's net worth tops US$105b as Amazon climbs in new year
summary: Jeff Bezos's net worth reached $105.1 billion, surpassing Microsoft's Bill Gates' record of $150 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Amazon shares have surged 6.6% this year, lifting the company's market value by 57% and cementing Bezos's position as the world's richest person. The Amazon founder's wealth surpassed Gates in October and crossed the $100 billion mark during the holiday shopping season. Bezos also controls Blue Origin and the Washington Post.

site_title: Gold rises on US dollar weakness, pause in stocks rally
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,318.98 an ounce, extending gains from the previous session, as the US dollar weakened and stocks paused their rally amid concerns over the US administration's protectionist stance. Oil prices held near three-year highs, supporting gold's value as investors seek inflation protection. Analysts predict gold could test $1,327 and $1,362 in the short term, while a stock market correction provides additional support.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose for a second day on Thursday, extending the gains in the previous session when prices climbed to the highest since September, as US dollar weakness and a flagging rally in equities enticed investors to buy the yellow metal.

site_title: World's top-ranked crypto venue added 240,000 users in hour
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, added 240,000 users in an hour, bringing its total registered users to "a couple of million" weekly. The company is limiting new customers due to high demand, with US$6 billion worth of trades hosted over the past 24 hours. CEO Zhao Changpeng expressed confidence in the market, despite Warren Buffett's comments that cryptocurrencies will come to a bad end. Binance is working to receive an exchange license from Japan's Financial Services Agency and is seeing interest from institutional investors.

site_title: Nvidia updates software, says graphic chips not hit by flaws
summary: Nvidia updates its software drivers for graphics processors in response to the Spectre security threat, but CEO Jensen Huang claims its chips are not affected by the same risks as Intel and other companies. The updates relate to software drivers that interact with potentially vulnerable CPUs, rather than the chips themselves. Nvidia's shares rose 0.8% after Huang's comments, while Intel's fell 2.5% and AMD's gained 1.2%. The security patches do not address the Meltdown flaw, and experts warn that Nvidia's driver updates could impact data centers and enterprise customers.

site_title: Westchester home market still sizzles while bracing for tax hit
summary: The Westchester County real estate market in New York continues to thrive despite a tax overhaul that increases costs for homeowners. In the fourth quarter, sales were brisk, with houses selling for a median of $475,000, a 8.4% increase from last year. However, the number of completed sales dropped 5.2% and purchase contracts fell 4.2% for single-family homes. Experts warn that buyers may be wavering, and prices may need to adjust to reflect the higher costs of owning a home in the area.

site_title: German economic growth accelerates less than forecast in 2017
summary: Germany's economy expanded 2.2% in 2017, the fastest pace in six years, but slightly weaker than forecast. This growth rate is the highest since 2011. The country's fiscal surplus reached 1.2% of GDP, the most since reunification. Strong business sentiment and order flows may boost prospects for 2018. Germany is the first of the world's largest developed nations to publish 2017 data, indicating a vibrant performance.

site_title: Sales slow at Japan's 7-Eleven; gains abroad drive owner's Q3 profits
summary: Japan's 7-Eleven parent, Seven & i Holdings, reported a 9.5% profit growth in Q3 despite domestic convenience store sales slowing. The company's reliance on Japan's convenience stores is a concern, as its superstores and department store businesses struggle. This raises pressure on President Ryuichi Isaka, who took the top job in 2016. Overseas sales, however, drove the profit growth.

site_title: South Korea preparing a bill to ban cryptocurrency trading: Justice Minister
summary: South Korea's justice minister announced plans to prepare a bill to ban cryptocurrency trading through exchanges, citing concerns over virtual currencies. The proposed shutdown is expected to be implemented in conjunction with a government task force. No specific details were disclosed about the bill.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) projects S$26 billion to S$31 billion in construction contracts for 2018, up from S$24.5 billion in 2017. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) may tweak quarterly reporting requirements, while the government expects 59 design for manufacture and assembly projects in 2018. Despite strong economic fundamentals, investors remain cautious. Meanwhile, Audi launched its premium car rental service in Singapore, and shares in the Singapore bourse closed 0.2% lower. Internationally, Vietnam was surprised by the Trump tariff announcement, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

images.alt_text: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) on Thursday projected that S$26 billion to S$31 billion in construction contracts could be awarded in 2018, up from the S$24.5 billion estimated to have been awarded in 2017.

site_title: More cold weather poses challenges to US corn ethanol makers
summary: US ethanol production fell sharply for a second week due to cold weather, with output averaging 996,000 barrels per day in the week ended Jan 5. Higher natural gas prices and slower turnaround on rail tanker cars limited production. Ethanol output had previously reached a record high of 1.108 million bpd in early December. US ethanol stockpiles increased to 22.72 million barrels, and demand may not rise significantly until the spring or summer. The recent slowdown may give the US Department of Agriculture pause when releasing its monthly supply and demand report on Friday.

site_title: Public works, en bloc projects to fuel S$26b-S$31b of construction demand in 2018: BCA
summary: Singapore's Building and Construction Authority (BCA) projects S$26 billion to S$31 billion in construction contracts for 2018, up from S$24.5 billion in 2017. The growth is driven by increased public sector work, with a projected S$16 billion to S$19 billion in 2018, and private sector growth, fueled by a stronger economic outlook and property market sentiment. The BCA anticipates medium-term construction demand to reach S$26 billion to S$33 billion per year from 2019 to 2020 and S$28 billion to S$35 billion per year from 2021 to 2022.

site_title: Fast Retailing posts record Q1 profit on brisk overseas Uniqlo sales
summary: Japan's Fast Retailing, parent company of Uniqlo, posted a record Q1 profit of 113.9 billion yen, beating estimates, driven by brisk sales at its overseas Uniqlo stores. The company's Uniqlo business saw a 54.7% operating profit growth abroad, while domestic sales rose 18.6%. Fast Retailing aims to overtake H&M and Inditex as the world's top apparel retailer, with a focus on expanding overseas. The company's operating profit forecast remains unchanged at 200 billion yen for the year.

site_title: China denies report it could halt US bond purchases
summary: China has denied reports that it may slow or halt purchases of US Treasury bonds, calling it "fake news" after the dollar tumbled following the story. A Bloomberg News report suggested officials were recommending slowing or halting US Treasuries, citing people familiar with the matter. The State Administration of Foreign Exchange stated that the story could be quoting a mistaken source or fake news.

site_title: Australian police investigate death of koala screwed to post
summary: Australian police are investigating the death of a koala found screwed to a post at a lookout in Queensland. The koala, with limbs wrapped around a wooden support, was found dead and appears to have been "cruelly attached" using building screws. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) will conduct an autopsy to determine the cause of death. Animal cruelty can result in up to seven years in jail or fines of up to A$252,300 in Queensland. The incident has sparked outrage from animal rights groups and highlighted the vulnerability of koalas.

site_title: Rio is said to drop pursuit of US$5b stake in lithium miner
summary: Rio Tinto Group has dropped its pursuit of a US$5 billion stake in lithium miner Soc Quimica & Minera de Chile SA. The decision comes as the company focuses on other ways to capitalize on the electric-car boom. Despite other strategic bidders remaining interested, Rio is instead exploring its own lithium projects, including a Serbian project that could meet 10% of global demand.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges lower as strong yen bites; cryptocurrency stocks tumble
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.3% to 23,710.43, hit by declines in automakers and electronic component makers due to the strong yen. Bitcoin-related stocks also tumbled after South Korea's justice minister announced a plan to ban cryptocurrency trading. Toyota Motor Corp and Honda Motor Co dropped 1% and 1.9%, respectively. The broader Topix index fell 0.2%.

site_title: Business sentiment improving, but not all companies on board with economic transformation: SBF survey
summary: Singapore Business Federation's annual National Business Survey found business sentiment improving, with 84% of respondents being SMEs, and 36% satisfied with the current business climate. Revenue growth is the top priority for 68% of respondents, while cost-cutting ranks second. However, a quarter of companies have yet to take significant steps towards business transformation, and those that haven't reported lower profitability. Companies that have transformed are more likely to have implemented new technology and increased profits.

site_title: Manhattan apartment rents fall most since 2014 in crowded market
summary: Manhattan apartment rents fell 2.7% to a median of $3,295 in December, the largest annual decline since 2014, according to a report by Miller Samuel Inc and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. The decline came as landlords made deeper price cuts to attract tenants in a crowded market. The vacancy rate decreased to 1.9%, the lowest for a December in five years, after landlords offered concessions such as free months and gift cards. The median rent after concessions was $3,208, down 2.5% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Apartment rents in Manhattan fell the most in almost four years as landlords made deeper price cuts to lure tenants in a market brimming with choices.

site_title: Strong fundamentals to support markets in 2018, but investors are skittish: DBS CEO
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta expects strong fundamentals to drive global markets in 2018, but investors' skittishness may trigger corrections. Geopolitical and sociopolitical tensions, including rising tensions in North Korea and inequality, are potential triggers. Despite this, Gupta identifies pockets of opportunity, including China's tech sector, South-east Asia's strong consumption trends, and rising interest rates benefiting financial services companies. In Singapore, property firms are expected to benefit from the market recovery.

site_title: European banks braced for "slow burn" payments revolution
summary: European banks are bracing for a "slow burn" revolution in online payments and banking, driven by new EU rules allowing retailers and consumers to bypass traditional banks. The Payments Services Directive 2 (PSD2) aims to increase choice and cut costs by widening the range of firms offering financial services, potentially forcing lenders to rethink their business models. As fintech startups and established companies like Amazon and Apple gain traction, banks may lose revenue from processing payments and overdrafts, and face increased competition in the market.

site_title: Aussie shares extend losses as banks weigh; NZ hits 5-week closing low
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 6,067.60, extending losses for a second session, amid concerns over China's potential reduction of US government debt purchases. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand dropped 1.4% to its lowest close in five weeks. Financials led declines, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and Westpac Banking Corp falling 0.2% and 0.5% respectively. The losses follow a similar decline on Wall Street, where investors became jittery over China's potential impact on US Treasury purchases.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin afternoon trading on lower ground; STI at 3,517.43
summary: Singapore stocks began afternoon trading on January 11, 2018, at 3,517.43, down 0.09% or 3.02 points. The Straits Times Index was marginally up from its pre-break level of 3,514.89. Losers outpaced gainers 211 to 150, with 1.4 billion shares worth S$574.5 million traded.

site_title: North Korea's 'army of beauties' set to invade South
summary: North Korea's female cheerleaders, known as the "army of beauties," are set to make their fourth appearance in South Korea at the upcoming Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. The cheerleaders, mostly in their late teens or early 20s, are handpicked by the North Korean regime and are required to meet strict criteria, including height and family background. Their presence is seen as a potential symbol of peace, but also raises concerns about diplomatic tensions and the strict rules governing their movements in the South.

site_title: Automated trader DRW eyes crypto hires in Asia, expands Singapore office
summary: DRW Holdings LLC, an automated trading firm, plans to expand its presence in Asia, particularly in Singapore and mainland China. The company aims to boost its Singapore staff to 100 from about 40 within five years and is considering opening an office in China. This move comes as trading firms struggle with low volatility and volume due to monetary easing by central banks. DRW started trading bitcoin in 2014 and has a regional cryptocurrency trading desk in Singapore, where its revenue rose 44% to S$30.4 million in 2016.

site_title: China quietly orders its bitcoin miners to cease operations, widening clampdown, say reports
summary: China has ordered its bitcoin miners to cease operations, a move that could widen the country's clampdown on cryptocurrencies. The order, issued by the Leading Group of Internet Financial Risks Remediation, comes after China banned initial coin offerings and shut down cryptocurrency exchanges. The country's bitcoin miners, estimated to produce three-quarters of the world's supply, are now required to make an "orderly exit" from China due to concerns over resource consumption and speculation. The move is seen as part of China's broader efforts to regulate the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Thursday, down 0.90 points to 1,822.02. Volume reached 95.75 million lots worth RM26.14 million, with 142 gainers and 67 losers.

site_title: Shanghai probes Marriott hotels over geography gaffe
summary: Shanghai authorities are investigating Marriott International over a customer questionnaire that listed Chinese-claimed regions such as Tibet and Hong Kong as separate countries, sparking an online uproar. Marriott has apologized and amended the questionnaire, while authorities are probing whether the gaffe violated national cyber-security and advertising laws. The company has cooperated with the investigation and expressed regret over the mistake, which was widely condemned on Chinese social media platforms. Authorities have a history of meting out punishment for similar cases, including a recent fine for a local advertising agency.

images.alt_text: Authorities in Shanghai are investigating hotel giant Marriott after it triggered an online uproar with a customer questionnaire that listed Chinese-claimed regions such as Tibet and Hong Kong as separate countries.

site_title: Vancouver mayor will not seek re-election amid housing crisis
summary: Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson announced he will not seek re-election amid the city's worsening housing crisis. Robertson cited the need to focus on transit projects and affordable housing during his remaining term. The city has implemented measures to address the crisis, including an empty-home tax and restrictions on home-sharing websites. Robertson's decision comes as the city struggles with high housing prices, homelessness, and public outcry over his party's ties to developers.

site_title: Xerox in talks for deal with Fujifilm: WSJ
summary: Xerox is in talks with Fujifilm to potentially do a deal that could include a change in control of the printer manufacturer, according to the Wall Street Journal. A full takeover is not on the table, but Xerox desperately needs new leadership after struggling to launch new products and increase revenue. Fujifilm aims to spend $5.92 billion on strategic acquisitions, and the two companies have a joint venture, Fuji Xerox, which is 75% owned by Fujifilm and 25% by Xerox. Xerox declined to comment on the report.

site_title: Australia shares slide as Wall St hit by China concerns; NZ at 4-week low
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to their weakest level in over a week due to declining Wall Street, pressured by a report that China may slow its buying of US government debt. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 33.4 points to 6,063.3. Financials, led by a decline in Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, bore the brunt of the downturn. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 1.4% to a four-week low.

site_title: China says protectionist sentiment rising in US as deals fall apart
summary: China criticized the US for blocking a Chinese takeover of MoneyGram International Inc and a deal with AT&T to sell Huawei smartphones in the US, citing rising protectionist sentiment. The US government cited national security concerns, sparking concerns about the impact on foreign investment. China's Ministry of Commerce stated that protectionist voices are rising in the US, threatening "win-win deals" and China's economic growth. The failed deals come as the US considers new tariff moves, including restrictions on steel and aluminum imports and punitive actions against China.

site_title: Uber's Chinese rival Didi Chuxing recruits in Mexico ahead of launch
summary: Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing has advertised for jobs in Mexico ahead of its planned launch in the country. Didi aims to recruit drivers and expand its operations in the region, a market where Uber has a strong presence. The company's expansion marks a turning point, as it shifts its focus from financial commitments to on-the-ground expansion. Didi will likely face regulatory battles in Mexico, following a similar path as Uber, which has already halted its service in Cancun due to regulatory issues.

site_title: Canada officials said to see rising odds Trump leaves Nafta
summary: Canada officials believe the likelihood of US President Donald Trump withdrawing from the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) increases, with a six-month notice potentially dragging down the Canadian dollar and yields on government bonds. The officials declined to specify the exact odds, but a White House official stated there has been no change in Trump's position. The comments raise concerns about the possibility of a US withdrawal notice, which could lead to a deterioration in trade relations between the US and Canada.

site_title: Broad support, but awareness lacking, for industry transformation maps: SBF chief
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) chief executive Ho Meng Kit stated that while there is broad support for the Industry Transformation Map (ITM) programme, companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), are lacking in awareness about the programme. A recent SBF survey found that 52% of the polled companies do not know enough about the ITMs, highlighting the need for increased awareness and education. The ITM programme, launched as part of a S$4.5 billion industry transformation package in 2016, aims to take an integrated approach to help each sector prepare for the future.

site_title: New 'emotional' robots aim to read human feelings
summary: New robots with "emotional intelligence" and empathy are being developed to better interact with humans, showcasing technology that can read and respond to body language, tone of voice, and emotional states. Robots such as Forpheus, Honda's 3E-A18, and SoftBank's Pepper are being designed to provide companionship and support, with potential applications in healthcare, education, and sports. However, experts note that developing emotional intelligence in robots is a challenging task that requires a deep understanding of psychology and trust.

site_title: Australian retail sales surge on iPhone, Black Friday bonanza
summary: Australian retail sales surged 1.2% in November, the largest monthly rise in four years, driven by strong demand for Apple iPhones and Black Friday promotions. This boost countered concerns of a consumer slump and helped lift the Australian dollar. Sales reached a record A$26.38 billion, with household goods and other retailing experiencing significant gains. The improved spending outlook suggests a stronger fourth-quarter GDP growth, despite sluggish wage growth and record-high household debt.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down, won a little weaker
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.33% to 2,491.55 points, while the Korean won remained flat at 1,071.1 per US dollar. The move came after mild losses in US stocks and Japanese stocks, which weakened 0.39% and 0.20% respectively. Foreign investors sold 167,752 million won worth of shares, contributing to the decline. Despite this, the Kospi is up 1.3% so far this year, and its current price-to-earnings ratio stands at 12.10.

site_title: BM Mobility makes RM850,000 offer for majority stake in Malaysian electric car-sharing firm
summary: BM Mobility Ltd, a Malaysian investment holding company, has made a RM850,000 (S$284,000) offer to acquire a majority stake in UNiRide Ecotour Sdn Bhd, a Malaysian electric car-sharing firm. The acquisition aims to expand BM Mobility's green energy business in Malaysia and increase revenue streams. The deal, expected to be finalized by January 31, will also give BM Mobility Malaysian dealership rights for the car-sharing business targeting public universities. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to scale up vehicle rental business with electric scooters.

site_title: Valeant CEO calls it 'turnaround opportunity of a lifetime'
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals CEO Joseph Papa calls the company's current state a "turnaround opportunity of a lifetime." Since taking over in 2016, Papa has reduced debt by over $6 billion through asset sales and refinancing. Despite a 51% stock rally in the past two months, the stock remains 35% below its 2016 levels. Papa expects the dermatology business to improve with new products and increased salesforce, citing a potential approval for a plaque psoriasis treatment and a salesforce expansion of 25%.

site_title: China Premier Li says 2017 GDP growth expected around 6.9%
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang said the country's 2017 GDP growth is expected to be around 6.9%, accelerating from a 26-year low in 2016. This beats the government's target of about 6.5% and is attributed to a construction boom, robust global demand for Chinese exports, and restraint from excessive stimulus. The country's corporate leverage ratio declined, and foreign exchange reserves rose to their highest in over a year. Policymakers aim to balance debt risks while maintaining a steady economy, with the 2018 GDP growth target set at around 6.5%.

site_title: Singapore government expects 59 tenders for design for manufacture and assembly projects in 2018
summary: Singapore's government expects 59 design for manufacture and assembly (DFMA) projects to be tendered out in 2018, according to Second Minister for National Development Desmond Lee. The Built Environment cluster sub-committee of the Future Economy Council aims to boost productivity in the construction and facilities management industries by adopting DFMA and digital technologies. The government targets 40% adoption of DFMA for the construction industry, up from the current 10%.

site_title: 'Global shift' as Olympics set up shop in Asia
summary: The International Olympic Committee is hosting three consecutive Olympic Games in Asia from 2018 to 2022, marking a "global shift of power" towards the region. The Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, will be followed by the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, and the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, China. This shift is attributed to the declining interest of Western powers in hosting the multi-billion-dollar events, with Rome, Hamburg, and Budapest withdrawing from the 2024 Summer Games bid process. Experts believe that Asia's economic growth and China's increasing influence are driving this trend.

site_title: Sydney homes aren't so attractive to Chinese investors this year
summary: Chinese investors are pulling back from Sydney's housing market, with demand cooling 5.5 percentage points in one year. Stricter enforcement of capital controls and tighter finance access have contributed to the decline. Foreign buyers now account for 18.1% of residential buyers in NSW by March, down from 23.6%. This may improve affordability for Australians, but also poses a risk for developers needing to sell apartments quickly. Meanwhile, foreign investors are investing heavily in Victoria's commercial real estate, with 22.6% of office deals in March expected.

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Thursday, with STI advancing 0.09%
summary: Singapore shares rose on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 0.09% to 3,523.66. Trading saw 40.8 million shares worth S$102.8 million, with gainers beating losers 67 to 47. The global economy is expected to grow 3.1% in 2018, according to the World Bank. Oil prices fell 15% to 5.1 Singapore cents due to a cost-cutting exercise by offshore and gas group IEV Holdings. UOB and OCBC Bank rose, while City Developments Ltd dipped after a joint-venture partnership made full payment for a German hotel.

site_title: South Korea's major cryptocurrency exchanges raided by police, tax authorities
summary: South Korea's major cryptocurrency exchanges, including Coinone and Bithumb, were raided by police and tax authorities for alleged tax evasion. The raids come amid concerns about the increasing use of virtual currencies in the country, which has seen a surge in demand for cryptocurrency trading due to Bitcoin's 1,500% rise last year. The government is attempting to calm the frenzied demand and prevent a surge in crime linked to virtual currency trading. The crackdown is part of a broader inspection of local banks offering virtual currency accounts to institutions.

site_title: Audi launches premium car rental service in Singapore
summary: Audi Singapore has launched its premium car rental service, Audi On Demand, with an initial fleet of 10 vehicles in the country. This is the first time a continental carmaker has offered such a service in South-east Asia, following its availability in five other markets. The service aims to provide customers with access to Audi's luxury vehicles, with the option to choose from a variety of models.

site_title: Brexit caused 37% fall in new London financial jobs in December: report
summary: A report by Morgan McKinley found that Brexit led to a 37% decline in new financial jobs in London's sector in December, with 3,150 new positions available compared to 4,980 in December 2016. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU made companies hesitant to hire, and around 10,000 finance jobs may be shifted out of Britain or created overseas. This decline is part of a broader slowdown in hiring, with a 30% year-on-year decrease in jobseekers in finance.

site_title: Airlines poised to gain with rising fuel costs as unusual ally
summary: Airlines are poised for a third consecutive year of stock gains despite rising jet-fuel prices, driven by stepped-up pricing power, steady economic growth, and a boost from the US tax overhaul. Analysts project Delta Air Lines and Alaska Air Group to rise 20% or more, while American Airlines and Southwest Airlines are set for smaller gains. The industry's strong earnings and low stock valuations, with airline shares at 12 times earnings, are expected to support investor confidence.

site_title: Hyundai Motor invests in ride-hailing firm Grab
summary: Hyundai Motor Co has invested in Singapore-based ride-hailing firm Grab, its first entry into the sector as it diversifies following a sales slump in China. Hyundai will jointly develop services in South-east Asia, including eco-friendly models, with Grab. The investment joins a recent fundraising round that includes Didi Chuxing, SoftBank, and Toyota Tsusho. Hyundai's interest in the region grew after a diplomatic row between Beijing and Seoul last year, and the company also announced a self-driving technology partnership with Silicon Valley start-up Aurora.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor Co said on Thursday it had invested in Singapore-based ride-hailing firm Grab, in the South Korean automaker's first foray into the rapidly growing sector as it tries to diversify following a sales slump in China.

site_title: BreadTalk prices S$100m of five-year notes to yield 4%
summary: BREADTALK Group priced S$100 million of five-year notes at a 4% coupon, with proceeds to be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing and capital expenditure. The notes mature on Jan 17, 2023, and were sold at par. OCBC Bank and Standard Chartered Bank are the joint lead managers and bookrunners.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks lower after US stocks see first drop of 2018
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 0.58% on January 11, 2018, following a 0.49% drop in the Topix index. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 137.89 points to 23,650.31. The decline was attributed to a strong yen weighing on sentiment and US stocks falling for the first time in 2018.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare to place out shares to Itochu for S$78.8m
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare is raising S$78.75 million through a private placement to Itochu Corp, with Itochu acquiring 25.3% stake in the company. The placement, valued at 14 Singapore cents apiece, will strengthen OUELH's financial position and enable business execution. The new shares are expected to be listed on the Catalist-board by Feb 10, contingent on SGX approval. The deal comes as Itochu seeks to diversify into Asia's expanding healthcare market.

site_title: Chinese workers abandon Silicon Valley for riches back home
summary: Chinese tech professionals are increasingly abandoning Silicon Valley for lucrative opportunities back home, driven by China's growing innovation and venture capital scene. US-trained Chinese-born talent now plays a key role in driving Chinese companies' global expansion and technological advancements. Many are lured by China's abundant venture capital, government incentives, and faster growth in salaries. The trend, dubbed "sea turtles," has significant implications for Valley stalwarts, with some Chinese engineers finding it more lucrative to join fast-rising Chinese companies. China's vast internet space and willingness to experiment with data also attract talent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: BreadTalk, OUE Lippo Healthcare, Rotary Engineering, Duty Free
summary: BreadTalk Group priced S$100 million of five-year notes yielding 4%, refinancing existing borrowing and capital expenditure. OUE Lippo Healthcare raised S$78.75 million through a private placement, giving Itochu Corp a 25.3% stake. Rotary Engineering accepted an unconditional cash bid to go private at S$0.46 a share. Duty Free International's third-quarter profit slumped 84.7% to RM3.3 million.

site_title: Armed robbers seize jewels worth about 4m euros from Paris Ritz
summary: Armed robbers targeted the Paris Ritz hotel, making off with an estimated 4m euros worth of jewels. The gang of five men, armed with hatchets, smashed windows on the ground floor and escaped. The heist occurred in Paris' luxurious Place Vendome. This is the latest in a string of high-profile heists in the French capital.

site_title: New York sues fossil fuel majors, plans divestment from pension funds
summary: New York City filed a multibillion-dollar lawsuit against five top oil companies, citing their contributions to global warming. The lawsuit, against BP, Chevron, ConocoPhillips, Exxon Mobil, and Royal Dutch Shell, comes as the city plans to divest fossil fuel investments from its $189 billion public pension funds over the next five years. The city's comptroller stated that safeguarding the retirement of city workers is linked to the sustainability of the planet, while the oil companies argue the lawsuits are politically motivated and serve special interests.

site_title: China's rethink on US Treasuries may prove hollow
summary: China's government has recommended slowing or halting purchases of US Treasuries due to trade tensions, but its warning had little impact on trading. Yields surged to the highest since March but ended unchanged. This move mirrors a previous episode in 2009, where China's warnings also failed to materialize into lasting change. The decision may prove hollow as China's massive Treasury holdings remain a significant influence on the US debt market.

site_title: Hong Kong property awash in cash shielded from rates: HSBC
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc says Hong Kong's abundant liquidity will likely keep interest rates stable, requiring a $10 billion outflow from commercial banks to show significant gains. According to George Leung, an HSBC adviser, an unforeseen political crisis is needed for substantial capital outflow, making a substantial rate spike unlikely in the near future.

site_title: Gold jumps on report China may slow US Treasury buys
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,318.67 an ounce, its highest in nearly four months, after a report that Chinese officials recommended slowing or halting US Treasury purchases. The dollar fell against major currencies, contributing to the gold surge. Rising Treasury yields could pressure gold prices, but the dollar's decline helped offset this effect.

site_title: Canada braces for possible US exit from Nafta trade pact: source
summary: Canada is preparing for a possible US withdrawal from the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), according to a senior government official. The official stated that Canada is aware of the possibility of President Trump's announcement and is prepared for that scenario. The next round of Nafta negotiations is set to begin in Montreal later this month.

site_title: Singapore passport ranks 2nd globally, bags top spot in S-E Asia
summary: Singapore's passport ranks 2nd globally in the 2018 Henley Passport Index, with holders enjoying visa-free access to 176 countries, up from 173 last year. Germany's passport remains top globally, allowing its holders visa-free access to 177 countries. Other South-east Asian countries also saw improvements, with Indonesia jumping 7 positions and Thailand and the Philippines rising 3. The Henley & Partners Singapore managing partner notes that global mobility will continue to face challenges, but opportunities in the world economy will drive growth.

site_title: Europe: Bond sell-off hits shares but boost banks
summary: European shares declined 0.4% on Wednesday, pulled back from a 2 1/2 year high, as bond yields hit multi-month highs due to concerns over US government bonds. Banks surged 2.1% to their highest in over 2 years, boosted by higher interest rates. European pharmaceuticals, utilities, and consumer staples fell, while telecoms firm Tele2 tumbled 7.5% after a US$3.2 billion takeover deal.

site_title: Trump says US could 'conceivably' return to Paris climate deal
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the country "conceivably" could return to the Paris climate accord, despite his previous intention to withdraw from the 2015 agreement. Trump expressed a desire for "clean water, clean air, and businesses that can compete," but emphasized the need for the US to maintain its competitive edge. The move could renew questions about Trump's intentions and potentially jeopardize global efforts to limit average warming to under two degrees Celsius.

site_title: Coal's best bet for a bailout may now come from rust belt
summary: The US coal industry's best hope for a bailout may lie in the Rust Belt, as the largest US power grid, PJM Interconnection LLC, considers an initiative to boost revenue for struggling coal plants. The proposal aims to revamp the way generators are paid during peak demand, allowing coal and nuclear plants to set their own energy prices. While analysts have raised concerns about the potential impact on ratepayers, some coal miners see it as a positive development. The plan, which has drawn skepticism from critics, may raise market prices by $4 per megawatt-hour, earning generators "hundreds of millions of dollars" over the course of a year.

site_title: Mnuchin's Treasury is tested by China's bond policy signals
summary: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin's team faced a test of their debt market response when China hinted at slowing US government debt purchases, prompting a brief spike in 10-year Treasury yields. This incident highlights a staffing gap in the Office of Domestic Finance, which deals with debt market disruptions. Mnuchin has not traveled to meet with Chinese counterparts on their home turf, unlike his predecessors, raising questions about his engagement with China, the US's largest creditor.

images.alt_text: China's hints that it may slow purchases of US government debt gave Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and his team a test-run on debt market shocks.

site_title: Car designer Henrik Fisker eyes comeback with pricey electric vehicle
summary: Henrik Fisker unveiled the Fisker EMotion, a $129,000 electric luxury car, at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. The vehicle features butterfly doors, semi-autonomous driving, and a range of 650km on a single charge. Fisker aims to improve range and charging time with his own battery technology and partnering with Quanergy for Lidar technology. The company also plans to launch a more affordable vehicle and a self-driving shuttle bus called the Orbit, priced around $40,000. Fisker's comeback effort faces competition from Tesla and other electric car manufacturers.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat, ending streak of records
summary: US stocks retreated for the first time in 2018, closing 0.1% lower on Wednesday amid worries over the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to 25,369.13, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also shed 0.1%. Shares of companies that benefit from NAFTA, such as General Motors and Constellation Brands, plummeted following a report that President Trump may abandon the trade pact. Despite this, US stocks remained above session lows, indicating a positive underlying sentiment towards equities.

site_title: Commentary
summary: IMB Research highlights five non-rated small-cap tech manufacturing stocks underperforming in 2017, with average returns below the industry average of 162%. The companies include Avi-Tech Electronics, Broadway Industrial Group, Fu Yu Corporation, InnoTek Holdings, and Manufacturing Integration Technology. These stocks have varying growth drivers, such as autonomous driving and the Internet of Things, and have different dividend payout policies. They trade at forward price-to-earnings ratios ranging from 11.9 to 16.5 times.

site_title: Stricken ship in East China Sea may burn for a month
summary: A South Korean ministry official stated that the stricken Iranian oil tanker Sanchi in the East China Sea may burn for up to a month following a collision with a freight ship. The blaze has raged for a fourth day, with rescue efforts battling strong winds and poisonous fumes to locate 31 missing sailors and contain the fire. Authorities are concerned that the highly flammable condensate could contaminate water if the ship sinks, and the tanker's bunker fuel poses a significant risk of explosion or explosion.

site_title: IEV Holdings to sell corporate headquarters in cost-cutting drive, after Indonesian oilfield exit
summary: IEV Holdings is selling its corporate headquarters in Malaysia for RM9.2 million to Vizione Holdings, primarily to settle a bank loan and working capital. The sale is part of the company's cost-cutting drive following its exit from the Indonesian oilfield. The majority of the proceeds will be used to settle the bank loan and working capital, with minimal impact on the company's financial position.

site_title: Is divestment of office assets on the cards for Alpha-CDL tie-up in '18?
summary: Alpha-CDL's 2018 tie-up may lead to divestment of office assets. A portfolio of less prominent office properties, including Manulife Centre, Central Mall, and 7 & 9 Tampines Grande, could hit the market. Alpha is setting up a new property fund and may sell assets to boost its track record and gain traction for the new fund. Manulife Centre, with a 97-year lease, could fetch around S$556-580 million, while 7 & 9 Tampines Grande may be sold for a higher price due to its prime location. CDL may retain the reversionary interest in Manulife Centre.

site_title: Is Hongkong housing market boom over?
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a slowdown, according to Credit Suisse Group AG. The brokerage projects a 3% rise in home prices this year, down from 13% in 2017. Rising interest rates and increasing housing inventory are contributing to the decline. This marks a shift from the city's previous boom, where prices surged in 2017.

site_title: Toyota, Mazda announce US$1.6b plant for Huntsville, Alabama
summary: Toyota and Mazda announced a $1.6 billion joint assembly plant in Huntsville, Alabama, set to employ up to 4,000 workers and produce 300,000 vehicles annually. The plant, expected to open in 2021, will produce Corolla cars and Mazda's crossover SUVs. Alabama will provide $370 million in tax incentives, with local incentives undisclosed. The move is seen as a boost to President Trump's efforts to expand US auto production, despite the US auto industry experiencing declining sales.

site_title: UK plans to eliminate avoidable plastic waste by 2042
summary: The UK government plans to eliminate avoidable plastic waste by 2042, with proposals including plastic-free aisles in supermarkets, a five-pence charge on plastic carrier bags, and new funding for plastics innovation. Prime Minister Theresa May will outline the plans in a speech, but opposition leaders and environmental campaigners have criticized them as insufficient, calling for more urgent action to address the scale of the environmental crisis. The government will also direct international development aid towards tackling pollution abroad.

images.alt_text: The government wants supermarkets to introduce plastic-free aisles and intends to inject new funding into plastics innovation.

site_title: Aramco seeking US$2b loan from Japan's export agency: sources
summary: Saudi Arabian Oil, Aramco, is seeking a $2 billion loan from Japan's export-credit agency as part of its initial public offering (IPO) preparations. The Japan Bank for International Cooperation is weighing the loan, which would value Aramco at $2 trillion. This deal would make the Japanese export-credit agency the second state institution to extend financing to Aramco ahead of its IPO. Japanese lenders are competing for a role in the IPO, with a successful loan potentially securing a closer relationship with the oil company.

site_title: IBM awarded most US patents in 2017, top for 25th straight year
summary: IBM received 9,043 US patents in 2017, breaking its own record set in 2016. This marks the company's 25th consecutive year as the top patent recipient in the US. While the patents reflect IBM's investments in emerging technologies like blockchain and artificial intelligence, the company still faces challenges in translating research into immediate business gains. The patents may not be directly applicable to current products, requiring years of development before they can generate revenue.

site_title: US crude inventory fall buoys oil, worries about rally persist
summary: US crude oil inventories fell 4.9 million barrels last week, exceeding expectations, and production declined sharply due to extreme cold temperatures. This led to a 61-cent increase in US West Texas Intermediate crude futures, settling at $63.57 a barrel, its highest since December 2014. Brent crude futures also rose, settling at $69.20 a barrel, amid a broader market rally and a weaker US dollar. Analysts warn of potential overheating in the market, despite US production expected to hit record highs by 2019.

images.alt_text: Crude oil prices jumped on Wednesday and settled near three-year highs after US government data showed a drop in crude inventories and production, even as fuel inventories rose.

site_title: Singapore to launch S-E Asia's first legaltech accelerator
summary: Singapore is launching Accelerate!, the first legaltech accelerator in South-east Asia, to digitally transform its legal sector. The program, announced by the Singapore Academy of Law, aims to groom legaltech startups and incubate new business models or services conceived by law firms. The initiative is part of the Future Law Innovation Programme, which prepares the legal industry for technological disruption. The accelerator is set to launch in April and is expected to support the growth of the legaltech industry in Singapore.

site_title: RHB remains neutral on three listed telcos; Singtel still on top
summary: RHB Research has maintained a neutral stance on Singapore's three listed telecommunications companies, Singtel, StarHub, and M1. The research firm forecasts a third consecutive year of shrinking mobile service revenue, with a 2-3% year-on-year decline in 2018. This is attributed to intense competition in the market.

site_title: Global rules-based framework needed for response to cyber threats
summary: A global rules-based framework is needed to respond to cyber threats due to the discovery of Meltdown and Spectre vulnerabilities in modern processors. These flaws, exposed since the mid-1990s, allow hackers to access sensitive data, and their patching and microcode fixes pose performance risks. The issue of who else knew about these vulnerabilities but chose not to disclose them also raises concerns. To tackle future threats, a strict, global framework like the financial sector's is required, rather than relying on individual companies to address these issues.

site_title: Developing a globally competitive life sciences industry
summary: Singapore's life sciences industry, despite its global standing, has yet to capture significant economic value, particularly in the startup/SME segment. The country's role as an Asian hub is changing due to China's rise, and many multinationals are shifting their Asian headquarters to Chinese metropolises. To develop a globally competitive life sciences industry, Singapore needs an updated industrial roadmap, focusing on niche therapeutic areas, diagnostics, and life sciences tools. The country should also refine its grant policies and investment strategy to support biotechnology firms and medical device startups.

site_title: Real estate still seen in HK as safest store of wealth
summary: Hong Kong's residential property prices are expected to rise 10% this year, driven by investor demand and limited supply. Despite concerns about the market, there is little chance of a crash, barring an external shock. The disconnect between property prices and stocks like CK Asset Holdings and Henderson Land Development has persisted, with investors preferring tangible assets over proxies. Banks' low savings rates and developers' reluctance to share dividends and buybacks have made real estate the safest store of wealth, with JLL forecasting a 10% increase in residential capital values.

site_title: Line to explore cryptocurrencies for payment services: sources
summary: LINE, a Tokyo-based messaging provider, is exploring the integration of cryptocurrencies into its platform as a way to differentiate its services and increase "stickiness". The company is in discussions with multiple companies on using cryptocurrencies for payment services, including Line Pay. LINE's move joins a growing list of businesses capitalizing on the hype surrounding bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. The company aims to fend off challenges from larger rivals like Facebook and Snap by offering digital money services deeper within its app, which has 168 million monthly active users in Japan, Taiwan, Thailand, and Indonesia.

site_title: New Google headset, camera aim to spread VR beyond gaming
summary: Google unveiled a new VR headset, Mirage Solo, in partnership with Lenovo, aiming to expand VR beyond gaming. The headset features high-end VR capabilities, including untethered displays and 360-degree footage capture with VR180 cameras. The devices are built to integrate Google services, such as YouTube and maps. Analysts expect broader VR adoption to begin in 2021, but some predict augmented-reality devices may surpass VR in market share. The Mirage Solo is expected to cost less than $400 and will be released in the second quarter of 2018.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) will exit the Singapore Exchange on January 22 after a record S$16 billion privatisation. Rotary Engineering has been taken private with a cash bid of 46 Singapore cents per share, and Duty Free International posted a net loss of RM3.3 million in the third quarter due to a net foreign exchange loss. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year.

site_title: Bitcoin can drop 50% and China's miners will still make money
summary: Bitcoin mining in China remains profitable even if the cryptocurrency value drops by 50% due to the country's low electricity costs, according to a report by Bloomberg New Energy Finance. At China's highest regulated electricity tariff, miners can still make money as long as bitcoin's value exceeds US$6,925. Currently, the digital currency trades around US$14,200, making China's miners financially stable despite potential market fluctuations.

site_title: STI slips 4.2 points to 3,520.45
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index slipped 4.2 points to 3,520.45, but Venture Corporation surged 91 cents to S$22.48, its highest level since March 2000, as the bull market continues. Brent crude traded above US$69 a barrel. Property counters like Country Garden in Hong Kong and Singapore developers City Developments and UOL rose. Analysts attribute the rallies to liquidity and earnings growth, with expectations of loose monetary policies due to low inflation.

site_title: A lone Wolff takes a bite of the US presidency
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing a "disconnect" between the country's economic growth and the chaotic state of the White House, according to a new book "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House" by Michael Wolff. The book portrays Trump as ignorant, unstable, and narcissistic, and his administration as riven by cunning aides and family members. Despite the economic indicators showing a robust recovery, the White House insists that Trump's policies are responsible for the growth, while critics warn that the economic bubble could burst and leave Americans with less money in their pension and retirement funds.

site_title: French beef producers cheer deal to end China ban
summary: French beef producers are hailing a deal reached by President Emmanuel Macron to end China's 16-year-old embargo on French beef. The agreement allows French producers to enter the huge Chinese market within six months, promoting the safety of French meat and opening new markets for ranchers. The ban was imposed in 2011 due to concerns over "mad cow" disease. The deal comes as French beef consumption continues to fall, and China's middle class expands, making imported meat increasingly popular.

site_title: Business leaders laud Enterprise Singapore chairman's appointment
summary: Business leaders in Singapore have praised the appointment of Peter Ong Boon Kwee as chairman-designate of Enterprise Singapore, the country's new one-stop agency to drive global growth. Ong, a former head of the Civil Service, brings over 30 years of experience to the role. He will provide strategic advice on economic strategies and champion enterprise growth, with the support of other board members to be identified. Leaders from various sectors, including the Singapore Business Federation and Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, have expressed confidence in Ong's ability to steer Enterprise Singapore's efforts.

site_title: Ukraine to launch its first solar plant at Chernobyl
summary: Ukraine is set to launch its first solar plant at the Chernobyl site, a 1-megawatt power plant located 100 meters from the new "sarcophagus" of the 1986 nuclear disaster. The project, funded by the international community, has cost $1.6 million and will provide power for a medium-sized village. The region aims to produce 100 times the initial solar power, taking advantage of the abundant sunshine. The plant's construction is seen as a step towards reviving the abandoned territory, which remains contaminated but suitable for innovative projects.

images.alt_text: Workers installing photovoltaic panels on the new one-megawatt solar power plant located just 100 metres from a giant metal dome sealing the remains of the 1986 Chernobyl accident.

site_title: Trump to attend Davos forum with 'America First' agenda
summary: US President Donald Trump will attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, with his "America First" agenda, despite expected "icy receptions" from global economic leaders. Trump's presence is expected to dominate the event, which aims to promote international cooperation and norms. His attendance is seen as a provocative move, following his withdrawal from international agreements such as the Paris Climate accord and trade deals. Trump's aides believe his base will support his decision, and some world leaders look forward to hearing from him directly. The forum's theme is "Creating a Shared Future in a Fractured World."

site_title: Three trends shaping taxation for businesses
summary: Three key trends are shaping taxation for businesses in Singapore, driven by globalization, international tax reforms, and digitalization. Firstly, complexities in tax reforms, including transfer pricing documentation and automatic exchange of information, are increasing tax authorities' visibility and power. Secondly, challenges of digitalization are resulting in uncertainty, with tax rules struggling to keep up with the pace of digitalization. Finally, the rapidly changing tax landscape is bringing greater power to tax administrations, which will require businesses to adapt by collecting, storing, and analyzing tax and financial data more effectively.

images.alt_text: As tax policy becomes more complex with heightened demands, tax matters should become part of an enterprise-wide strategic concern that warrants attention and leadership from the top.

site_title: 400 deaths a day forcing India to take car safety seriously
summary: India's government is implementing stricter car safety regulations, requiring manufacturers to add features like airbags, audio speed warnings, and anti-lock braking systems to vehicles sold in the country. The bill, passed by the lower house of Parliament, aims to curb the 400 fatalities a day in traffic accidents. The changes are expected to boost manufacturing costs for domestic and foreign carmakers, with costs increasing by 7-8% for small car segment manufacturers. The new law is expected to take effect on July 1, with penalties for offenses like drunken driving being increased.

site_title: Singapore property prices seen to rebound in 2018
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to rebound in 2018 with private residential prices rising 1-10% and home sales increasing 40% that year, according to Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, and OCBC Investment Research. Developer valuations remain attractive, and collective sales are expected to enhance the market. However, potential government cooling measures pose a risk, which may be premature given the market's recent recovery. Experts also predict that home prices could double by 2030.

site_title: Sluggish housing rentals may find footing in second half of 2018
summary: Singapore's housing rental market showed sluggishness in December, with private non-landed rents slipping 0.3% and HDB rents falling 0.6%. Despite a 0.5% full-year decline in private non-landed rents and 3.5% drop in HDB rents, analysts predict a gradual recovery in the second half of 2018. Rents for private homes are expected to rise 1-3% by the fourth quarter, while HDB flats may see a decline of 3-4% for the year. New supply of completed homes is expected to taper off, supporting a rental market improvement.

site_title: Richest Asian banker plans family office but spurns crypto
summary: Uday Kotak, India's 8th-richest person and Asia's wealthiest banker, is setting up a family office to invest in assets like private equity, stocks, and real estate. The office will avoid investments in debt and cryptocurrencies, including bitcoin, which Mr. Kotak's family office deemed too risky. The office will be managed by Venkat Subramanian, who will oversee a team of family members. Mr. Kotak's $1.2 billion in cash and investable assets will be deployed in these asset classes, with the goal of staying clear of direct competition with his bank, Kotak Mahindra Bank.

site_title: US dollar slumps on report China may halt bond buys
summary: The US dollar slumped against the Japanese yen after a report that China may slow or halt its US treasury purchases, citing people familiar with the matter. The dollar fell 1.2% to a six-week low of 111.3, its weakest since late November. This move follows the Bank of Japan's decision to trim its purchases of long-dated government bonds. The dollar's decline is attributed to China's potential shift in its foreign-exchange holdings, which could cause a problem for the US if foreign holders of US Treasuries were to suddenly stop buying.

site_title: Fire And Fury is the hottest book of 2018 - too bad it's so dull
summary: A review of Michael Wolff's book "Fire And Fury" criticizes its lack of depth and insight, calling it a "real slog to get through." The author's use of clichéd language and trite references is seen as a reflection of his own limited thinking. While the book provides some interesting observations, particularly about the Trump administration's treatment of women, it lacks a coherent narrative and argument. The reviewer notes that Wolff's portrayal of Stephen Bannon as a strategic genius is misleading, and that the book ultimately fails to provide a nuanced understanding of the Trump presidency.

site_title: Djokovic 'very happy' with winning start to the year
summary: Novak Djokovic made a successful return to competition after six months out with an elbow injury, beating world number five Dominic Thiem 6-1, 6-4 at the Kooyong Classic. The 12-time Grand Slam winner expressed optimism about his chances for the Australian Open, despite still feeling the effects of his injury. Djokovic's form was on display, and he credited his team's work for helping him regain his competitive edge.

site_title: M&S deserves praise for just saying no to discounting
summary: Marks & Spencer (M&S) has been praised for resisting the temptation to discount prices during the Christmas season, protecting its margins and giving consumers confidence in prices. This stance is a departure from previous practice under former CEO Marc Bolland, who relied on discounts to boost sales. M&S has made progress in reducing its reliance on discounts, with a 50% decrease in clearance sales, and analysts expect the company to outperform expectations despite a predicted 3.4% decline in same-store clothing sales.

site_title: Your best response when a company shouts crypto? Run
summary: US-listed companies are exploring cryptocurrency ventures, despite struggling financially. Long Island Iced Tea, Renren, and Eastman Kodak are among those considering ICOs, with Kodak and Line seeing potential in blockchain for intellectual property management. However, the crypto universe is littered with failed ICOs, and these companies' histories raise doubts about their ability to execute successfully, with Line's share surge largely attributed to speculation rather than solid execution.

site_title: Cutting out Brussels middleman, UK ministers make Brexit pitch to Germany
