summary: British Finance Minister Philip Hammond and Brexit Minister David Davis made a direct pitch to Germany to cut economic ties between the UK and the EU after Brexit, aiming to avoid a tough deal that could harm both economies. They argued that a good deal would benefit Germany as well, as it would avoid losses in trade and investment. The move comes as the UK faces a tough line from Brussels on post-Brexit economic ties.

site_title: US wholesale inventories rebound strongly in November
summary: US wholesale inventories rebounded 0.8% in November, exceeding initial estimates, suggesting a boost to economic growth in the fourth quarter. This increase, combined with a 1.5% rise in sales at wholesalers, indicates a faster pace of inventory turnover. Inventory investment contributed 8.1% to the economy's 3.2% annualized growth pace in the third quarter, with auto inventories and sales of motor vehicles also rising.

site_title: Troubled Noble Group says goodbye to global oil trading
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, is closing its London oil desk and winding down its Asia oil operations due to heavy losses and high debt. The company had reported a nine-month loss of US$3 billion and had sold its US oil trading business to Vitol. Noble will exit the oil trading business and return to its roots as a hard commodities business in Asia, mainly involved in coal marketing. The company's market value has shrunk to around US$215 million, and it has sought alternative financing to avoid insolvency.

site_title: EU to propose plastic-bag tax as China curtails waste imports
summary: The European Union plans to propose a tax on plastic bags and packaging to reduce waste and fill a budget gap, following China's move to curb plastic waste imports. China, which accounted for half of the world's plastic scrap imports in 2017, closed its markets to plastic waste and will no longer accept plastic waste for reprocessing since January. The EU's budget chief, Guenther Oettinger, aims to reduce the quantity of plastic used in Europe through the proposed tax, which details are yet to be decided.

site_title: Why low inflation is no surprise
summary: Low inflation has persisted in the global North, contrary to expectations, with some attributing it to temporary supply-side shocks. However, the author argues that this diagnosis is based on a flawed assumption about the primary driver of inflation since World War II, and that historical evidence suggests a more complex relationship between demand and supply. The author cites the 1970s as a period of low aggregate demand and few inflation jumps, and argues that central bankers' hesitation to commit to price stability contributed to the persistence of low inflation.

site_title: Singapore 'highly susceptible' to threat of fake news: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam has warned the country is "highly susceptible" to fake news, urging the government to set up a select committee to study the issue. The committee will examine the causes and consequences of deliberate online falsehoods and consult with experts and the public. With 91% of Singaporean households having internet access, the minister sees the country as vulnerable to foreign interference and destabilization. Deliberate online falsehoods could undermine trust in institutions and social cohesion, Shanmugam said, following recent examples of false rumors spreading on social media.

site_title: New SGX listings in 2018 may curb hollowing out from delistings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to see more consolidation in 2018 due to the high number of delistings in 2017. Despite the SGX's robust market rally, more than $12 billion in market value was lost from delistings in 2017, while new listings added only $8.7 billion. Experts attribute delistings to China firms' appetite for overseas expansion, driven by the "One Belt, One Road" initiative. New listings and IPOs are expected to continue, with the SGX aiming to attract more companies from the healthcare and logistics sectors.

site_title: Moon open to meeting Kim, but will never accept N Korea's nukes
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In stated that he is open to meeting North Korean leader Kim Jong Un under the right conditions, but will never accept North Korea's nuclear program. Moon emphasized the importance of denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula, saying it's a non-negotiable position for South Korea. The two nations had a rift in talks on Tuesday, but Moon expressed willingness to sit with Kim, provided certain conditions are met. Moon also praised US President Donald Trump for bringing North Korea to talks, and welcomed China's support for the dialogue.

site_title: Cambodia finds new target for real estate: China investors
summary: Chinese investors are increasingly targeting Cambodia's real estate market, driven by concerns over their country's mounting debt. Agents in Phnom Penh are adapting by learning Mandarin to cater to these buyers. The influx of Chinese capital is part of a larger building boom in the city, with projects geared towards these investors.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of a Parisian themed development on Diamond Island in Phnom Penh. A building boom is becoming more noticeable, and its largest projects are often geared towards Chinese investors, who have recently taken interest in the nation's real estate market.

site_title: India relaxes foreign direct investment rules
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi relaxed foreign direct investment rules, allowing overseas airlines to invest up to 49% in state carrier Air India Ltd. The move aims to revive the country's economy, which has seen its slowest growth since Modi took power in 2014. The government also eased restrictions on single-brand retailers and foreigners owning up to 100% in real estate brokerages. The changes are part of Modi's efforts to attract foreign capital and improve ease of doing business.

images.alt_text: PM Modi is trying to lure foreign capital to revive an economic growth that is seen expanding at the slowest pace since 2014.

site_title: Food is the real magic at Disney World
summary: Disney World visitors flock to the destination for various reasons, but the author of the article highlights the importance of food in their experience. Contrary to expectations of typical theme park treats, the author discovered a diverse range of culinary options, showcasing the magic of food at Disney World. The article aims to challenge the conventional perception of Disney World as a solely theme park-focused destination.

site_title: US slaps tariffs on Canadian paper imports
summary: The US Commerce Department imposed tariffs of up to 10% on Canadian paper imports, citing subsidies given to Canadian producers as an unfair advantage in the US market. This is the latest in a series of trade actions by President Trump's administration, targeting Canada and China. The tariffs, ranging from 4.42 to 9.93%, affect exports worth $1.27 billion in 2016. Canadian officials call the move "unjustified" and vow to defend the industry, warning of job losses in the US printing sector. A final decision is set for late May.

site_title: Canada takes United States to WTO in complaint over trade remedies
summary: Canada has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the United States, challenging the use of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties. The 32-page complaint cites nearly 200 examples of alleged US wrongdoing, primarily targeting other trading partners such as China, India, and the European Union. Canada claims US procedures broke WTO rules, including the Anti-Dumping Agreement and the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures. This move is seen as a significant challenge to US trade practices, which have been criticized for being overly punitive and disrupting global trade.

site_title: Exit with care, investors remind central banks
summary: Global central banks are being warned by investors to tread carefully with their monetary policy planning, as even minor tweaks can spark market volatility. Recent changes by the Bank of Japan, China's central bank, and European Central Bank officials have seen the yen, yuan, and euro experience significant fluctuations. Investors are on high alert for any signals of central banks' intention to withdraw emergency stimulus, which has been in place since the financial crisis. Policymakers are walking a fine line with forward guidance, as any misinterpreted signals can create market volatility and undermine the path to action.

site_title: Malaysia to pay firm up to US$70m if MH370 is found
summary: Malaysia has signed a deal with US seabed exploration firm Ocean Infinity to search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane MH370 in the Southern Indian Ocean. The company will search a 25,000 sq km area on a "no-cure, no-fee" basis, with payment increases for finding the plane within specific distances. If found within 25,000 sq km, Ocean Infinity will receive up to $70 million, while the search is expected to be completed within three or four weeks, covering up to 60,000 sq km in 90 days.

site_title: Is greed really good?
summary: The article discusses the shift in Western economic orthodoxy in the 1970s, influenced by figures like Margaret Thatcher, Ronald Reagan, Milton Friedman, and Ayn Rand. The government's control over economies was seen as ineffective, and a new model of deregulated markets was promoted, emphasizing individual pursuit of wealth. This ideology led to a decline in government intervention and a focus on market efficiency, with the Civil Rights Movement and counterculture taking a back seat. The article highlights the significant impact of this shift on economic policies and the global economy.

site_title: World Bank revises 2018 growth upwards, but warns upswing will be fragile
summary: The World Bank has revised its 2018 growth forecast upwards to 3.1%, citing a stronger-than-expected 2017 recovery. However, the upswing is expected to be fragile due to potential financial stress, protectionism, and rising geopolitical tensions. The bank also notes that China's transition to slower but more sustainable growth may moderate East Asia and Pacific region activity. Despite these risks, the global economy is on track to operate at or near full capacity for the first time since the financial crisis, with growth projected to hit 3% in 2019.

site_title: Currency futures: SGX sees volume surge in 2017
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a surge in currency futures trading volume in 2017, with annual trading volume reaching nearly 10 million contracts, a 59% increase from the previous year. This growth was driven by increased trading in Indian rupee and offshore renminbi futures, with notional values rising to US$245 billion and US$190 billion, respectively. Economic initiatives in India, such as the introduction of a standardized goods and services tax, are believed to have contributed to the growth.

site_title: Thailand's 2017 rice exports hit record 11.48 million tonnes
summary: Thailand exported a record 11.48 million tonnes of rice in 2017, valued at over $5.1 billion, surpassing the previous record of 10.96 million tonnes in 2014. The country is expected to ship out 9.5 million tonnes this year, with a lower forecast due to bad weather affecting crops. Thailand aims to pursue government-to-government deals with countries like Iraq, Iran, and Indonesia to boost exports.

site_title: Modi eases rules to lure foreign investors as India growth slows
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi eased foreign investment rules, allowing overseas airlines to invest in Air India, single-brand retailers to operate without federal approval, and foreigners to own 100% in real estate brokerages. The move aims to revive economic growth, which has slowed to its lowest pace since 2014, with foreign direct investment rising 17% to $21 billion in the April-September period. Modi seeks to attract foreign capital to boost growth, following a series of economic reforms since taking power in 2014.

site_title: Rotary Engineering to be delisted as takeover offer declared unconditional
summary: Rotary Engineering's takeover offer to go private has been declared unconditional after a shareholder vote. The cash bid of 46 Singapore cents per share was made through Orochem, controlled by the Chia family group, which holds 73% of shares. The offer will remain open until January 24. The move follows a shareholder vote, with the Chia family group's controlling stake increasing to 64.7%.

site_title: British PM May to meet finance bosses on Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet with major finance executives on Thursday to discuss the impact of Brexit on London's financial status and potential job losses. Concerns arise as banks prepare to relocate thousands of jobs to the EU to preserve access to the single market. The meeting will be attended by Finance Minister Philip Hammond and junior Brexit minister Robin Walker, as part of a regular series with business leaders.

site_title: China officials recommend slowing or halting US bond purchases
summary: China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange recommended slowing or halting US bond purchases, citing the market becoming less attractive and trade tensions with the US as a reason. This move pushed US Treasury yields to multi-month highs, causing the US dollar to fall. China holds approximately $3 trillion in foreign-exchange holdings, with $1.19 trillion in US Treasuries. The decision is seen as a geopolitical move, potentially affecting the global market for US securities.

site_title: Real estate investing startup Cadre partners with Goldman Sachs
summary: Cadre, a real estate investing startup, has partnered with Goldman Sachs to allow the bank's private wealth management clients to invest through the platform. Goldman Sachs clients have committed to investing $250 million in properties through Cadre's platform, which offers a high-quality, diversified way to invest in real estate with more transparency and lower fees. This partnership highlights sustained interest by large banks in working with young financial technology companies to make financial services more user-friendly and accessible.

site_title: Trump's willingness on immigration deal gives talks urgency
summary: President Donald Trump has signaled his willingness to negotiate an immigration deal with Democrats, potentially clearing a stalemate on multiple issues, including government funding. Trump outlined a broad outline for an agreement during a meeting with bipartisan lawmakers, suggesting he's willing to split the contentious immigration issue into two parts: a DACA replacement and border security measures. The talks inject a sense of urgency, with Democrats expressing optimism and Republicans seeking certainty. An immigration agreement could open the way to a broad spending bill, which in turn could carry disaster relief funds and other measures.

site_title: Sanli secures S$10 million in 3 new contracts
summary: Sanli Environmental has secured three new contracts worth S$10 million from the private and public sectors. The contracts involve building a pilot plant for water treatment and servicing equipment at water reclamation plants. This brings the company's order book to S$114.3 million, expected to contribute to revenue for the financial year ending March 31, 2018. Sanli CEO Sim Hock Heng expressed plans to tap into the demand for water and waste management solutions to grow the business further.

site_title: US import prices post smallest gain in five months
summary: US import prices posted their smallest gain in five months, increasing 0.1% in December, beating economists' expectations. The increase was attributed to declining costs for food and consumer goods, with prices for imported petroleum rising 2% and imported capital goods remaining unchanged. Underlying imported price pressures were muted, and export prices slipped 0.1% in December, declining for the first time since June. The data suggests a slowdown in inflation, with economists optimistic that recent US dollar depreciation and a tightening labor market will help lift inflation towards the Federal Reserve's 2% target this year.

site_title: Foxconn's Dec sales rise 50% y-o-y
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, reported a 50.2% year-on-year rise in revenues for December, reaching NT$675.1 billion. Despite initial concerns over iPhone X demand, Foxconn's sales rose despite shares dipping in December. Analysts still expect significant iPhone shipments in the March quarter, contrary to expectations of lower demand.

site_title: Norway's US$1 trillion fund wants to invest in private equity
summary: Norway's $1 trillion wealth fund has expressed interest in investing in private equity, citing the potential to boost returns and diversify its portfolio. The fund believes its experience in real estate investing has provided the necessary expertise for private equity investments, and proposes investing alongside private equity funds. This move would allow the fund to access a broader range of companies and potentially generate higher returns. The Norwegian government is considering the proposal, following a previous decision to increase the fund's stake in stocks to 70% of its portfolio.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group is closing its global oil trading operations due to heavy losses and high debt. The housing rental market in Singapore remained soft in December, but full-year declines eased in 2017. Private home prices are expected to rebound this year, according to Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley. Singapore's currency futures traded up 59% in 2017, and GLP is set to delist from the Singapore Exchange on January 22. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US tariff announcement, and the Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs.

site_title: Have an artful week with Weekend magazine
summary: Singapore prepares for the upcoming Art Week, featuring a diverse range of art from around the world. Weekend Magazine offers a comprehensive guide, including restaurant recommendations, healthy lifestyle tips, and the latest Spring runway looks. The magazine also covers various topics such as corporate purpose, financial literacy, and sustainable living.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks see 12th straight rise, eye on record
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a 12th consecutive day, edging up 0.20% to close at 31,073.72, putting them on track for a record high not seen since 2007. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also climbed 0.23%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.33%. This marks the ninth consecutive rise for Shanghai. The rally comes despite US trade threats, with traders brushing off the concerns to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Pertamina terminates operations agreement with IEV's Indonesian unit
summary: IEV Holdings' Indonesian subsidiary, PT IEV Pabuaran KSO, has had its operations terminated by PT Pertamina EP due to non-completion of a US$18.6 million work programme by Dec 11, 2017. The termination, effective Jan 2, is attributed to prolonged low oil prices making the operation commercially unviable. IEV will exit exploration and production, focusing on offshore engineering, and impair its assets, potentially affecting FY2017 financial results.

site_title: Indian prince throws open palace doors to vulnerable LGBT people
summary: Indian Prince Manvendra Singh Gohil, heir to the Rajpipla throne, is building a centre for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender people in his ancestral palace. The 52-year-old prince, who came out over a decade ago, aims to provide rooms, a medical facility, and vocational training to help people find jobs. The centre, funded through an online crowdfunding campaign and donations, is a response to India's colonial-era law criminalizing consensual same-sex relations. The prince's efforts have helped raise awareness and support for the LGBT community in India.

site_title: Boxing: Former world champion Amir Khan to return to ring
summary: Former world champion Amir Khan is set to return to the boxing ring on April 21 in Liverpool against an unnamed opponent, ending a nearly two-year hiatus. Khan, 31, signed a three-fight deal with British boxing promoter Eddie Hearn, following his last bout in May 2016, where he was knocked out by Saul 'Canelo' Alvarez. Khan's return to boxing comes after a stint on a reality TV program in the jungle.

site_title: Singapore shares hang on above 3,500 points as Venture nears dotcom high
summary: Singapore stocks ended 0.1% lower on Wednesday, closing at 3,520.45. Venture Corp surged 4.2% to a 91-cent gain, trading at a high not seen since March 2000. Losers outnumbered gainers 250 to 201. Despite the decline, the Straits Times Index has notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.03 points lower at 1,822.92 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 5.7 billion lots worth RM3.8 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 630 to 426.

site_title: Duty Free International Q3 net profit sinks 85%, stronger ringgit results in forex loss
summary: Duty Free International (DFS) reported a net profit of RM3.3 million in Q3, down 84.7% from the same period last year. A net foreign exchange loss of RM7.5 million and a surge in inventories purchased and material consumed contributed to the decline. Revenue was up 0.4% to RM133.5 million. A third interim dividend of S$0.01 per share was declared. The group attributed the decline to challenging economic conditions and a competitive business environment.

site_title: Pavillon funds Johor Bahru acquisition with RM29.9 million convertible bonds issue
summary: Pavillon Holdings has issued RM29.9 million in 5% convertible bonds to settle debts for its Johor Bahru property, including 99 strata lots and eight plots of land. The bonds are convertible into approximately 98.7 million ordinary shares at 30.25 sen each. The funds will be used to pay off the remaining balance of Fengchi Real Estate's payments for the properties.

site_title: Britain's M&S deserves praise for just saying no to discounting
summary: Britain's Marks and Spencer (M&S) is being praised for resisting the trend of discounting during the Christmas season, which can erode consumer confidence and hurt sales. By maintaining full prices, M&S has protected its margins and given shoppers confidence in the prices they pay. Analysts expect a 3.4% decline in same-store clothing and home furnishing sales, but the company's progress in cutting discounts could be a positive sign. M&S has made a deliberate effort to step away from discounting, a strategy that could lead to lasting benefits despite short-term pain.

site_title: LHN secures second carpark contract in Hong Kong plus JTC contract to license 10 carparks
summary: LHN Limited secured a second carpark management contract in Hong Kong and a contract to license 10 carparks from the Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) in Singapore. The Hong Kong contract, signed on January 4, 2018, is for a two-year period, while the JTC contract, signed on New Year's Day, runs for three years with an option for renewal. This brings LHN's total carpark management portfolio to 54, with 52 in Singapore and two in Hong Kong.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare announces private placement of 562.5 million shares to Itochu Corp
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare announced a private placement of 562.5 million new shares to Itochu Corp for S$78.75 million, with the shares to be listed by February 10. Itochu will acquire the shares at 14 Singapore cents per share, gaining a 25.3% stake in OUELH on a fully diluted basis. The placement is contingent on approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets dip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 2 points to 7,728.80. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also dropped 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively.

site_title: GSH unit incorporates property development company in China
summary: GSH Corporation's subsidiary, GSH (Xi'an) Investments, has incorporated a property development company in China, GSH (Xi'an) Property Development Co, with registered capital of S$135.25 million. This move aligns with the group's expansion plans into China.

site_title: UK industry on track to have boosted economy in Q4 2017
summary: The UK's industrial output is expected to contribute to a strong economic growth in Q4 2017, despite slower construction growth. Industrial output rose 2.5% in the year, driven by a 3.9% increase in manufacturing, while construction output dropped 2% in the three months to November. The goods trade deficit widened to a five-month high, but exports were 9.1% higher than a year ago. Economists expect the economy to grow at a quarterly rate of 0.4% in Q4, driven by industrial output.

site_title: Naspers is said to plan 2.5b rand investment in Swiggy
summary: Naspers is set to invest up to 2.5 billion rand (S$269.68 million) in India's Swiggy, a food delivery company, in partnership with Tencent Holdings. This comes after Naspers' initial US$80 million investment in Swiggy in May. The talks are advanced, with Naspers and Tencent seeing significant opportunities to co-invest in India's growing food delivery industry. The investment aims to increase Naspers' stake in Swiggy, with the goal of closing the valuation gap between the company's Naspers stake and Tencent's stake.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close lower as yen firms
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on January 10, 2018, due to a stronger yen weighing on the market. The bellwether index lost 0.26% to end at 23,788.20, while the Topix index gained 0.15%. Investors took profits after three days of rallies, with the yen's firming contributing to the decline.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda must stay to handle easing fallout, opposition head says
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is expected to be reappointed after his term expires in April, according to opposition leader Kouhei Ohtsuka, who believes Kuroda should stay to handle the potential fallout from five years of unprecedented monetary easing. Ohtsuka warns that winding back easing could lead to market instability and a recession, which would disproportionately affect ordinary workers and households. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe remains undecided, but Kuroda's reappointment is widely expected.

site_title: Japan's Aeon posts higher Q3 profit on restructuring boost
summary: Japan's Aeon Co Ltd, the country's largest retailer, reported a 37% jump in third-quarter operating profit to 17.8 billion yen, driven by restructuring efforts to boost sales at its struggling general merchandise stores. The company has been redesigning and rebranding its stores to attract customers away from discount stores and specialists. Aeon maintained its forecast for a record high operating profit of 200 billion yen for the year. The company's efforts come as Japanese consumption remains weak due to uncertainty over the economic outlook and households holding onto cash.

site_title: Oil prices hit highest since 2014, but analysts warn of overheated market
summary: Oil prices surged to their highest levels since 2014 due to ongoing production cuts by Opec and healthy demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reached $63.47 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose to $69.19 a barrel. Analysts warn of an overheated market, citing declining refining margins in Asia and rising production levels in the US.

site_title: Bayer, J&J win reversal of US$28m verdict in Xarelto lawsuit
summary: A Pennsylvania state court judge overturned a $27.8 million jury award to an Indiana couple who accused Bayer and Johnson & Johnson of failing to warn of internal bleeding risks of their drug Xarelto. The verdict was the first trial loss for the companies in Xarelto litigation. The judge ruled the decision was related to a "very narrow issue" and Bayer and J&J will continue to defend against allegations in related litigation.

site_title: UK factories on best run since 1997 amid global upswing
summary: UK manufacturers posted a seventh consecutive month of expansion in November, with factory output rising 0.4% and industrial production also increasing 0.4%. The sector's growth is attributed to a global upswing, particularly in the euro area, and a broad-based expansion across 10 out of 13 manufacturing sectors. However, construction output declined 0.4% and the trade deficit widened to £2.8 billion, while the economy is forecast to expand by 1.4% in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia to pay US firm up to US$70m if it finds missing MH370
summary: Malaysia has signed a deal with a US seabed exploration firm to search for the missing MH370 aircraft in the Southern Indian Ocean. The search, which must be completed within 90 days, could result in a payment of up to US$70 million. The aircraft vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board, making it one of the world's greatest aviation mysteries. A previous search in the area ended without finding the plane, but the new search area is larger, spanning 25,000 square kilometers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slump on chip worries; won ends at 2-week low
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index declined 0.42% to 2,499.75, its lowest level in two weeks, due to investor concerns over Samsung Electronics' disappointing profit guidance. The won also fell to a two-week low, closing at 1,071.9 per US dollar. This drop was attributed to worries about the chip sector, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index down 0.50% and Japanese stocks weakening 0.26%.

site_title: US pharma execs expect deals to pick up after tax overhaul
summary: US pharmaceutical executives expect a surge in major acquisitions in 2018 due to the Trump administration's tax overhaul, which lowers the corporate tax rate to 21% from 35%. The tax reform is expected to clear decks for industry consolidation, with CEOs like Brent Saunders of Allergan anticipating more oncology deals and larger, transformative deals to follow in the back half of 2018 or 2019. Several companies, including Amgen and Bristol-Myers, have already announced plans to bring overseas cash into the US, which is expected to boost the market and facilitate more strategic opportunities.

site_title: US House backs greater ties with Taiwan, risking China's ire
summary: The US House of Representatives passed two bills supporting Taiwan, increasing diplomatic ties and potentially straining relations with China. The bills aim to encourage US-Taiwan exchanges and help Taiwan regain its observer status in the World Health Organization. This move could test the US-China relationship, particularly amid trade disputes and North Korea tensions. The bills must still be approved by the Senate and signed into law by President Trump to become effective.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on negative ground; STI at 3,518.48
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.2% to 3,518.48 at 1:03pm, with 860.9 million shares traded worth S$577 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 204 to 157, and Spackman was the top gainer, up 9.1%. DBS and Singtel also fell, down 0.23% and 0.28%, respectively.

site_title: Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, OCBC see Singapore private home prices rebounding this year
summary: Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, and OCBC predict a rebound in Singapore's private home prices this year, with potential increases of up to 10% and 8%. After a four-year slump, prices rose 1% in 2017, with developer valuations remaining attractive. Collective sales and new home sales are expected to boost the market, with home sales projected to increase 40% in 2018. However, potential government cooling measures pose a risk, and prices could double by 2030.

site_title: SGX currency futures traded up 59% in 2017 on rupee, offshore renminbi contracts
summary: SGX currency futures trading surged 59% in 2017, driven by increased trading in Indian rupee (INR) and offshore renminbi (CNH) contracts. Notional values rose to US$245 billion, with USD/CNH futures nearly quadrupling against the previous year. The growth was attributed to economic initiatives, such as India's GST reform, and the yuan's 5.7% gain against the US dollar. The report noted that volatility in the currency markets benefited SGX, with 126 trading days in 2017 featuring trades over US$1 billion.

images.alt_text: Amid recent tensions on the Korean Peninsula,the yuan usurped the greenback as a safe-haven currency.

site_title: Australian shares end lower after notching 10-year peak; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares reached a 10-year high before closing 0.6% lower at 6,096.7, snapping a five-session winning streak. Materials and real estate stocks led declines, with Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton falling 0.8% and 0.3% respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index peaked at 6,150 points in early trade.

site_title: AirAsia explores India unit IPO, seeks partner for services business
summary: Malaysia-based AirAsia Bhd is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its Indian unit, AirAsia India, and seeking a partner for its services business. The airline's group CEO, Tony Fernandes, said the Indian venture is a "very valuable asset with huge growth potential" despite incurring start-up losses. AirAsia India has 14 planes, aiming to reach 20 for international routes, and its revenue is expected to double to 12 billion rupees in 2018. The company will seek approval to pick a banker for an IPO process.

site_title: Line said to explore cryptocurrencies for payment services
summary: Line, a Tokyo-based messaging platform, is exploring the integration of cryptocurrencies into its services. The company is in talks with multiple firms to use cryptocurrencies for payment services, including Line Pay. This move aims to increase user "stickiness" and differentiate Line from competitors like Facebook and Snap. Line shares surged 10% earlier this week, following speculation about a potential alliance with a South Korean bitcoin exchange. The company joins a growing list of businesses capitalizing on the technology and hype surrounding bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.

site_title: China's top developers poised for strong sales as debt woes linger
summary: China's top developers are poised for strong sales in 2018, with the top 10 developers expected to capture nearly 35% of the market share, up from 27% now. Despite slowing sales growth and debt concerns, major developers such as China Evergrande and Sunac China are confident in double-digit sales growth. The market is expected to remain resilient, with steady prices underpinning the market, and investors are focusing on revenue rather than debt risks. However, analysts warn that the expansion rate of China's largest developers may not be sustainable, and a market correction could test developers' liquidity.

site_title: Venture capital investing hits highest since dot-com boom
summary: Venture capital funding in the US reached its highest level since the dot-com era, with US$84 billion deployed in over 8,000 companies last year. This is comparable to the dot-com era, but the VC ecosystem appears healthy due to different dynamics. Later-stage companies with strong consumer traction are commanding large rounds of financing, while the number of exits fell for the third consecutive year. SoftBank's $100 billion Vision fund and other non-traditional investors have contributed to this trend, funding companies that would have otherwise gone public or sold themselves.

site_title: French President Macron says contract with China for 184 A320s to be finalised soon
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced a contract with China for 184 Airbus A320s, expected to be finalized soon. Macron also expressed ambitions to sell A350 and A380 planes to China in the coming weeks or months. China has assured Macron that it will respect market-share parity between Airbus and Boeing. This follows a recent visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping, where China placed an order for 140 Airbus jets. The deal is part of Airbus' plans to boost production in Tianjin to six A320 family jets per month by 2020.

site_title: Troubled Noble Group says goodbye to global oil trading
summary: Noble Group, a troubled commodities trader, is closing its London oil desk and winding down its Asia oil operations due to heavy losses and high debt. The company's US oil trading business was sold to Vitol in October, and it reported a nine-month loss of $3 billion in November. Noble's market value has shrunk from $6 billion to $215 million, and it is returning to its roots as a hard commodities business in Asia, mainly involved in coal marketing. The closures mark an effective exit from the oil trading business, with many key traders leaving to join competitors.

site_title: With pricey electric car, Fisker eyes comeback
summary: Henrik Fisker unveiled the $129,000 Fisker EMotion, an electric luxury car, at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, marking a comeback effort for the renowned auto designer. The car features semi-autonomous driving, a 650km range, and butterfly doors. Fisker aims to improve range and charging time with his own battery technology and partnerships with companies like Quanergy. A more affordable vehicle, priced around $40,000, is also in development, along with a self-driving shuttle bus called the Orbit. Fisker's comeback faces competition from Tesla and other electric car manufacturers.

site_title: Bitcoin can drop 50% and China's miners will still make money
summary: Bitcoin mining in China remains profitable even if the cryptocurrency price drops by 50%, according to a report by Bloomberg New Energy Finance (BNEF). The report states that as long as the price of bitcoin is above $6,925, miners can still make money, regardless of the electricity price in China. This is because miners can negotiate low electricity rates, and the computers used in mining are relatively cheap and can be easily replaced. China's plan to restrict bitcoin miners' power use may not have a drastic impact on the global bitcoin network.

site_title: Here's where BOJ may next send a signal on Japan bond yields
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) limited forward guidance has led investors to speculate on potential shifts in policy, with recent bond purchases trimmed in favor of ultra-long yields. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's comments in November hinted at a theory that extremely low interest rates can harm the banking industry, fueling speculation of yield curve adjustments. Personnel appointments, including deputy governors' terms, may provide further clues on the BOJ's policy outlook, with a potential boost in yield curve targets considered likely in the late second-quarter to early third-quarter of this year.

site_title: US judge blocks Trump move rescinding immigrant programme
summary: A US judge blocked President Donald Trump's administration from ending the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which provides legal status to young immigrants who entered the country illegally as children. The program, enacted during Barack Obama's presidency, was set to be rescinded but Judge William Alsup's ruling has ordered the administration to reinstate it on a nationwide basis. Former DACA recipients are now eligible to submit renewal applications, and the government must post public notice that the program is active unless overturned by a higher court.

site_title: New Google headset, camera aim to spread VR beyond gaming
summary: Google has released a new VR headset, the Mirage Solo, designed to spread virtual reality beyond gaming. The device features high-end VR capabilities, including untethered use and displays that don't blur when moving. Google also introduced VR180 cameras, meant to encourage 360-degree footage capture for viewing in VR devices. This move aims to address the current limitations of VR adoption, which are largely driven by gaming. The new technology is set to expand VR's reach to a broader audience.

site_title: Hyundai Motor considering plant in South-east Asia after China setback
summary: Hyundai Motor is considering building a car plant in South-east Asia, with Indonesia and Vietnam as potential locations, in an effort to diversify after a sales slump in China. The automaker is looking to expand its presence in the region after a diplomatic row between Beijing and Seoul over the US anti-missile defense system THAAD. Hyundai expects its China sales to reach 900,000 vehicles in 2018, a recovery from last year. The company plans to enter China's fuel cell electric car market with its new NEXO model.

site_title: South Korea's Moon says Trump deserves 'big' credit for North Korea talks
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In credited US President Donald Trump for sparking the first inter-Korean talks in over two years, which aimed to resolve problems between the two Koreas through dialogue. The talks, held on the demilitarized zone, resulted in an agreement to revive military consultations and resolve all issues between the two sides. However, Pyongyang warned that it would not discuss its nuclear weapons with Seoul, and Moon cautioned that provocations would lead to stronger sanctions if continued. The US welcomed the talks as a first step towards solving the North Korean nuclear crisis.

site_title: Australia swelters through one of hottest years on record
summary: Australia experienced its third-hottest year on record in 2017, with seven of the 10 warmest years occurring since 2005. Despite no El Nino weather phenomenon, temperatures were extremely warm, with maximum temperatures being the second-warmest on record. The country's annual mean temperature increased by 1.1 degrees Celsius since 1910, with the eastern states of New South Wales and Queensland being the hardest hit. Climate change is linked to the extreme heat, with significant coral bleaching on the Great Barrier Reef and prolonged high sea surface temperatures.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars stall as US bond yields climb
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell on Wednesday due to a sharp rise in US Treasury yields, which reached a 10-month peak of 2.55%. The US dollar gained strength after China's central bank loosened controls on the yuan, prompting investors to short the Aussie. However, commodity prices, including oil and iron ore, remained buoyant, supporting the Australian dollar. The losses in Australian and New Zealand bond markets mirrored the losses in Treasuries.

site_title: Your best response when a company shouts crypto? Run
summary: A US-listed company's entry into cryptocurrency often results in a surge in shares, followed by a sharp decline. Speculators capitalize on the initial gain, while others are left holding losses. This pattern has repeated itself in the past, with some investors making quick profits and others facing significant losses. The article does not provide specific details on the company in question, but highlights the volatility and unpredictability of the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Hyundai Motor considering plant in South-east Asia after China setback
summary: Hyundai Motor is considering building a car plant in South-east Asia, with Indonesia and Vietnam as potential locations, following a sales slump in China due to diplomatic tensions. The move aims to diversify the company's operations, which have been heavily reliant on the Chinese market. Hyundai currently has pure assembly operations in Indonesia and Vietnam using "knock-down" kits. The company's efforts to expand in the region come after a diplomatic row between Beijing and Seoul over the US anti-missile defense system THAAD.

site_title: Tennis: Halep, Wozniacki lead race to seize Serena's Aussie crown
summary: Simona Halep and Caroline Wozniacki lead the charge to succeed Serena Williams at the Australian Open, following her withdrawal due to pregnancy. The tournament is now open to a host of players, including Elina Svitolina and Maria Sharapova, who is returning from a 15-month doping ban. Halep, the world number one, will need to overcome her poor record at Melbourne Park, while Wozniacki is riding high after a resurgence in 2017. The competition is fierce, with other contenders including Venus Williams and Karolina Pliskova.

site_title: Former civil service head Peter Ong to chair Enterprise Singapore
summary: Former civil service head Peter Ong Boon Kwee was named chairman-designate of Enterprise Singapore, following the first reading of the Enterprise Singapore Board Bill in Parliament. This appointment aims to better help local firms grow and go global. The formation of Enterprise Singapore was announced last year, resulting from the merger of International Enterprise (IE) Singapore and Spring Singapore.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents continued to slip in December but full-year declines eased in 2017
summary: Singapore's housing rental market showed a soft patch in December, with private non-landed segment rents slipping 0.3% and HDB rents falling 0.6%. The full-year declines were more moderate than the previous year, at 0.5% for private non-landed and 3.5% for HDB.

site_title: Asia: Shares step back from 2007 peak, oil at 3-year high
summary: Asian shares declined 0.3% on Wednesday, snapping a six-day winning streak, as investors took profits from high-tech shares. Oil prices rose to a three-year high due to production cuts and low inventories, boosting inflation concerns. Despite this, economic growth expectations remained solid, with US fourth-quarter earnings expected to rise 11.8% and the Fed to raise interest rates slowly. Markets reacted cautiously to North Korea's talks with South Korea, but risk sentiment was boosted by easing tensions.

site_title: Domino's turnaround CEO to step down in June
summary: Domino's Pizza Inc. announced that CEO Patrick Doyle will step down in June, to be replaced by Richard Allison. Doyle oversaw a turnaround that improved the company's pizza taste and invested in online ordering. His departure led to a 2.8% drop in shares to $201. Doyle, 54, is seen as a potential candidate for Chipotle's CEO job, which has struggled with food safety issues and digital efforts. Allison, 50, will take over as CEO on July 1.

site_title: IBM breaks patent record in 25th straight year as No 1
summary: IBM has broken the record for the most US patents in 25 consecutive years, receiving 9,043 patents in 2017. The company's research and development investments continue to focus on emerging technologies such as blockchain and artificial intelligence, with over 1,400 patents related to AI. Despite this, IBM's struggles to turn itself around are evident, with slowing sales in older business lines and growth in newer areas not yet closing the gap.

site_title: Aramco seeking US$2b from Japan's export agency: sources
summary: Saudi Arabian Oil, Aramco, is seeking a $2 billion loan from Japan's export-credit agency, the Japan Bank for International Cooperation. This comes as Aramco prepares for its planned initial public offering (IPO), potentially valuing the company at $2 trillion. The loan facility would make the Japanese agency the second state institution to extend financing to Aramco ahead of the IPO. Competing lenders, including Goldman Sachs and Citigroup, are vying for a role in the IPO.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian sees Tianjin Zhong Xin poised for 'stellar 2018' under new management
summary: UOB Kay Hian analysts are optimistic about Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group's prospects in 2018 under new management. The brokerage reiterated its "buy" call and target price of US$1.52, an upside of 57.5%, following the successful price hike of the company's flagship medication, Su Xiao Jiu Xin heart medication.

site_title: Singapore passport ranks second globally, first in Asia
summary: Singapore's passport ranks second globally and first in Asia, with holders enjoying visa-free access to 176 countries, up from 173 last year. Germany's passport holds the top spot, allowing its holders visa-free access to 177 countries. Other countries in South-east Asia also improved in the rankings, with Indonesia rising by seven positions and Thailand and the Philippines each rising by three. The Henley Passport Index attributes the improvements to the rise in global opportunities in the economy, despite facing impediments such as the US travel ban.

site_title: 'To boldly grow': Japan astronaut worried by space growth spurt
summary: Japanese astronaut Norishige Kanai claims to have grown 9cm in space, sparking concern about fitting into the Soyuz capsule upon return. Initially, he measured himself and tweeted the growth, but later corrected the claim after re-measuring himself, revealing a 2cm increase. Kanai's spine can extend in space due to zero-gravity, but this returns to normal upon re-entry. The astronaut later apologized for the "fake news," expressing relief that he likely won't have issues with the Soyuz capsule.

site_title: Sony chief wants to be buyer in media consolidation wave
summary: Sony CEO Kaz Hirai expressed interest in acquiring 21st Century Fox's film and TV assets, citing a desire to maintain control over the assets the company has grown. Theatrical films remain a priority, and Hirai also aims to expand TV production. Sony ranked fifth at the box office last year, with US$1.09 billion in North American ticket revenue. Despite losing to Walt Disney in the acquisition, Hirai emphasized the need for Sony to be a buyer in the media consolidation wave.

site_title: HNA fails to disclose how it controls Virgin Australia stake
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, failed to disclose how it controls its $350 million stake in Virgin Australia Holdings, citing "relevant interest" from 518 entities across the globe. This comes after regulators in New Zealand blocked HNA's acquisition in December citing the company's opaque ownership structure. The belated disclosure was made in a letter to Virgin Australia on January 2, following the New Zealand regulator's decision.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.92 points to 1,828.87. The index saw 179.65 million lots traded worth RM39.58 million, with 208 gainers and 52 losers.

site_title: Australia: Shares lose steam as real estate weighs; NZ drops
summary: Australian shares declined 22.8 points, or 0.4%, to 6,113, their biggest intraday drop in over a week, as real estate and materials stocks weighed down the S&P/ASX 200 index. Property stocks fell, with Goodman Group and GPT Group dropping 2.5% and 2.8%, respectively. US Treasury yields hit a 10-month high, contributing to the decline, and analysts attributed the drop to concerns over higher interest rates and valuation pressure on real estate investment trusts.

site_title: Ukraine to launch its first solar plant at Chernobyl
summary: Ukraine is set to launch its first solar plant at the Chernobyl disaster site, a one-megawatt power plant located near the sarcophagus of the damaged reactor. The project, funded by the international community, aims to revive the abandoned territory and produce 100 times the initial solar power. The solar installation, which has 3,800 photovoltaic panels, will cover the needs of a medium-sized village and is expected to pay for itself within seven years. The project follows a similar solar power plant in neighboring Belarus and is seen as a potential way to exploit the region's potential for renewable energy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE Lippo Healthcare, Hiap Tong Corp, USP Group
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare halted trading due to an announcement. Hiap Tong Corporation secured a five-year lifting services contract extension with ExxonMobil, expected to positively impact earnings. USP Group signed agreements with Harbin Engineering University and Maxthon Yachts for boat building interests.

site_title: 400 deaths a day are forcing India to take car safety seriously
summary: India is implementing stricter car safety regulations, with over 400 daily traffic fatalities prompting the government to introduce a bill requiring automakers to add safety features such as airbags and anti-lock braking systems. The bill, passed in the lower house of parliament, is expected to increase manufacturing costs for domestic and foreign carmakers. India aims to become the world's third-largest car market by 2020, and the new law is expected to boost safety standards, but its success will depend on strict implementation.

images.alt_text: In India, more than 150,000 people are killed each year in traffic accidents. That's about 400 fatalities a day and far higher than developed auto markets like the US, which in 2016 logged about 40,000.

site_title: Iranian oil tanker in East China Sea could burn for a month: South Korean official
summary: A South Korean official warned that an Iranian oil tanker in the East China Sea could burn for up to a month after colliding with a freight ship. The blaze raged for a fourth day, leaving 31 missing sailors and sparking concerns the ship may explode or sink. The tanker's highly flammable condensate poses a risk of water contamination if it sinks. Authorities suspect the fire started immediately after the collision, and the tanker has moved 100km southeast, reducing the likelihood of oil spreading to South Korea.

images.alt_text: The stricken Iranian oil tanker in the East China Sea could burn for as long as one month, South Korea's Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries told Reuters on Wednesday, as the blaze raged for a fourth day following a collision with a freight ship.

site_title: Richest Asian banker plans family office but spurns crypto
summary: Uday Kotak, billionaire managing director of Kotak Mahindra Bank Ltd., is setting up a family office to invest in assets like private equity, stocks, and real estate worldwide. The office will manage his family's $1.2 billion in cash and investable assets, excluding debt and cryptocurrencies. The move is aimed at diversifying his wealth and staying clear of investments that could conflict with his bank. Venkat Subramanian will oversee the family office, which is expected to focus on asset classes outside of debt and cryptocurrency investments.

site_title: SRX resale condo price index up for 5th consecutive month
summary: Singapore's resale condo price index rose 0.4% in December, marking the fifth consecutive month-on-month gain. The city-fringe or Rest of Central Region apartments led the increase with a 0.6% gain, while the overall resale price index for non-landed private homes is up 6.2% year-on-year. The overall resale volume decreased 38.3% in December compared to November. Experts attribute the price gains to improved market sentiment, fewer new projects, and strong land bids in collective sales.

site_title: French beef producers cheer chance for return to China
summary: French beef producers welcomed a deal to end China's 16-year embargo on French beef, allowing them to enter the huge Chinese market within six months. The ban was imposed in 2011 due to the "mad cow" disease scare. The agreement comes as French President Emmanuel Macron promotes the safety of French meat and opens new markets for its ranchers, who have seen declining consumption. The Chinese market is expected to be competitive, requiring investment to establish a presence.

site_title: GLP privatisation scheme goes into effect; delisting date set for Jan 22
summary: GLOBAL Logistic Properties (GLP) is set to delist from the Singapore Exchange on January 22, marking its exit in a record S$16 billion privatisation deal. The deal, backed by Chinese private equity consortium Nesta Investment Holdings, will see shareholders receive S$3.38 per share in cash. National sovereign wealth fund GIC, GLP's largest shareholder, will receive a nearly 37% stake in the deal. The privatisation scheme became effective on January 10, with payment expected by January 19.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI slips by 0.09% in morning trading
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 3.1 points, or 0.09%, to 3,521.55. However, the overall trend is expected to be lifted by optimism over corporate earnings announcements and improved geopolitical relations. Gainers outnumbered losers 85 to 40, and 45.9 million shares changed hands, worth S$99.6 million. Despite the initial drop, investor sentiment remains positive, driven by the highest number of constituents paying out dividends in 2017.

site_title: Bannon steps down from Breitbart News in post-book storm
summary: Steve Bannon has stepped down from Breitbart News, a conservative news outlet, amid controversy over incendiary remarks about President Donald Trump in a new book. Bannon's departure comes after being abandoned by financial patrons, condemned by allies, and ridiculed by Trump. The book, "Fire and Fury," portrays Trump as disengaged, ill-informed, and unstable. Bannon's exit from Breitbart threatens to further isolate the site, which was once a champion of anti-Washington populism.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slightly up, won pulls back
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.63 points, or 0.06 percent, to 2,511.86 at 01.04 GMT. The Korean won weakened 0.3 percent to 1,070.3 per dollar, while bond yields rose. Despite this, the Kospi is up 1.7 percent for the year and 1.06 percent in the past 30 days. Foreigners were net buyers of 5,423 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat after rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat after three consecutive days of rallies, with the Nikkei 225 index edging down 0.07% to 23,832.46. Investors took a cautious stance amid ongoing market volatility and US tariff threats. The broader Topix index opened up 0.05%. The flat opening follows a recent surge in Asian markets, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Huawei hit by last minute collapse of AT&T phone distribution deal
summary: Huawei's phone distribution deal with AT&T has collapsed at the last minute due to security concerns, a major setback for the Chinese firm's global ambitions. The collapse occurred just before the deal was set to be finalized. This development is a significant blow to Huawei's efforts to expand its presence in the US market. The exact nature of the security concerns is not disclosed, but it is clear that they were a major factor in the collapse of the deal.

site_title: Interior design contractor Serrano names 2 new board members
summary: Serrano, an interior design contractor, appointed Winston Tan Tien Hin and Ong Kian Guan to its board of directors, effective January 16, 2018. The appointments follow the departures of four board members and come as the company undergoes restructuring. The arrangements are interim, with the company assessing suitable candidates for its board and committees.

site_title: Cash company China Bearing gets another six months to meet criteria for Catalist listing
summary: China Bearing, a Singapore-based cash company, has received a six-month extension to meet criteria for a Catalist listing until June 20, 2018. The company cited due diligence for its proposed acquisition of an Indonesian nickel mine as the reason for the extension. China Bearing needs shareholder approval for the acquisition and relisting on the Catalist board. The acquisition, valued at US$50 million, involves the purchase of a 1,301-hectare nickel ore mine in Indonesia, with the company to issue up to 95.8 million new shares to the vendor.

site_title: Boeing logs record deliveries for 2017, upbeat on 2018
summary: Boeing reported a record 763 commercial plane deliveries in 2017, surpassing its forecast and the prior record set in 2015. The company's deliveries were led by its 737 and 787 models, with 912 new orders in 2017 valued at $134.8 billion. Boeing's shares jumped 2.6% following the announcement, with analysts praising the company's strong performance and upward pressure in the market. The company is on track to raise production rates for its 747 and 737 models, and is also in talks with Brazil's Embraer about a potential partnership.

site_title: Microsoft says security patches slowing down PCs, servers
summary: Microsoft reported that security patches for microchip security threats are slowing down PCs and servers, particularly those using older Intel processors. The patches, which fix flaws in Intel and AMD chips, have caused noticeable performance decreases. Microsoft's comments are the first clear indication of the impact of the patches. Intel's shares fell 2.5% and AMD's shares rose 4% as investors speculated about market share shifts. The patches also affected Cisco's products, with the company expecting patches in about five weeks.

site_title: Cryptocurrency may be getting channelled to N Korea university
summary: A cybersecurity firm has discovered software that appears to mine cryptocurrency and sends mined coins to a server at Kim Il Sung University in Pyongyang, North Korea. The software uses Monero, a cryptocurrency that offers anonymity, and is believed to be part of North Korea's efforts to infuse its economy with cash. The university hosts foreign students and lecturers, raising questions about the true purpose of the software. This discovery highlights North Korea's interest in cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology as a potential means to circumvent economic sanctions.

site_title: UK economy set for "underwhelming" 2018, says British Chambers of Commerce
summary: The UK economy is expected to experience an underwhelming 2018, according to the British Chambers of Commerce. The survey found businesses are in a subdued mood due to Brexit uncertainty, cost pressures, and weak productivity. The services sector expanded at a slow pace, while manufacturers saw a slowdown in domestic and export sales. Economists predict modest growth, but below most peers, with the services sector facing recruitment difficulties and expected to raise prices, potentially dampening economic activity.

site_title: Gold drifts lower on Europe concerns, buoyant shares
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,312.58 per ounce, weighed down by a stronger US dollar and concerns over European political uncertainty. The euro's decline due to Italian election concerns and Brexit worries also contributed to the decrease. Palladium reached a record high, boosted by increased demand from the automotive industry, while silver and platinum also declined.

site_title: 'Roseanne' returning to TV as Trump supporter
summary: "Roseanne," a classic ABC sitcom, is set to return for a 10th season in March 2018, with its title character, played by Roseanne Barr, as a supporter of President Donald Trump. Barr defends her decision, citing her desire to reflect the societal reality of the 2016 election. The show's revival features original cast members John Goodman and Sara Gilbert, and will air on ABC on March 27, with Barr open to working on an 11th season.

site_title: Nafta has worked for US oil industry: executive
summary: US oil industry executive Jack Gerard urged the Trump administration to keep the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) intact, citing its benefits to the energy sector. Gerard stated that the energy part of Nafta is not broken, warning that altering the terms would be a mistake. The next round of Nafta talks is set to open in Montreal later this month.

site_title: Internet giants not doing enough to take down illegal content: EU
summary: The European Union expressed concerns that internet giants like Facebook, Google, and Twitter are not removing illegal content quickly enough. Five EU Commissioners met with representatives from these companies to discuss progress in removing hate speech, extremist material, and counterfeit products. The companies have made efforts to detail changes, but more action is needed to address the issue. The EU is under pressure from several European governments to take stronger action against illegal online content.

site_title: Swiss National Bank expects record 2017 profit of 54b Swiss francs
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) expects a record annual profit of 54 billion Swiss francs (S$73.4 billion) for 2017, the largest in its 110-year history. The bank attributes the profit to its successful strategy to weaken the Swiss franc, which has depreciated by nearly 9% against the euro last year, boosting its foreign currency positions and gold holdings. The record profit exceeds its previous highest annual profit of 38.3 billion francs in 2014.

site_title: US crude hits 3-year high as prices climb in tight market
summary: US crude oil prices reached a 3-year high of $63.24 per barrel on Tuesday, driven by OPEC-led production cuts and expectations of declining US crude inventories. This is the highest price since December 2014. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies, including Russia, are maintaining supply limits to reduce a price-denting glut of oil in inventories. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 2% to settle at $62.96 per barrel, driven by tight market conditions.

site_title: EU risks financial crisis if it blocks Brexit deal, warns UK
summary: The European Union risks another global financial crisis if it refuses to give the UK a good trade deal, two senior UK ministers warned. Chancellor Philip Hammond and Brexit Secretary David Davis called for close cooperation between EU and UK regulators to prevent a financial catastrophe. They want a deal that supports collaboration within the European banking sector, rather than forcing it to fragment. The EU's hardline stance on banking has raised concerns, with EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warning that UK banks will lose their "passporting" rights.

images.alt_text: The European Union (EU) risks opening the door to another global financial crisis if it refuses to give London's bankers a good trade deal, two senior UK ministers said, as the finance industry emerged as a key battleground for Brexit talks.

site_title: Theresa May's weakness resurfaces as Cabinet reboot results in chaos
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's attempt to refresh her Cabinet resulted in chaos as senior ministers rejected proposed moves, including Education Secretary Justine Greening's refusal to accept another job. The reshuffle, which was meant to inject momentum into domestic policies, was marred by disagreements and opposition from lawmakers. May's ability to navigate the Brexit talks is now seen as compromised, with her government facing a delicate balance of pro- and anti-EU voices. The outcome raises concerns about her leadership and the party's ability to deliver a Brexit deal.

site_title: Toyota, Mazda to build US$1.6b plant in Alabama: sources
summary: Toyota and Mazda are investing $1.6 billion in a new car plant in Huntsville, Alabama, employing up to 4,000 people and producing 300,000 vehicles annually. The plant is a result of US President Donald Trump's efforts to persuade manufacturers to build new US facilities. A formal announcement is expected in Montgomery on Wednesday, marking a boon for Alabama, which already hosts a large Toyota engine plant and automotive suppliers.

images.alt_text: Alabama will be the site of a new US$1.6 billion Toyota Motor and Mazda Motor car plant, a victory for US President Donald Trump who had prodded manufacturers to build new US facilities and threatened tariffs on foreign production, sources said on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Shares at fresh highs on earning optimism, dealmaking
summary: European shares rose for a fourth consecutive session, reaching fresh highs, driven by optimism about company earnings, dealmaking in the auto industry, and a weaker euro. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.4% to its highest level since August 2015, with cyclical stocks, such as Altice and Continental, leading the gains. Stronger metals prices and a boost from the financial sector also contributed to the rally, with strategists expecting solid earnings and low risk of valuation issues.

site_title: World Bank upgrades global growth forecasts as recovery strengthens
summary: The World Bank has upgraded its global growth forecasts for the first time in many years, citing a "good story" of highly synchronized economic expansion across regions. Global growth is now expected to rise to 3.0% in 2017, 3.1% in 2018, and 3.0% in 2019. The bank warns that countries must invest in education, health, and infrastructure to improve growth prospects before the next economic crisis. Risks include rising debt levels, trade restrictions, and a potential slowdown in advanced economies. The World Bank recommends a combination of investments and reforms to boost long-term growth and poverty reduction.

images.alt_text: For the first time in many years, the World Bank's outlook for the global economy is better than expected rather than worse, with all regions seeing improved growth, according to its latest forecast released Tuesday.

site_title: Mexican vehicle exports up in 2017 despite Nafta fears
summary: Mexican vehicle exports reached a record high in 2017, growing 12.1% and production increased 8.9%. Despite concerns over the renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), exports rose 16.7% in December, and production forecast for 2018 is over 4 million units, a 6% increase. Car sales in Mexico contracted 4.6% in 2017, with Ford suffering the biggest drop in business, down 18% compared to 2016.

site_title: Will the economy save Trump?
summary: US President Trump's economy forecast for 2018 is looking strong, with a predicted 2.6% growth rate and unemployment rate dropping below 4%. The improving global economy and a "Goldilocks" economy, where growth is fast enough to create jobs but not inflation, are expected to boost consumer spending and the stock market. However, some economists warn that sky-high stock prices pose a recession risk, and a financial crisis in China or war on the Korean Peninsula could derail the forecast.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records, extending rally
summary: US stocks closed at new records, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index finishing 0.4%, 0.1%, and 0.1% higher, respectively. This marks the sixth straight day of record closes. Investors are optimistic ahead of key earnings reports, fueled by the US tax cut plan and better economic data. Shares of JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo, and other financial heavyweights rose, while biotech companies like Gilead Sciences and Illumina also gained. However, Intel slumped 2.5% due to concerns over a computer chip vulnerability.

site_title: Pole-dancing robots spice up nerd fest
summary: British artist Giles Walker's robots, designed to resemble strippers, are performing at a Las Vegas club as part of the 2018 Consumer Electronics Show. The robots, made from scrap materials, are powered by recovered windshield wiper motors and were intended to comment on surveillance, power, and voyeurism. The performance received mixed reviews, with some attendees preferring human dancers and others finding the robots' moves appealing. The event aimed to add variety and creativity to the venue, which hosts attendees to one of the world's largest tech shows.

site_title: GM races to build a formula for profitable electric cars
summary: General Motors (GM) aims to make a profit selling electric cars by 2021, a goal set by CEO Mary Barra. The company plans to achieve this by combining proprietary battery technology, low-cost vehicle design, and high-volume production in China. GM's strategy includes slashing cobalt in its new battery system, increasing nickel content, and cutting battery costs by over 30% by 2021. The company expects this to reduce the cost of battery packs from $10,000 to $6,000.

site_title: Price isn't everything in mastering South-east Asia's mobile markets
summary: South-east Asia's mobile markets have entered a new phase, shifting from price wars to a focus on providing a superior customer experience. With penetration rates exceeding 100%, operators can no longer rely on low rates to attract customers. Instead, they're investing in networks for fast and reliable service, particularly for data-intensive activities. A Bain & Company survey found that customers prioritize strong voice connections, fast video downloads, and hassle-free social media access. Operators like TrueMove H, Telkomsel, and Globe Telecom are adopting differentiated strategies to meet customers' changing needs, including offering value-for-money propositions and special plans for heavy users of certain apps.

site_title: HK court fines ivory trader US$1,000 for illegal trading as China cracks down
summary: A Hong Kong court fined US$1,000 (HK$8,000) ivory trader Lau Sai Yuan for illegal ivory possession, following China's total ban on ivory sales implemented at the end of 2017. Wildlife activists hail the ban as a step towards reducing elephant slaughter. Hong Kong lawmakers consider increasing penalties, with fines up to HK$10 million and 10 years in jail. The former British colony has lagged in cracking down on illegal ivory trading, with the largest retail market for ivory.

site_title: Singapore tops Asean for 2018 property market growth forecasts
summary: Morgan Stanley forecasts Singapore's property market to experience 8% price increase and nearly 50% presales growth in 2018, making it the most promising Asean market. The research house expects City Developments (CDL) to be its top stock pick, driven by a buoyant collective sale market and a tight supply of unsold inventory. CDL's revalued net asset value (RNAV) estimate is also expected to increase, and the stock trades at a discount to RNAV, making it an attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: US economy may be poised for a supply-side surprise
summary: The US economy may experience a supply-side surprise in 2018, potentially boosting inflation and requiring the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Despite the Fed's pessimistic view of the economy's growth potential, a high-pressure economy could stimulate investment and productivity growth, leading to faster wage growth and inflation. However, this could also lead to upward pressure on the yield curve, making it difficult for the Fed to ease policy. The outcome may be a more accommodative monetary policy, despite the Fed's current rate forecast, and could lead to a faster pace of potential growth.

site_title: Investor residency scheme created 6,000 jobs from 2011-2016
summary: Singapore's Global Investor Programme created over 6,000 jobs and generated S$1.8 billion in total business expenditure from 2011 to 2016 through investments from high-level investors and entrepreneurs. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Sim Ann stated this in Parliament.

site_title: Australia's home building boom gets new burst of energy
summary: Australia's home building boom surged to 15-month highs in November 2017, with 21,055 building approvals reaching the third strongest on record. The 11.7% increase in approvals, or 17% on a year-over-year basis, was a surprise to analysts. The value of approved homes jumped to A$7.7 billion, a record peak, and is expected to drive economic growth and job creation. The Reserve Bank of Australia is keeping interest rates at record lows, allowing the sector to continue its revival, which has already lasted almost five years.

site_title: Carmakers saying 'slow down' to early rollout of robo-cars
summary: Top auto and tech executives say truly driverless vehicles are years away, despite recent advancements in self-driving technology. Executives from Toyota, Hyundai, and Lyft downplay expectations for the arrival of autonomy, citing major hurdles such as replicating the human brain and addressing safety concerns. Companies are instead focusing on semi-autonomous capabilities and collaborating on infrastructure development for autonomous vehicles. Experts predict a long journey to achieving true Level 5 autonomy, with some targeting 2021 for Level 4 capability, but human drivers will likely remain necessary for the foreseeable future.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Taxes, transformation and tooling up for the future
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat is expected to focus on tax revenue, economic transformation, and social measures in the 2018 Budget. With a stronger economy, the government plans to invest in infrastructure and social spending, which may lead to tax increases. This year's Budget aims to balance fiscal health with economic growth and social welfare.

site_title: Rising inflation in Japan can shake bond markets
summary: Japan's low inflation rate, currently below 1%, may trigger a market shock as it approaches the country's long-targeted level of 2% in autumn 2018, driven by a tight labor market, higher commodity prices, and increased consumer spending. This could lead to a surge in government bond markets, not just in Japan but also in the US and Europe. The Bank of Japan is expected to err on the easing side, adjusting its monetary policy framework to maintain low yields, but may also normalize interest rates gradually due to international monetary authorities' caution.

site_title: NTU unveils all-in-one Smart Pass to support Smart Campus
summary: NTU in Singapore has unveiled an all-in-one Smart Pass, a credit card with a student's picture, for various campus activities and contactless payments. The pass, embedded with Nets' FlashPay function, will be used for identification, access to classrooms, and payments at canteens and vending machines. The university plans to deploy fully electric shuttles and autonomous buses, with the goal of becoming the largest Smart Campus in Singapore. The Smart Campus initiative also aims to enhance digital literacy and introduce new educational modules, including an undergraduate program in data science and AI.

site_title: Great tips on workplace collaboration
summary: A 2017 e-book by Dropbox and The School of Life highlights four virtues for great collaboration: gaining clarity, becoming comfortable with ambivalence, practising silence, and appreciating the contributions of others. To achieve these virtues, individuals, teams, and organizations can use tools such as clarifying roles, building private work time, and implementing an "obligation to dissent." Organizations can also role model directness, foster a culture of constructive conflict, and track employee contributions to appreciate the value of collaboration. By adopting these practices, individuals and teams can improve their collaboration and achieve greater success.

site_title: 'Batterygate' may give Apple a much-needed recharge
summary: Apple has admitted to secretly slowing down older iPhones with aging batteries, sparking widespread outrage and lawsuits. The company's apology marks a significant opportunity for a "recharge" and a reevaluation of long-held assumptions. This episode may prompt Apple to rethink its approach to battery management and customer trust.

site_title: Working together key to growing S'pore's startup ecosystem
