summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem is thriving, with the country consistently ranked as a globally recognized leader in scientific research and intellectual-property protection. The government's support for the venture capital community and education system has contributed to the growth of startups, including those in deep-tech areas such as artificial intelligence. Despite the lack of a large domestic market, Singapore's unique position as a hub for South-east Asia and a member of the global business community makes it an attractive location for international investors. To further advance its deep-tech capabilities, Singapore needs to encourage more people to believe in their ability to build impactful products, and corporations must be more involved in supporting ambitious founders and startups.

site_title: Modest Japanese wage gains point to cautious consumption outlook
summary: Japan's real wages, adjusted for inflation, rose for the first time in 11 months in November, driven by year-end bonuses. However, economists caution that wages are unlikely to keep pace with general price increases, potentially hurting consumer spending and hindering economic growth. The wage data suggests the government faces challenges in generating sustained consumer spending growth, which could impact the economy's growth trajectory.

images.alt_text: The wage data released on Tuesday suggests that the government still faces obstacles in generating a sustained increase in consumer spending needed to support faster economic growth.

site_title: Oprah for US president? Speech fuels talk
summary: Oprah Winfrey's impassioned Golden Globes speech has sparked speculation that she may run for US president, with many fans and liberals calling for her to challenge Donald Trump. Despite her denial of any plans to seek office, some close friends and her partner, Stedman Graham, have hinted that she may consider a run. Winfrey's extraordinary personal story, wealth, and fame could make her a formidable candidate, and some polls show her with a favorable rating higher than Trump's.

images.alt_text: Ms Winfrey posing with the Cecil B DeMille Award at the 75th Golden Globe Awards on Jan 7 in Beverly Hills, California.

site_title: 'Bullish glow' continues in local bourse
summary: The Singapore stock market continued its "bullish glow" on Tuesday, reaching a fresh two-and-a-half year high as it rode on strong upward momentum. The Straits Times Index climbed 12.47 points to 3,524.65, with gains in five out of six trading sessions this year, taking the index's year-to-date gains to 3.6%. Banking stocks led the gains, with DBS and UOB rising 0.2% and 2% respectively. Analysts attribute the rally to favourable global sentiment and upbeat economic developments, with the US expected to see positive surprises in the upcoming earnings season.

site_title: Cryptocurrency player Ripple keen to set off blockchain waves in Singapore
summary: Ripple, the blockchain firm behind the world's second-most valuable cryptocurrency, is seeking to engage with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to develop the use of blockchain technology in cross-border payments. CEO Brad Garlinghouse stated that the company is keen to set off blockchain waves in Singapore, offering its technology to banks to speed up payments from days to seconds. This move comes as Ripple sees South-east Asia as a priority market with pressing remittance demands.

site_title: GIC invests in US multi-family properties through JV
summary: GIC has formed a joint venture with Cortland Partners and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board to acquire and renovate 8,000-10,000 Class B multi-family units in the US. The joint venture aims to raise US$550 million in equity, with GIC and CPPIB owning 45% interest each and Cortland Partners holding 10%. This investment is part of GIC's US property acquisition hunt, targeting a significant presence in the US multi-family market.

site_title: Price isn't everything in mastering South-east Asia's mobile markets
summary: South-east Asia's mobile markets have shifted from price wars to focusing on superior customer experiences. As penetration rates exceed 100%, operators can no longer rely on cutting rates to attract customers. Instead, they're investing in networks for fast and reliable service, particularly for data-intensive activities. A survey found that customers prioritize strong voice connections, fast video downloads, and hassle-free social media access. Leading telcos are developing differentiated strategies, such as network coverage and reliable service, to attract customers willing to pay for high-quality connections.

images.alt_text: Telkomsel of Indonesia has used a differentiation strategy aimed at customers who value a superior experience for more basic activities such as calling and texting.

site_title: North and South Koreas agree to hold military talks and further high-level dialogue
summary: North and South Korea agreed to hold military talks and further high-level dialogue, seeking to resolve issues via negotiations. Pyongyang will send a delegation to the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics in South Korea next month. Despite disagreements over denuclearization, Seoul is prepared to lift some sanctions temporarily for the visit. The talks, the first formal talks in over two years, aim to reduce tension on the Korean peninsula and promote reconciliation through dialogue and negotiation.

site_title: Millions of dollars in oil allegedly stolen from Shell Singapore; 11 men charged
summary: Eleven men were charged in a Singapore court for allegedly stealing millions of dollars in oil from Shell's largest refinery, with six more men still being held for questioning. The investigation, launched in August 2017, resulted in the seizure of millions of dollars in cash and a tanker, and police say the stolen fuel is generally sold across South-east Asia. The case is the second high-profile instance of wrongdoing at a company in Singapore this year, following a $422 million bribery settlement by Keppel Corporation.

site_title: Top 20% of taxpayers paid $9.8b in personal income tax last year
summary: In Singapore, the top 20% of taxpayers collected $9.8 billion in personal income tax in 2017, more than doubling from $4.3 billion in 2007. This is attributed to an increase in the number of taxpayers and higher average tax collections. The figure represents a significant portion of the total $21.4 billion collected in personal income tax that year.

site_title: Creating learning opportunities
summary: Singapore-based edutech company ALLiN Technologies has launched Jnrlink, a cognitive development-based programme to help children build a foundation for learning a second language. The programme, which uses technology and science-based pedagogies, will be taught to over 300 kindergartens in rural China, starting in mid-2018. Research studies have shown that learning a second language at a young age can improve cognitive development, focus, and concentration. The programme aims to provide a lifelong foundation for learning, with a scalable and consistent approach, and is part of the China government's "one village, one school" campaign to alleviate poverty through education.

site_title: Olam chief is new chair of World Business Council for Sustainable Development
summary: Olam International's co-founder and CEO Sunny Verghese has been appointed chair of the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD), a global advocacy organization. He is the first Asia-based CEO to hold the position and the first from the agri-sector. Verghese's two-year term began on January 1, succeeding Unilever's Paul Polman. As chair, Verghese aims to create a sustainable future for all and is also a commissioner of the Business & Sustainable Development Commission, working towards the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals by 2030.

site_title: Laws passed to clarify jurisdiction of Singapore International Commercial Court
summary: Singapore's International Commercial Court (SICC) has clarified its jurisdiction to hear international commercial arbitration cases, increasing its attractiveness as a seat of arbitration. The SICC has heard 17 cases since its establishment in 2015, with parties from Japan, Israel, and India. New laws passed to clarify its jurisdiction will not give the SICC additional powers, but are expected to boost its reputation and efficiency, with most judgments delivered within three months. The move aims to solidify Singapore's position as a leading international arbitration hub.

site_title: China's Sinograin sells from corn stockpiles, gains from recent price rises
summary: China's state grains stockpiler Sinograin sold 26,719 tonnes of corn at an average price of 1,870 yuan (S$383) per tonne, amid concerns of falling supply due to reduced plantings. The sale reflected the "heat in the market" and the good quality of the grain. Chinese corn futures surged 12% in recent weeks, but fell 0.8% on Tuesday. The supply and demand imbalance is expected to result in a deficit of 4.57 million tonnes by the end of the 2017/18 crop year, with the physical market remaining strong.

site_title: Rex International unit awarded US$1.95m as HiRex arbitration ends
summary: Rex International Holding's wholly owned subsidiary, Rex Technology Management, has been awarded US$1.95 million in arbitration against HiRex Petroleum Sdn Bhd, a joint venture company between Rex International and Hibiscus Petroleum Berhad. The award was made by the International Chamber of Commerce Arbitral Tribunal in Geneva. The arbitration began in 2016 after Rex Technology Management sought payment for services rendered to HiRex, and the final award was received in 2017.

site_title: Samsung disappoints as iPhone screens prove no match for rising won
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. missed analyst profit estimates due to a surge in the South Korean won against the US dollar, outweighing display orders from Apple for the new iPhone X. The company's operating income was 15.1 trillion won, falling short of estimates by one trillion won. Samsung is spending more to boost sales, but the won's 7% jump against the US dollar is creating headwinds for the company. The impact of the currency fluctuation is estimated to be around 600 billion won, affecting Samsung's quarterly operating profit.

site_title: How technology will power a modern Singapore construction industry
summary: Singapore's construction industry is undergoing a technological transformation, driven by the government's Industry Transformation Map (ITM) to increase productivity and efficiencies. The sector must adopt and master technologies such as 5D Building Information Modelling (BIM), Mixed Reality with HoloLens, Drones, Photogrammetry, and the Internet of Things. These technologies will enable real-time data analysis, improved design and construction, and better decision-making. The ITM aims to train 80,000 tech-ready construction professionals by 2025, providing a pipeline of talent for smaller contractors. Successful adoption of these technologies will enable Singapore companies to stay ahead of global competition.

images.alt_text: The onset of change in the construction sector is so rapid that inevitably those capable of responding to change and integrating technology will be the winners, while those who do not adapt risk being left behind.

site_title: UK ban on microbeads takes effect to save oceans from plastics
summary: The UK has implemented a ban on microbeads in products such as cosmetics and shampoo, effective immediately, in an effort to protect marine life. Environment Minister Therese Coffey stated that the ban aims to tackle the plastic that devastates marine life. This move follows global efforts to reduce plastic pollution in oceans.

site_title: Allcargo shifts focus from port logistics to e-commerce
summary: Mumbai-based Allcargo Logistics Ltd is restructuring to focus on e-commerce, investing in new warehouses and considering acquisitions of technology-driven logistics players. The company aims to capitalize on India's growing e-commerce market, with an expected 200 million users by 2023. Allcargo plans to offer last-mile delivery services for e-commerce companies like Amazon and Flipkart, and its shares have risen 31% in the past year. The company's move is seen as a response to the growing demand for seamless logistics connectivity in the country.

site_title: Industry transformation maps 'disconnected from needs of businesses'
summary: Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) in Singapore have been criticized for being disconnected from the needs of businesses and SMEs. Panellists at a pre-Budget roundtable pointed to the lack of links between ITMs and other industries, as well as the limited involvement of the private sector. Concerns were raised about the relevance and timeliness of ITMs, which were seen as too focused on larger companies. The government has defended the ITMs as a means to transform the economy, but acknowledged that they are still in an early phase and may need to change course based on feedback.

site_title: Alibaba founder Ma says he will 'seriously consider' HK listing
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma has expressed interest in listing the company in Hong Kong, stating he will "seriously consider" the move. This comes after Hong Kong announced plans to allow dual-class shares, a change expected to be implemented soon. Ma's comments were made in response to a call from Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam, who hopes Alibaba will return to the city to list.

site_title: Nokia launches sleep tracker for beds after Apple's move
summary: Nokia has launched a sleep tracker device called the Nokia Sleep, priced at $99, which will be sold at the CES consumer electronics show in Las Vegas. The device features movement sensors and software algorithms to track sleep duration, interruptions, and snoring. It will also work with smart home appliances to adjust lighting and other settings. This comes after Apple acquired a similar product from Beddit and is seen as a move by Nokia to expand into new hardware categories after exiting the consumer phone business.

site_title: JPMorgan's Dimon regrets calling bitcoin a 'fraud'
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon regrets calling bitcoin a "fraud" in an interview, stating he was wrong but still not interested in the cryptocurrency. His initial comments sparked a 30% rise in bitcoin value, but the asset has since declined. Despite Dimon's criticism, several banks and companies have shown interest in bitcoin, with some embracing it as a legitimate investment opportunity. Dimon has commended blockchain technology, used by bitcoin, as "real." Bitcoin traded at US$14,202 in early trading, down nearly 5% from its previous day.

site_title: Tesco the best Christmas performer among major UK grocers: Nielsen
summary: Tesco reported the strongest overall sales growth among Britain's major UK grocers during the key Christmas quarter, with a 3.4% year-on-year increase in sales, according to Nielsen. This surpassed the growth of 2.1%, 1.7%, and 1.2% at Asda, Morrisons, and Sainsbury's, respectively. Tesco maintained its market share at 27.5%, while Aldi UK and Lidl UK enjoyed sales growth of 12.8% and 15.7% in the quarter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hiap Tong Crane & Transport secured a five-year extension to its lifting services contract with ExxonMobil Asia Pacific, with the contract set to continue until 2023. HC Surgical Specialists reported a 80% jump in revenue for the first fiscal half year, with net profit rising to S$2.92 million. Jason Holdings Limited has been given a final deadline of February 28, 2018, to hold its annual general meeting and submit financial statements.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OCBC Investment Research and UOB KayHian have issued positive reports on OUE Commercial Reit (OUECT) and Cityneon Holdings, respectively. OUECT's income support is set to expire in 2019, but its robust office occupancy and improving market sentiments suggest a strong 2018. Cityneon Holdings has signed a lucrative deal with Fabulous Inc for a digital media signage board in Las Vegas, providing a potential stream of income. Both stocks are undervalued, with OUECT trading at a 12-month blended forward consensus price-to-book ratio of 0.67 times and Cityneon at a 7.7% premium to its major shareholder's price.

site_title: Kuwait Energy in merger talks with Soco Int'l: sources
summary: Kuwait Energy is in talks to merge with Soco International, a London-listed oil and gas company, according to two sources. The potential merger would allow Kuwait Energy to go public after it failed to complete an initial public offer last year. The deal could value Soco International at around $1.2 billion, with Kuwait Energy seeking to raise around $150 million. The merger would provide Kuwait Energy with a means to increase its global presence and expand its operations.

site_title: Outlook for emerging markets still positive but returns may be muted
summary: The outlook for emerging market (EM) equities remains positive in 2018, despite potential headwinds. Key factors supporting growth include global trade, US dollar depreciation, and improved corporate performance. However, China's economic growth is expected to decelerate, with a forecasted 6.4% growth rate in 2018, down from 6.8% in 2017. Other emerging markets, such as Russia, Brazil, and Central European countries, are also expected to experience continued growth. Despite these factors, risks to EM growth include China's rapid debt increase and potential protectionist US trade policy, which could negatively impact market sentiment and trade.

site_title: Iron ore exports from Australia's Port Hedland at all-time high
summary: Iron ore exports from Australia's Port Hedland reached an all-time high of 497 million tonnes in 2017, despite bearish forecasts. The 5% increase from 2016 indicates a growing global supply. Shipments to China set a monthly record, boosting port stockpiles to over 150 million tonnes. Analysts suggest prices may be sustained due to expected demand revival in steel production, but the Australian government predicts prices will drop to below $50 a tonne by 2019.

site_title: Panic as China imposes ban on waste imports
summary: China has imposed a ban on imports of plastic scrap and unsorted paper waste, sparking panic among European and North American authorities. The ban, announced last July, has taken many by surprise, with no clear plan for disposal. The move could disrupt the balance of container transport pricing, potentially affecting low-value goods. Despite concerns, shipping analysts predict continued growth in the industry, with some estimating a potential shortage of containers in the future. The ban may signal an underlying shift towards localizing recycling, which could impact global trade and transportation patterns.

site_title: Vietnam walks thin line between China and US
summary: Vietnam is navigating a delicate balance between its relations with the US and China, adopting a "Goldilocks" approach to maximize benefits without compromising autonomy. This strategy, inspired by the children's story, aims to avoid overly close ties with either power, which could lead to collusion at Vietnam's expense. By maintaining a balanced relationship, Vietnam seeks to derive benefits from both sides while preserving its independence, a strategy that President Lyndon B. Johnson reportedly used during the Vietnam War.

site_title: Saudi said to weigh increasing size of US$10b loan
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering increasing the size of a US$10 billion loan with banks, after lenders offered to lend more. The government is in talks with lenders to increase the loan amount or arrange new facilities. This decision comes after banks expressed interest in lending more to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Hedge fund sees more juice in Greek rally as yields hit 2006 low
summary: A London hedge fund, Algebris Investments, is betting on Greece's economic recovery and potential exit from its bailout program in 2018, driving down borrowing costs. The country's 10-year yield spread narrowed by 44 basis points this month, and the yield on the Greek benchmark bond has sunk to its lowest since 2006. The firm expects the yield spread to tighten to as little as 250 basis points, with Greece's credit profile boosted by a potential German governing coalition. However, liquidity remains a concern in Greece's debt market.

site_title: Possible routes for Sembcorp after strategic review
summary: Sembcorp Industries is set to release the conclusions of its strategic review, which has been ongoing since May last year, and is expected to be a re-rating catalyst for the stock. Analysts suggest three possible options: selling off its marine business, privatizing SembCorp Marine, or divesting or listing other assets. Selling off SembCorp Marine could re-rate Sembcorp's utilities business, but may not be easy to find a buyer. Privatising SembCorp Marine could tap into its balance sheet, but may not extract the best value for shareholders. Divesting or listing other assets could raise S$1.5-2 billion in proceeds, but may not address the group's net gearing issues.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lippo makes S$63.1m joint offer for TIH shares
summary: Hong Kong's Lippo Ltd, through a joint offer with Argyle Street Management, has made a S$63.1 million offer for all shares of Singapore-listed closed-end fund TIH Limited, at a price of S$0.57 per share. The offer is a premium of 12.87% over the last traded price. The joint offerors plan to maintain TIH's listing status and existing activities, with no major changes to its business.

site_title: Opec's cheer over 2018 oil rally tinged by shale worries
summary: Opec's oil price rally has reached its highest since May 2015, with benchmark Brent crude exceeding US$68 a barrel. However, some Opec members are concerned that the surge may prompt US shale companies to increase production, leading to oversupply and potentially weighing on prices. Saudi Arabia, the top Opec producer, wants to see crude above US$60 to boost Aramco's valuation, but US production is expected to rise above 10 million barrels per day, driven by shale output. Market fundamentals remain strong, but economic growth in consuming countries could slow, and higher prices may encourage some producers to pump above their targets.

site_title: Clamping down on cartels and collusive practices
summary: The European Commission has fined several electronics firms for collusive practices, including price fixing and anti-competitive collusion. In 2010, six LCD panel producers were fined 649 million euros for operating a cartel from 2001 to 2006. In 2012, six firms were fined 1.47 billion euros for market manipulation in cathode ray tubes from 1996 to 2006. These cases highlight the ongoing issue of cartels and collusive practices in various industries, including electronics.

site_title: If subsidised, Statoil will eye Norway's offshore wind
summary: Norway's Statoil may participate in the country's first tender for floating offshore wind turbines if there are sufficient long-term subsidies. Statoil's CEO, Eldar Saetre, stated that subsidies are necessary for the project to be profitable. The Norwegian state will not influence Statoil's renewable investment decisions, which will be made by the company's board. This follows Statoil's successful pilot project in Scotland, which generates power at costs exceeding the regular market price.

site_title: HC Surgical Specialists H1 profit jumps on surge in revenue
summary: HC Surgical Specialists reported a significant jump in net profit for the first fiscal half year, with a net profit of S$2.92 million, up from S$19,000 in the same period last year. Revenue increased by 80% to S$7.7 million, driven by contributions from new subsidiaries acquired in the previous financial year. The firm also recorded a S$750,000 gain from an associate. A dividend of 1.1 Singapore cents per share was declared, down from 1.8 cents per share last year.

site_title: Airbus Lifts narrow-body output in China, explores A380 pact
summary: Airbus plans to increase production of the A320 model in China to six planes a month by 2020, aiming to meet global demand. The current rate at the Tianjin plant is four planes a month. Airbus also explores a partnership with China on the A380 superjumbo, with discussions underway but no new orders. The company aims to boost production globally, with a goal of 60 A320s a month by 2020. This move comes as Airbus seeks to capitalize on demand in China, which is the largest economy in Asia.

site_title: US: Stocks add to records, joining global rally
summary: US stocks continued their rally, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index reaching new records for the sixth straight day. The gains were fueled by strengthening global economic data and expectations for higher US corporate earnings, following President Trump's tax cut. However, analysts warn that stocks may falter if big US companies signal the tax cut won't lift earnings as expected. The Dow rose 0.3% to 25,352.59, while the S&P 500 gained 0.2% to 2,752.85, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.1% to 7,162.55.

site_title: Chinese court jails two for life over 15.6b yuan pyramid scheme
summary: A Chinese court has sentenced two individuals, Huang Dingfang and Cai Keyi, to life imprisonment for their roles in a 15.6 billion yuan pyramid scheme that deceived over 200,000 investors. The scheme, which began in 2015, promised annual returns of over 250% and was shut down after authorities ordered the return of over 5.7 billion yuan to more than 170,000 investors. Nineteen others were given sentences ranging from 3 to 12 years, bringing the total losses to more than 15.6 billion yuan.

site_title: SpaceX dealt blow as classified military satellite goes missing
summary: A classified military satellite launched by SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket on Sunday appears to have crashed into the sea following a malfunction during its ascent. The US Strategic Command, which tracks over 23,000 man-made objects in space, is not tracking any new satellites. SpaceX has denied responsibility, citing a nominal performance, but a US official suggests the second-stage booster section failed, resulting in the loss of the satellite and rocket. The incident is a setback for SpaceX, which was on track for a busy year with 30 planned missions.

site_title: The 2 Koreas agree to hold military talks
summary: North and South Korea agreed to hold military talks for the first time in over two years, aiming to resolve issues via dialogue and negotiations. The talks, which took place after a formal dialogue on Tuesday, will focus on reducing tension on the Korean peninsula. North Korea has also decided to send a delegation and cheering squad to the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics in South Korea, despite expressing negative sentiment over denuclearisation discussions. The talks are closely watched by world leaders seeking a reduction in tension amid rising fears over North Korea's missile launches and nuclear development.

site_title: Asia Mobility Industries in joint venture with Baidu to launch US$200m smart mobility fund
summary: Asia Mobility Industries has teamed up with Baidu to launch a $200 million joint venture, Apollo Southeast Asia, focused on autonomous driving and intelligent transportation technologies. The venture aims to commercialize Baidu's autonomous driving platform in the region. The partnership was announced at the Consumer Electronics Show 2018 in Las Vegas, marking a foothold for Baidu in the US market.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% higher
summary: Singapore's stock market closed 0.4% higher, with 3,524.65 points. 1.8 billion shares worth S$1.2 billion were traded, slightly outpacing the 1.9 billion shares from the previous day. Gainers outnumbered losers with 237 counters up and 210 counters down.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.2 points lower on Tuesday, at 1,826.95. The index saw 6.5 billion lots traded, worth RM4.4 billion, with 716 losers outnumbering 387 gainers.

site_title: Eurozone unemployment falls to 9-year low as recovery strengthens
summary: Europe's eurozone unemployment has fallen to its lowest level since January 2009, reaching 8.7% in November. This marks a significant improvement, with the EU's overall unemployment rate also decreasing to 7.3% in November, the lowest since October 2008. Despite this positive jobs picture, the European Central Bank remains concerned about low inflation, which is still below the ECB's target of 2%. The economic recovery is deepening, with the ECB starting to wind down its support measures, but high unemployment remains a challenge in some member states, particularly Greece and Spain.

site_title: Spain to revise 2018 economic forecast to above 2.5%: Econ Minister
summary: Spain is revising its economic forecast for 2018 to above 2.5% due to a potential resolution of the Catalonia crisis, according to Economy Minister Luis de Guindos. The forecast was previously set at 2.3%. The revision is expected to be announced in the upcoming budget.

site_title: PSA Singapore unveils advanced port technologies in new exhibition
summary: PSA Singapore unveiled its advanced port technologies in a new exhibition, showcasing innovations such as amphibious drones, automated quay cranes, and robotic arms. The exhibition, "Intelligent Port of the Future," will run from January 10-14 and features a first-time look at technologies used at container terminals in Singapore. The new Tuas Port, set to handle 65 million containers annually, will incorporate features like automated yard cranes and port equipment to increase productivity and reduce labor costs. The exhibition aims to upskill staff and demonstrate PSA's commitment to advanced technologies and innovation.

site_title: Britons' festive fun undercut by faster food-price inflation
summary: Britain's non-food sales fell 1.4% in the fourth quarter, the most since 2009, as faster food-price inflation reduced consumers' spending power. Online demand outperformed high street sales, which dropped 3.7%. UK inflation accelerated to 3.1% in November, with food prices rising four%, outpacing workers' average earnings growth. Retailers, including Debenhams, reported disappointing year-end sales, and consumer spending growth in December was weaker than in 2016. The UK's economic slowdown is attributed to the pound's decline after Brexit and sluggish wage growth.

site_title: Europe's 'largest casino complex' to open in Cyprus by 2021
summary: A casino complex billed as Europe's largest is set to open in Cyprus by 2021, boosting the economy. The $956.2 million complex, called City of Dreams Mediterranean, will feature 500 hotel rooms, 136 gaming tables, and 1,200 gaming machines. The project is expected to contribute 700 million euros to the country's GDP and attract 300,000 tourists annually. The complex will be operated by Melco International and Cyprus Phassouri Ltd, with a 30-year license to build an integrated casino resort in Limassol.

site_title: Warm smiles on cold frontier
summary: North and South Korean officials exchanged warm greetings at the Demilitarized Zone on January 9, 2018, marking a contrast to previous frosty gatherings. Delegates, including North's Ri Son-Gwon and South's Cho Myoung-Gyon, shook hands, joked, and discussed the North's participation in the Winter Olympics. Ri suggested talks be fully opened to the media, a departure from previous meetings, which were tense and broke down without agreeing on further meetings. The talks aimed to foster inter-Korean dialogue and rapprochement.

site_title: Feeding the fashionistas: Gucci turns to fine dining
summary: Gucci has opened a 50-seat restaurant, Gucci Osteria, in Florence, Italy, where three-Michelin-star chef Massimo Bottura serves high-end dishes. This move by the luxury fashion house is part of a trend of high-end brands expanding into fine dining, with LVMH and Tiffany's & Co also opening restaurants. The investment is seen as a way to enhance global brands and create a unique experience for customers, rather than generating significant financial returns. The restaurant is part of the Gucci Garden complex and offers dishes such as Parmigiano Reggiano tortellini and pork belly buns.

site_title: Peugeot plans 1,300 French job cuts under new law: union
summary: Peugeot plans to eliminate 1,300 French jobs in 2018 through voluntary cuts under a new law introduced by President Emmanuel Macron. This is part of 2,200 planned job cuts, down from 2,670 in 2017. The company is among the first to use the new flexible labor measures.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Resale condo prices rose 0.4% in December, with a 6.2% increase for 2017, according to SRX Property. Oil explorer Rex International received a $1.95 million arbitration award. The government aims to create good jobs, according to Liang Eng Hwa. Credit Suisse strengthened its Asia investment team. Eleven men were charged over fuel misappropriation from Shell Singapore. Singapore shares closed 0.4% higher. Internationally, Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry braced for higher tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Aston Martin is said to seek £5b value in IPO talks
summary: Aston Martin is reportedly seeking a valuation of up to £5 billion in a potential initial public offering, comparable to Ferrari's valuation. The luxury sports car maker plans to expand into the SUV segment in 2019, boosting investor interest. Aston Martin surpassed 5,000 deliveries last year, exceeding its 2017 guidance, and expects to exceed earnings projections. The company has held preliminary talks with advisers and no decision has been made on the possible listing.

site_title: London beats New York among foreign investors in real estate
summary: London has overtaken New York City as the top destination for foreign investors in real estate, according to the 26th annual survey by the Association of Foreign Investors in Real Estate. London jumped from third to first place, while Los Angeles tied with New York for the top US city. The survey found that foreign investors are less concerned about the impact of Brexit, and the US remains the top destination for planned real estate investment, followed by the UK, Germany, Canada, and France.

site_title: World's biggest covered-bond market tests extreme rate territory
summary: Denmark's covered-bond market, the world's largest, continues to test extreme rate territory with interest rates at historic lows. Mortgage-backed bonds offer 1.5% for 30 years, comparable to US government bonds. Foreign demand for Danish bonds remains strong, with Nordea predicting up to $8.58 billion in prepayments in the April refinancing quarter. The extreme demand raises concerns about the pricing of callable mortgage bonds, which may not reflect the true value of the risk premium.

site_title: Continental is said to consider major overhaul, possible breakup
summary: Continental, a German auto-parts supplier, is exploring a major overhaul and possible breakup. The company is in talks with advisers to create a holding company and list shares of its more profitable units, such as the tire business. This reorganization is seen as a response to the industry's shift to electric and self-driving vehicles. Other companies in the industry have also undergone changes in recent years. The review is still in its early stage, with no decision on whether the changes will be carried out.

site_title: Huawei's global ambitions hit by AT&T phone distribution deal's collapse
summary: Huawei's planned deal with US carrier AT&T to sell its smartphones in the US has collapsed due to security concerns. The decision comes after the US Senate and House intelligence committees expressed concerns about Huawei's plans to launch consumer products through a major US telecom carrier. This setback is a significant blow to Huawei's global ambitions, which had been boosted by the potential partnership. The collapse of the deal is the latest in a series of setbacks for the Chinese firm, which has faced intense scrutiny over its ties to the Chinese government.

site_title: Jason Holdings must hold AGM by Feb 28, report FY2015 and FY2016 financial statements
summary: Jason Holdings Limited has been given a final deadline of February 28, 2018, to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) and submit financial statements for the 2015 and 2016 financial years. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) warned that failure to comply will result in enforcement action. The company had initially requested an extension to April 30, 2018, but was denied. Jason Holdings' shares are suspended on the Singapore Exchange due to the company's financial issues.

site_title: Tesco the best Christmas performer among major UK grocers: Nielsen
summary: Tesco saw the strongest overall sales growth among Britain's big four supermarket chains over the key Christmas quarter, with a 3.4% year-on-year increase, according to Nielsen. This surpassed Asda's 2.1%, Morrisons' 1.7%, and Sainsbury's 1.2%. German-owned discounters Aldi UK and Lidl UK enjoyed significant sales growth of 12.8% and 15.7% respectively, while Tesco maintained its market share at 27.5%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for eleventh successive day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for an 11th consecutive day, driven by a global market rally. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.36% to close at 31,011.41, matching a 2012 winning streak. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter gaining 0.32%. The rally follows a record close on Wall Street and amid a decline in US stocks due to tariff threats.

site_title: Olam CEO appointed World Business Council for Sustainable Development chair
summary: Olam International CEO Sunny Verghese has been appointed chair of the World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD), a position effective January 1, 2018, for a two-year term. He is the first Asia-based CEO and the first from the agri-sector to hold the position. Verghese, who also serves as a commissioner of the Business and Sustainable Development Commission, aims to push the business world to achieve the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals by 2030 through collective positive action.

site_title: China's Sinograin sells from corn stockpiles, gaining from recent price rises
summary: China's state grains stockpiler Sinograin sold 26,719 tonnes of corn at an average price of $287.71 per tonne, capitalizing on recent market gains amid concerns of falling supply due to reduced plantings. The sale of mainly first-grade corn from 2014 stockpiles reflects strong demand in the physical market, driven by a corn deficit in the 2017/18 year and increased feed and industrial demand. Prices are expected to remain tight until the Lunar New Year holiday, unless the state increases supplies in large volume.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.4% to 7,727.15 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 0.1% each. The gains were attributed to gains across Asia and were seen as a sign that traders are brushing off US trade threats.

site_title: Hiap Tong unit awarded five-year extension to lifting services contract with ExxonMobil
summary: Hiap Tong Corporation's wholly owned subsidiary, Hiap Tong Crane & Transport, has secured a five-year extension of its lifting services contract with ExxonMobil Asia Pacific, effective since January 1, 2018. The contract, similar to the previous one, will provide crane rental and/or lifting services to ExxonMobil at its Singapore facilities until December 31, 2023.

site_title: Kuwait Energy in merger talks with London-listed SOCO International: sources
summary: Kuwait Energy is in merger talks with London-listed SOCO International, a potential move to help the Kuwaiti firm go public after a failed initial public offer last year. The merger would give Kuwait Energy a portfolio of low-cost assets and allow it to monetize its holdings, while SOCO would gain a portfolio of attractive assets. The deal would be a "merger of equals" with similar size and operations, but different geographic exposures.

site_title: Credit Suisse boosts Asia investment team with two Singapore-based strategists
summary: Credit Suisse has hired two Singapore-based strategists, Eddy Loh and Julian Wee, to bolster its Asia investment team. Loh, a former Bank of Singapore executive, will develop regional investment strategies, while Wee will cover macroeconomic and policy developments impacting Asian markets. Both will report to John Woods, Credit Suisse's investment chief in Asia, to enhance the bank's services for Asia Pacific-based clients.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks turn down as Samsung Electric extends losses; won eases
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index weakened on Tuesday, closing down 3.05 points or 0.12% at 2,510.23. Samsung Electronics extended losses to over 3% after missing profit expectations, contributing to the decline. The won inched down 0.1% to 1,067.1 per US dollar on the onshore platform, while bond yields rose. The dollar remained flat against the won, with a change of 0.01% this year.

site_title: China fines two truck makers for pollution, emissions fraud
summary: China's environment ministry fined two truck makers, Kama Automobile Manufacturing Ltd and Shandong Tangjun Ouling Automobile Co Ltd, a total of 38 million yuan for manufacturing vehicles exceeding pollution standards and engaging in emissions fraud. The fines include confiscated revenues and an additional levy for substandard vehicles, marking the first time automakers have been fined for violating China's air pollution regulations. The move demonstrates the country's "zero tolerance" for firms that break the law, as tackling vehicle pollution remains a key element in China's war on pollution, particularly in its big cities like Beijing.

site_title: Payout power: Singapore loves dividends, Australia most generous
summary: Singapore and the Philippines led the world in dividend payments, with nearly 97% of companies making or pledging payouts in 2017. Australia's benchmark index offered the highest yield among developed countries, with 4.18% dividend yield, followed by Norway and the UK. In contrast, the US saw a lower dividend yield of 1.89% in 2017, and Japan's Nikkei 225 index had only 20% of companies declaring payouts. The US may see an earnings bump due to a new tax law, with predicted annual dividend growth slowing to 7.7%.

site_title: Barefoot Catholics throng icon in huge Philippine procession
summary: A massive procession in Manila, Philippines, drew over half a million devotees to a centuries-old Black Nazarene statue, with many risking injuries to touch the icon with towels, believing it has miraculous powers. The event, part of the nation's largest religious festival, was marred by over 700 injuries, including a suspected cracked spine. Devotees see the procession as a test of faith, with some critics labeling it as pagan worship. The procession coincided with criticism of the Catholic church's stance on the Philippines' drug war, which has resulted in thousands of deaths under President Rodrigo Duterte's rule.

site_title: Seeing 200 million Indians shop online, Allcargo shifts focus
summary: Mumbai-based logistics company Allcargo Logistics Ltd is shifting its focus to e-commerce logistics after seeing 200 million Indians shop online. The company plans to invest in new warehouses and consider acquiring technology-driven logistics players to expand its services. With increasing broadband and mobile penetration, e-commerce is expected to grow, and Allcargo aims to capitalize on this trend. The company's shares have risen 31% in the past year, and it plans to reach $2 billion in revenues by 2020 through acquisitions.

site_title: H&M apologises after using black child in 'monkey' hoodie ad
summary: H&M apologized for using a black child in an ad for a 'coolest monkey in the jungle' hoodie, which sparked widespread criticism and a backlash from artists The Weeknd and LeBron James. The company removed the image and the garment from its product line, citing that it was a mistake. This incident comes amid a challenging time for H&M, with shares slumping 30% last year and analysts slashing their ratings. The company will investigate the incident to prevent similar mistakes.

site_title: Hong Kong housing market is starting to cool, Credit Suisse says
summary: Hong Kong's property market is cooling down, according to Credit Suisse, with projected 3% price growth in 2018, down from 13% in 2017. Rising interest rates and increasing housing inventory are contributing factors. Analyst Susanna Leung advises investors to favor developers with strong sales in recent years, citing CK Asset Holdings and New World Development as top picks. The slowdown in demand and price growth is expected to continue, with developers' financings typically benchmarked to prime rates.

site_title: Tech a new religion at consumer gadget extravaganza
summary: Industry leaders gather in Las Vegas for the 2018 Consumer Electronics Show, touting tech as a solution to global problems such as urban congestion, cancer, and depression. The event highlights the potential of gizmos, artificial intelligence, cloud computing, and fast internet connections to improve lives.

site_title: China's Didi Chuxing to launch bike-sharing platform and brand
summary: China's Didi Chuxing is launching a bike-sharing platform within its app, hosting partner firms like Ofo and its own bike-sharing brand. The platform will also feature deposit-free arrangements. This move comes as the bike-sharing industry faces strains, with several companies folding. Didi has invested in Ofo and has also partnered with Bluegogo, another Chinese bike-sharing firm. The company aims to capitalize on the bike-sharing craze in China.

site_title: 'Batterygate' may give Apple a much-needed recharge
summary: Apple's recent admission to slowing down older iPhones with ageing batteries has led to widespread outrage and a corporate apology. However, this incident may be an opportunity for the company to rethink its long-held assumptions about the upgrade cycle. With customers increasingly seeking to extend the lives of their phones, Apple could capitalize on this demand by offering repair services and spare parts. The company's restrictions on repair and spare parts have been a missed opportunity, as the smartphone aftermarket is a growing market worth billions. By relinquishing control, Apple could tap into this market and improve its relationship with customers in emerging markets.

site_title: Recovery to drive Brazil M&A pipeline in 2018 after 33% jump
summary: Brazil's economy is expected to drive a surge in mergers and acquisitions in 2018, with a 33% increase in M&A activity to $61.77 billion in 2017. Record-low interest rates and a rebounding economy are shifting the focus from scandal-driven asset sales to investor bets on a broad recovery. Conglomerates are expected to sell assets, while financial acquirers such as buyout firms may benefit from record-low interest rates. Key deals include China's Didi Chuxing's acquisition of Brazilian ride-hailing app 99 and Boeing's tie-up talks with Embraer.

site_title: Oil explorer Rex International unit gets US$1.95m arbitration award
summary: Rex International Holding announced a US$1.95 million arbitration award in favor of its subsidiary, Rex Technology Management, against HiRex Petroleum Sdn Bhd. The award, made by the International Chamber of Commerce Arbitral Tribunal in Geneva, Switzerland, includes principal sum, interest, and costs. The tribunal also dismissed HiRex's counterclaim. The arbitration began in November 2016, following a claim by HiRex alleging a breach of fiduciary duties. Rex International has considered the claims as "unfounded" and does not believe it is liable for the allegations.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits 26-year high; Fast Retailing top contributor
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average reached a 26-year high on January 9, closing at 23,849.99, due to gains on Wall Street during a Japanese holiday. Fast Retailing Co. contributed the most, with Uniqlo's same-store sales rising 18.1% in December. The company's shares rose 1.2% and added 20 points to the Nikkei index, the highest closing level since November 1991.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on positive ground; STI at 3,527.46
summary: Singapore shares opened in positive territory on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,527.46, up 0.4% or 15.28 points. The market was evenly matched, with 185 gainers and 179 losers, and 918.5 million shares traded. Notable movers included Blumont, up 25%, and UOB, up 1.87%. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: GM races to build a formula for profitable electric cars
summary: General Motors aims to become profitable in selling electric cars by 2021, a bold claim in a market driven by government policy rather than consumer demand. To achieve this, GM plans to combine proprietary battery technology, a low-cost, flexible vehicle design, and high-volume production mainly in China. The company expects to slash the cost of battery cells by over 30% and reduce the price of battery packs from $10,000-$12,000 to $6,000 by 2021. This would enable GM to offer electric vehicles at competitive prices, potentially increasing demand and revenue.

images.alt_text: General Motors chief executive Mary Barra has made a bold promise to investors that the Detroit carmaker will make money selling electric cars by 2021.

site_title: Macron urges China, EU to avoid pitfalls of protectionism
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron urged China and the EU to avoid protectionism during a three-day state visit, warning of a "lose-lose" situation if trade imbalances are not addressed. Macron proposed opening up France to Chinese investment in exchange for greater access to Chinese markets, aiming to reduce a $47.9 billion trade deficit. Deals are expected in nuclear, aerospace, and agrifood sectors, with French companies such as Areva and BNP Paribas set to sign commercial agreements. Macron hopes to achieve "more than symbolic stuff" and reduce trade restrictions.

site_title: Tencent-backed Douyu plans IPO this year
summary: Douyu, a live game-streaming platform backed by Tencent, plans to raise $300-400 million through an IPO this year, with a potential Hong Kong listing. Founded in 2013, Douyu has seen rapid growth, with revenue surging 708 times over the past three years. The company has received significant investments from technology giants, including a $100m round led by Tencent in 2016. Douyu's IPO could further fuel its growth in the rapidly expanding gaming sector in China.

site_title: Thai foreign minister says fugitive former PM Yingluck in London
summary: Thai Foreign Minister Don Pramudwinai confirmed that fugitive former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra is in London, as verified by Thai police. Yingluck, who fled Thailand in August to avoid a 5-year prison sentence for mismanaging a rice subsidy scheme, has not commented publicly since. Thailand and the UK have an extradition treaty, but the Thai government has not indicated whether they will seek her extradition. Yingluck's whereabouts remain unknown, with Thai authorities in touch with their British counterparts to locate her.

site_title: Venture capital investing in US hits highest since dotcom boom
summary: US venture capital funding reached its highest level since the dotcom era, with $84 billion invested in over 8,000 companies last year. This is comparable to the dotcom era but driven by different dynamics. Later-stage companies with strong consumer traction are commanding large rounds of financing. However, the number of exits fell for the third consecutive year, making it harder for investors to get their money out. Billion-dollar-plus companies raised over $19 billion in capital, and 209 funds were started, raising a total of $32 billion.

site_title: End goal is to create good jobs, says Liang Eng Hwa at Pre-Budget Roundtable
summary: Liang Eng Hwa, chairman of the Government Parliamentary Committee for Finance, Trade & Industry, emphasized the importance of creating good jobs in Singapore's economy. He stated that economic growth is a means to achieve this end, and that businesses must adopt a pro-business approach to create opportunities. The government will support this through initiatives such as SkillsFuture, industry transformation maps, and the establishment of an intellectual property ecosystem. Liang also highlighted the need for businesses to build digital capabilities and internationalize to capture opportunities in the changing job market.

site_title: 11 men charged over misappropriation of fuel from Shell Singapore
summary: Eleven men, including nine Shell employees, have been charged in connection with the misappropriation of fuel from Shell Singapore. The men allegedly conspired to steal 1,260 metric tons of gas oil worth $687,960 and 2,322 metric tons worth $1.3 million. The stolen fuel was transferred to a vessel, and police have seized cash and a tanker. The charges carry serious consequences, including dismissal. The case is ongoing, and further charges are expected.

site_title: Britons' festive fun undercut by faster food-price inflation
summary: Britain's clothing and department store sales declined 4.4% in the fourth quarter, the largest drop since records began, due to faster food-price inflation eating into consumers' non-essential spending. UK inflation accelerated to 3.1% in November, with food prices rising 4% and workers' average earnings growth slowing. Retailers offered deep discounts during the festive period, but consumer spending still grew 4% in December, weaker than the same period in 2016. The UK's inflation surge is attributed to the pound's decline after the Brexit vote and sluggish wage growth.

site_title: Samsung Electronics unveils driverless car parts, infotainment platform
summary: Samsung Electronics unveiled its first driverless car parts, including an automotive camera system and a "digital cockpit" for personalizing cars. The system features machine learning and augmented reality, and is expected to begin shipping this year. The company collaborated with Harman International, which it bought for $8 billion in 2017, to develop the technology. Additionally, Samsung plans to deliver 5G technology for cars and has set up a $300 million fund to invest in automotive start-ups and technology.

site_title: Pole-dancing robots aim to spice up nerd fest
summary: Robots designed by British artist Giles Walker have been introduced to the Sapphire Gentleman's Club in Las Vegas as part of the 2018 Consumer Electronics Show. The robots, which resemble strippers, use recovered windshield wiper motors and scrap materials to move and perform. The robots were brought in to add a new entertainment twist to the crowds attending the tech show, with the goal of appealing to both men and women. The robots received mixed reviews, with some customers praising their uniqueness and others preferring human dancers.

site_title: HK court fines ivory trader US$1,000 for illegal trading as China cracks down
summary: A Hong Kong court fined US$1,022 for illegal ivory possession, a relatively light penalty, after Lau Sai Yuan pleaded guilty to the crime. The fine comes as China cracked down on ivory sales, a move welcomed by wildlife activists as a step towards reducing the slaughter of endangered elephants.

site_title: Modest Japan wage gains point to cautious consumption outlook
summary: Japan's real wages, adjusted for inflation, posted a 0.1% gain in November, the first increase in 11 months, driven by year-end bonuses. However, economists warn that wages may not keep pace with general price increases, potentially hurting consumption. Despite this, some companies are open to raising wages this spring, and labor market reforms could mitigate declines in consumption. The Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target is within reach, but real wage gains are unlikely to support sustained economic growth.

site_title: US apologises to Japan over repeated military accidents
summary: The US has apologized to Japan over a series of military accidents, including the emergency landing of a helicopter in Okinawa, sparking anger over American operations in the country. US Secretary of Defense James Mattis apologized to Japanese counterpart Itsunori Onodera after a string of incidents, including a window falling from a helicopter and a helicopter bursting into flames. The incidents have fueled opposition to US bases in Okinawa, which serve as a launchpad for American military activity in Asia, and have triggered protests and irritants in relations between Japan and the US.

site_title: Nokia launches sleep tracker for beds after Apple buys similar startup
summary: Nokia has launched a sleep tracker device called the Nokia Sleep, priced at $99, which will nestle under bed sheets and track sleep duration, interruptions, and snoring. The device uses movement sensors and software algorithms to provide a "sleep score" and integrate with smart home appliances. This comes after Apple acquired a similar product from Beddit, which is still sold on Apple's website. The device is marketed as more useful than competitors like Withings' Aura, which sold for nearly $300.

site_title: Trishaws keep rolling on Myanmar's clogged streets
summary: Myanmar's Yangon city remains congested despite efforts to improve traffic with bus systems, flyovers, and water taxis. Trishaw makers like Aye Zaw continue to produce traditional pedal-powered three-wheelers, defying the changing times. With over 25,000 licensed drivers, trishaws remain a vital mode of transport, with drivers like Aung Ba praising their safety and flexibility. The iconic vehicles are expected to endure, with Aye Zaw's sons potentially taking over the family business.

site_title: Fund managers say proposals to launch bitcoin ETFs withdrawn due to US SEC concern
summary: US companies have withdrawn proposals to launch bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) due to concerns from the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over the digital asset's liquidity and valuation. Two firms, Rafferty Asset Management and Exchange Traded Concepts, canceled plans to launch three bitcoin funds, citing the SEC's ongoing scrutiny. This move adds a hurdle to Wall Street firms' efforts to capitalize on investor interest in cryptocurrencies, highlighting the regulatory agencies' differing approaches to regulating the asset.

site_title: US spy satellite believed destroyed after failing to reach orbit: officials
summary: A US spy satellite, code-named Zuma, failed to reach orbit after launching on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The satellite broke up or plunged into the sea, with officials assuming it is a total loss. An investigation is underway, but initial findings show no signs of sabotage or interference. SpaceX's Falcon 9 performed nominally, according to the company. The incident marks the first major failure of a SpaceX launch since its first satellite for the US military in May last year.

site_title: Jack Ma's debt giant grinds to halt as China curbs micro-loans
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma's debt giant, Ant Financial, has halted fundraising of asset-backed securities backed by consumer loans due to government curbs on micro lending. The company, controlled by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.'s founder, had issued a record 238 billion yuan (US$37 billion) in such securities last year. Authorities require micro lenders to consolidate ABS into their balance sheets, limiting Ant Financial's ability to lend to consumers. This pause may lead to a slowdown in new consumer loans and a decrease in the online cash micro-lending industry.

site_title: UK ban on microbeads takes effect to save oceans from plastics
summary: The UK has implemented a ban on microbeads in cosmetics and other products, effective immediately, in an effort to protect marine life from plastic pollution. The move follows similar bans in the US, New Zealand, and Canada. Environment Minister Therese Coffey stated that the UK's ban is the strongest and most comprehensive globally, aiming to reduce microplastic waste in oceans. The UK previously introduced a 5p charge on plastic bags in 2015, and plans to explore further initiatives to tackle plastic waste.

images.alt_text: "I am delighted that from today cosmetics manufacturers will no longer be able to add this harmful plastic to their rinse-off products," said Environment Minister Therese Coffey.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on blistering start to year
summary: Asian markets rose for the 11th consecutive trading day, with Hong Kong leading the gains. The global rally, fueled by strong economic readings and hopes for US tax cuts, has made the region's markets their best start to a year since 2006. Investors remain optimistic, despite concerns about US trade tensions, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch's head of Asia Pacific strategy calling the environment "great" for Asian equities.

site_title: Bucking trend, Hyundai bets on hydrogen fuel cell for new car
summary: Hyundai unveiled the Nexo, a hydrogen fuel-cell powered sport utility vehicle, at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. The vehicle uses voice commands, artificial intelligence, and can transform into an autonomous car. Hyundai plans to sell the Nexo in California later this year, betting on hydrogen technology despite rivals shifting to battery power. The company overcame issues such as starting in extreme cold weather and extended the range to nearly 600km, with a partnership with Silicon Valley startup Aurora Innovation to promote self-driving technology.

site_title: Australia dollar lifted by upbeat data, kiwi firm
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.22% to US$0.7857 after strong domestic data showed a 11.7% surge in home building approvals to a 15-month peak, supporting economic growth. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar hit a three-month high. The US dollar fell amid Asian selling, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains to decade-high; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to a decade-high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 6,149.5, driven by firmer financials and solid commodity prices. Mining stocks, such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, led the gain, while banking stocks like Commonwealth Bank of Australia also rose. China's new curbs on steel production boosted iron ore prices, contributing to the market's gains.

site_title: Australia's home building boom gets new burst of energy
summary: Australia's home building approvals surged to 15-month highs in November, driven by increased apartment tower approvals. The ANZ-Roy Morgan confidence index rose 4.7% in the latest survey, marking the highest level since November 2013. This boost is expected to drive economic activity and hiring, following a marked improvement in consumer mood. The strong housing market signals a potential pick-up in spending, offering a hopeful sign for the Australian economy.

site_title: 17 arrested, S$3.05m seized in suspected Shell oil heist
summary: Seventeen men have been arrested and S$3.05 million in cash seized in connection with a suspected oil theft at Shell's Pulau Bukom refinery in Singapore. The arrests were made during raids on Sunday, with some of those arrested being Shell employees. The investigation began after Shell reported the theft in August last year. The stolen fuel is believed to have been sold across South-east Asia, with a small tanker and bank accounts also seized.

site_title: Cryptocurrency may be getting quietly channelled to North Korea university: report
summary: A cybersecurity firm has discovered software that installs Monero cryptocurrency mining code and sends mined coins to a server at Kim Il Sung University in Pyongyang, suggesting North Korea is exploring ways to infuse its economy with cash. The application was created on December 24 and may be part of the country's efforts to find alternative revenue sources due to sanctions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their winning streak, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.11% to 30,933.51 at the open, marking an 11th consecutive day of gains. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight declines. The rally follows positive performances on Wall Street, where stocks hit new records despite US trade tensions.

site_title: Mexican auto exports surge in 2017 despite NAFTA fears
summary: Mexican auto exports surged 12.1% and production increased 8.9% in 2017, despite fears of a NAFTA renegotiation hurting shipments to the US and Canada. Record-high exports to the US grew nearly 10%, while December exports rose 16.7% and production increased 1.5%. The auto industry group AMIA forecasts over 4 million units for 2018, a 6% increase. The success is attributed to cheap labor and free trade pacts, but car sales in Mexico contracted 4.6% in 2017 due to high inflation.

images.alt_text: Mexican auto production and exports hit a record high in 2017, far outpacing growth in 2016, despite fears that shipments could be hurt by a renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with top trading partners the United States and Canada.

site_title: Digital assistants duel for dominance at major electronics show
summary: Key players in the digital assistant market, including Google, Amazon, and Samsung, showcased their virtual assistants at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES). Google Assistant and Alexa are vying for dominance in the smart home market, with Google and Amazon collaborating with various electronics companies to integrate their assistants into devices. Samsung's Bixby assistant is also being enhanced to compete, with new features and integrations announced. Microsoft's Cortana is seen as a weaker contender, while LG and Panasonic are developing their own AI platforms to collaborate with users and other companies. The competition is expected to drive innovation and shape the future of smart homes and devices.

site_title: Euro rally loses steam, US dollar firms slightly vs yen
summary: The euro slipped 0.5% to US$1.1968 on Tuesday, its largest daily drop since late October, after a months-long rally. Analysts say a correction is inevitable due to signs of acceleration in the euro zone economy and potential for profit-taking by speculators. The US dollar firmed against the yen, reaching 113.15 yen, driven by upbeat risk sentiment. Market focus is on North and South Korea's talks later in the day, which may provide signs of reduced tensions on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Intel to form new cybersecurity group amid chip flaw, says report
summary: Intel plans to create a new internal cybersecurity group amid recently disclosed flaws in its microchips. The group, called "Intel Product Assurance and Security," will be led by Leslie Culberstone and includes Vice President Steve Smith. The move comes after researchers reported security issues in Intel's widely used microprocessors, allowing hackers to steal sensitive information. The changes are effective immediately and aim to address customer satisfaction, integrity, and excellence. Intel CEO Brian Krzanich emphasized the importance of uncompromising integrity and highest standards of excellence in the memo.

site_title: 'It can't be true.' Inside the chip industry's meltdown
summary: A former Intel engineer, Thomas Prescher, and a cybersecurity researcher, Anders Fogh, discovered a possible vulnerability in the world's computer chips. Prescher, who was working on a personal project, created code that reinforced Fogh's theory, suggesting a serious flaw in the chips' security. The finding raised concerns about the potential for widespread hacking, prompting Prescher to sound the alarm. The incident has been described as a "meltdown" within the chip industry, highlighting the need for increased security measures to protect critical infrastructure.

site_title: Alibaba founder Jack Ma says to consider Hong Kong listing: SCMP
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, the founder Jack Ma, announced that the company will consider listing in Hong Kong, following the city's decision to allow dual-class share listings. This move comes after Hong Kong's stock exchange operator proposed rule changes that will be put up for public consultation. Alibaba previously held a record US$25 billion public float in New York in 2014 due to Hong Kong's refusal to accept its governance structure. Ma expressed his intention to further invest in Hong Kong and enhance the company's participation in the city's economy.

site_title: London beats New York among foreign investors in real estate
summary: London surpassed New York City as the top destination for foreign investors in real estate, according to the 26th annual survey by the Association of Foreign Investors in Real Estate. London's ranking jumped from third to first place, while Los Angeles tied New York for the top US city. The survey found that foreign investors are less concerned about the impact of Brexit, and the US was the top destination for planned real estate investment, followed by the UK, Germany, Canada, and France.

site_title: Feelin' the love, US junk bond market off to strong start
summary: The US junk bond market is experiencing a strong start to the year, with average spreads narrowing to 336bp over US Treasuries, just 1bp shy of pre-crisis tights. Retailers, such as L Brands and Sunoco, are issuing new debt to refinance existing debt, with spreads tightening across the board. Triple C bond spreads have narrowed 60bp since the start of the year, driven by a rebound in energy bonds. Analysts expect the market to continue its rally, despite predictions of defaults in the retail sector, which will peak at 11% in March.

site_title: LG adds Google AI in 'smart home' push
summary: LG Electronics is integrating Google Assistant into its smart home devices, including televisions, headphones, and smart speakers, marking a significant push into artificial intelligence. The AI platform, called ThinQ, aims to enable devices to adapt to users' individual preferences and collaborate on tasks. LG's vision includes enabling appliances, cars, and other devices to work together seamlessly. The company collaborates with Google and Amazon, and its smart speaker, LG ThinQ, with Google Assistant, is expected to be available in coming months.

site_title: Rare giant lily pads draw impressive crowds to Paraguay lagoon
summary: A rare sight has drawn crowds to a Paraguay lagoon as giant round water lilies, measuring over 1.5 meters in diameter, float on the water. Locals call them "alligator lilies" due to their ability to provide a hiding place for small alligators. These aquatic plants, known as Victoria cruziana, appear every third or fourth southern hemisphere summer. The unusual attraction has become a tourist draw, showcasing the natural beauty of the hidden lagoon in Paraguay.

site_title: Spanish property developer Metrovacesa plans stock market listing
summary: Spanish property developer Metrovacesa plans to list on the stock market, marking renewed investor faith in Spanish real estate. The company, which owns the largest land bank in Spain, has a net asset value of 2.7 billion euros and aims to widen its shareholder base to ease access to capital markets and financing. Metrovacesa plans to sell existing shares owned by Spanish banks Santander and BBVA, which obtained the majority stake in 2009 in exchange for Metrovacesa's massive debt. The IPO is expected to take place in early February.

site_title: TIH gets S$63.1m voluntary unconditional offer from Lippo unit, majority shareholder
summary: Hedge fund Argyle Street Management is making a voluntary unconditional offer to buy all shares of Singapore-listed fund TIH Ltd for S$0.57 per share, a 12.87% premium. The offer, valued at around S$63.12 million, is being made in partnership with Lippo China Resources, which owns a 75% stake. The deal would see TIH continue to operate and maintain its Singapore listing, with no major changes to its business. The offer will remain open for at least 28 days.

site_title: GoPro cuts staff, considers selling company after weak holiday sales
summary: GoPro announced it will cut over 20% of its staff and consider a sale after weak holiday-season sales. The company will reduce its workforce to fewer than 1,000 employees and exit the drone business. GoPro's share price plummeted amid disappointing reports, with the company projecting fourth-quarter sales of $340 million, below analyst expectations. CEO Nicholas Woodman said the company will remain independent but consider a sale if it can scale bigger with a parent company.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, adding 0.97% to the benchmark Nikkei 225 index, following a new 26-year-high last week and fresh records on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. Japanese markets were closed on Monday for a public holiday. The Topix index also rose 0.75%. The gains were driven by encouraging investor sentiment.

site_title: Cheese is the beef as EU-Mexico trade talks resume
summary: The EU and Mexico resumed trade talks, aiming to modernize their 18-year-old agreement, which has been stalled due to issues such as Mexico's dairy industry's right to produce "Manchego cheese." The Europeans want exclusive rights to the name, while the Mexican dairy industry argues its version is ingrained in local culture and doesn't resemble the Spanish original. Talks, the eighth since 2016, will focus on rules of origin, technical barriers to trade, and intellectual property, with no set deadline for a final deal. EU-Mexico trade has nearly tripled to $61.7 billion annually.

site_title: Condo resale prices rise 0.4% in December, 6.2% for all of 2017: SRX Property
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose 0.4% in December, a month-on-month increase, according to SRX Property. For the year, prices increased 6.2% as all locations saw appreciation. Resale volumes also rose 79.7% year-on-year, but fell 38.3% in December due to the year-end holiday. Analysts attribute the rise to en bloc fever, a recovering economy, and government policy changes. Resale prices remain down 2.1% from their peak in January 2014.

site_title: Qualcomm unveils new products and numbers to show it's ok alone
summary: Qualcomm unveiled new products and customer wins, showcasing its expansion beyond mobile technology. The company generated $3 billion in sales outside its main business in 2017 and has secured orders for car parts, including those from Jaguar Land Rover, Honda, and BYD Auto. Qualcomm is directly competing with Broadcom in Wi-Fi chips for home routers and is poised to take share in the market for radio frequency parts in phones. The company also developed chips for voice-controlled speakers and wireless headphones, targeting markets disrupted by mobile technology.

site_title: Airbus to boost China output as nears jet deal during Macron trip
summary: Airbus is set to boost production of narrowbody jets in China as it nears a new multi-billion-dollar deal to supply the world's fastest-growing aviation market during French President Emmanuel Macron's visit. The deal is expected to include orders for around 100 jetliners, with Airbus likely agreeing to assemble more aircraft in Tianjin. Airbus will not announce a breakthrough in support for the A380 superjumbo, whose future is threatened by poor sales.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks gain, won weakens against dollar
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 7.61 points, or 0.30%, to 2,520.89 at 01.18 GMT on Tuesday. The won weakened against the dollar, trading at 1,067.7 per dollar, a 0.16% decline from its previous close. The Kospi is up 1.9% this year and 1.07% in the past 30 days. Foreigners were net buyers of 82,615 million won worth of shares, while bond yields climbed.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 9.12 points to 3,521.3. About 72.8 million shares worth S$84.9 million changed hands, with Blumont rising 0.1 Singapore cent to 0.5 Singapore cent. This marked a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: FCL to raise S$300m from perpetual bond issue
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) plans to raise S$300 million through a perpetual bond issue with a fixed interest rate of 4.38% per annum. The bonds, valued at S$250,000, will be issued on January 17, 2018, with no fixed final redemption date. The net proceeds will be used for corporate funding requirements. The issue falls under FCL's S$5 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, guaranteed by the company, and is being managed by OCBC bank.

site_title: Huawei is said to fail to get AT&T to sell its phones in US
summary: Huawei has failed to secure a deal with AT&T to sell its flagship phones in the US, a setback for the Chinese mobile-phone maker. Despite this, Huawei will still sell its unlocked Mate 10 Pro smartphone in the US. The company had been negotiating with carriers, including AT&T and Verizon, to enter the US market, which is dominated by Apple and Samsung. Huawei will continue to try to forge deals with other carriers, including Verizon, to expand its presence in the US.

site_title: iPhone addiction may be a virtue, not a vice for investors
summary: Apple Inc investors are dismissing concerns about iPhone addiction, viewing it as a potential profit booster. Hedge funds and pension funds have expressed concerns about the impact on children's developing brains, but some investors believe the habit-forming nature of gadgets and social media has contributed to the company's significant market value growth in 2017. The issue highlights the tension between the potential long-term risks of addiction and the short-term benefits of increased profits.

site_title: Keppel O&M graft case: Global resolution achieved more than what S'pore alone could, says Indranee
summary: Senior Minister of State for Law Indranee Rajah stated that a global resolution reached by Keppel O&M over a corruption scandal achieved more than what Singapore alone could have attained. The company has paid US$422 million in fines and will strengthen its internal controls and compliance programs. Singapore does not condone or tolerate corruption, and firms must comply with laws in countries where they operate. The maximum fine under Singapore law is S$100,000 per charge, which is significantly less than the US$422 million penalty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Datapulse, Cheung Woh, Ley Choon
summary: CapitaLand's 20 mall portfolio cut in China may boost shares, with RHB Research upgrading the stock to a "buy" call.
