Datapulse Technology will hold two EGMs by Feb 26 to re-evaluate its diversification strategy after a family move to replace four directors. No other companies mentioned in the article have specific developments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 7.23 points to 1,839.38. The market saw a gain of 320 to 95 gainers to losers, with a total volume of 512.81 million lots worth RM155.45 million.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q4 operating profit likely up 64%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a likely 64% increase in Q4 operating profit to 15.1 trillion won, beating the market's average forecast of 15.9 trillion won. Revenue is estimated to have risen 24% to 66 trillion won. The company did not elaborate on its performance and will disclose detailed earnings in late January.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Samsung Electronics said on Tuesday its fourth-quarter operating profit likely rose 64 per cent from a year earlier, falling short of market expectations.

site_title: Gold dips further from 3-1/2-month peak as dollar fights back
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,318.84 an ounce, retreating from a 3-1/2-month high, as the US dollar strengthened against the euro and traders anticipated further US interest rate hikes. The dollar's rise helped lift US assets, and gold's price sensitivity to rising interest rates increased. Market participants expect the Federal Reserve to hike rates at least twice in 2018, with inflation data due later this week expected to show a 0.2% increase in December.

site_title: World's busiest air routes: Tiny island beats London, New York
summary: The world's busiest air route in 2017 was between Seoul and Jeju Island, South Korea, with 65,000 trips, equivalent to 178 flights a day. This surpassed the Los Angeles to San Francisco route, which had 35,000 trips. Asian cities dominated the list, while North America and Europe were underrepresented. Jeju Island, a popular beach destination, attracted tourists from Japan, China, and South Korea, while other busy routes included Melbourne-Sydney, Mumbai-Delhi, and Rio de Janeiro-Sao Paulo.

site_title: Koreas set for first official talks in two years
summary: North and South Korean officials will hold their first official dialogue in over two years on Tuesday, focusing on the North's participation in the upcoming Winter Olympics in South Korea. The talks will also discuss joint sports entrances, the size and membership of the North Korean delegation, and accommodation. Analysts expect North Korea to send a large delegation, including cheerleaders, to the Games. The meeting aims to ease tensions and pave the way for future talks, including discussions on the resumption of family reunions and a permanent end to military drills.

site_title: UK minister resigns after rejecting PM's reshuffle: govt source
summary: UK Education Minister Justine Greening resigned after refusing a Cabinet position in Prime Minister Theresa May's reshuffle. Greening declined the welfare and pensions brief, citing her decision to leave the government. She will return to the House of Commons backbenches. Greening's departure marks the fourth minister to leave the government since November due to scandals, with Damian Hinds replacing her as employment minister.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit highest since August 2015, Ablynx soars
summary: European shares hit their highest level in over two years, closing 0.3% higher at 398 points, driven by confidence in global economic growth and mergers and acquisitions. Belgian biotech group Ablynx soared 45.3% after rejecting a $4.1 billion bid, while shares in payment processor Wirecard and Italian-American automaker Fiat Chrysler also rose. Optimism for sectoral consolidation and U.S. tax cuts boosted investor appetite, with analysts predicting a positive year for European companies.

site_title: Oprah for president? Speech sparks fevered speculation
summary: Oprah Winfrey's impassioned Golden Globes speech has sparked speculation about her potential presidential run. After a watershed moment on sexual harassment, her speech fueled calls for a self-made, billionaire chat show queen to run for the White House. Hollywood's disdain for Donald Trump and Democrats' surprise at a reality star's potential presidency have fueled talk of Oprah as a viable candidate. With no previous government experience, speculation centers on her qualifications and "right" politics.

site_title: Paris prosecutors probe Apple over 'planned obsolescence' in iPhones
summary: Paris prosecutors have launched a probe into Apple over suspected "planned obsolescence" in some of its iPhone models, following a complaint by the association Stop Planned Obsolescence. Apple had admitted to intentionally slowing down older iPhones to extend performance and prevent shutdowns. The probe is being led by anti-trust and consumer protection specialists in the French economy ministry, which could result in fines up to 5% of Apple's annual sales. This case follows similar investigations into Japanese printer maker Epson.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records for fifth day; Dow ends lower
summary: US stocks reached new records for the fifth consecutive session, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index ending at 2,747.71 and 7,157.39, respectively. However, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.1% to 25,283.00, its first drop of 2018. Investors are awaiting corporate earnings reports, which may impact equity valuations, amid concerns about the impact of tax reform on company profits.

site_title: Sanofi to market new haemophilia drug in deal with Alnylam
summary: Sanofi has obtained global development and commercialization rights to fitusiran, a new haemophilia drug, in a deal with Alnylam Pharmaceuticals. Sanofi Genzyme will market the drug, while Alnylam will receive royalties. This agreement complements Sanofi Genzyme's rare haematology portfolio and brings an innovative treatment for people with hemophilia. In return, Alnylam will receive global development and commercialization rights to a new treatment of ATTR amyloidosis.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tee International and its subsidiary TEE Land have issued profit guidance, warning of a loss for the second quarter and half-year due to impairment losses on a Thai associate and unsold units. Straits Trading's CFO Yeo Sock Koon has resigned. Ley Choon Group Holdings has won a S$10.4 million contract with PUB for network renewal. Mary Chia Holdings has applied for an extension to raise its public float to at least 10% to keep its listing status.

site_title: US oilfield service firms dust off IPO plans as crude prices surge
summary: US oilfield service companies, including Liberty Oilfield Services, are gearing up for initial public offerings (IPOs) as crude prices surge above $60 a barrel. The companies, which provide hydraulic fracturing services, have shelved IPOs last year during a weak period for oil prices. Several firms, including BJ Services, FTS International, and Nine Energy Service, have updated their filings, signaling they may try again. Analysts predict a quick ramp-up in IPOs as market conditions improve, with as many as five oilfield service companies potentially going public in the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: May keeps Davis, Rudd, and Hammond in her Cabinet
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May began her 2018 Cabinet reshuffle, maintaining stability at the top of her negotiating team as Brexit talks enter their most pressurized period. Senior officials, including David Davis, Amber Rudd, and Philip Hammond, kept their jobs, while Boris Johnson retained his position as foreign secretary despite causing trouble on Brexit policy. The reshuffle also saw new appointments, including David Lidington as Cabinet Office minister and Brandon Lewis as chairman of the Conservative Party. May starts 2018 in a stronger position than she has enjoyed since her poor 2017 general election performance, but must balance eurosceptics and EU advocates.

images.alt_text: With more announcements to come, Mrs May (sixth from left) took the unusual step of posing for a photo mid-reshuffle with an array of junior members of the Tory party chairman's team, probably to highlight the mix of genders and ethnic backgrounds they represent.

site_title: Things are going well but potential flash points can still roil markets
summary: Stock markets have started 2018 on a positive note, with the US dollar weak and oil prices up, amid a stable job market and low unemployment. Central banks remain a monetary backstop, and inflation has not spiked, preventing interest rate hikes. However, potential flash points include rising interest rates, inflation, and China's growing debt, as well as US politics and the upcoming mid-term elections. Despite the calm atmosphere, investors remain cautious, as bull markets often end when investors pile in for fear of missing out.

site_title: Oil mostly flat as rising US output offsets Opec worries
summary: Oil prices remained stable on Monday, trading near their highest since May 2015, as rising US production offset concerns over Opec nations. Brent futures rose 16 cents to $67.78 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose 29 cents to $61.73. US production is expected to rise above 10 million barrels per day, driven by shale drillers, but Opec will only boost output if there are significant production disruptions. The Opec versus shale debate is expected to be a key price-driving factor this year.

site_title: Fortune of China's richest woman up US$2b in 4 days
summary: Yang Huiyan, China's richest woman and controlling shareholder of Country Garden Holdings, saw her fortune increase by US$2.1 billion in the first four trading days of 2018, rising to US$25.6 billion and ranking as the fifth-richest person in China. This surge follows a 6.9% increase in Country Garden's shares, taking its year-to-date gain to 16%. Yang inherited her father's controlling stake in the company in 2005, and her father co-founded Country Garden in 1992.

site_title: Trump and Bannon are like two overweight men trying to share a sleeping bag
summary: US President Donald Trump and his former chief strategist Steve Bannon are at odds over their differing views on the presidency and the campaign's strategy. The controversy surrounding the book "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House" has highlighted their disagreement, particularly over Bannon's comments on Trump's family and his role in the campaign. Trump has fired back, threatening to sue Bannon, while Bannon has defended his actions. Amidst the drama, Trump's administration has been using government agencies to pursue his personal grudges, raising concerns about the erosion of democratic principles.

site_title: Australia warns of volatile iron ore prices as China curbs ease
summary: Australia's Department of Industry, Innovation and Science warns of volatile iron ore prices in 2018 due to China's efforts to manage steel production. Prices may be higher in the first half as China relaxes curbs, but are expected to drop in the second half due to growing global supply and weaker steel output in China. Iron ore prices averaged US$71.36 in 2017, with prices expected to average US$52.60 in 2018. Australian exports are forecast to increase, while China's imports remain flat.

site_title: China airlines shares up on fare liberalisation
summary: China's Civil Aviation Administration and National Development and Reform Commission have given airlines more freedom to set fares for domestic flights, easing state control over prices. China removed caps on full fares and allowed airlines to set prices for routes with at least five carriers, with increments of 10% or less. This move, part of China's gradual liberalization, has boosted airline earnings and shares of state-owned carriers such as China Southern Airlines and Air China, which jumped 11% and 10% respectively. The new rule extends market-based pricing to over 306 routes, up from 31 in 2013.

site_title: MOU opens doors in India for S'pore tech startups
summary: Singapore tech startups can now collaborate with Indian companies through a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed between IE Singapore and the Confederation of Indian Industry. The agreement aims to facilitate business partnerships and knowledge exchange in the tech sector, allowing Singaporean startups to pilot innovations in India and acquire best practices from Indian companies. This partnership is expected to promote economic growth and innovation between the two countries.

site_title: South Korea sees speedy trade talks with US, but 'uphill battle' ahead
summary: South Korea expects a speedy trade talk with the US, but faces an "uphill battle" due to disagreements over the bilateral trade deal. US President Donald Trump is unhappy with the existing pact, which has doubled the US goods trade deficit with South Korea since 2012. The US wants to maintain a 25% tariff on Korean pick-up trucks and negotiate on vehicle safety and emissions rules, while South Korea is pushing for a partial revision of the deal to address its concerns over US import restrictions. The talks are set to continue despite potential risks to the alliance with North Korea.

site_title: India's economy faces an ominous new year in 2018
summary: India's economy appears to have recovered from recent disruptions, with exports rising 30% and growth speeding up in the last quarter. However, macroeconomic numbers are not as stable as they should be, with inflation returning to 4.9% and crude oil prices increasing. This may put pressure on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to increase spending, which could lead to fiscal deficits and inflation. The government's fiscal deficit target is 3% of GDP, and increasing transfers to farmers could make this task nearly impossible. Policymakers are worried that 2018 may not be a happy new year for India's economy.

site_title: Chinese property stocks turn red-hot on sales optimism
summary: Chinese property stocks have surged, with real estate firms accounting for eight of the 10 best performers on MSCI's offshore Chinese shares in January. Shimao Property Holdings Ltd and China Vanke Co have led the charge in Hong Kong and Shanghai, respectively, with 28% and 22% gains. This optimism is driven by sales expectations, with developers rallying the most among industry groups on the Shanghai benchmark. The rally marks a clear winner for Chinese equities this year, with real estate emerging as the standout performer.

site_title: Cheung Woh posts Q3 loss amid higher cost of sales
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies, a Singapore-based hard disk drive manufacturer, reported a net loss of S$449,000 for the third quarter of 2018, down from a profit of S$264,000 in Q3FY17. The company's gross profit margins came under pressure, despite a 5.8% year-on-year increase in turnover to S$21.55 million, driven by higher sales in the HDD components segment.

site_title: Euro stumbles after recent rally; outlook bullish
summary: The euro slipped 0.3% to $1.19890 after a recent rally, as investors took profits amid uncertainty over the European Central Bank's policy stance. Despite this, currency markets remain bullish on the euro's outlook due to a strengthening economic recovery in Europe and a global growth trend. Inflation estimates for December were 1.4%, below the ECB target, and the US nonfarm payrolls increased by 148,000 jobs last month, supporting the euro's value.

site_title: Analysts stick to 'buy' on CapitaLand
summary: Analysts have maintained a "buy" rating on CapitaLand following the company's sale of 20 Chinese malls, citing it as a "positive catalyst" for investing in higher-yield properties. RHB Research, DBS Group Research, CIMB, and OCBC Investment Research all upgraded or reiterated their "buy" positions, with target prices ranging from S$3.90 to S$4.35. Analysts believe the move will allow CapitaLand to focus on its core competencies and invest in higher-yield properties, driving robust results and growth.

site_title: Baltimore leads the pack again in 2018 as US bedbug capital
summary: Baltimore tops the list of US cities with the most bedbug infestations, for the second consecutive year, according to a report by Orkin LLC. A total of 50 US cities, including Cincinnati, Detroit, Las Vegas, and Denver, were ranked on the list. The infestation rates are out of control, with no specific solutions mentioned.

site_title: At the receiving end of a robotic world
summary: A growing trend towards automation is being felt in everyday life, with many services and transactions becoming less human-centered. In Hong Kong, banks only offer gift cheques in specific denominations, and some universities require physical bank statements for overseas funding. In Sweden, some hotels have no staff in the evenings, relying on automated systems. Meanwhile, cash is increasingly being phased out in many places. As machines become more prevalent, concerns arise about the impact on social interaction and customer service.

site_title: SPH launches new Mandopop radio station 96.3 Hao FM
summary: SPH launches 96.3 Hao FM, a new Mandopop radio station playing classic hits from the 1980s and 1990s, featuring lifestyle, healthcare, and finance programs. The station debuted on January 8, 2018.

site_title: UK house prices slip 0.6% in December, first fall in six months
summary: UK house prices fell 0.6% in December, marking their first decline in six months, according to Halifax. This decline is attributed to the 2016 Brexit vote and the subsequent interest rate hike, weighing on the country's housing sector. Economists had expected a 0.2% rise in house prices. On an annual basis, house price growth slowed to 2.7%, weaker than a 3.9% rise in November.

site_title: China's new aviation routes in Taiwan Strait irresponsible: Taipei
summary: Taipei has criticized China's unilateral expansion of civil aviation routes in the Taiwan Strait, calling it an irresponsible act that threatens regional security. China opened several disputed air routes, including a northbound M503 route, without informing Taiwan, contravening a 2015 deal to first discuss such flight paths. This move is seen as a threat to regional stability and undermines Taiwan's sovereignty. The incident has sparked tensions between Beijing and Taipei, with China's actions deemed irresponsible by the Taiwanese government.

site_title: Inter-Korean talks: Is a corner being turned?
summary: High-level talks between North and South Korea have been underway, offering a potential for diplomacy to reduce tensions amid North Korea's nuclear development. The US has supported the talks, which aim to enable North Korea's participation in the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. China is pleased with the development, as it aligns with its call for a suspension of US-South Korea military exercises in return for a suspension of North Korean tests. The talks will focus on the Olympics, but both sides intend to extend them into political realms, with potential for wider multilateral talks on North Korea's nuclear weapons.

site_title: Forget Milan. Florence razes the runways in Italian fashion
summary: Florence, Italy is set to host the 93rd Pitti Uomo trade fair, showcasing the city's rich history as a fashion capital. The event, which kicks off on Tuesday, will feature over 1,200 brands, including Gucci and Ferragamo, and is expected to draw 36,000 attendees. Florence's connection to fashion dates back to the 12th century, when powerful craft guilds dominated the city's economy and cultural landscape, laying the groundwork for the city's reputation as a hub for high-quality fashion.

site_title: Yuan erases gains as central bank adviser eyes rate of 6.6 against US dollar
summary: China's yuan rose to 6.4832 against the US dollar at the start of the week, but erased gains in the afternoon as a central bank adviser suggested the currency may stabilize at around 6.6 in the long-term. The yuan had strengthened due to US dollar weakness and rising interest rates in China's financial markets, but these factors are expected to recede. China's foreign exchange reserves rose for 11 months in a row to their highest level in over a year, and analysts predict further policy changes to encourage capital inflow.

site_title: Virtual aide market a 'wildfire' at CES gadget show
summary: Virtual assistants are expected to be a "wildfire" trend in the consumer electronics industry this year, with sales of smart speakers nearly doubling in the US to $3.8 billion. Industry researchers predict that compatibility with digital assistants will become table stakes, leading to increased pressure for more voice interaction with machines. Artificial intelligence will also improve, enabling machines to think like people and hold conversations. 5G networks will be key to enabling self-driving cars to process sensor data quickly, and spending on consumer electronics is expected to climb 3% to $351 billion.

site_title: Containing Iran without boots on the ground
summary: US President Donald Trump's increasing support for anti-government protesters in Iran via tweets is raising concerns of another Middle Eastern war involving Iran, Saudi Arabia, and Israel. This stance is reminiscent of the historical analogy of the "Vietnam Syndrome," which warned of disastrous military interventions abroad. However, Trump's approach differs from his predecessors, as he aims to apply diplomatic and economic pressure on Iran without using military force. This strategy may be effective in containing Iran's influence in the region, potentially giving birth to a new "Iran historical analogy."

site_title: Confidence in eurozone economy highest in 17 years
summary: The European Commission's sentiment index reached its highest level in 17 years in December, with a reading of 116, driven by improved industry and services outlooks. The eurozone economy is expected to continue its momentum in 2018, with growth possibly the fastest since before the financial crisis. Despite low unemployment and record economic activity, inflation remains slow, partly due to stagnant wages. The European Central Bank's bond buying program is set to continue until September, with some policymakers pushing for an extension or increase.

images.alt_text: The ECB's bond buying is set to continue until September. The monthly pace was halved to 30b euros from January, but officials have retained an option to prolong or increase the programme if needed.

site_title: UBS in talks to buy majority stake in China securities JV: CEO
summary: UBS is in talks to acquire a majority stake in its Chinese securities joint venture, with CEO Sergio Ermotti stating the bank is ahead of its plan to double headcount in China. The discussions, which could be concluded in months, come as global banks seek to capitalize on China's pledge to further open its financial markets. UBS aims to hold 1,200 staff in China by the end of the year, with a majority stake not significantly impacting its control over the venture.

site_title: Accreditation scheme extended to maritime and shipping lawyers
summary: Singapore's Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon announced the extension of the Specialist Accreditation Scheme to maritime and shipping lawyers, recognizing professional excellence in the industry. The scheme, which was initially introduced to building and construction lawyers, has seen 24 lawyers gain accreditation since its introduction. The accreditation requires at least five years of experience and tests/interviews to assess knowledge and skills. The move aims to raise standards and provide a guide for the public seeking specialist lawyers.

site_title: Sale of US gas & power unit nets final amount of US$168m: Noble
summary: Noble Group has sold its US gas and power unit, Noble Americas Gas & Power Corp (NAGP), to Mercuria Energy America Inc for approximately US$168 million, higher than the initial US$102 million announced in October. The disposal is part of Noble's efforts to reduce its debts, which stood at US$3.5 billion as of September 30, 2017. The company reported a net loss of US$1.2 billion for the three months to September 30, largely due to write-downs related to business sales.

site_title: North-South rapprochement still a tenuous one
summary: US President Donald Trump's resumption of high-level bilateral talks with North Korea is a surprise mini-rapprochement, following a year of spiralling tensions over nuclear and missile programmes. The talks come after Pyongyang's offer to send athletes to the Winter Olympics hosted by South Korea and the re-opening of a diplomatic hotline. However, the warming is fragile and faces challenges from continuing tensions between Pyongyang and Washington, raising questions about its significance and sustainability. Trump's allies are cautious about destabilizing the hermit state, making a sustained rapprochement uncertain.

images.alt_text: A Seoul official checks the direct communications hotline with Pyongyang at the border village of Panmunjom, South Korea.

site_title: Singapore needs to go beyond tax perks and develop new trump cards, says Heng
summary: Singapore Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat stated that the country needs to develop new competitive advantages beyond tax incentives, as global tax rates continue to decrease. The US tax reform package, which lowers corporate and personal tax rates, may make Singapore's tax competitiveness comparable to other countries. Heng emphasized the importance of maintaining a pro-business environment, connectivity to global markets, and developing industries and people to stay relevant and attractive to investors.

site_title: Mix it up, robot bartender
summary: Souschef, a startup company founded by 24-year-old Tushar Mohan, has developed an automated drink dispensing system that can mix cocktails and other beverages. The system, which can produce a fresh cup every six to seven seconds, is leased to businesses in the hospitality industry and available for event rentals. Souschef has raised S$85,000 in venture capital and is targeting corporate pantries and events, as consumers are more conservative about new ideas in the food and drink industry. The company plans to expand into providing beverage brands with marketing and consumer data, and has partnered with Singapore Airlines for a one-month pilot in its lounges.

images.alt_text: SUTD graduate Tushar Mohan photographed with Souschef, an automated drinks dispensing system that changes the way food and beverage outlets/events dispense their drinks.

site_title: Thailand's Central Group expects online surge through pact with JD
summary: Thailand's Central Group, the country's largest retail company, is partnering with JD.com to boost its online sales. The partnership aims to increase online sales to 15% of revenue in five years, up from 2% currently. Central Group expects annual revenue growth of 13% in 2018 based on its five-year strategy plan.

site_title: Asia-Pac healthcare M&A expected to jump 80% to US$55b in 2018
summary: Asia-Pacific healthcare mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are expected to surge 80% to US$55.1 billion in 2018, driven by pharmaceutical companies investing in manufacturing sites in more affordable markets. Global healthcare M&A is also expected to rise 50% to US$418 billion, fueled by buoyant market conditions and the US corporate tax rate decrease. North America is projected to contribute US$250.2 billion, while Europe will be the second largest contributor, with Africa & the Middle East and Latin America rounding out the top five.

site_title: Medical law and ethics lawyer Kuah Boon Theng appointed senior counsel
summary: Singaporean medical law and ethics lawyer Kuah Boon Theng, 50, has been appointed senior counsel, a prestigious honor given to outstanding lawyers. Kuah, who has practiced law for nearly 30 years, was admitted as an advocate and solicitor in 1991 and obtained a Master's degree in medical ethics and law from King's College University of London in 1993. This marks the 64th appointment of senior counsel in Singapore, a title equivalent to Britain's Queen's Counsel.

site_title: Tech faithful assembling at temple of innovation
summary: The 2018 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas showcased technology as a solution to various societal issues, including urban congestion, cancer, and depression. Exhibitors demonstrated advancements in artificial intelligence, robotics, and cloud computing, with companies like Nvidia and Byton highlighting potential applications in self-driving cars and traffic optimization. However, analyst Bob O'Donnell noted the darker side of tech, citing concerns over cybersecurity and data leaks. Despite these concerns, many believe technology will continue to improve communication, health, and productivity, and will play a key role in shaping the future of cities and industries.

site_title: Fee benchmark part of plan to keep healthcare costs affordable: MOH
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) is introducing a fee benchmark to keep healthcare costs affordable and sustainable. The benchmark will serve as a reference for the public to know if their doctor is charging a reasonable fee, and the Singapore Medical Council can identify and take action against doctors who overcharge. The MOH believes the benchmark will encourage appropriate charging practices, and recent government measures have helped reduce healthcare inflation to 1.2% between 2013 and 2016. The benchmark will be set by the MOH with advice from an independent committee.

site_title: Danish drugmaker Novo goes public with 2.6b euro bid for Belgium's Ablynx
summary: Danish drugmaker Novo Nordisk has made a 2.6 billion euro bid for Belgium's Ablynx NV, its largest takeover offer ever. The move aims to expand Novo's blood-disorder unit and gain medicines targeting rare diseases. One Ablynx treatment, caplacizumab, is set for approval this year for a disorder causing blood clots in small vessels. The deal signals Novo's higher appetite for deals beyond diabetes medicines, following the company's new CEO's expansion strategy.

site_title: Partners Group buys 45% stake in wind project
summary: German investor Partners Group Holding AG has taken a 45% stake in a 700 megawatt offshore wind project in the Netherlands, purchasing shares from Shell, Mitsubishi, and Eneco. The terms of the partnership were not disclosed. This move is part of the "Blauwwind II" consortium, a 700 MW offshore wind project in the Netherlands.

site_title: MAS looking to cap insurers' migration package offers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is proposing guidelines to regulate insurance agent migration, aiming to safeguard consumers' interests. The regulator is exploring capping migration package sizes, requiring call back services, and clawing back agents' commissions for improper conduct. MAS is also considering "appropriate funding" of migration packages, which could potentially be borne by customers in the long run. The guidelines aim to address the risks of improper switching following mass agent migration, following a surge in poaching activity in the industry.

site_title: Former top Visa exec starts work at Grab to steer e-payments push
summary: Former Visa executive Ooi Huey Tyng has joined Grab as managing director for GrabPay in Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, underscoring the company's ambitions in e-payments. The move comes as Grab plans to roll out consumer payments for Malaysian users in the first six months and expand its peer-to-peer fund transfer service in the Philippines. Tyng brings leadership expertise from the region's premier banks and payments providers, and her experience will be invaluable as GrabPay moves into its next phase of growth.

site_title: Task force formed to improve SkillsFuture fraud detection
summary: A task force has been formed in Singapore to improve the fraud detection system for SkillsFuture claims, following a nearly $40 million loss to the government agency. The task force, involving SSG, the Ministry of Education, and other agencies, aims to implement a "good and effective data analytics system" by the third quarter of this year. The move comes after a scam involving a criminal syndicate that submitted fraudulent claims, and the government will also review the claims process for SkillsFuture Credit to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: Imperium Crown responds to SIAS queries over governance practices
summary: Imperium Crown, a Catalist-listed real estate developer, has responded to queries from the Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) over governance practices. SIAS questioned the company's corporate governance report, citing a S$48,000 payout to former CEO John Lyn Hian Woon. Imperium Crown stated that the payout was in recognition of Mr. Lyn's efforts in stabilizing the company after a turbulent period. The company also clarified its rating of Wonder Stone Park, a tourist attraction in China, which lost its "AAAA" rating due to inadequate facilities, but aims to regain it.

site_title: Cryptocurrency may be getting quietly channelled to N.Korea university - report
summary: A cybersecurity firm, AlienVault, has discovered software that appears to install code for mining cryptocurrency Monero and sends mined coins to a server at Kim Il Sung University in Pyongyang, North Korea. The application, created on December 24, uses host computers to mine Monero and sends coins to the university, which may be a sign of North Korea's interest in cryptocurrencies to infuse its economy with cash. This is the latest indication of North Korea's interest in cryptocurrencies, with experts citing the country's desire to earn foreign currency due to economic sanctions.

site_title: Feel-good sentiment boosts market
summary: The Singapore stock market rose 0.7% to 3,512.18, led by banking stalwarts such as DBS and UOB, with the Straits Times Index (STI) nearing its 2015 high. Positive news on global economic resilience, robust job market conditions, and buoyant energy prices contributed to the gains. Analysts expect the upward momentum to continue into the fourth-quarter reporting season, with Credit Suisse favoring banks, developers, and cyclical stocks.

site_title: German metal workers striking for 6% pay raise
summary: Germany's powerful metalworkers union, IG Metall, is calling for mass strikes over pay and working hours demands. The union seeks a 6% pay raise and the right to temporarily switch to a 28-hour week to care for family, which employers claim would be illegal and could lead to bare factory floors. The strikes, expected to involve up to 700,000 workers, could impact key industries and the national labor market if negotiations fail by late January.

site_title: China's Lanzhou relaxes property tightening curbs
summary: China's Lanzhou city has eased property curbs, lifting restrictions in suburban areas and relaxing rules on home purchases in downtown districts. This move, aimed at addressing high inventories, may be followed by other second-tier cities. Analysts believe Lanzhou's easing signals a market shift, allowing for some overly-strict measures to be adjusted. The decision comes amid China's nationwide clampdown on housing speculation, which has fueled concerns of price bubbles in the real estate sector.

site_title: A digital meltdown looms - be afraid, very afraid
summary: A new class of security vulnerabilities, affecting nearly all major microprocessor chips, has been announced, threatening personal computer and cloud computing security. The flaws, which have been present for decades, can enable hackers to steal information from personal computers and cloud services. While temporary fixes may be available, they may come at a performance cost, and the problem is built into the hardware, making long-term solutions expensive. Experts warn that modern computing security is like a flimsy house that needs to be fundamentally rebuilt, and that the industry's lack of accountability for security failures is a major concern.

site_title: Awards and a reckoning at Golden Globes
summary: The 75th Golden Globes ceremony took place on January 8, 2018, as a show of solidarity against men accused of misconduct, including Harvey Weinstein. Oprah Winfrey delivered an emotional speech, invoking the #MeToo movement and expressing hope for a new day when women no longer have to say #MeToo. The ceremony saw a mix of reactions, with some winners addressing the issue and others not. Sterling K. Brown made history as the first black man to win best dramatic actor, while Lady Bird won best picture, musical or comedy. The event was marked by a "night draped in black" with actresses and some actors using their attire to make a statement about sexual harassment in Hollywood.

site_title: Singapore dollar surges to 2015 levels
summary: The Singapore dollar has surged to 2015 levels, trading at 1.3256, as global investors pour into local assets amid improving risk appetite and the greenback's weakness. The SGD's value has remained steady since last Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching a 2.5-year high of 3,512.18. Experts predict the SGD will continue to appreciate, with some forecasting it to hit 1.30 by end-2018, driven by a synchronous global recovery and supportive risk appetite.

site_title: Online shoe retailer Spartoo set to buy Vivarte's Andre
summary: French online shoe retailer Spartoo plans to acquire rival shoe brand Andre from debt-laden clothing retailer Vivarte, nearly doubling its annual sales to 300 million euros. Spartoo, which generates 150 million euros annually, competes with Zalando in Europe. The acquisition is part of Vivarte's restructuring efforts, following the sale of several brands last year. The sale is expected to be announced on Tuesday.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand's divestment of non-core retail assets in China and India reduces its portfolio focus and lowers retail exposure risk. The company has signed seven management contracts, which are expected to generate recurring income. Analysts upgrade CapitaLand's target price to S$4.20, citing long-term growth potential. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust acquires Shatin No 3 in Hong Kong for HK$610.0 million, gaining full control of the property and potentially optimizing returns for unitholders.

site_title: Best practices for Singapore software firms eyeing a global market
summary: Singapore's software firms can compete globally by following best practices in software development, such as planning, designing, implementing, verifying, and releasing high-quality software. Key steps include creating a strong plan, designing with user experience and security in mind, implementing secure coding guidelines, verifying for bugs and vulnerabilities, and releasing with a "red team assessment" to identify potential weaknesses. By adopting these practices, Singaporean software companies can rise above the competition and potentially become billion-dollar giants.

site_title: HK home prices more than double 1997 levels
summary: Hong Kong home prices have more than doubled from 1997 levels, with affordability deteriorating. Financial Secretary Paul Chan warned that mortgage payments now account for 68% of median household income. Despite this, the Hang Seng Property Index has risen 6.5% this year and 40% over the past year, outperforming the broader index. Experts caution that rising interest rates may put pressure on the residential property market, with the affordability ratio potentially spiking to 88% if interest rates rise by three percentage points.

site_title: New Berlin airport needs extra 1b euros before opening: report
summary: Germany's new Berlin airport is facing another delay due to a lack of funding, requiring up to €1 billion (S$1.6 billion) in extra funds before its planned October 2020 opening. The airport's management has informed the supervisory board of the shortfall, which would be another setback for the project. The airport's original budget was expected to be sufficient, but the additional costs have been revealed. The delay is a significant concern for the German government and the airport's operators, who are already facing criticism for the project's prolonged timeline.

site_title: Why 2017 was the best year in human history
summary: A 2017 article claims that 2017 was the best year in human history due to significant improvements in global health, poverty, and literacy rates. A smaller percentage of people were hungry, impoverished, or illiterate than ever before, and child mortality rates decreased. Leprosy, trachoma, and other diseases also saw a decline in cases. This is attributed to advancements in healthcare, economic growth, and global cooperation, contrasting with the perceived challenges of the time, such as rising tensions and conflicts.

site_title: Allianz to invest US$59m in digital US healthcare provider
summary: Allianz invests $59 million in digital US healthcare provider American Well, aiming to make its business global. The partnership will develop digital health solutions combining wearable sensors, remote monitoring, and virtual visits. American Well connects patients to doctors and healthcare providers over secure video, expanding its platform globally with Allianz's international expertise.

site_title: Rescuers struggle to tame oil tanker fire off China; body of mariner found
summary: Rescuers are struggling to bring under control a fire on an Iranian oil tanker off China's east coast, which collided with a grain ship on Saturday night, causing a 136,000-tonne oil spill. One of the 32 missing crew members was found dead on the tanker, and concerns are growing that the tanker may explode and sink. The blaze has hampered rescue work, with poor weather and toxic gas from the burning oil posing a major risk. The disaster has the potential to be one of the worst since a 1991 oil spill off the Angolan coast.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.18 points to 1,832.15 on Monday, with a 853-312 gain-to-lose ratio. The index closed at RM4.6 billion in volume.

site_title: Fed's monetary policy lodestar comes under attack
summary: Economists question the usefulness of the Phillips Curve, a cornerstone concept in mainstream economics, at the American Economic Association's annual meeting. The re-jigged version of the theory, which includes a natural rate of joblessness and inflation expectations, is not panning out in practice, despite the US unemployment rate being below the natural rate. Some Fed officials, including James Bullard, are questioning the Fed's strategy, and former Fed vice chairman Stanley Fischer conceded that the theorem doesn't seem to be working as expected.

site_title: US bank gains from new tax law start with short-term Q4 red ink
summary: US banks face short-term losses due to multi-billion-dollar tax charges from the new federal tax code, but are expected to benefit from lower corporate rates in the long term. Citigroup may report a quarterly loss of over $15 billion, while Goldman Sachs could lose around $3 billion. JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America are also expected to see significant declines in net income. Despite these short-term hits, analysts believe the overall benefit from lower taxes will outweigh the costs, and banks will use the extra money for stock buybacks and dividends.

site_title: Sanofi to market new haemophilia drug in deal with Alnylam
summary: Sanofi has secured the rights to develop and sell fitusiran, a new haemophilia treatment, in a deal with Alnylam Pharmaceuticals. Sanofi will handle global commercialization, while Alnylam will receive royalties. This agreement complements Sanofi's rare haematology portfolio and offers an innovative treatment for people with hemophilia A and B. In return, Alnylam will receive rights to develop and sell a treatment for ATTR amyloidosis, a rare disease. The deal reflects Sanofi's interest in Alnylam's genetic medicine portfolio.

site_title: Mothercare's shares plunge on report of poor Christmas sales
summary: Mothercare Plc reported a 7.2% decline in UK like-for-like sales over the holiday season, with gross margins expected to fall due to higher discounting. The company's shares plummeted 32%, the largest intraday decline on record. Mothercare's poor Christmas sales are attributed to the Brexit-induced weakness of the pound, inflation of costs, and a shift to online shopping, which has led to market share loss to grocery chains and Amazon. The company expects a full-year pretax profit of between £1 million and £5 million.

site_title: Global tech demand drives Taiwan's exports to new high
summary: Taiwan's exports reached a record high in December, rising 14.8% from the previous year, driven by strong demand for smartphones and other gadgets globally. The growth momentum is expected to continue, with the government raising its 2018 growth forecast to 2.29% from 2.27%. The robust exports cycle is attributed to factors such as artificial intelligence, bitcoin mining, and mobile phone products.

site_title: MMA world title beckons for Tiffany Teo in Jakarta
summary: Singaporean MMA star Tiffany Teo is set to face off against China's Xiong Jingnan for the One Championship world title in Jakarta on January 20. Teo, 27, has been training at Tiger Muay Thai & MMA Gym in Phuket, Thailand, for three weeks to prepare for the fight. Despite parental objections, Teo is determined to win the title and do her country proud. With a 7-0 professional record, Teo aims to remove the word "defeat" from her vocabulary and prove her skills in the martial arts world.

site_title: Imperium Crown gets SIAS queries over governance practices
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has queried Catalist-listed real estate developer Imperium Crown over governance practices, including a S$48,000 payout to its former CEO, John Lyn Hian Woon. The payout was made in recognition of his efforts to stabilise the company after a turbulent period in 2016. SIAS also questioned Imperium Crown's rating of Wonder Stone Park, a tourist attraction in China, and the appointment of an independent director, Pok Mee Yau, who had ties to the company's legal firm.

site_title: Mary Chia seeks extension to raise public float, keep listing
summary: Mary Chia Holdings, a Singapore-based slimming services chain, has applied for an extension to raise its public float to at least 10% by March 9, 2018, to keep its listing status. The company's shares have been suspended since October 2017 after a mandatory unconditional cash offer by Suki Sushi, a restaurant chain controlled by Lee Boon Leng, the husband of the company's CEO. The offeror acquired 60.98% of the firm for S$11 million, resulting in a 93.18% stake.

site_title: Ley Choon unit wins S$10.4m PUB contract
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings won a S$10.4 million contract from Singapore's PUB to replace water mains as part of network renewal. The work will be carried out by Ley Choon's unit. This contract is a significant win for the construction firm.

site_title: Datapulse to call 2 EGMs by Feb 26
summary: Datapulse Technology will call two extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) by February 26, following a move by the family of its co-founder to replace four directors and re-evaluate the company's diversification strategy. The move comes after Datapulse acquired Wayco Manufacturing in December, which was questioned by the Singapore Exchange. The company's substantial shareholders, who hold a combined 16% stake, have called for the removal of existing directors and the replacement with new ones. The EGMs will be held separately, with the first focused on the change of board and the second on the company's diversification strategy.

site_title: Cheung Woh posts loss of S$449,000 in Q3FY18
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies reported a net loss of S$449,000 in Q3FY18, compared to a profit of S$264,000 in Q3 FY2017. The company's turnover increased 5.8% to S$21.55 million, driven by higher sales in the HDD components segment. However, cost of sales rose 16% due to increased materials and labor costs. The loss per share was 0.15 cents, down from 0.09 cents in Q3 FY2017.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as tech, bank stocks weigh
summary: US stock indexes opened flat on Monday, with losses for banking and technology stocks. The Dow Jones fell 5.47 points, or 0.02%, to 25,290.4, while the S&P 500 lost 0.79 points, or 0.028799%, to 2,742.36. The Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.54 points, or 0.02%, to 7,135.02, marking a halt to Wall Street's strongest start to a year in over a decade.

site_title: Rescue crews wrestle to tame China oil tanker fire; body of mariner found
summary: A Chinese oil tanker caught fire after colliding with a grain ship on Saturday in the East China Sea, with rescue crews struggling to bring the blaze under control. One of the 32 missing crew members was found dead on the tanker. The tanker, carrying 136,000 tonnes of highly volatile condensate, had collided with the CF Crystal, a freight ship carrying US grain, in waters not frequently used by large vessels. Environmental concerns are growing, with the potential for a massive oil spill and explosion.

site_title: Qatar to make copper wires, aluminium bars as it resists embargo
summary: Qatar's Aamal Co plans to build three factories to produce copper wires, aluminum bars, and cables, aiming to reduce reliance on imports amid an embargo by other Arab states. The $31.6 million facilities, funded by equity and debt, are set to be completed by 2019 and will cater to Qatar's growing demand for wires and cables. The move is part of Qatar's efforts to boost local production and self-sufficiency, following Saudi Arabia's and three other Arab countries' diplomatic and transport link cuts in June last year.

site_title: Lufthansa to hire 8,000 workers in 2018
summary: Lufthansa plans to hire over 8,000 workers in 2018, with more than half being flight attendants. The airline will add 2,500 employees to its main operations and 2,700 to its subsidiary Eurowings. The hiring spree is part of Lufthansa's expansion efforts to compete with low-cost carriers. The airline recently received EU approval to buy Air Berlin's assets, including 33 leased planes and landing slots, after offering concessions to alleviate competition concerns.

site_title: Booze alert as young Japanese come of age
summary: Thousands of young Japanese women marked their 20th birthday with Coming of Age ceremonies, celebrating their entry into adulthood and the freedom to legally drink and smoke. The ceremonies, which began as a samurai tradition, were held across Japan, with many attendees later hitting bars to celebrate. The estimated 1.23 million new adults mirrored Japan's shrinking population, with half the 1970 peak of 2.46 million. Many opted for traditional kimonos and business suits, with some expressing concerns about responsibility and drinking limits.

site_title: British income squeeze shows in spending and house-price decline
summary: British households face increasing pressure from surging inflation, with consumers curbing spending for the first time in five years in 2017. A decline in house prices and a squeeze on incomes are attributed to the UK's Brexit vote and the pound's decline. Inflation is at 3.1%, the highest in over five-and-a-half years, and wage growth is failing to keep pace. Economists predict growth will slow to 1.4% this year, with uncertainty over the economy and Brexit negotiations affecting consumer confidence and business investment.

site_title: Shell sells partial stake in Dutch wind farm to Switzerland's Partners Group
summary: Shell sells 20% stake in Dutch wind farm 'Blauwwind II' to Switzerland's Partners Group, which now holds 45% stake. The project, worth 700 MW, aims to provide 1 billion euros in funding. Shell will continue investing, then dispose of stake once financing is arranged and purchasing agreements are in place. The Dutch government has confirmed several companies, including Vattenfall and Statoil, have participated in the Hollandse Kust Zuid auction, with the winner to be announced in mid-March.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.7% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 22.7 points, or 0.7%, to 3,512.18 on Monday, with 1.9 billion shares traded worth S$944 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 258-161. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Former top Visa executive Ooi Huey Tyng starts work at Grab to steer e-payments push
summary: Former Visa executive Ooi Huey Tyng has started work at Grab as managing director for GrabPay in Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, underscoring the company's ambitions for 2018. The move follows a high-profile financing round in 2017, which included investments from Didi Chuxing and SoftBank Group Corp. Grab plans to roll out consumer payments for Malaysian users and expand its peer-to-peer fund transfer service in the Philippines. The appointment brings deep leadership expertise to GrabPay, with Ooi's experience in the region's premier banks and payments providers.

site_title: Ford launching diesel truck to grab fuel economy edge
summary: Ford Motor Co plans to launch a diesel engine version of its F-150 pickup truck in the spring, aiming to gain a marketing edge over rivals. The F-150 diesel model is expected to achieve 30 miles per gallon highway fuel efficiency, comparable to some midsize cars. This move comes as major rivals are introducing more efficient pickups, such as the Chevrolet Silverado and Ram 1500.

site_title: Hong Kong eyes new trading rules, adding rebates to spur volume, fight competition
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) is considering rule changes to increase trading volume and competitiveness. Proposed measures include rebates to market makers, simplified rules for collateral, and reduced stamp duty charges. The exchange aims to attract innovative companies and international fund companies, following China's relaxation of capital market caps. HKEX's share price has risen 37% in the past year, outperforming its peers, as the exchange expands its derivatives market and introduces new products, including iron ore futures.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore tech firms can pilot new innovations in India under a new bilateral MOU. Noble Group sold its US gas and power unit for $168m. CapitaLand's mall divestment in China received positive feedback from local banks. Stratech Group missed its AGM deadline due to funding delays. Senior Counsel Kuah Boon Theng was appointed by Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon. The STI Today reported a 0.7% gain for Singapore shares. Meanwhile, international news included Vietnam's surprise over Trump's tariff announcement, a Malaysian agency seizing assets, and China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Medical law and ethics lawyer Kuah Boon Theng appointed senior counsel
summary: Medical law and ethics lawyer Kuah Boon Theng, 50, was appointed senior counsel in Singapore, a prestigious honor given to outstanding lawyers with extensive knowledge of the law. Kuah, who has practiced law for almost 30 years, has a special interest in healthcare law and has obtained a Master of Arts degree in medical ethics and law from King's College University of London. The appointment brings the total number of senior counsel in Singapore to 63, with Kuah joining the ranks of other top lawyers in the country.

site_title: Denmark's Novo Nordisk offers 2.6b euros for Belgian biotech group Ablynx
summary: Denmark's Novo Nordisk has made a 2.6 billion euros bid for Belgian biotech group Ablynx, a 14% higher offer than its previous attempt. Ablynx rejected the initial bid in December and has declined to discuss the new offer. The acquisition would be Novo Nordisk's first under CEO Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen, aiming to broaden its product line. Ablynx's shares have doubled in value in the past year, with its products targeting various diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and cancer.

site_title: US bank gains from tax law start with red ink
summary: US banks are expected to face significant short-term losses due to the new federal tax code, with Citigroup potentially reporting a quarterly loss of over $15 billion and Goldman Sachs a loss of about $3 billion. However, analysts believe the long-term benefit of lower corporate tax rates will outweigh the initial charges, with some banks expected to see significant profit increases in 2019. For example, Bank of America could earn $4.5 billion more in 2019 due to the lower tax rate, while Wells Fargo could see a $2.5 billion boost to its bottom line.

site_title: Mothercare plummets in latest UK retail Christmas disaster
summary: Mothercare Plc reported a 7.2% decline in UK sales over the holiday season, with shares plummeting 32% due to higher discounting and post-Christmas sales. The company expects a full-year pretax profit between £1 million and £5 million, significantly lower than the estimated £11.9 million. The poor Christmas sales are attributed to Brexit-induced cost increases, nimbler online rivals, and squeezed disposable incomes. This is part of a broader UK retail Christmas disaster, with Debenhams and House of Fraser also warning of weak holiday sales.

site_title: UK house prices fall for first time in 6 months: Halifax
summary: UK house prices fell 0.6% in December, their first decline in 6 months, according to Halifax. This marks a reversal of the 0.3% rise in November, and annual growth slowed to 2.7%, weaker than a 3.9% rise in November. The decline is attributed to economic uncertainty, including the Brexit vote and the Bank of England's interest rate hike, which has led to higher mortgage rates. Despite this, Halifax still forecasts growth of 0-3% in house prices in 2018 due to a shortage of homes up for sale.

site_title: LG Electronics' Q4 profit estimate misses expectations, shares slide
summary: LG Electronics reported a Q4 operating profit estimate that missed market expectations, with a potential 367 billion won (S$457.28 million) compared to a Thomson Reuters estimate of 485 billion won. Shares fell 6.8% before paring losses. Revenue likely rose 14.8% to 17 trillion won, exceeding expectations. Analysts attribute the miss to increased spending to expand market share in the home appliances business, despite solid forecasts for the TV business. Full results will be announced at the end of January.

site_title: Tech faithful gather to worship at mecca of innovation
summary: The 2018 Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas has brought together tech industry leaders to showcase innovations in artificial intelligence, robotics, digital health, and more. Exhibitors, including Nvidia and Byton, highlight advancements in machine learning, self-driving cars, and health technologies that aim to tackle urban congestion, cancer, and depression. However, concerns over cybersecurity and the potential darker side of tech are also raised, with some analysts cautioning that tech is being seen as a solution to all problems.

site_title: Iron ore powerhouse warns of volatility as China curbs ease
summary: Australia's Department of Industry, Innovation and Science warns of iron ore price volatility in 2018 due to China's efforts to manage steel production. China's steel production restrictions may boost demand in the first half, but prices are expected to drop in the second half due to growing global supply from low-cost producers. Benchmark spot prices averaged US$71.36 last year, and prices may reach US$76.80 per ton in Qingdao. The forecast predicts robust growth in steel production and iron ore demand after winter restrictions are lifted, but prices are expected to decline beyond the first half of 2018.

site_title: Taiwan calls China's new aviation routes in Taiwan Strait irresponsible
summary: Taiwan's government has condemned China's unilateral expansion of civil aviation routes in the Taiwan Strait, calling it an irresponsible act that threatens regional security. China opened several disputed air routes last week, including a northbound M503 route, without informing Taiwan, violating a 2015 agreement to discuss flight paths. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen stated that the move "seriously affects aviation safety and damages the current situation in the Taiwan Strait." The incident has raised tensions between Beijing and Taipei, with Taiwan viewing the move as a provocative act.

site_title: Hong Kong IPO said to be 1,500 times oversubscribed in frenzy
summary: Hong Kong IPO of C-Mer Eye Care Holdings Ltd has been oversubscribed 1,557 times, the highest retail participation in 11 years, with individual buyers placing orders for at least 1,500 times the initial stock set aside. The offering aims to raise up to $73 million, with 10% earmarked for retail buyers. This surpasses the oversubscription of Yixin Group Ltd's IPO in November, which was over 500 times. The company's IPO will complete order-taking today and start trading on January 15.

site_title: UBS in talks to buy majority stake in China securities joint venture
summary: UBS is in talks to acquire a majority stake in its Chinese securities joint venture, with CEO Sergio Ermotti stating the bank is ahead of its plan to double its China headcount to 1,200 by the end of 2018. The discussions come after China relaxed foreign ownership restrictions, allowing 51% stakes, with UBS aiming to conclude the talks in a matter of months. Other global banks, such as Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, are also exploring majority stakes in their Chinese ventures, following the government's announcement.

site_title: Singapore dollar soars to levels last seen 3 years ago
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has surged to levels not seen in three years, reaching 1.3256 on Monday, according to Bloomberg. This is due to global investors snapping up local assets, driven by a synchronous global recovery and improving risk appetite. The Straits Times Index (STI) has hit a two-and-a-half year high, and short-term Singapore government securities yields have decreased. Analysts predict the SGD will reach 1.30 by end-2018, driven by a wobbly USD, resilient growth environment, and supportive risk appetite.

site_title: Aramco joins Saudi firms boosting pay after royal orders
summary: Saudi Arabian Oil Co (Aramco) and other major Saudi firms will increase pay for eligible staff by 1,000 riyals (S$355) a month for one year, following a royal order to boost handouts to government workers amid public discontent over rising prices. The payments will apply to employees earning 20,000 riyals or less a month, with those in apprenticeship and college degree programs receiving an additional 10% of their monthly stipend. The move aims to ease public discontent and prepare for Aramco's potential initial public offering.

site_title: Europe: Equities rise at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets advanced on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.1%, Paris's CAC 40 gaining 0.2%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 increasing 0.6%. This follows a broadly upbeat session in Asia. Analysts attribute the rise to tightening employment markets, despite a below-forecast jobs reading in the US. The gains come as US-EU trade talks remain in focus, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks enjoy gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.28% to close at 30,899.53, marking a tenth consecutive gain, as Asian markets followed Wall Street's rally. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also advanced, with the Shanghai Index rising 0.52% and the Shenzhen Index climbing 0.22%. The gains came despite US tariff threats.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise; won down on suspected greenback buying by government
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 15.79 points or 0.63% to 2,513.31, while the won fell 0.31% to 1,066 per dollar, as suspected government buying of $1.5 billion in the market boosted the currency.

site_title: Volkswagen, Uber to deploy Nvidia's technology for self driving
summary: Nvidia is partnering with Uber and Volkswagen to deploy its artificial intelligence expertise in self-driving cars. Uber will use Nvidia processors and software for its self-driving vehicles, while Volkswagen will develop an intelligent co-pilot system. Nvidia's CEO Jen Hsun Huang touted the tie-ups as a way to claim leadership in the emerging field of self-driving cars. The companies aim to provide convenience and assistance features, such as recognizing driver drowsiness and maintaining proper lane speed. The partnerships are seen as a significant step forward in the development of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Yuan erases gains as central bank adviser eyes rate of 6.6 against US dollar
summary: China's yuan rose initially after the People's Bank of China set a stronger midpoint setting, but gains were erased as market weighed comments by an adviser to the central bank. The adviser, Sheng Songcheng, suggested the yuan would stabilize around 6.6 against the US dollar in the longer-term, citing factors such as US dollar weakness and rising interest rates in China's financial markets receding. The yuan's spot rate rose to 6.4760 before pulling back to 6.4869.

site_title: Baltimore gets top ranking that no city wants: #1 in bed bugs
summary: Baltimore has been ranked the top city in the US for bed bugs, according to Orkin LLC's Top 50 Bed Bug Cities list for the second consecutive year. The list is based on residential and commercial treatments for bed bugs from December 2016 to November 2017. This ranking reflects a rising number of infestations across the US, with Tim Husen, an Orkin entomologist, attributing it to the increasing prevalence of the pests. The city's historic neighborhoods and residential areas are among those most affected.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS raises Keppel target price by S$2.20 to S$9.80
summary: DBS analysts have maintained a "buy" call for Keppel Corporation, increasing its target price to S$9.80 due to a higher valuation of the company's property segment. The analysts are unfazed by a S$570 million fine for corrupt payments to officials in Brazil, citing Keppel's long track record, proactive actions, and tightened internal controls. The property segment is seen as "underappreciated and undervalued" with a huge land bank and nascent profitability. The analysts also expect the offshore and marine industry to recover due to oil price increases and new contract wins.

site_title: Ford to launch diesel truck to grab fuel economy edge
summary: Ford plans to launch a diesel engine version of its best-selling F-150 pickup truck, offering 30 miles per gallon highway fuel efficiency. The model will cost between $2,400 and $4,000 more than a comparable gasoline truck. Production will be at a Ford plant in Britain, with about 5% of F-150 models expected to be ordered with the diesel engine. The diesel F-150 will target customers who tow large trailers, competing with General Motors and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles for the most fuel-efficient large pickup.

site_title: China's Tiangong-1 space lab is not out of control: top Chinese engineer
summary: China's Tiangong-1 space lab, launched in 2011, is not out of control and poses no safety threat, according to a top Chinese engineer. The space station is expected to re-enter the Earth's atmosphere in the first half of 2018, burning up and falling into the designated South Pacific ocean, where debris from Russian and US space stations have previously landed. China has extended the station's mission multiple times, with President Xi Jinping prioritizing advancing China's space programme for peaceful purposes and potential national security benefits.

site_title: Parliament: Inter-agency task force reviewing SkillsFuture fraud; data analytics system to be up by Q3
summary: A task force has been formed to review the SkillsFuture fraud detection system, following a nearly S$40 million loss to the government agency. A data analytics system is expected to be in place by Q3, and measures have been taken to strengthen the system through data analytics and collaboration with the private sector. The task force involves multiple government agencies and will focus on detecting false claims without affecting genuine employers. Additionally, a review of SkillsFuture Credit claims has been conducted, with over 4,400 individuals found to have made false claims, amounting to over S$2 million.

site_title: Malaysia stocks on path to fulfill historical rally before polls
summary: Malaysia's benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index posted its best monthly performance in five years in December, extending gains last week by 1.2%. The rally is driven by bets on government-linked companies benefiting from upcoming elections and a strengthening ringgit. This is similar to past rallies preceding elections, with gains of up to 49% recorded before the 1999 election. Foreign investors continue to buy Malaysian shares, with the country recording the biggest foreign inflows in Southeast Asia last week.

site_title: Accreditation scheme to be expanded to raise professional standards in legal industry
summary: Singapore's Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon announced the expansion of the Specialist Accreditation Scheme to the maritime and shipping industry, aiming to raise professional standards in the legal sector. The scheme, introduced last year, has already recognized 24 lawyers. Menon emphasized the need for lawyers to commit to continuous professional development in response to changing legal practice. The expansion is part of initiatives to enhance education and training for law graduates and lawyers, with the goal of making Singapore a significant contributor to the regional legal sector.

site_title: South Korea inspects 6 banks over clients' virtual currency accounts
summary: South Korea's financial regulator has jointly inspected six local banks offering virtual currency accounts to institutions over concerns of money laundering, scams, and speculation. The Financial Services Commission and Financial Supervisory Service will check if banks adhere to anti-money laundering rules and use real names for accounts. The six banks include NH Bank, Industrial Bank of Korea, and Shinhan Bank. Officials are also exploring ways to reduce risks associated with cryptocurrency trading, potentially shutting down institutions that use such currencies. The regulator warned of severe side effects and cracking down on virtual currency crime.

site_title: And the Golden Globes goes to... press freedom
summary: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association has announced a $2 million donation to combat growing threats to press freedom. The organization, which runs the Golden Globe Awards, has given $1 million each to the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists and the Committee to Protect Journalists. The move comes amid concerns over the preservation of a free press, with US President Donald Trump frequently denouncing "fake news." The donations aim to support in-depth cross-border probes and defend journalists worldwide, highlighting the importance of a free press in holding those in power accountable.

site_title: Australian shares end at 10-year high; NZ eases off record
summary: Australian shares reached a 10-year high, ending the day 0.1% higher on Monday. Banking stocks and positive cues from Wall Street drove gains, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group leading the way. Real estate and healthcare stocks also rose, while miners fell due to easing global commodity prices. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index retreated 0.4% lower, snapping a three-session gain streak.

site_title: BBC editor quits China post over pay discrimination
summary: BBC editor Carrie Gracie resigned from her post in Beijing over pay disparities with male colleagues, citing a "crisis of trust" at the broadcaster. Gracie, who worked 30 years for the BBC, was offered a pay increase but felt it was "far short of equality." The BBC had previously acknowledged the issue, stating that fairness in pay is vital, but an audit found no systemic discrimination against women. Gracie called for an independent arbitration to settle individual cases. The BBC has pledged to close the gender gap by 2020.

site_title: Noma has lost everything. Can it come back even stronger?
summary: Chef Rene Redzepi is revamping his renowned Copenhagen restaurant Noma after shutting it down last year. The new Noma will open on February 15, featuring a seafood, vegetarian, and game menu, with a focus on seasonal, local ingredients and innovative Nordic cuisine. The restaurant has been rebuilt to accommodate 40 diners, with a greenhouse and a private dining room. Redzepi is taking a risk by moving away from the restaurant's previous Michelin-starred reputation, but he believes it will allow for new ideas and creativity. Reservations have already sold out for the first 10 weeks, and the restaurant is expected to be a major destination for foodies.

site_title: Chaos at JFK airport with flood, storm backlog
summary: Chaos reigned at JFK airport for a third consecutive day due to a flooded terminal and chronic delays caused by a deadly winter storm. A water pipe broke in Terminal Four, flooding the area and forcing the closure of arrivals and departures. Passengers were stranded, with some waiting for hours to access gates and others forced to sleep on the floor. The incident highlighted complaints about poor infrastructure serving the US financial capital, with officials investigating the cause of the break and promising accountability. Delays and cancellations continued, with international flights diverted to other airports.

site_title: Singapore firms must uphold integrity: Indranee
summary: Senior Minister of State for Finance and Law Indranee Rajah emphasized the importance of integrity for Singapore companies operating overseas. In response to questions about the corruption scandal surrounding Keppel Corporation, Indranee stated that Singapore companies must uphold their own standards of integrity, comply with local laws, and develop ways to operate with clean systems. The government expects them to not lower their standards and not bring back practices alien to Singapore's norms. Keppel Offshore & Marine was fined US$422 million for bribery charges in a global resolution with US, Brazil, and Singapore authorities.

site_title: Singapore tech firms to pilot new innovations in India following bilateral MOU
summary: Singapore tech firms can now pilot new innovations in India through a bilateral MOU signed by IE Singapore and CII. The agreement aims to facilitate business partnerships and knowledge exchange between Singapore and Indian tech companies. India is emerging as the world's third-largest startup base, with over 5,000 tech startups in 2017. The MOU will enable Singapore companies to participate in joint programmes and build engagement platforms for Indian and Singaporean tech business leaders.

site_title: New Berlin airport needs up to 1b euros more before opening: report
summary: Berlin's new airport is facing a major setback, with a report stating it needs up to 1 billion euros in extra funds before opening in October 2020. The Flughafen Berlin Brandenburg GmbH management informed the supervisory board before Christmas of the funding shortfall. This would be another delay for the project, which has already been plagued by issues and delays. The exact amount needed is not specified, but it is clear that the project's completion timeline is uncertain.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin afternoon session on higher ground; STI at 3,496.76
summary: Singapore shares began trading on Monday in positive territory, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.21% to 3,496.76. The index was down marginally at 1pm, with 195 gainers beating 146 losers. Midas Holdings and Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) Co were among the top gainers, while DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank were among the top losers. The market was active, with one billion shares worth S$422.9 million traded.

site_title: Oprah Winfrey claims lifetime Golden Globe, calls for 'a new day' for women
summary: Oprah Winfrey received the lifetime Golden Globe award, becoming the first black woman to receive the honor. In her speech, she praised women who shared their stories of sexual harassment and abuse, declaring a "new day" for girls and women. Winfrey, a renowned actress, producer, and talk show host, used her platform to support victims and promote strong female characters, calling for an end to the "me too" movement's "me too" refrain.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices reach double '97 level and stocks rally
summary: Hong Kong home prices have surpassed double their 1997 levels, reaching a 25-year high, with the Hang Seng Property Index up 6.5% this year and 40% in the past year. Financial Secretary Paul Chan warned that affordability has deteriorated, with mortgage payments accounting for 68% of median household income. Despite this, stocks continue to rally, with Wharf Holdings Ltd. and China Overseas Land & Development seeing significant gains. Chan cautioned that rising interest rates could put pressure on the residential property market in the future.

images.alt_text: Here's a scary statistic: Hong Kong home prices are more than double their 1997 levels, when the city's biggest housing bubble burst.

site_title: China's Lanzhou eases property tightening measures, more cities may follow
summary: China's Lanzhou eases property curbs, relaxing restrictions on home purchases in downtown areas and lifting measures in suburban suburbs. This move comes amid a nationwide clampdown on housing speculation, with over 100 cities implementing tightening curbs. Analysts predict other second-tier cities may follow suit, further inflating price bubbles in the sector. The easing of measures aims to address high inventories and facilitate property sales for first-time home buyers and those seeking improved living conditions.

site_title: US dollar clings above 3-1/2-months lows; loonie stands tall
summary: The US dollar held steady above a 3-1/2-month low against a basket of major currencies, influenced by slower-than-expected US jobs growth and expectations for further Federal Reserve interest rate increases in 2018. The dollar index rose to 91.919, with the euro and Canadian dollar also gaining ground. Traders remain optimistic about rate hikes, citing strong economic growth and low unemployment.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up at start of week but Hong Kong struggles
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, following Wall Street records, but Hong Kong fell after nine consecutive gains. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.2% as investors anticipated a top in the bull market. Shanghai, Sydney, and Singapore rose, while Seoul and Taipei also increased. The US jobs report, which showed 148,000 new jobs, was seen as a solid number, supporting a tight labor market and potential wage and inflation increases. The dollar held up against peers, with the Federal Reserve's hawkish minutes providing support.

site_title: Brokers' take: CapitaLand's mall divestment in China gets thumbs up from DBS, RHB, CIMB
