Construction tender prices seem to have stabilized, with some analysts predicting that companies like Yongnam and Wee Hur may benefit from potential major order wins in the NSC project.

site_title: 56 years on, Singapore Open still awaiting a local winner
summary: The Singapore Open golf tournament, held at Sentosa Golf Club's Serapong course, has been running for 56 years but has yet to produce a local winner. Six Singaporeans have confirmed spots in the upcoming $1 million event, with a few more hoping to qualify through the qualifying tournament. Sentosa Golf Club may consider granting a "practice privilege" to the Singaporean players, allowing them to play practice rounds at the challenging course, in an effort to boost local participation and celebrate the country's golfing heritage.

site_title: SPH Reit's Q1 DPU unchanged at 1.34 cents
summary: SPH Reit posted unchanged distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.34 Singapore cents for Q1 2018, driven by 1.7% growth in gross revenue to S$53.5 million. Net property income rose 1.9% to S$42.2 million. Despite a negative 10.6% rental reversion at Paragon, both retail malls maintained full occupancy. The company remains focused on strengthening property quality and positioning, with a gearing level of 25.4% and average cost of debt at 2.84%.

site_title: Nordic Group to buy Tuas property
summary: Nordic Group has signed an option to purchase an industrial property in Tuas, Singapore, for S$6.2 million. The 5,677.90 sq m property has a 30-year lease period from 1989, with an option for another 30 years, which has been granted by Jurong Town Corporation. The deal is part of Nordic Group's expansion plans, but no further details on the project's timeline or purpose have been disclosed.

site_title: Memories Group surges 30% on first trading day
summary: MEMORIES Group, a Singapore-listed company, made its first trading day with a 30% surge to close at 37 Singapore cents after completing a reverse takeover and placement of 50 million shares. The company, formerly known as SHC Capital Asia, focuses on Myanmar tourism-related businesses and now has a 47.6% stake in Yoma Strategic Holdings. The listing on the SGX Catalist aims to enhance shareholder value through tourism-related acquisitions and expansion.

site_title: China to keep 6.5% fiscal growth target amid debt push: sources
summary: China is set to maintain its economic growth target at around 6.5% for 2018, according to sources. This target, which was also set for 2017, will be officially unveiled at a meeting of the National People's Congress in March. Despite criticism of regulators and finance officials for not addressing financial risk and debt, China's economy has already surpassed last year's growth goal. The country is poised for its first full-year acceleration since 2010, with fourth-quarter growth at 6.7%.

site_title: CapitaLand rejigs China focus with mall disposals
summary: CapitaLand is selling 20 Chinese retail malls for 8.37 billion yuan (S$1.71 billion), generating net proceeds of S$660m and a net gain of S$75m. The group is refocusing its China focus on Tier-1 and Tier-2 cities, disposing of small, first-generation malls with long leases. The transaction is expected to be completed in Q2 this year, and analysts see it as a timely move to free up capital and reposition the portfolio.

images.alt_text: CapitaMall Quanzhou in Fujian Province. The divestment allows CapitaLand to focus on its core city clusters of Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Wuhan, Chongqing and Chengdu.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices unreasonable, unsustainable: SC Capital
summary: Hong Kong home prices are deemed unreasonable and unsustainable by SC Capital Partners, a US$2.6 billion real estate private equity firm, citing cooling measures' ineffectiveness. Despite measures like stamp duties, investors continue to buy properties violating investing fundamentals. The city's chief executive Carrie Lam acknowledged government measures' failure. SC Capital Partners' founder attributes Hong Kong's housing sector to mainland Chinese buyers and a lack of public housing programs. Rising interest rates may hit property prices, and the firm is evaluating South-east Asian investments, including in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: An option to upgrade, with zero cash
summary: A Singapore home owner can upgrade to a more expensive property without paying any upfront cash, as the existing property's value appreciates over time. This occurs through unrealised capital gains, which can accumulate significantly over time, making the home a valuable asset.

site_title: STI dips below 3,500 as banks, Singtel pull back
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore slipped 11.71 points to close at 3,489.45, down 0.33% due to a pullback by DBS, UOB, and Singtel. Midas Holdings rose 5.7% and Memories Group, a Myanmar tourism firm, significantly increased to S$0.37 after its listing on the Catalist board. Concrete supplier Pan-United Holdings ended trading at S$0.44 after going ex-entitlement.

site_title: Meteoric rise of bitcoin rival Ripple upends Forbes' rich list
summary: The value of Ripple, a virtual currency, has skyrocketed, briefly catapulting co-founder Chris Larsen to fifth place on Forbes' list of the world's richest people, with an estimated net worth of over $59 billion. The boom is driven by speculation and FOMO, with other top Ripple holders seeing their fortunes surge over 100% in the last week and 30,000% in the last year. However, the value of virtual currencies is highly volatile, and Larsen's wealth could fluctuate rapidly, making his fortune fragile.

site_title: US firm seals deal to resume MH370 hunt: Malaysia
summary: Malaysia has agreed to allow a US exploration firm, Ocean Infinity, to resume the search for missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, one year after the search was suspended. The deal is on a "no find, no fee" basis and will involve a research vessel and autonomous submarines to scour the seabed for the jet. The search area is expected to be in the southern Indian Ocean, where the plane is believed to have disappeared. The search is expected to start in January and February, with relatives of the victims informed of the decision.

site_title: The (really) old and new meet in Naples
summary: An exhibition at the Madre contemporary art museum in Naples, Italy, showcases artworks from nearly 2,000 years ago, preserved in the ash of the 79 AD Vesuvius eruption. The artworks, featuring vibrant narrative frescoes, are examples of the fourth Pompeian style, created by interior designers after a 62 AD earthquake. The display highlights the long-lasting nature of these ancient artworks, offering a unique glimpse into life in Pompeii before its destruction. The exhibition features the preserved wall paintings for the first time, providing a rare opportunity for the public to see these ancient masterpieces.

site_title: Analysts are expecting the party to end - they just don't know exactly when
summary: Investors are bracing for a potential market correction as the bull run reaches its limits. Despite being overvalued and overbought, many investors remain optimistic, with some attributing the market's resilience to Donald Trump's presidency. Analysts, including James Stack and Jerome Dodson, expect a correction to be healthy, but warn that the longer the market continues without one, the greater the risk of a severe downturn. Experts recommend staying the course, rebalancing portfolios, and focusing on undervalued sectors such as healthcare and consumer staples. Active management may also outperform index funds in a potential market reversal.

site_title: Mortgage rates stumble heading into the new year
summary: US mortgage rates retreated to pre-previous-week levels, falling to 3.95% for 30-year fixed-rate averages and 3.38% for 15-year fixed-rate averages, according to Freddie Mac data. The decline was attributed to a drop in Treasury yields. Experts predict mortgage rates will remain stable in the near term, with some expecting a potential spike if wage increases exceed expectations. Mortgage applications also declined, with the refinance index dropping 7% and the purchase index ticking up 1%.

site_title: London house market worst in UK with price drop last year
summary: London's house market experienced its worst performance in the UK last year, with a 0.5% price drop, lagging behind a 2.6% national increase. This is the first full-year decline since the 2009 recession and may persist in 2018, according to Nationwide Building Society and other reports. Factors contributing to the slowdown include inflation, Brexit uncertainty, and tax changes affecting landlords and owners of second homes, with some predicting price declines in the city.

site_title: Japanese companies begin to buckle as Abe pressures them to raise wages
summary: Japanese companies are under pressure to raise wages by 3% or more, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pushes for increases in the face of a tight labor market. Despite the nation's best economic growth in a decade and high corporate profits, many companies are hesitant to meet the government's demand. Some, such as Asahi Group Holdings, have announced plans to raise wages, while others are discussing the possibility. The government plans to introduce legislation to lower corporate taxes for companies that meet the wage increase threshold, aiming to boost consumer spending and inflation.

site_title: Healthcare Services Bill proposed amid new healthcare scene
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health proposes a new Healthcare Services Bill to enhance oversight and safeguard patients amid a growing need for new care models and emerging healthcare services such as telemedicine. The bill aims to regulate healthcare services, nursing, and allied health services, while strengthening governance and oversight of licensed healthcare services. Key features include a services-based licensing framework, patient data sharing for better care coordination, and safeguards to protect patient confidentiality. The bill is open for public feedback until February 15, 2018.

site_title: Li Ka-shing predicts strong demand
summary: Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's richest man, stated that demand for property remains strong, indicating no end to the driving force behind the world's most expensive real estate market's price hikes.

site_title: Summit Power awards US$150m contract to PSA subsidiary in Bangladesh
summary: Summit Power International awarded a 15-year contract worth approximately US$150 million to PSA Marine Bangladesh for support vessel services at its liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal in Bangladesh. The contract, expected to start in early 2019, includes berthing, mooring, pilot, and personnel transfer services for LNG ships. This is part of Summit Power's US$1 billion investment program to deliver 1,000 megawatt of power and gas in Bangladesh.

site_title: Local banks to gain in 2018 from rising rates, loans growth
summary: Local banks in Singapore are expected to benefit from rising interest rates and healthy loan growth in 2018, despite concerns about their exposure to the struggling oil and gas sector. Analysts predict middle to high single-digit loans growth for DBS, OCBC, and UOB, driven by strong fourth-quarter GDP numbers and property market recovery. However, banks' asset quality in the oil and gas sector is expected to deteriorate, with non-performing loan ratios forecast to rise.

site_title: Investors sense opportunities in Big Oil - but mind the gap
summary: Investors are cautiously optimistic about the energy sector, particularly Big Oil, as shares in top energy firms have risen despite underperforming compared to recovering crude markets. The sector's performance gap with broader equity indexes remains, but investors see opportunities in the sector's revival in profits and cash generation. Analysts predict a gradual rise in oil prices by 2020 and earnings growth for European integrated oil stocks. Companies like Shell and BP are expected to maintain capital discipline and return to paying dividends fully in cash, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Keppel O&M CEO joins KrisEnergy board
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas company, has appointed Keppel Offshore & Marine CEO Chris Ong Leng Yeow as a non-executive director, effective January 5, 2018. Ong replaces Michael Chia, who is retiring after completing his contract. Chairman Tan Ek Kia welcomed Ong's experience and expertise, citing the company's focus on development projects. Chia, who served from 2016, was thanked for his contributions during KrisEnergy's financial restructuring and business realignment.

site_title: India, S'pore can clone India's digital miracle in Asean: envoy
summary: Indian High Commissioner to Singapore, Jawed Ashraf, suggests that India and Singapore can replicate India's digital transformation in ASEAN, speeding up the region's growth. ASEAN, like India, faces challenges in rural development and primitive economic sectors. The two countries share traits that enable digital power to drive growth, with India's digital technology expanding the financial system and Singapore's efforts to become a smart nation. An entrepreneurship platform, InSepreneur, aims to connect Indian and Singaporean businesses, capital, and ideas, and is seen as a springboard for further cooperation.

site_title: London luxury home at 'unbelievable' discount
summary: A London luxury home at One Blackfriars is being sold for £1.8 million, a 22% discount from its 2013 price of £2.3 million. The two-bedroom apartment on the 20th floor is now available for S$3.24 million. The significant price drop is described as "unbelievable" by the broker.

site_title: Oil eases from 3-year high after climbing on supplies
summary: Oil prices eased from a three-year high after a surge in US crude stockpiles and rising output. Crude stockpiles in the US declined by 7.42 million barrels last week, while oil output rose for the 10th time in 11 weeks. Despite efforts by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to boost prices, analysts believe further price gains may be limited, with some speculating that prices may retreat near $62.50 a barrel.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Dec jobs data
summary: US stocks opened at records on Friday, driven by wage growth signs and investors overlooking weaker-than-expected December job additions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 52 points, the S&P 500 gained 8.21 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 27.70 points. Despite tariff threats, the market extended its rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Indonesia's new cyber agency looks to recruit staff of hundreds
summary: Indonesia's newly established cyber security agency plans to recruit hundreds of personnel to combat online misinformation and hoaxes ahead of local elections later this year. The agency, led by Djoko Setiadi, will track cyber crimes and coordinate with the police and military to identify perpetrators. While it remains unclear if the agency will have the authority to prosecute crimes, it will focus on protecting government institutions, private companies, and the public. The agency's budget is set to be announced this month, following discussions with parliament.

site_title: China looks to tighten banks' NCD debt issuance - sources
summary: China's central bank has restricted the issuance of negotiable certificates of deposit (NCDs) for banks in 2018, aiming to reduce borrowing risks. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has advised banks to apply for permission specifying a maximum amount (annual quota) for NCD issues, with rejected applications exceeding one-third of total liabilities. This move follows a surge in NCD issuance, which exceeded 8 trillion yuan last year, and is part of the government's campaign to liberalize the interest rate market.

site_title: S'pore share buyback value fell to S$425m in 2017
summary: Singapore's share buyback value dropped to S$425 million in 2017, a decline from S$826 million in 2016, according to the Singapore Exchange. This represents a decrease in the number of companies participating in share buybacks, from over 100 in 2016 to 82 in 2017. Despite this decrease, the value of shares repurchased remains significant, indicating a strong market performance in 2017.

site_title: Summit Power awards US$150m contract to PSA subsidiary
summary: PSA Marine, a subsidiary of Summit Power International, has awarded a 15-year contract worth approximately US$150 million to provide support vessel services to LNG ships at Summit's terminal in Bangladesh, starting in early 2019. The contract includes berthing, mooring, pilot, and personnel transfer services, with three escort tugboats, one fast crew boat, and one offshore supply vessel. This contract is part of Summit Power's US$1 billion investment program to deliver 1,000 megawatt of power and gas in Bangladesh.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to take $1.25b hit for US tax revamp
summary: Morgan Stanley is taking a $1.25 billion hit to earnings in the fourth quarter due to the US tax overhaul. The charge, primarily from writing down US deferred tax assets, is offset by a gain of $160 million from a multiyear tax examination. The move is similar to other banks, such as Goldman Sachs and Bank of America, which are also feeling the impact of the new tax law. The lower corporate tax rate is expected to benefit some banks, but the near-term charges are a result of foreign earnings facing taxation and declining deferred tax assets.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust acquires remaining stake in HK property for HK$610m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has acquired the remaining 38% stake in a Hong Kong property for HK$610 million, gaining full ownership of the 18-storey warehouse with 39,125 sq m of net lettable area. MLT aims to reposition the building through asset enhancements to attract higher-value tenants, targeting a higher yield and improved capital value. The acquisition is part of MLT's expansion in Hong Kong, an attractive market with healthy organic growth due to supply constraints, and will be financed through bank borrowings and internal funds.

site_title: China beer shares surge on report prices have been boosted
summary: China beer shares surged on a report that breweries have increased prices by 10-20% due to higher raw material and labor costs, with Tsingtao Brewery Co leading the jump and climbing 23% in Hong Kong. China Resources Beer (Holdings) Co also rose 12%. The price hike is attributed to rising costs, despite no official announcement from the breweries.

site_title: Wall Street giddy on emerging markets amid overheating signs
summary: Emerging markets kicked off 2018 with a strong start, with equity inflows reaching the highest level since 2006 and developing-nation currencies rallying to their highest in almost five years. Analysts attribute the optimism to supportive data in China, reduced political volatility in South Africa, and stronger growth prospects for Brazil. However, some warn that the rally may be overlooking warning signs, including overbought currencies and a potentially expensive dollar. Despite this, many emerging-market debt managers remain bullish, citing stretched valuations and near-term spread performance.

site_title: 'World's ugliest pig' spotted in Indonesia
summary: Rare images of the "world's ugliest pig," a critically endangered species known as the Javan warty pig, have been captured in Indonesia. The species, found only on Java island, has declined significantly since the 1980s due to hunting and habitat loss. British and Indonesian researchers set up camera traps in the forests of Java to document the elusive creature. The images offer a glimpse into the species' plight and highlight the need for conservation efforts to protect the Javan warty pig from extinction. The species is believed to be on the brink of disappearing.

site_title: Axiata surges as wireless carrier said to mull US$500m tower IPO
summary: Axiata Group Bhd, Malaysia's largest wireless carrier, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) of its tower unit that could raise at least US$500 million. The news sent shares of the company surging 6.6% on Friday, the largest gain in over two years.

site_title: Hyflux unit files arbitration notice over contract dispute
summary: Hyflux's unit, Hydrochem, filed an arbitration notice against Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Environmental & Chemical Engineering Co and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Asia Pacific over a sub-contract dispute for a waste-to-energy plant. The dispute concerns a contract dated May 12, 2016. Hyflux expects the arbitration to not significantly impact its operations and financial performance.

site_title: Value of deals in GCB areas rises to five-year high
summary: The number of transactions and total value of Good Class Bungalow (GCB) deals in Singapore rose to a five-year high in 2017, with 40 transactions and a total value of S$855.14 million. The sector is expected to improve this year due to "pent-up demand" and narrowing gap between buyers and sellers' expectations. Experts predict prices to appreciate 5-7% this year, driven by demand from young entrepreneurs, newly minted citizens, and those upgrading from smaller bungalows.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% down on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.3% on Friday, closing at 3,489.45, after a five-day rally. Around 1.97 billion shares worth S$1.13 billion changed hands, with Midas being the most actively traded counter. Gainers outnumbered losers 217 to 192, indicating a slight bias towards buying.

site_title: Five-star experience
summary: A writer, new to hosting Airbnb Experiences, led a Saturday-night leisure run through Singapore's Central Business District, followed by dinner at a popular restaurant. The first guests, a young couple from China, gave a 4-star review, citing a great experience but suggesting more cultural history discussion. The writer notes that 4-star reviews are commendable but not excellent, and that constructive feedback is valuable. The experience highlights the importance of trust and honesty in the sharing economy, where high standards and strong values are crucial for quality experiences.

site_title: Vard Holdings to build car and passenger ferry for Norwegian public transport firm
summary: Vard Holdings has secured a contract to build a car and passenger ferry for Norwegian public transport firm Boreal. The ferry, featuring an electrical battery solution, will be built in Romania and delivered in Norway in 2019. Scheduled to operate in Norway from 2020, the vessel is designed for environmentally friendly operations in the Norwegian fjords.

site_title: Vallianz Holdings defers distribution for US$22.5m perpetual securities
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore support vessel owner and operator, has deferred the distribution of US$22.5 million for its 4% senior perpetual securities due to not making any payments for obligations junior to the securities in the preceding 12 months. This decision was made in accordance with the company's rights to defer the payment. The distribution is now postponed, with no new timeline provided.

site_title: Addictive gaming to be recognised as disease: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is set to recognize "gaming disorder" as a disease in the 11th edition of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD), to be published in June. The disorder is characterized by impaired control over gaming, increased priority given to gaming, and negative consequences. An individual must demonstrate an abnormal fixation on gaming for at least a year to be diagnosed. The WHO notes that the condition disproportionately affects younger people and calls for further research and resources to combat the problem. Official recognition is seen as a step towards addressing the issue.

site_title: Malaysia to suspend export tax on palm oil for three months
summary: Malaysia will suspend its export tax on crude palm oil for three months starting January 8, aiming to boost prices and protect the country's oil palm industry. The suspension will be lifted if crude palm oil stocks fall to 1.6 million tonnes. This move is intended to mitigate the impact of falling prices on smallholders' incomes and maintain the industry's competitiveness.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China Vanke, SCPG, and Triwater acquired CapitaLand's 20 malls, while Singapore shares fell 0.3% due to stronger market price gains. Nordic Group bought a Tuas property for S$6.2 million. Analysts from Jefferies upgraded City Developments Limited to 'buy' with a price target of S$14.8. The Ministry of Health is seeking public feedback on the Healthcare Services Bill until Feb 15.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.52 points to 1,817.97, closing higher on Friday with 5.83 billion shares worth RM3.94 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 696 to 405, marking a positive trading session.

site_title: BreadTalk says latest JV with Perennial is not a diversification of its business
summary: BreadTalk Group clarified that its investment in a joint venture with Perennial Real Estate in China does not diversify its business, despite the proposed development of healthcare integrated mixed-use developments connected to China's high-speed railway stations. BreadTalk invested S$33.6 million for a 5% stake in the venture, which has an initial committed capital of S$672.04 million. The move aims to capitalize on China's growing healthcare and transportation sectors, but does not represent a strategic shift for the company.

site_title: Keppel FELS delivers first of five rigs to Borr Drilling
summary: Keppel FELS has delivered the first of five oil rigs to Borr Drilling, marking a recovery sign for the offshore industry. The rigs, built to Keppel's KFELS Super B Class design, can operate at 400 ft depth and drill to 35,000 ft. This is part of a 2017 agreement where Borr took over construction contracts initially ordered by Transocean for $1.1 billion.

site_title: Toshiba exorcises Westinghouse ghost with sale to Brookfield
summary: Toshiba has sold its former nuclear unit Westinghouse Electric Co. to Brookfield Business Partners LP for $4.6 billion, ending a saga of financial woes that led to the bankruptcy of Westinghouse in March. The sale includes Westinghouse's US business and European operations, which will be reorganized under Brookfield's leadership. The deal marks a positive turn for Toshiba, which had written down the value of Westinghouse by billions and posted a net loss of $11.4 billion last fiscal year. The sale is seen as a way for Toshiba to move on from the Westinghouse debacle and for Brookfield to expand its presence in the nuclear industry.

site_title: Euro-area inflation slows, undermining calls for ECB to curb QE
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) saw euro-area inflation slow to 1.4% in December, undermining calls for the ECB to curb its quantitative easing (QE) program. Despite solid economic growth and declining unemployment, the underlying inflation rate held at 0.9%, and the ECB's stimulus measures may need to remain in place for longer. ECB officials, including President Mario Draghi, have expressed caution about unwinding QE, with some favoring a decision before the summer.

site_title: China to limit oil, refined product exports to North Korea
summary: China will limit exports of crude oil, refined oil products, steel, and other metals to North Korea, starting January 6, in line with UN sanctions imposed after North Korea's missile tests. This move follows an agreement by North Korea to hold talks with South Korea and follows China's adherence to recent UN sanctions, which cap refined petroleum exports at 500,000 barrels and limit crude oil supplies to 4 million barrels per year. The measures aim to restrict North Korea's access to refined petroleum products and crude oil.

site_title: French dairy giant Lactalis to buy Icelandic style skyr yogurt maker siggi's
summary: French dairy giant Lactalis has agreed to buy US-based siggi's, maker of Icelandic-style skyr yogurts, for an undisclosed price. Siggi's, founded in 2005, is available at major retailers like Whole Foods and Starbucks. The company will remain a standalone entity under its current leadership, operating from its New York City office. Lactalis, a privately held dairy company, has annual sales of around 17 billion euros and owns a 22% stake in siggi's, which it acquired from Swiss milk processor Emmi.

site_title: China beer shares surge on report prices have been boosted
summary: Chinese beer stocks surged, with Tsingtao Brewery leading the gain, after reports of a 10-20% price hike due to higher raw material and labor costs. The price increase is seen as a relief for breweries' cost pressure and net profit. This move may signal a shift in the competitive landscape, with breweries racing to overtake foreign brands, including Anheuser-Busch InBev. Analysts expect this price hike to be followed by consolidation in the industry.

site_title: India, Singapore can clone India's digital miracle in Asean: India High Commissioner
summary: India and Singapore can replicate India's digital transformation in Asean by partnering through the India-Singapore Entrepreneurship (InSpreneur) initiative, said India's High Commissioner to Singapore, Jawed Ashraf. Both countries have a strong pool of talent and supportive environments, with India leveraging digital technology to transform governance and delivery of public services, and Singapore driving its economy on digital power. Asean and India share similar characteristics, including economic growth disparities and isolated rural regions, making it an ideal partnership for digital development in the region.

site_title: Trump administration to delay Obama-era fair housing rule
summary: The Trump administration plans to delay enforcement of a federal fair housing rule until 2020, requiring communities to assess racial segregation in housing and offer plans to correct it. The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) will delay submission deadlines and stop reviewing plans that have already been filed. Critics say this move would effectively halt the first major effort to address racial inequality in housing since 2015. The change is part of a series of rollbacks by the Republican Trump administration.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb on tech rally, won subdued
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.26% to 2,497.52 on Friday, driven by foreign investors' purchases, particularly in the tech sector. The won ended flat against the US dollar, while bond yields fell. The Kospi gained 1.2% for the week, its biggest weekly percentage gain since early November, and rose 0.7% on a weekly basis for the fourth consecutive week.

site_title: SPH Reit's Q1 DPU at 1.34 cents
summary: SPH Reit reported unchanged Q1 distribution per unit of 1.34 Singapore cents, driven by an enlarged unit base and 1.7% growth in gross revenue to S$53.5 million. Net property income rose 1.9% to S$42.2 million, with both retail malls maintaining full occupancy amid retail headwinds.

site_title: China's money rates fall after year end
summary: China's primary money market rates dropped by 41 basis points to 3.05% in the first week of the new year, easing liquidity demand after peak cash demand at year-end. The central bank drained 510 billion yuan from the market, but analysts expect liquidity worries to resurface in mid-January due to seasonal factors and maturing loans. China's central bank has maintained liquidity in the banking system is "relatively high" and sufficient to absorb maturing reserve repos.

site_title: Golden Globes kick off introspective post-Weinstein awards season
summary: The 2018 Golden Globes ceremony kicks off the awards season, with the focus on speaking out against a culture of misconduct in Hollywood following the downfall of Harvey Weinstein. The event is expected to highlight stars' acceptance speeches and messages behind prizes, as much as performances, in response to the pervasive culture of misconduct. The ceremony is seen as a crucial moment for Hollywood to unite against sexual harassment, with the spotlight on the stars' voices and messages on the night.

site_title: Europe: Frankfurt, Paris stocks rise at open
summary: The Frankfurt and Paris stock markets rose in opening deals on Friday, with the Paris CAC 40 index gaining 0.2% to 5,424.16 and the Frankfurt DAX 30 rising 0.4% to 13,219.11. London's FTSE 100 index remained almost unchanged at 7,696.35 points. This follows record peaks on Wall Street, but US stocks edged down amid tariff threats.

site_title: Google eyes Chinese e-sports market with US$120m investment in Chushou
summary: Google has led a $120 million investment in Chinese live-stream mobile game platform Chushou, expanding its services to target overseas viewers. Chushou, founded in 2015, has 8 million streamers and 250,000 live streams daily. The investment, Google's second in a Chinese startup, aims to help Chushou grow globally as the US search engine giant seeks new avenues into the Chinese market, blocked by censorship authorities since 2012. Google joins existing investors and will help Chushou expand its services.

site_title: Clock ticks for French workers as GE confronts bloated legacy
summary: General Electric Co. is cutting 4,500 European power division jobs, including 1,411 in France, despite previously guaranteeing 1,000 net jobs by the end of 2018. The decision comes as the company seeks to trim costs and reverse a slump in shares. French labor groups say the job cuts are inevitable, as the initial guarantee only lasted through the end of 2018, and the company's new CEO, John Flannery, is under pressure to cut costs. The move further tarnishes GE's reputation, which is already facing scrutiny over its Alstom acquisition.

site_title: US job growth slowed more than expected in December
summary: US job growth slowed more than expected in December, with 148,000 jobs created, the lowest increase since March. Retail payrolls fell 20,300, while average hourly earnings rose 0.3% and the unemployment rate remained at 4.1%. The slowdown is attributed to a labor market nearing full employment, but a US$1.5 trillion tax cut package could boost job growth. Economists expect job growth to slow further this year, with annual wage growth projected to top 3.0% by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: US job growth slowed more than expected in December amid a decline in retail employment

site_title: Singapore share buyback value falls to S$425m in 2017 on the back of stronger market price gains
summary: Singapore's share buyback value fell to S$425 million in 2017, down from S$826 million in 2016, due to stronger market price gains. The majority of the buyback, S$221 million, was made by OCBC Bank, accounting for 52% of the total. The remaining 29% was distributed among nine other stocks. Buyback consideration was highest in May, June, and August, with a surge in December. The decline in buyback levels coincided with stronger price gains in the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes at fresh 26-year high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index reached a 26-year high for the second consecutive day, closing at 23,714.53 on January 5, 2018. The index added 0.89% or 208.20 points to its previous close. This marks the best level since January 1992. The record-setting advance on Wall Street continues despite ongoing US tariff threats.

site_title: Fed aiming to restrict credit, raising eventual recession risk
summary: The US Federal Reserve is shifting its approach to monetary policy, aiming to restrict the economy to achieve its inflation target. Fed officials believe interest rates may need to rise above their long-run equilibrium level, potentially leading to higher unemployment and recession risk. The central bank's goal is to stabilize inflation at 2%, which has been below target for over 90% of the time since 2012. Fed officials forecast a jobless rate of 3.9% by the end of this year and 4% by 2020, which may lead to a "soft landing" of the economy.

site_title: Olive branch or booby trap? North Korea's new tone divides analysts
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un has made overtures to Seoul, expressing a willingness to discuss improved North-South relations and sending athletes to the Winter Olympics. However, analysts warn that this may be a trap to drive a wedge between the US and South Korea, as Pyongyang seeks to divide their 70-year alliance. The US and South Korea have agreed to postpone joint military drills, but the long-term implications of this rapprochement are unclear. Experts say that while symbolic actions like Olympic participation and Panmunjom chats may be valuable, they are not enough to achieve lasting change without concrete steps towards disarmament.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for a ninth day
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a ninth consecutive day, driven by a rally in oil prices and benefiting energy firms. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.25%, closing at 30,814.64, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also rose. The gains follow a similar trend on Wall Street, where stocks hit new records despite US tariff threats.

site_title: Malaysia's Nov export growth at 14.4% y-o-y, above forecast
summary: Malaysia's November exports rose 14.4% year-over-year, exceeding the forecast of 13.9%. This growth was driven by robust shipments of manufactured goods, which expanded 18.2% from a year earlier. However, agricultural and mining goods shipments declined, mainly due to lower prices and volumes. Imports grew 15.2% year-over-year, resulting in a narrowed trade surplus of RM9.95 billion. Exports to the US, China, and the European Union also showed growth, with exports to the US rising 13.4% and to China growing 3.3%.

site_title: Peru's Fujimori leaves clinic as free man, reigniting anger over pardon
summary: Peru's former authoritarian leader Alberto Fujimori was released from a hospital as a free man on Thursday, sparking anger over a pardon granted by President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski on Christmas Eve. Fujimori, serving a 25-year sentence for graft and human rights crimes, was released due to health concerns and has been met with protests and criticism. The pardon has polarized Peru, with Fujimori's supporters rallying in support, while critics warn President Kuczynski will be beholden to Fujimori and his right-wing party.

site_title: Renault-Nissan alliance, Mitsubishi seek robo-taxi deals with tech players
summary: Renault, Nissan, and Mitsubishi are partnering with tech companies to develop robo-taxis, aiming to unveil names in coming months. The Franco-Japanese alliance plans to create 15 models with autonomous features by 2022, including a fully self-driving vehicle. The companies have already reached agreements to share research and development costs, with partnerships with Google, Uber, and Microsoft. The alliance aims to monetize autonomous technology through services like car-hailing, entertainment, and maintenance, while selling vehicles to individuals remains the core business.

site_title: Nordic Group to buy Tuas property for S$6.2m
summary: Nordic Group has signed an option to purchase an industrial property in Tuas, Singapore, for S$6.2 million. The 5,677.90 square metre property, which has a 30-year lease, will enable the company to consolidate three subsidiaries under one roof. The group plans to tap bank loans to fund the purchase, with the second option term granted by Jurong Town Corporation running from Dec 16, 2019.

site_title: Australia dollar weathers trade blow, NZ$ holds firm
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars maintained near multi-week highs on Friday, driven by optimism on global growth and commodity prices. The Aussie dollar was steady at US$0.7848, despite a trade deficit of A$628 million in November, as analysts expect a sharp increase in iron ore prices, boosting exports. The New Zealand dollar also held firm, last at US$0.7150, with no data to worry about. Commodity prices, including iron ore and liquefied natural gas, have been trending higher, supporting risk appetites.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session lower; STI at 3,498.7, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks began the afternoon session on Friday, January 5, 2018, down 0.1% at 3,498.7, with the Straits Times Index 2.46 points lower. About 975 million shares worth S$501 million changed hands, with Midas being the most actively traded stock, falling S$0.002 to S$0.157.

site_title: MOH seeking public feedback on new Healthcare Services Bill
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore is seeking public feedback on a new Healthcare Services Bill, which aims to safeguard patient safety and well-being in an evolving healthcare environment. The bill proposes broadening regulatory scope to cover healthcare services, nursing, and allied health services, and introducing a services-based licensing framework. It also includes measures to strengthen governance, oversight, and patient confidentiality, as well as provisions to protect patient safety and welfare. The public can provide feedback until February 15, 2018.

site_title: Uber ex-CEO Kalanick selling nearly a third of stake for US$1.4b: source
summary: Uber co-founder Travis Kalanick is selling nearly a third of his 10% stake in the company for approximately $1.4 billion, according to a source. The sale is part of a deal led by SoftBank Group Corp, which is taking a 17.5% stake in Uber. The deal values Uber at $48 billion, a 30% discount from its previous valuation of $68 billion. This investment comes as part of a $1.25 billion fresh funding round at the higher valuation.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata surges as carrier said to mull US$500m tower unit IPO
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group surged 6.6% after reports emerged that the carrier is considering an initial public offering (IPO) of its tower unit, Edotco Group, which could raise at least $500 million. The IPO, potentially listing this year, would help unlock value for Axiata and ease its debt burden. Axiata's shares outperformed the country's benchmark index, with the company's CEO previously stating plans to expand its overseas infrastructure operations. Deliberations are at an early stage, and Axiata could decide not to proceed with the offering.

images.alt_text: Axiata Group rose the most in more than two years after people with knowledge said Malaysia's biggest wireless carrier is considering an initial public offering of its tower unit that could raise at least US$500 million.

site_title: Apple to issue fix for iPhones, Macs at risk from 'Spectre' chip flaw
summary: Apple plans to release a patch for its Safari web browser to fix a vulnerability from the 'Spectre' chip flaw, which affects nearly every modern computing device. The flaw, disclosed by Google and other security researchers, leaves Macs and iOS devices vulnerable to hackers. Apple's Mac and iOS devices are affected by both Meltdown and Spectre, but recent operating system updates protect users against the Meltdown attack. The Spectre patch will be released in the coming days, and Apple Watch is not affected by the Meltdown or Spectre flaws.

site_title: China Vanke, Vanke's unit SCPG, Triwater unveiled as buyers of CapitaLand's malls
summary: CapitaLand has sold 20 retail malls in China to China Vanke, Vanke's subsidiary SCPG Commercial Property, and Triwater, an affiliate of a fund. The malls, mostly first-generation and small in size, were purchased over a decade ago and have long leases with Walmart, limiting CapitaLand's ability to reposition them. The disposal allows CapitaLand to focus on its core city clusters in China, including Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou. The company will receive S$3.66 billion from the disposal, which it can redeploy into investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: The buyers of CapitaLand's 20 retail malls are China Vanke, Vanke's subsidiary SCPG Commercial Property, and Triwater, an affiliate of a fund, according to disclosures made by Vanke on the Hong Kong stock exchange on Friday.

site_title: Lawmakers propose 'latte levy' to cut coffee cup waste
summary: UK lawmakers propose a 25-pence charge on disposable coffee cups to encourage recycling and reduce waste. The latte levy would fund recycling facilities nationwide, with a goal to recycle all cups by 2023. If the goal is not met, the cups would be banned. The UK uses 30,000 tons of coffee cup waste annually, with only 0.25% being recycled due to plastic linings. The proposal aims to increase consumer responsiveness to charges over discounts for reusable cups.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.34 points to 1,804.79. Volume was 94.28 million lots worth RM28.5 million, with 169 gainers and 44 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong asset manager Value Partners ends stake sale talks with HNA: sources
summary: Hong Kong asset manager Value Partners Group Ltd has ended talks with Chinese conglomerate HNA Group to sell a stake in the company, according to sources. The talks were initiated by two of Value Partners' top shareholders, chairman Cheng Hye Cheah and Yeh V-Nee, who were looking to sell a combined 19.2% stake valued at around $385 million. The termination of talks comes amid pressure on HNA's finances due to scrutiny of its opaque ownership and use of leverage. Value Partners cited "solely commercial consideration" as the reason for the deal's collapse.

site_title: China stats bureau says final 2016 GDP at 74.36t yuan
summary: China's final 2016 gross domestic product (GDP) was reported at 74.36 trillion yuan, down 54.2 billion yuan from the initial figure. The annual growth rate remained at 6.7% unchanged. This data follows a series of economic indicators suggesting China's GDP growth may be slowing, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Quicksilver owner to acquire Billabong in major sportswear merger
summary: US company Boardriders, owner of Quicksilver, has signed an agreement to acquire Australian rival Billabong in a major sportswear merger. The deal will create the world's leading action sports company, combining 630 retail stores in 28 countries and over 7,000 retail customers in 110 countries. Boardriders will buy the remaining shares of Billabong at A$1 per share, a 28% premium over the stock price. The acquisition is expected to enhance Billabong's brands' authenticity and heritage with the scale and financial security of a larger organization.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with fresh rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with a 0.51% rise, adding 157.38 points to the Hang Seng Index, following a fresh record in European and US markets. Energy firms continued their gains, but the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The rally came despite US tariff threats, with traders brushing off concerns to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Wi-Fi but no water: Can smart tech help a city's poor?
summary: In Barcelona, Spain, high-tech solutions have improved daily life for residents. Sensors detect when garbage trucks need to empty bins, reducing waste collection frequency. Magnetic sensors also help drivers find parking spaces, cutting emissions. Other innovations include smart street lamps, traffic lights, and parking meters. These technologies demonstrate the potential for smart tech to enhance urban living, particularly for low-income residents, by streamlining services and reducing waste.

site_title: GoPro cuts 200-300 jobs in aerial products unit: TechCrunch
summary: GoPro Inc is cutting 200-300 jobs in its aerial products division as part of a restructuring effort. The job cuts, which affect employees, will continue to be on the company's payroll until February 16. The move comes as the company struggles with cheaper rivals and smartphones featuring advanced cameras. GoPro has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally stumbles after recent surges
summary: Asian markets experienced a rally that stuttered on Friday, with investors taking profits after recent surges. The rally was boosted by a forecast-smashing reading on private take-ups and US tax cuts, but was hindered by US tariff threats. Key US jobs data is expected later in the day, which may influence market sentiment.

site_title: Australia shares finish higher; NZ hits another record
summary: Australian shares finished higher on Friday, hitting a fresh decade-peak and closing 0.7% higher at 6,122.3. Financials and material stocks outperformed other sectors on the S&P/ASX 200 index, with the benchmark closing slightly up in the previous session, marking its first weekly session of gains in the new year.

site_title: Starfish eating Australia's Great Barrier Reef alarm scientists
summary: A major outbreak of coral-eating crown of thorns starfish has been found on Australia's Great Barrier Reef, prompting the government to begin culling the spiky marine animals. The outbreak, discovered in the Swains Reefs, is the fourth major outbreak since the 1960s, and scientists warn that "a lot of coral will be lost." The reef is still recovering from two consecutive years of major coral bleaching, and the tourism industry that supports it is also at risk. The government will mount another mission to cull the starfish this month.

site_title: China's baby-formula revamp may trigger boom for Nestle, Danone
summary: China's new regulations on baby formula have led to the removal of 1,400 products from store shelves, clearing the way for international brands like Nestle and Danone to capture a larger share of the US$20 billion market. The regulations require factories to register products with the Food and Drug Administration and pass safety inspections, limiting products to three brands each. The move aims to improve the quality of life for Chinese citizens, following a 2008 scandal and recent incidents of fake formula. As a result, foreign brands are poised to capitalize on the market, with Nestle and Danone targeting parents in China's secondary cities and countryside.

site_title: Bombshell book to publish early despite Trump's blocking attempt
summary: US President Donald Trump attempted to block the publication of "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House" by author Michael Wolff, which quotes key aides expressing doubt about his fitness for office. The publishers responded by moving the book's release date up by four days to Friday, despite Trump's lawyers' efforts to prevent its release. The book's early publication is seen as a significant development in the ongoing scandal surrounding Trump's presidency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks extend gains at open after hitting a 26-year high the previous day
summary: Tokyo stocks continued their upward trend, extending gains after hitting a 26-year high on Thursday. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.46% to 23,614.99, while the Topix index opened up 0.46% to 1,872.44. This follows a record-setting advance on Wall Street. The recent gains are attributed to a rally in Asian markets despite US trade tensions, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Broker's take: Jefferies upgrades CDL to 'buy' on property market upswing
summary: Jefferies analysts have upgraded City Developments Limited (CDL) to a "buy" rating with a price target of S$14.8, citing an upswing in the property market and the growth of CDL's land bank. The analysts expect S$200 million of profit from two recent residential projects and anticipate benefits from upcoming project launches. However, they maintain a cautious view on CDL's hotel division and UK operations, citing Brexit-related risks and concerns over increased room supply and changing market dynamics.

site_title: Memories Group begins trading on SGX at S$0.285 after reverse takeover of SHC
summary: Memories Group, a spin-off of Yoma Strategic Holdings, began trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at 28.5 Singapore cents after completing a reverse takeover of SHC Capital Asia. The company raised 50 million shares through a placement at 25 cents each, with Yoma controlling a 47.6% stake. Memories Group plans to expand its tourism-related businesses and develop new tourist destinations, with chairman Serge Pun stating that the listing will enhance shareholder value. The company's market cap is approximately S$88 million.

site_title: China lifts blizzard alert but forecasts second round of snow
summary: China lifted a blizzard alert on Friday, with fewer areas expected to face heavy snow, but warned of a second wave of snow and sleet in parts of the country. Record snowfall since Wednesday has paralyzed parts of China, with at least one death reported in Anhui province. The National Meteorological Center forecasts light to moderate snowfall across the north, with heavy snow in some areas and sleet in others. The blizzard alert was lifted, but authorities have warned of further disruptions.

site_title: CapitaLand to sell 20 malls in China for 8.37b yuan
summary: CapitaLand is selling 20 retail malls in China for 8.37 billion yuan (about S$1.71 billion) to unrelated parties. The malls, located in 19 cities, including 14 non-core cities, will be sold for US$881.1 million in equity and US$220.4 million in outstanding shareholder loans. The transaction is expected to generate net proceeds of about S$660 million and a net gain of about S$75 million, with the loss of recurring income limited to 4% and 7% of CapitaLand's respective total and China shopping mall portfolio valuation.

site_title: BOJ's 2% inflation target unrealistic in 2018: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse's chief Japan economist Hiromichi Shirakawa says the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target is unrealistic, citing a cyclical recovery without structural change. Japan's economy is benefiting from global demand, but labor productivity and consumption are not improving, and savings rates remain high. The central bank is likely to have already given up on achieving 2% inflation and is considering normalizing monetary policy. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda disagrees, citing a persistent deflationary mindset, and maintains the quantitative easing program.

images.alt_text: While the Bank of Japan (BOJ) resolutely maintains its 2 per cent inflation target, Credit Suisse Group AG says that's an unrealistic goal.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound, won firms slightly
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 13.16 points, or 0.53%, to 2,479.62 on Friday. The won edged up, and bond yields rose, reversing a decline caused by heavy profit-taking by local institutions. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index also rose 0.40%, while Japanese stocks gained 0.31%. The Kospi is flat so far this year, and foreigners were net buyers of 1,032 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, retreating 1.82 points, or 0.1%, to 3,499.34. This follows a rally on Wall Street, where the Dow ended above 25,000 for the first time, amid optimism on the US economy. Despite this, about 48.5 million shares worth S$61.9 million changed hands on the Singapore bourse, with gainers outnumbering losers 79 to 46.

site_title: Trump seeks to open most US coastal waters to new drilling
summary: The Trump administration proposes opening nearly all US coastal waters to oil drilling, including areas off California and Florida, in a move that could lead to 47 possible auctions of drilling rights in over 90% of the US outer continental shelf. The plan, which goes beyond the president's April order, aims to expand domestic energy development and produce enough energy to meet US needs at home and export enough to lead the world. Environmentalists and coastal residents oppose the move, citing risks of oil spills and harm to marine life, and have urged the administration to reconsider.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration is proposing to open almost all US coastal waters to oil drilling, including those off California and Florida where activists have fought for decades to spare delicate ecosystems from oil spills.

site_title: GLP gets nod to issue onshore Belt and Road bonds in China
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has received approval from China's China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) to issue up to 12 billion yuan (S$2.45 billion) of Belt and Road (B&R) bonds on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange. The funds will be used to repay existing debt from the purchase of logistics assets in Europe. GLP's Chinese arm, GLP China, has an AAA credit rating and plans to issue the B&R bonds in multiple tranches. This marks the first time a company has issued onshore B&R bonds in China.

site_title: Call to stagger GST hike; or lower registration threshold for companies: Deloitte (Singapore Budget 2018)
summary: Two professional services firms, Deloitte and EY, have recommended that Singapore consider a phased increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to minimize its impact on households. Deloitte also suggested exempting basic necessities like children's clothing and certain prescription medicines from GST. Alternatively, the government could reduce the GST registration threshold for companies, currently set at S$1 million. The firms also suggested simplifying the tax system for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to reduce compliance costs.

site_title: US: Dow hits 25,000 points for first time on hiring data
summary: The US stock market hit 25,000 points for the first time, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 25,045.86, up 0.5% from Wednesday's close. Strong private-sector hiring data and better-than-expected economic data reinforced confidence in a strengthening global market, with analysts predicting continued momentum for equities. However, some forecasters anticipate greater volatility and potential risks from the Trump administration's trade policies.

site_title: Shareholders in Brazil demand Petrobras match US$3b US settlement
summary: Brazilian shareholders of state-controlled Petroleo Brasileiro SA are petitioning a Brazilian court to be paid on similar terms as US shareholders in a $2.95 billion US settlement. The settlement, reached over a bribery scheme, was agreed upon by Petrobras despite denying any wrongdoing. Petrobras is now being asked to pay proportional values to Brazilian shareholders, as the same facts and defendants apply regardless of jurisdiction.

site_title: Ascott lands contract to manage nine more properties in China
summary: Ascott has signed contracts to manage nine properties with over 2,000 units in China, doubling its units added in 2016 and exceeding its target of 20,000 units for China in 2017. This marks a record year for Ascott in China, with over 5,600 units across 28 properties. The new properties will start operations in stages from this year through 2023, expanding Ascott's portfolio in cities including Harbin and Zhuhai.

site_title: North Korea accepts talks offer from South Korea, meeting to be held Jan 9
summary: North Korea has accepted South Korea's offer for talks, set to take place on January 9. The agenda will include the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics and other mutual interests. This marks a significant development in relations between the two countries, following a series of high-profile diplomatic events in recent years. The talks are seen as a step towards improving ties and potentially easing tensions on the Korean Peninsula.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, SembMarine, Sunpower Group
summary: CapitaLand divested its interest in 20 Chinese retail malls for S$1.71 billion, generating S$660 million in net proceeds and a S$75 million net gain. SembMarine's Jurong Shipyard was fined S$230,000 for poor equipment maintenance resulting in two worker deaths in 2011.

site_title: Euro near 3-yr high vs sagging dollar, better risk appetite weighs on yen
summary: The euro hovered near a three-year high against the dollar, reaching US$1.2069, driven by narrowing US-euro zone debt yield spreads and improving investor risk appetite. This marks a 0.6% gain for the euro so far this week, with a rise above US$1.2092 taking it to its highest level since January 2015. The yen, on the other hand, was weighed down by the better risk appetite.

site_title: Bubbly HK housing is unsustainable, US$2.6b fund says
summary: Hong Kong's home prices are considered unsustainable and may not be sustained, according to SC Capital Partners, a US$2.6 billion real estate private equity firm. Despite cooling measures, investors continue to buy properties that "violate" investing fundamentals. The city's chief executive Carrie Lam said government measures haven't worked, while billionaire Li Ka-shing said demand remains strong for property. SC Capital Partners attributes the issue to demand from mainland Chinese buyers and expects rising interest rates to hit property prices.

site_title: Guns N' Roses reunion becomes fourth biggest tour ever
summary: Guns N' Roses' reunion tour has become the fourth highest-earning tour in history, grossing $475 million. The "Not in This Lifetime" tour surpassed Roger Waters' 2010-13 "The Wall Live" tour, with U2 holding the record at $784 million. The band, which reunited in 2016 after years of internal friction, has reached 4.3 million fans worldwide. A fresh European leg is scheduled to close on July 21 in Sweden, with the tour excluding rhythm guitarist Izzy Stradlin, who refused to participate due to concerns about unequal earnings.

site_title: Japan's historic Tsukiji market holds final auction
summary: Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo held its last pre-dawn auction on January 5, 2018, with a giant tuna selling for over $320,000. The market, in operation since 1935, is relocating to Toyosu on October 11 due to concerns over earthquake resistance, sanitation, and fire safety. The move was originally slated for 2016 but faced opposition from businesses and was delayed. Despite the challenges, the market's representative vowed to continue the "Tsukiji brand" at the new site, with the goal of establishing a new brand.

site_title: Starry-Eyed
summary: Christian Dior's artistic director Maria Grazia Chiuri pays homage to the late designer's astrological connections by featuring stars in her Resort 2018 collection, titled "Stars." The collection includes clutches, wallets, and accessories with Dior's lucky stars, reflecting the brand's continued tribute to Christian Dior's superstitious beliefs.

site_title: 'Bomb cyclone' hits US East Coast energy, power supply
summary: A severe winter storm, classified as a "bomb cyclone," has disrupted energy and power supply on the US East Coast, causing widespread electricity outages for over 80,000 homes and businesses. The storm has frozen pipes and disrupted refineries, leading to higher fuel prices and a potential heating oil shortage. Natural gas demand remains near record highs, and utilities in the Southeast have restored power to some affected customers. The region's reliance on heating oil is highest, with over 21% of households using oil for space heating, and concerns remain about fuel availability and emissions limits throughout the cold spell.

site_title: Gold steadies with rate rises in focus; palladium at record high
summary: Gold steadied around a 3-1/2-month high on Thursday as prospects for further US interest rate increases limited its rally. Spot gold rose 0.5% to $1,319.27 per ounce, while palladium reached a record high of $1,105.70 per ounce due to tight supplies. Analysts doubt the Fed's plan for future rate hikes, making gold an attractive investment option, and expect it to trade between $1,200 and $1,300 over the next six months.

site_title: US Fed members divided over rate hikes in 2018
summary: US Federal Reserve members are divided on the pace of interest rate hikes in 2018, with some arguing that three rate increases are too fast and others believe they should be "somewhat faster" to address low inflation. The disagreement centers on whether inflation has remained below the 2% target due to temporary or more enduring factors. The Fed has forecast three rate hikes in 2018 and one in 2019, but policymakers' views are conflicting, with some warning of potential financial instability.

site_title: The role and challenges of the non-executive board chair
summary: A non-executive board chair, unlike the CEO, holds immense influence behind the scenes. They set the agenda, influence board discussions, and shape the board's composition to ensure long-term company success. However, this position comes with significant challenges, including interacting with controlling shareholders, leading a diverse board, and establishing productive relationships with the CEO and executives. Effective communication and a willingness to lead by example are key to overcoming these challenges and making a difference as a board chair.

site_title: Coral reefs are starving; by 2050 they'll have nowhere to hide
summary: Coral reefs are facing unprecedented threats due to human activity, with rising water temperatures accelerating bleaching events. A study of 100 reefs worldwide found that coral will experience bleaching every 6 years, up from every 27 years in the 1980s. By 2050, reefs may bleach every hot summer due to climate change, with 31% of reefs at risk of bleaching in 2016, up from 4% in the 1980s. The study warns that a 1.5-2 degree Celsius warming above pre-industrial conditions will contribute to further reef degradation.

site_title: Nintendo shares up 5% on expectations of Pokemon Go launch in China
summary: Nintendo shares rose 5% on expectations of a Pokémon Go release in China, the world's largest gaming market. Niantic Inc, the game's developer, plans to bring existing games into China, with a potential partnership with local company NetEase Inc. A release in China would boost revenue and benefit shareholders. However, there are hurdles to overcome, including government registration and data supply issues. Nintendo declined to comment on a possible release date, while China's gaming market was valued at $32.5 billion in 2017.

site_title: Gross Imaginary Product is no fantasy
summary: The Gross Imaginary Product (GIP) has exploded globally, particularly in regions with low real interest rates. GIP includes imaginary assets like cryptocurrencies, zombie companies in Silicon Valley, and excessively valued stocks. In the US, GIP is estimated to be around $1.3 trillion, or 7% of GDP, and is expected to reach the entire economy by 2033. The phenomenon is also prevalent in Japan, Europe, and other countries with "funny money" policies. This surge in GIP poses significant economic challenges, including obscuring true economics and creating unrealistic expectations.

site_title: Dow powers above 25,000 pts for first time
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassed 25,000 points for the first time on January 4, 2018, driven by a strong private jobs report and robust economic growth indications. The ADP National Employment Report showed a 250,000 job increase in December, exceeding economists' forecasts. This marks a bullish sentiment, contributing to new highs for other major indexes.

site_title: Zuckerberg makes 'fixing' Facebook a personal goal
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has set a personal goal for 2018 to "fix" Facebook, citing the social network's struggles with abuse, hate, and interference by nation states. The goal aims to make Facebook a more positive and trustworthy platform. Zuckerberg plans to gather experts to address issues such as politics, media, and technology, and will explore the use of encryption and digital currency to decentralize power. He acknowledges the challenges, stating that Facebook cannot prevent all mistakes or abuse, but aims to improve its policies and tools to reduce errors.

site_title: Had a great profit quarter? Let's fu pan it!
summary: A strategic concept called "fu pan" is a holistic reflection process that helps organizations maximize success by examining both successes and failures. The process involves four steps: clearly stating the original goal and results, articulating highlights and lowlights, identifying root causes, and evaluating actions. Fu pan can be applied to any process, from campaign strategies to personal life, and is most effective when practiced continuously as a discipline. By examining success as well as failure, organizations can learn from their experiences and repeat successes, rather than attributing them to fate or chance.

site_title: Indian delegation here to mark 25 years of India-Asean ties
summary: A high-level Indian delegation, including Minister of External Affairs Sushma Swaraj and Assam Chief Minister Sarbananda Sonowal, is in Singapore to celebrate 25 years of dialogue partnership between India and the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean). The delegation attends the Asean-India Pravasi Bharatiya Divas (Overseas Indian Day) convention and the India-Singapore/Asean Entrepreneurship Bridge (InSpreneur) event. Singapore is also sending a prominent delegation led by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean, with all 10 Asean leaders expected to attend a special commemorative summit in New Delhi on January 25.

site_title: Kia Stinger 2.0 review: Korea's answer to BMW
summary: The Kia Stinger 2.0 is a roomy and practical car offering a great driving experience for S$166,999. It strikes a balance between youth and maturity, providing an exciting ride without being expensive. The Kia Stinger is a competitor to BMW, offering a similar experience at a lower price point. The article suggests that the car's attributes make it an attractive option for those seeking a premium driving experience without breaking the bank.

site_title: China regulators set new rules on bond trading: sources
summary: China's financial regulators have published new rules to regulate bond trading, focusing on restricting leverage and banning under-the-table deals. The rules, jointly issued by the People's Bank of China and other regulators, require institutions to sign written deals for bond repurchase and forward transactions. The move aims to prevent a repeat of the 2016 US$2.4 billion bond scandal and restrict leverage by setting caps on repo transactions. Financial institutions must report financial data to regulators if their outstanding volumes exceed certain limits, effective in reducing the practice of "Daichi", a popular method to keep leverage boosts off regulatory radar.

site_title: Europe: UK's FTSE touches record high but lags global equity rally
summary: The UK's FTSE 100 index reached an all-time high of 7,702.11 points on Thursday, driven by a rise in oil majors such as BP and Shell, which rose 1.1% and 1% respectively. The index closed 0.3% higher at 7,696.50, despite retailers like Debenhams falling 17.7% after a profit warning and the real estate sector suffering due to slowing house prices. A rally in cyclical sectors and positive metals prices also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Bursting of bitcoin bubble gives timely boost to gold
summary: Gold prices have surged 6% since mid-December, reaching US$1,312 an ounce, as investors seek safer assets amid the bursting of the bitcoin bubble. Despite a relatively flat trading range of US$1,200 to US$1,350, analysts expect gold to break out if physical purchases increase, driven by investor psychology and geopolitical events. Central bank policies, including monetary expansion and interest rate rises, also influence gold prices. Experts diverge on gold's future performance, with some predicting a rise to US$1,400 by year-end and others cautioning against price volatility.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research forecasts Asia equities to deliver 5-15% gains in 2018, driven by a global recovery. This reiterates the key driver of earnings and valuation re-rating in Asian markets in 2017.

site_title: Expectations of strong earnings power STI past 3,500 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) has reached 3,501.16 points, surpassing the 3,500-point mark for the first time since April 2015 and 2007. The market's optimism stems from higher corporate earnings, with local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC driving the rally. The banks' price-to-book multiples have risen, and their digital strategies are expected to boost profitability. Industrial and tech firms are also seeing increased demand, with energy and tech stocks leading regional market rallies.

site_title: River of life
summary: Local artist Melissa Tan, known as Paintinks, has contributed a heritage-themed drawing of Noah's Ark floating down the Singapore River to BTWeekend's monthly colouring series. The artwork, which blends Tan's love for animals and the city's past, is part of the series that invites local artists to share their original creations. Tan, a full-time behavioural therapist, often runs along the Singapore River, appreciating its unique blend of old and new. Her artwork showcases the river's beauty and significance to the local community.

site_title: UK new car sales record biggest drop since 2009
summary: British new car sales plummeted by 5% in 2017, the largest drop since 2009, due to uncertainty over potential new diesel charges and weakening consumer confidence since Brexit. Registrations fell to 2.54 million vehicles and are expected to decline by up to 7% this year. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) attributes the decline to consumer hold-off on diesel cars, pushing up average CO2 emissions, and business-led uncertainty over Brexit. The automotive sector is concerned about tariffs and customs delays if the government fails to strike the right Brexit deal.

images.alt_text: British new car sales recorded their biggest drop since 2009 last year, falling by more than 5 per cent due to uncertainty over potential new diesel charges and weakening consumer confidence since Brexit, an industry body said on Friday.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Straits Trading Company is investing in a Japanese real estate fund, Savills IM Japan Residential Fund, through its indirect subsidiary SRE Japan 11 Pte Ltd. The fund will acquire residential properties in the Greater Tokyo area and other key markets. This investment aligns with Straits Trading's previously stated strategy of investing in the real estate sector.

site_title: 'Pre-election malaise' holding back Malaysian stocks
summary: Malaysia's stock market, led by the FBM KLCI index, underperformed its Asian peers in 2017, with a 9.5% gain despite a strong global economy and recovering currency. The index's poor performance is attributed to "pre-election malaise" or fear, similar to the 2013 General Election, where the stock market declined before a relief rally after the election. With the 2018 election expected in March or April, investors are cautious, despite the country's projected 5.2-5.7% economic growth and strong external front.

site_title: Allianz plans to double Asian property investments over 3 years
summary: Allianz plans to double its Asian property investments over the next three years, with a potential increase to 3.75 billion euros (S$6 billion) by 2020. The growth is driven by the firm's insurance operations in the region, which are accumulating funds to be channeled into property investments. Logistics is a favored sector due to Asia's fast growth in e-commerce, with opportunities in China, Japan, India, and other countries. The firm aims to focus on offices, logistics, and other sectors, and is exploring new markets and investment strategies.

site_title: Quest for new oil finds still on back burner
summary: Global oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell, are expected to cut spending on exploration for a fifth consecutive year in 2018, with investment reaching $37 billion. Despite a growing need to replenish reserves, companies prioritize capital discipline, citing a modest uptick in drilling activity as they focus on well-charted basins. Exploration success rates have dropped to 35% over the past decade, highlighting the importance of acquisitions. Oil majors are expected to continue making acquisitions, with a focus on deepwater basins in Mexico, Brazil, and Guyana.

site_title: US braces for 'bomb cyclone', heavy snow expected
summary: A rare "bomb cyclone" or "bombogenesis" winter storm hit the US Southeast on Wednesday, dumping snow on Florida's capital for the first time in three decades. The storm, forecast to bring heavy snow to New England on Thursday, prompted governors of Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia to declare states of emergency. The storm's rapid pressure drop is expected to bring significant snowfall, disrupting travel in the affected areas.

site_title: Wackiness In A Box
summary: "Weird Al" Yankovic has released a 15-CD box set called Squeeze Box, featuring 14 studio albums and rare tracks. The collection spans 30 years and showcases Yankovic's continued sense of fun and creativity, evident in songs like Word Crimes and Tacky. The limited edition box set is available on pledge music.com.

site_title: Made in China: new, potentially lifesaving drugs
summary: China is developing innovative, potentially lifesaving drugs, including a cancer treatment that stops the spread of cancer to other organs and a blood cancer treatment. A third drug utilizes the immune system to kill tumors, with encouraging results and needing only US approval. These breakthroughs were created in China, marking a significant push for the country to play a larger role in the global pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: India seeks approval to issue 800b rupees bank recap bonds
summary: India's finance ministry seeks parliamentary approval to issue approximately $16.8 billion in bank recapitalization bonds, with plans to sell the bonds by March 31. The recapitalization plan aims to inject capital into state-controlled lenders weighed down by soured loans. The bonds will carry an annual interest of over 60 billion rupees. The move is expected to boost shares of Indian state banks, which have been impacted by low loan growth. The government hopes to bolster loan growth and address stressed assets, a move seen as a step forward in resolving bad debt.

site_title: Home Away From Home
summary: In Tokyo, living like a local through Airbnb experiences can be a unique and immersive way to explore the city, but it requires a hands-on approach. Guests must navigate the DIY lifestyle, managing tasks such as resetting gas meters, finding local amenities, and interacting with hosts and local experts. While it can be challenging, the experiences can be rewarding, offering a glimpse into local culture and daily life. From sake tastings to Taiko drumming sessions, guests can discover the authentic side of Tokyo, and connections made with locals can last long after the trip ends.
