site_title: MAS chief named best central bank governor in Asia-Pacific
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon has been named the best central bank governor in Asia-Pacific in 2018 by UK-based magazine The Banker. The magazine praised the Monetary Authority of Singapore for its "cutting-edge" regulatory approach to fintech while maintaining macroeconomic stability. Menon's approach includes setting up a dedicated fintech group and data analytics team to understand technology's risks and benefits, and has led to the MAS publishing cloud computing guidelines and aiming for "zero duplication" in data requests. This marks Menon's second top honor, following Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's award in 2011.

site_title: May apologises as overwhelmed hospitals cancel non-emergency operations
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May apologized to tens of thousands of patients whose non-emergency operations were cancelled due to hospital staff and bed shortages. The cancellations were recommended to free up resources to deal with emergency patients amid a flu outbreak, colder weather, and high respiratory illnesses. May acknowledged the frustration and disappointment caused by the cancellations, which have put pressure on the National Health Service (NHS) and raised concerns about funding.

site_title: The best airports are both well-managed and pro-business
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport Group successfully opened its fourth terminal, Terminal 4, on schedule and within budget in October 2017. The airport has consistently delivered on its ambitious vision to become a global air hub, with a capacity of 60 million passengers per annum (mppa) and serving over 380 cities connected by 100 airlines. Key factors contributing to its success include strong government support, effective development strategies, and a highly motivated and innovative leadership team. With plans to expand capacity to 132 mppa by 2050, Changi Airport remains committed to upholding its mission as a global air hub.

site_title: Toronto home sales fall 18.3% in 2017 from record level
summary: Toronto home sales dropped 18.3% in 2017, the largest decline since 1997, as provincial government measures to cool the housing market took effect. The measures, including a foreign buyers tax, restrained demand, but tight supply boosted the average price. Detached homes saw a 23% decline, while condo sales fell 9.6%. Despite the decline in sales, the average selling price increased 12.7% to C$822,681.

site_title: US private sector adds 250,000 jobs in Dec, biggest rise since March
summary: US private employers added 250,000 jobs in December, the largest monthly increase since March, according to a report by ADP Research Institute. This surpasses economists' forecasts of 190,000 jobs, with estimates ranging from 165,000 to 225,000. The report precedes the US Labor Department's more comprehensive non-farm payrolls report, which is expected to show a similar increase. The unemployment rate is forecast to remain at 4.1%.

site_title: India probes report on breach of national identity database
summary: India has begun investigating a report that access to its Aadhaar database, containing 1 billion citizens' identity details, was being sold for $8 on social media. The Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI) confirmed the breach and initiated a police complaint against those responsible. Despite assurances that biometric data is secure, the incident highlights concerns over data safety and privacy. The breach is the latest in a program facing scrutiny over privacy concerns, with India's Supreme Court set to decide on the mandatory linking of Aadhaar to services.

site_title: Pavillon withdraws from China joint venture
summary: Pavillon Holdings is withdrawing from a joint venture in China, Fengchi Technology Co, by transferring its 30% stake to Tianjin Yinxing Environmental Protection Technology Co. This move will allow Pavillon to reallocate resources to other businesses in China, where Fengchi has yet to commence operations. The company did not specify the reasons for the withdrawal.

site_title: Volvo cars race to record sales in 2017
summary: Volvo Cars achieved record sales for the fourth consecutive year in 2017, with 571,577 cars sold worldwide, a 7% increase from 2016. Growth was driven by Asia Pacific, with a 20.9% increase, and China, where sales rose 25.8%. The company attributed its success to the 90-series cars and XC60 model. Volvo announced plans to launch only electric or hybrid models from 2019, marking a "historic end" to combustion engine vehicles. The company has seen a strong recovery since its acquisition by Geely in 2010.

site_title: Samsung overtakes Intel as world's biggest chip maker
summary: Samsung has overtaken Intel as the world's biggest maker of semi-conductors, according to a study by Gartner. In 2017, Samsung's sales grew 52.6% to $61.2 billion, surpassing Intel's 6.7% growth to $57.7 billion. The global semi-conductor market grew 22% to $419.7 billion, driven by booming demand for memory chips, which accounted for over two-thirds of all semiconductor revenue growth. Samsung's market share rose to 14.6%, while Intel's fell to 13.8%.

site_title: Critical hardware flaws put almost every smartphone, computer at risk: SingCert
summary: A critical hardware flaw, Meltdown, affects Intel-based computers, while Spectre affects AMD and ARM processors, putting billions of smartphones and computers worldwide at risk. The vulnerabilities allow hackers to steal data, including confidential information, and compromise entire server networks. Security fixes are being rolled out, and major companies like Google, Amazon, and Microsoft have issued patches for their cloud services and devices. Users are urged to apply the fixes immediately to prevent data theft and exploitation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.66 points to 1,803.45. Volume reached 5 billion lots worth RM3.3 billion, with gainers more than doubling losers.

site_title: Winter storm threatens US East Coast energy industry
summary: A winter storm is threatening the US East Coast energy industry with heavy snowfall and high winds, potentially disrupting refineries and power plants. The storm, known as a bomb cyclone, has caused power outages, icing over roadways, and closed hundreds of schools. Heating oil prices have reached their highest levels in years, with inventories at their lowest levels since 2015, sparking fears of a shortage. The US Coast Guard has deployed ice-breaking ships to help keep trade traffic moving, but delays are expected.

site_title: Olam CEO joins board committee on sustainability
summary: Olam International CEO Sunny Verghese has joined the corporate responsibility and sustainability committee, replacing COO Shekhar Anantharaman. Verghese will also join the capital and investment committee, while Anantharaman will join the board risk committee, effective January 4.

site_title: Great place if you enjoy your drinks
summary: Ma Cuisine, a French gastro-bar, offers hearty comfort food, but its wine-centric concept may alienate non-drinkers. The restaurant's menu is designed around wine pairings, and the chef's attention to detail is evident in dishes like bread, snails, and lamb shoulder. However, the pressure to order wine can be overwhelming, and some dishes, such as seared scallops, are overcooked. The restaurant's pricing can also be steep, with some main courses reaching S$120 for two people. Overall, the food is rich and satisfying, but the wine-centric concept may deter some diners. Rating: 6.5/10.

site_title: Perennial prices S$120m fixed rate notes due 2021
summary: Perennial Real Estate has launched and priced S$120 million in fixed-rate notes due 2021, with a 3.9% per annum interest rate. The notes will be issued on January 12, 2018, and the net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing existing borrowings and financing working capital. The notes are part of Perennial's S$2 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Stagger GST hike, remove tax on basic necessities to cushion impact, says Deloitte
summary: Deloitte recommends that Singapore's Goods and Services Tax (GST) be phased in gradually to minimize its impact on households. The firm suggests exempting basic necessities such as children's clothing, foodstuffs, and certain prescription medicines from GST. Alternatively, reducing the GST registration threshold for companies could also help ease the financial burden on small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Europe: Equities rise at open, London nears record
summary: Europe's major stock markets rose at open on Thursday, with London nears a record high. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.3% to 7,696.62 points, while Paris' CAC 40 added 0.5% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.7%. The rally follows a strong Asian market performance, driven by soaring oil prices.

site_title: Clearbridge Health unit to buy stake in Philippine medical centre operator
summary: Clearbridge Health, a medtech investor, will acquire a 65% stake in Marzan Health Care Inc, a Philippine medical centre operator, for 69.6 million pesos (S$1.9 million). The deal is part of Clearbridge Health's growth plans to expand its network of medical clinics in the region. Marzan Health Care has the required licences to provide a wide range of medical services in the Philippines, and the acquisition is expected to accelerate the group's expansion into the country.

site_title: Acra instructs Oriental Group to hold AGM, prepare financial statements
summary: Acra instructs Oriental Group to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) and prepare financial statements by February 28, 2018. The judicial manager stated that the company received the directive and has been given a deadline to present its financial statements up to December 31, 2016.

site_title: Sunpower Group wins 34.98m yuan contract, its first in flue gas desulphurisation market
summary: Sunpower Group's wholly owned subsidiary Jiangsu Sunpower Technology Co has won its first contract in the flue gas desulphurisation market, worth 34.98 million yuan (S$7.2 million). The project will use ammonia desulphurisation technology, owned by the group, and is expected to positively impact the company's 2018 financial year results. Chairman Guo Hongxin stated that the contract win showcases the group's technology capabilities in the smog governance industry, laying the groundwork for expansion into the growing flue gas desulphurisation business.

site_title: OCBC launches OneAdvisor Home, a one-stop portal for property purchases
summary: OCBC Bank has launched OneAdvisor Home, a one-stop portal providing comprehensive advice for first-time homebuyers and seasoned investors. The portal offers property listings, policy details, and affordability analysis, allowing customers to compute their budget and generate a shortlist based on their affordability price range. The service also includes a step-by-step guide to financing a new home, mortgage and home content insurance, and a mortgage specialist for a customised consultation. The portal aims to demystify the home buying process and provide seamless financing for customers, with future plans to expand its offerings.

site_title: Singapore shares surge past 3,500-point mark
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.1% to 3,501.16, marking its sixth consecutive day of gains. The index surpassed the 3,470 resistance level and is now targeting 3,549.85, a post-financial crisis high. About 2.63 billion shares worth S$2 billion changed hands, with gains outnumbering losses 272 to 163.

site_title: Straits Trading unit to invest in Japan real estate fund
summary: Straits Trading, a unit of the Straits Trading Company, announced it will invest in the Savills IM Japan Residential Fund, a limited partnership in Singapore, to acquire residential properties in Japan's Greater Tokyo area. The investment is part of Straits Trading's strategy to redeploy capital from its existing low-yielding properties into potentially higher return opportunities. The investment is not expected to impact the company's earnings per share or net tangible asset per share for the current financial year ending December 31, 2018.

site_title: Jurong Shipyard fined $230,000 for death of two workers due to poor equipment maintenance
summary: Jurong Shipyard, a unit of Sembcorp Marine, has been fined S$230,000 for the death of two workers due to poor equipment maintenance. The workers fell 30m into a dry dock on October 29, 2011, while working on an aerial platform that was not properly maintained. The fine was imposed under the Workplace Safety and Health Act for the company's failure to ensure the aerial platform was in safe condition. The incident occurred in 2011, and the fine was imposed nearly seven years later.

site_title: 4G ministers say they will settle on a leader "in good time"
summary: Singaporean ministers, including Education Minister Ong Ye Kung, Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, and Minister in the Prime Minister's Office Chan Chun Sing, are vying to become the country's fourth Prime Minister. Ong Ye Kung expressed his intention to pick a leader, but declined to name the person, citing a need for a consensus. The three ministers are among the top contenders, with no clear timeline for the selection process.

site_title: 66 property agency licences and 1,344 property agent registrations issued in 2017: CEA
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) in Singapore issued 66 new property agency licences and 1,344 new property agent registrations in 2017, resulting in a 0.6% increase in registered property agents to 28,571. The number of licensed property agencies decreased by 0.6% to 1,269, largely due to industry consolidation. Additionally, 44 property agency licences and 2,028 agent registrations lapsed after December 31, 2017.

site_title: North Korea keeps sneaking in oil with secret ship transfers
summary: North Korea is continuing to receive oil shipments despite international sanctions, using ship-to-ship transfers to obscure its origin and destination. The illicit fuel sales are facilitated by suppliers using an old oil-trading practice, making it difficult to track supplies. The practice, known as STS transfers, can be used to hide a ship's true identity and location. The US and South Korea are working to identify those involved, but the lack of transparency and complexity of the transactions make it challenging. Reports suggest that Chinese ships have been transferring fuel to North Korean vessels, which may deter perpetrators and prompt major oil trading companies to take additional precautions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Airlines to drop credit card fee for tickets issued in Singapore. Industrial site at Tuas Bay Close put up for sale. COE prices mixed in the first round of bidding in January. MAS chief Ravi Menon named best central bank governor in Asia-Pacific. Yang Kee Logistics completes S$52.1m acquisition of Fliway in New Zealand. HDB resale prices inch up 0.1% in December. Singapore shares surge past 3,500-point mark, closing 1.1% higher.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has decided not to introduce a credit card fee for tickets issued in Singapore.

site_title: Citic Envirotech acquires additional 15% stake in United Envirotech Water (Changyi)
summary: CITIC Envirotech (CEL) acquired an additional 15% stake in United Envirotech Water (Changyi) Co from an existing minority shareholder for 32.5 million yuan (S$6.6 million), resulting in CEL owning Changyi Co post-acquisition. Changyi Co operates five industrial wastewater treatment plants in Shandong province with a total design capacity of 200,000 cu m per day.

site_title: Yang Kee Logistics completes S$52.1m acquisition of New Zealand peer Fliway
summary: Yang Kee Logistics has completed the S$52.1 million acquisition of New Zealand listed company Fliway Group, expanding its presence in the Oceania region. The deal boosts Yang Kee's revenue by S$81.9 million, bringing its total revenue to over S$400 million. The acquisition, announced in October, marks Yang Kee's second major Oceania purchase and strengthens its global networks and supply chain capabilities.

site_title: Crashed Australia seaplane recovered as deadly history revealed
summary: A seaplane crashed into an Australian river on New Year's Eve, killing five British tourists and the pilot. The DHC-2 Beaver Seaplane was recovered with severe damage. Investigators found the plane had been involved in a fatal accident in 1996, and experts are examining the recovered parts. A preliminary report is due in 30 days, and a final report will be released within a year. The crash is being investigated by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau.

site_title: UK house prices will barely rise in 2018, Nationwide forecasts
summary: The UK house prices are forecast to rise only about 1% in 2018, significantly slower than the 2.6% increase in 2017, according to Nationwide Building Society. The slowdown is attributed to factors such as inflation and Brexit uncertainty, with London experiencing a 0.5% decline, marking its first annual decline in eight years.

site_title: COEs finish mixed in the first round of bidding in 2018
summary: In the first round of bidding in January 2018, Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices in Singapore showed mixed results. Category A cars saw a premium increase from $38,200 to $41,400, while Category B cars and open category COE prices decreased from $47,002 to $45,289 and $48,011 to $47,390 respectively. Motorcycle premiums rose from $7,501 to $7,701, and goods vehicle and bus COE premiums fell from $45,112 to $40,101.

site_title: Europe's biggest private biotech company raises US$270m
summary: BioNTech, Europe's largest privately held biotech company, has raised $270 million to support its development of personalized immunotherapies for cancer. The company has brought in $950 million since its founding in 2008 and plans to go public in the future due to the capital-intensive nature of its business. BioNTech's experimental cancer vaccine, tailored to individual patients, showed promising results in an early-stage clinical trial and is being tested with Roche's Tecentriq. The company has partnerships with major drugmakers and is working on various cancer-fighting technologies.

site_title: Apple battery fix may mean 16 million fewer new iPhones sold
summary: Apple's battery replacement offer for older iPhones may impact sales of new handsets, with Barclays analyst Mark Moskowitz estimating 16 million fewer iPhone upgrades in 2018. The offer, which costs $29, has been seen as a good public-relations move, but analysts worry it could dent future sales of iPhones, which account for two-thirds of Apple's revenue. The battery program is only in effect through the end of the year, but other factors, such as the release of new iPhone models, may still drive upgrades.

site_title: Australia shares end flat; NZ reaches another record high
summary: Australian shares ended flat at 0.1% gain, reaching a near-10-year high, driven by healthcare and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished at 6077.1, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high of 8,443.5, up 0.2%. Oil Search Ltd was the top gainer, and healthcare stocks led the gains in New Zealand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks take winning streak to eighth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their winning streak, advancing for the eighth consecutive day. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.57%, closing at 30,736.48, driven by gains in energy firms with oil prices surging. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased, adding 0.49% and 0.36%, respectively.

site_title: India seeks approval for 800 billion rupees bank recap bonds
summary: India's finance ministry seeks parliamentary approval to issue 800 billion rupees (S$16.7 billion) of bank recapitalization bonds by March 31, as part of plans to inject capital into state-controlled lenders. The bonds will carry annual interest of over 60 billion rupees. The move is expected to boost shares in Indian state banks and help resolve bad debts weighing down their balance sheets. This is part of a 2.11 trillion rupee capital infusion plan announced by the government in October to bolster loan growth and address stressed assets.

site_title: Nordic Group clinches contracts worth S$20.6 million
summary: Nordic Group has secured contracts worth approximately S$20.6 million from various customers, including multinational firms and companies in the marine, oil and gas, infrastructure, and petrochemical industries. The contracts include a three-year maintenance service contract worth S$10.8 million for petrochemical services, scaffolding and insulation capital projects worth S$6.7 million and S$1.7 million respectively, and system integration and precision engineering services contracts worth S$1.4 million and S$1.7 million.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes up 3.26% on first trading day of 2018
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 3.26% on the first trading day of 2018, closing at 23,506.33, driven by optimism over the US economy. This surge follows recent rallies on Wall Street. The broader Topix index also rose 2.55%. The gains were fueled by investor optimism, with the Nikkei index surpassing its 2017 closing high.

site_title: Indian pilots grounded after 'mid-air row'
summary: Indian airline Jet Airways grounded two pilots after a mid-air row on a New Year's Day flight from London to Mumbai. The incident allegedly involved a male pilot slapping a female colleague, leading her to leave the cockpit in tears. The male pilot also briefly left the cockpit, leaving the controls unattended. The flight continued safely, and the pilots have been derostered pending an internal investigation. The airline prioritizes safety and has zero tolerance for actions compromising it.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide, won erases losses
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.80% to 2,466.46, reversing earlier gains. The Korean won rose 0.22% against the US dollar, while Asian shares rose 0.29%. The benchmark index slumped on local profit-taking ahead of Samsung Electronics' earnings guidance. The won's high for the year is 1,060.35 per US dollar, while the Kospi is up 0.8% so far this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session on higher ground; STI at 3,472.7
summary: Singapore stocks rose on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,472.7, up 0.2% or 8.42 points, driven by a higher opening. The index gained 0.06% before the midday break. About 1.27 billion shares worth S$635.3 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 210 to 146.

site_title: Saudi Aramco seeking adviser for global gas acquisitions: sources
summary: Saudi Aramco is seeking a bank to advise on acquiring natural gas assets globally, with targets in the US, East Africa, and Russia. The company aims to meet soaring domestic demand for electricity, as it diverts crude oil to power plants. Aramco has also invited banks to pitch for a role in its planned initial public offering later this year. The move could be the world's biggest share sale, with the company planning to appoint a group of banks for the deal early this year.

site_title: Quest for new oil discoveries still on back burner
summary: Global oil companies are cutting spending on exploration for the fifth consecutive year in 2018, with a 7% decline in investment and a 60% drop from 2014 levels, according to Wood Mackenzie. Despite lower rig rates and a focused approach, drilling activity is expected to remain flat. The majors will focus on deepwater basins, such as Mexico, Brazil, and Guyana, where large discoveries have been made. Analysts predict a modest uptick in drilling activity, with the need for more merger and acquisition to build resources.

site_title: Gold prices drop on profit-taking, firmer US dollar
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,308.82 an ounce as investors took profits and the US dollar firmed, following a 3-1/2-month high on Wednesday. The Federal Reserve's December policy minutes bolstered expectations for more interest rate hikes, increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold. US factory activity increased more than expected, further supporting the dollar. Gold has rallied $85 from its 5-month lows, but analysts expect a pullback towards $1,290-$1,295 as a buying opportunity.

site_title: Nintendo jumps on expectations of Pokemon Go launch in China
summary: Nintendo rose 5% in Tokyo after expectations of a Pokémon Go release in China, the world's largest gaming market. Niantic's founder John Hanke confirmed plans to bring existing games to China, which could boost revenue and benefit Nintendo and shareholder NetEase. However, releasing Pokémon Go in China will require registration with the government and coordination with Google, whose services are blocked in the country. China's gaming market is worth $32.5 billion, making it a lucrative opportunity for Nintendo and Niantic.

site_title: AT&T plans to offer mobile 5G wireless phone service in US this year
summary: AT&T plans to launch mobile 5G wireless phone service in the US this year, becoming the first US carrier to do so. The company will offer faster connections in over a dozen US cities, enabling services like virtual reality and 4K video. AT&T has invested in network upgrades and fixed wireless trials to prepare for the rollout. However, challenges remain, including the estimated $200 billion annual research and capital expenses needed to develop 5G technology. AT&T has not disclosed its launch plans or details on airwaves and network equipment.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant apologises for baiting users into credit system
summary: Ant Financial, controlled by Alibaba founder Jack Ma, has apologized for automatically enrolling users in its Sesame Credit system without consent. The company initially rolled out a free service to generate a consumption profile, but users were unknowingly enrolled in the credit system. Ant Financial has changed the setting and acknowledged the move as "extremely idiotic." The incident highlights growing concerns over data transparency in China, where tech giants are increasingly using personal data to determine credit-worthiness.

images.alt_text: Ant Financial, the internet finance behemoth controlled by billionaire Alibaba founder Jack Ma, has apologised for roping unsuspecting users into its fledgling but fast-growing credit-score system.

site_title: Reserve list industrial site at Tuas Bay Close put up for sale
summary: JTC has accepted an application to put an industrial site at Tuas Bay Close on the reserve list for sale by public tender. The land parcel was put on the reserve list in July 2017, and a minimum acceptable bid of S$17.5 million has been received, triggering the release of the site for sale. Developers are now invited to submit a bid to acquire the site.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: EY calls on Budget 2018 to sharpen Singapore's global competitiveness, stagger any GST increases
summary: Accounting firm EY has released a wish-list for Singapore's Budget 2018, calling for measures to sharpen the country's competitiveness and attractiveness to global investors. The firm's Head of Tax Services, Chung-Sim Siew Moon, emphasized the need to build resilience and agility in businesses, workforce, and population to adapt to change and innovate in a fast-changing landscape. The focus should be on broad-based, progressive, and fair taxes. The budget should also consider the global tax environment, including Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) action plans and US reforms.

images.alt_text: Accounting and professional services firm EY in its Budget 2018 wish-list released on Thursday called on the Singapore government to take a two-pronged focus - sharpening the country's competitiveness and attractiveness to global investors and keeping taxes broad-based, progressive and fair.

site_title: World's most-valuable airport operator is now in Thailand
summary: Airports of Thailand surpassed Spain's Aena as the world's most-valuable airport services company, driven by a 75% gain since May 1 and a 23% surge in international tourists in November. The company's shares jumped 9.2% in December, reaching a market capitalization of over 1 trillion baht (S$41.05 billion), outperforming Shanghai International Airport.

site_title: Cate Blanchett to head Cannes festival jury
summary: Cate Blanchett, a double Oscar-winning actress, has been selected to head the jury at this year's Cannes Film Festival, set to take place on May 8. Blanchett, 48, is also a prominent figure in the #MeToo movement, having launched the "Time's Up" initiative. She becomes the 12th woman to lead the prestigious jury panel, following a statement from Cannes president Pierre Lescure and delegate general Thierry Fremaux expressing their welcome for the unique artist.

images.alt_text: Cate Blanchett, the double Oscar-winning actress leading a Hollywood campaign to tackle sexual harassment in the workplace, will head the jury at this year's Cannes Film Festival, organisers said on Thursday.

site_title: Tennis: Injured Murray out of Australian Open
summary: Former world number one Andy Murray withdrew from the Australian Open due to a hip injury, joining injured Japanese star Kei Nishikori on the sidelines. Murray, 30, has not played on the ATP tour since Wimbledon last year, citing that he is not yet ready to compete.

site_title: Online retailer JD follows Alibaba into the supermarket game
summary: JD.com Inc has launched its first high-tech supermarket, "7Fresh", in Beijing, marking its entry into traditional retail. The store features digital payments, mobile app integration, and a robot cart system. JD aims to compete with Alibaba Group's Hema chain by leveraging its supply chain technology and inventory control. The move is part of China's largest internet companies' strategy to transform retail by infusing technology into stores, with JD and Alibaba planning to connect online and offline shopping to boost online orders and customer data.

site_title: Philippine inflation seen steady in December, but pressure seen building
summary: Philippine consumer prices remained steady in December, increasing at the same annual pace as the previous month, holding the year's average within the 2-4% target range. Headline inflation was 3.3%, with the country's policy settings remaining steady since 2014. Despite this, economists expect price pressures to build up, potentially leading to policy action in the near term, particularly with tax reforms taking effect this month. The central bank expects average inflation to hit 3.4% this year, taking into account the "transitory" effects of tax hikes.

site_title: South Korea's Park 'took money from spy agency': reports
summary: South Korea's ousted President Park Geun Hye is to be charged with accepting millions of dollars in bribes from the National Intelligence Service, a state spy agency. She allegedly received between 50-200 million won (now $62,500-$250,000) per month from 2013 to 2016, totaling 3.8 billion won. Park is already on trial on 18 charges, including bribery, coercion, and abuse of power, and prosecutors will add a 19th count regarding the payments. Park has refused to cooperate with prosecutors and has been in custody since March 31.

images.alt_text: Ousted South Korean president Park Geun Hye is to be charged with accepting millions of dollars worth of bribes from the state spy agency, news reports said on Thursday.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Wanda Commercial Property to junk on offshore funding concerns
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Dalian Wanda Commercial Property to 'BB+' from 'BBB', citing concerns over the company's inability to access offshore funding channels. The downgrade was prompted by Wanda's lack of definitive funding channels to boost offshore liquidity, which could lead to repayment pressure. This marks the second downgrade since 2016, following previous downgrades by S&P and Moody's. Wanda's liquidity position may be under substantial pressure if it fails to meet demands from offshore lenders or raise sufficient offshore liquidity.

site_title: Mercedes rides SUV craze to second annual US luxury win
summary: Mercedes-Benz held the top spot in the US luxury vehicle market for a second year, selling the most luxury vehicles in the country with a 0.9% annual sales slip. The brand's SUVs, particularly the GLC, drove the sales, with deliveries surging 53% last month. Mercedes' focus on SUVs helped it maintain a lead over BMW and Lexus, despite annual sales slipping. Smaller rivals like Audi and Jaguar Land Rover also gained ground, with Audi's sales jumping 7.8% to a record 226,511 vehicles in 2017.

site_title: Hyundai speeds development of robot taxis to catch Google, GM
summary: Hyundai Motor is speeding up its development of robot taxis to compete with Google's Waymo and General Motors, aiming to launch a driverless taxi service by 2021. The company has assembled a team of 200 researchers and formed partnerships with tech companies like Cisco Systems and Baidu to integrate artificial intelligence, robotics, and energy storage. Hyundai plans to expand its research and development efforts, investing in startups and setting up data centers in China and Silicon Valley. The move is crucial for the company to catch up with competitors and stem declining sales in its biggest markets.

site_title: Hot stock: F J Benjamin shares actively traded; prompts SGX query
summary: F J Benjamin Holdings shares surged 6.1% to 8.7 Singapore cents after a spike in trading volume, prompting the Singapore Exchange to query the company. The retailer attributed the high trading volume to a renounceable non-underwritten rights cum warrants issue announced in October 2017. This is the second SGX query in two months, following a 36.2% jump in November. The company narrowed its net loss to S$942,000 in the first quarter of 2018, and revenue fell 19% to S$41.4 million.

site_title: Malaysia will try to reach balanced budget by 2022-23: second finance minister
summary: Malaysia is unlikely to meet its earlier target of achieving a balanced budget by 2020 and will need another two to three years to reach the target, according to second finance minister Johari Abdul Ghani. He stated that attempting to achieve a balanced budget by 2020 would "squeeze economic development." Malaysia will instead aim to reach a balanced budget by 2022-23, with a reduced fiscal deficit of 2.8% this year.

site_title: Tories don't want second Brexit vote, but everyone else does
summary: A survey of UK political party members shows that 14% of Conservative Party members favor a second Brexit vote, while 78% of Labour members, 87% of Scottish National Party members, and 91% of Liberal Democrat members support it. The data highlights the divide between party members and the general electorate, with the Conservatives opposing a second referendum and favoring austerity, while the opposition parties support a second referendum and oppose austerity.

site_title: HDB resale prices inch up 0.1% in December as volume drops nearly 20%: SRX
summary: Resale prices of Housing Board (HDB) flats in Singapore rose 0.1% in December, reversing a 0.1% dip in November, according to SRX Property. However, the number of flats sold dropped nearly 20% to 1,585 units, the lowest since May 2010. This marks a 13.9% year-on-year increase in resale volume, but a 56.6% decline compared to the peak in 2010. The full-year HDB resale price index is down 1.8%, close to the official flash estimates' 1.5% decline.

site_title: Asia: Markets enjoy fresh rally as energy firms surge
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, driven by soaring oil prices and gains in energy firms, with Tokyo leading the charge. Oil prices surged to three-year highs due to a US freeze, tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, and a weaker dollar. Energy-linked plays jumped around 2% in early Asian exchanges, with Japan's Nikkei rising over 2% and Hong Kong's main contracts up 2%. This follows a strong start to the year for equities, with analysts predicting US economic growth and further interest rate hikes.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slip, won weakens
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index declined 8.35 points, or 0.34%, to 2,478.00 on Thursday, while the Korean won weakened, falling 0.25% to 1,067.2 per dollar. This follows a 0.08% drop in MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index. The won's value is down 0.08% against the US dollar this year, with a high of 1,060.35 per dollar on January 2 and a low of 1,067.6 on January 4.

site_title: MAS chief Ravi Menon named best central bank governor in Asia-Pacific
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon has been named the best central bank governor in Asia-Pacific for 2018 by UK-based magazine The Banker. The award recognizes his regulatory approach to fintech while maintaining macroeconomic stability. Menon, who was also awarded the honor in 2011, attributes his success to containing and managing technology risks, making Singapore a safe financial center. The MAS was among the first to set up a dedicated fintech group, highlighting its innovative approach to regulation.

site_title: Macron plans law to fight "fake news" in 2018
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron plans to overhaul media legislation to combat "fake news" on social media, a threat to liberal democracies. Macron, who was targeted by fake news and a data hack during his 2017 election campaign, aims to increase transparency requirements for internet platforms, limit sponsored content, and allow judges to delete or block content in cases of fake news. The reform also seeks to maintain a healthy distance between the government and the press, a move seen as a departure from his predecessor's close relations with the media.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB picks Food Empire, Dairy Farm as top consumer plays for 2018
summary: Analysts at RHB predict a pick-up in consumer spending in Singapore and the region in 2018, driven by a strong 2017 GDP growth and improving job prospects. The broker recommends buying Food Empire and Dairy Farm, citing their potential to benefit from the World Cup and a boost in consumer sentiment. RHB expects Food Empire's revenue to increase, with a target price of S$1, and Dairy Farm's supermarket operations to benefit from a pick-up in consumer spending, with a target price of US$9.53.

site_title: British 'fat cat' bosses overtake average annual pay in four days
summary: British CEOs at FTSE 100 companies will have earned more than the median yearly salary of £28,758 in the first four days of 2018, dubbed "Fat Cat Thursday" by a think tank and human resources body. The average annual pay of top executives is calculated to surpass employees' median yearly salary on this day.

site_title: China to 'strictly' ban any new steelmaking capacity in 2018
summary: China will strictly ban new steelmaking capacity in 2018, eliminating outdated capacity and preventing it from reopening. The move follows a 50 million-tonne reduction in steel capacity in 2017 and phasing out 120 million tonnes of low-tech steel product capacity. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) aims to achieve these goals, ensuring China's continued dominance in the world's largest steelmaking country.

site_title: Hong Kong will start atoning for missing Alibaba
summary: Hong Kong is poised to regain its status as a preferred venue for Chinese technology firms' initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2018. The city has been working to address its past shortcomings, including its inability to accommodate dual-class shares, which Alibaba's 2014 listing was denied due to. Hong Kong's stock exchange is expected to allow companies with weighted voting rights structures to list on its mainboard, a move that could attract tech giants such as Toutiao, Meituan-Dianping, and Didi Chuxing. This could result in a record-breaking IPO, potentially raising over $30 billion.

site_title: Allianz plans to double Asian property investments over 3 years
summary: Allianz SE's property unit plans to double Asian investments over three years, aiming to reach 3.75 billion euros by 2020. The growth is driven by the firm's accumulating money from insurance operations in the region, with Asia having the most potential. China and India currently account for over half of Allianz's Asian investments, with a focus on offices, logistics, and student accommodation. The unit is also exploring new markets such as India, South-east Asia, and South Korea, and plans to start a lending book in Asia for long-tenure, fixed-rate loans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally moves into eighth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied for an eighth consecutive day, driven by surging oil prices and a record on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.43% to 30,691.71, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.06%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.09%. The rally follows a string of positive market movements amid global economic optimism and reduced trade tensions.

site_title: Ascott to manage 9 more serviced residences in China
summary: Ascott has sealed contracts to manage nine serviced residences in China, adding over 5,600 units across 28 properties in 2017, doubling its 2016 numbers. The new properties will bring Ascott's total units in China to over 20,000, surpassing its 2017 target. The nine new properties, across 31 cities, are set to start operations in stages from 2018 to 2023, further expanding Ascott's global portfolio of 72,000 units.

site_title: CIMB sees Malaysian IPOs of over 10b ringgit in first half of 2018
summary: Malaysia's IPO market is expected to raise over 10 billion ringgit (S$3.31 billion) in the first half of 2018, according to CIMB Group Holdings. The market saw a revival in 2017 after a decline in 2016 due to poor investment conditions and a volatile ringgit. Several large IPOs are planned, including QSR Brands, Edra Energy, and Bank Islam Brunei Darussalam, which are targeting to raise around US$500 million to US$1 billion. This marks a significant increase from 2017's largest IPO, Lotte Chemical Titan Holding, which raised over US$850 million.

site_title: China regulators set new rules on bond trading: Sources
summary: China's financial regulators have published new rules to regulate bond trading, focusing on restricting leverage and banning under-the-table deals. The rules, jointly issued by the People's Bank of China and other regulators, require institutions to sign written deals for bond repurchase and forward transactions, and ban deals designed to dodge regulations. The goal is to reduce leverage in the financial system, following a $2.4 billion bond scandal in 2016. The rules also set caps on repo transactions for various financial institutions, aiming to prevent similar practices.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank bond issue boosts Australian banks' funding options
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia has successfully raised US$1.25 billion in 30-year subordinated debt in the US, attracting three times the amount it aimed to raise. The successful auction suggests offshore investors are not concerned about a money-laundering lawsuit against CBA and a looming government enquiry into the country's banking sector. This move may encourage other Australian banks to follow suit and boost their funding options.

site_title: Tortilla, petrol prices unnerve Mexicans as election year begins
summary: Mexico's government is addressing concerns over rising fuel and tortilla prices ahead of a presidential election year. Forecasted price hikes of 7-21% for petrol and 11-21% for tortillas have triggered social media outrage and protests. Officials claim the increases are unjustified, but the government's ability to set prices ended in November due to fuel liberalization. The country's inflation rate hovers near a 16-year high at 7%, and the government is sensitive to potential protests that could erode voter support.

site_title: Australia green-lights medicinal cannabis exports
summary: Australia has approved the export of medicinal cannabis, aiming to become a leading world supplier. The country's first medical marijuana farm received a growers' licence in March 2017, and the government sees significant growth potential. Health Minister Greg Hunt stated that the export licence will improve the likelihood of domestic growth, with Australia targeting to become the world's number one medicinal cannabis supplier. The decision comes as the global market is expected to reach $55.8 billion by 2025, driven by increasing demand for medicinal marijuana.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday, STI up 12.82 points
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.4% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index up 12.82 points to 3,477.1. About 110 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 108 to 32. The S&P 500 Index and other regional markets also reached record highs, driven by Federal Reserve policymakers' gradual approach to raising interest rates.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.36 points to 1,797.15. The market saw 164.63 million lots traded worth RM57.76 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 237 to 40.

site_title: Japan December final manufacturing PMI highest since February 2014
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded at its fastest pace in nearly four years in December, with a seasonally adjusted PMI of 54.0, according to a revised survey. This is the highest since February 2014 and marks the 16th consecutive month of expansion. Output growth accelerated for a fifth month, while new business opportunities rose sharply, indicating steady economic growth into the new year. The news comes as the Japanese government prepares to secure parliamentary approval of a record budget for fiscal 2018.

site_title: BlackBerry, Baidu announce autonomous vehicle partnership
summary: BlackBerry and Baidu have partnered to accelerate the deployment of connected and autonomous vehicle technology worldwide. BlackBerry's operating system will be the foundation for Baidu's Apollo autonomous driving open platform. This collaboration aims to support automotive OEMs and suppliers, following Baidu's $1.5 billion investment in autonomous driving projects over the next three years.

site_title: Manhattan home resales drop as buyers waver on tax reform
summary: Manhattan home resales dropped 11% in the final quarter of 2017 to 2,127, the lowest since 2011, as buyers delayed purchases due to uncertainty over the tax overhaul. This decline followed a year of steady sales, with 2017 seeing a 3% increase in resales. The decrease was attributed to buyers' reluctance to overpay, despite the expectation of tax reform. The drop in sales was also influenced by a strong rental market, with Manhattan rents reaching a record high. The slowdown in resales may indicate a potential shift in the market.

site_title: Australia shares touch decade-best levels; NZ at record high
summary: Australian shares reached a decade-best level, rising 0.5% to 6,102.2, driven by strong oil prices and gains on Wall Street. Miner BHP Billiton and healthcare stocks contributed to the gains, with BHP rising 1.4% to its highest since May 2015. The benchmark New Zealand index also hovered around record highs, with Auckland International Airport up 2.1%. US factory activity increased in December, boosting economic momentum, and oil prices surged due to escalating tensions in Iran.

site_title: Golden Globes: Men in black mocked for flimsy #MeToo support
summary: At the upcoming Golden Globes, many actresses, including Jessica Chastain, Meryl Streep, and Emma Stone, plan to wear basic black attire as a protest against sexual harassment in Hollywood. However, some male stars, including Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson, have expressed support for the cause by pledging to wear black, although many will likely stick to traditional tuxedos. Designers and stylists are working to accommodate the trend, with some men opting for black suits and pocket squares instead of full black attire.

site_title: India, Thailand risk being added to US currency watch list
summary: India and Thailand may be added to the US currency watch list if they don't intervene to curb their currencies' gains, potentially reducing their export competitiveness. The Reserve Bank of India has already exceeded the US threshold for intervention, while Thailand's central bank has also passed the level. To avoid penalties, policymakers in both countries may need to allow their currencies to appreciate, which could lead to losses in export competitiveness, despite previous gains of 6.4% for the rupee and 10% for the baht.

site_title: Tesla's Model 3 volume production target pushed back again
summary: Tesla Inc. has pushed back its production target for the Model 3 sedan for the second time, now aiming to reach 5,000 vehicles per week by the end of the second quarter, down from an initial goal of 5,000 by the end of the first quarter. The delay, which sent shares down 1.8% in after-market trading, is attributed to ongoing manufacturing challenges. Despite "major progress," Tesla fell short of expectations in the fourth quarter, delivering only 1,550 Model 3s, and faces high cash burn and the risk of reservation cancellations.

site_title: US dollar advances after strong US data, Fed minutes
summary: The US dollar surged on Wednesday after strong US manufacturing and construction data, with the dollar index posting its largest daily gain in over two weeks. Minutes from the Federal Reserve's December meeting showed the central bank remains on track to raise interest rates several times this year, citing solid labor market gains and expansion in economic activity, despite low inflation. The US dollar index rose 0.8% to 92.18, with the euro and yen also experiencing gains, amidst expectations that the Fed will continue a gradual approach to rate hikes.

site_title: Trump slams ex-aide Bannon, says he's 'lost his mind'
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon, calling him "insane" and "irrelevant" after excerpts from a new book described a meeting between Trump's son Don Jr and a Russian lawyer as "treasonous" and "unpatriotic". Trump also denied Bannon's claims that he didn't believe he would win the 2016 presidential election. The book, "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House", is set to be published next week and has sparked a public feud between Trump and Bannon.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher to chase Wall Street rally
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on the first trading day of 2018, driven by optimism over the US economy and recent Wall Street rallies. The Nikkei 225 index surged 1.44% to 23,092.08, while the Topix index added 1.30% to 1,841.18. This follows a strong performance on Wall Street, where stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. The rally is seen as a reflection of market confidence in the US economy.

site_title: US manufacturing activity jumps in December: survey
summary: US manufacturing activity surged in December, with the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) purchasing managers index reaching 59.7%, its second-highest level in seven years. The sector expanded for the 16th consecutive month, driven by strong new orders and manufacturing output. The production index rose to 65.8%, while employment index fell to 57%. Despite this, prices rose to 69%, marking 22 months of increases. Experts attribute the growth to the recently approved tax cut and the sector's ability to pass on input prices to customers, potentially boosting the entire economy.

site_title: Merrill Lynch bans clients, advisors from trading bitcoin-related investments: WSJ
summary: Merrill Lynch has banned clients and advisors from trading bitcoin-related investments, including Grayscale's Bitcoin Investment Trust (GBTC). The brokerage will not offer new purchases of the fund but will maintain existing positions in brokerage accounts. The decision is driven by concerns over suitability and eligibility standards. This move comes amid widespread concern that bitcoin is a bubble or susceptible to manipulation, with its price soaring over 1,300% in the last 12 months. Merrill Lynch joins other Wall Street firms in refraining from facilitating customers' bets on bitcoin.

images.alt_text: Bank of America Corp's Merrill Lynch told employees last month not to offer clients Grayscale's Bitcoin Investment Trust (GBTC), one of the few financial instruments directly holding the digital coin, as the brokerage broadly eschews the virtual currency.

site_title: Singapore Airlines U-turns on credit card fee for tickets issued in Singapore
summary: Singapore Airlines has decided not to introduce a credit card fee for tickets issued in Singapore, reversing its initial plan to implement a 1.3% fee capped at $50 on discounted Economy Lite tickets. The airline first introduced credit card fees in 2016, which currently apply to routes departing from Australia, Belgium, Netherlands, New Zealand, and the UK. The decision was made following a further review, with no further reason given. This move comes as few full-service airlines impose credit card surcharges, with budget carriers like Scoot, AirAsia, and Jetstar being exceptions.

site_title: President of the Mormon church, Thomas Monson, dies at 90
summary: President Thomas Monson, the 16th President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, died at 90 at his home in Salt Lake City, Utah. He led the church from 2008 and was considered a prophet by its members. Monson was succeeded by Russell Nelson, who is 93 years old. President Donald Trump expressed his condolences, praising Monson's wisdom and compassion. The church, with 15.9 million members worldwide, announced Monson's death on its website.

site_title: Security flaws put virtually all phones, computers at risk
summary: Security researchers have disclosed two major security flaws, Meltdown and Spectre, that affect nearly every modern computing device containing chips from Intel, AMD, and ARM. The flaws, which were discovered by Google Project Zero and other researchers, allow hackers to bypass security measures and steal sensitive information, including passwords. Intel and ARM have pledged to release patches to fix the issue, while AMD says it believes there is "near zero risk" to its products. Users are advised to update their operating systems and devices to mitigate the risks.

site_title: Mingle with the like-minded in the Weekend magazine
summary: A new generation of country clubs offers exclusive, affordable membership to like-minded individuals who want to "change the world." These clubs, priced at a fraction of the traditional cost, provide a unique opportunity to mingle with game changers, disruptors, and socially-conscious individuals. Meanwhile, Airbnb is offering immersive living experiences in Tokyo, and SIHH will showcase new timepieces.

site_title: Music sales soar in US, as streaming takes over market
summary: US music sales grew 12.8% in 2017, a third consecutive year, driven by streaming services such as Spotify. This outpaced the 4.2% growth seen in 2016. On-demand streaming services are replacing downloads, with platforms like iTunes experiencing a decline. The shift marks a significant change in the music industry, which has been shaped by streaming outlets for years.

site_title: Didi buys 99 Taxis, igniting fight with Uber in Latin America
summary: Didi Chuxing, a Chinese ride-hailing company, has acquired 99 Taxis in Brazil, directly competing with Uber in the Latin American market. The $100 million deal marks a significant expansion of Didi's global strategy, entering a market where Uber has faced minimal competition. This move suggests that the ride-hailing industry may become dominated by global companies, rather than local monopolies. The acquisition also puts Didi in direct competition with Uber, which had previously sold its Chinese business to Didi in exchange for a 17.5% stake.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aoxin Q & M Dental Group's market capitalization has crossed the S$75 million threshold, triggering the requirement to announce quarterly financial results by May 15, 2019. Cheung Woh Technologies expects a loss for the third quarter due to production targets missed, while United Industrial Corp's mandatory offer for Singapore Land shares closed on January 3, with UOL holding 99.772% of shares.

site_title: Computer chip 'flaw' sparks security debate amid scramble for fix
summary: Intel acknowledged a vulnerability in its computer chips that could allow hackers to access stored data, but said the security risks were minimal. The flaw, known as "access memory," is used by most modern processors and operating systems, and Intel is working with rivals and operating system makers to develop an industry-wide fix. The fix could slow down computer systems by up to 30%, but Intel claims this impact will be mitigated over time. Security experts warn that the flaw could allow hackers to access sensitive information, including passwords and encrypted data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Venture Corp, Perennial, UOL, Cheung Woh
summary: Venture Corporation is set to join the Straits Times Index on January 5, replacing Global Logistic Properties. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has established a US$1.2 billion joint venture to develop large-scale healthcare integrated mixed-use developments in China. UOL's mandatory offer for Singapore Land shares closed on January 3, and Cheung Woh Technologies expects to report a loss for the third quarter due to production issues.

site_title: Sex is big business in dairy farming and has room for plenty of growth
summary: A growing US dairy industry is driving demand for sex-specific semen to ensure only female calves are born, as artificial insemination can produce a 50-50 chance of either sex. Companies like Inguran LLC and Engender Technologies are capitalizing on this market, selling semen vials for $30 each, which can double the price of conventional semen. The technology has the potential to boost milk output and increase the value of dairy cows, with some farmers willing to pay a premium for the guarantee of a female calf.

site_title: Copenhagen fund that beats 95% of peers ignores CEO talk, research
summary: A Copenhagen-based fund manager, Maj Invest, claims that internal research and CEO talks are more effective than external research and meetings in beating the market. Head of value equities, Kurt Kara, stated that "the best research is the one you generate internally" and that external research and meetings are unlikely to provide useful information. This approach has allowed Maj Invest to outperform 95% of its peers.

site_title: Cosco's takeover offer for Cogent turns unconditional
summary: Chinese shipping company Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) has made its takeover offer for Cogent Holdings unconditional after receiving valid acceptances representing 92.05% of the total number of shares. The offer price is 3.5 times Cogent's net tangible asset per share. Trading in Cogent's shares will be suspended upon the offer's closure. Cosco will exercise its compulsory acquisition right and delist Cogent Holdings from the Singapore Exchange. The offer remains open until Jan 19, and Cosco has no intention of extending it beyond the final closing date.

site_title: Uber is sued over payment for mobile ads it called fraudulent
summary: A British mobile advertising agency, Fetch Media Ltd, has sued Uber Technologies Inc for millions of dollars in unpaid bills, claiming the ride-hailing company misclassified ads as fraudulent. Fetch alleged Uber paid for ads that were not viewed, and Uber counters that Fetch failed to stop ad fraud, causing at least $50 million in damages. The case seeks over $19.7 million in unpaid invoices.

site_title: Oil at highest in 2-1/2 years on Iran tensions, strong demand
summary: Oil prices surged to the highest in 2-1/2 years, rising about 2% on Wednesday, driven by unrest in Iran and strong economic data from the US and Germany. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reached $61.63 a barrel, and International benchmark Brent crude futures rose to $67.84 a barrel. The price increase is attributed to concerns over the ongoing unrest in Iran, a major oil producer, and the ongoing economic growth in key oil-consuming countries.

site_title: Federal Reserve members divided over US rate hikes in 2018
summary: Federal Reserve members are divided over how fast to raise interest rates in 2018, with some arguing for a faster pace and others believing it's too fast. The Fed raised interest rates for the third time in 2017 and is expected to increase it three more times in 2018, but there is uncertainty about the impact of the recently adopted tax cut, which could boost spending but also lead to mergers and share buybacks. The Fed's preferred inflation measure remains below 2%, and officials are perplexed about why inflation has remained low despite steady job creation.

site_title: Bidding adieu to the idea of a core business - for now
summary: Singapore Press Holdings, a media conglomerate, has diversified its business portfolio over the years, shifting its focus from core media operations to investments in property, healthcare, and other sectors. The practice of diversification is no longer seen as taboo, but rather as a valuable strategy to combat cyclical and structural challenges. Companies like Unilever, Ayala Corporation, and Jardine Matheson Holdings have successfully diversified their businesses, while others, such as Singapore Post and Keppel Corporation, have seen significant revenue growth from non-core activities.

site_title: Giant sugar glut to erase two years of shortages
summary: A global sugar surplus is forecast to erase two years of shortages, with production expected to beat demand by 10.4 million metric tons in 2017-18, a 26% increase over combined deficits. Favorable Asian rains and the end of output curbs in the European Union contributed to the surplus. However, low sugar prices and ethanol production in Brazil may impact global supplies, with output in the centre-south expected to drop 8.7% year on year.

site_title: Merrymaking continues with STI up 1%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 3,464.28, outperforming regional peers, driven by gains in banking stocks. This comes ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting minutes, which may assess the US inflation outlook. The index's climb was seen as a positive start to 2018, despite rising rhetoric between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Tax may affect choice of extra remuneration or dividends
summary: A study suggests that controlling shareholders in Singaporean companies may prefer to receive extra remuneration rather than dividends due to tax benefits. For a 30% controlling stake and a 22% personal income tax bracket, remuneration yields a higher after-tax return compared to dividends. However, the threshold for this preference decreases as the controlling stake increases, and at a 94% stake, the preference for remuneration shifts to dividends. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) may challenge remuneration payments as a tax avoidance scheme if they are deemed artificial or lack commercial substance.

site_title: Europe: Shares post strong rebound as dollar, Wall Street rise
summary: European shares rebounded 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by a rising dollar and new records on Wall Street. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% as exporters benefited from the greenback rally. France and Germany's blue chips also gained, fueled by upbeat US manufacturing and construction data. The implementation of the new European MiFID II market rules had a minimal impact on trading volumes.

site_title: Low Keng Huat to launch 2 freehold landed projects
summary: Singapore-listed property developer Low Keng Huat will launch two freehold landed projects, Kismis Residences and Tranquilia@Kismis, in the landed residence enclave of Lorong Kismis and Eng Kong Park off Upper Bukit Timah Road. The projects have already seen strong demand, with 50% of units sold during the soft launch period. Kismis Residences will start from S$4.155m, while Tranquilia@Kismis will be priced from S$3.521m. The projects are being marketed by ERA Realty Network and OrangeTee & Tie.

site_title: Race for 'smart' hits fever pitch at CES
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is set to open in Las Vegas, with device makers touting hardware with artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities, such as smart home devices and voice-assisted digital assistants. Analysts predict a "year of smart" with gadgets learning about users and anticipating their needs. Key tech firms, including major carmakers, will showcase innovations in AI, robotics, and autonomous vehicles, with a focus on contextual intelligence and empathy in devices. The event will also feature zones and marketplaces for various industries and conferences on tech policy and AI.

site_title: Building the right culture for the app age
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

The rise of apps has transformed the way businesses operate and engage with customers, but it also creates new challenges, including cyber security threats. As Asian millennials increasingly demand real-time, intuitive, and secure app experiences, companies must prioritize speed and security. Cyber security threats are not only coming from external sources but also from within the organization, where employees are often the biggest culprits. Education and awareness are key to creating a security-first culture, and governments are recognizing the importance of guidelines around safe cyber security systems to mitigate risks. A proactive approach is needed to protect organizations.

images.alt_text: Apps are changing business models, operations and engagements. This year, smart companies will operate in an app-centric way and build services with the balance of speed and security at the heart of their customer's experience.

site_title: Google saved billions in tax by moving profits around jurisdictions in 2016
summary: Google moved 15.9 billion euros to a Bermuda shell company in 2016, saving the company billions of dollars in taxes. The company uses a "Double Irish" and "Dutch Sandwich" structure to shield international profits from taxation. According to regulatory filings, this tax structure saved Google approximately $3.7 billion in US taxes. The European Union has been exploring ways to make US technology companies, including Google, pay more taxes.

site_title: Ant Financial drops deal with MoneyGram as US approval fails
summary: Ant Financial, an affiliate of Alibaba, has abandoned a $1.2 billion deal to buy US remittances firm MoneyGram after failing to get approval from US regulators. The decision follows a number of moves to prevent Chinese purchases of US firms due to concerns over data security. The deal's termination is a blow to Alibaba boss Jack Ma's push into the world's biggest financial market. Despite the setback, Ant Financial and MoneyGram will still cooperate in other ways, with plans to make the platform more accessible to unbanked and underserved communities globally.

site_title: Singapore is wasting away - why don't we seem to care?
summary: Singapore is facing a looming national waste disaster, with over 2 million tonnes of household waste generated in 2016, enough to fill 14 Olympic-sized swimming pools daily. The country's only landfill site will run out of space in less than 20 years, threatening marine life and water pollution. Despite efforts by the government, businesses, and individuals, recycling rates have stagnated at 20%, with many unaware of the problem's scale. To address this, Singaporeans must make individual changes, such as recycling more, reducing waste, and adopting sustainable habits to prevent a catastrophic environmental disaster.

site_title: Cordlife to buy cord blood bank HealthBaby
summary: Cordlife Group has signed an agreement to buy out private cord blood bank HealthBaby Biotech (Hong Kong) Co from Stemgen Biotech Holding. The deal includes a cash payment of about US$7 million and assumes HealthBaby's debt of HK$138.2 million. HealthBaby, a leading private cord blood bank in Hong Kong, has stored about 20,000 cord blood units and made an after-tax net profit of HK$12.7 million in 2017. The acquisition aims to capitalize on Hong Kong's efforts to boost its birth rate, with Cordlife becoming the leader in the market adjacent to China.

site_title: Britain says it's too soon to seek TPP trade pact membership
summary: Britain's trade minister Liam Fox said it's too soon to seek membership of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact due to its uncertain future. Fox stated that the UK wants to be an open, outward-looking country and will keep an open mind on potential membership. This comes as Prime Minister Theresa May seeks to accelerate Brexit negotiations and finalize a trade deal with the EU by October. The UK cannot agree to new trade deals before it leaves the bloc in March 2019, according to EU rules.

site_title: Germany's jobless rate drops to record low as economy booms
summary: Germany's unemployment rate has dropped to a record low of 5.5% in December, following a sixth consecutive month of decline. The Federal Labor Agency reported a 29,000 decrease in the number of unemployed, exceeding economists' median estimate. This boom in the economy may lead to higher wages and inflation.

site_title: FSM Invest Expo to focus on lifelong investing
summary: The FSM Invest Expo 2018, a two-day event in Singapore, will focus on lifelong investing. It will be held at Suntec Convention Centre from 10am to 6pm on January 6-7. Investment specialists and experts from various companies will share advice on strategies for meeting long-term goals. The event will feature presentations, panel discussions, and a showcase of robo-advisory portfolios. Admission is free, and interested participants can register at expo.fsmone.com.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: HRnetGroup, the largest recruitment firm in the Asia-Pacific, has seen its shares close at S$0.80, surpassing its target price of S$0.96. The company's recent IPO has introduced co-ownership models with incentive programmes, aiming to boost productivity and operating performance. Analysts believe the labour market has bottomed, leading to a potential recovery, which could benefit HRnet.

site_title: Gold holds losses after Fed minutes show case for rate hikes
summary: Gold prices fell on Wednesday, extending losses after the Federal Reserve released minutes of its December policy meeting, which indicated more US interest rate hikes are in store. The Fed's meeting minutes showed disagreement among policymakers, but still suggested the tax cuts would boost consumer spending and GDP, increasing the likelihood of future rate hikes. This view put pressure on gold, despite a 3-1/2 month high in early trading.

images.alt_text: Gold fell on Wednesday, extending losses after the Federal Reserve released minutes of its December policy meeting, which fed the view among investors that more US interest rate hikes are in store.

site_title: North and South Korea reopen cross-border hotline, paving the way for formal talks
summary: North and South Korea reopened a cross-border hotline on January 3, 2018, after a year of tensions, paving the way for potential talks about sending a North Korean delegation to the Winter Olympics in February. This marks the first formal dialogue since December 2015 and could ease tensions after a series of nuclear and missile tests. The brief conversation on the hotline laid the groundwork for official talks, which could lead to a reduction in tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Venture Corp to join STI from Jan 5, replacing GLP
summary: Venture Corp will join the Straits Times Index (STI) on Jan 5, replacing Global Logistic Properties (GLP) as the latter is taken private. Venture maintained the highest market capitalization among STI Reserve constituents as of Jan 2 and is expected to have a weight of 1.8% in the STI, surpassing GLP's 3.3% weight. Venture generated a 115.4% total return in 2017 and saw its net profit grow 81.4% year-over-year in the nine months to Sept 30.

site_title: Real estate veteran named ARA assistant group CEO
summary: ARA Asset Management appointed Chia Nam Toon as assistant group CEO, effective January 2, taking on a dual role as CEO, Reits & Business Development. Toon has over 10 years of real estate experience.

site_title: Dollar rebounds but investors focus on consolidating positions
summary: The US dollar rebounded 0.3% on Wednesday, ending a three-week losing streak, as investors consolidated positions ahead of manufacturing data and Federal Reserve minutes. Despite the rebound, market strategists remain downbeat about the dollar's prospects due to concerns over future rate hikes and low inflation. The euro rose to a four-month high, driven by optimism over the eurozone economy and expectations of the European Central Bank's bond-buying stimulus winding down in 2018.

site_title: Southwest buys more Boeing Max 8 planes, defers smaller Max 7 orders
summary: Southwest Airlines has delayed orders for 23 of Boeing's 737 Max 7 aircraft, pushing them out until 2023 and 2024, raising doubts about the variant's future. The airline is instead adding 40 Max 8 deliveries valued at nearly $4.5 billion, citing benefits from the recent corporate tax rate reduction. This decision may lead to the conversion of Max 7 orders to larger models, potentially benefiting Boeing in the long run. The move further casts doubt on the Max 7's viability as airlines opt for larger planes to save on operating costs.

site_title: Trafigura denies involvement in North Korea oil transfer
summary: Trafigura denies involvement in the illicit transfer of fuel to North Korea, despite South Korea accusing the world's third-biggest independent oil trader of owning a cargo that was shipped in breach of UN sanctions in October. Trafigura claims it sold the shipment to a Hong Kong-based company, which then sold it to another firm, and had no involvement in its final destination. The incident has raised concerns among international traders, potentially increasing pressure on North Korea to abandon nuclear weapons.

site_title: China set to lead in global natural gas imports
summary: China is set to surpass Japan as the world's largest importer of natural gas by the end of 2018, driven by Beijing's efforts to reduce pollution. China imports around 40% of its natural gas needs due to insufficient domestic production. This move aims to replace coal, which is a dirtier fuel. China is already the world's largest importer of oil and coal, and this shift in energy consumption is part of its broader efforts to reduce pollution and meet growing energy demands.

site_title: Devastating weather can be expected in the years to come
summary: US weather in 2017 was marked by devastating hurricanes and wildfires, with scientists increasingly linking these events to climate change. A new framework examines connections between global warming and extreme events, suggesting that climate change may have contributed to disasters like Hurricane Harvey, which caused $180 billion in damage. While hurricanes are complex, research indicates that global warming has increased the frequency of intense storms and altered atmospheric conditions, making events like Harvey's record rainfall and storm surge more likely.

site_title: UPS expects to handle a record 1.4m returns in a single day
summary: UPS expects to handle a record 1.4 million returns in a single day as Americans return unwanted merchandise, creating new issues for shipping companies and retailers. This surge in returns coincides with the end of the holiday season and Americans heading back to work.

site_title: China boosts investment in Sri Lankan mega-project
summary: China has invested US$1 billion in a mega-project near Sri Lanka's main port, aiming to boost its influence in the Indian Ocean. The project, initiated by former president Mahinda Rajapakse, involves building three 60-storey buildings and reclamation work for a financial centre comparable to Singapore and Europe. The deal follows an earlier Chinese investment of US$1.4 billion, and Sri Lankan officials hope it will create thousands of jobs and draw billions in foreign investment. The project's completion date was not given, but progress on reclamation work is expected to be completed by next year.

site_title: More than 5,000 BlueSG electric car rentals in first 3 weeks of service
summary: BlueSG, a Singapore-based electric car-sharing service, announced that over 3,300 people have signed up for its service in the first three weeks of operation, with 5,000 rentals. The company launched on December 12 with 80 vehicles and 32 charging stations. Managing Director Franck Vitte expressed encouragement over the response, planning to deploy more stations islandwide. By 2020, BlueSG aims to have 1,000 electric cars and 500 charging locations, making it the second-largest electric-car sharing programme globally.

images.alt_text: Users can rent any of the 80 battery-powered hatchbacks, drive to their destinations and drop the car off at any of the 32 charging locations in housing estates, the city, one-north business park and Science Park.

site_title: Finnish firm wins PSA contract to service cargo handling equipment
summary: Finnish cargo-handling services firm Kalmar, a unit of Cargotec, has secured a three-year contract to maintain and repair mobile equipment at Pasir Panjang Terminal in Singapore. The contract, worth an unspecified amount, is an extension of Kalmar's existing relationship with PSA Corp, which has been working together for over 11 years. The contract supports the maintenance of up to 700 prime movers and trailer sets, aiming to extend the equipment's lifespan and reduce the port authority's total cost of ownership.

site_title: Samling planning RM1b IPO of its automotive operations: sources
summary: Samlings Group, a Malaysian timber giant, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) of its automotive operations, valued at over RM1 billion (S$330 million). The company, which also owns luxury auto distributor StarChase, is exploring a possible dual listing in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore later this year. This would be the third major IPO in South-east Asia in 2018, following US$11.3 billion in first-time share sales in 2017. Samling's automotive business includes car dealerships in Malaysia and operations in Hong Kong and mainland China.

images.alt_text: The share sale could include Samling's domestic car dealership division as well as operations under StarChase, a luxury auto distributor backed by the group's controlling Yaw family.

site_title: Farewell to an architect who re-envisioned the modern hotel
summary: John Portman Jr., a renowned architect known for his iconic hotel and shopping complexes featuring cavernous atriums, died at 93 on December 29 in Atlanta.
