Portman's signature design, which included waterfalls, fountains, and ivy, redefined the modern hotel and was replicated in hotels worldwide. His career spanned over five decades, with notable projects including the Hyatt Regency, Peachtree Center, and Marriott Marquis. Despite criticism, Portman's buildings were successful in attracting visitors and businesses, and his philosophy of creating an environment that all people respond to remains influential.

site_title: GIC joint venture buys US student housing portfolio for US$1.1b
summary: A joint venture between Singapore's GIC, Canada's CPPIB, and US-based The Scion Group has acquired a US$1.1 billion student housing portfolio comprising 24 assets with 13,666 beds across 20 university campus markets in the US.

site_title: Next boosts UK's Brexit-hit shops with stronger Christmas sales
summary: NEXT Plc reported stronger-than-expected Christmas sales, lifting its profit guidance. The company's shares rose 9.9% amid easing price pressure in the coming year. This boosted UK retailers struggling with Brexit-related costs and the rise of online shopping. Marks & Spencer Group Plc and Debenhams Plc also saw gains, with Marks & Spencer rising over 4% and Debenhams up more than 4%. The positive news contrasts with the US market's decline due to tariff threats.

site_title: Airlines join banks in dishing out US$1,000 tax bill bonuses
summary: US airlines American Airlines and Southwest joined banks and other companies in offering US$1,000 tax bill bonuses to employees, following the passage of the 2018 tax overhaul. The move is seen as an attempt to sway public opinion in favor of the unpopular tax bill. Industry leaders believe the bonuses will benefit shareholders and employees, as the companies face regulatory issues with the Trump administration. The bonuses were announced after the close of business on Tuesday, following similar moves by other companies.

site_title: Midas climbs 43% after joint venture unit clinches contracts
summary: Midas Holdings shares surged 43.2% to close at 15.9 Singapore cents after its associate company, CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co, secured 2.68 billion yuan (S$547.9 million) of new contracts to supply metro train cars in China. The contracts, worth a total of 3.48 billion yuan, were jointly awarded by Hangzhou Metro Group Co and Hangzhou Hangfu Rail Transit Co. Midas' CEO, Patrick Chew, expressed confidence in the company's market position in China's rail industry, despite Midas' shares being down 26% from a year ago due to concerns over trade receivables and debt.

site_title: Ryanair's annual passenger count grows at slowest pace since 2014
summary: Ryanair's annual passenger count grew 10% to 129 million in 2017, the slowest pace since 2014, due to a staffing crunch among pilots that led to the cancellation of 2,100 and 18,000 flights. The airline has cut its forecast for 2018 to 138 million customers. Despite this, Ryanair's shares have gained 3.8% last year. The company has also applied for a British operating licence in case of a hard Brexit in March 2019.

site_title: SMEs hope for pickings in 2018, but are still dogged by challenges
summary: Singapore SMEs are optimistic about 2018, but still face challenges in cashflow management and internationalization. A recent survey found that 35% of SMEs experienced finance-related issues, with 81% of those experiencing delayed payments from customers. To address this, SMEs are advised to implement tighter credit controls, improve financial reporting, and consider alternative financing options such as trade products and foreign-exchange contracts. Meanwhile, the lack of opportunities for SMEs to collaborate with government-linked companies (GLCs) to venture abroad remains a significant obstacle, with some SMEs citing difficulties in navigating emerging markets and understanding local cultures.

site_title: The Last Jedi gives a new hope to box offices for 2018
summary: The Last Jedi became the highest-grossing movie of 2018, earning US$66.8 million in US and Canadian sales over the New Year's break and surpassing Beauty and the Beast's US$504 million. Worldwide, it has pulled in at least US$1 billion, boosting Disney's position as the top movie studio by market share for the second year in a row. This success, combined with other upcoming releases, suggests a promising year for Hollywood, which has faced big-budget bombs and competitive threats in recent years.

site_title: LTA launches two research grant calls to improve public transport services
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has launched two research grant calls to improve public transport services. The grants focus on four areas: reducing transport journey time, optimising public transport services, reducing and reclaiming road spaces, and improving the accuracy of measuring bulk excavations. Researchers will use data analytics to identify bottlenecks and propose solutions such as new ticketing technologies and dynamic lane markings. The grants are open to research and development organisations in Singapore and have a closing date of February 21.

site_title: Claimants in South China Sea dispute need to work out a collective strategy
summary: China continues to expand its presence in the South China Sea, claiming nearly all of the sea within its infamous Nine Dash Line map, and has added over 1,294 hectares of land to its occupied territories by the end of 2017. The region is a crucial shipping route, with estimated maritime trade flows of $3.4 trillion in 2016, and is also an important fishing ground for several countries. The US has conducted freedom of navigation exercises in the area, and other claimants, including Asean countries, are urged to work out a collective strategy to counter China's aggressive tactics and impose costs on its behavior.

site_title: No fanfare for Indonesia despite economy reaching US$1 trillion mark
summary: Indonesia's economy reached a milestone of $1 trillion in 2017, but the government missed its revenue targets, with tax revenue at 14% of GDP. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati attributed the shortfall to high tax targets in previous years, which created doubts about the credibility of the state budget and pressure on companies. The government also underspent on its budget, resulting in a 2.6% fiscal deficit. Despite this, the government aims to improve its tax collection process and coordination between agencies to meet its revenue goals.

site_title: Why TelcoTech will be the next great equaliser
summary: A new wave of technology disruption is reaching the telecom industry, with cloud-based platforms like TelcoTech leveling the playing field for operators. These platforms focus on building digital infrastructure, bypassing traditional infrastructure constraints, and monetizing data. Telecom operators can unlock significant value from their data, with potential revenues from data monetization reaching 20% of their total revenue. The concept of being paid for one's digital footprint is revolutionary, with each person potentially earning thousands of dollars from the value generated from their data.

site_title: Unfiltered fervour: The rush to get off the water grid
summary: The "water consciousness movement" is gaining momentum, with startups and entrepreneurs promoting untreated, unfiltered water as a healthier alternative to tap water. Companies like Live Water, Tourmaline Spring, and Zero Mass Water are selling bottled water on demand, often claiming it's "raw water" that's been untouched by infrastructure. Proponents argue that tap water contains fluoride and other chemicals, while critics warn of the risks of untreated water, including bacterial contamination. The movement has attracted influential supporters from Silicon Valley and beyond, with some entrepreneurs and health advocates swearing by the benefits of raw water.

site_title: Oil dips from mid-2015 highs as higher output looms
summary: Oil prices dipped below mid-2015 highs as US production is set to rise further, undermining Opec's efforts to tighten the market. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $60.34 a barrel, down three cents from the previous close. Higher US and Russian output is seen as a major factor in the price drop, despite Opec's efforts to trim oil demand for the next four years. The move follows a bearish outlook from traders amid concerns about Trump's tariffs on Canada and other countries.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate and Pontiac Land reach settlement on Capitol Singapore
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Limited and Pontiac Land have reached a settlement agreement on Capitol Singapore, resolving a deadlock over the iconic heritage property. The pact allows either Perennial or Pontiac Land to purchase the other's shares, with the sale and purchase expected to be completed within 19 weeks. The agreement is deemed "in the ordinary course of business" and does not require shareholder approval, as it won't change the group's business nature or risk profile.

site_title: The Circus will go on without Mark Halperin
summary: The Showtime documentary series "The Circus" will return in April without Mark Halperin, who was replaced by Alex Wagner due to allegations of sexual harassment and assault. Halperin's co-hosts, John Heilemann and Mark McKinnon, stated that the show's concept, not the hosts, is the key to its success. The new season will focus on the 2018 mid-term elections and will be produced without addressing Halperin's absence on the air. Wagner, a liberal CBS News anchor, will join Heilemann and McKinnon to examine topics such as American identity and tribalism.

site_title: City Towers, Sixth Avenue Centre and Kovan Apts join en bloc wagon
summary: Three Singapore projects are being marketed for en bloc sale: City Towers at Bukit Timah Road for S$355 million, Sixth Avenue Centre for S$90.5 million, and Kovan Apartments for S$33 million. The projects offer owners potential returns of S$2.45 million to S$10.17 million, more than double their individual unit values. The en bloc fervour continues, with the Bukit Timah area seeing recent successful collective sales, including Royalville and Crystal Tower.

site_title: US: Stocks add to records ahead of Fed minutes
summary: US stocks rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes, with technology and energy companies leading the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 advanced 0.2% to records, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.3% to surpass 7,000. Tech giants Apple, Facebook, and Alphabet rose, and energy shares advanced due to higher oil prices. The release of the Fed's December meeting minutes will provide insight into the latest interest rate increase.

site_title: Reits, business trusts, F&B to drive IPOs on SGX in 2018
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects Reits and business trusts to continue dominating the IPO market in 2018, with a combined S$6.6 billion raised in 2017. The sector's attractive dividend yields, averaging 6.4%, outperformed the MSCI Asia Pacific Reit index. F&B companies are also expected to list, with three companies raising S$90.3 million in 2017. However, SGX faces stiff competition from rivals, including Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange, and the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, which may attract more local companies.

images.alt_text: The stock market rally during the latter half of 2017 has propelled the Singapore Exchange (SGX) into the "trillion-dollar club", but more consolidation is expected with China companies still hungry for mergers and acquisitions (M&As).

site_title: US factory activity accelerates; construction spending at record high
summary: US factory activity surged in December, with the Institute for Supply Management's index rising to 59.7, indicating growth in manufacturing, which accounts for 12% of the US economy. Construction spending reached a record high in November, rising 0.8% to $1.257 trillion. The strong economic data, combined with a US$1.5 trillion tax cut, is expected to boost manufacturing and exports. GDP estimates for the fourth quarter are converging around a 2.8% annualized rate, and the US dollar rose against major currencies following the data release.

site_title: Spotify is said to file to go public on NYSE
summary: Spotify has filed confidentially to go public on the New York Stock Exchange, aiming to list its shares directly without a traditional initial public offering. The move avoids underwriting fees and restrictions on stock sales, allowing the company to retain control over its equity. Spotify, with over 60 million paying subscribers, is valued at $8.5 billion and would be one of the largest consumer technology providers to go public in recent years. The company plans to list its shares in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: French inspectors 'missed salmonella at baby milk plant'
summary: French food safety inspectors failed to detect salmonella contamination at a Lactalis factory in northwest France, three months before a major recall of baby milk. The inspectors were tasked with vetting a part of the plant not related to baby milk production, and gave it a clean bill of health. The contamination was discovered in December after 30 infants fell ill, prompting a recall of all production from the site since February 2017. Lactalis faces investigation and potential charges of causing involuntary injuries and endangering lives.

site_title: Possible scenarios in the year of the Brexit
summary: The UK government and EU aim to finalize an agreement on the UK's divorce and future trading relationship by 2018, amidst divisions within the Conservative Party and opposition Labour Party. Three possible scenarios emerge: the base case, where a transition deal is reached but a full trade agreement is delayed; the upset, where negotiations collapse and Labour wins the general election; and the walkout, where the UK walks out of talks and pursues a no-deal Brexit. The EU proposes a "Canada+++" deal, offering tariff-free trade and services access, but the UK's future trade agreement remains uncertain.

site_title: Euro zone yields edge lower as MiFID II kicks in
summary: Euro area borrowing costs edged lower on Wednesday as EU financial market rules took effect, stabilizing after a bond market sell-off driven by hawkish ECB comments. Germany's 10-year government bond yield dropped 3 basis points to 0.437%, while Italy's 10-year yield narrowed to 160 basis points. The move followed a two-month high in Germany's bond yield, as investors adapted to the new market rules.

site_title: Cold heats up battle between US energy lobby groups
summary: A cold snap in the eastern US is reigniting debates over the reliability of various energy sources. The Nuclear Energy Institute claims nuclear power is the most reliable option, with 99 operational units. However, concerns over nuclear waste and safety have led to past policy arguments. Meanwhile, renewable energy sources like solar are experiencing increased investment and growth, particularly in China. As the cold snap continues, the US energy lobby will likely focus on promoting the benefits of their respective energy sources, potentially reigniting past policy disputes.

site_title: China is said to curb power supply for some Bitcoin miners
summary: China plans to limit power use by some bitcoin miners, citing concerns over low power prices and affecting normal electricity use. The People's Bank of China outlined the plan at a closed-door meeting, with local officials and regulators to investigate high consumption. The move follows a cryptocurrency crackdown last year, which outlawed initial coin offerings and halted virtual currency trading. Bitcoin was little changed on the day, with the global industry's energy-intensive practices using as much electricity as 3.4 million US homes.

site_title: Shares of China's small banks plunge on signs of more policy pain in 2018
summary: China's smaller banks suffered significant declines in the first trading days of 2018, with Bank of Tianjin Co plummeting 12% and others falling over 3%. The declines came after regulators announced a policy stance favoring larger banks, excluding smaller ones from a reserve requirement reduction mechanism during the Lunar New Year festival. Analysts say smaller banks face increased borrowing costs and solvency risks due to China's deleveraging campaign, which has pushed up their borrowing costs and weakened profit growth.

site_title: Perennial-led consortium rolls out US$1.2b JV to expand in China
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has launched a US$1.2 billion joint venture to expand its presence in China by acquiring and developing healthcare-integrated mixed-use developments near high-speed railway (HSR) stations. The venture, Perennial HC Holdings, secured US$500 million in its first closing, with Perennial holding a 45% stake. The JV aims to develop projects with a total gross floor area of over four million sq m, positioning Perennial as a leading player in China's HSR market.

site_title: Dell-EMC merger a success in Asia-Pacific, Japan
summary: Dell Technologies' acquisition of EMC Corporation has been a success in the Asia-Pacific and Japan region. The company has achieved three major milestones in its first year, including de-leveraging US$9.5 billion of debt, completing three divestments, and integrating its sales forces. The merger has worked well, particularly in the APJ region, where digital transformation is a key focus among customers. Dell EMC's private company status allows it to prioritize innovation and agility, enabling it to respond quickly to future challenges. The company's combined portfolio enables it to serve both large enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises, providing a range of solutions for digital transformation.

site_title: Baidu to use BlackBerry software in self-driving platform
summary: Baidu and BlackBerry Ltd. signed a deal to develop self-driving vehicle technology, with Baidu using BlackBerry's QNX Hypervisor 2.0 software on its Apollo open platform. The partnership aims to enable carmakers to transition from prototype to production systems. BlackBerry's shares rose 8% to a four-year high, with analysts hailing the deal as a "very solid win" and a material opportunity for technology companies in the rapidly growing automotive industry.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda Global gains sustainability approvals
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures (FGV) has received certification from the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) for eight of its processing mills, two years after voluntarily handing over its earlier certifications. This move marks a significant step towards sustainability for the world's third-largest palm plantation operator. The certification demonstrates FGV's commitment to environmentally responsible practices in its operations.

site_title: Amazon will buy Target this year, influential tech analyst predicts
summary: Amazon is predicted by tech analyst Gene Munster to acquire Target Corp this year, citing shared demographics and manageable store count as ideal partners. Munster estimates a $41 billion deal, a 15% premium to Target's value, and believes investors would view it as a positive move. This potential acquisition would follow Amazon's $13.7 billion purchase of Whole Foods Market last year, and comes as the e-commerce giant continues to expand its Prime service, shipping over 5 billion items worldwide in 2017.

site_title: Failure of Ant, MoneyGram deal casts pall over Chinese dealmaking
summary: Alibaba's failed Ant-MoneyGram deal has cast a shadow on Chinese dealmaking, with US regulatory uncertainty driving Chinese investors to look at Germany, the UK, and Israel for foreign assets. The failed deal followed a meeting between Alibaba founder Jack Ma and then-US President-elect Donald Trump in January 2018, where they discussed a plan to help one million US small businesses access Chinese consumers.

site_title: Ford, GM sales beat estimates as US market growth streak ends
summary: Ford and General Motors reported better-than-expected US sales for December, beating analyst estimates. Ford's deliveries rose 1.3%, while GM's fell 3.3%. The F-Series pickup line saw its best year since 2005, and Chevrolet Silverado truck sales surged 25%. The US market growth streak has ended, with sales expected to drop in 2018 due to higher interest rates and used SUV availability. Light trucks accounted for 63% of US sales through November, up from 59% a year earlier.

site_title: Design flaw found in Intel chips; fix causes them to slow: report
summary: A design flaw in Intel microprocessors has been discovered, allowing hackers to potentially exploit other security bugs and expose sensitive information. The flaw affects Intel chips manufactured over the past decade, particularly kernel memory, and can be exploited by normal applications. Intel and Microsoft are working to issue updates, which will incur a performance hit of 5-30% on affected products. Competing chip maker AMD is not vulnerable to the attack. The updates will also affect major cloud computing platforms, including Amazon EC2, Microsoft Azure, and Google Compute Engine.

site_title: GIC JV buys US student housing portfolio for US$1.1 billion
summary: A joint venture between Singapore's GIC, Canada's CPPIB, and US-based Scion Group has acquired a US$1.1 billion student housing portfolio consisting of 24 assets in 20 university campus markets, comprising 13,666 beds. The portfolio is the latest addition to the joint venture's US student housing portfolio, which now totals 73 communities with 46,555 beds. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand the joint venture's presence in tier-1 university markets in the US.

site_title: Airbnb defeats Aimco lawsuit over unauthorised subleases
summary: Airbnb has defeated a lawsuit by Apartment Investment & Management Co (Aimco) over unauthorised subleases. A federal judge in Los Angeles ruled that Airbnb is shielded from liability by the Communications Decency Act, which protects online service providers from user-posted content. The judge found that Airbnb hosts, not the platform, are responsible for providing listing information. Aimco had sued Airbnb over complaints of noisy Airbnb tourists and required additional security staff. Airbnb has argued that most short-term rentals are innocent and support tenant hosts who use the platform to make ends meet.

site_title: India cancels US$500m missile deal with Israel's Rafael
summary: India has cancelled a US$500 million missile deal with Israel's Rafael Advanced Defense Systems Ltd, just two weeks before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's scheduled visit. The deal was intended to buy Rafael's Spike anti-tank missiles, but the Indian government instead plans to design, develop, and manufacture its own anti-tank missile. This decision comes after a "long and rigorous process" and is seen as a way to boost the country's defense capabilities. Rafael has expressed regret over the cancellation and will still accompany Netanyahu on his visit.

site_title: Deutsche Bank faces new 740m-euro claim
summary: Deutsche Bank faces a 740 million-euro lawsuit from 31 investors, alleging they were underpaid for shares in subsidiary Postbank. The investors claim Deutsche Bank controlled Postbank in 2008, when it bought out their shares, and should have paid them the value of their stock at that time, rather than 25 euros received in the full takeover two years later. The suit accuses Deutsche Bank of striking secret contracts with Postbank's former owner Deutsche Post, which helped both sides weather the financial crisis.

site_title: Gold slips from 3-1/2 month peak as US dollar edges higher
summary: Gold prices slipped from a 3-1/2 month high due to a firmer US dollar, which pressured assets priced in the US currency. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $1,316.56 per ounce, while analysts predict it may drop further to $1,225. Investors await manufacturing data and US Federal Reserve minutes for clues on monetary policy, which affects gold's value.

site_title: Bitcoin loses some dazzle as second-tier crypto coins catch up
summary: Bitcoin's market value has dropped to about 37% from 56% a month ago, as second-tier cryptocurrencies like Stellar and Cardano have gained popularity and market capitalization. Stellar has more than doubled in value, reaching a record market cap of over $13 billion, while Cardano has risen 40-fold. Experts say that second-tier coins are not competing with Bitcoin but rather offering alternative uses, such as cross-border payments and smart contracts. The growing popularity of these coins may signal a shift away from Bitcoin as the market leader.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing grows for 16th straight month in December but pace shows signs of slowing
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced 16 consecutive months of growth in December, with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 52.8. Although the pace of expansion is showing signs of moderating, it capped a year of strong growth. The electronics sector saw a slight dip in PMI to 53.2, while factory output and inventory slowed, but new orders and employment increased. The sector is expected to remain a key growth driver in the year ahead, making up a fifth of the economy.

site_title: Sangamo partners with Pfizer to develop gene therapy for ALS
summary: Sangamo Therapeutics and Pfizer have partnered to develop a gene therapy for ALS, a disease affecting nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord. The therapy aims to treat patients with a brain disorder caused by gene mutations linked to about a third of hereditary ALS cases. The partnership follows the FDA's recent update on gene therapy guidance and the approval of a gene therapy for a rare form of blindness. Sangamo will receive a $12 million upfront payment and $150 million in milestone payments from Pfizer.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 34 points, or nearly 1%, to 3,464.28 on Wednesday, with 2.5 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion traded. Gainers outpaced losers, with 253 counters up and 178 down. The increase follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: More than half of new Norway car sales now electric or hybrid
summary: Norway has reached a record, with more than half of new car sales being electric or hybrid in 2017, exceeding 52% of all new registrations. The shift is attributed to generous subsidies, exemptions from taxes and road tolls, and the country's reliance on hydropower, reducing air pollution and climate change. Norway aims to phase out fossil fuel vehicles by 2025, and the nation is ahead of other countries in electric car sales, with the International Energy Agency noting a significant increase in electric car sales in 2017.

site_title: Iran's elite guard says anti-government protests are over
summary: Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps declared an end to the anti-establishment unrest, with about 20 people dead over the past week. The protests, sparked by economic policies of President Hassan Rouhani, spread to other cities and targeted the broader religious and political establishment. A heavy police presence was reported in Tehran, while pro-government demonstrations took place in other Iranian cities. The government has detained hundreds of people, and officials have struck a conciliatory tone, pledging to listen to protesters' demands. The unrest comes at a critical time for Iran, with the US threatening to renege on the nuclear accord and the economy slowly recovering.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A PwC report suggests Reits and business trusts will drive IPOs on the Singapore Exchange. The Singapore Exchange will continue to see listings of these investment vehicles, according to the report.

images.alt_text: Listings of Reits and business trusts will continue to dominate IPOs on the Singapore Exchange, according to a PwC report.

site_title: Football: Zidane, Real Madrid hoping for more glory in 2018
summary: Real Madrid, under coach Zinedine Zidane, begins the 2018 season with a Copa del Rey match against Numancia, aiming to win the trophy for the first time since Zidane's appointment in 2016. Zidane has already won eight out of ten trophies in his first year and a half, including five in 2017. The team has already won three trophies this season and will face Paris Saint-Germain in the Champions League in February. Zidane is focused on the next six months and is satisfied with his current squad, but rumors of a potential transfer for Kepa Arrizabalaga have been circulating.

site_title: High-tech ship en route to resume hunt for MH370
summary: A high-tech research vessel, Seabed Constructor, leased by US exploration firm Ocean Infinity, is en route to resume the hunt for missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in the Indian Ocean. The search area, approximately 120,000 square kilometers, was previously abandoned in January 2017. The vessel aims to arrive in the search zone by mid-January, with negotiations between the Malaysian government and Ocean Infinity nearing completion for a "no find, no fee" basis. The search is expected to use autonomous submarines to scour the seabed for fragments of the jet.

site_title: Formula One: Ferrari pay tribute as Schumacher turns 49
summary: Ferrari paid tribute to Michael Schumacher on his 49th birthday, honoring the retired seven-time Formula One world champion who suffered catastrophic brain injuries in a 2013 skiing accident. Schumacher has been receiving care at his home in Switzerland since. Ferrari's tribute on Twitter expressed the team's thoughts and well wishes for Schumacher, using hashtags #Keepfighting and #ForzaMichael.

site_title: Perennial sets up US$1.2 billion JV to invest in healthcare developments in China
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has established a US$1.2 billion joint venture (JV) to invest in healthcare developments connected to high-speed railway (HSR) stations in China. The JV, Perennial HC Holdings, has secured US$500 million in its first close, with plans to acquire and develop large-scale projects with a total gross floor area of over 4 million square meters. This move aims to grow Perennial's HSR portfolio to eight projects, positioning the company as a leading player in the market.

site_title: Oil dips away from mid-2015 highs as higher output looms
summary: Oil prices held steady near mid-2015 highs, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $60.50 a barrel and Brent crude futures at $66.74 a barrel. High US production and doubts about demand growth are expected to keep prices stable, despite concerns over unrest in Iran. Supply disruptions in the North Sea and Libya have resolved, and Iranian production is not expected to be impacted by protests. Analysts predict a potential price downturn in early 2018 due to rising US output and concerns about the Chinese economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks chalk up seventh day of gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a seventh consecutive day, extending an Asia-wide rally at the start of the year. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.15% to close at 30,560.95, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.62% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 0.77%. This follows another record close on Wall Street. The gains are attributed to the Asia-wide rally, despite US tariff threats.

site_title: Cheung Woh Technologies issues profit warning for Q3 as typhoon disrupts production
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies, a hard disk drive manufacturer, has issued a profit warning for the third quarter due to production disruptions caused by Typhoon Hato, which damaged machinery and led to a temporary shortage of manpower. The company expects to report a loss for the quarter, with production of baseplates falling short of its target yield. Further details will be disclosed when the company releases its third-quarter results on or before January 12.

site_title: Europe: Buoyant retailers lead European shares higher
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by gains in retail stocks and a stronger-than-expected update from British retailer Next. The Stoxx 600 index also rose 0.4% in Germany and 0.2% in the euro zone. However, the UK's FTSE 100 was flat due to a stronger pound. Energy and technology sectors also contributed to the gains, while the retail sector index rose 0.7% despite losing 3% in 2017.

site_title: Ziwo Holdings changing name to BM Mobility
summary: Ziwo Holdings has changed its name to BM Mobility following an extraordinary general meeting on January 2. The name change, confirmed by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore, takes effect immediately. The company plans to update its trading counter name on the mainboard.

site_title: Trendlines portfolio company receives FDA clearance for sinus stent
summary: A company in The Trendlines Group's portfolio, ST Stent, has received FDA clearance for a sinus stent that helps reduce complications from sinus surgery. The stent, which keeps the sinus cavity open for up to 28 days, aims to improve patient outcomes and reduce revision surgeries. This comes after successful clinical trials on 30 patients in 2017. The FDA clearance will allow ST Stent to market its product in the US, marking a significant milestone for the company.

site_title: Venture Corp to join STI from Jan 5, replacing GLP
summary: Venture Corporation is set to join the Straits Times Index (STI) on January 5, replacing Global Logistic Properties (GLP), which is being taken private. Venture maintained the highest market capitalization of the STI Reserve List, and its inclusion is expected to boost its weight in the index by up to 1.8%. The company achieved a 115.4% total return in 2017 and saw its net profit grow 81.4% year-over-year in the nine months to September 30.

site_title: SingLand offer closes with UOL controlling 99.772% stake
summary: UOL's mandatory offer for Singapore Land shares closed at S$11.85 apiece, with UOL controlling 99.772% stake. The obligation was triggered under Singapore's takeover code when UOL attained statutory control of United Industrial Corporation (UIC), which owns over 99% of SingLand. The offer was made after UOL acquired shares it did not already own.

site_title: Nigeria loses almost half its power output after pipeline fire
summary: A fire at the Escravos-Lagos pipeline in Nigeria interrupted gas supplies to power plants generating over 3,000 megawatts, causing a nationwide grid shutdown. The fire affected the 1,320-megawatt Egbin power plant, the country's largest, and five others. Most of Nigeria's power is generated from thermal sources, with gas supplies delivered through pipelines owned by Nigerian Gas Processing and Transportation Company. The shutdown resulted in a significant loss of power output, with the nation losing almost half its power output.

site_title: China is boosting ties in Latin America. Trump should be worried
summary: China is strengthening its economic ties in Latin America, surpassing the US as the region's top trading partner, excluding Mexico. China's dominance is driven by its demand for commodities such as iron ore, soybeans, and raw materials. The US uncertainty under President Trump, including potential withdrawal from the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), could create an opportunity for China to expand its presence in the region. China's expansion could accelerate if Nafta dissolves, potentially creating a vacuum that China would try to fill.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge up; won slips
summary: South Korea's won slid against the US dollar on Wednesday, reversing its three-year high from the previous day, amid concerns of capital outflows. The won rose 12.8% in 2017. The KOSPI stock index rose 0.27% to 2,486.35. The government is considering measures to boost capital outflows if the won continues to rise sharply.

site_title: Suu Kyi govt ups Myanmar minimum wage as economy staggers
summary: Myanmar's government has announced a 33% increase in the minimum wage to 4,800 kyats (S$4.68) per day, effective immediately. This increase is the highest in the country's history and aims to boost the economy, which has been struggling since Aung San Suu Kyi's civilian government took power in 2016. The move is seen as a step to improve the standard of living for workers, particularly in the garment industry, which accounts for a significant portion of the country's economy. The new wage rate will be applied nationwide to all businesses with 10 or more workers.

site_title: Sixth Avenue Centre up for collective sale
summary: Sixth Avenue Centre, a 1980s mixed-use development in Bukit Timah Road, is being put up for collective sale with an indicative guide price of S$90.5 million. The site, zoned for commercial and residential use, has a gross plot ratio of 3 and a land area of 1,394 sq m. Developers are expected to compete for the site, which could accommodate a 5-storey development with retail and 35 apartments. The tender closes on January 31, with Savills Singapore handling the sale.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.09 points to 1,792.79, closing higher on Wednesday. The index saw 5.11 billion shares traded for RM3.67 billion, with 771 gainers and 305 losers.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate and Pontiac Land reach settlement on Capitol Singapore
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Limited and Pontiac Land have reached a settlement agreement on Capitol Singapore, ending a deadlock over the iconic heritage property. The agreement allows either Perennial or Pontiac Land to purchase all of the other parties' shares, providing a mechanism for a potential sale. The settlement involves Perennial's wholly owned subsidiaries, Pontiac Land's affiliate Chesham Properties, and Patina Hotels & Resorts Pte Ltd. The agreement marks a significant development in the fate of Capitol Singapore, which has been a topic of interest for several years.

site_title: Samling is said to prepare 1b ringgit IPO for Bentley dealer
summary: Malaysia's Samling Group is planning a potential initial public offering (IPO) of its automotive operations, which could raise over 1 billion ringgit (S$330.53 million). The IPO may include Samling's car dealership division and StarChase, a luxury auto distributor. Deliberations are at an early stage, with the possibility of listing the business in only one stock market. This would add to the growing trend of first-time share sales in South-east Asia, with US$11.3 billion raised in 2017, up from US$6.1 billion in 2016.

site_title: Australia shares end higher; NZ starts 2018 on strong note
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,070.4, driven by gains in material stocks and metal prices. The metals and mining index reached a 10-year high, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Ltd advancing 1.7% and 1.5% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also rose 0.32% to a record close, with Fletcher Building Ltd and Auckland International Airport leading the gains. The rally was boosted by a synchronized global economic upturn and upbeat manufacturing surveys.

site_title: All talk, few answers from FOMC for Yellen's long inflation miss
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting in December showed little progress in resolving the issue of low inflation, despite Janet Yellen's efforts to address it. Minutes of the meeting indicate that the outlook for consumer prices continued to dominate the discussion, with forecasts for three interest-rate hikes in 2018 remaining unchanged. The FOMC's 2% inflation target remains a challenge, with some members expressing concerns that inflation may not reach the goal. Fed Governor Jerome Powell will take over as chair after Yellen's term ends, and the committee's discussion of inflation risks and the economy's potential growth rate will be crucial in shaping future policy decisions.

site_title: Jack Ma needs to prove he's serious about coming to America
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma has abandoned his bid to buy MoneyGram International Inc for US$18 per share after the US Committee on Foreign Investment (CFIUS) delayed its decision. Ma had hoped to gain favor with President-elect Donald Trump, but the deal ultimately fell through. Instead, Ma and MoneyGram plan to collaborate on a joint venture to provide money transfer services, with Ant Financial exploring capabilities in remittance and digital payments. Ma's failure to secure the deal raises questions about his commitment to entering the US payments industry, and experts suggest he should focus on building a locally owned platform with US leadership.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda Global gains sustainability approvals after 2016 withdrawal
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures, the world's third-largest palm plantation operator, has received RSPO certification for eight of its processing mills, two years after withdrawing earlier approvals due to sustainability issues. The company aims to certify another eight mills by March 2018 and all 70 mill complexes by the end of 2021. This move follows the company's voluntary withdrawal in 2016 to correct sustainability issues in its supply chain. The certification is a step towards promoting the use of sustainable palm oil products and reducing deforestation and haze in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Ant's MoneyGram failure casts pall over Chinese dealmaking
summary: US security concerns have torpedoed Alibaba affiliate Ant Financial's $1.2 billion takeover of MoneyGram International Inc, a Dallas-based company, due to data safety concerns. This is the most high-profile Chinese deal to fall foul of the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) under the Trump administration. The failure has raised questions about the future of Chinese dealmaking in the US, with some experts suggesting Chinese companies may shift their focus to other countries. The incident marks the latest challenge to Chinese investment in the US, with lawmakers introducing bills to broaden the government's power to stop foreign purchases of US companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session up; STI at 3,445.74 up 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% in the afternoon session, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,445.74. About 1.08 billion shares worth S$574 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 186 to 163. Key movers included Keppel Corporation and Venture Corporation. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Ex-banker found liable for S$6.5m guarantee claimed by former client
summary: A former private banker, Karl Liew, has been held liable for S$6.5 million in investments he guaranteed to a businessman, Alan Zhou. Liew, the son of a CapitaLand Group executive, was found liable for deceit in making false representations about the investments, which were in China. A court default judgment had already been entered against a second defendant, Realm Capital, and Liew was not sanctioned by the Official Assignee to defend the suit. The judgment was made despite Liew's claims of Zhou's breach of agreements and his own payment of S$500,000 to help repay the monies.

site_title: Euro takes breather after rally; US dollar holds steady
summary: The euro took a breather, easing 0.1% to US$1.2048 after a 3% gain from a mid-December trough. The currency hit a four-month high on Tuesday, boosted by data showing euro zone manufacturers ramped up activity at the fastest pace in over two decades. The US dollar held steady despite the euro's drop, as investors await the European Central Bank's decision on bond-buying stimulus in 2018.

site_title: More than 5,000 BlueSG electric car rentals in first 3 weeks of service
summary: BlueSG, a Singapore-based electric car-sharing service, announced over 5,000 rentals in its first three weeks of operation, with more than 3,300 people signing up. The company launched with 80 vehicles and 32 charging stations on December 12. Managing Director Franck Vitte expressed encouragement over the "overwhelming response" and plans to quickly deploy more stations islandwide. By 2020, BlueSG aims to have 1,000 electric cars and 500 charging locations, making it the second-largest electric car-sharing program globally.

site_title: Trafigura denies involvement in North Korea oil transfer
summary: Trafigura Group denied involvement in the illicit transfer of fuel to North Korea, despite South Korea stating the company originally owned a cargo shipped in breach of UN sanctions in October. The controversy may increase pressure on North Korea by limiting its access to fuel, despite international sanctions. President Donald Trump previously accused China of allowing ship-to-ship fuel sales to North Korea, further straining relations.

site_title: Ryanair annual passenger count grows at slowest pace since 2014
summary: Ryanair's annual passenger count rose 10% to 129 million in 2017, the slowest pace since 2014, due to cancellations of 2,100 flights and a staff-rostering issue. The airline scrapped 18,000 additional services into the summer, leading to its first-ever pilot strike. This resulted in a 2 million passenger decrease from initial forecasts and a 15% gain in 2015. Ryanair has cut its forecast to 138 million customers for 2018. Meanwhile, Wizz Air Holdings Plc reported a 24% jump in customers to 28.3 million.

site_title: In the year that makes or breaks Brexit, what could 2018 bring?
summary: The UK and EU aim to reach an agreement on their divorce and future trading relationship by 2018, amid divisions within both camps. The British government and Labour Party have differing views on Brexit, while the Scottish nationalists oppose leaving the EU. The UK's governing Conservatives remain split on what Brexit means, and the opposition Labour Party is avoiding the question. The outcome of these talks will determine the future of Brexit and its impact on the UK's economy.

site_title: Amazon will buy Target this year, influential tech analyst predicts
summary: Amazon is predicted to acquire Target Corp this year, according to Loup Venture co-founder Gene Munster. The deal would be a 15% premium to Target's value, estimated at $41 billion. The acquisition would be beneficial for Amazon due to shared demographics and manageable store count, with both companies focusing on mothers and families. Market-share numbers suggest regulators would approve the deal, and investors view it as a positive move for Amazon.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.47% on Wednesday, reaching levels not seen since late 2007, following a record on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index closed at 30,658.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell marginally and the Shenzhen Composite Index remained unchanged.

site_title: Draghi succession at ECB hinges on gender as well as nationality
summary: The European Central Bank is undergoing a two-year leadership overhaul, with five key positions to be vacated by 2019. The selection process will prioritize ability over experience, but also consider non-traditional candidates, including women and government ministers. The new leaders will shape ECB policy, including stimulus withdrawal and resilience measures, and have a significant impact on the eurozone's future. The succession will be a significant shift, with Mario Draghi's departure likely to be influenced by his nationality and gender, as well as his ability to lead the institution.

site_title: China set to top Japan as world's biggest natural gas importer
summary: China is poised to surpass Japan as the world's largest natural gas importer this year, driven by Beijing's efforts to reduce pollution and transition from coal to cleaner energy sources. China's 2017 imports of pipeline gas and liquefied natural gas (LNG) reached 67 million tonnes, up over a quarter from the previous year. LNG imports alone surged more than 50%. Analysts expect China to maintain this trend, overtaking Japan in 2018 and becoming the world's largest gas importer until around 2028.

site_title: Copenhagen stock fund that beats 95% of peers ignores CEO talk, research
summary: A Copenhagen-based stock fund, Maj Invest, has reported beating 95% of its peers, despite its CEO's statement that internal research is more effective than external sources. According to Kurt Kara, head of value equities, internal research is key to creating the fund's own mindset and logic. This approach differs from other fund managers who rely on external research and CEO discussions. The fund's success suggests that internal research may be a more reliable method for achieving market-beating performance.

site_title: Southwest moves up some Boeing Max orders, defers smallest mode
summary: Southwest Airlines has delayed orders for 23 of Boeing's 737 Max 7 aircraft, pushing most of its orders until 2023 and 2024, casting doubt on the future of the smallest Max variant. The airline is instead converting 40 Max 8 orders valued at nearly $4.5 billion into firm orders, which will provide a steady delivery of the larger plane through 2025. This move may help Boeing in the long run if the orders are converted to larger models, and comes as airlines opt for larger planes to save on operating costs.

site_title: Sex is big business in dairy farming and focus of legal battles
summary: US dairy farmers are shifting focus to sex-specific semen, a new technology that guarantees female calves, due to the randomness of natural breeding. Inguran LLC and Engender Technologies are leading the market with products costing around $30 per dose, double the price of non-guaranteed semen. Companies are also battling in court over patents for the technique, which has improved breeding to boost milk output. The trend is expected to increase competition and benefit farmers, who welcome the premium pricing for sex-sorted semen.

site_title: Low Keng Huat to launch 2 freehold landed projects off Upper Bukit Timah Road on Friday
summary: Singapore-listed property developer Low Keng Huat will launch two freehold landed projects off Upper Bukit Timah Road, Kismis Residences and Tranquilia@Kismis, on Friday. Kismis Residences is a 31-unit development, while Tranquilia@Kismis is a seven-unit strata landed project launched by Low Keng Huat's joint venture with Wenul Development. ERA Realty Network and OrangeTee & Tie are the appointed joint marketing agents for both projects.

site_title: Thai Dec headline CPI rises 0.78% y-o-y, below forecast
summary: Thailand's headline consumer prices rose 0.78% in December, below forecasts and the central bank's target range of 1-4%. This is the second consecutive month of below-forecast inflation, giving policymakers room to keep interest rates low. The Bank of Thailand expects headline inflation to be 1.1% in 2018, and has left its policy interest rate unchanged at 1.50%. This is a departure from expectations of a policy change in 2018, with some predicting an interest rate hike in the second half of the year.

site_title: Midas unit clinches 2.68b yuan of contracts to supply metro train cars
summary: Midas Holdings, a 32.5% joint venture, secured 2.68 billion Chinese yuan (S$547.9 million) in metro train car supply contracts in China. The contracts, worth 1.15 billion yuan, 1.09 billion yuan, and 0.44 billion yuan, were awarded to CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co for projects in Shenzhen, Hangzhou, and the Hangzhou-Fuyang Inter-city Metro Project. Deliveries are set between 2018 and 2020.

site_title: Manhattan home resales tumble as US tax overhaul sidelines buyers
summary: Manhattan home resales dropped 11% in the fourth quarter, the lowest since 2011, as buyers delayed purchases ahead of the US tax overhaul. 88% of homes sold at or below the asking price, with resellers offering 5.7% discounts on average. The median price for resales was $916,425, a 1.8% increase from the previous year. This decrease in sales is attributed to buyers holding out for the best deal, as the expected tax overhaul may impact their purchasing decisions.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC upgrades SembMarine to 'hold'
summary: OCBC Investment Research has upgraded SembMarine to a "hold" rating despite a drop in its share price following Keppel Corp's agreement to pay a US$422 million fine. The upgrade is attributed to SembMarine's announcement to sell its West Rigel rig for US$500 million, a 12% discount from the original price. Analysts cited the company's pure play status and smaller asset base compared to Keppel as reasons for the divergence in share price performance.

site_title: North Korea says will open inter-Korean hotline
summary: North Korea announced it will restore a hotline with South Korea at 0630 GMT, following Seoul's proposal for high-level talks in response to Kim Jong Un's calls for better relations and potential participation in the Winter Olympics. The move comes after South Korea's unification minister offered to hold talks on January 9. North Korea's Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of Korea will discuss practical matters involving North Korean athletes at the Pyeongchang Games. The development was welcomed by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, who expressed gratitude to South Korean President Moon Jae In for supporting his reconciliation efforts.

site_title: Google's 'Dutch Sandwich' shielded 15.9b euros from tax
summary: Google shielded 15.9 billion euros from tax in 2016 by moving revenue through a "Dutch Sandwich" structure, which involves shifting profits from an Irish subsidiary to a Dutch company with no employees, and then to a Bermuda mailbox. The move saved Google an estimated US$2.4 billion in taxes, according to tax expert Robert Willens. The European Union is exploring ways to make US technology companies like Google pay more tax, and the US tax law now requires companies to pay taxes on overseas income held outside the US.

site_title: Amazon, Salesforce shifting business away from Oracle: report
summary: Amazon and Salesforce, two major customers of Oracle, are shifting their business away from the company's software. They are replacing Oracle's database with lower-cost open-source alternatives, motivated by the high cost of Oracle's database. Amazon has already switched two internal databases to open-source NoSQL, while Salesforce is developing a database replacement, "Sayonara," to be deployed internally by 2023. Oracle's shares have slid following the report, which aims to reduce its dependence on the two major customers.

site_title: US office vacancy rate rises in fourth quarter: Reis
summary: US office vacancy rate rose to 16.3% in the fourth quarter of 2017, marking the first increase in at least five years, according to Reis Inc. Asking and effective rents increased 0.6% in the quarter, with 1.8% growth for 2017. Net absorption plummeted 60% to 5.21 million square feet, and construction activity slowed to 7 million square feet. Experts attribute the rise to renewed business confidence, driven by the recently passed tax bill, which is expected to boost leasing activity and rent growth, possibly in late 2018.

site_title: Race for 'smart' hits fever pitch at electronics show
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is set to open in Las Vegas, showcasing innovations in smart devices, artificial intelligence, and voice assistants. Device makers will highlight hardware with "smarts" to anticipate needs and desires, with digital assistants like Amazon's Alexa, Google Assistant, and Apple Siri being integrated into various products. The event will also feature major carmakers, tech platforms for self-driving vehicles, and robotics. Analysts predict a "year of smart" as consumers increasingly adopt voice-assisted digital assistants, with major firms locked in a battle to be at the heart of smart homes and devices.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise, korean won takes a breather
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.25% to 2,485.75 points on Wednesday, driven by gains in the Asian-Pacific shares. The Korean won weakened 0.3% to 1,064.4 per US dollar, after touching a three-year high on Tuesday. MSCI's Asia-Pacific index rose 0.32%. Foreigners were net buyers of 165.236 million won worth of shares. The Kospi is up 0.5% this year and 2.18% in the past 30 days.

site_title: PSA Corp awards 3-year cargo handling equipment service contract to Kalmar
summary: PSA Corp has awarded a 3-year cargo handling equipment service contract to Kalmar, a unit of Cargotec, for the maintenance and repair of up to 700 prime movers and trailer sets at Pasir Panjang Terminal in Singapore. This contract extends Kalmar's 11-year working relationship with PSA and aims to extend the lifetime of the equipment fleet, reducing costs of ownership.

site_title: Reits, business trusts to continue to drive IPOs on SGX: PwC report
summary: A PwC report suggests that real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts (BTs) will continue to dominate initial public offers (IPOs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to their successful track record, with 88% of total funds raised in 2017. The SGX may see more listings of food and beverage companies, but faces challenges from rival exchanges and private equity firms offering alternative funding opportunities. The report also notes that Hong Kong's stock exchange is gaining popularity, with local companies listing on the exchange in increasing numbers.

site_title: Australian shares recover as miners rally; NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,072.3, driven by a 2% gain in the metals and mining index, led by BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. The rally followed strong Chinese manufacturing data and a weak US dollar. US stocks also rose, with the Nasdaq closing above 7,000 for the first time. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high on its first day of trade in 2018, driven by gains in dairy and industrial stocks.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars supported by global commodity demand
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars consolidated near multi-week highs due to positive factory surveys globally supporting commodity exports. The Aussie dollar was steady at US$0.7826, while the New Zealand dollar retreated to US$0.7090. The gains come as investors await the impact of US tariffs and global economic trends on the two countries' economies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cosco Shipping International (S), Cogent, HC Surgical, Weiye
summary: Cosco Shipping International has made its S$1.02-a-share cash offer for Cogent Holdings unconditional, with 92.05% of Cogent shares accepted. HC Surgical will acquire a 51% stake in HMC Medical Pte Ltd for S$673,000. Weiye Holdings has entered an agreement to buy 40% of Huzhou Ganghong Zhiye Co, Ltd for S$1.64 million, with a shareholder loan of 114.8 million yuan. These developments may impact trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: China's central bank lifts yuan mid-point to highest since May 2016
summary: China's central bank lifted its official yuan midpoint to 6.4920 per US dollar on January 3, 2018, the highest level in over 1-1/2 years and surpassing the 6.5 per US dollar threshold. This follows the US dollar's weakness and China's solid spot yuan performance, which rose to its firmest against the US dollar in nearly four months on Tuesday. The move reflects expectations of a slower pace of interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Asia shares eye all-time high on global growth cheer
summary: Asian stocks reached a decade high on January 3, 2018, as risk appetites increased following upbeat manufacturing surveys indicating a synchronized global economic upturn. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index outside Japan rose 0.1% to a fresh decade high, driven by strong European stocks and emerging market trades. The euro strengthened to a four-month high against the US dollar, while bond yields rose in Europe. The global economy's virtuous cycle, where growth supports equities, which in turn fuels growth, was highlighted by industry surveys and a potential European Central Bank asset buying program wind-down.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.09 points, or 0.17%, to 1785.79. The market saw 122.8 million lots traded worth RM47.28 million, with 192 gainers and 58 losers.

site_title: Airlines join banks in dishing out US$1,000 tax bill bonuses
summary: Two US airlines, American Airlines and Southwest, have joined other companies in offering $1,000 bonuses to employees due to the 2018 tax overhaul. The bonuses, totaling $130 million, will be paid this quarter to workers. The move is seen as an attempt to sway public opinion in favor of the unpopular tax bill. Several other industries, including banks and insurers, have also made similar announcements. The bonuses are expected to benefit employees and shareholders alike, with American Airlines citing its financial losses as a reason for the payment.

site_title: ARA names Chia Nam Toon as assistant group CEO
summary: ARA Asset Management has appointed Chia Nam Toon as assistant group CEO, effective January 2, 2018. Chia, a veteran with over 10 years of real estate experience, will drive growth opportunities in existing Reits and develop new Reits across Asia, the US, and Europe. His appointment is seen as a boost to the company, with Group CEO John Lim stating that Chia's experience will contribute to continued growth within the Reits division. Chia previously held CEO and CFO roles at Ascendas Reit and Ascendas-Singbridge.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS initiates coverage on HRnet, issues 'buy' on labour market recovery
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on HRnetGroup with a "buy" call, assigning a target price of S$0.96, representing a 21% upside. Analysts believe the recruitment firm will benefit from a labour market recovery, driven by growth in Singapore's services sector. However, they note key risks, including economic downturns, increased competition, and relatively low stock liquidity. HRnet, the largest recruitment firm in the Asia Pacific region, has a co-ownership model that could aid productivity and drive better performance.

site_title: US warns North Korea against new missile test, plays down talks
summary: The US has warned North Korea against a new missile test, with Ambassador Nikki Haley saying the US would not take talks seriously if North Korea does not give up its nuclear weapons. South Korea has offered talks with North Korea next week, with the goal of discussing North Korea's participation in the Winter Olympics. US President Donald Trump has responded by saying that North Korea can talk to anyone, but the US is not going to recognize it until they agree to ban nuclear weapons. North Korea has stated its intention to continue developing nuclear warheads despite UN sanctions.

images.alt_text: The US ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, warned North Korea on Tuesday against staging another missile test and said Washington would not take any talks between North and South Korea seriously if they did not do something to get Pyongyang to give up its nuclear weapons.

site_title: YouTube star apologises for viral suicide video
summary: YouTube star Logan Paul apologized for posting a viral video of a suicide victim in Japan, which was viewed by six million people before being deleted. The video, filmed in Aokigahara, a forest known for its high suicide rates, showed a man hanging himself, and Paul was seen laughing and joking about the incident in outtakes. Paul claimed he posted the video to raise awareness about depression and suicide, but acknowledged he handled the power of his platform "incorrectly." YouTube removed the video due to its violent and gory content.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 7.47 points
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 7.47 points to 3,437.77. Around 93 million shares worth S$66 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 102 to 34. The most actively traded stock was Magnus Energy, with 16.8 million shares changing hands.

site_title: How Facebook could stop a disease outbreak
summary: Researchers have found that Facebook accounts and phone records can help identify individuals most likely to spread disease-causing germs in a disease outbreak. These "central" individuals are more likely to be connected to diverse communities, making them key "bridges" for germ transmission. Vaccinating these individuals can be as efficient as existing vaccination strategies and is cheaper, as digital activity is easy to trace. This method aims to reduce the population at risk of infection and achieve "herd immunity."

site_title: Philippines suspends work at call centre of US firm, mall after deadly fire
summary: The Philippines has suspended operations of a shopping mall and a call centre in Davao City, where a fire killed 38 people in December. The New City Commercial Center and American firm Research Now SSI failed to meet fire safety requirements for five consecutive years, according to investigators. The suspension was issued by the Philippine Economic Zone Authority, citing failure to comply with safety regulations since 2013. The incident has raised concerns about fire safety lapses in the country.

site_title: New York fire injures 23, including nine children
summary: A fire in The Bronx, New York, injured 23 people, including nine children, on January 2, 2018. The blaze destroyed a three-floor building and left 11 families homeless. Four of the injured were in life-threatening condition, while a firefighter suffered minor injuries. The fire occurred just days after a deadly fire in the same borough, killing 12 people.

site_title: US dollar slides to more than 3-month low on first trading day of 2018
summary: The US dollar slid to its lowest level in more than three months, reaching a 3-1/2-month trough of 91.751, due to expectations of slower interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve amid a tepid US inflation picture. The euro rose to a nearly four-month high, while the yen benefited from the Bank of Japan's consideration of tightening monetary policy. The dollar's decline extended its underperformance in 2017, marking its weakest annual performance in 14 years.

site_title: GIC, Goldman's Vintage Funds become biggest limited partners in 2 Vector Capital funds
summary: GIC and Goldman Sachs' Vintage Funds have become the largest limited partners in Vector Capital's restructured funds, Fund II and III, following a US$450 million restructuring. The move provides more liquidity for investors and enhances investments in technology firms Corel and WatchGuard. The restructuring aims to give the companies additional capital for strategic M&A opportunities and growth strategies, with GIC and Goldman Sachs receiving a premium value for their investments. The deal is seen as a positive outcome for investors and a value-enhancing strategy for Vector Capital.

site_title: City Towers in Bukit Timah launches en bloc tender with S$355m reserve price
summary: City Towers, a 17-storey freehold property in Bukit Timah, is launching an en bloc tender with a reserve price of S$355 million. The site, which spans 9,711.3 square meters, can be redeveloped into a 24-storey apartment block with 190 new homes. The reserve price includes a development charge, and owners stand to receive S$2.45 million to S$10.17 million from the sale. The collective sale process was successful, with over 80% of owners approving the tender. The site's location near Orchard Road and prestigious schools is expected to appeal to future homebuyers.

site_title: Amazon says over 5 billion items shipped in 2017 via Prime
summary: Amazon shipped over 5 billion items worldwide via its Prime service in 2017, marking a significant milestone for the e-commerce giant. This number includes over 1 billion items shipped during the 2016 holiday season. Amazon Prime has been attracting more subscribers annually, with the service now available in 16 countries worldwide. The company's shares rose 1.5% following the announcement.

site_title: Peru bus plunge kills 36: police
summary: At least 36 people were killed in a bus plunge in Peru after the vehicle collided with a truck and was thrown off a seaside cliff. The bus, carrying 53 passengers, plunged 100 meters and landed upside down on rocks. Six people are trapped, with 30 bodies recovered and six confirmed survivors. The accident occurred on the "devil's curve" coastal highway, known for its dangers due to frequent fog and high humidity. The bus had undergone a mechanical check before the trip.

site_title: Cordlife to acquire Hong Kong private cord blood bank HealthBaby
summary: Cordlife Group has signed an agreement to acquire Hong Kong private cord blood bank HealthBaby Biotech (Hong Kong) Co, Limited for approximately US$7.0 million. The acquisition will expand Cordlife's presence in Hong Kong and Macau, with HealthBaby's Hong Kong operation having stored around 20,000 cord blood units. The deal comes as Hong Kong aims to boost its birth rate, with Chief Executive Carrie Lam announcing initiatives to encourage young couples to start parenthood early. Cordlife will assume HealthBaby's debt and treat it as an intercompany loan to its new subsidiary.

site_title: Whither rock? Beyonce, Eminem to headline Coachella
summary: Beyonce, Eminem, and The Weeknd will headline Coachella in April, marking the first time no rock act will headline the festival. Beyonce's appearance is a return after she was replaced in 2017 due to pregnancy concerns. Eminem is set to perform after releasing his latest album, while The Weeknd is a first-time headliner. The festival still features a mix of rock acts, including indie and electronic performances, amidst growing signs of hip-hop's cultural dominance in the US.

site_title: Cookie-cutter won't cut it anymore
summary: Singaporean businesses must differentiate themselves to stay competitive in a rapidly changing market. The travel, leisure, and wellness industry, in particular, is highly dependent on consumer preferences and economic conditions. SMEs must focus on uniqueness, personalization, and customization to keep customers coming back. Technology can also drive productivity and increase reach, but traditional businesses must be willing to adapt. Companies like The Warehouse Hotel, Anywhr, and 24 Saturn have found ways to carve out a niche and attract customers. SMEs that prioritize customer needs, differentiate themselves, and leverage technology can thrive in the competitive market.

site_title: US blocks MoneyGram sale to Jack Ma's Ant Financial
summary: The US government rejected Ant Financial's $1.2 billion acquisition of MoneyGram International Inc over national security concerns, citing data safety risks. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) rejected proposals to mitigate concerns, leading to the deal's collapse. The decision represents a blow to Chinese internet conglomerate Alibaba Group's executive chairman Jack Ma, who had promised to create 1 million US jobs. MoneyGram shares fell 8.5% after the news, and the companies will now explore cooperation in remittance and digital payments in Asia and the US.

site_title: That's sick! Humans identify infected peers from a photo
summary: Researchers found that humans can identify infected peers from a photo just two hours after infection, demonstrating a crucial survival skill called "disease avoidance". In a study with 16 healthy volunteers, participants were given a shot of lipopolysaccharides, mimicking flu-like symptoms, and their photos were taken. Observers rated the infected individuals based on subtle facial clues, correctly identifying 81% of them. This ability could help medical doctors and computer software detect sick people, potentially leading to a valuable diagnostic tool in disease outbreaks.

site_title: Britain wants financial services included in EU trade deal
summary: Britain's Brexit Minister David Davis stated that financial services should be included in a trade deal with the EU, calling any deal without it "cherry picking." EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier expressed doubts about the inclusion of financial services, sparking a disagreement. The inclusion of financial services in a trade deal would cover a full sweep of economic areas and is a key priority for Britain.

site_title: Singapore holds fugitive Vietnam intelligence agent: lawyers
summary: A fugitive Vietnamese intelligence officer, Phan Van Anh Vu, 42, wanted for allegedly disclosing state secrets, was arrested in Singapore on December 28, 2017, at a border checkpoint. Vu, a senior officer in the Vietnamese intelligence services, is being sought for "deliberately revealing state secrets" and could face the death penalty if repatriated. His arrest follows a year of anti-corruption crackdowns in Vietnam, including the alleged kidnapping of a Vietnamese former oil executive in Germany. Vu's lawyers are seeking asylum in Germany, arguing he could provide valuable information on the abduction.

site_title: Wing Tai names two new board directors
summary: Wing Tai Holdings has appointed two new non-executive directors, Guy Daniel Harvey-Samuel and Zulkurnain Awang, to its board. The company bid farewell to long-serving director James Lee Kim Wah, who retired at 80 after 50 years with the company. Harvey-Samuel, 60, has experience as non-executive chairman of HSBC (Singapore) Ltd, while Awang, 67, previously held positions in Malaysia's government. Wing Tai chairman Cheng Wai Keung praised Lee's contributions to the company and the wider labour community, citing his dedication to staff training and development.

site_title: Cosco cash offer for Cogent turns unconditional
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) has made its S$1.02-a-share cash offer for Cogent Holdings unconditional after receiving 92.05% valid acceptances. This move falls below 10% of Cogent shares held in public hands, leading to trading suspension. Cosco will proceed to delist Cogent Holdings from the Singapore Exchange and exercise its compulsory acquisition right. The offer remains open until January 19, with no intention of extension. Cosco plans to maintain Cogent's existing business activities with no major changes.

site_title: Ryanair applies for UK licence ahead of Brexit
summary: Ryanair has applied for a UK operating licence in case of a hard Brexit in March 2019, which could disrupt air traffic between Britain and continental Europe. The move follows similar actions by other airlines, including Wizz Air UK and easyJet, to prepare for potential Brexit fallout. Ryanair's UK subsidiary, Ryanair UK, has filed an application with the Civil Aviation Authority for an Air Operator's Certificate (AOC).

site_title: Gold prices extend rally as palladium touches record high
summary: Gold prices rose 1% to $1,315.11 per ounce, touching late September highs, driven by a softer US dollar. Spot palladium reached a record high due to fears of short supplies, after a 57% surge in 2017. Gold has risen in each trading session since December 15. US gold futures for February delivery settled up 0.52% at $1,316.10 per ounce.

site_title: Oil hits highest since mid-2015 but settles down as outages abate
summary: Oil prices reached mid-2015 highs on Tuesday before settling down due to the restart of pipelines in Libya and the UK, and a surge in US production. Crude futures hit $60.74, the highest level since June 2015, but closed at $60.37 for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) and $66.57 for Brent crude. The narrowing Brent-WTI spread was attributed to traders returning to work after the holidays. Despite this, analysts noted that rising US production could temper the bullish outlook and push the market into surplus in 2018.

site_title: Justin Timberlake gets 'personal' in first album in five years
summary: Justin Timberlake announced his first album in nearly five years, "Man of the Woods," set to release on February 2, 2018. The album is inspired by his home, family, and upbringing in Memphis, Tennessee. The 36-year-old singer and actor described the album as "personal" and "somber," hinting at a new sound. Timberlake's last full album was released in 2013, but he has been releasing music and acting in the past few years. The album will be released just two days before he headlines the Super Bowl.

site_title: Eastern US braces for more frigid weather, storm
summary: A record-shattering freeze gripped the eastern US on Tuesday, causing at least seven deaths and closing schools. Temperatures in Boston tied a 100-year-old record, with people struggling in frigid conditions. A state of emergency was declared in 28 Georgia counties, and officials urged people to seek shelter and warmth. Heavy snow was expected on the East Coast by midweek, with up to 15 inches in Maine and 2-4 inches in New York City. Multiple deaths were reported in other states, including Texas, Iowa, Wisconsin, and West Virginia, attributed to exposure to the cold.

site_title: Europe: Stocks see faltering start to 2018 as autos weigh
summary: European stocks faltered at the start of 2018, with the Stoxx 600 index dipping 0.2% due to weak autos sales and a stronger euro. Car registrations in France fell 0.51% in December, and UK car sales are forecast to decline by 5% in 2018. Basic resources stocks rose 1.2% as copper and base metal prices increased, while oil majors supported the market. Trading volumes were muted ahead of the launch of new EU financial market rules.

site_title: Recreational marijuana off to a blazing start in California
summary: California's recreational marijuana law went into effect, marking the first day of legal sales. The state's large population and booming economy are expected to make it the world's largest market. Eight states, including California, have legalized recreational marijuana, with the US federal government still outlawing it. Customers flocked to licensed shops, with some lines forming outside, and many expressed excitement and relief at being able to purchase the substance without illicit dealers. The law includes taxes, restrictions on consumption, and limits on possession and cultivation.

site_title: Trump draws rebukes after touting aviation safety record
summary: US President Donald Trump credited himself for a record year of safety in commercial aviation in 2017, stating there were zero fatal passenger jet crashes. However, two safety groups reported no fatal crashes worldwide in 2017, attributing the achievement to trends before his administration. Trump's claim drew criticism, with commentators suggesting the trend predated his presidency.

site_title: Fighting climate change, one laundry load at a time
summary: A Danish biotechnology company, Novozymes, is studying enzymes in mushrooms to develop more environmentally friendly laundry detergents. The enzymes, found in oyster mushrooms, speed up chemical reactions and can work at lower temperatures, reducing water and energy consumption. This could lead to significant energy savings, particularly in European households where washing machines account for 6% of electricity use.
