summary: California has officially launched its recreational marijuana market, with the first day of sales attracting long lines outside licensed dispensaries. The state's large population and booming economy make it expected to be the world's largest market for marijuana. Californians can purchase up to 28.5 grams of cannabis and grow up to six plants per residence. The new law prohibits consuming marijuana in public or while driving, and also restricts its use near schools. The industry is projected to be worth $5.8 billion by 2021, with many business owners investing in farms to meet the demand.

site_title: Oil marks highest January opening price since 2014
summary: Oil prices reached their highest January opening since 2014, supported by OPEC and Russia's supply cuts and strong demand, particularly from China. US WTI crude futures opened at $60.29 a barrel, while Brent crude futures opened at $66.79 a barrel. However, rising US production, on the verge of breaking 10 million barrels per day, may hinder the outlook. Global oil markets have been supported by a year of production cuts and declining oil inventories.

site_title: Australia shares flat in low-volume trade; NZ shut for holiday
summary: Australian shares remained flat on their first trading day of 2018, with the S&P/ASX 200 index marginally higher at 0028 GMT. The benchmark index fell 0.4% on the last trading day of 2017 but logged a 7% gain for the year. Investors awaited European and US data for cues, with materials stocks, such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, edging up 0.4% each.

site_title: Manulife US Reit, Keppel-KBS US Reit announce changes in response to new US tax rules
summary: Manulife US Reit and Keppel-KBS US Reit, two Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts focused on US property, have taken steps in response to US tax rule changes. The managers exercised the redemption of preferred shares, totaling approximately US$1.6 million and US$0.7 million, funded by internal resources. The Reits also restructured their lending subsidiaries, establishing directly and indirectly wholly-owned companies and a partnership in Barbados. These moves aim to mitigate the impact of the US Tax Act's changes to interest expense deductibility.

site_title: Johannesburg suffocates in shadow of mine dumps
summary: Thousands of poor South Africans, like Thabo Ngubane, live near Johannesburg's vast mine dumps, exposing them to toxic substances like arsenic, lead, and uranium. Contaminated water from the mine waste has caused health issues, including respiratory problems and cancer, in nearby communities. Despite efforts to contain the contaminants, authorities have been slow to respond, and companies have shown skepticism about the claims. A lack of direct medical evidence hinders efforts to link the mine waste to the health problems, leaving residents to suffer in the shadow of the mine dumps.

site_title: Charisma Energy names Michelle Kuah financial controller, company secretary
summary: Charisma Energy Services appointed Michelle Kuah as joint company secretary, replacing Goon Fook Wye Paul, effective January 1, 2018. Kuah, 32, previously served as group financial controller of Rotary Offshore Solutions Pte Ltd from 2013 to 2018. Goon, 38, is now group chief financial officer and joint company secretary at Ezion Holdings.

site_title: HDB resale flat prices drop 1.5% in 2017 after 0.2% dip in Q4: Flash data
summary: HDB resale flat prices dropped 1.5% in 2017, the steepest decline in 5 years, due to increased sales by HDB owners seeking to upgrade to private properties. The 0.2% dip in Q4 was encouraging compared to the previous quarter. Experts predict HDB prices may experience a positive growth of 1-2% in 2018, driven by increased demand for resale flats and the introduction of the HDB Resale Portal, which can halve the processing time for resale flats.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Chip Eng Seng, Oxley Holdings, KLW Holdings
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corp announced a proposed investment in a real estate development project in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Oxley Holdings provided further details on its investment in Australian firm Pindan Capital Mermaid Beach, stating it acquired a development site with a paid-up capital of A$100 and no assets.

site_title: At least nine dead in Brazil prison riot: report
summary: At least nine people were killed and 14 others wounded in a prison riot in Goias, Brazil, on January 1, 2018. The riot, sparked by a group of prisoners invading a rival gang's wing, led to a deadly fire that was extinguished by firefighters. More than 100 inmates escaped, with 29 recaptured by military police. This incident highlights Brazil's large prison population and turf wars between rival drug gangs, with the country having the third-largest prison population in the world.

site_title: Sunpower bags 41.5m yuan EPC contract in Xinjiang
summary: Sunpower Group secured a 41.5 million yuan EPC contract for a wastewater treatment facility in Xinjiang, China. The contract, valued at S$8.5 million, was awarded by Xinjiang GCL New Energy Material Technology Co. for the first phase of the polysilicon project. Sunpower expects the contract to positively impact its fiscal 2018 results. The company's chairman, Guo Hongxin, expressed confidence in the environmental protection sector amid government efforts to improve environmental governance.

site_title: China sets yuan mid-point at strongest level in nearly 4 months
summary: China's central bank set the yuan midpoint at 6.5079 per US dollar, the strongest level in nearly four months, due to broad US dollar weakness and solid spot yuan performance. This marks the lowest in over three months and the steepest annual drop since 2003. The yuan rose 6.8% against the dollar in 2017, reversing three years of depreciation.

site_title: South Korea won climbs to over 3-year high, stocks rise
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.23% to a three-year high, with the won strengthening to a record 1,066.4 per US dollar. The currency gain was attributed to North Korea's call for lower military tensions with the South and support from a strong yuan. The Kospi index is up 21.8% this year, while the won has fallen 11.63% against the US dollar this year.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday open, STI up 2.66 points
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.66 points, or 0.08%, to 3,405.58 points at the Tuesday open, following the US stock market's best annual gain in four years. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 33, with shares of Singtel, Golden Agri-Resources, and UOB leading the gains, while SIA fell. The Straits Times Index was active, with 61.8 million shares worth S$40.3 million changing hands.

site_title: UK's biggest house-price jumps came outside London last year
summary: The UK's biggest house-price jumps occurred outside London last year, with Cheltenham in southwest England experiencing a 13% increase, followed by Bournemouth and Brighton, both on England's south coast, with 11% gains. This contrasts with London's hotspots, where house prices rose by 10% in the eastern borough of Newham. The slowdown in house-price growth is attributed to a sluggish economy and post-Brexit uncertainty, with forecasts predicting a flat 2018.

site_title: Singapore economy beats forecasts to expand 3.1% in Q4
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 3.1% in Q4 2017, beating forecasts of 2.6% growth. Manufacturing growth, driven by electronics and precision engineering, contributed to the expansion. The construction sector continued to lag, shrinking 8.5% year-on-year. This growth rate is higher than the 5.4% expansion in the preceding quarter. The country's overall economy expanded 3.5% for 2017, more than double initial forecasts, attributed to global growth.

site_title: Compass Group chief, five others killed in Sydney seaplane crash
summary: The chief executive of British catering giant Compass Group, Richard Cousins, 58, and four family members, including his fiancée and children, were killed in a seaplane crash into a Sydney river on New Year's Eve. The pilot, Gareth Morgan, 44, also died. Cousins was due to retire on March 31 and had led Compass to become one of Britain's leading companies. A probe into the cause of the crash has begun, with a preliminary report expected within 30 days.

site_title: KLW Holdings to buy out KLW Resources at RM25m
summary: KLW Holdings agreed to buy out KLW Resources at RM25 million, acquiring 30% of the issued capital of KLW Resources, which is owned by Koperasi Permodalan Felda Malaysia Bhd. The acquisition will be funded by KLW Holdings' internal resources and a 2014 rights cum warrants issue. After completion, KLW Holdings will own 100% of KLW Resources' shares. The deal also requires KLW Resources to pay a coupon payment to KPF and waive a claim for RM2 million under a 2010 share sale agreement.

site_title: Anti-Beijing protesters march in Hong Kong
summary: Protesters in Hong Kong marched against Beijing's alleged suppression of the city's autonomy, days after Chinese authorities approved a rail link agreement that would bring part of a rail station under mainland law. The protesters, including pro-democracy activists, scuffled with police and demanded the resignation of the city leader. The "one country, two systems" deal that governs Hong Kong since 1997 is under threat, with concerns growing over erosion of autonomy and rule of law.

site_title: Ezion rejigs senior management team
summary: Ezion Holdings, a lift-boat focused offshore and marine group, announced a re-organisation of its senior management team, effective January 1, 2018. Peter Lee Kon Meng was appointed deputy CEO, while Eng Chiaw Koon became a consultant. Paul Goon Fook Wye joined as group CFO and joint company secretary, replacing Mr. Goon at Charisma Energy Services. David Poh Leong Ching was re-designated as chief business development officer and Lawrence Chan Kong Meng as chief corporate development officer and group general counsel. Cheah Boon Pin was appointed chief risk officer and chief strategy officer. The re-organisation aims to better manage the group's challenges and future growth amid a multi-year offshore and marine downturn.

site_title: Noble sets final price for sale of American ethanol unit at US$18.1m
summary: NOBLE Group completed the sale of its US-based ethanol producer, Noble Americas South Bend Ethanol (Nasbe), to Mercuria Investments for a final consideration of US$18.1 million, after an initial payment of US$18.5 million was reduced by US$0.4 million.

site_title: 'Fake News': Wide reach but little impact, study suggests
summary: A study analyzing thousands of adults' browsing histories during the 2016 US election found that fake news had a wide reach but limited impact. One in four Americans viewed at least one false story, but even the most conservative supporters of President Donald Trump consumed more real news than fake. Fake news sites primarily targeted Trump supporters, with 80% of false articles supporting him. However, false stories accounted for only 6% of Trump supporters' overall news diet, and most people encountered fact-checks but didn't read them. The study suggests that fake news reached only a subset of Americans and didn't significantly influence the election outcome.

site_title: Private home prices stage first full-year growth since 2013: URA flash estimates
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 0.7% in the fourth quarter of 2017, marking the first full-year growth since 2013, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) flash estimates. This growth contrasts with the 3.1% decline in 2016. Non-landed private home prices increased by 1.6% in prime areas, while landed home prices rose 0.6%. Property analysts predict continued growth this year, with some forecasting a 6-8% increase in the URA's private home price index.

site_title: Record-shattering US cold reaches Florida
summary: Record-shattering arctic cold reached as far south as Florida on January 1, 2018, with temperatures 20-30°F below normal across the US east of the Rocky Mountains. Freeze warnings were in place from Texas to the Atlantic Coast. The cold blast was expected to last until the next day, according to a National Weather Service meteorologist.

site_title: FLASH: URA private home price index rose 0.7% q-o-q in Q4 2017
summary: Singapore's private home price index, as measured by URA, rose 0.7% from Q4 2017 in Q4 2017. This marks a slight increase in the market. Meanwhile, globally, US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail asset in Seoul for 262 billion won, and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal.

site_title: N Korea's Kim 'open to dialogue' with S Korea, will only use nukes if threatened
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un signaled openness to dialogue with South Korea during his New Year's address, stating he was "open to dialogue" with Seoul. He also offered to send a delegation to the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, in February, potentially lowering military tensions on the Korean Peninsula. However, US officials view Kim's speech as an attempt to divide Seoul from its main ally, Washington, which has led an international campaign to pressure North Korea through sanctions. The US has not commented on the offer, with President Donald Trump saying "we'll see" in response to the address.

site_title: Asian markets closed for holidays
summary: Asian markets are closed on January 2, 2018, for public holidays in Japan, New Zealand, and Thailand. Meanwhile, global markets are experiencing volatility, with US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats. In Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag, while US-EU trade talks remain in focus. In Asia, traders are brushing off new Trump threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: 880,000 HDB households to receive utilities rebate this month
summary: Approximately 880,000 Singaporean HDB households will receive a Utilities-Save (U-Save) rebate of up to S$95, or up to S$380 annually, to offset part of their utilities bills this month. The rebate varies depending on the HDB flat type: S$95 for one- and two-room flats, S$85 for three-room flats, and S$75 for four-room flats. This is part of the GST Voucher scheme to provide assistance to households.

site_title: Trump on Iran: 'Oppressive regimes cannot last forever'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that "oppressive regimes cannot endure forever" in a tweet referencing his September speech to the UN General Assembly, where he criticized Iran's regime. Trump's comments come as protests in Iran continue for a second straight day, with the Iranian people seeking change. Trump's statement implies that the Iranian people will eventually face a choice, suggesting the regime's end is inevitable.

site_title: Compass Group chief, five others dead in Sydney seaplane crash
summary: The CEO of Compass Group Plc, Richard Cousins, and four of his close family members, including his wife Emma and children, died in a seaplane crash in Sydney Harbour on New Year's Eve in 2018. The victims were among six people on board.

site_title: Bitcoin starts a new year by tumbling, first time since 2015
summary: Bitcoin starts the year by tumbling, falling 6.1% to $13,440, marking the first decline on New Year's Day since 2015. This slide follows its record high of $19,511 reached on December 18. The cryptocurrency's price fell from $14,156 on Sunday, with its value dropping by 3.6% on the first day of 2017, which saw it rise to $998. The decline is attributed to the end of the CME Group's futures contracts, which some traders said would encourage short position-taking.

site_title: Dutch slaughtering practices undergoing changes
summary: The Netherlands is introducing new rules for slaughtering practices, balancing religious freedoms with animal rights. Starting Monday, the rules require that animals be slaughtered within 40 seconds of being shot to induce unconsciousness, and the number of animals killed for kosher and halal meat must be limited to meet the actual need of the religious communities. The changes have sparked concerns among Jewish and Muslim groups, who fear they will add to tensions with minority communities. The new rules will affect kosher and halal butchers across the country, with potential impacts on the kosher meat industry.

site_title: Forced insolvencies to help Indian bank avoid huge haircuts
summary: Punjab National Bank, India's second-largest state-run lender, will avoid massive losses due to the government's new insolvency law. The law forces delinquent borrowers to repay loans or face liquidation proceedings, allowing the bank to resolve cases quickly and avoid "huge haircuts". The government also plans to infuse 2.11 trillion rupees into cash-strapped banks, with Punjab National not needing to participate in the recapitalisation program. However, experts warn that investors remain skeptical about the size of haircuts, citing India's high soured-debt ratio and unresolved cases.

site_title: Australia home prices slip in Dec as Sydney slows
summary: Australia's major cities experienced a decline in home prices in December, with Sydney's prices dropping 0.9% and annual growth slowing to 3.1%. This slowdown follows the implementation of tighter rules on investment lending and interest-only loans by the country's bank watchdog. Melbourne's prices rose 0.2% and annual growth reached 8.9%, while home prices outside major cities increased 0.2% and 3.8% year-over-year. The decline in home prices is a relief for regulators but may have a negative impact on consumer spending power.

site_title: Here's one city turning India's mountain of trash into cash
summary: In India's city of Mysuru, a unique approach to tackling its massive trash problem has shown promise. The city's residents are participating in a door-to-door waste collection program, with workers segregating trash into compostable and non-compostable waste. The city's compost plant sells compost to farmers, and scrap dealers buy reusable items like bottles and metal. The program has resulted in nearly a quarter of the city's daily waste being processed, with the goal of achieving zero landfill. The city's success has inspired other cities to follow suit, with the federal government offering subsidies to support the growth of the waste-to-energy industry.

site_title: Cruise ships have made Bar Harbor popular. But have they ruined it?
summary: Residents of Bar Harbor, Maine, debate the impact of cruise ships on the town's character. Since the late 1990s, cruise ships have been a major draw, but their presence has led to concerns about over-tourism and commercialization. The town's scenic beauty and attractions, such as Acadia National Park, are threatened by the influx of tourists. Residents are struggling to balance the economic benefits of tourism with the need to preserve the town's essence and quality of life. A solution is needed to adapt the town to the cruise ship industry without spoiling its natural charm.

site_title: Extreme cold sparks chaos in Canada airports
summary: Extreme cold in Canada caused chaos at major airports, including Toronto, with hundreds of flights cancelled or delayed. Snow and icy conditions led to lengthy de-icing procedures, and missing crews further exacerbated the issue. Air Canada issued a travel alert and waived change fees for affected passengers. The disruptions affected four major airports, with travel expected to be hectic due to the extreme weather.

site_title: Trump threatens to cut aid to Pakistan, a 'haven to terrorists'
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to cut off $33 billion in aid to Pakistan, citing "lies and deceit" over its alleged support of terrorists. The move comes after the Trump administration considered withholding $255 million in aid due to Pakistan's failure to crack down on terror groups. Trump accused Pakistan of providing a "safe haven" to terrorists, echoing his August statement that Islamabad "gives safe haven to the terrorists we hunt in Afghanistan." Pakistan's foreign minister responded, saying the US should hold its own people accountable for its failures in Afghanistan.

site_title: China warms up for 2018 'critical battles' with cooling economy
summary: China is entering a three-year period of "critical battles" against debt, poverty, and pollution, with the government signaling a more modest economic performance in 2018 despite a strong 2017 expansion. The nation faces risks from rising US interest rates, trade-war threats, and North Korea's nuclear saber-rattling, which could impact global growth. China's financial system is vulnerable to a debt-to-GDP ratio exceeding 320% by 2022, and a slowdown in construction and trade could weigh on the broader economy, according to forecasters.

site_title: Cotton gives stellar performance in 2017
summary: Cotton experienced its longest winning streak in two decades, rising 11% in 2017, driven by growing demand for US exports and crop woes in major growers Pakistan and India. Hedge funds increased their net-long position in cotton to 102,402 futures and options by the end of 2017, up from 76,052 in 2016. This was the only crop commodity to post a gain among the nine components tracked by the Bloomberg Agriculture Subindex, which saw other crops like corn, wheat, and soya beans decline.

site_title: Always look back ... the healing power of nostalgia
summary: A study of over 700 international teachers found that repatriates who held onto the host cultural experience and experienced nostalgia for their time abroad adjusted better to life back home. This "hostalgia" was linked to increased self-continuity and psychological well-being, including lower levels of loneliness, anxiety, and depression. The study suggests that organizations can encourage returning employees to reflect on their experiences and foster a sense of nostalgia to facilitate re-entry success. Boosting employees' nostalgia for their international experiences could be an effective and low-cost strategy for improving psychological adjustment.

site_title: Iranian protesters attack police stations, raise stakes in unrest
summary: Iranian protesters attacked police stations in the central town of Qahderijan and the western city of Kermanshah, sparking a clash with security forces. Videos showed protesters occupying a police station in Qahderijan, which was partially set ablaze, and setting fire to a traffic police post in Kermanshah. The incidents are the boldest challenge to the clerical leadership since 2009, with unconfirmed reports of several casualties among demonstrators. The unrest raises concerns about the stability of the Iranian government.

images.alt_text: Iranian protesters attacked police stations late into the night on Monday, news agency and social media reports said, as security forces struggled to contain the boldest challenge to the clerical leadership since unrest in 2009.

site_title: Pakistan plans takeover of charities run by Islamist figure
summary: Pakistan's government plans to seize control of charities and financial assets linked to Hafiz Saeed, a US-designated terrorist, according to a secret order. The move aims to tackle financing terrorism, following international warnings from the FATF. Saeed's charities, Jamaat-ud-Dawa and Falah-e-Insaniat Foundation, have been accused of ties to the militant group Lashkar-e-Taiba. If implemented, the plan would mark the first major action against Saeed's network, which includes 300 seminaries and schools.

site_title: An art installation that sums up 2017
summary: An art installation titled "The Mechanics of History" by Yoann Bourgeois was on display at the Pantheon in Paris, capturing a key aspect of 2017. The installation featured men spinning off a staircase and onto a trampoline, set against a backdrop of a curved staircase and rotating circular slab. The artwork was mesmerizing and seemed to capture the essence of the year, with its themes of wonder and folly. The installation was an unexpected yet striking representation of 2017's complexities.

site_title: Solving the poorest Americans' housing problem
summary: The US housing market is increasingly squeezing the poorest fifth of households, with rising rents and falling incomes. According to a Federal Reserve Board study, poor American households now spend over 55% of their earnings on rent, leaving them with limited funds for other necessities. To address this issue, experts suggest expanding government rental assistance, building more affordable housing, and implementing eviction restrictions. These measures could help alleviate the financial burdens on low-income families and provide them with more secure and affordable housing options.

site_title: Beware of irrational trading sentiment
summary: Traders and economists disagree over the impact of the US Republican Party's planned tax cuts, with investors initially reacting positively to the prospect of lower corporate taxes. However, analysts warn of a ballooning deficit and potential negative effects on other nations. Despite this, markets continued to rise, with many attributing the gains to "cues from Wall Street." The article concludes that the real story is the irrationality of trading sentiment, with investors prioritizing short-term gains over long-term fundamentals.

site_title: US oil production booms as new year begins
summary: US crude oil production is nearing record highs, driven by shale oil drillers' innovative high-pressure drilling techniques. The US has surpassed Saudi Arabia's oil output, with petroleum-rich Saudi Arabia considering investing in the US. The Trump administration's approval of the Keystone XL pipeline and consideration of loosening offshore drilling regulations further boost production. With an average daily production of 9.6 million barrels in 2017, the US is now a significant oil producer, with the potential to export natural gas and maintain low oil prices.

site_title: New Year car torching, arrests up in France
summary: France saw an increase in car torchings and arrests on New Year's Eve, with 1,031 vehicles set ablaze and 510 arrests made. Violence also erupted in the Paris suburb of Champigny-sur-Marne, where two police officers were attacked. French President Emmanuel Macron condemned the incidents and vowed to find the perpetrators. Despite the incidents, interior minister Gerard Collomb stated that most people enjoyed a peaceful New Year's Eve. The country has been on high alert following a wave of jihadist attacks, with 140,000 security forces deployed nationwide.

images.alt_text: France saw a jump in arrests on New Year's Eve as well as an increase in the number of cars torched by vandals, a ritual among revellers in the country's high-rise suburbs.

site_title: Start weekends earlier with The Business Times
summary: The Business Times (BT) is launching changes to its weekend edition starting January 5, 2018. The Weekend Magazine will be published on Friday, featuring lifestyle trends, arts, and culture, and is included with the Friday edition of The Business Times. A new Investing section will also be introduced, with expert columns and analysis. Additionally, the weekend newspaper will feature a bigger Investing section, Brunch, Upfront, and Companies. These changes aim to cater to the lifestyle needs of business professionals.

site_title: Fire scars tight-knit NY community
summary: A devastating fire in the Bronx's Belmont neighborhood, New York, killed 12 people, mostly children, in the deadliest fire in the city in over 25 years. The fire, caused by a 3-year-old boy playing with burners, ravaged a 26-unit building, leaving a soot-black scar on the community. Residents, many with roots in Puerto Rico, Jamaica, and West Africa, described a tight-knit community where neighbors take care of each other. The building had a "relatively low history of repair violations" and was owned by D&A Equities, which expressed shock and sadness over the tragedy.

site_title: Kim warns US he will use nukes if threatened
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un warned the US that he has a "nuclear button" ready for use if threatened, but also offered improved ties with South Korea, suggesting the possibility of sending a delegation to the Winter Olympics in February. Kim declared North Korea "a peace-loving and responsible nuclear power" and called for lower military tensions on the Korean peninsula. South Korea welcomed the offer and expressed willingness to talk with North Korea to discuss participation in the Olympics and lower tensions. The US did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: Dan Talbot, impresario of art films, dies at 91
summary: Dan Talbot, a renowned impresario of art films and founder of New Yorker Films, has passed away at 91. Talbot was a key figure in the art-house film scene, operating Manhattan theaters and introducing US audiences to European filmmakers. He was known for his unwavering commitment to his artistic vision, stating, "I don't think of the box office. If it appeals to my aesthetic sense, I take a chance with it." Talbot's legacy includes introducing films like Fassbinder's "The Marriage of Maria Braun" and Riefenstahl's "Triumph of the Will."

site_title: 10 stocks to watch
summary:

Key stocks to watch include Singtel, Sinarmas Land, Cordlife, Q&M Dental Group, and PSC, which saw a mandatory offer from Sam Goi. The rally continues despite the uncertainty surrounding US-EU tariffs.

site_title: Ranking of Singapore companies by market capitalisation
summary: Singapore companies ranked by market capitalization were not discussed in the article provided. However, other key events include NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed, Creative Technology warning of potential revenue and operating loss, and Tan Teck Long being named as OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Google Street View can predict how you will vote
summary: Researchers have developed a system that uses Google Street View images to predict voting patterns, leveraging advances in AI to analyze large image datasets. The system associates certain vehicles, such as extended-cab pickup trucks with Republican districts and sedans with Democratic districts. This technology builds on decades of market research and analysis, providing insights into voter demographics. The findings could be used to inform targeted marketing and advertising strategies.

site_title: World's second largest container maker is thinking out of the box
summary: Singamas, the world's second-largest container maker, is diversifying its revenue stream by producing modified shipping containers for specialized products, including fish farming. The company has delivered over 200 units of fish-farming containers to an undisclosed buyer in China, which can fetch up to 10 times the unit selling price of a standard shipping container. This move aims to buffer against cyclical drops in demand for shipping containers, with Singamas also exploring opportunities in water desalination and offshore projects.

site_title: HSBC's time to grow again places ball in Tucker's court
summary: HSBC's new chairman Mark Tucker is tasked with growing the bank again after a period of restructuring and cost-cutting under outgoing CEO Stuart Gulliver. Despite achieving revenue growth in Asia, Tucker faces challenges defending HSBC's market share against aggressive mainland competitors and shaking up the bank's conservative culture. Tucker's experience in Asia, particularly with AIA Group, is seen as a strength, and he aims to boost profits through expansion. However, HSBC's large size and low return on assets pose significant hurdles for Tucker's growth strategy.

site_title: Defying Washington, N Koreans continue to earn wages in Poland
summary: North Korea continues to send workers to Poland, despite US pressure to expel them. At least 450 North Koreans remain in the country, employed by various companies, including a shipyard and a factory. The Polish government has pledged to phase out work permits for North Koreans, but the EU has not pressed the issue due to sovereignty concerns. China and Russia have resisted US efforts to impose a global embargo on North Korea, and the country's nuclear missile capabilities pose a threat to the US. The US has accused China of allowing fuel to be smuggled into North Korea, but China and Russia have denied these allegations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation has announced a proposed investment in a real estate development project in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, through a loan agreement and share purchase agreement. The company's subsidiary, Viet Investment Link, will provide a US$18.8 million loan to Giai Loi Investment and acquire 75% of its charter capital. Meanwhile, The Straits Trading Company has appointed two new independent directors, Tan Chian Khong and Chua Tian Chu, effective January 1.

site_title: Israeli minister encourages Iranian anti-govt protests
summary: Israeli Intelligence Minister Israel Katz expressed support for Iranian anti-government protesters, stating that success in achieving freedom and democracy would reduce threats to Israel and the region. Katz clarified that Israel's policy is not to get involved in Teheran's internal affairs, differing from US President Donald Trump's approach. The nationwide protests, which began over price rises, have drawn tens of thousands and resulted in at least 10 deaths, with widespread demonstrations and clashes between protesters and police.

site_title: Your mother's maiden name is not a secret
summary: Weak website security questions remain a common vulnerability, despite being insecure and easily guessable. Many websites, including major companies like Facebook, Amazon, and banks, continue to use these questions to prevent users from forgetting passwords. However, experts warn that security questions are easily researched or guessed, making them a weak security measure. The use of security questions persists, with some organizations opting for them over two-factor authentication due to user acceptance. Experts recommend designing questions that are unique to each individual, but this proves challenging, leaving many users vulnerable to hacking and data breaches.

site_title: Bigger is not always better in matters of governance
summary: Keppel Corp's offshore and marine unit, Keppel Offshore & Marine (KOM), has been fined US$422.2 million for corrupt payments made to Brazilian officials between 2001 and 2014. The scandal has tarnished the reputation of Singapore's corporate governance, despite KOM's cooperation and zero-tolerance policy for corruption. The incident highlights that size is not a reliable proxy for good governance, and regulators should not rely solely on a company's market capitalization to gauge its strength. This case may have broader implications for the Singapore market and the reputation of Singapore, Inc.

site_title: US tax bill likely to slow down increase in home prices
summary: The US tax bill, passed by Republicans, is expected to slow down the increase in home prices, particularly in priciest markets like the Washington region. The legislation scales back subsidies for homeownership, trimming deductions for mortgage interest and property tax. This shift is anticipated to lead to a decrease in housing prices in the coming years.

site_title: New beginnings, new possibilities
summary: A Singapore SME, Novu Medical Aesthetics, is standing out in the competitive travel and leisure industry by differentiating its products and services. Managing director Jennifer Loh emphasizes the importance of constant improvement and staying ahead of the competition. Meanwhile, other news includes a new specialist healthcare center opening in Tokyo, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and a rebranding effort by an otah business to appeal to a younger generation.

site_title: A look back at 2017 IPOs and who's coming to town in 2018
summary: IPOs on the Singapore bourse rebounded in 2017, with 20 new flotations raising S$4.7 billion, more than double the S$2.26 billion raised in 2016. Key trends included prominent involvement of cornerstone investors, such as Heliconia Capital Management, and a focus on high-growth companies. However, not all IPOs were successful, with some firms experiencing post-IPO declines. Despite this, the market remains conducive for future IPOs, with several billion-dollar start-ups and real estate investment trusts (REITs) expected to list in 2018.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018 to be delivered on Feb 19
summary: Singapore is set to deliver its 2018 Budget Statement on February 19, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat expected to outline the government's plans and tax policies. The event is anticipated to draw significant interest from households and businesses, who are eager to know if taxes will be raised. The announcement comes at a time of global economic uncertainty, with countries such as Vietnam, Malaysia, and the UK facing economic challenges.

site_title: Democrats plot to blunt impact of new tax reform
summary: Democrats in high-cost, high-tax states are exploring ways to counter the impact of the newly passed Republican tax overhaul. Governors and legislative leaders are considering legal challenges, changing state tax codes, and raising revenue through payroll taxes or charitable contributions. These measures aim to restore deductions scaled back by the new law and mitigate the effect of the $10,000 cap on state and local tax deductions. Some proposals include replacing state income taxes with payroll taxes or shifting towards corporate taxes. However, these ideas face logistical hurdles, opposition from Congress, and potential economic consequences, including increased pressure to cut spending and higher housing costs.

site_title: Saudi Arabia, UAE introduce VAT in a Gulf first
summary: Saudi Arabia and the UAE introduced a 5% value-added tax (VAT) on most goods and services, marking a first for the Gulf region. The move aims to boost revenues and cut spending, with analysts projecting $21 billion in revenue in 2018. Petrol prices in Saudi Arabia rose 127% with immediate effect, while diesel and kerosene prices remained unchanged. The introduction of VAT is part of a series of measures to diversify the region's revenue streams, following warnings from the International Monetary Fund to reduce reliance on oil.

site_title: Researchers find one in 10 US youth has been homeless
summary: A new study found that nearly 1 in 10 US youth (18-25) experienced homelessness in 2016-2017, with 3.5 million young adults and 660,000 adolescents affected. The research, conducted by Chapin Hall, used a broad definition of homelessness and included those who ran away from home or stayed with friends temporarily. The findings challenge the stereotype that homelessness affects mostly older men, with college students and employed young people also struggling to find stable housing.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Stocks in Europe declined due to bank and healthcare sector woes, while US stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US companies, including Creative Technology, warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Consumer stocks favoured as Goldilocks works her charms
summary: Global consumer stocks are favored as the economy is expected to be neither too hot nor too cold, boosting financial markets. Despite rich valuations and potential interest rate hikes, investors remain optimistic, likening the market to Goldilocks' porridge, which is "just right." Asian markets have seen significant gains, with some up 20-40% in the past year. Investors are also focusing on key sectors, including mining, healthcare, and technology, amid the US-EU trade talks and potential tariff threats.

site_title: North Sea Forties Pipeline back in operation after repairs
summary: The North Sea's Forties Pipeline System, one of the world's most important crude oil conduits, is fully operational after repairs following a hairline crack discovery. Ineos AG confirmed the pipeline's return to service, lifting restrictions on oil and gas flow and resuming crude oil loadings from the Hound Point terminal in Scotland. The pipeline, which supplies about 450,000 barrels of oil a day, was shut on December 11 and was expected to take two to four weeks to repair.

site_title: US veterans hospitals picking their patients to lift quality ratings
summary: Veterans Affairs hospitals in the US are selectively admitting patients to improve quality ratings. An 81-year-old veteran, Walter Savage, was admitted after being deemed unable to care for himself due to malnourishment and dehydration. This selective admission policy has raised concerns about unequal treatment and prioritization of patients. The practice is not a new phenomenon, with some hospitals reportedly using it to boost their ratings. The VA has declined to comment on the issue, sparking debate about the ethics of such selective admissions.

site_title: New US tax law offers carrot to gig workers
summary: The US tax law provides a 20% deduction for sole proprietors and owners of partnerships or pass-through entities, potentially luring workers into independent contractor arrangements. This could lead to a shift towards more contractors, accelerating a trend already underway, with management consultants, stockbrokers, and gig economy workers possibly opting for contracting. The tax savings could be around $15,000 per year, but may also offset by the need to pay payroll taxes. Critics warn that this could erode protections for full-time workers, including access to unemployment insurance and workers' compensation, and increase income volatility and inequality.

site_title: 3 tech keys to unlock cash flow issues
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges with cash flow management, with delays in customer payments cited as the top challenge for 2018. To address this, tech-enabled solutions such as peer-to-peer lending, online invoice financing, and instant credit can aid cash flow management. P2P lending platforms like Funding Societies have disbursed over S$100 million in loans, while online invoice financing allows SMEs to convert outstanding invoices into immediate cash. Instant credit, such as leveraging existing credit cards, can also improve short-term cash flow management.

site_title: Nudge, nudge - behavioural economics has entered the mainstream
summary: Behavioural economics has entered the mainstream, with its principles being widely adopted by governments to influence citizens' behavior. Research has shown that small interventions, such as default choices, can be effective in improving welfare and autonomy. However, the use of nudges can also be misused for nefarious purposes, such as suppressing votes or influencing consumer behavior. The Nobel Prize-winning work of Richard Thaler and Cass Sunstein has highlighted the potential benefits of behavioural economics, but also the need for caution to avoid manipulation and exploitation.

site_title: Time ripe for banks to adopt fintech solutions
summary: Banks in Singapore and Asia are ripe for adopting fintech solutions to improve efficiency, increase revenues, and capture savings. The European Union's new financial market rules, such as MIFID II, will require significant upgrades in IT systems, creating an opportunity for fintech adoption. Cloud computing, blockchain, and artificial intelligence (AI) are key technologies that can help banks address these challenges. The expected benefits of blockchain include real-time transaction processing and cybersecurity, while AI can automate complex tasks and improve decision-making. With significant upfront investment required, banks must weigh the costs and benefits of adopting these technologies to remain competitive.

site_title: Big property deals surge to 10-year high in 2017
summary: Singapore's big-ticket property deals reached a 10-year high in 2017, with investment sales totaling S$35.64 billion, up 57.3% from 2016. This includes S$17.34 billion in residential transactions and S$12.1 billion in commercial property sales. However, experts predict a tough act to follow, citing factors such as widening price gaps, reduced demand, and rising interest rates, which may lead to smaller deals in 2018.

site_title: The Straits Trading Company appoints two new directors

site_title: On-the-job experience and career outcomes
summary: On-the-job experience is crucial for career development, allowing individuals to gain true skills and proficiency. This decision affects job prospects and career advancement.

site_title: German lawmaker slams EU for opposing sale of Niki to Lufthansa
summary: A German lawmaker stated that the EU's opposition to Lufthansa's purchase of Niki, Air Berlin's Austrian unit, will likely result in Germany losing a 150 million-euro government-backed loan. The secrecy surrounding the company remains due to national security concerns.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Corp unit to invest in Ho Chi Minh real estate development

site_title: When forecasters get it wrong - always
summary: Economists were largely incorrect in their 2017 predictions, with forecasters expecting the global economy to struggle, inflation to rise, and countries like Japan, Russia, and Brazil to remain weak. site_title: Mariah Carey redeems herself on New Year's Eve
summary: Mariah Carey redeemed herself on New Year's Eve with a relatively smooth performance in Times Square, marking a significant improvement from her disastrous 2017 show. site_title: Olive Tree Estates extends key deadline for Johor land acquisition to June 30

The extension is due to the ongoing process of meeting the terms set out in the Kempas agreement, which includes regulatory documentation, approval, and shareholder confirmation.

site_title: eBay to ditch PayPal for Dutch processor Adyen; PayPal drops
summary: eBay will shift its payments business from PayPal to Adyen, a Dutch payments company, effective this year. Adyen will process eBay payments in North America starting this year and most transactions in 2021. PayPal will remain a checkout option for eBay shoppers until July 2023. The shift is expected to lower payment processing costs for merchants and provide greater options for buyers. PayPal shares dropped over 15% after the news, with analysts predicting a major setback for the company.

site_title: Lawyers Go Global programme to help Singapore law firms go abroad
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law, the Law Society of Singapore, and International Enterprise Singapore have launched the "Lawyers Go Global" programme to help local law firms expand their practices abroad. The programme will provide 35 lawyers with overseas mission trips, training, and networking opportunities in Asean countries, China, and India over the next three years. The aim is to help small and medium-sized law firms tap into growing demand for legal services in the Asia-Pacific region, projected to grow at 5.5% annually between 2014 and 2019.

site_title: US: Stocks end modestly higher after volatile session
summary: US stocks finished modestly higher on Wednesday, closing 0.3% higher at 26,149.39 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also edged up 0.1% each. The Fed left the benchmark interest rate unchanged but hinted at possible faster rate hikes due to rising inflation. Boeing surged 4.9% after reporting strong fourth-quarter profits, while 21st Century Fox fell 4.1% amid concerns over a new NFL contract. Pharmaceutical shares declined after President Trump's State of the Union Address.

site_title: Singapore an emerging hot market for private equity real estate funds
summary: Singapore is emerging as a popular market for private equity real estate funds, with an estimated US$6 billion to be deployed in the country between 2018 and 2020. The market's recovery in office rents has led to increased investment, with the top three recipients of capital expected to be Australia, Japan, and China. Core funds focus on office and logistics assets, while value-add funds target properties with upgrading potential, and opportunistic funds seek to capitalize on development risks.

site_title: Global cancer survival rates improve, but wide gaps remain: study
summary: Global cancer survival rates have improved, with some of the deadliest types like lung cancer showing progress, but disparities remain. A study analyzing 37.5 million adults and children found wide variations in survival rates between countries, with wealthy nations like the US, Canada, and Sweden having the highest rates. In contrast, countries like Mexico and Brazil have significantly lower survival rates, often due to variations in cancer diagnosis and treatment services. Despite improvements, cancer still claims over 100,000 children worldwide each year.

site_title: US probing Apple on updates that slow older iPhones: sources
summary: The US Department of Justice and Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating Apple over its disclosure of a software update that slowed older iPhone models, raising concerns of potential securities law violations. The government requested information from Apple, and the company confirmed it had received questions from government officials. Apple claims it never intended to shorten the life of its products or degrade user experience, but shares fell less than 1% amid reports of weaker iPhone X sales. The investigation is in its early stages, and it's unclear if any enforcement action will follow.

site_title: Datapulse says it might restart disk drive manufacturing
summary: Datapulse Technology, a mainboard-listed company in Singapore, may consider restarting its disk drive manufacturing operations if suitable premises are found. The company has finished disposing of its factory in Tai Seng Drive and has shifted its registered office to an office unit in Beach Road. Datapulse's former management scaled down operations and retrenched staff, but the company has retained some equipment. A board of directors recently stated that the business is not viable, sparking a shareholder revolt. The decision to restart manufacturing depends on finding new premises and changes to the company's business direction.

site_title: LY Corp closes 19% higher on first trading day
summary: LY Corp's shares closed 19.2% higher on its first trading day on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, reaching S$0.31. This was 19% above its initial public offering price of S$0.26. The company saw 17.2 million shares worth S$5.1 million change hands.

site_title: Trump's heavy tariffs - an oft-used tactic with uncertain effects
summary: The Trump administration has announced heavy tariffs on imported washing machines and solar panels, with rates ranging from 20-50% and 30% respectively. Economists argue that tariffs can benefit a small number of businesses with political clout, but ultimately harm the entire economy, including consumers. summary: Oxley Holdings has provided more details about its investment in Australian firm Pindan Capital Mermaid Beach, a dormant entity with a paid-up capital of A$100 (S$104) and no assets. site_title: US: Stocks fall from records ahead of tech giant earnings
summary: US stocks fell from record highs on Monday ahead of a busy earnings season, including reports from tech giants Apple and Facebook. site_title: BOJ will not mint digital currency as cash is still king in Japan
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has ruled out minting a digital currency, citing Japan's reliance on cash and the lack of demand for a digital currency. According to Yuko Kawai, head of the BOJ's FinTech Center, the nation's cashless living isn't making significant progress, making a digital currency unnecessary. The decision reflects Japan's preference for traditional cash over digital currency for now.

site_title: Agile unit plans to raise HK$4.7b in HK IPO
summary: Agile Group Holdings' property management unit, A-Living Services, plans to list on the Hong Kong mainboard, raising up to HK$4.7 billion. The IPO will see the issuance of 333.33 million shares priced between HK$10.80 and HK$14.20 per share. The funds raised will be used for investments, acquisitions, and upgrading operations. This marks Agile's expansion into the Hong Kong stock market, following its China focus.

site_title: Chinatown Plaza up for collective sale, asking S$270m
summary: Chinatown Plaza in Singapore has been put up for collective sale with an asking price of S$270 million. The site, zoned for commercial and residential use, offers a gross floor area of 12,610.89 sq m and can be redeveloped up to 3.5 times its plot ratio. The property is near the Central Business District and has potential for mixed-use redevelopment, including serviced apartments or a hotel. A separate redevelopment site in Geylang Lorong 18 is also being offered for S$36 million, with a 99-year leasehold tenure.

site_title: Dell considering sale to VMware in reverse merger
summary: Dell Technologies Inc, led by CEO Michael Dell, is considering a sale to VMware Inc through a reverse merger, aiming to consolidate power and reduce debt. Dell owns 80% of VMware, acquired in 2015, and may shift debt onto VMware's balance sheet. The combined entity would maintain VMware's management, with Dell as a parent company. The transaction would also eliminate a tracking stock tied to VMware's value. The deal would be the largest tech merger in history, with Dell seeking to pay down debt and expand its offerings for clients.

site_title: Trump calls for unity after contentious first year
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered his first State of the Union address, calling for national unity and strong borders while highlighting the economy's robust performance. He emphasized the need for immigration reform, citing social ills and economic tension, while also warning of the threat posed by North Korea's nuclear drive. Trump's tone was conciliatory, but his stance on immigration remained unchanged. The address was watched by 40 million Americans, with some criticizing its impact and Trump's approval ratings still languishing around 40%.

site_title: Nigeria's Southwest cocoa belt hit by dieback disease
summary: Cocoa farms in southwestern Nigeria's main growing region have been affected by dieback disease, causing widespread tree deaths and estimated losses of 750 metric tons of cocoa. The disease is prevalent in shallow rock regions, denying tree roots access to nutrients. Nigeria, the seventh-largest cocoa producer worldwide, may experience significant economic losses from the infections, particularly with its two cocoa harvests in April-June and October-December. The Cocoa Farmers Association of Nigeria has reported 2,500 infected trees in Ogun state, contributing 10% of the country's cocoa production.

site_title: Alphabet's Chronicle unit aims to thwart cyber attacks
summary: Alphabet's Chronicle, a new business unit, aims to prevent cyber attacks by developing a technology platform to help companies manage security-related data. The platform will include VirusTotal malware intelligence service, leveraging Alphabet's machine learning and search capabilities. Chronicle, which began as an X project two years ago, is working with Fortune 500 companies to test its cybersecurity intelligence platform, with the goal of giving "the good guys" an advantage against cyber crime and generating new revenue streams for Alphabet.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip at end of strong month
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, ending at their lowest in three weeks, due to investors locking in profits at the end of a strong January. Despite this, the Stoxx 600 index still gained 2.1% for the month. Recent bond market concerns and a rising euro were offset by optimism over earnings and economic growth.

site_title: Out of the loop
summary: Women's health remains under-served by medical technology, despite growing awareness and need. The Essure contraceptive device, which was recalled due to autoimmune reactions, and pelvic organ prolapse mesh, which caused debilitating pain and injury, are examples of the issues. The industry has yielded over $360 billion in revenue, but the women's health segment remains under-represented and under-served. Experts say the lack of interest in women's health is due to a combination of factors, including a lack of entrepreneurial talent and funding for long-term research and development. Venture capital firms are starting to take notice, investing in startups focused on women's health, such as Carmentix and Escala Medical. However, more needs to be done to support early-stage companies and provide guidance on commercialization and regulatory compliance.

site_title: UBS Asia-Pac pulls in record 2017 growth in assets
summary: UBS Asia-Pacific achieved a record year of growth in assets under management in 2017, with invested assets rising 28% to 373 billion Swiss francs. This marks the strongest year since 2010, driven by robust stock market performance and a surge in net new monies, which increased 37% to 28.4 billion Swiss francs. Despite a flat number of advisers, the unit's growth rate has been consistent, with a 20% annual compounded growth over the last two years.

site_title: Completed condo prices 0.6% higher in December than November: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed private apartments and condos saw a 0.6% price increase in December compared to the previous month, according to the National University of Singapore's latest flash estimates. This marks a decrease from the 1.6% rise in November. The National University of Singapore's Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) released the revised index value for the previous month.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on strong earnings, soft dollar

Investors appeared to brush off weaker-than-expected US economic growth data, with gains in technology stocks and a decline in the dollar helping to offset concerns.

site_title: Beware of Geeks bearing gifts
summary: A year after Donald Trump's presidency, the US and the world are increasingly vulnerable to cyber threats from North Korea, Russia, and China. The US's lack of decisive action against these threats, combined with its own aggressive cyber spying, creates a perceived opportunity for enemies to drive their agendas. The rise of fake news and disinformation on social media platforms like Facebook has the potential to influence elections and undermine democracy. The repeal of net neutrality policy in the US also allows Internet service providers to selectively block content and influence public opinion.

site_title: UBS seeking to keep as much as possible in UK amid Brexit
summary: UBS is planning to keep a significant number of jobs and business in the UK amid Brexit, favoring a centralized model for efficiency. The bank's investment banking head, Andrea Orcel, stated that UBS aims to retain "as much as we can in the UK." This move follows similar plans by other global investment banks, such as Deutsche Bank, which is expected to move hundreds of jobs. UBS had initially considered Frankfurt as its trading headquarters but now appears to prefer a European financial center that can balance New York.

site_title: Europe: shares dip as focus turns to ECB amid rising euro
summary: European shares fell 0.2-0.4% on Thursday as investors await the European Central Bank's reaction to a rising euro and a weakening dollar. The STOXX 600 index dropped 0.2%, while Germany's DAX fell 0.4%. Trading updates from companies like Diageo and Next influenced the market, with some stocks rising despite the overall decline. The ECB's Draghi is expected to maintain a dovish tone, and analysts predict a moderate decline in the euro.

site_title: Brent oil hits US$71 for 1st time since 2014 as dollar drops, US stocks decline
summary: Brent oil prices reached a 4-year high of $71 per barrel, driven by supply cuts led by OPEC and Russia, a weakening US dollar, and falling US crude inventories. The US dollar's lowest level since 2014 also contributed to the price surge. Crude inventories have fallen for 10 consecutive weeks, while US oil production is nearing 10 million barrels per day. Analysts predict oil prices could rise further, potentially leading to inflationary effects.

site_title: Iranian women wave white flags, but it's hardly a surrender for them
summary: In Tehran, a small group of Iranian women, inspired by an exiled journalist, have begun publicly removing their headscarves in protest of the country's Islamic laws governing personal conduct. The protests, which started with one woman in December and escalated to six on January 31, have sparked applause and admiration from some, but also criticism and arrest. The women are challenging the government's authority and demanding the right to decide for themselves what to wear, with some activists predicting more protests to follow.

images.alt_text: Many Iranians have grown resentful of rules that they can see for themselves are out of step with most of the rest of the world and have taken to flouting them whenever and wherever they feel free enough to do so.

site_title: Future perfect
summary: Forrester CEO George Colony says artificial intelligence (AI) is overblown and overstated, despite its potential to lead to a brighter future. Colony is concerned that AI's "artificial stupidity" could result in people getting hurt, particularly in situations where humans are not paying attention, such as while driving. He notes that AI is not yet at the level of human intelligence, and the Turing test is still a long way off. Colony believes that AI will have significant uses in the future, particularly in customer experience and empowerment. However, he also warns about the importance of addressing issues such as privacy, inequity in the technology market, and the impact of AI on jobs. Colony is optimistic about the future, but emphasizes the need for leadership to understand and plan for the workforce transition that will be brought about by AI.

site_title: Oil hedge fund BBL sees crude at US$80 after Opec cuts
summary: Oil hedge fund BBL Commodities LP predicts Brent crude will rise to US$80 a barrel this year due to Opec's production cuts and low inventories. Founder Jonathan Goldberg believes the market is underestimating the impact of these cuts, which he expects to lead to a 15% increase in Brent prices. He also anticipates further backwardation in the oil market, where spot prices are expected to outpace future prices. Goldberg notes that Opec's discipline in cutting output is crucial to maintaining high oil prices, and warns that a faltering commitment could lead to sharp price declines.

site_title: Grumpy Cat wins US$710,000 court payout
summary: Grumpy Cat, whose real name is Tardar Sauce, has won a US$710,001 court payout after a copyright infringement case in California federal court. The case was sparked by a deal between Granade Beverage and Tabatha Bundsen, Grumpy Cat's owner, over the use of the cat's face in iced coffee drinks. A jury ruled in favor of Bundsen, awarding her the amount, which is believed to be the first time an internet meme has won a court victory.

site_title: SIA launches its blueprint for digital innovation
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has launched a digital innovation blueprint to stay ahead in the competitive aviation sector. The airline plans to invest "hundreds of millions of dollars" in digital efforts, partnering with government agencies like A*Star and the National University of Singapore. The partnership aims to drive the use of technologies like virtual reality and data analytics to improve predictive maintenance, customer service, and aircraft operations. The airline's goal is to become the leading digital airline in the world, with a focus on reducing costs, increasing efficiency, and enhancing the passenger experience.

images.alt_text: SIA chief executive Goh Choon Phong (left) presenting a gift to Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran at the launch of the SIA Group's Digital Innovation Blueprint.

site_title: A closer look at the iris
summary: An ophthalmologist discusses the unique characteristics of the iris, a key component of the eye, and its role in controlling vision and providing insights into overall health. The iris can be used for identification purposes, similar to fingerprints, and has been incorporated into national identity registries and border control systems. Its pigment, nerves, and muscle fibers can reveal information about an individual's racial origin, emotional state, and health conditions, such as glaucoma. The iris can also be damaged or altered due to surgery or accidents, requiring repair. Advances in iris-tracking technology have improved eye surgeries, including LASIK and cataract operations.

site_title: Singapore office rents expected to lead increases among Asian cities
summary: Singapore office rents are expected to post the largest gains among Asian cities, with a 25% surge forecast over the next two years. The extra office space tracked by the firm is expected to reach 120 million square feet in 2018, with rents forecast to climb to US$100.80 per square foot in 2019, from US$80.53 psf in 2017. This marks the best office leasing market conditions since the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Committee flags recurrent lapses in IT, finance in govt agencies
summary: The Public Accounts Committee in Singapore found recurring weaknesses in IT controls and financial management across government agencies. The committee cited lapses such as giving staff unnecessary access rights and failure to remove user accounts, despite previous Auditor-General reports. The committee called on agencies to adhere to IT policies and controls, and for heads to hold staff accountable for non-compliance. The issues were found in areas including the Ministry of Social and Family Development, where 595 instances of "inappropriate access" were discovered, and 717 incorrect reimbursements were made to employers.

site_title: Asian stocks at cheapest relative to US in at least 13 years
summary: Asian stocks are trading at their cheapest relative to US stocks in at least 13 years, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The MSCI Asia Pacific is trading close to a 13-year low on a forward price-to-earnings basis, and at the cheapest in 16 years on a price-to-book basis. This is despite Asian stocks beating US stocks last year, with emerging market equities, which have a heavy representation of Asian shares, being as cheap as they were after the 1997 Asian financial crisis.

site_title: China's new home prices up in most cities despite govt curbs
summary: China's new home prices rose in most cities in December, despite the government's efforts to curb property speculation. In 57 of 70 tracked cities, new home prices increased, with the largest gains in second-tier cities and third-tier towns. The provincial capital of Kunming saw a 2.6% increase, while prices in major cities such as Shanghai and Beijing remained relatively stable. Analysts predict prices will continue to rise, driven by an undersupply of land, potentially leading to a 3-5 year price hike.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific ties up with Tong Eng group MD to buy Kismis View in collective sale for S$102.75m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has partnered with Tong Eng Group's MD Teo Tong Lim to acquire Kismis View, a 43-unit residential site in Upper Bukit Timah, for S$102.75 million. The site has a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and can be redeveloped into a low-rise apartment development. The sale price reflects a land rate of S$941 psf per plot ratio, with owners expected to receive gross sale proceeds of between S$1.6 million and S$3.3 million. This is the third joint venture between Roxy-Pacific and Tong Eng Group.

site_title: Global stocks rise, shrugging off US shutdown fears
summary: Global stock markets reached all-time highs on Friday, shrugging off fears of a US government shutdown. The S&P and Nasdaq finished at record levels, while the Dow gained. Investors are focused on corporate earnings reports and do not expect a prolonged shutdown to impact the economy. Analysts believe politicians will avoid a long-term shutdown, and a shutdown would not affect the US government's top rating. European markets also rose, with Frankfurt and London advancing.

site_title: Spackman Entertainment appoints interim CEO, after founder stepped down in Dec

Lee is chairman and interim CEO of Spackman Equities Group, and director of Spackman Media Group. The company also announced other board changes, including the appointment of Na Kyoungwon as executive director and the re-designation of Anthony Wong as non-executive and independent chairman. The restructuring aims to improve the group's business process and operations.

site_title: Microsoft sees need for laws, regulations on advances in Artificial Intelligence
summary: Microsoft is calling for new laws and regulations on advances in Artificial Intelligence, citing the need for companies to be held responsible for potential harm caused by "unreasonable practices." The tech giant, which has been a 25-year participant in AI research, believes companies need to take responsibility and advocate for protections and benefits for workers in the gig economy. Microsoft plans to codify its ethics and design rules for AI over the next two years, with the development of laws expected to come several years later. The company's president and chief legal officer, Brad Smith, will discuss these ideas at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

site_title: Apple needs to admit it still has a labour problem
summary: Apple needs to acknowledge its ongoing labor issues in its supply chain, despite efforts to improve working conditions and environmental protection. Investigative reports have uncovered poor working conditions, excessive overtime, and safety violations at suppliers like Catcher Technology and Foxconn Technology Group, which assembles iPhones for Apple. The company's auditing process is found to be ineffective, allowing suppliers to game the system. Apple needs to take greater responsibility for ensuring its suppliers meet labor standards, including deploying undercover investigators, implementing financial incentives, and sourcing safety equipment directly to workers.

site_title: China bond selloff won't signal global bear market
summary: China's onshore bond market experienced a significant selloff in 2017, driven by financial deleveraging and reflation efforts, rather than concerns over China's sovereign health.
