China's monetary policy will continue to prioritize financial stability and deleveraging in 2018, making it a cautious market for investors.

site_title: WTA Finals to move to China for next 10 years
summary: The WTA Finals, the elite women's tennis season-ending event, will move to Shenzhen, China for 10 years from 2019 to 2028. The 10-year deal doubles the event's prize money to $14 million in 2019 and includes a new $450 million facility with a 12,000-seat indoor stadium in downtown Shenzhen. The move deepens the tour's commitment to China, a crucial market, and marks a significant shift in the event's location.

site_title: Indonesian president replaces social affairs minister in modest reshuffle
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo replaced the social affairs minister, Khofifah Indar Parawansa, in a modest Cabinet reshuffle. Idrus Marham, a Golkar party member, took the position, replacing Parawansa who is standing for election in East Java province. Widodo also appointed a new chief of staff, Moeldoko, a retired military chief. The reshuffle is seen as a preparation for the 2019 legislative and presidential elections, with some ministers requesting leaves of absence to participate in regional elections.

site_title: 'Fire and Fury' to get TV adaptation: reports
summary: "Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House," a tell-all book by Michael Wolff, is set to be adapted for television after its rights were acquired by Endeavor Content. The book, which questions Trump's fitness for office, has been dismissed as "phony" and "complete fantasy" by Trump and his spokeswoman. Despite Trump's claims, the book's publisher has moved forward with the TV adaptation, with Wolff as executive producer. The project's development comes as Trump has sought to halt publication of the book, labeling it "libelous."

site_title: Storm to disrupt traffic at Amsterdam airport on Thursday
summary: Air France-KLM has cancelled 228 European flights to and from Amsterdam's Schiphol airport on Thursday due to a storm expected to disrupt traffic at the Dutch national airport. Runway capacity will be severely restricted, with heavy winds making ground handling operations impossible. Passengers of other flights can expect delays throughout the day. The storm is set to impact Schiphol on Thursday morning, with KLM advising passengers to check for updates before their flights.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Developing, drawing unicorns to Singapore a possible growth strategy: SME panel
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has proposed a growth strategy that includes developing and attracting "unicorns" to Singapore, or startups valued at over US$1 billion. The SME Committee (SMEC) recommends incentives such as grants and tax breaks to entice unicorns to set up base or relocate in Singapore, with a minimum equity stake of 30% required. The goal is to make Singapore a hub for high-potential startups and investors, creating jobs and promoting partnerships between large companies and SMEs.

site_title: Finishing on a high
summary: Bassam Salem, CEO of Citi Private Bank Asia-Pacific, is retiring at 60 after a 37-year career in banking. Salem, who survived the 2008 Mumbai terror attack, made a promise to himself to retire early if he survived. During his tenure, Citi Private Bank achieved a 23% revenue growth and US$218 billion in assets under management. Salem attributes the challenges facing the industry to an oversupply of banks, not regulation and compliance. He believes private banks are targeting the wrong clients and lack differentiation, leading to low profitability. After retiring from banking, Salem plans to launch "Obuhi," a platform to help people find work independently.

site_title: A Black And White Story
summary: The Business Times Weekend Magazine explores Singapore's colonial black and white houses, now rented out as homes or converted into restaurant spaces. The Tzu Chi Daai Gallery, located in Sembawang, showcases the foundation's history and charitable work. Visitors can learn about the organization's efforts in disaster relief and helping the less fortunate, amidst a peaceful and natural environment. The gallery is open free of charge and offers a unique space for relaxation and self-reflection.

images.alt_text: This black and white bungalow is now home to the Tzu Chi Daai Gallery.
A quiet reading corner in the Gallery.Tower at Jurong Hill Park.

site_title: Piracy, armed robbery incidents rose in Asia last year: report
summary: Piracy and armed robbery incidents against ships in Asia rose 19% in 2017, with 101 reported incidents, compared to 85 in 2016. The most severe incidents declined by over 50% in 2017. The majority of incidents occurred in the Straits of Malacca and Singapore, and South China Sea, with 85 being armed robbery and 16 piracy incidents.

site_title: First Reit secures up to S$400 million in syndicated secured loans from OCBC
summary: FIRST Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) secured up to S$400 million in syndicated secured loans from OCBC Bank. The facilities, consisting of term loans and a revolving credit facility, will be used to refinance outstanding loans, fund property investments, and meet working capital requirements. OCBC will be the mandated lead arranger and bookrunner for the facilities, fully underwriting them subject to certain terms and conditions. The loans will have a three-year, four-year, and five-year term, with each facility having a maximum quantum of S$100 million.

site_title: MLT's Q3 DPU rises on stable portfolio performance and new acquisitions
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 24.5% increase in income available for distribution to S$58.3 million in Q3, driven by stable portfolio performance and new acquisitions. Distribution per unit rose to 1.907 Singapore cents, despite an enlarged unit base. The trust's gross revenue grew 2.8% to S$98.2 million, with higher contributions from existing properties in Hong Kong and Australia. MLT's net property income expanded 3.9% to S$83 million. The trust's shares closed two cents lower at S$1.35.

site_title: Hugo Boss sales pick up at stores, online and in US
summary: Hugo Boss reported a 5% currency-adjusted sales increase in the fourth quarter, driven by store growth, online sales, and a recovery in the US market. Sales rose 1% to 735 million euros, beating analyst forecasts. The company revamped its core brands, closed loss-making stores, and overhauled its website. Sales from its own retail business rose 7% and online sales jumped 42% after improving its website and search engine ranking. Hugo Boss expects its 2017 EBITDA to be in line with its forecast.

site_title: False 'missile alert' in Hawaii sparks anger, demands for answers
summary: A false ballistic missile alert in Hawaii on Saturday caused widespread panic, with authorities admitting the "wrong button was pushed" during a shift change. The alert was issued at 8:00 am, but it took nearly 40 minutes for a corrected message to be issued, sparking anger and demands for answers. Hawaii's governor and the Federal Communications Commission have promised a full investigation into the incident, which was described as "totally unacceptable" by the state's governor.

site_title: New Zealand food prices fall in December, pointing to weaker Q4 inflation
summary: New Zealand's food prices dropped 0.8% in December for the fourth consecutive month, indicating weaker inflation. This decline, mainly due to pre-Christmas discounts, suggests a lower consumer price index (CPI) in the fourth quarter. The fall in food prices adds downside risk to economists' forecasts and may prompt the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to keep interest rates on hold. The move is seen as a positive for the New Zealand dollar, which fell to US$0.7234 after the announcement.

site_title: Saudi Arabia begins screening films after decades-long ban lifted
summary: Saudi Arabia has begun screening feature-length animated children's films in a makeshift theatre after lifting a 35-year ban on cinemas. The first permanent theatres could open as early as March, part of a liberalising reform drive that includes concerts, comedy shows, and women drivers. The government plans to open 300 cinemas with 2,000 screens by 2030, aiming to contribute $31.7 billion to the economy and create 30,000 jobs. Films will be censored to align with the kingdom's "moral values."

site_title: Singapore shares open up on Friday morning, with STI up 0.42% at start of trading
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.42% at 3,527.55, following a 7.77-point slip at Thursday's close. Gainers outnumbered losers 111-29, driven by a lift in energy stocks amid Brent crude's overnight surge. Addvalue Technologies and Singtel rose, while Singapore Press Holdings gained 0.38% ahead of its Q1 results release.

site_title: Saudi Prince Alwaleed in settlement talks with govt: sources
summary: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, detained for over two months in an anti-corruption crackdown, is in settlement talks with authorities, but no agreement has been reached. The billionaire prince, chairman of Kingdom Holding, has a net worth estimated at US$17 billion. His detention is part of a broader anti-corruption effort led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The outcome of the negotiations is uncertain, but a settlement is seen as a possible outcome.

site_title: London, HK next in line to receive SIA's new A380 cabin products
summary: Singapore Airlines will introduce its new Airbus A380 cabin products on London and Hong Kong routes starting February 16, with the London route operating as SQ322 and the Hong Kong route as SQ860. The airline is investing US$850 million to upgrade 19 A380s with new luxury Suites and Business Class seats, offering more stowage space and separate beds. The refreshed cabins will be available across the entire A380 fleet by 2020, replacing 14 aircraft currently in service.

site_title: Declines in major industries drag China factory inflation down
summary: China's factory inflation slowed to a 13-month low in December, with the producer price index (PPI) rising 4.9% year-on-year, its lowest rate since November 2016. The decline was due to falls in five major industries, including oil and natural gas mining. Consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.8% year-on-year, just below forecasts. The data suggests continued fragility in China's economy, but analysts expect moderate inflation to boost consumption.

site_title: Didi Chuxing to launch bike-sharing platform and brand
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing firm, plans to launch a bike-sharing platform within its app, partnering with Ofo and Bluegogo. The platform will offer deposit-free arrangements and host multiple bike-sharing brands. Following a bike-sharing craze in China, the business has shown signs of strain, with companies like Ofo and Mobike facing challenges. This move aims to capitalize on the trend and expand Didi's offerings.

site_title: China's factory inflation eases to lowest since November 2016
summary: China's factory inflation eased to 4.9% in December, the lowest level since November 2016, due to slowing output and higher year-ago base comparisons. This easing of factory prices may reduce pressure for the People's Bank of China to raise borrowing costs, alleviating bond market pressures. Policymakers signaled a "prudent and neutral" monetary policy approach, with no immediate plans to raise interest rates. Experts attribute the easing to a "high-base factor" and suggest the near-term outlook for interest rate hikes remains unchanged.

site_title: Yen climbs as BOJ move fuels tightening speculation
summary: The Japanese yen reached a five-day high against the US dollar after the Bank of Japan trimmed its purchases of long-dated government bonds, fueling speculation of a potential exit from its stimulus policy. The yen rose 0.3% to 112.81 yen per dollar, while the euro slipped 0.2% to a 10-day low of $1.1941. Many analysts believe a correction is inevitable for the euro after its 5% rally in six weeks, driven by signs of a strong eurozone economy.

site_title: Staying healthy to a ripe old age
summary: Scientists are working to enhance human healthspan, or the period of healthy life, by understanding and addressing the mechanisms of cellular aging. Researchers have discovered that cellular aging is linked to DNA damage and epigenetic changes, which can lead to genetic disorders and premature death. A potential solution involves reprogramming or transdifferentiating cells to restore their youthful state, with promising results in animal experiments. The discovery of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) and the use of specific proteins to reprogram cells have shown promise in reversing cellular aging. While challenges remain, this new approach may one day lead to increased healthspan and longevity.

images.alt_text: An image of human cells (above). When cells divide and multiply, it is natural for some of the DNA at the telomeres to be lost, resulting in shortening of the telomeres. Once the telomere length is critically shortened, the cell will undergo destruction.

site_title: Maybank KE kicks off Venture coverage with 'buy' call, above-consensus target price
summary: Maybank Kim Eng has initiated coverage of Venture Corporation with a "buy" call and a target price of S$27.50, the highest in town, beating the analyst consensus of S$24.35. The company is expected to see a 39% surge in revenue to around S$4 billion in FY results, driven by growth from major customers and investments in research and development. Analysts attribute the stellar performance to "multifaceted" growth prospects, despite some downside risks, including customer demand and currency fluctuations.

site_title: Mentor extraordinaire
summary: John Bittleston, an 85-year-old British businessman, is a prolific mentor and career coach to executives. Over the past 25 years, he has mentored thousands of people, including business executives and young writers. Bittleston, who built his career in advertising and later in the food industry, emphasizes the importance of purpose, creativity, and treating people well. He attributes his success to his "good fortune" from four influential people in his life, including his mentors and wives. Bittleston is known for his witty and insightful writings, which he shares in his "Daily Paradox" column. He advocates for a more human-centered approach to business and life, and has expressed his desire to see Singapore become a "canopied, air-conditioned, tsunami-protected city" with electric vehicles.

site_title: Saudi said to weigh increasing size of US$10b existing loan
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering increasing the size of a $10 billion loan from banks, including HSBC, JPMorgan, and Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ. The loan, which was initially agreed upon in 2016, could be expanded by up to $5 billion. The move aims to bridge the country's expected $52 billion budget deficit and fund growth plans. Saudi Arabia plans to borrow $31 billion this year, up from $36 billion last year. Final decisions have not been made, and discussions may not result in a new deal.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank KE puts a 'buy' on Venture Corp, with bullish target price of S$27.50
summary: Maybank KE initiated coverage of Venture Corp with a "buy" call and a target price of S$27.50, surpassing the analysts' consensus of S$24.35. The brokerage expects the group's revenue to surge by 39% in 2017 to S$4 billion, driven by growth from potential customers such as Broadcom and Thermo Fisher Scientific. Venture's research and development investments are also expected to contribute to its growth prospects. The target price is based on an estimated price-to-earnings ratio of 18.8 times.

site_title: MAS puts more scrutiny on bank loans for property development
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is scrutinizing bank loans for property development, following a spate of aggressive land deals by developers last year. The MAS is collecting data on key covenants and loan-to-value ratios from banks, and expects them to adopt sound credit underwriting standards. Industry players believe the MAS is paying more attention to en bloc and government land sale tenders due to high loan-to-value ratios. The MAS has already taken measures in Hong Kong, where it lowered construction financing caps, but its effectiveness is debated.

site_title: Juncker seeks bigger EU budget despite Brexit
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker called for EU nations to increase their budget contributions to fill the Brexit void and meet growing needs on defense, migration, and climate change. The proposed 1.1% of GDP increase aims to replace Britain's 0.1% contribution after its departure in 2019. The EU budget, currently set at 963 billion euros, will be revised to address growing needs and fund European policies.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after report China may slow US bond buys
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Wednesday, down 0.26% due to a report that China may slow or halt purchases of US government debt. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 65.71 points to 25,320.09, while the S&P 500 lost 8.51 points to 2,742.78 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 33.98 points to 7,129.60. The news caused concern among investors, leading to a decrease in stock prices.

site_title: MiFID II seen driving 20% cut in EU funds' external research budgets
summary: EU fund managers have cut their 2018 investment research budgets by 20% due to MiFID II, a European Union law requiring asset managers to separate payments for research from trades. The decline is driven by more selective fund managers buying research from a smaller number of banks. Continental European fund managers have made the largest cuts, with a 32% decline, compared to a 17% drop in the UK. The trend is expected to spread globally, with 54% of respondents predicting MiFID-style unbundling practices will be adopted outside of Europe in the next five years.

site_title: Australian shares hit 10-year closing high; NZ recovers
summary: Australian shares reached a 10-year closing high, driven by solid commodity prices and mining stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% to 6,138, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gaining 1.7% and 2.3% respectively. Chinese iron ore futures surged 3% amid steel production cuts, boosting Australian metals and mining stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index closed up 0.1%, following Monday's losses, while energy stocks also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Toyota to Hyundai say pump brakes on hopes of robo-car's arrival
summary: Top executives from Toyota, Hyundai, and ride-hailing service Lyft have tempered expectations about the arrival of self-driving cars, stating that truly driverless vehicles are years away. Toyota and Hyundai project a longer timeline, with Toyota targeting 2020 and Hyundai aiming for 2021, for Level 4 capability. The companies acknowledge significant hurdles, including replicating human intuition and overcoming regulatory challenges. Executives also emphasize the need for human drivers for the foreseeable future, with Lyft's chief strategy officer predicting an increase in drivers over the next decade.

site_title: Show rescues photo comics from dustbin of history
summary: A major museum retrospective in France is showcasing photo comics, a genre infamous for its stilted storylines and sugary romantic melodramas, but also a significant pop cultural success in postwar Europe. The "Roman-Photo" exhibition at the Mucem museum in Marseille features works by creators who initially scorned their own creations, but which now reflect changing moral values and fed the rise of feminism with stories about taboo subjects. The genre, which was popular among one in three French people in the 1960s, has been reevaluated, with curators arguing that photo comics are "modern fairy tales" that deserve a more positive reputation.

site_title: Saudi king orders new allowances to offset rising cost of living
summary: Saudi King Salman ordered a monthly payment of 1,000 riyals to state employees and 5,000 riyals to military personnel in compensation for rising cost of living due to domestic gas price hikes and VAT introduction. The king also directed the state to bear the burden of VAT in some situations, including special health and education services. The decree aims to alleviate the economic burden on certain segments of the population, with a total estimated cost of about 23 billion riyals.

site_title: Chinese Airline shares jump after state rules on fares eased
summary: Chinese airline shares surged after the government eased state control over domestic flight fares, allowing airlines to set prices without caps on full fares. China removed caps on fares for routes served by at least five carriers, with price increments limited to 10%. State-owned airlines China Southern, Air China, and China Eastern jumped 11%, 10%, and 10% respectively. The move is part of China's gradual liberalization of domestic flight fares, with more routes and pricing freedom introduced over the past few years.

images.alt_text: China Southern Airlines Co, the Guangzhou-based carrier that's Asia's largest by passenger numbers, jumped as much as 11 per cent in Hong Kong trading to its highest intraday level in more than two years.

site_title: LeEco founder defies order to return to China, sends family instead
summary: LeEco founder Jia Yueting defied Chinese regulators' order to return home to oversee his electric car startup, Faraday & Future Inc., citing the need to work on the US-based project. His brother and wife have been empowered to handle Leshi Internet Corp.'s affairs in China. Jia apologized for the debt crisis of LeEco and Leshi, blaming a single late payment and "false and malicious" reports. Chinese authorities have seized and frozen his assets, leading to a struggle to pay suppliers and lenders.

site_title: STI passes 3,500 level as traders pile in
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) surpassed the 3,500 level for the sixth consecutive rise, driven by investor optimism and a synchronized global recovery. Tech stocks in the US continued to soar, while Brent oil prices reached a record high, boosting oil and gas stocks. Midas Holdings, a small-cap aluminum profile maker, surged 43% after securing contract wins, despite concerns about its profitability. The STI closed at 3,501.16 points, up 1.1%, with local banks hitting new historical highs.

site_title: A growing Asian footprint
summary: Prudential CEO Mike Wells credits technology for the insurer's growth, citing its Asian footprint as a key area of expansion. The company employs 14,000 people in the region and has 600,000 financial consultants and 15 million policyholders. Asia accounts for nearly 36% of long-term business operating profits and 53% of new business profit. Wells sees challenges in the region, including new entrants and foreign competitors, but also opportunities to offer risk products that diminish risk while providing better returns. Prudential invests nearly $1 billion annually in technology, with initiatives such as fintech partnerships and the use of cognitive-powered chatbots.

site_title: Neo Garden Begins the year With Love
summary: Neo Group's company-wide initiative "Begin With Love" starts the year with charitable donations. Since its inception in 2012, the company has raised over $218,000 for 14 non-profit organizations, and its SEED fund has supported over 50 charities. Neo Group also organizes blood donation drives, with 1,038 units donated in 2017, and aims to clock 5,000 hours of volunteer work in 2018. The company encourages employees to donate a portion of their salary to the SEED fund, with founder Neo Kah Kiat matching their contributions dollar for dollar.

site_title: Germany's jobless rate drops to record low as economy booms
summary: Germany's unemployment rate has dropped to a record low of 5.5% in December, with 29,000 fewer people out of work than expected. The country's economy is experiencing a strong boom, supported by domestic spending and solid global trade, which could lead to higher wages and inflation. Business optimism has slipped, however, as corporate executives worry about production constraints and finding skilled workers, potentially lifting costs. Wage growth is moderate, but pay talks between employers and the industrial union IG Metall are struggling to reach an agreement.

images.alt_text: Germany's unemployment rate fell to a record low as the number of people out of work slid for a sixth month, reflecting a boom in Europe's largest economy that could push up wages and inflation.

site_title: Big geopolitical crisis in 2018 could happen: Eurasia Group
summary: Eurasia Group warns that 2018 could see a major geopolitical crisis, comparable to the 2008 financial meltdown, due to rising tensions between China and the US, as well as Iran-US tensions. China's consolidation of global power and influence is seen as a major risk, with Eurasia predicting a "world is a more dangerous place" without a global security underwriter. Other concerns include cyberattacks, North Korea, and the Middle East, with the US-Iran nuclear deal potentially surviving the year.

site_title: Productivity gains seen in economy's uptick, but momentum uncertain
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 3.1% in Q4 2017, higher than expected 2.6% growth, driven by an uptick in global trade. The country's productivity growth, however, remains uncertain, with economists suggesting that the recent increase may be concentrated in specific sectors. While the government has made efforts to improve productivity, economists warn that sustaining this growth will be crucial for long-term sustainability. The labor market also remains soft, with growth expected to moderate in 2018.

site_title: Trump to Kim: My nuke button 'much bigger'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned North Korean leader Kim Jong Un that his nuclear button is "much bigger and more powerful" than Kim's, in a tweet that dismissed the prospect of high-level talks between the two Koreas. Trump's statement came after South Korea suggested a date for talks aimed at easing tensions on the Korean Peninsula. The US questioned whether talks could be taken seriously, with Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley saying Washington would never accept a nuclear-armed Pyongyang. The exchange followed a series of personal insults between the two leaders.

site_title: Total revamp at KL airport to boost rankings
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) will undergo a total revamp to boost its international rankings, which have been steadily declining. The airport was ranked 34th in 2017, down from 24th in 2016. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) is set to submit a report on passenger congestion, recommending automation and other improvements. The revamp is expected to take two years and aims to improve efficiency and airport service quality, with KLIA currently ranked 12th in the Airport Service Quality (ASQ) survey.

site_title: NTUC Income's digital investment gathers steam
summary: NTUC Income's digital investment platform, Integrated Financial Advisory (IFAM), is gaining momentum with four more financial advisory firms expected to join the platform this year. The platform aims to streamline the sales process and ease compliance with regulations. IFAM has already seen 90% of Income's business done through electronic submissions, with the goal of reducing backend workloads by 20-30%. The insurer expects the platform to improve efficiency and productivity, and is on track to meet its growth targets, with a weighted premium growth rate of 28% in Q3.

site_title: Toronto, Vancouver home sales fall in 2017 as prices jump
summary: Canadian housing markets saw a decline in home sales in 2017, with Toronto and Vancouver experiencing the largest drops. In Toronto, detached home sales fell 23% and condo sales dropped 9.6%, while Vancouver's sales declined 9.9% and condo prices rose 25.9%. Despite the decline, average home prices jumped 12.7% to C$822,681 in Toronto and 15.9% to C$1,050,300 in Vancouver, with condo prices increasing 23.1% and 25.9% respectively. The decline in sales was partly due to government measures to cool the markets.

site_title: US: Stocks end at fresh records on strong data, higher oil prices
summary: US stocks ended at fresh records on Wednesday, driven by strong manufacturing data, higher oil prices, and continued tech strength. The Dow Jones rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 gained 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index surged 0.8%, all reaching new highs. Investors remain optimistic about the US economy, citing improving data and tax cut benefits. Petroleum-linked shares rose sharply, while technology shares also saw significant gains, with Amazon, Facebook, and Alphabet all increasing over 1%.

site_title: Iranian oil tanker collides with Chinese ship on way to Korea
summary: An Iranian oil tanker, the Sanchi, collided with a Chinese cargo ship off China's coast on January 6, 2018, and caught fire, leaving at least 32 crew members missing. The tanker, carrying 1 million barrels of natural gas condensate, was on its way to South Korea. The cause of the crash is unknown. Iran is the third-largest oil producer in OPEC, and the incident has raised concerns about the country's oil exports. Search and rescue operations were underway, but no further updates were available at the time of the article.

images.alt_text: An Iranian oil tanker sailing to South Korea collided with a cargo ship off China's coast and caught fire, leaving at least 32 people missing on Sunday.

site_title: Taiwan court orders dentist to pay mother NT$22m for raising him
summary: Taiwan's top court has ordered a 41-year-old dentist, Chu, to pay his mother around NT$22.3 million for raising and educating him after she spent 20 years caring for him. The court upheld a previous ruling that Chu should honour a contract he signed with his mother promising to refund her 60% of his net profit. The mother, Lo, had divorced her husband and raised their two sons on her own, but was ignored by her sons after they started relationships.

site_title: US car makers hit reverse gear in 2017
summary: US car manufacturers reported a 1.8% decline in 2017 domestic new-vehicle sales to 17.2 million cars and light lorries, marking the end of a seven-year growth streak. Experts predict an even larger drop in 2018, with Edmunds.com forecasting 16.8 million light vehicles sold. Rising fuel prices, tariffs, and increased competition from SUVs and lorries are cited as factors contributing to the decline. Despite this, worldwide sales remain on the rise, with global light vehicle sales increasing 1.5% to 93.5 million cars and lorries in 2017.

images.alt_text: Chrysler Pacifica minivans at a dealership, where incentives were being offered to reduce manufacturers' inventory, in Michigan. The decline in the American market in 2017 is expected to continue, and may force carmakers to trim production and find new ways to entice customers.

site_title: 2017 safest year on record for commercial passenger air travel: aviation groups
summary: Airlines recorded zero accident deaths in commercial passenger jets in 2017, making it the safest year on record for commercial air travel. According to To70 and the Aviation Safety Network, there were no commercial passenger jet fatalities in 2017, but 10 fatal airliner accidents resulted in 44 fatalities onboard and 35 on the ground. This marked a significant decline from 2016, when 16 accidents and 303 deaths occurred among airliners, and 412 fatalities in the US in aviation accidents.

site_title: Year of the Cryptocoin
summary: Cryptocurrency investors and experts weigh in on the future of the industry, with some predicting a surge in adoption and others expressing skepticism. The Year of the Crypto, 2018, is expected to bring more ICOs, fintech innovations, and increased mainstream acceptance. Experts debate the potential for Bitcoin to replace fiat money, with some arguing it's too volatile and lacks underlying fundamentals. Others see a future with a diverse range of cryptocurrencies serving different purposes. The industry faces challenges, including education and regulation, but proponents believe it has the potential to drive entrepreneurship and create a more equal and efficient society.

site_title: Malaysia gears up for election as Najib targets 'fake news'
summary: Malaysia gears up for an election within months, with Prime Minister Najib Razak launching a portal to combat "fake news" ahead of the August election. Najib aims to protect the ruling Barisan Nasional coalition's unbroken rule for over 60 years. The opposition Pakatan Harapan alliance is expected to name its pick for prime minister, with speculation centered around former premier Mahathir Mohamad. The election comes as Najib faces criticism over rising living costs and corruption allegations, but his government claims a stronger economy and ringgit will boost his chances.

site_title: The when and why of amontillado
summary: A wine expert explores the complexities of Amontillado, a type of sherry wine. The writer recommends three Amontillado bottles, including Hidalgo La Gitana, Valdespino, and Fernando de Castilla, and notes that they pair well with mushroom risotto. However, the writer also suggests that Amontillado is best enjoyed by the glass, as its high 17.5-19% alcohol content can overpower a meal. The wine's production process, involving the interaction of oxygen and wine in barrels, contributes to its unique character and aging potential.

images.alt_text: Certain wines, amontillado for one, are riddles nowadays: When to drink, what to serve; what's their role, their use?

site_title: Online retailer JD follows Alibaba into the supermarket game
summary: JD.com, a Chinese online retailer, has opened its first high-tech supermarket, 7Fresh, in Beijing, marking its entry into traditional retail. The store offers features like digital payments, mobile apps, and robot carts, aiming to connect online and offline shopping. JD's strategy is to leverage its supply chain control and scale to compete with Alibaba's Hema chain. The move is part of a broader trend by China's largest internet companies to infuse technology into retail, with Alibaba set to open 30 Hema supermarkets in Beijing this year.

images.alt_text: JD, Wal-Mart Stores' partner in China, is counting on control of its supply chain and long experience in sourcing its own inventory to compete with Alibaba.
